Meanwhile, the yen slumped 1.55% to 136.11 against the US dollar after the Bank of Japan maintained ultra-low interest rates and removed a pledge to keep rates low.

images.alt_text: The ECB is due to raise rates on May 4, with policymakers weighing another 50 basis point hike against the merits of slowing rises down to 25 basis points

site_title: US senator introduces bill targeting AI’s shortfalls
summary: US Senator Michael Bennet introduced a bill to create a task force on artificial intelligence, focusing on reducing threats to privacy, civil liberties, and due process. The bill comes amid growing concerns about AI's impact, including its use by foreign adversaries and cheating in education. Experts anticipate a need for "improvisation and iterative approaches" to address AI's rapid development and global implications. The task force will examine US policies on AI and provide recommendations for regulation and oversight.

site_title: Retail space rents fall by 0.3%, vacancy rate rises to 7.6%: URA
summary: Retail space rents in Singapore's central region fell 0.9% in Q1 2023, a decrease of 0.3% from the previous quarter. The islandwide vacancy rate rose to 7.6%, up from 7.1% in December. Despite this, average prime retail rents increased by 5% year-on-year. Analysts expect a recovery in the retail market with growing foreign visitor numbers and the return of Chinese tourists. The decline in retail rents marks a smaller dip than the 1.1% decrease in Q4 2022.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Prices for retail space in the central region fell by 0.9 per cent, following a 2.1 per cent decrease in the previous quarter, the Urban Redevelopment Authority said on Friday

site_title: EU’s proposed ESG rule puts executive bonuses in crosshairs
summary: The European Union is proposing a new bill, the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD), that would hold C-suite managers personally responsible if their companies fail to meet climate transition targets. The bill, which has faced intense opposition from the finance industry, would also force companies to identify and address human rights and environmental abuses in their value chains. Companies with over 1,000 employees would face bonus cuts and regulatory penalties if they breach the directive, with fines of at least 5% of their net global revenue.

images.alt_text: The extent to which ESG investment strategies deliver better returns than their conventional equivalents remains a topic of debate.

site_title: Wilmar posts 26.2% fall in Q1 net profit to US$391.4m
summary: Wilmar International reported a 26.2% drop in net profit to US$391.4 million in Q1, down from US$530.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 3.8% to US$16.9 billion. The company attributed the decline to an uncertain macroeconomic outlook, but noted higher sales volume in food products and feed business segments. Despite the drop, Wilmar remains cautiously optimistic about its performance for the rest of the year, citing its diversified business strategies.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Looking ahead, UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) expects production yields to improve now that the rains have subsided. A strong recovery, however, is unlikely due to prominent signs of tree stress which could lead to lower productivity.
CGS-CIMB analyst Ivy Ng expects a more challenging FY2023 for Wilmar after the group reported FY2022 results that exceeded the brokerage’s expectations by 6 per cent.

Including the interim dividend of S$0.06 per share paid out last August, the total dividend paid and proposed for FY2022 stands at S$0.17 - the highest cash dividend paid out by Wilmar since its listing.

site_title: Conflicting economic data muddies picture for ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces a challenging decision on May 4, as mixed economic data from the eurozone complicates its interest rate hike. Germany and France stagnated or grew slowly, while Spain and Italy expanded more than expected due to a rebound in trade. Inflation data is also unclear, with some states seeing slowing price growth. ECB policymakers weigh a 50 basis point hike against a slower rise to 25 basis points, as a surge in food prices shows signs of easing in France and Spain.

images.alt_text: In a monthly report released this week, Germany's central bank said gross domestic product probably expanded in the first quarter, changing an earlier forecast of a slight contraction.
The eurozone's second-largest economy saw GDP growth of 0.2 per cent in Q1, in line with expectations, after a flat fourth quarter, helped by steady household consumption.

site_title: French GDP edges up in Q1 despite strikes and high inflation
summary: France's GDP grew 0.2% in Q1, in line with expectations, despite strikes and high inflation. Household consumption contributed to the growth, while energy demand rebounded and trade figures improved. Inflation rose to nearly 6% in April, driven by higher energy prices, but eased to 0.6% month-over-month. French bond yields rose 3 basis points, and the budget deficit is expected to decrease to 2.7% by 2027. However, higher debt servicing costs are a concern, and the government must balance fiscal discipline with economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Federal Labour Office said the number of people out of work increased by 24,000 in seasonally adjusted terms to 2.567 million. Analysts polled by Reuters had expected that figure to rise by 10,000.

For the January-March period, annual GDP shrank by 3.02 per cent from a year earlier, following a contraction of 0.41 per cent in the previous quarter, preliminary data from the statistics agency showed on Friday (Apr 28).

site_title: Despite moratorium, Philippine banks still financing fossil fuel projects: report
summary: Philippine banks continue to finance fossil fuel projects despite a 2020 moratorium on new coal projects. A report by Withdraw from Coal: End Fossil Fuels found that banks funded $930 million for fossil gas projects and $867 million for coal projects from 2022 to 2023. The "dirtiest" bank, Bank of the Philippine Islands, was followed by BDO Unibank, which is now the top financier of fossil gas projects. Experts urge banks to divest from fossil fuels and prioritize renewable energy sources to meet the country's climate targets and limit global warming.

images.alt_text: Reduced fossil fuel use and increased demand for land during climate change mitigation adversely affect agricultural production and pushes up food prices.
The energy crisis has raised the prospect of more long term sustainable debt issuance to finance Europe's energy transition.

Wind turbines, including some from RWE's new Kaskasi offshore wind farm, are pictured during the opening of the RWE-Offshore-Windpark Kaskasi, north of Helgoland, Germany, March 23, 2023.    Christian Charisius/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: England and Wales company insolvencies remain near 13-year high in Q1
summary: The number of companies declared insolvent in England and Wales in Q1 2023 reached 5,747, a 18% increase from the previous year and close to a 13-year high. This is attributed to surging energy costs affecting smaller businesses, particularly in hospitality and retail. Many firms still carry debts from lockdown closures caused by the pandemic. Total insolvencies measured as a proportion of active companies are the highest since 2014, with creditors' voluntary liquidation reaching a record high over the past four quarters.

images.alt_text: Inflation has lingered in double digits for seven months, prompting investors to price in more interest-rate hikes in the months ahead.

site_title: UK government faces fresh calls to scrutinise regulators
summary: The UK government is facing renewed calls to scrutinize regulators as members of the House of Lords prepare amendments to the Financial Services and Markets Bill. The bill aims to boost oversight of regulators, with some industry groups and peers pushing for a statutory body to analyze regulators' performance and a joint Commons and Lords committee. The Treasury has been reluctant to revisit the issue, but officials may consider amendments to avoid opposition from the House of Lords. The push for greater oversight comes as the government aims to pass the bill by summer and promote the City of London as a post-Brexit growth hub.

images.alt_text: Some 5,747 companies in England and Wales were declared insolvent in Q1 2023 compared with 5,969 in the final quarter of 2022, which was the highest number since mid 2009.

site_title: German inflation slows unexpectedly after economy stagnated
summary: Germany's consumer prices slowed to 7.6% from a year ago in April, down from 7.8% in March, contrary to economists' expectations. This easing in inflation comes after the economy stagnated at the start of 2023, just avoiding a recession with flat first-quarter output. The statistics office attributed the slowdown to goods and services, providing mixed data for the European Central Bank to consider before its interest-rate decision next week.

images.alt_text: The Federal Labour Office said the number of people out of work increased by 24,000 in seasonally adjusted terms to 2.567 million. Analysts polled by Reuters had expected that figure to rise by 10,000.

site_title: OpenAI restores ChatGPT in Italy, addresses regulator demands
summary: OpenAI has restored access to its ChatGPT chatbot for Italian users after addressing concerns raised by the country's privacy regulator, the Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante). The regulator had launched a probe over data collection and age verification issues. OpenAI has posted explanations about its data collection and usage, and added new opt-out forms and age verification tools. The company also offered greater transparency into its privacy policies. Regulators in Italy have now allowed access to ChatGPT, following constructive discussions with OpenAI.

images.alt_text: The source said member states were not seeking to punish or make rules that will affect Microsoft Corp-backed ChatGPT owner OpenAI, but rather to create general policies that “are transparent.”
FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Twitter owner Musk is assembling a team of AI researchers and engineers, says the FT report.
Italy fines Amazon record 1.13b euros for abuse of market dominance

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's employment levels grew 34,500 in Q1 2023, led by non-resident employment growth, but labour market improvements have moderated. Retrenchments rose for the third straight quarter, while unemployment rates remained low. Private home prices increased 3.3% in Q1, taking the year-over-year increase to 11.4%. Manufacturers and services firms showed slight optimism about the next six months. The labour movement launched a "career trial model" for young employees, while Singapore manufacturers and services firms appeared slightly more upbeat about their outlook.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics posts 63% fall in Q3 profit to S$1.6 million
summary: Micro-Mechanics reported a 63% fall in Q3 profit to S$1.6 million, from S$4.4 million in the same period last year, due to a 24.2% decline in revenue. The decline in revenue reflects slower global semiconductor industry conditions. CEO Chris Borch stated the company will focus on long-term industry fundamentals, not short-term valuations. The global semiconductor market is expected to slow until excesses and supply-demand imbalances ease.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Venture helps companies design and produce high-tech products. Its margins have been consistently been around 10 per cent in the last five years.

Chris Borch, chief executive of Micro-Mechanics, noted that the group began to see slower market conditions for semiconductors amid softening demand and higher chip inventories at the start of its financial year.
Micro-Mechanics posted a 14.6 decline in net profit, marking the end of four consecutive quarters of growth.

site_title: China’s home sales by top developers rise for  third month
summary: China's top 100 real estate developers saw a 31.6% increase in new home sales in April, reaching 566.5 billion yuan, marking a third consecutive month of growth. This rise is attributed to government support measures, including financial aid and eased mortgage rates. Economists are optimistic about China's growth prospects, with some predicting a 6% growth rate for 2023, driven by a rebound in the housing market. The improvement in the property sector is expected to boost the country's economy, which has been recovering after the pandemic.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 14, 2021 shows the construction site of an Evergrande housing complexin Zhumadian, central China’s Henan province. - Pummelled by a housing crisis that caused a record-breaking slump in 2022, some Chinese property developers are starting to see light at the end of the tunnel, but analysts warn the sector is still on course to slow down in the long term. (Photo by JADE GAO / AFP)

site_title: Strong currency, high rates help slow Sri Lanka’s inflation
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation eased in April, reaching 35.3% from a year ago, driven by a stronger local currency and higher borrowing rates. The Central Bank of Sri Lanka's efforts to reach single-digit inflation by the end of the year appear to be bearing fruit. The country secured a $3 billion IMF bailout, which has supported the local currency and boosted imports of food and fuel. However, a debt restructuring plan has been pushed back to mid-May, citing concerns from foreign bondholders and local banks.

images.alt_text: A worker fills petrol in an auto rickshaw at a fuel station on March 21, 2023. - Sri Lanka must not allow entrenched corruption to undermine a bailout for its bankrupt economy, the IMF said on March 21, 2023 after signing off on a $3 billion loan for the crisis-hit nation. (Photo by ISHARA S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: China’s travel rush over holiday leads to soaring tourism, spending
summary: China's tourism and consumer spending surged during the first day of the Golden Week holiday, with 19.7 million railway trips made on April 29, the highest on record. This marks a 20% increase from 2019 and a significant rebound after three years of Covid restrictions. Retail and catering companies saw a 21% jump in sales, with key food chains experiencing a 37% revenue boost. However, concerns remain about the sustainability of the recovery due to weak household income growth and high youth unemployment.

images.alt_text: Travelers in the departure hall at Hangzhou East Railway Station ahead of the Golden Week holiday in Hangzhou, China, on Thursday, April 27, 2023. Shares connected to China’s tourism sector gained as investors position ahead what's expected to be a strong travel season during the five-day Golden Week holiday starting Saturday. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Alternative paths to tech jobs exist, but potential applicants may need to temper expectations
summary: Alternative paths to tech jobs exist, offering opportunities for fresh graduates and mid-career professionals to reskill and seek better-paying tech roles. However, smaller firms may not be able to pay top dollar for talent like bigger counterparts. Retraining can lead to better job prospects, but applicants should temper expectations regarding salary.

images.alt_text: student, typing, keyboard
Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Europe takes tougher stance toward China in boost to US policy
summary: Europe is strengthening its stance against China, mirroring US policy, amid China's close ties with Russia and repression at home. European nations like Germany, Italy, and the Netherlands are studying export and investment controls adopted by the US, aiming to reduce economic dependencies and risks. The shift reflects a growing frustration and sense of vulnerability toward China, with senior officials calling Chinese actions "more than shocking" and "systemic rival." G7 leaders will discuss China and economic security at their meeting in Japan next month, with a focus on coordinating a reaction against economic coercion without breaking completely.

images.alt_text: (Clockwise from L) British Foreign Secretary James Cleverly, German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, Japan's Foreign Minister Yoshimasa Hayashi, Canadian Foreign Minister Melanie Joly, French Foreign Minister Catherine Colonna, Italy's Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani, and Deputy Secretary-General of the European External Action Service (EEAS) Enrique Mora pose for photographs at the start of the fifth working session of a G7 Foreign Ministers' Meeting at the Prince Karuizawa hotel in Karuizawa on April 18, 2023. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Smartphone demand recovery unlikely this year, Sony COO says
summary: Sony's COO, Hiroki Totoki, expressed skepticism about smartphone demand recovery this year, citing built-up oversupply and strained handset makers. The global smartphone market is expected to remain depressed, with Sony attributing this to pockets of oversupply in China, softness in premium US handsets, and a slowdown in Europe. The company also noted a 51% increase in its global smartphone image sensor market share over the past fiscal year, highlighting the ongoing challenges in the industry.

images.alt_text: epa10595944 The Sony logo on a building in Tokyo, Japan, 28 April 2023. Sony Group Corp. announced its full year results for the fiscal year starting April 2022 and ending March 2023, showing its group sales increase by 16 percent from a year earlier to reach 11.5 trillion yen (76 billion euros).  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

site_title: China’s leaders stick to pro-growth stance, vow support
summary: China's economy expanded at its fastest pace in a year in the first quarter, driven by stronger consumer spending and government investment in infrastructure. The Communist Party's Politburo reiterated support for the private sector, committing to "more forceful" fiscal and monetary policies to boost demand. Despite a cautiously optimistic view, policymakers acknowledged demand remains weak and faces new challenges, including relatively high unemployment and a global slowdown. The Politburo also vowed to support internet companies, household consumption, and stricter control of local government debt.

site_title: After Reliance-Warner deal, JioCinema pricing, local content in focus
summary: Reliance's JioCinema is set to focus on pricing and local content following a deal with Warner Bros, which will make popular series such as Harry Potter and Succession available next month. A pricing strategy is still under discussion, but Ambani's reputation for disrupting rivals with cheap offers may influence the platform's approach. The deal aims to attract the premium English-speaking audience in India, where the video streaming market is expected to grow 22-25% annually to reach $13-15 billion by 2030. JioCinema's current offerings include old Hindi and local language movies, and it plans to introduce dozens of TV shows and movies in the coming months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People take pictures with their mobile phones in front of the logo of Jio at the ongoing India Mobile Congress 2022, at Pragati Maidan, in New Delhi, India, October 3, 2022. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo

site_title: China automating mines to improve safety as coal output grows
summary: China is automating its coal mines to improve safety, with state-owned Shaanxi Coal Group's Hongliulin mine using 5G technology to reduce underground workers by 18% and Xiaobaodang mine by 42%. The project aims to cut costs and attract workers, following a decade-long push by global miners like Rio Tinto and BHP Group. China's National Energy Administration is urging miners to adopt "smart mining" technology to boost safety and efficiency as coal output grows.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees monitor screens showing real-time footages of mining operations in a ground control centre, at Xiaobaodang Coal Mine, during a Huawei-organised media tour, in Shenmu of Yulin city, Shaanxi province, China April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Exxon delivers record Q1 profit on higher output
summary: ExxonMobil reported a record first-quarter profit of $11.43 billion, more than double from the same period last year, driven by strong production growth and higher oil and gas output. The company's oil and gas production rose by nearly 300,000 barrels per day, with significant contributions from the Permian Basin and Guyana. Despite a 16% drop in oil prices, Exxon's refining margins and fuel production expansion helped offset the decline. The company ended Q1 with $32.7 billion in cash, with no plans to tap it for mergers or acquisitions, but remaining open to deals offering synergies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Exxon Mobil Corp building is pictured in Georgetown, Guyana February 18, 2022. REUTERS/Sabrina Valle/File Photo

site_title: Three-quarters of Blossoms by the Park in Buona Vista snapped up despite cooling measures
summary: In Singapore, the development Blossoms by the Park in Buona Vista sold over 200 out of 275 units at an average price of $2,423 per square foot, with a 75% take-up rate. The majority of buyers, 96%, were Singaporeans or permanent residents, while foreigners made up only 4%. Despite new cooling measures, including a doubling of the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) for Singapore citizens and permanent residents buying their second and subsequent properties, the strong sales performance affirms a resilient market driven by local demand.

images.alt_text: Blossoms by the Park achieved a take-up rate of about 75 per cent, at an average price of $2,423 per square foot (psf).

site_title: German unemployment rises more than expected in April
summary: German unemployment rose more than expected in April, increasing by 24,000 to 2.567 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of a 10,000 rise. The seasonally adjusted jobless rate remained stable at 5.6%. This marks a sluggish economy's impact on the labor market, contradicting a strong spring revival.

site_title: China’s big banks post scant profit gains as margins shrink
summary: China's largest banks posted minimal profit gains in the first quarter of 2023, with margins shrinking due to prime rate reductions and increasing time deposits. Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) saw a 0.02% increase in net income, while China Construction Bank, Bank of China, and Agricultural Bank of China reported gains of 0.3%, 0.5%, and 1.75% respectively. The results come as the banking sector faces challenges, including a murky economic recovery and structural issues, with many smaller regional banks struggling with high debt and exposure to ailing local government financing vehicles.

images.alt_text: The Industrial & Commercial Bank Of China Ltd. (ICBC) logo is displayed atop a branch in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, April, 24, 2015. ICBC is winning its duel with Wells Fargo & Co. for the title of world's most valuable bank as China's government rolls out stimulus and a buying frenzy drives up the nation's stocks. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

site_title: MUFG says Credit Suisse AT1 debt sold to help clients diversify
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group (MUFG) sold Credit Suisse's riskiest bonds, AT1 notes, to help clients diversify their portfolios. The bonds, worth about $1.4 billion, were sold to 1,300 individuals and 250 corporate accounts, with US$700 million in losses suffered by MUFG clients. The firm continues to examine its sales practices and plans to follow up with clients to confirm their understanding of the risks involved. Despite the losses, MUFG's brokerage venture saw its net income more than double to 13 billion yen in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japan's national flag is seen behind the logo of  Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc (MUFG) at its bank branch in Tokyo, Japan September 5, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Credit Suisse South-east Asia FIG head said to join Deutsche Bank
summary: Credit Suisse South-east Asia Financial Institutions Group (FIG) head Nick Thursby is joining Deutsche Bank as part of the German lender's efforts to poach staff following the US$3.2 billion purchase of its Swiss rival. Thursby, who worked at Credit Suisse for over eight years, will lead Deutsche Bank's investment banking for FIG deals in the South-east Asia region, focusing on mergers and acquisitions and initial public offerings. This move comes as several of Credit Suisse's banking peers, including Deutsche Bank, have snapped up its staff following the collapse in confidence.

site_title: Amazon jolts investors with talk of cloud growth slowdown
summary: Amazon reported a slowdown in its cloud computing business, with AWS revenue rising 16% to $21.4 billion in Q1 2023, the slowest growth rate since Amazon began breaking out the unit's sales. Despite this, the company's overall revenue increased 9.4% to $127.4 billion, driven by growth in advertising and seller services. Amazon shares initially fell after the disclosure, but later rebounded. The company has been working to cut costs and streamline its businesses, with plans to eliminate 27,000 jobs. Despite the cloud slowdown, Amazon projects sales and operating profit for the current period.

images.alt_text: The logo of Amazon Web Services AWS is seen on the opening day of the Integrated Systems Europe (ISE) audiovisual and systems integration exhibition in Barcelona on January 31, 2023. (Photo by Pau BARRENA / AFP)

site_title: Top interview questions jobseekers should ask now
summary: Many young jobseekers are forgetting that an interview is a two-way street, and asking questions is crucial to determine if a role is a good fit. With the job market becoming tougher, job postings are down 15% compared to last year, and nearly three out of four recent graduates are worried about the economy. To make informed decisions, jobseekers should ask questions about the company culture, role responsibilities, and growth opportunities. This can help them avoid potential nightmares and find dream jobs.

images.alt_text: office, notes, notepad
Do you know who that worker you just hired really is?
Preparing youths for the workforce

site_title: Funders for Hyflux’s lawsuit against Olivia Lum to give undertaking for legal costs of up to S$90,000
summary: Hyflux has sued Olivia Lum, its former CEO, for at least S$690.6 million in a lawsuit alleging negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. Funders Omni Bridgeway Limited and Omni Bridgeway (Singapore) have agreed to provide an undertaking for up to S$90,000 of Lum's legal costs, which has been accepted by the High Court. The funders have sufficient assets to cover the costs, and the judicial commissioner believes there is little risk of them not honouring the undertaking.

images.alt_text: Ex-Hyflux CEO Olivia Lum leaving from the State Courts, 17 Nov 2022. The charges are related to violations of Singapore's Securities and Futures Act.
Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Baosteel expects China’s 2023 steel output flat to lower vs last year
summary: Baosteel, China's largest listed steelmaker, expects the country's 2023 crude steel output to be flat or slightly lower than last year. The company aims to produce 48.77 million tonnes of iron and 50.89 million tonnes of steel this year. China's steel market is awaiting official confirmation on a mandate to cap steel output, a measure to help meet emissions goals. The country's steel production fell 1.7% in 2022. The consolidation in the Chinese steel industry is expected to accelerate, with large firms holding a 65% share of the domestic market within five years.

images.alt_text: Apparent steel consumption reached 243.42 million tonnes during the first three months, officials from the China Iron and Steel Association (Cisa) said in a quarterly briefing.

site_title: Ermotti taps UBS veterans for Credit Suisse transition team
summary: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti has tapped Tom Naratil, a former UBS executive, to lead the integration division overseeing the Credit Suisse merger. Naratil will become the group's chief financial officer and oversee the merger. This move comes as UBS reappoints Ermotti as CEO to oversee the historic acquisition. The selection of Naratil, who held senior positions at UBS, suggests a focus on integrating Credit Suisse operations.

images.alt_text: Sergio Ermotti, chief executive officer of UBS Group AG, speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. UBS attracted $28 billion from wealthy clients in the months running up to its takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG, in an early indication of how many assets the combined firms will be able to retain. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Leveraged finance deals making a comeback as markets calm
summary: Leveraged finance deals are making a comeback as investors seize on calmer markets following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse Group. In April, European loan and high-yield bond issuance reached its busiest two-week period since February 2023, with over $22 billion in US loans issued in April compared to $8 billion in March. Secondary prices have also recovered some losses, creating pent-up demand from investors. This resurgence is attributed to less volatile conditions in bond and loan markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker cleans ATM machines at the Swiss bank Credit Suisse in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Toyota’s Daihatsu admits to fudging crash test results on 88,000 cars
summary: Daihatsu, a subsidiary of Toyota Motor, admitted to manipulating crash test results on 88,000 cars produced in Thailand and Malaysia, affecting Toyota-branded Yaris Ativ and Agya models, as well as Perodua cars. The issue was discovered due to differences in components used during crash tests and those sold to the public. Daihatsu apologized to customers and stakeholders, stating that sales will resume once the vehicles are certified properly. A third-party investigation will be conducted, following a similar incident by another Toyota unit in 2022.

images.alt_text: Global sales for the 12 months ended March rose to 9.61 million vehicles from 9.51 million in the prior year, setting another annual record for the company.

site_title: Huawei’s profit halved as it researches blacklist workarounds
summary: Huawei's net income plummeted to 3 billion yuan in Q1 2023, marking its first annual profit decline in over a decade, as the company spent heavily on research to evade US technology sanctions. Revenue barely grew, and sales edged up 0.8% to 132.1 billion yuan. Huawei aims to stay competitive by investing in research and development, despite being vulnerable to US-Chinese tensions, which have imposed strict controls on chip exports to China. The company expects to tap emerging demand from new markets.

images.alt_text: The Chinese smartphone market registered double-digit contractions for most of the past year.

site_title: BOJ’s Ueda scraps rates guidance, commits to stimulus for now
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) removed guidance on future interest rate levels and reaffirmed its commitment to stimulus measures, marking a departure from its price-fighting stance. Governor Kazuo Ueda prepared the ground for a more neutral policy stance by calling for a long-term review of monetary policies. The BOJ maintained its rock-bottom interest rate and asset purchase settings, and projected core inflation to rise 1.6% in fiscal 2025. The decision suggests the BOJ will stick to its easing framework for now, but may adjust its policies based on economic developments.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Tokyo is a leading indicator of the nationwide trend.

site_title: Key takeaways from a better-than-feared start to earnings season
summary: US stocks rallied ahead of earnings season, with nearly 81% of S&P 500 companies beating analysts' estimates, but share prices haven't rebounded due to concerns about a recession and higher interest rates. Despite upbeat results from Big Tech and consumer spending, valuations have stretched, and the market remains cautious. Analysts warn that a better season may not lead to a sustained rally, citing investor exhaustion and a narrowing breadth of beats. Companies are instead focusing on cost cuts and pricing power, with some reporting strong earnings growth despite slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - APRIL 26: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on April 26, 2023 in New York City. The stock market opened up slightly high as investors respond to earnings reports from tech companies' after losses on Tuesday following rough economic data and earnings earlier in the day.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Chinese banks seize on Russia, oil trade to internationalise yuan
summary: Chinese banks are promoting the international use of the yuan, driven by China's booming trade with Russia and the Middle East. Cross-border yuan business has surged, with Harbin Bank seeing a nine-fold increase, and China Construction Bank and Agricultural Bank of China reporting significant growth in their Moscow subsidiaries. China aims to expand trade with Russia and promote yuan internationalization, despite the yuan's share of global payments remaining at 2.5%.

images.alt_text: Chinese Yuan and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Rating agencies put China's Wanda Commercial on negative watch
summary: Rating agencies Fitch and S&P have put China's Wanda Commercial Management Group on negative watch due to concerns over its Hong Kong listing, which may damage its financial profile. The listing, which requires approval from China's securities regulator, has become inactive for the third time in two years. A failure to complete the listing by the end of 2023 may trigger a pre-IPO option for investors to request Wanda Commercial to repurchase shares worth 40 billion yuan (S$7.7 billion).

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of Dalian Wanda Group in China glows during an event in Beijing, China, March 21, 2016. REUTERS/Damir Sagolj/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan slips into recession as Q1 GDP hits 14-year low
summary: Taiwan's economy slipped into recession in the first quarter, with its GDP shrinking 3.02% from the previous year, the worst performance since 2009. Exports, which account for a significant portion of the economy, fell 19.17% year-on-year in March, and private consumption was strong but external demand was weak. Despite this, the government predicts a 2% growth target for 2023, with revised full-year growth forecasts expected in late May.

site_title: Germany expected to dodge recession with weak Q1 growth
summary: Germany's central bank reported that the country's gross domestic product probably expanded in the first quarter, contrary to earlier forecasts of a slight contraction. Falling energy prices and China's reopening boosted manufacturers, offsetting the impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Analysts expect a 0.2% growth rate, avoiding a "technical recession." The improving economic picture suggests Germany has weathered the energy crisis better than feared, with inflation falling to 7.4% in March.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on October 26, 2022 the container ship 'COSCO Pride' of China COSCO Shipping Corporation is unloaded at the Tollerort Container Terminal owned by HHLA, in the harbour of Hamburg, northern Germany. - Germany is reassessing whether to allow a Chinese firm to buy a stake in a Hamburg port, the economy ministry said on April 12, 2023, after the terminal was classed as critical infrastructure. (Photo by Axel Heimken / AFP)

site_title: China’s Sinopec to develop coal-to-chemicals mine for 30.15 billion yuan
summary: China's Sinopec Group has won mining rights to develop a coal mine in Inner Mongolia for 30.15 billion yuan. The mine, to be developed by Sinopec Greatwall Energy and Chemical, will produce 10 million tonnes of coal annually, supplying coal for a coal-to-olefins project. This is the first coal chemicals mine in the region, supporting the upgrading of the traditional coal industry and extending its value chain.

site_title: BBC chairman Sharp resigns after breaching rules over Boris Johnson loan
summary: BBC chairman Richard Sharp resigned on Friday after an independent report found he had breached public appointment rules by not disclosing potential conflict of interest in securing a US$1 million loan for former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Sharp agreed to stay on until the end of June to allow the government to find a successor, citing a desire to prioritize the BBC's interests. The opposition Labour Party criticized the breach, saying it had caused "untold damage" to the broadcaster's reputation.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file video grab taken from footage broadcast by the UK Parliament's Parliamentary Recording Unit (PRU) on February 7, 2023 shows BBC chairperson Richard Sharp testifying in front of a Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) Committee in London - Sharp announced his resignation on April 28, 2023 over involvement in securing a private credit line for up to £800,000 ($990,000) for the then-PM Boris Johnson from a Canadian businessman. (Photo by Handout / PRU / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO /  PRU" - NO MARKETING - NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS

site_title: Indonesia to allow Freeport, Amman Mineral to ship copper concentrate until 2024
summary: Indonesia will allow Freeport Indonesia and Amman Mineral to continue exporting copper concentrate until May 2024, despite a planned June ban on raw mineral exports. The move aims to allow for the completion of copper smelters, which are currently at 60% completion. The government seeks to boost the value of its exports and attract investment into its metals processing industry. A regulation detailing requirements for the export leniency for copper will be issued.

site_title: MPACT’s Greater China lag takes shine away from strong Singapore showing
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) reported a strong showing in Singapore, with VivoCity mall experiencing positive rental reversions of 7.7% and 30.6% in tenant sales. However, its assets in Greater China, including Hong Kong and China, lagged behind due to a slower recovery, with rental reversion rates of minus 12.7% and minus 3.7% respectively. The trust's gross revenue grew 65.4% to S$826.2 million, while net property income rose 62.6% to S$631.9 million. MPACT's distribution per unit (DPU) increased by 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Tenant sales for the full year in VivoCity set a “new record at over S$1 billion, well surpassing pre-Covid levels”, the trust’s manager said.
MPACT's manager said the growth in gross revenue and NPI was in part driven by higher earnings from the trust’s Singapore portfolio, which includes shopping mall VivoCity (above).
Mapletree Business City on April 21, 2022.

site_title: Thai economy slows in March, but seen improving in future: central bank
summary: Thailand's economy slowed in March, with declining exports, but is expected to improve in April and beyond, according to the Bank of Thailand. Economic activity improved in the first quarter, driven by the tourism sector and private consumption, despite a decline in exports. A recovery in trading partners' economies is also forecast to boost exports, leading to a gradual improvement in economic activity.

images.alt_text: “Despite the export fall, it’s still considered very good,” Poonpong Naiyanapakorn, head of the ministry’s Trade Policy and Strategy Office, told a news conference.
Exports, a key driver of Thai growth, are expected to drop 0.5 per cent this year.

site_title: Indonesia's Q1 FDI sees annual growth of 20.2%, focuses on downstream investment
summary: Indonesia's foreign direct investment (FDI) grew 20.2% annually in Q1 2023, reaching 177 trillion rupiah (S$16 billion), with the base metal industry being the biggest recipient. The industry's FDI was boosted by efforts to attract investment in processed minerals. The government aims to draw 1,400 trillion rupiah of investment this year and is focusing on downstream investment. Key investors in Q1 included Singapore, Hong Kong, and China, with the ministry setting a target to be among the world's top five countries in terms of gross domestic product.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of a nickel mining site of Vale in Sorowako, South Sulawesi province, Indonesia, March 29, 2023. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana

site_title: The race to keep data centres cool is heating up
summary: Data centre workloads continue to rise, prompting scientists and operators to push cooling technology limits. A single Nvidia H100 GPU, used in blockchain, animation, and machine learning, generates 700 watts of heat. To put this in perspective, a microwave oven produces 600-1,200 watts. This heat must be managed to maintain optimal temperatures, as data centre infrastructure demands increase. Innovations in cooling technology are necessary to keep temperatures under control and ensure efficient data centre operation.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Nongsa Digital Park in Batam, Indonesia is one of a number of hotspots in South-east Asia that are seeing strong interest from data centre operators.
Keppel Data Centres and Woodside Energy are looking into utilisig liquid hydrogen for cooling of data centres.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rate slips to 7-month low in March; overall revenue rises
summary: Singapore hotels experienced a 7-month low in average room rates in March, with luxury, upscale, mid-tier, and economy segments all recording lower rates. Despite this, overall room revenue rose to its highest level since November 2022, driven by a record 1 million tourist arrivals in March, the first time since the pandemic began in 2020.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Singapore's tourism arrivals rose to 1,021,036 in March, up from the 957,839 visitors recorded in the previous month.
GlobalTix co-founders Chan Chee Kong (left), who is chief operating officer, and Chan Chee Chong, who is chief executive officer, aim to work with more payment gateways so more e-wallets can be used.

site_title: Free to move about, China May Day tourists to stoke petrol, jet fuel use
summary: China's tourists are expected to boost petrol and jet fuel consumption during the May Day holiday, with jet fuel consumption forecasted to reach 790,000 barrels per day and petrol demand potentially rising to 3.94 million barrels per day. This surge in fuel demand could ease downward pressure on refinery profit margins in Asia and support global crude prices. Domestic travel bookings are up 233% from 2019, while international departures are at 79% of the 2019 level, driven by lifted PCR test requirements for international travel.

images.alt_text: Passengers walk through the arrivals hall for international flights at the Capital International Airport in Beijing on March 14, 2023. - China will once again start issuing a range of visas to foreigners on March 15, in a major easing of travel restrictions in place since the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)

site_title: Singapore manufacturers, services firms slightly more upbeat about outlook for next 6 months
summary: Singapore manufacturers and services firms are slightly more optimistic about business conditions in the next six months, with a net weighted balance of 2% of manufacturing firms anticipating a favourable business situation from April to September. This marks the first improvement in three quarters of pessimism, following a previous quarter where 25% of manufacturers expected a less favourable situation.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore manufacturers’ sentiment worsens; services sector mood moderates: surveys

site_title: Hong Kong seeks to help crypto firms escape their exile from the banking sector
summary: Hong Kong's Monetary Authority urged banks to provide services to licensed virtual-asset firms, aiming to become a crypto hub. The move contrasts with the US crackdown on the digital-asset sector. Banks should support regulated businesses with bank accounts and train staff to avoid "wholesale de-risking." Hong Kong plans to let retail investors trade major tokens starting June 1. The city's biggest virtual bank, ZA Bank, plans to offer token-to-fiat currency conversions. This push aims to attract crypto firms and create a stable environment for the industry.

images.alt_text: It remains profitable for the traders to borrow the Hong Kong dollar cheaply and buy the higher-yielding greenback, pocketing the rate difference.

site_title: China stocks close up ahead of record May Day holiday rush
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 Index closed up 1% and the Shanghai Composite Index finished 1.1% higher ahead of the record-high May Day holiday. Investor sentiment was boosted by the Politburo meeting's call for proactive fiscal policy and a stabilization of US-China relations. Financials and IT firms led the gains, with Ping An Insurance Group rising 1.6% and IT firms climbing 2.4%. Authorities expect 19 million rail trips on the first day of the holiday, a record high.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An investor looks at his mobile phone in front of a board showing stock information at a brokerage office in Beijing, China January 2, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Singtel restructuring ‘first step’ to monetise higher-valued infrastructure assets: analysts
summary: Singtel is restructuring its organisational structure to better monetize its higher-valued infrastructure assets, including a Digital InfraCo unit that will oversee regional data centres, subsea cables, and 5G platforms. Analysts expect cost savings from merging consumer and enterprise businesses and the formation of the new unit, which could lead to a strategic partner or initial public offering. The move aims to increase the value of Singtel's infrastructure assets, which typically trade at higher valuation multiples than traditional telco services.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

The telco also announced plans to form a standalone infrastructure unit, dubbed Digital InfraCo, which will include the group’s regional data centre business, subsea cable, satellite carrier businesses and Paragon platform.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz sees order book supporting sales in slowing economy
summary: Mercedes-Benz expects its order backlog to support sales in a slowing global economy, with automaking margins at the upper end of its forecast range. The luxury-car maker forecasts a 12-14% return on sales this year, down from 14.6% in 2022. Mercedes aims to sell around 2 million vehicles, the same level as last year, and is shifting its model lineup to better weather downturns by focusing on higher-end cars. Despite Tesla's recent price cuts, Mercedes plans to protect its pricing strategy.

images.alt_text: BYD has unveiled its Seagull electric hatchback at the recent Shanghai car show, stunning visitors with a price from just 78,000 yuan – around half the level of the cheapest new energy vehicles available elsewhere.

Zeekr’s shift to the gigapress technique comes at the same time Chinese rival Xpeng has adopted a new vehicle platform technology that also mimics the way Tesla designs and manufactures electric cars.
The EV maker's stock price on Wednesday (Apr 26) fell as much as 3.5 per cent to US$155.03 in New York and is on pace to close at the lowest level since Jan 25.

site_title: South-east Asia's strong IPO markets an outlier as global deals fizzle
summary: South-east Asia's IPO market has grown 4.5% to $2.23 billion this year, with Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia leading the way. This marks a significant outlier in the Asia-Pacific region, excluding Japan, where other markets have seen declines. South-east Asia accounted for nearly 7% of global IPO funds raised so far this year, up from 4% in the same period of 2022. The region's elevated economic growth and stable interest rate outlook have made it an attractive destination for major new share sales.

images.alt_text: Chinese regulators are reviewing the IPO and scrutinising areas including Syngenta’s debt levels and the potential use of proceeds before deciding whether it is a good time for the company to list.
VinFast's parent Vingroup, Vietnam’s biggest conglomerate, will provide a grant of US$500 million plus a US$1 billion loan with maturity of up to five years.
Time is running out for Singapore SPACs to do a business combination with about nine months left to the deadline
Bonds from sovereign and quasi sovereign names, such as Indofood and Pertamina, have seen greater investor interest.

site_title: 'Death zone' queues feared on Everest as Nepal grants record climbing permits
summary: A record 463 permits have been granted to climb Mount Everest in Nepal, sparking fears of overcrowding and potential traffic jams on the mountain, particularly in the "death zone" above 8,000m. The high number of climbers, including 96 Chinese nationals and 87 US climbers, has raised concerns about the safety of climbers, with experts warning of the risks of oxygen shortages and exhaustion. The Nepalese government has implemented measures to manage climbing activities, including a team of doctors and officials at the base camp, and is considering introducing a requirement for climbers to scale a 6,000m peak before attempting Everest.

images.alt_text: A group of tourists visits a business street in Beijing on April 18, 2023. (Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia central bank to hold rates at 2.75% for rest of 2023: poll
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, is expected to keep its key interest rate at 2.75% for the rest of 2023 and 2024, as inflation has cooled faster than expected. The decision comes after a slowdown in inflation, with rates expected to remain unchanged until at least the end of 2024. Economists predict Malaysia's economic growth rate will halve to 4.0% in 2023 and recover marginally to 4.6% next year.

images.alt_text: Economists said extending the retirement age may be an inevitable option for low income groups in Malaysia to rebuild their retirement savings.
Malaysia’s inflation in March has grown at a slower pace, underpinned by a decrease in the price of unleaded petrol.

site_title: Sony posts record annual profit driven by chip, music units
summary: Sony has posted a record annual profit of 1.21 trillion yen ($12 billion) driven by strong performance at its music and microchip units. The company sold 19.1 million PlayStation 5 consoles in the past year, up from 11.5 million a year earlier. However, Sony predicts a 3.2% decline in operating profit to 1.17 trillion yen for the current year, lower than analysts' average estimate of 1.275 trillion yen.

site_title: GIC buys six Japan logistics assets from Blackstone for more than US$800m
summary: Singapore state investor GIC has acquired six logistics facilities in Japan from global asset manager Blackstone for over US$800 million. The deal expands GIC's exposure to logistics assets and provides stable income streams with growth potential. The six modern warehouses, spanning 4 million square feet, have an average age of five years and are located in regional logistics hubs with high occupancy rates. This is GIC's first acquisition of logistics facilities developed and managed by Daiwa House Industry, and marks a significant expansion of its Japanese real estate portfolio.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Japan’s property market has become a global target for large investors as the government prepares to scrap most of its remaining pandemic travel restrictions on Oct 11.
GIC is one of the top shareholders of Pagaya, which went public in June 2022.
Sovereign wealth fund GIC will acquire about half of Works Human’s shares, Nikkei said, with the rest held by Works Human executives and a new fund to be established by Bain Capital.
Stripe emphasised that it “does not need this capital to run its business”.

In the past five years, China (above, Wuhan, in Hubei province) has swung from being a huge source of profit for many firms to becoming nearly uninvestible, amid heavy government interventions and pandemic restrictions. Now it is seeking to jump-start its economy, engage with the world and welcome investors.
GIC retains position as most active state-owned investor for second year running: report

site_title: EU proposes new copyright rules for generative AI
summary: The European Commission has proposed new copyright rules for generative AI, requiring companies to disclose any copyrighted material used to develop their systems. The AI Act, which will classify AI tools according to risk level, aims to regulate the technology and balance innovation with citizens' rights. Companies deploying generative AI tools will need to be transparent in their operations and classify their tools accordingly, with high-risk tools subject to stricter regulations. The proposal follows a late addition to the bill, which dropped a proposal to ban copyrighted material entirely.

images.alt_text: Democratic Senator Mark Warner raised concerns about potential risks posed by AI technology.
French startup Emobot has created a bot that uses AI to track the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns.

site_title: Saudi Arabia may cut June Arab Light crude prices to Asia
summary: Saudi Aramco may cut the official selling price (OSP) for its Arab Light crude by about 40 cents a barrel in June, following three months of price hikes. This move comes as refiners face sliding fuel prices and consider reducing output. The price cut is also seen as a response to China and India snapping up cheap Russian crude. The decision is based on customer recommendations and calculations of the oil's value change over the past month.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 15, 2019 shows an Aramco oil facility near al-Khurj area, just outside the Saudi capital Riyadh. - Saudi Arabia's push for oil production cuts has placed new strain on its stormy relationship with the United States, though analysts say any predictions of an all-out break are premature. The move by OPEC+ -- composed of the Riyadh-led OPEC cartel and an additional group of 10 exporters headed by Russia -- would reduce global output by two million barrels per day from November. (Photo by FAYEZ NURELDINE / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: CapitaLand Investment is UOBKH’s top pick as property stocks take a hit
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has chosen CapitaLand Investment (CLI) as its top pick for the property sector despite recent hikes to Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates. The brokerage maintains its "buy" call with a target price of S$4.28, citing CLI's inexpensive price-to-book valuation and expected sustained China recovery. UOBKH also keeps "buy" recommendations for City Developments Limited and PropNex, with target prices of S$8 and S$2.14, respectively.

images.alt_text: Singapore's government estimates the new round of cooling measures to impact about 10 per cent of all residential property transactions.
CapitaLand also hired Hideto Yamada from Japan’s Government Pension Investment Fund, as a managing director in the country.
An artist's impression of Newport Residences which will be built on the site of the former Fuji Xerox Towers on Anson Road.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise after big gains on Wall Street
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, tracking gains on Wall Street fueled by strong tech earnings and mixed macroeconomic data. Hong Kong and Tokyo posted solid gains, while Shanghai, Seoul, and Sydney also rose. Jakarta was the sole loser, with Singapore remaining flat. US regional banks also showed resilience, with First Republic Bank rising 8.8% after two straight declines. The market is now focusing on the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting next week, with investors expecting a possible interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 84 to 33 after 89.3 million securities worth S$53.7 million changed hands.

site_title: London rents top £2,500 for first time as supply of homes drops
summary: London rents have reached a record high of £2,500 (S$4,169) per month, driven by a shortage of rental properties and high demand. The number of tenants seeking a place has risen, adding strain to the system. Despite a slowdown in quarterly growth, rents are still up 14% year-on-year, with competition easing as supply slowly improves. The UK's housing crisis continues, with 10 prospective tenants for every available property across the country.

images.alt_text: The 60 per cent Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty that foreigners now pay for a home in Singapore means the city’s levies exceed those of other international hubs including Hong Kong, London and New York by a large margin.

site_title: ComfortDelGro appoints Mark Greaves as new chairman after Lim Jit Poh
summary: ComfortDelGro has appointed Mark Greaves as its new chairman, replacing outgoing chairman Lim Jit Poh who stepped down after 20 years in the role. Greaves, who joined the company in 2020, will also chair the nominating and remuneration committee and be a member of the sustainability committee. Lim was conferred the title of chairman emeritus, recognizing his decades of service to the group. Managing director Cheng Siak Kian praised Lim as a "consummate professional" who laid the strategic foundation for ComfortDelGro.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
ComfortDelGro says the transaction will not have a material impact on the company’s net tangible assets nor earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023.
The Swedish capital is expanding its three-line metro network, with extensions as well as a fourth line being built, and these will come into service from 2025.

site_title: Japan to give up to US$1.8 billion in subsidies for storage battery, chip projects
summary: Japan plans to provide up to $1.8 billion in subsidies for storage battery and chip-related projects, aiming to boost supply chain security. The government will give up to $1.83 billion in subsidies for eight storage battery proposals and up to $56.4 million for two semiconductor projects. This includes a $158.7 million subsidy for Honda Motor and GS Yuasa's plan to boost storage battery production. The move is part of Tokyo's efforts to secure its supply chain and reduce dependence on foreign companies.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Tokyo is a leading indicator of the nationwide trend.

site_title: Vietnam central bank says will restructure loans for struggling businesses
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam, announced plans to restructure loans for struggling businesses, including delaying repayments by up to 12 months, to support the slowing economy. The restructuring measures will be implemented through June 2024. The move comes as the country faces weakening global demand, with exports falling 11.9% in the first quarter. Vietnam's economic growth slowed to 3.32% in the January-March period, and the government has asked the central bank to target more firms for loan restructuring.

site_title: South Korea March factory output jumps by most in nearly three years
summary: South Korea's factory output surged 5.1% in March, the largest monthly gain in nearly three years, beating economists' expectations. This followed a 2.7% decline in February. Semiconductor and automobile production drove the growth, with jumps of 35.1% and 6.5%, respectively. The data is a positive sign for the South Korean economy, which narrowly avoided a recession in the first quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, MPACT, Mapletree Industrial Trust, CDLHT, FEHT, FHT, Japfa
summary: Several Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (REITs) reported positive earnings for the first quarter of 2023, with CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) seeing a 11.3% rise in net property income (NPI) to S$276.3 million. Other REITs, including Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT), CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT), and Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT), also reported increases in NPI. In contrast, Japfa, an agri-food company, posted a US$43 million loss for Q1 2023 due to high raw-material costs and inflationary pressures.

site_title: If there are no new ideas, how do we keep innovating?
summary: Author Sheena Iyengar argues that innovation is about assembling old ideas in a new way, calling successful innovators "strategic copiers." In her book "Think Bigger: How to Innovate," Iyengar writes that all thinking is an act of memory and that combining existing ideas creates something new. Iyengar cites examples of famous innovators, such as Isaac Newton and Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, who built on the work of others to create something new. She also emphasizes the importance of discernment and choosing the right combination of ideas, rather than relying on magic or intuition.

site_title: Prudential posts 35% rise in Q1 APE sales; new business profit up 30%
summary: Prudential reported a 35% increase in Q1 annual premium equivalent (APE) sales to $1.6 billion, driven by higher demand for its Hong Kong businesses following the removal of COVID-19 restrictions. New business profit rose 30% to $743 million, with Hong Kong APE sales growing 106% and Indonesia seeing gains in APE sales and production. site_title: The green transfer problem
summary: The green transition is crucial for limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, requiring $1.3 trillion by 2025 and $3.5 trillion by 2030. However, foreign aid can have unintended consequences, such as increasing income inequality and real exchange rate appreciation, as seen in the case of Urbana, where a $1 billion annual aid package from abroad bid up the prices of cement and engineering services, leading to no new infrastructure development. In contrast, Heliopolis successfully transitioned to green energy with the aid, highlighting the need for careful consideration of the transfer problem to ensure the desired effects of green finance.

site_title: Women take on Japan’s political gender gap for ‘true democracy’
summary: A small group of young women in Japan are being offered mentoring and financial support to break into the male-dominated political scene. The Murakami Family Foundation has organized seminars by leading politicians for 20 women under 40, with participants receiving a grant of one million yen. Despite only two women in the current cabinet, Japan has never had a female prime minister, and lawmakers face sexism and harassment. The foundation's chair, Rei Murakami, aims to address the "homogenous" power base and promote diversity in politics, with participants expressing determination to challenge the status quo and create change.

site_title: Landed homes post bigger price and rental gains in Q1 vis-a-vis condos and private apartments: URA data
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) Q1 data shows a 3.3% quarter-over-quarter increase in the overall private home price index, with landed homes experiencing bigger price and rental gains compared to non-landed properties. Market watchers attribute this trend to the scarcity of landed properties and strong demand from ultra-high net worth individuals seeking to establish family offices in Singapore, resulting in premium prices for these residences.

site_title: Top air-conditioner maker Daikin targets European heating market
summary: Daikin, the top air-conditioner maker in Europe, is targeting the European heating market with plans to quadruple its production capacity by 2025. The company, which has been the top provider of heat-pump systems in Europe since 2019, is betting on new regulations and soaring energy prices to spur sales. Other Japanese manufacturers, such as Panasonic and Mitsubishi Electric, are also increasing production in anticipation of growing demand for heat-pump systems, which can help reduce carbon emissions if sourced sustainably.

site_title: Gold heads for small weekly rise on muted dollar
summary: Gold prices were little changed on Friday, but headed for a small weekly gain due to a weaker dollar and lingering economic concerns. The dollar index fell, making gold less expensive for other currency holders. US economic growth slowed in the first quarter, and the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next week, potentially dulling gold's appeal.

summary: Asian finance leaders will discuss strengthening market safeguards against market turbulence and the impact of US interest rate hikes on regional capital flows. Japan, co-chairing the Asean+3 meeting, aims to propose a facility enhancing existing currency swap lines, allowing members to tap funds in emergencies. Despite regional confidence in foreign reserves and buffers, policymakers may enhance existing arrangements to combat potential market upheaval.

summary: Apple and Oppo battled for the top spot in China's smartphone market, with Oppo having the biggest share of shipments at 19.6% and Apple following close behind. The Chinese smartphone market contracted double-digit for most of the past year due to economic disruptions, with shipments to mainland China declining 11% in the first quarter. Apple regained the top spot in the final three months of last year following the release of its iPhone 14 and 14 Pro series, but none of the top five vendors in China recorded positive growth.

site_title: Singapore employment rises for 6th straight quarter in Q1 2023
summary: Singapore's employment levels rose for the sixth consecutive quarter in Q1 2023, driven by non-resident worker growth, particularly in the construction sector. Total employment excluding migrant domestic workers increased by 34,500, surpassing the pre-pandemic level by 3.9%. However, retrenchments rose for the third consecutive quarter, and labour market improvements have moderated. Unemployment rates remained low, but domestic unemployment could edge up due to global economic headwinds and a softer labour market. Employment growth is projected to slow to around 100,000 this year.

site_title: From rabak to rabs kebabs: the creative evolution of Singlish
summary: Researchers are studying the evolution of Singlish, Singapore's unique contact language, and finding it to be both structured and flexible. Unlike previous misconceptions, Singlish is not simply "bad English," but rather a systematic language created by interactions between different languages. Experts are building a network map of Singlish words to understand how speakers associate words, which could have applications in marketing and AI development. The study highlights Singlish's ability to innovate and reflect changes in society, making it a valuable part of Singapore's cultural heritage.

site_title: LVMH zeros in on China for global Tiffany & Co overhaul

site_title: NTUC launches ‘career trial model’ for fresh school-leavers and NSmen
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has launched a "career trial model" called NTUC Career Starter Lab, offering one-on-one career mentorship to 300-600 youths, including fresh graduates and national servicemen (NSF), for a three-month trial at their workplace. The pilot aims to provide guidance and support for those transitioning into the workforce, with a focus on NSF who often face challenges after national service. Participating companies will receive training allowance support, and NTUC will match applicants with suitable positions.

summary: Singapore's office rents rose 5.1% in Q1 2023 compared to Q4 2022, maintaining the same increase as the previous quarter. Experts attribute this to weaker sentiment due to recent tech layoffs and increased shadow space.

site_title: Intel posts biggest ever quarterly loss as chip sales collapse
summary: Intel reported its largest ever quarterly loss of $2.8 billion, with revenue falling 36% to $11.7 billion in the first quarter of 2023. The decline was attributed to a drop in demand for semiconductors, resulting from rising prices, a global chip glut, and poor demand for hardware. This collapse was less severe than expected, but still led to a 2% loss in the stock's post-session trading. Intel faces competition from Nvidia in the generative AI sector and struggles to meet demand for data center chips.

summary: Inflation and the hike in the Additional Buyer Stamp Duty (ABSD) significantly impacted Singapore's real estate market, affecting both domestic and international markets. This week, the ABSD hike led to a decline in property sales, while inflation concerns caused investors to reassess their portfolios. The Singapore government's ABSD hike was seen as a measure to curb speculation and boost housing affordability. site_title: Ed Sheeran sings to jury to rebut claim he copied Marvin Gaye
summary: Ed Sheeran testified in a New York court to defend himself against claims he copied Marvin Gaye's song "Let's Get It On" for his Grammy-winning hit "Thinking Out Loud." Sheeran, 32, claimed he wrote the song with collaborator Amy Wadge in February 2014, inspired by a new romantic relationship and elderly partners. SimCorp surged 38.3% after a 3.9 billion euro takeover offer from Deutsche Boerse. Other strong performers included Barclays (5.3%) and Deutsche Bank (2.5%). site_title: Debt restructuring for commodity exporters
summary: Debt-distressed countries, particularly in Africa, face significant challenges due to commodity price volatility. Many countries rely heavily on exports, making them vulnerable to fluctuations in oil, copper, and other commodity prices. To mitigate this risk, commodity-exporting debtor countries could issue commodity-denominated bonds, such as oil or copper bonds, which would shield them from market volatility. Multilateral lenders like the World Bank could denominate loans to these countries in commodities, creating a market for commodity bonds. This approach could help reduce the risk of debt distress and facilitate successful debt restructuring.

site_title: Caterpillar profit surges as machine demand jumps

site_title: Hong Kong runs down liquidity buffer with little impact on rates, for now

site_title: The ethics of personal transactions
summary: Portfolio managers must prioritize clients' interests over personal financial interests. The CFA Institute's Priority of Transactions Standard ensures this responsibility. However, conflicts can arise when portfolio managers make personal transactions that contradict client recommendations. To avoid these conflicts, portfolio managers must follow the three criteria: (1) the client is not disadvantaged, (2) the portfolio manager does not benefit personally, and (3) the portfolio manager complies with regulatory requirements. A case study illustrates how a portfolio manager's actions can violate these standards, highlighting the importance of ethical conduct in investment decisions.

Governor of Central Java since 2013, Ganjar is among a generation of provincial leaders from outside of Indonesia’s political elite who have built their voter base on a track record of reform, efficiency and transparency.
eFishery provides farmers with a dispenser that scatters pellets based on data from thousands of users.

site_title: Tokyo inflation regains momentum ahead of BOJ Ueda’s first meet
summary: Tokyo's inflation accelerated to 3.5% in April, exceeding forecasts, and remains above the Bank of Japan's 2% target. This is the 11th consecutive month of inflation above the target, fueling concerns that the BOJ may underestimate underlying price increases. Governor Kazuo Ueda's first monetary policy meeting is expected to conclude without major changes to interest rates or asset purchases. The labor market weakened in March, with the jobless rate rising to 2.8%, and daily necessities continue to rise in costs, with prices excluding energy and fresh food hitting 3.8% in April.

images.alt_text: The services producer price index rose 1.8 per cent in fiscal 2022, higher than a 1.2 per cent increase in the previous year.

site_title: An ill for every pill
summary: People are taking too many pills, with 15% of England's population and 20% of Americans aged 40-79 taking five or more prescription drugs daily. This "polypharmacy" imposes a significant drag on health, with nearly 1 in 5 hospital admissions caused by adverse reactions to drugs. Doctors, pharmacists, and nurses are setting up "de-prescribing networks" to spread the word, and some countries have published plans to reduce overprescribing. However, medication overload persists due to factors such as advertising, lack of unified personal health records, and patients forgetting to stop taking drugs.

images.alt_text: The US is the only industrialized country that does not control drug prices, and it is by far the world’s biggest market for prescription medications at about US$600 billion in 2021.
The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.8 per cent on Wednesday, with healthcare stocks tumbling 2.5 per cent, clocking its worst performance since late January, 2022.

Psilocybin bottles (top). Psychiatrists in Australia will be able to prescribe MDMA and psilocybin – more commonly known as ecstasy and magic mushrooms from July after finding “sufficient evidence for potential benefits in certain patients”.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust’s first-half year DPS rises 80% on higher revenue
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's first-half year distribution per stapled security (DPS) rose 79.7% to S$0.012649, driven by 41.1% growth in gross revenue to S$62.2 million and 42.9% growth in net property income to S$45.2 million. Same-store gross revenue and net property income increased 68.1% and 77.3%, respectively. The trust's managers attribute the recovery to leisure demand, corporate demand, and marquee events across cities.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within FHT. RevPAR for its Singapore portfolio increased 78.9 per cent year on year in Q1 FY 2023.
Frasers Hospitality Trust expects properties in countries with domestic travel market to recover faster
Colin Low resigns as CEO of FHT's managers after less than two years
FHT managers appoint Eu Chin Fen as CEO
Frasers Hospitality Trust to redeem S$100m 4.45% perps on first call date
FHT could reap benefits if managers repay 4.45% perps with debt: DBS report

site_title: Amazon shares surge as earnings beat expectations
summary: Amazon reported a profit of US$3.2 billion on sales that climbed 9% to US$127.4 billion in the first quarter of 2023, beating analyst expectations. The company's shares surged 7% to US$117.87 after the earnings release. Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy attributed the strong performance to the company's ability to deliver for customers, particularly in an uncertain economy. The company also announced plans to cut 9,000 more jobs, following a previous 18,000 layoffs.

images.alt_text: It is unclear how many Singapore employees have been laid off so far. As at October 2021, Amazon had about 2,000 full-time and part-time employees in Singapore.
Amazon, which in March announced it was laying off 9,000 workers as part of its second retrenchment drive, started informing some of the affected employees on Wednesday.
Overall, Amazon is axing 27,000 mostly corporate positions, after a hiring spree during the pandemic left the company with too many people.

site_title: Zuckerberg’s fortune jumps US$10 billion on Meta sales rebound
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's net worth jumped $10 billion to $87.3 billion after Meta Platforms reported robust first-quarter sales, a 14% increase in shares. This is his third-biggest one-day increase and his highest in over a year. The rebound reverses the 57% decline in his net worth in 2022, and he used the results to emphasize investments in AI and virtual reality.

site_title: Australia closes oldest coal plant, pivots to renewables
summary: Australia's oldest coal-fired power plant, Liddell, shut down on Friday, marking a significant shift towards renewable energy. The closure is part of a broader plan to phase out ageing coal-fired plants, with 82% of the country's electricity expected to come from renewable sources by 2030. Experts say the move is necessary to meet Australia's climate targets, as coal-fired plants are inefficient, polluting, and expensive to repair. The closure of Liddell and other coal plants will test whether renewables can fill the gap, with challenges including energy storage and transmission.

images.alt_text: BP in February announced that it expected to boost its profits between now and 2030 by investing more in both renewable energy and hydrocarbons, slowing the pace of its transition.
Fuel suppliers must ensure that 2 per cent of fuel made available at EU airports is SAF in 2025, rising to 6 per cent in 2030, 20 per cent in 2035 and gradually to 70 per cent in 2050.
The energy crisis has raised the prospect of more long term sustainable debt issuance to finance Europe's energy transition.

site_title: Snap misses revenue expectations, warns on second quarter outlook
summary: Snapchat's revenue for the first quarter fell short of analyst expectations, reaching $989 million, down from $1.06 billion last year, due to changes to its advertising platform. The company warned of potential revenue decline in the second quarter, citing a 6% year-over-year drop. Daily active users rose 15% to 383 million, but shares plummeted 19% in after-market trading. CEO Evan Spiegel attributed the decline to the need for time to adjust to new ad platform improvements.

images.alt_text: Snap launched Snapchat+ in June, making it available to a handful of countries, including the US, UK, Germany and United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Defiant Trump warns of ‘anarchy’ if US reelects Biden
summary: Former US President Donald Trump vowed to "crush" Joe Biden in the 2024 election, warning of "anarchy" if Biden is reelected. Trump's first campaign stop since Biden's announcement came as he faces legal woes, including a civil trial in New York and potential charges from the Department of Justice. Despite this, Trump maintains a double-digit lead in Republican primary polling, running ahead of rival Ron DeSantis. Trump's defiant speech came as many top Republicans question his ability to win again, with some calling him a "loser."
