images.alt_text: (COMBO) This combination of file pictures created on October 30, 2020, shows US President Donald Trump speaks during a campaign rally at Manchester-Boston Regional Airport in Londonderry, New Hampshire on October 25, 2020 and Democratic Presidential candidate and former Vice President Joe Biden speaking at a voter mobilization event in Cincinnati, Ohio, on October 12, 2020. - Biden announced April 25, 2023, his bid "to finish the job" with re-election in 2024, plunging at the record age of 80 into a ferocious campaign that could set up a rematch against former President Donald Trump. (Photo by MANDEL NGAN and JIM WATSON / AFP)
An NBC News poll released last weekend found that 70 per cent of Americans, including 51 per cent of Democrats, believe Joe Biden should not run in 2024.
US President Joe Biden (right) faces the prospect of a rematch with Donald Trump at next year's presidential election.
Jury selection began in Manhattan federal court in the Trump’s rape case, where the accuser E Jean Carroll (above) is also accusing Trump of defamation.

site_title: Bored Ape’s new boss seeks to revive NFTs through gaming, events
summary: Yuga Labs, the company behind the popular Bored Ape Yacht Club NFT collection, has appointed former Activision Blizzard executive Daniel Alegre as its new CEO. Alegre aims to revive NFTs by integrating them into gaming, events, and e-commerce experiences. Yuga is expanding its video game offerings, including a virtual world called Otherside, and partnering with brands like Gucci and Puma. Despite a decline in global NFT sales, Alegre remains optimistic, citing the potential for web3 to transform community, creativity, and connection.

images.alt_text: Auctions and private sales of non-fungible tokens ( NFTs  ) in the “GRAILS” collection will kick off next month in New York.

site_title: UK weighs reform of uninsured bank deposits after SVB collapse
summary: The UK Treasury and Bank of England are considering reforms to give uninsured depositors immediate access to their cash in the event of a bank failure. The proposed reforms aim to speed up payouts and could put taxpayers on the hook. The move follows the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and other US regional lenders, and comes as regulators worldwide examine ways to deal with bank runs. The proposed reforms would cover a portion of the funds upfront and could involve an assessment of how much cash uninsured depositors are likely to recover.

site_title: Netflix increases Asian leads, lags in Latino roles, report finds
summary: Netflix has increased representation of Asian and women in lead roles, but still lags in representing Latinos, the disabled, and women of color. A study by the streaming platform and USC found that only 1.1% of Netflix characters have a disability, despite 27% of the US population identifying as disabled. The study also highlighted a lack of progress for Latino actors, with 5.8% of main casts, compared to 17.1% for Blacks and 9.4% for Asians.

images.alt_text: Globally, more than 100 million people use an account they don’t pay for, according to Netflix.
Netflix offered a lighter-than-expected forecast last week.
From January through March,  Netflix added 1.75 million streaming subscribers, missing analyst estimates of 2.06 million additions.

site_title: Reimagining Workfare to uplift low-wage families
summary: Singapore is reimagining its Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) policy to uplift low-wage families, not just individual workers. The revised policy will focus on households, providing support to those in need. This move aims to address poverty and vulnerability in society. The government plans to establish an official poverty line and enhance employment support. The reimagined WIS policy is part of President Halimah Yacob's address, emphasizing the need to step up support for the disadvantaged. The goal is to empower workers and their families, ultimately uplifting society as a whole.

images.alt_text: Workers' Party Member of Parliament Jamus Lim called for a committee comprising government representatives, civil society leaders and academic experts to be set up to decide what the poverty line should be.

Low-wage platform workers to get 75%
offset of additional CPF contributions for first year
MPs covered a wide range of issues during the Budget debate on Thursday, seeking greater support for vulnerable workers, even as they called for larger businesses to do more to contribute to society.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts lower FY22/23 DPU due to enlarged unit base
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported lower distributable income per unit (DPU) for FY22/23 due to higher borrowing costs and a larger unit base. The trust saw a 3.5% decline in Q4 FY22/23 DPU to S$0.0333, despite a 4.3% increase in gross revenue and 3.8% rise in net property income. MIT's FY22/23 gross revenue rose 12.3% to S$684.9 million, while net property income increased 9.7% to S$518 million. The trust's CEO attributed the decline to a challenging macroeconomic environment and higher operating expenses.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) and sponsor Frasers Property Limited (FPL) jointly acquired a 50 per cent stake in suburban mall Nex for S$652.5 million.

An artist’s impression of Mapletree Industrial Trust’s proposed high-tech industrial precinct at Kallang Way. To-date, about 39 per cent of the redevelopment at 161, 163 and 165 Kallang Way’s net lettable area have been committed.

site_title: US economy grows at 1.1% rate in first quarter
summary: The US economy grew at a 1.1% annual rate in the first quarter, driven by resilient consumer spending despite rising prices and higher borrowing costs. This marks a third consecutive quarter of growth, following a contraction in the first half of last year. Weakness in housing and business investment were attributed to interest rate hikes. Consumer spending rose at a 3.7% annual rate, but forecasters warn it could weaken amid recession concerns. Fed policymakers aim for a gradual slowdown to cool inflation without causing widespread layoffs.

images.alt_text: The dollar index was down 0.1 per cent on the day, making gold less expensive for other currencies holders.
The US dollar index was last up around 0.2 per cent at 101.37, having dropped over 3.3 per cent since the beginning of March.

site_title: Meta shares surge as digital ad rebound fuels AI investments
summary: Meta Platforms' shares surged 15% after the company reported a surprising rebound in digital advertising sales, beating analysts' estimates. The company's revenue and user growth exceeded expectations, with Meta's stock gaining 74% this year. CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the company is well-positioned in the AI industry and plans to invest in generative AI, citing its potential to improve customer service, advertisement creation, and gaming experiences. Meta's revenue rose to $28.6 billion, with a forecast of $32 billion for the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Meta, the owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp is working to move faster while cutting costs in what chief executive officer Mark Zuckerberg has dubbed the “year of efficiency”.

site_title: Pinterest’s ad woes hurt revenue growth, shares slump
summary: Pinterest's second-quarter revenue growth fell short of Wall Street estimates, with shares plummeting 13% due to a pullback in advertising spending. The company forecast revenue growth in line with the first quarter, citing stabilizing ad market uncertainty. Despite this, shares of peer Snap also dropped 18% after weak first-quarter revenue. Pinterest aims to boost its ad business by opening up third-party ad demand, partnering with Amazon for its first ad delivery platform. Global monthly active users grew 7% to 463 million, with revenue rising 5% to $602.58 million in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The job cuts came from teams across the San Francisco-based company, though not all were affected to the same degree, a person familiar with the company said.

site_title: China Evergrande extends deadline for debt restructuring incentive to May 18
summary: China Evergrande Group has extended the deadline for receiving an incentive for its debt restructuring proposal to May 18, citing support from 77% of class-A bondholders and 30% of class-C bondholders. The company's debt restructuring plan requires approval from more than 75% in creditor value in each debt class to pass. Despite securing support from major bondholders, smaller creditors have expressed concerns over the deal terms, with some planning to sell their bonds soon.

images.alt_text: Evergrande eventually needs to secure support from 75 per cent of creditors in value to implement its debt restructuring, one of China’s biggest ever, through so-called schemes of arrangement.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after tech earnings pass muster
summary: US stocks rallied on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.4% to 12,142.24, driven by strong earnings from Facebook parent Meta, which surged 14%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, with the Dow climbing 1.6% and the S&P 500 gaining 2.0%. Analysts attributed the gains to Meta's favourable results and strong consumer spending data, as well as reassuring earnings from US lenders. However, Caterpillar's earnings fell short of expectations, and Southwest Airlines announced plans to trim capacity and slow hiring.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 79.79 points, or 0.24 per cent, at the open to 33,381.66.

site_title: Mortgage rates in the US rise to highest level since mid-March
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 6.43% for a 30-year, fixed loan, the highest level since mid-March, according to Freddie Mac. The average rate increased from 6.39% the previous week, squeezing homebuyers. The housing market is constrained by a lack of homes for sale, with contracts to buy existing homes falling 5.2% last month. However, signs of decelerating inflation may lead to lower mortgage rates later this year, potentially easing the burden on buyers.

images.alt_text: The National Association of Realtors’ (NAR) index of contract signings to purchase previously owned homes dropped 5.2 per cent in March to 78.9, according to data released on Thursday (Apr 27).
US consumers have proved resilient in the face of both rising prices and higher borrowing costs.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as upbeat earnings lift mood
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by better-than-expected earnings from Meta Platforms, Eli Lilly, and Comcast, outweighing data showing the US economy slowed in the first quarter. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 79.79 points, or 0.24%, to 33,381.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The positive start to the day was seen as a relief for investors after the slower-than-expected economic data.

site_title: US pending home sales fall 5.2%, biggest drop since September
summary: US pending home sales dropped 5.2% in March, the largest decline since September, according to the National Association of Realtors. The decrease was worse than expected, with contract signings falling 23.3% year-over-year. Housing supply remains constrained due to homeowners' reluctance to list properties, despite some encouraging signs of stabilizing demand. The decline is attributed to limited inventory and elevated borrowing costs, which are expected to rise again after the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike next week.

images.alt_text: US consumers have proved resilient in the face of both rising prices and higher borrowing costs.

site_title: Euro hovers near one-year high as US outlook clouds over
summary: The euro hovered near a one-year high against the US dollar, last up 0.1% at US$1.104, driven by Europe's resilient economy contrasting with US banking risks and debt ceiling standoff. The US dollar index remained flat at 101.4, following a 0.4% slide the previous day. Analysts expect a challenging environment for the US dollar, citing moderating US inflation and outperformance of the eurozone.

site_title: ABSD shock seen hitting prime housing market hardest, could drive away foreign investors
summary: Singapore's latest cooling measures, which double the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rate for foreigners to 60%, are expected to hit the prime housing market the hardest. This will deter foreign investors, who typically account for a larger share of sales in prime areas. In contrast, demand from Singaporeans and permanent residents will moderate due to a 3-5 percentage point hike in ABSD rates. The move is seen as a measure to protect Singaporeans' aspirational housing needs, but may also chase away ultra-rich foreigners and affect developers' land bidding strategies.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Private home prices may correct, with demand from foreigners and local investors crimped by the latest hike in Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty.

The 60 per cent Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty that foreigners now pay for a home in Singapore means the city’s levies exceed those of other international hubs including Hong Kong, London and New York by a large margin.
An artist's impression of Newport Residences which will be built on the site of the former Fuji Xerox Towers on Anson Road.
For Singapore citizens, ABSD will be raised to 20 per cent from 17 per cent for the purchase of their second property, and to 30 per cent from 25 per cent for their third and subsequent properties.
ABSD rate will be raised from 30% to 35% for SPRs purchasing their 3rd and subsequent residential property;

site_title: Japan’s SMFG boosts US presence via bigger stake in Jefferies
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp (SMBC) will raise its stake in US firm Jefferies from 4.5% to as much as 15%, giving it the right to nominate a board member. This deal marks a significant boost to SMBC's US presence and follows a collaboration between the two companies on cross-border M&As, healthcare, and leveraged finance since 2021. The move aims to expand SMBC's domestic rival, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's, US presence, which has been strengthened by a $9 billion investment in Morgan Stanley in 2008.

site_title: One of world’s oldest newspapers to end daily print run
summary: Austria's state-owned newspaper, Wiener Zeitung, will shift primarily to online publication starting July 1, after a years-long dispute with the government. Founded in 1703, the paper will maintain a minimum of 10 print publications per year and establish a media hub, content agency, and training center for journalists. The move is in line with a European directive to centralize official information online. The decision has sparked protests and concerns about the future of serious journalism, with nearly half of the newspaper's 200 employees at risk of being laid off.

site_title: Singapore not spared as Amazon carries out retrenchment exercise affecting 9,000 workers
summary: Amazon is conducting a retrenchment exercise affecting approximately 9,000 employees, including those in its cloud services division, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and other departments. The move, announced in March, comes after the company laid off 18,000 jobs between November 2022 and January. As of October 2021, Amazon had about 2,000 full-time and part-time employees in Singapore. The company is providing severance packages, including separation payments and transitional health insurance benefits, to affected employees.

images.alt_text: Overall, Amazon is axing 27,000 mostly corporate positions, after a hiring spree during the pandemic left the company with too many people.

site_title: Credit Suisse employee bonuses tied to AT1 bonds also wiped out
summary: Credit Suisse erased contingent capital awards (CCAs) worth 360 million Swiss francs (S$537.3 million) for employees, tied to AT1 bonds that were wiped out in the firm's emergency sale to UBS Group. The move adds to pay pain for senior bankers, following share awards plummeting in value and some bonuses cut or canceled by government decree. The CCAs, designed to carry similar risks as the AT1 bonds, were excluded from the writedown by regulator Finma in private talks.

images.alt_text: The UK headquarters of Credit Suisse Group AG in Canary Wharf financial district in London, UK, on Monday, March 20, 2023. European stocks slumped on Monday, as UBS Group AG’s agreement to buy Credit Suisse Group AG failed to assuage fears about potential global banking turmoil. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
UBS has been a beneficiary of Credit Suisse’s troubles, with wealthy clients adding US$23.3 billion net new fee-generating assets already in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust posts 17.3% fall in Q4 DPU to S$0.0225
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) reported a 17.3% decline in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0225, due to higher finance costs. Despite this, the trust saw a 85.9% increase in gross revenue to S$233.3 million and an 82.2% increase in net property income to S$177.4 million, driven by contributions from recently acquired properties. For the full year, DPU rose 0.8% to 9.61 cents, while NPI and gross revenue grew 62.6% and 65.4%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Mapletree Business City on April 21, 2022.
MPACT's manager said the growth in gross revenue and NPI was in part driven by higher earnings from the trust’s Singapore portfolio, which includes shopping mall VivoCity (above).

site_title: Japfa reports US$43 million loss for Q1 2023 on compressed margins
summary: Japfa, an agri-food company, reported a US$43 million loss for Q1 2023, a reversal from a profit of US$13.5 million in Q1 2022, due to high raw material costs and inflationary pressures. Revenue fell 7% to US$1 billion, and gross profit declined 51% to US$77.4 million. Japfa plans to recalibrate its growth plans amid margin compression, freezing non-essential growth capital expenditure and streamlining operations. The company's Vietnam swine and poultry businesses were particularly impacted by low average selling prices and high production costs.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Notably, Japfa’s APO business in Vietnam was affected by the African Swine Fever (ASF) outbreak, and there were continued disruptions to the group’s supply of pork and swine fattening prices.
Japfa’s chief executive Tan Yong Nang said the listing of AustAsia also splits Japfa’s business neatly in terms of geography.
印尼佳发公司希望掌握新兴亚洲市场快速发展的牛奶行业。 （印尼佳发公司提供）

site_title: Mobileye cuts revenue forecast on slow China EV demand, shares sink
summary: Mobileye Global reduced its annual revenue forecast due to a slowdown in electric-vehicle demand in China, where automakers offer discounts to arrest a demand slowdown. The company lowered its revenue forecast to $2.07-2.11 billion, down from previous estimates of $2.19-2.28 billion. Shares dropped nearly 15% before the bell. The decline is attributed to China's decision to end subsidies for electric vehicles, intensifying competition in the assisted driving market from Nvidia and Qualcomm, and regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Mobileye, majority owned by Intel, forecast full-year 2023 revenue between US$2.19 billion and US$2.28 billion.

site_title: Mastercard shrugs off economic jitters as consumers continue to splurge
summary: Mastercard reported a quarterly profit of US$2.4 billion, beating estimates, despite rising interest rates and inflation. The company's cross-border volumes surged 35% due to pent-up demand from consumers, driving US$2.1 trillion in gross US dollar volumes. Mastercard expects second-quarter revenue in the high end of low double-digits, aligning with Street expectations. The results contrast with Visa's recent beat and American Express's miss, and analysts see the guidance as leaving room for managing uncertain macroeconomic conditions.

images.alt_text: Starting in 2028, Mastercard will require all banks issuing one of its payment cards to use sustainable materials as it seeks to remove first-use, PVC plastics from its network
Visa and Mastercard are each being sued by hundreds of claimants at London’s Competition Appeal Tribunal, which is currently managing the various cases together.

site_title: CDL’s Newport Residences preview postponed; developers take stock of ABSD hikes
summary: CDL has postponed the preview of its luxury project Newport Residences in Singapore's prime downtown area due to the government's latest cooling measures, which include a doubling of Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for foreigners. The project, priced north of S$3,000 per square foot, had been scheduled to start previews this weekend. CDL will monitor market conditions closely and unveil its launch at an appropriate time. The move comes as other luxury projects in the CBD also face uncertainty, with some developers planning to proceed with sales launches despite the increased ABSD rates.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

Minister for National Development speaking to reporters on Thursday (Apr 27) at HDB MyLearningSpace after the Singapore government announced on Wednesday that it will be stepping up ABSD rates for residential properties, in fresh cooling measures.

site_title: Shakespeare In The Park returns with stellar cast in ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’
summary: Singapore Repertory Theatre's open-air production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, part of the Shakespeare In The Park series, reimagines Shakespeare's enchanted forest as an "inverted industrial-chic set with lots of water". The production, directed by Guy Unsworth, features a stellar cast, including Julie Wee as Titania and Ghafir Akbar as Oberon. The play, which speaks to environmental destruction and its impact on humankind, runs from May 3 to 28 at Fort Canning Park. The production aims to celebrate the themes of love, togetherness, and fun, bringing people together to celebrate life after the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Brian Gothong Tan's stunning, surreal images were created using an AI tool. Like other artists in Singapore, Tan has been turning to AI for collaboration and inspiration.
Gallerists manning one of the over 170 booths at Art Basel Hong Kong selling modern and contemporary art.
The UOB-NAC  Acceleration Programme For The Arts included a hands-on video-making lesson on creating slick short videos using camera phones and CapCut free video editing tool.

site_title: Amex apologises for SMSes to cardholders about temporary card suspensions
summary: American Express has apologized for sending erroneous text messages to cardholders about temporary card suspensions in Singapore. The messages claimed cardholders' unsecured interest-bearing balances exceeded 12 times their monthly income for three consecutive months, but the company assured cardholders it was an error and no further action is required. The company is experiencing high call volumes and apologizes for the inconvenience caused, urging cardholders to disregard the message.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Boards should seriously consider meeting requisitions, conduct them expeditiously: SGX RegCo
summary: SGX RegCo CEO Tan Boon Gin advises boards to "seriously and objectively consider" general meeting requisitions by shareholders, and conduct them "expeditiously". Boards should discuss concerns with requisitionists and consider the merits of proposals from the issuer's and shareholders' perspective. Requisitionists must provide the board with necessary information and adhere to procedural requirements, such as giving proper notice to all shareholders. Delays in completing the meeting can lead to uncertainty and detract from the company's business conduct.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Judicial Commissioner Goh Yihan declared the requisition notice for USP Group's upcoming EGM invalid, as the requisitioning shareholders were not deemed as “members” of USP under the Companies Act.
Minority shareholders of watch-listed USP Group are looking to take the company out of the watchlist by gaining control of its board and injecting it with new projects.
Recent boardroom tussles involving SGX-listed companies have seen varying degrees of success for requisitioning parties, and not all cases are straightforward.

site_title: UK sets out tougher gambling rules for smartphone era
summary: The UK government has announced proposals to crack down on problem gambling, updating regulations for the £14 billion industry since the 2005 Gambling Act. The changes include introducing online stake limits between £2 and £15, and forcing firms to step up affordability checks. A statutory levy will also be introduced to fund research, education, and treatment for problem gamblers. The reforms aim to bring the industry up to date with the rise of online and smartphone gambling, with two major companies, Entain and Flutter, welcoming the proposals.

site_title: China brokerage Citic posts 3.6% rise in Q1 profit
summary: Citic Securities, China's largest brokerage, reported a 3.6% rise in Q1 profit to 5.4 billion yuan, driven by a 89.6% surge in investment income to 5.82 billion yuan. The company attributed the growth to the economy's recovery.

site_title: Sinopec first-quarter net income down 12% on lower oil prices
summary: Sinopec Group, Asia's top oil refiner, reported a 12% decrease in first-quarter net income to 20.1 billion yuan (S$3.9 billion) due to lower crude oil prices. Refinery throughput fell 3% to 62.24 million tonnes, while petrol output dropped 8%. Total refined fuel sales rose 10% despite lower oil prices, driven by recovering demand after the lifting of Covid controls. The company's petrochemicals arm reported a 7.2% decline in ethylene production and a 3.02 billion yuan loss before tax and interest.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust Q1 2023 results affected by forex volatility
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a 6.2% increase in net property income to 352.1 billion rupiah in Q1 2023, driven by a depreciating rupiah. Rental revenue fell 1.9% to 317.1 billion rupiah, while gross revenue rose 3.5% to 558.6 billion rupiah. The trust's portfolio of properties reported stable operating performance due to improving conditions in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Lippo Mall
Fitch says its latest rating action reflects the increased likelihood that LMIRT would be unable to refinance its S$547 million debt maturing over the next 18 months.
LMIRT continues to explore options and measures to maintain a sustainable capital structure and reduce the aggregate leverage of the trust, says its manager.

site_title: EV giant BYD’s Q1 profit jumps five times to 4.13 billion yuan
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle giant, reported a fivefold increase in its first-quarter profit to 4.13 billion yuan, driven by a 79.8% surge in revenue. The company outsold Volkswagen-branded cars in China, solidifying its market leadership. BYD's affordable electric hatchback, the Seagull, was unveiled at the Shanghai car show with a price tag of 78,000 yuan, around half the cost of comparable new energy vehicles.

images.alt_text: BYD sold almost 550,000 cars globally in January-March, more than all of the passenger vehicle registrations in the UK in that period.

site_title: Russia’s Yandex reports revenue jump, return to Q1 profitability
summary: Russia's Yandex reports a 54% jump in Q1 revenue to 163.3 billion roubles ($2.7 billion) and returns to profitability after a net loss in the same period last year. Revenue growth was driven by investments in advertising technologies and reduced competition from Google, which stopped selling online ads in Russia. Yandex's search and portal market share averaged 63.3% in the quarter, up from 61% a year ago.

images.alt_text: “As a result of the deal, Yandex will become the sole owner of the group, which includes a taxi ordering service, carsharing and scooter rental,” Yandex said in a statement.

site_title: FJ Benjamin returns to luxury with new lifestyle concept
summary: FJ Benjamin, a luxury retailer, has launched a new lifestyle concept called Avenue on 3 in Paragon Shopping Centre, Singapore. The 8,000 sq ft store offers a multi-label retail and lifestyle experience featuring shoes, skincare, a cafe, bar, chocolatier, and pop-up space. Key highlights include designer footwear, luxury skincare products, and artisanal chocolates. The open-concept store aims to provide an experiential shopping experience, with a focus on high-end and bespoke services, and is a return to the luxury market for the company after the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: F J Benjamin receives in-principle approval from SGX for transfer to Catalist board

site_title: Manchester United asks bidders for sources of wealth ahead of deadline
summary: Manchester United has requested bidders to provide information on the source of their wealth and who will be the club's ultimate beneficial owner ahead of a looming deadline. The questions were sent by the Glazer family's bankers to ensure compliance with UK government-proposed ethics tests. The two main contenders, Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad Al Thani and Jim Ratcliffe, will be scrutinized under the new regulations, which require owners to declare their money sources and debt management abilities. The deadline for bids is Friday, with Manchester United currently fourth in the Premier League.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - Europa League - Play-Off Second Leg - Manchester United v FC Barcelona - Old Trafford, Manchester, Britain - February 23, 2023
General view of a corner flag inside the stadium before the match REUTERS/Carl Recine

site_title: Singtel combines Singapore consumer, enterprise businesses; forms infrastructure arm
summary: Singtel combines its Singapore consumer and enterprise businesses into a singular operating company, effective June 1, 2023. The move aims to optimize synergies and capabilities to drive growth. A standalone infrastructure unit, Digital InfraCo, will be formed, including regional data centre business, subsea cable, and satellite carrier businesses. This consolidation will allow Singtel to turn its digital infrastructure assets into an area of growth, according to group CEO Yuen Kuan Moon.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Singtel shares ended Wednesday down 0.4 per cent, or S$0.01, to S$2.51.

site_title: SGX reprimands ASTI, directs company to hold AGM
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has directed ASTI Holdings to convene its FY2021 and FY2022 annual general meetings (AGMs) by July 31, 2023. The company was given an extension to hold the FY2021 AGM by September 7, 2022, after its external auditor was unable to provide an opinion by August 18, 2022.

images.alt_text: hammer, books, law
Benjamin Cher

site_title: UK train drivers announce fresh strikes, including FA Cup final date
summary: UK train drivers' union, ASLEF, has announced three more days of strike action, including the FA Cup final on June 3, after rejecting a 8% pay offer. The strikes will also impact the Eurovision Song Contest in Liverpool. ASLEF general secretary Mick Whelan rejected the offer, calling it "risible." The Rail Delivery Group, representing train operators, urged the union to return to negotiations, saying the strikes will add pressure to an industry facing a financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Commuters wait for a train at Clapham Junction station in south London on March 16, 2023 as train drivers staged a strike over pay, the latest in a wave of UK industrial action. - Britain's government vowed a hefty £94 billion ($114 billion) in cost-of-living support for this year and next, as it forecast the UK to stay out of recession and inflation to slow sharply. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished with gains on Thursday, closing 0.42% higher at 19,840.28, despite a disappointing initial public offering by Chinese baijiu maker ZJLD. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.67% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.12%. The gains come as Chinese GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Signage for Hong Kong Stock Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) during the listing ceremony of ZJLD Group Inc. at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, April 27, 2023. Shares of Chinese liquor company ZJLD tumbled on their debut in Hong Kong on Thursday following what was the Asian financial hubs biggest initial public offering this year. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines consortium makes US$1.8b bid to upgrade Manila airport
summary: A Philippines consortium, consisting of six major conglomerates, has submitted a US$1.8 billion bid to upgrade and operate the Ninoy Aquino International Airport, ranked among the world's worst international travel hubs. The proposal includes a significant upfront payment and investments in new facilities and technology to transform the airport into a world-class hub, capable of serving up to 62.5 million passengers per year by 2028. The consortium is seeking a 25-year concession and aims to address the airport's issues of regular flight delays and crumbling facilities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man takes a picture of passengers queueing at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport, in Pasay City, Metro Manila, Philippines, January 2, 2023. REUTERS/Eloisa Lopez/File Photo

site_title: Vingroup chairman-backed GSM aims to take its electric taxis beyond Vietnam
summary: GSM Green and Smart Mobility JSC, backed by Vingroup chairman Pham Nhat Vuong, has launched Vietnam's first electric-only taxi company, Green SM Taxi, with 600 VinFast electric vehicles in Ho Chi Minh City. The company aims to expand to 20,000 electric taxis nationwide and eventually take its services abroad. GSM plans to operate with a hybrid model, allowing passengers to book via mobile apps and phone calls, and has partnered with Grab's local rival, Be Group, to provide exclusive rates for VinFast electric cars and motorbikes. The company's expansion is part of Vietnam's goal to convert all taxis to electric vehicles by 2030.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Minister for National Development Desmond Lee announced a "pre-emptive measure" to curb investment demand in Singapore's property market, prioritizing local buyers. This comes as property investment demand rises, adding stress to the local housing market. Meanwhile, Singapore moves forward with testing ammonia as a green marine fuel, and firms are urged to transform for productivity despite economic uncertainty. Rents and industrial space prices continue to rise, and property counters decline following the government's property cooling measures, causing the STI to fall 0.4%.

site_title: Hublot injects new spirit into the Big Bang
summary: Hublot has unveiled the Spirit of Big Bang Sang Bleu, its third collaboration with tattoo artist Maxime Plescia-Buchi. The new chronograph timepiece features an enhanced 42mm barrel-shaped case with faceted design, showcasing 3D geometry. The watch is available in three limited editions: titanium, all black ceramic, and King Gold. Prices range from US$28,300 to US$70,400, depending on the material. This collaboration marks a new dimension in the Spirit of Big Bang line, blending art and time.

images.alt_text:
pmtag27 - TH CARRERA PLASMA 44mm PRESS RELEASE




Credit : Tag Heuer

site_title: Surging home loans in Philippines show rate hikes not biting yet
summary: The Philippines' housing and auto loans surged 40% and 30% in the first quarter, respectively, as consumers continued to spend despite 16-year-high borrowing costs. Credit card base rose 14% and loans nearly doubled, with the country's consumption-driven economy expected to grow 7% in 2023. Despite the Philippine central bank's aggressive monetary tightening, consumer credit is growing, with nonperforming loans muted, according to Bank of the Philippine Islands. The favorable outlook is attributed to a resilient consumer sector and a pivot to the US market.

images.alt_text:
Newly built high-rise buidlings tower over a small community in Mandaluyong, Philippines October 14, 2017. 

Photo by Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

site_title: India’s Reliance JV strikes content streaming deal with Warner for JioCinema
summary: Reliance's JioCinema has struck a deal with Warner Bros Discovery to bring Hollywood content onto its streaming platform, including popular shows like Succession, Game of Thrones, and Harry Potter. The multi-year agreement starts next month and will see Warner Bros' HBO content, as well as its own TV series, available on JioCinema. The deal is exclusive and will make JioCinema the primary platform for Warner's marquee content in India, competing with rivals like Netflix and Amazon.

site_title: Germany in talks to limit export of chip chemicals to China
summary: Germany is in talks to limit the export of chemicals to China used to manufacture semiconductors as part of efforts to reduce economic exposure to the Asian nation. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government is discussing measures to cut off China's access to goods and services needed for advanced semiconductor production. The proposal would restrict exports of chemicals from German companies such as Merck and BASF, which are critical for making semiconductors. The move aims to strike a balance between supporting Germany's economic interests in China and addressing national security and human rights concerns.

images.alt_text: Two employees of German semiconductor manufacturer Infineon Technologies AG work in a clean room on the production line of 300-millimeter wafers at the company's plant in Dresden, eastern Germany, on April 26, 2023. - German chipmaker Infineon will launch the groundbreaking of a new factory, the Smart Power Fab, in Dresden on May 2, 2023. Supply chain snarls during the Coronavirus pandemic have exposed how over-reliant Europe has become on chip imports from abroad in recent years, disrupting numerous industries that depend on the components. The European Union in 2022 launched a plan known as the "Chips Act", which aims to double Europe's market share in semiconductors by 2030. (Photo by JENS SCHLUETER / AFP)

site_title: Quick takes: The impact of new ABSD rates for residential properties
summary: The Singapore government has raised Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for residential properties. For Singapore citizens, the rates are 20% for second properties and 30% for third and subsequent properties. Permanent residents will face 30% for second properties and 35% for third and subsequent properties. The adjustments aim to manage investment demand and implement cooling measures. The changes take effect on April 27, 2023.

images.alt_text: Generic property landscape in Singapore

site_title: Diamonds are a watch’s best friend
summary: TAG Heuer has launched two new watch models featuring lab-grown diamonds, marking its commitment to innovation. The 44mm Carrera Plasma Diamant d'Avant-Grade Chronograph Tourbillon showcases diamonds in various shapes and colors, while the 36mm Carrera Plasma Diamant d'Avant-Garde features colored lab-grown diamonds. Both watches feature nearly every component set with lab-grown diamonds, totaling 15.5 carats in the larger model. The watches are limited productions, priced at 500,000 Swiss francs and 90,000 Swiss francs, respectively.

site_title: Top bunker hub Singapore implements maritime projects
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority has announced updates on shipping decarbonisation projects, aiming to stay competitive and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Key projects include a methanol bunkering pilot, a green corridor with the Port of Los Angeles and Port of Long Beach, and the development of Tuas Port with a handling capacity of 65 million TEUs. The port authority also plans to introduce electric vessels, biofuel bunkering standards, and an ammonia bunkering facility, with plans to launch an electric harbour craft and deploy a charging station by 2030.

images.alt_text: This picture shows vessels parked along the Singapore anchorage in Singapore on April 26, 2023. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Swedish economy expanded in Q1, outlook uncertain
summary: Sweden's economy expanded 0.2% in Q1, the first quarter-on-quarter growth since Q4 2022, as GDP rose 0.3% year-over-year. Despite this, economists expect a shallow recession this year due to high household debt and inflation. The Riksbank still forecasts a 0.7% contraction in 2023, but may revise its outlook if inflation expectations continue to fall.

site_title: Japan’s life insurers plan to boost JGBs, eye more BOJ policy tweaks
summary: Japan's life insurers plan to increase holdings of Japanese government bonds (JGBs) this fiscal year, anticipating a possible tweak in the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) yield curve control policy. Market players expect new BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda to maintain ultra-loose monetary settings, but anticipate a change in the BOJ's yield curve control policy at the June policy meeting. Insurers will steadily increase JGB purchases if yields rise, driven by a possible tweak in the BOJ's policy, with some considering buying 30-year JGBs above 1.5% yield.

images.alt_text: epa10590387 Pedestrians cross a street in Tokyo, Japan, 25 April 2023. The Japanese government's monthly economic report maintained a general assessment that the economy was recovering moderately, despite some weaknesses.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA

site_title: JPMorgan creates AI model to analyse 25 years of Fed speeches
summary: JPMorgan has developed an AI model to analyze 25 years of Federal Reserve speeches and statements, aiming to decipher policy signals and predict future interest rate changes. The model, called the Hawk-Dove Score, rates policy signals on a scale from easy to restrictive and has shown potential in predicting changes in policy and tradeable signals. The tool has been found to be useful in detecting rising hawkishness among Fed speakers, which has led to more hawkish policy statements and increased yields on one-year government bonds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers are reflected in the windows of the Canary Wharf offices of JP Morgan in London September 19, 2013. REUTERS/Neil Hall/File Photo

site_title: From ChildAid to a solo career, Corey Koh charts his own path
summary: Singaporean singer Corey Koh, 20, has launched his debut single "Only Love" and plans to release an EP and a Chinese single "对的时候" in the coming months. Koh, a classically trained singer, has transitioned to pop music, citing his classical training as lending itself well to the genre. He sings fluently in six languages and owns 34 electric guitars. Koh aims to stage his first solo charity concert later this year to support children from low-income families.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Portrait of Corey Koh
Local media, citing the police, reported that Moonbin had been found unresponsive on Wednesday evening in his apartment in the upscale Gangnam neighborhood of Seoul.
Brian Gothong Tan's stunning, surreal images were created using an AI tool. Like other artists in Singapore, Tan has been turning to AI for collaboration and inspiration.

A visitor takes a picture with his mobile phone of an image designed with artificial intelligence by Berlin-based digital creator Julian van Dieken (C) inspired by Johannes Vermeer's painting "Girl with a Pearl Earring" at the Mauritshuis museum in The Hague on March 9, 2023.

site_title: Private home prices look set for a welcome correction amid higher ABSD rates
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to correct amid higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates. Citizens and permanent residents buying second homes will pay 20% and 30% ABSD respectively, while foreigners will pay 60% ABSD. This increase may lead to a decrease in demand from foreigners and local investors, potentially resulting in a correction in the market.

images.alt_text: Generic private properties around Orchard area.
Leslie Yee

site_title: China’s CNOOC profit slips 6.4% in first quarter on lower oil price
summary: China's state-owned oil company CNOOC reported a 6.4% decline in first-quarter profit to 32.1 billion yuan (S$6.2 billion) due to lower realized oil prices. Despite a 8.6% increase in total net production to 163.9 million barrels of oil equivalent (boe), the profit was squeezed by a 23.9% slide in oil prices. Revenue rose 7.5% to 97.7 billion yuan (S$18.9 billion). CNOOC aims to increase production by 6% annually by 2025, with a target of 650-660 million boe in 2023.

images.alt_text: Asia’s top oil refiner, also known as Sinopec, reported 20.1 billion yuan (S$3.9 billion) net profit under Chinese accounting standards, versus 22.61 billion yuan a year earlier, in a filing to the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Thursday (Apr 27).

site_title: GoTo narrows Q1 loss to 3.9 trillion rupiah, but expects slower growth
summary: GoTo Group, Indonesia's tech giant, reported a net loss of 3.9 trillion rupiah (S$354.1 million) for Q1, a 41% narrower loss from last year. The company's Q1 gross revenue grew 14% to six trillion rupiah, with net revenue more than doubling to 3.3 trillion rupiah. The on-demand services segment, including Gojek's ride-hailing and food delivery, saw a 5% decline in gross transaction value (GTV). GoTo expects slower growth, but shares are tipped for a rebound after a recent US$2.2 billion sell-off.

images.alt_text: Gojek riders wait for their delivery orders at a distribution centre in Surabaya on May 17, 2021, as Gojek and Tokopedia unveiled a merger to form GoTo Group, creating the largest tech firm in the world's fourth most populous country. (Photo by Juni Kriswanto / AFP)
Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Carlsberg lifts profit guidance on strong Chinese sales
summary: Carlsberg, the world's third-largest brewer, has lifted its profit guidance for the year, citing strong beer sales in China at the beginning of the year. The company now expects organic operating profit growth between minus 2% and plus 5%, up from a previous range of minus 5% to plus 5%. Revenue per liter sold globally increased by 12% as consumers returned to bars and restaurants after pandemic-related lockdowns, driving sales of more expensive beers. However, uncertainty remains over consumer reaction to higher prices and high inflation, particularly in Europe.

site_title: Singapore’s 60% property tax makes London, New York look cheap
summary: Singapore has increased its Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) to 60% for foreign buyers, the highest rate among major global markets. This move is expected to deter foreign investments, with London, New York, and Hong Kong potentially benefiting from the change. A $5 million property purchase in Singapore would incur $3.25 million in taxes, compared to 4% in New York and 15% in London. The move aims to curb property price growth driven by mainland Chinese buyers, with Hong Kong seen as a possible beneficiary.

images.alt_text: A view of private residential condominium properties at the Orchard district in Singapore April 27, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Sinochem exploring ways to salvage Syngenta IPO plan
summary: Chinese regulators are reviewing Sinochem's planned Shanghai listing of Syngenta Group, scrutinizing debt levels and potential use of proceeds. State-owned Sinochem is exploring ways to salvage the IPO plan, including a smaller initial public offering and delaying the listing to later this year or next year. The delay comes as China's new financial watchdog reviews the IPO and considers the impact on domestic liquidity. Sinochem is negotiating with Chinese authorities, and it's unclear whether the regulator will accept proposals to reduce the fundraising size or delay the listing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss agrochemicals maker Syngenta is seen at its headquarters in Basel, Switzerland July 22, 2016.    REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Property counters lead declines following ABSD hike; STI down 0.4%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,282.03, led by declines in property counters following the government's hike in the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD). Losers beat gainers 295 to 269, with property developers City Developments and UOL leading the decline. Meanwhile, Singtel gained 2% to close at S$2.54. Experts expect a negative reaction to share prices of developers with a material exposure to the Singapore residential sector, with private residential property price growth expected to range between minus 3% and 1%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Minister for National Development speaking to reporters on Thursday (Apr 27) at HDB MyLearningSpace after the Singapore government announced on Wednesday that it will be stepping up ABSD rates for residential properties, in fresh cooling measures.
Private home prices may correct, with demand from foreigners and local investors crimped by the latest hike in Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty.
Singapore's government estimates the new round of cooling measures to impact about 10 per cent of all residential property transactions.
For Singapore citizens, ABSD will be raised to 20 per cent from 17 per cent for the purchase of their second property, and to 30 per cent from 25 per cent for their third and subsequent properties.

site_title: US prosecutors say leak suspect may still have access to classified materials
summary: US prosecutors claim National Guardsman Jack Teixeira, accused of leaking classified documents online, may still have access to sensitive materials. Teixeira allegedly took steps to obstruct the investigation and accessed hundreds of classified documents unrelated to his job. Prosecutors argue that his release would pose a risk of further unauthorized disclosures, recommending his detention.

site_title: 💪 (Wo)Man with a plan
summary: A young adult in Singapore can start planning their finances by setting clear goals, finding an accountability buddy, and gradually increasing savings and investments. Starting with small steps, such as setting aside $50-$300 per month for savings or investing, can help alleviate pressure and make progress towards long-term financial goals. Experts also recommend creating a budget, building an emergency fund, and exploring high-interest-yielding accounts, while staying informed about financial literacy and regulations. Most importantly, time is on one's side, and making mistakes is a normal part of the learning process.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: On his podcast ‘Wine and Hip Hop’, Jermaine Stone aims to bridge cultures
summary: Jermaine Stone, a 38-year-old former rapper from the Bronx, is bridging cultural divides through his podcast "Wine and Hip Hop" and company Cru Luv Wine. Stone, who rose rapidly in the wine industry, aims to make wine accessible to historically ignored communities, using hip-hop as a vehicle. He works with major wine companies, including Constellation Brands, and has paired wine with familiar Black culture elements, such as cheeseburgers and chopped cheese sandwiches. Stone's goal is to eliminate pretension and make wine feel comfortable for all cultures, following the industry's failure to deliver on diversity promises after the George Floyd murder in 2020.

images.alt_text: After years of higher temperatures, kabinett riesling producers have a vintage that seems like a throwback to the time when growers battled to ripen grapes.

site_title: Toyota edges past 9.1 million vehicle output goal, warns chip shortage lingering
summary: Toyota Motor set a global annual output record with 9.61 million vehicles produced in the 12 months ended March, edging past its 9.1 million target. The company attributed the achievement to easing factory disruptions from chip supply woes and pandemic lockdowns. However, Toyota warned that the lingering global chip shortage remains a challenge, making it difficult to predict its impact. The company has sold 17,473 battery electric vehicles worldwide so far this year, a significant decrease from the 24,466 sold in 2022.

images.alt_text: “We need to increase our speed and efforts to firmly meet the customer expectations in the Chinese market,” Toyota CEO Koji Sato said.
“We must first do what we can and start by electrifying,” Koji Sato said in his first public appearance since becoming CEO and president on Apr 1.

site_title: Indonesia to ease palm oil domestic sales rules starting May
summary: Indonesia is easing its palm oil domestic sales rules, lowering the mandatory threshold from 450,000 tonnes to 300,000 tonnes per month starting May. This move aims to boost domestic demand for cooking oil ahead of the holy Islamic month of Ramadan. The government will also adjust the ratio of exports to domestic sales, tightening it to four times for most products but easing it for some cooking oil products. This decision comes after the government froze around 3 million tonnes of palm oil export permits, which can be used in stages over the next nine months.

site_title: Indonesia food regulator pressed to probe instant noodles after Taiwan, Malaysia recall
summary: Indonesia's consumer protection agency (BPKN) has urged the food regulator to test Indomie's "special chicken" instant noodles for carcinogenic ethylene oxide, following a recall in Taiwan and Malaysia. The product, produced by Indofood CBP, has been linked to elevated cancer risks due to its presence in Taiwan and Malaysia. BPKN has asked BPOM to verify the product's ingredients and recall it if it doesn't meet safety standards. Indonesia's health ministry has referred queries to BPOM, which has yet to comment.

site_title: ADB warns of rising food, energy prices if climate policy not well managed
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) warns that poorly managed climate change mitigation policies could lead to rising food and energy prices in Asia, with up to 22% of land converted to forests and bioenergy and a 34% increase in food prices. However, ADB suggests that this can be offset by redistribution measures, such as recycling carbon revenue as universal basic income. The bank also notes that aggressive decarbonization could create 1.5 million new jobs in the energy sector by 2050, mostly in manufacturing and installing renewable energy systems.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The environmental performance of Asia's governments and companies could help determine whether the world succeeds or fails on its shared climate goals, says a World Economic Forum report.
We now only have a headroom of 0.4 deg C, with global warming at 1.1 deg C above pre-industrial levels.
The prices of Redd+ credits have fallen 19 per cent since coming under intense scrutiny earlier this year, Trove noted.
Giant forest trees in Singapore's Bukit Timah and Central Catchment nature reserves.
Large oil storage tanks seen against the waters of the Singapore Strait.

site_title: European commercial real estate investment slumps to 11-year low in Q1 2023
summary: European commercial real estate investment plummeted to an 11-year low in Q1 2023, with a record-low 10.8 billion euros in transactions. The sector was impacted by higher interest rates and recession fears, causing investors to put acquisition plans on hold. Despite this, the UK remained the largest commercial real estate market, while Paris overtook London as the most active investment destination. A recent survey cited commercial real estate as a potential cause of the next financial crisis, further exacerbating concerns about financial stability.

site_title: Study finds ‘low or mitigable’ risks for testing ammonia bunkering in Singapore
summary: A study commissioned by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore found that the risks of testing ammonia as a marine fuel in Singapore's port waters and Jurong Island sites to be "low or mitigable". The country may need to meet a 50 million tonne demand for ammonia marine fuel by 2050, given its 20% global marine fuel demand from 2012 to 2021. This could pave the way for pilot studies on the feasibility of ammonia as a green marine fuel.

images.alt_text: Large oil storage tanks seen against the waters of the Singapore Strait.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to cut 800 jobs after strong first quarter
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 11th consecutive quarter of profit, with net profit reaching 1.158 billion euros. The bank will cut 800 jobs in a cost-saving drive, reversing a staff buildup from recent quarters. The move is part of a plan to cut costs by an additional 500 million euros over the next few years. Despite a slump in investment bank revenue, the bank's corporate and retail divisions saw revenue increases of 35% and 10%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Online and mobile shopping payments will be added later on, along with subscription instalments, and services such as buy now, pay later, over time.

A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. Deutsche Bank vowed to increase profit and revenue further this year, after snapping a long streak of market share gains in trading in the final quarter of Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing's turnaround plan. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
London remains the big beast in European finance for now, with headcount vastly outnumbering the rest of Europe.
The French bank is being accused of violating antitrust law by conspiring with rivals to rig Euribor, a key European interest rate benchmark.

site_title: Barclays beats profit expectations on US credit card boom
summary: Barclays reported a 16% profit jump to £2.6 billion in its first-quarter results, beating analyst forecasts, driven by strong performance at its US credit card business. The bank's consumer, cards, and payments division saw a 47% increase in income to £1.3 billion, but bad loans provision rose to £524 million due to higher credit card balances. Investment banking income declined, while fixed income, currencies, and commodities rose 9% to £1.8 billion. Barclays' shares rose 4% in early trading, outperforming the STOXX European banks index.

images.alt_text: The Barclays blunder is one of several high-profile incidents that have helped make ETNs notorious in financial circles.

site_title: ANA bounces back from Covid with first annual profit since 2020
summary: ANA Holdings reported its first annual profit since 2020, with operating income of 120 billion yen for the full year till March. The airline's recovery was driven by cost-cutting and government support, and it beat analysts' forecasts. ANA expects to reach an operating profit of 140 billion yen for the coming year. The airline plans to increase weekly flights between Japan and China by 50% by June as demand recovers. This marks a significant turnaround for ANA after suffering operating losses of 638 billion yen in the previous two years.

site_title: Hamptons luxury-home prices soar to records even as sales slow
summary: Luxury home prices in New York's Hamptons reached record highs in the first quarter, with median sales prices reaching US$8.54 million and average prices reaching a record US$16.1 million. Despite strong demand, sales fell 57% to 171, the second-lowest total since 2005, due to a shortage of listings and economic uncertainty. Inventory has shown signs of improvement, but agents and buyers remain frustrated by the limited selection.

images.alt_text: New York City rents in April were up 4.4 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: STMicro Q1 revenue soars 20% on carmaker demand
summary: STMicroelectronics' net revenue rose 20% to $4.25 billion in the first quarter, driven by strong demand from carmakers, particularly Tesla, and its industrial division. This growth insulated the company from the broader semiconductor industry downturn. The company forecasts $4.28 billion in net revenue for the second quarter and increased its 2023 net revenue target to $17.8 billion. Despite a disappointing forecast from Texas Instruments, the automotive division's 44% growth and industrial division's growth are expected to continue.

images.alt_text: STMicroelectronics is one of a several that are using AI to help design chips, which involves translating a complicated circuit architecture into a blueprint for fabricating billions of transistors on a small piece of silicon.

site_title: Unilever quarterly sales beat estimates as prices surge
summary: Unilever reported a 10.5% rise in underlying first-quarter sales to 14.8 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts of a 7.2% increase. The company attributed the growth to high price growth (10.7%) and an improved volume performance, despite a 0.2% dip in volumes. Unilever expects price growth to remain high during the first half of the year but soften through the year as inflation abates. This follows recent reports from rival companies P&G and Nestle, which also reported stronger-than-expected quarterly sales with price hikes offsetting lower volumes.

images.alt_text: Unilever reported on Thursday that full-year underlying sales in China fell 1 per cent as people stayed home.
Hindustan Unilever's total profit for its third quarter has climbed nearly 12 per cent to 25 billion rupees (S$406.8 million).

site_title: BP faces angry shareholders over climate plans
summary: BP faces a shareholder revolt over its decision to slow its energy transition, with activist investors threatening to block the re-election of the board head and calling for more ambitious climate objectives. Britain's biggest pension funds have also warned they will oppose the renewal of Helge Lund's mandate.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled at US$77.69 a barrel, losing US$3.08, or 3.8 per cent on Wednesday.

site_title: MPA partners standards organisations in digitalisation, decarbonisation efforts
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has partnered eight internationally recognized classification societies to develop new technologies and solutions for maritime digitalisation and decarbonisation. The collaboration, signed during the Accelerating Decarbonisation Conference, will focus on areas such as smart and autonomous shipping, cybersecurity, electrification, and zero and low-carbon fuel. The partnership aims to streamline recognition of Singapore Registry of Ships and develop industry and workforce capability to improve safety, security, and efficiency, while preparing the maritime workforce for digitalisation and decarbonisation.

images.alt_text: Ever Given setting sail to leave through the Suez Canal after a settlement in 2021. Decarbonisation of the shipping industry is expected to be a major topic at the Singapore Maritime Week.
The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will collaborate with Shell Eastern Trading to support the adoption of electric harbour craft.

An artist impression of an electric ferry conceptualised under the Keppel Offshore and Marine consortium. An existing 30-pax ferry belonging to Eng Hup Shipping, a harbour craft operator, would be retrofitted to become fully electric under the project.

site_title: TSMC aims to get newest chip technology into cars faster
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) plans to release new software to help automotive chip suppliers use its latest technologies two years sooner. This move aims to narrow the gap between car chips and consumer electronics. The software will enable designers to start work on their designs about two years earlier, allowing them to use the automotive version of TSMC's N3 chipmaking technology as soon as it becomes available in 2025. This change is expected to benefit companies such as NXP Semiconductor and STMicroelectronics, which rely on TSMC for chip production.

images.alt_text: TSMC expects its business to hit a bottom in the second quarter and pick up after that.

TSMC is building new facilities in Japan and the US in part to address national security concerns about the primary chip-making facilities concentrated in Taiwan amid rising geopolitical tensions and supply chain shocks.
Taiwan’s largest company is grappling with persistently weak electronics demand, as consumers and corporations tighten their budgets to deal with soaring inflation and a potential global recession.

site_title: China’s industrial profits continue to plunge as prices decline
summary: China's industrial profits plummeted 21.4% in the first three months of the year, despite a slight improvement in factory activity, due to persistent producer deflation and a decline in prices. This drop narrowed from a 22.9% decline in the first two months of 2023. Foreign firms saw a 24.9% fall in profits, while private firms dropped 23% and state-owned enterprises 16.9%. Despite this, China's economy is recovering faster than expected, with growth forecasts being upgraded, and the government aims for a 5% growth rate for the year.

images.alt_text: China has been talking about imposing a nationwide tax for more than a decade but progress has been slow, and an expansion of trials was put on hold during the housing slump last year.
A group of tourists visits a business street in Beijing on April 18, 2023. (Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP)

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust Q1 income up 19% to 3.3 billion rupees
summary: CapitaLand India Trust recorded a 19% increase in total property income to 3.3 billion rupees in Q1, driven by higher occupancy and additional income from industrial facilities. Net property income rose 16% to 2.6 billion rupees, but was partially offset by increased expenses. The trust's portfolio occupancy remained at 88% and its net gearing stood at 35%.

images.alt_text: Total property income for H2 grew 15 per cent to 6.2 billion Indian rupees (S$107.3 million), resulting in a 12 per cent rise for the full year to 11.9 billion rupees.
Amid a "general nervousness" in the market, Sanjeev Dasgupta, CEO of CapitaLand India Trust, is optimistic about India's growth trajectory.
CapitaLand India Trust's trustee-manager says the acquisition complements an existing portfolio in Bangalore.

site_title: Chinese spirit maker ZJLD slumps 17% in Hong Kong debut
summary: Chinese spirit maker ZJLD Group's shares plummeted 17% in their Hong Kong debut, following the largest new share sale in the city this year. The company raised $675.2 million, but its shares opened at HK$9 compared to the issue price of HK$10.82. ZJLD produces baijiu, China's national liquor and world's most consumed liquor. The disappointing debut came amid a weak start to the year for IPOs and global market volatility driven by rising interest rates and financial market volatility.

images.alt_text: ZJLD, which accounts for 69.5 per cent of the alcoholic beverage market in China and is backed by US private equity giant KKR, was offering about 490.7 million shares in a price range of HK$10.78 to HK$12.98 each.
Wine exports in 2022 were severely impacted by high inflation and global supply chain problems that led to a significant slowdown of sea freight, OIV said.

site_title: Geely’s EV brand Zeekr jumps on the ‘gigapress’ bandwagon
summary: Geely's EV brand Zeekr has adopted the "gigapress" die casting technique pioneered by Tesla to slash the cost of electric cars. The technique, which involves massive aluminum die casts to make large underbody sections, has helped Zeekr eliminate 800 welding points, reduce defects, and improve structural stiffness. The shift comes as Chinese rival Xpeng also adopts a new vehicle platform technology mimicking Tesla's design and manufacturing process. While concerns about repairability exist, Zeekr plans to change select parts of the larger die cast section in the event of a collision, reducing repair costs.

images.alt_text: A GWM executive unveils the B07 Fierce Dragon Max from the company’s export-focused Haval brand.
The Geely-owned brand said it also planned to offer the SUV-styled Zeekr X and its Zeekr 001 EV sedan in Western Europe without saying when that would be.

site_title: Rents, prices of Singapore industrial space rise for 10th straight quarter: JTC
summary: Industrial rents in Singapore rose 2.8% quarter-over-quarter and 8.8% year-over-year, while prices for industrial space gained 1.5% on the quarter and 6.9% on the year. This marks the 10th consecutive quarter of rising rents and prices, driven by new manufacturing activities and a deteriorating outlook for manufacturing and exports.

images.alt_text: Based on JTC's latest market report, on the quarter, rent of industrial spaces inched up by 2.1 per cent while prices rose 1.7 per cent.

site_title: Fugees rapper Pras Michel guilty in corruption scheme involving Jho Low
summary: Prakazrel "Pras" Michel, a member of the hip hop group The Fugees, was found guilty on 10 counts of conspiring with Malaysian financier Jho Low to orchestrate foreign lobbying campaigns influencing the US government. Michel was accused of funneling money from a billion-dollar Malaysia scam into US politics, including into former President Barack Obama's 2012 re-election campaign. He faces up to 20 years in prison and must forfeit any assets obtained through the scheme.

images.alt_text: Pras Michel told a federal jury in Washington that Low hired him to be a “celebrity surrogate” to get the photo.
DiCaprio met Low at a party and they bonded over several years and on trips.
Federal prosecutors ask US District Judge Margo Brodie in Brooklyn, New York, to order Ng to forfeit the sum as ill-gotten gains from the conspiracy to loot the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Insurer AIA’s new business value surges 28% on strong China, Hong Kong sales growth
summary: AIA Group reported a 28% surge in first-quarter new business value, driven by strong sales growth in China and Hong Kong. The Asia-focused insurer's new business value jumped to $1.046 billion, with China and Hong Kong accounting for half of global growth. AIA China and Hong Kong businesses logged double-digit growth, with mainland Chinese visitors contributing significantly to new sales. The company expects further growth support from China's economic recovery following pandemic restrictions.

images.alt_text: China and Hong Kong removed Covid curbs for mainland travellers in early February, and visitor numbers are expected to pick up rapidly.

site_title: US lifts import ban on Malaysia’s Smart Glove
summary: The US has lifted a 17-month import ban on Malaysian rubber glove maker Smart Glove, following the company's remediation measures to address exploitative labor practices. Smart Glove, which produces medical and food industry gloves, had committed to the well-being of its workers and opposed forced labor. The company has implemented new worker-centered policies, improved living conditions, and repaid recruitment fees borne by migrant workers. The ban was imposed in 2021 over allegations of forced labor, and the US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) stated that Smart Glove has taken necessary steps to address these concerns.

images.alt_text: Top Glove says the long-term industry prospects are “still promising”.

site_title: US House passes Republican debt ceiling bill with steep spending cuts
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill to raise the nation's $31.4 trillion debt ceiling, attaching sweeping spending cuts for the next decade. The 217-215 vote defied President Joe Biden's insistence on a debt limit increase with no strings attached. The bill, which includes deep spending cuts to programs like healthcare for the poor and law enforcement, is expected to increase Washington's borrowing authority by $1.5 trillion. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer described the bill as "dead on arrival," while House Speaker Kevin McCarthy hopes it will pressure Biden into negotiations on cutting spending.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (right) faces the prospect of a rematch with Donald Trump at next year's presidential election.
“Let’s finish this job. I know we can,” US President Joe Biden said.

site_title: China real estate register unlikely to expedite property tax
summary: China's nationwide real estate registration system, which has over 1.5 billion records, is expected to lay the groundwork for a property tax. However, the levy is unlikely to be introduced soon due to the fragile housing market. Analysts say market sentiment needs to normalize before rolling out the tax, with the earliest nationwide implementation expected in 2026. The system can help regulators control home markets, but a property tax is not the only purpose of the registration system, which can also aid in real-time updates and standardization of real estate certifications.

images.alt_text: Evergrande eventually needs to secure support from 75 per cent of creditors in value to implement its debt restructuring, one of China’s biggest ever, through so-called schemes of arrangement.
China's cabinet will issue subsidies to some firms that hire college graduates and unemployed youths till the end of this year.

site_title: EBay rises after second-quarter revenue outlook tops estimate
summary: EBay's shares rose 8% in after-market trading after the company exceeded analysts' revenue estimates for the second quarter, with $2.47-$2.54 billion in projected revenue. The company's efforts to boost sales, including selling luxury items and refurbished goods, appear to be paying off. First-quarter revenue also beat estimates, reversing sales declines, and the company announced cost-cutting measures earlier this year. Gross merchandise volume declined 5% to $18.4 billion, but active buyers remained at 133 million, down 7% from last year.

images.alt_text: More than 270 employees, whose roles include inspecting cards as well as packing and shipping them from an authentication center in Syracuse, New York, will be members of the Communications Workers of America.
eBay plans to lay off 500 employees globally, representing 4 per cent of its total workforce.

site_title: Australia’s Blackmores gets A$1.88 billion offer from Japan’s Kirin
summary: Japan's Kirin Holdings has made a $1.88 billion offer to acquire Australian natural health firm Blackmores, with a 23.7% premium to the stock's last close. The deal has been unanimously recommended by Blackmores' board, with top shareholder Marcus Blackmore agreeing to vote in favor. The offer includes a $95 cash per share payout, and Blackmores expects to declare a special dividend of $3.34 per share if the deal goes through.

images.alt_text: Amazon, which in March announced it was laying off 9,000 workers as part of its second retrenchment drive, started informing some of the affected employees on Wednesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CapitaLand India Trust, Starhill Global Reit, Digital Core Reit, Elite Commercial Reit
summary: Singaporean banks and real estate investment trusts (REITs) reported varying results in the first quarter of 2023. UOB's net profit rose 67% to S$1.5 billion, driven by higher net interest income and other non-interest income. CapitaLand India Trust's total property income increased 19% to S$53.9 million. Starhill Global Reit's net property income declined 1.3% to S$38 million, while Digital Core Reit's distributable income fell 10% to US$10.9 million. Elite Commercial Reit's distribution per unit declined 26.6% to 0.94 pence.

site_title: Gold inches up as dollar eases, US GDP data in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,991.14 per ounce, driven by a softer dollar and economic uncertainty. The US dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold less expensive for holders. Investors await US GDP data for signs of interest rate pauses. New orders for US-manufactured capital goods fell more than expected, suggesting business spending on equipment may have dragged on Q1 economic growth.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty, higher interest rates dim the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Hot stocks: Property plays slip into negative territory upon ABSD hike
summary: Singapore's government raised Additional Buyer Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for residential properties, impacting about 10% of transactions. Property counters, including City Developments, UOL Group, and Tuan Sing, fell in early trade, with some recovering later in the day. The ABSD increases apply to Singapore citizens for the purchase of their second property (20% from 17%) and third and subsequent properties (30% from 25%), while foreigners face a 60% increase. Real estate agencies also experienced a decline in early trade.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
About three-quarters of all units at The Sky Eden@Bedok were sold at an average price of $2,100 per square foot during its launch on Sept 7., 2022.
Senior Minister of State for Finance Chee Hong Tat speaking in Parliament on Friday. He was responding to questions about the 99-to-1 arrangement for the purchase of property in Singapore.
Maybe how ABSD is levied on family members who jointly own homes here can be tweaked..

Iras is looking into “various forms of property holding arrangements”, including “scenarios where buyers purchase properties under a contrived or artificial arrangement in order to reduce or avoid the additional buyer’s stamp duty (ABSD) or any other form of stamp duties they have to pay”.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 16.96 points to 3,276.95. The decline followed hikes in Additional Buyer Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for residential properties. Sembcorp Marine led the losses, while Singtel rose 0.8%. The broader market saw 79 losers outnumbering 45 gainers. Major US indices also fell, with the Dow Jones down 0.7% and the S&P 500 down 0.4%.

images.alt_text: UOB's total income for the fiscal quarter rose 49 per cent on year to S$3.5 billion, buoyed by higher net interest income and other non-interest income.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon offers tax breaks if Musk builds car factory
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol offered tax breaks and manpower support to Tesla CEO Elon Musk if he invests in building a new factory in the country. Musk expressed interest in South Korea as a potential location for a new Tesla factory, citing the country's favorable conditions. The two leaders also discussed cooperation between South Korean businesses and SpaceX for space exploration. Yoon aims to bolster South Korea's participation in the space race, with electric vehicles, rechargeable batteries, and spacecraft seen as key growth drivers of the economy.

site_title: Biden, Yoon warn North Korea of nuclear response to any attack
summary: US President Joe Biden and South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol warned North Korea that a nuclear attack would result in the "end" of the regime and a devastating response. The two leaders strengthened the US security shield for South Korea, bolstering the US nuclear umbrella over the country. They agreed to share information and consult in the event of a North Korean attack, with the US retaining control of nuclear weapons. The US has also pledged not to station nuclear weapons in South Korea, but will deploy strategic assets, including a nuclear ballistic submarine, to the country.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk told President Yoon Suk Yeol that South Korea remains among the top candidates to host a new Tesla factory and he anticipates a chance to visit.
