An NBC News poll released last weekend found that 70 per cent of Americans, including 51 per cent of Democrats, believe Joe Biden should not run in 2024.
US President Joe Biden (right) faces the prospect of a rematch with Donald Trump at next year's presidential election.

site_title: ABSD hikes a ‘pre-emptive measure’ to crimp renewed investment demand, prioritise Singaporeans: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates have been increased to curb investment demand in the residential property market. Starting from April 27, the rates will be higher for foreign buyers, with a 60% rate for all residential properties and 65% for properties bought by entities or in trust. The government aims to prioritize Singaporeans buying homes for owner occupation, as investment demand has risen after falling back in the last few years, adding stress to the local housing market.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
For Singapore citizens, ABSD will be raised to 20 per cent from 17 per cent for the purchase of their second property, and to 30 per cent from 25 per cent for their third and subsequent properties.

site_title: Microsoft’s US$69 billion deal tripped up by niche gaming market
summary: UK regulators blocked Microsoft's $69 billion purchase of Activision Blizzard due to concerns it would harm competition in cloud gaming, a growing segment of the industry. The UK Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) ruled that Microsoft's dominance in cloud gaming would be strengthened by acquiring Activision's titles like Call of Duty, threatening growth in the sector. The companies plan to appeal, and the merger agreement expires on July 18, with a breakup fee of $3 billion.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is poised to scale to a market capitalisation of US$2.2 trillion, helping it reclaim the title of the world’s second most valuable public company.
Musk responded to the announcement by accusing Microsoft of using Twitter data “illegally” and threatening a lawsuit.

site_title: Singapore firms must transform for productivity amid economic uncertainty: SNEF
summary: Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) president Robert Yap emphasizes the need for firms to transform for productivity despite economic uncertainty. Productivity declined in 2022, but SNEF is working with the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) to help employers transform jobs through the Productivity Solutions Grant-Job Redesign and Company Training Committee Grant. Yap calls on employers to proactively train workers and workers to take charge of their own development, with a focus on lifelong learning and better career pathways for lower-wage workers.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

The Empower Pillar in the Forward Singapore exercise is an opportunity to work with the public on renewing the social compact “to deliver opportunities and assurance to Singaporean workers at every stage of life”, says Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.
The NTUC supports every worker, says labour leaders, highlighting measures to help groups such as senior workers and those with caregiving responsibilities.

site_title: China Evergrande debt restructuring incentive to test creditor appetite
summary: China Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, is testing creditor appetite with its offshore debt restructuring proposal. The company needs 75% support from creditors to implement the restructuring, which includes swapping debt for new notes with maturities of 10-12 years or equity-linked instruments. Investors are offered a 0.25% consent fee for early support, but some creditors have expressed dissatisfaction with the proposal's complex terms. The proposal's outcome will be decided by court later in the third quarter, with a voting date to be set.

images.alt_text: Under the sanctions, both Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges were critical of Hengda Real Estate and China Evergrande Group executive director Qian Cheng for not filing the report by Apr 30, 2022.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the electric vehicle (EV) factory of China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group in Tianjin, China October 20, 2021. Picture taken October 20, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun/File Photo

site_title: Stellantis offering voluntary buyouts to 33,500 US employees
summary: Stellantis is offering voluntary buyouts to 33,500 US employees, covering 31,000 hourly workers and 2,500 salaried workers, as part of its efforts to streamline operations and become more efficient. The move comes amid increased competition in the automotive industry and rising costs of electric vehicle production. The United Auto Workers union criticized the effort, calling it "disgusting" and a "slap in the face" to employees and their communities.

images.alt_text: Stellantis’ chief executive officer Carlos Tavares warned in February more job cuts could be in the offing as the cost of electrification eats into the company’s profit margins.
Stellantis will boost production at its Melfi plant in southern Italy to focus on EVs and plug-in hybrid vehicles.

site_title: Tyson Foods to eliminate 10% of corporate jobs, 15% of senior leaders
summary: Tyson Foods will eliminate about 10% of corporate jobs and 15% of senior leadership roles, with discussions with affected employees set to take place this week. The layoffs are part of the company's cost-cutting efforts amid declining profit and struggles in its iconic chicken business. The move follows recent changes in executive leadership and comes as the company faces declining operating margins and increased competition in the meatpacking industry.

images.alt_text: Amazon, which in March announced it was laying off 9,000 workers as part of its second retrenchment drive, started informing some of the affected employees on Wednesday.

site_title: First Republic faces potential curb on borrowing from Federal Reserve
summary: US bank regulators are considering downgrading their assessment of First Republic Bank, which could limit its access to Federal Reserve lending facilities. The FDIC has been giving the bank time to reach a private deal to shore up its finances, but as weeks pass without a transaction, officials are increasingly weighing a downgrade. The move could restrict the bank's use of the Fed's discount window and emergency facility. First Republic has been struggling to find a rescuer, and any steps to raise capital or sell assets could be painful for current shareholders.

images.alt_text: US government officials were currently unwilling to intervene in the First Republic rescue process, CNBC reported, citing sources.
Fed policymakers have signalled they are on track to raise rates by a quarter point at the May meeting and signal a potential pause in June.

site_title: Samsung flags H2 recovery after record chip loss in Q1
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a record loss of 4.58 trillion won in its semiconductor business for the January-March quarter, driven by weak demand for tech devices due to an economic slowdown and rising inflation. The company expects a gradual market recovery and a rebound in global demand in the second half of the year, with chip prices expected to recover. Despite the loss, Samsung's mobile business reported a profit increase, and the company plans to invest in memory semiconductors to secure mid- to long-term competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The company, which supplies Tesla, General Motors and others, reported an operating profit of 633 billion won for the January-March period, versus 259 billion won a year earlier.
Hynix’s losses show the slump that has gripped the US$160 billion global memory industry.
GM is diversifying its battery vendors to better secure capacity of the crucial components to support its electrification goals, as the Detroit-based company attempts to catch up with Tesla.
South Korea is home to three of the world’s five biggest electric vehicle (EV) battery makers - LG Energy Solution (LGES), Samsung SDI and SK On.

site_title: Sexist views, harassment among obstacles to diversity among seafarers
summary: Women seafarers face numerous challenges in the maritime industry, including sexist perceptions, harassment, and systemic hurdles. According to a report by the Global Maritime Forum, women account for less than 2% of the maritime workforce and often experience difficulties achieving professional success due to perceived incompetence. Harassment, particularly from superior officers, is a widespread issue, with 66% of women seafarers reporting experiences. To address these challenges, the All Aboard Alliance plans to implement solutions through a pilot phase and roll out changes across the industry by 2025.

images.alt_text: Not one single Singapore company in WTW's study had diversity & inclusion metrics in its incentive plans; should we be worried? PHOTO:

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts 26.6% lower Q1 DPU
summary: Elite Commercial Reit posted a 26.6% lower distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.94 pence for Q1 FY2023 due to higher borrowing costs, lower revenue from vacancies, and an enlarged equity base. Revenue slipped 0.4% year-over-year to £9.2 million. The Reit's gearing ratio increased to 46.6% and its portfolio occupancy fell to 97.9% from 100% in 2022. Despite this, the manager expects rent escalation reviews to mitigate increased borrowing costs and offset reduced rent contribution from vacant assets.

images.alt_text: Elite Commercial Reit says that there were a total of 136 assets with a rent review on Apr 1, 2023.
Great Western House, Birkenhead, one of the 155 properties in Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio whose valuation stands at £466.2 million as at end-2022, down 9.9 per cent year on year.
The Reit's loan extension adjusts aggregate borrowing to approximately 4.2 per cent, with an improved weighted average debt maturity of 2.2 years and 60 per cent of interest rate exposure fixed.
Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands
Distributable income rose 9.7 per cent to £12.2 million, driven mainly by the full half-year rental contribution from the Reit’s maiden acquisition and tax savings.
ELITE Commercial Reit’s distribution per unit (DPU) rose by 4.9 per cent to 1.28 pence for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, from 1.22 pence a year ago.

site_title: Biden shrugs off age concerns, saying ‘I feel good’
summary: US President Joe Biden addressed concerns about his age, stating he "feels good" despite being 86 if re-elected in 2024. A recent NBC News poll found 70% of Americans, including 51% of Democrats, believe he should not run again. Biden rarely discusses his age, but his Republican opponent is expected to use this as a campaign point.

images.alt_text: US Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy after the House passed the debt limit bill at the Capitol in Washington on April 26, 2023.
US President Joe Biden (right) faces the prospect of a rematch with Donald Trump at next year's presidential election.

(COMBO) This combination of file pictures created on October 30, 2020, shows US President Donald Trump speaks during a campaign rally at Manchester-Boston Regional Airport in Londonderry, New Hampshire on October 25, 2020 and Democratic Presidential candidate and former Vice President Joe Biden speaking at a voter mobilization event in Cincinnati, Ohio, on October 12, 2020. - Biden announced April 25, 2023, his bid "to finish the job" with re-election in 2024, plunging at the record age of 80 into a ferocious campaign that could set up a rematch against former President Donald Trump. (Photo by MANDEL NGAN and JIM WATSON / AFP)

site_title: US: Stocks close mostly down on Wednesday on recession worries
summary: US stocks closed mostly down on Wednesday, despite solid corporate earnings, due to recession worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7% to 33,301.87, while the S&P 500 declined 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.5%. First Republic Bank suffered a 30% decline, and shares of Activision Blizzard plummeted 11.5% after a proposed Microsoft takeover was blocked on antitrust grounds. Recession concerns, particularly in the banking industry, are deepening, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 65.51 points, or 0.20 per cent, at the open to 33,596.34.

site_title: Barbie maker Mattel swings to loss as retailers cut orders, costs rise
summary: Mattel, the maker of Barbie, reported a larger-than-expected loss for the first quarter due to higher costs and retailers cutting back on orders. Worldwide gross billings for Barbie fell 41% as consumers and retailers grappled with supply chain issues and increased labor and material costs. Despite this, gross margins fell 640 basis points to 40% due to excess stock forcing retailers to cut orders and maintain tight inventory levels.

images.alt_text: The toy was brought to market through work with the National Down Syndrome Society (NDSS), to ensure it accurately represents someone with the condition, the Mattel said.
Guests can explore rooms in the 20,000 square-foot attraction dedicated to Barbie’s careers and hobbies as well as an assortment of doll selections that celebrate diversity.

site_title: Hyundai Motor to exit Russia, selling its plants: media report
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to exit Russia, selling its manufacturing plants to a Kazakh company, following negotiations in the final stage. The automaker has been waiting for Russian government approval. Hyundai Motor suspended operations in Russia last year due to sanctions and equipment shortages. The company builds about 200,000 vehicles per year in Russia, but Chinese brands are now replacing them in the war-torn economy. Hyundai and sister Kia are among the world's top 10 automakers by sales, but their Russian operations will cease.

site_title: New York City still has the priciest rents, but Jersey City is closing in
summary: Jersey City, New Jersey, leads the US in apartment-rent growth, with a 28% increase from a year earlier, surpassing only its neighbor New York City. The median monthly rent for a one-bedroom unit in Jersey City was $3,000, tied with San Francisco. In contrast, New York City's median rent was $3,570, a 4.4% increase from a year earlier. The trend reflects the growing affordability and convenience of Jersey City, making it attractive to renters priced out of New York City's outer boroughs and urban enclaves.

images.alt_text: Miami is attracting plenty of wealthy investors, including Citadel’s Ken Griffin.

site_title: As Marina Bay Sands enters its teens, an elevation towards new era of luxury hospitality
summary: Marina Bay Sands, a Singapore integrated resort, is undergoing a major transformation to elevate its luxury hospitality offerings. A US$1 billion renovation program has completed over 850 rooms in Towers 1 and 2, with 422 new suites. The program also includes upgrades to the hotel lobby, SkyPark, casino, restaurants, and wellness offerings. Chief Operating Officer Paul Town expects the Singapore market to remain buoyant, driven by China's growing demand for safe destinations. The resort is hiring 1,000 new staff to meet growing demand, and Town remains optimistic about the outlook for Singapore's tourism and hospitality industry despite global economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mass gaming revenue reaches a record US$549 million in Q1, parent company Las Vegas Sands says.
Construction deadline for MBS’ S$4.5 billion extension pushed back again to April 2024

site_title: Consumer players' cost inflation is slowing, but shoppers may wait for lower prices
summary: The world's top consumer-goods companies, such as Nestle, P&G, and Reckitt Benckiser, continued to raise prices sharply in the first quarter despite easing input costs. While cost inflation is expected to be significantly lower this year, with Reckitt predicting a 5-9% increase, it may take time for shoppers to see lower price tags. Companies have been buying ingredients in advance, leading to a delay in passing on lower costs to customers.

images.alt_text: The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index fell to 101.3 – the lowest since July 2022 – from a revised 104.0 in March.

site_title: Oil drops nearly 4% as recession fears outweigh US inventory draw
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 4% on Wednesday, with Brent crude settling at $77.69 a barrel, losing $3.08, or 3.8%, amid growing recession fears for the US economy. Despite a report showing US crude inventories fell more than expected, prices declined, as fears of a global economic downturn outweighed the inventory data. US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $74.30 a barrel, shedding $2.77, or 3.6%.

images.alt_text: Brent crude fell by US$1.96, or 2.4 per cent, to settle at US$80.77 a barrel on Tuesday, its lowest close since March 31, before Opec announced plans to cut production.

site_title: Amazon to shut down Halo division, lays off some staff
summary: Amazon is shutting down its Halo division, which sells health and sleep trackers, as part of its company-wide layoffs. The company informed some affected employees in the US and Canada on Wednesday, with services to stop on July 31 and full refunds for Halo device purchases made in the past 12 months. This move follows Amazon's earlier layoffs of 9,000 workers in March.

site_title: Banking on technology firms to win in South-east Asia
summary: Tech firms seeking to grow in South-east Asia must re-evaluate their financing needs as the end of cheap money hits the region. Partnering with banks that offer deep market knowledge and local business networks can provide customized innovative solutions. Tech firms must leverage data analytics to cater to the needs of young, emerging-affluent, and tech-savvy consumers, and understand local nuances to succeed. Standard Chartered suggests that banks can help tech firms with challenges such as low banking penetration, limited talent pool, and differing regulatory regimes.

images.alt_text: Mak Joon Nien, CEO, Standard Chartered Malaysia
Simon Cooper, CEO of corporate, commercial & institutional banking at Standard Chartered, sees opportunities for the bank to leverage interest in Asean and become a “connector” for investors.

site_title: UOB posts 67% rise in Q1 profit to S$1.5 billion
summary: UOB reported a net profit of S$1.5 billion for Q1 2023, a 67% increase from the same period last year, driven by growth across its wholesale, global markets, and retail businesses. Excluding one-off expenses, the bank's net profit was a record S$1.6 billion, up 74% year-over-year. CEO Wee Ee Cheong attributed the strong results to UOB's diversified franchise.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Michelle Zhu
Analysts expect limited upside for NIM growth ahead, while rising recession risks may result in weaker loan growth and rising asset quality risks.
At UOB's annual general meeting, chief risk officer Chan Kok Seong said that ultimately, it is the level of trust and confidence in the bank that will ensure its long-term survival.

Although net underwriting profit fell 38 per cent to S$3.5 million, this was more than offset by a rise in non-underwriting income to S$2.2 million, which turned profitable after the group recorded a loss of S$0.12 million in the corresponding period last year.
UOB will build a 300,000 square feet centre in Punggol Digital District, to house around 3,000 talents in technology, innovation and digital roles to further the bank’s digital ambitions.

site_title: Consider paying CEOs less and taxing them more
summary: Singapore's CEOs are among the highest-paid globally, with some earning up to S$20.5 million annually. The median monthly household income in Singapore is S$10,099, making S$10 million a CEOs' salary equivalent to 83 times the annualised median household income. Experts suggest that companies should consider paying CEOs less and taxing them more, as their lavish pay may not be justified. Higher taxes could also incentivize top talent to pursue entrepreneurial ambitions over corporate careers.

From left to right: Tony Tan, CEO of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial T
Exxon, the largest US oil company on Thursday (Apr 13) disclosed chief executive Darren Woods was paid US$35.9 million last year.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as healthcare stocks hit by drug reforms
summary: European shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, their second consecutive decline, due to a 2.5% drop in healthcare stocks. The decline is attributed to Brussels' draft of a proposed overhaul of the EU's pharmaceuticals industry laws, aiming to ensure equal access to innovative treatments and generic drugs across countries. This is the worst performance of healthcare stocks since late January 2022.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7 per cent to 33,301.87 on Wednesday.

site_title: Amazon starts round of layoffs in AWS cloud services division
summary: Amazon has started laying off 9,000 employees in its AWS cloud services division, part of a broader 27,000 corporate position cuts. The move is aimed at reducing costs amid slowing sales growth in AWS, the company's most profitable division. AWS chief Adam Selipsky said the layoffs are necessary to focus on top priorities and will impact teams across the organization. The cuts follow previous rounds of layoffs earlier this year, and Amazon is now down to 1.54 million employees worldwide.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is poised to scale to a market capitalisation of US$2.2 trillion, helping it reclaim the title of the world’s second most valuable public company.

The proposed bill's threshold will apply to firms with a global turnover above £25 billion or a UK turnover above £1 billion, potentially putting giants such as Meta, Google, Amazon, Apple and Microsoft in the firing line.

site_title: Tesla broke US labour law by silencing workers, official rules
summary: A US labour board judge ruled that Tesla supervisors in a Florida service centre violated US labour law by silencing workers who discussed pay and working conditions. The judge ordered Tesla to cease and desist from violating workers' rights and post notice of the violations. The ruling came after an employee was fired after complaining about new hires being paid more. Tesla faces multiple lawsuits alleging widespread discrimination, including a recent loss before the labour board. The company has denied wrongdoing in these cases.

images.alt_text: The EV maker's stock price on Wednesday (Apr 26) fell as much as 3.5 per cent to US$155.03 in New York and is on pace to close at the lowest level since Jan 25.
At US$46,990, the base Model Y now costs US$759 less than the average amount paid for a car or truck in the US.

site_title: US senator urges AI company CEOs to take steps to address risks
summary: US Senator Mark Warner urged CEOs of AI companies to prioritize security measures, combat bias, and responsibly roll out new technologies. He sent letters to CEOs of major AI companies, citing the need for regulation to address potential risks posed by AI technology. Warner's concerns follow Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer's efforts to establish AI rules and address national security and education concerns. This comes as AI programs like ChatGPT, created by OpenAI, have gained widespread attention and attracted significant investment from major tech companies.

site_title: A string of shophouse deals in Stanley, Telok Ayer and Amoy streets
summary: Singapore-based real estate investment company 8M Real Estate has acquired 28 Stanley Street for S$29 million, boosting its shophouse portfolio in the central business district (CBD). The freehold property, diagonally opposite Solitaire on Cecil, is expected to receive a boost from the nearby development. Nearby, SilkRoad Property Partners is selling two adjoining shophouses at Amoy Street for S$75 million, while NC Properties acquired 94 Amoy Street for S$21.8 million. Market watchers note that prices of conservation shophouses in Districts 1 and 2 have been higher this year, driven by foreign buyers seeking high-end dining options.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The six-storey shophouse at 52 Boat Quay is the tallest conservation shophouse along the Singapore River.
Sales in Q1 2023 were marginally higher than the 23 shophouses sold in the second quarter of 2020, when pandemic restrictions wiped out activity.
The transaction, brokered by Savills Singapore, marks a new record per square foot price for strata office space in the Central Business District.
Fujian buyers cast wider net in Singapore property market

site_title: PropertyBT: BTO - choosing between mature and non-mature estates (Ep 18)
summary: Leslie Yee discusses the pros and cons of choosing a mature or non-mature estate for HDB BTO flats with Wong Siew Ying, head of research and content at Propnex Realty. Mature estates offer prime locations, but may have higher prices and limited resale options. Non-mature estates offer lower prices and more resale options, but may be farther from amenities. The pair weigh the risks and benefits of each option, noting that buyers should consider their individual circumstances and priorities.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of HDB flats and condominiums in Bishan on Feb 16, 2023.

For first-timers and especially young households, BTO flats may make the most financial sense. 
First-timers should choose homes they can best afford, and BTO flats are considered the most affordable housing in today’s market.
Successful applicants for Jurong West Crystal and Brickland Weave be able to move into their new homes earlier, as these projects have shorter waiting times.

site_title: Fake volunteers hope to disrupt Paris Olympics
summary: A group called Saccage 2024 plans to recruit fake volunteers for the 2024 Paris Olympics to disrupt the event, citing concerns about the Games' environmental impact and favoritism towards big businesses and elites. The fake volunteers, who would be paid, aim to withdraw at the last minute or cause disruptions to protest the event's effects on locals. The move reflects widespread discontent in France, following recent protests against a pension law increase and the Olympics themselves.

images.alt_text: Leaders from nine countries including Germany, France and Britain are set to gather in Ostend, Belgium on Monday, to pledge to more than quadruple offshore wind capacity in the North Sea by 2030.

site_title: Meta surges as sales, forecast beat estimates on ad recovery
summary: Meta's first-quarter revenue exceeded analyst estimates, rising to $28.6 billion, its first growth in three quarters. The company reported a return to growth, beating the $27.7 billion average analyst projection. Meta's shares surged 12% in after-market trading and predicted revenue of up to $32 billion for the current quarter, surpassing the $29.5 billion average estimate. This marks a significant recovery in digital advertising, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg calling it the "year of efficiency" as the company cuts costs to move faster.

images.alt_text: Meta already cut about 13 per cent of its workforce, or about 11,000 jobs, in November.
Meta executives are discussing a ban on political ads in Europe due to concerns that Facebook and Instagram will be unable to comply with the new EU regulations targeting online campaigns.

site_title: Singapore hikes residential property ABSD, doubles foreigner rate to 60%
summary: The Singapore government has increased the Additional Buyer Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for residential properties, effective April 27, 2023. For Singapore citizens, the rate will be raised to 20% for their second property and 30% for their third and subsequent properties. For permanent residents, the rate will be raised to 30% for their second property and 35% for their third and subsequent properties. Foreigners will face a doubled ABSD rate of 60%. The measures aim to curb investment demand and moderate the housing market.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.
About three-quarters of all units at The Sky Eden@Bedok were sold at an average price of $2,100 per square foot during its launch on Sept 7., 2022.

site_title: Bosch buys US semiconductor foundry to expand EV chip output
summary: Bosch has agreed to buy US semiconductor foundry TSI Semiconductors for an undisclosed price, investing $1.5 billion to expand production of silicon carbide chips for electric vehicles. The facility in Roseville, California will become the third pillar of Bosch's in-house semiconductor production, alongside two sites in Germany. The investment aims to start producing silicon carbide chips by 2026, with demand growing 30% annually due to increasing demand from electric vehicle manufacturers.

site_title: Trading up in the world of oil
summary: NW Corporation, a Singapore-based oil trading company, has expanded its operations geographically and in scope, becoming a significant player in the industry. Founded by co-founders Borg Ang and Jason Tan in 2016, the company provides end-to-end commodities trading, including oil, metals, and minerals. Despite facing setbacks, including failed trades and the COVID-19 pandemic, NW Corporation has remained profitable and has grown its international presence, setting up subsidiaries in Malaysia and China. The company prioritizes risk management through digital technology and has developed capabilities in dynamic planning and ESG concerns.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz exits Russian market with buyback option
summary: Mercedes-Benz has exited the Russian market by selling shares in its Russian subsidiaries to local investor Avtodom, with a buyback option allowing the company to potentially return in the future. The deal includes a plant in the Moscow region with a capacity of 20,000 cars per year. Avtodom will soon disclose plans for resuming production. The repurchase option gives Mercedes-Benz six years to exercise the option at market price.

site_title: Using generative AI to transform customer experiences
summary: Generative AI is transforming customer experiences and workforce productivity, offering unprecedented power, flexibility, and personalization. By automating tasks such as generating knowledge articles, personalized agent chat replies, and sales tasks, organizations can enhance customer satisfaction and drive business growth. However, the technology also raises concerns about trust, accuracy, and transparency, emphasizing the need for responsible development and implementation. To harness the benefits of generative AI, businesses must educate themselves and equip users with a better understanding of its strengths and weaknesses, ensuring that the technology is used safely and transparently.

images.alt_text: Lawyers are to provide clients with effective legal representation, which often means they have to grapple with novel issues by coming up with arguments previously not advanced.

ChatGPT has already provoked a storm of controversy over its apparent liberal bias – the bot initially refused to write a poem praising Donald Trump but happily churned out couplets for his successor as US President Joe Biden.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on upbeat Microsoft, Boeing results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by strong results from Microsoft and a positive cash-flow forecast from Boeing. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 65.51 points, or 0.20%, to 33,596.34, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. Rising interest rates and their impact on the US economy remain a concern, but the positive earnings reports helped to offset these worries.

site_title: Microsoft’s earnings surge to add record US$151 billion in value
summary: Microsoft's quarterly earnings surged, adding a record $151 billion in market value, bringing its market capitalization to $2.2 trillion. The company's Azure cloud-computing business saw 31% revenue growth, beating analyst projections. Microsoft is poised to reclaim its title as the world's second most valuable public company, surpassing Saudi Aramco's $2.1 trillion value. The company's stock rose 8% on the day, with analysts upgrading their recommendations, citing durable growth opportunities and a premium valuation.

images.alt_text: “The CMA’s decision rejects a pragmatic path to address competition concerns and discourages technology innovation and investment in the UK.” Brad Smith, vice-chair and president of Microsoft, said.

site_title: ASML CEO says China access ‘essential’ as country develops semiconductor industry
summary: ASML CEO Peter Wennink stated that market access to China is "essential" for the company as the country develops its semiconductor industry. China's restrictions on foreign tech products have led to a surge in demand for older ASML tools, which are not subject to US-led restrictions. Wennink expressed confidence that the global chip market will double to $1.0 trillion-$1.2 trillion by the end of the decade, despite concerns about new manufacturing capacity and potential shortages.

site_title: US goods trade deficit narrows sharply in March; retail inventories rise
summary: The US goods trade deficit narrowed 8.1% in March to $84.6 billion, driven by a $4.9 billion increase in exports to $172.7 billion, boosted by industrial supplies like motor vehicles. Imports declined $2.5 billion to $257.3 billion, pulled down by decreases in industrial supplies and capital goods. Retail inventories rose 0.7% in March, rebounding from a 0.3% gain in the prior month. The narrowed trade deficit suggests a positive economic growth trend in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty, higher interest rates dim the non-yielding asset’s appeal.
Low-interest rates can boost demand for homes, which drives up prices, building activity and construction jobs.

site_title: Possible Biden-Trump rematch in a vastly different political and economic landscape
summary: US President Joe Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024, setting up a potential rematch with Republican frontrunner Donald Trump. The upcoming election will take place in a vastly different political, economic, and social landscape, with the US economy still grappling with a 40-year high in inflation. Biden will face scrutiny over his performance in office, including his handling of the pandemic and his policies, while also navigating the challenges of being the oldest president in US history.

images.alt_text: “Let’s finish this job. I know we can,” US President Joe Biden said.

The  National Semiconductor Technology Center will be an independent nonprofit so that it’s trusted by companies in the industry and viewed as neutral and science driven, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said.
In June, Biden waived tariffs on solar panels from Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam in an effort to create a “bridge” while US manufacturing ramped up.
The proposal, which could be unveiled in coming days, is the EPA’s second attempt to clamp down on carbon dioxide released from power-plant smokestacks.

site_title: Eurozone set to dodge recession, says ECB VP
summary: Eurozone economy is set to avoid a six-month recession, according to European Central Bank (ECB) vice-president Luis de Guindos. Leading indicators suggest growth in the first quarter of the year is possible, reversing a baseline of a technical recession in December. The ECB is parsing data to determine interest rate hikes, with a first estimate of first-quarter economic growth due Friday. Strong labor market and easing energy crisis after Russia's war in Ukraine are contributing factors.

images.alt_text: The ECB has added at least 50 basis points in six successive meetings but some policymakers remain cautious as past hikes are yet to fully filter into the economy.

site_title: First Republic strain poses question for Fed as it weighs rate hike
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers are on track to raise interest rates by a quarter point at the May meeting, signaling a potential pause in June, amid concerns over First Republic Bank's struggles. The bank's share price has plummeted to a record low, raising questions about the Fed's decision. Despite this, investors still expect a hike, with over three-quarters odds of a rate increase. Fed officials weigh the potential impact of tightening lending standards on spending and growth, potentially lessening the need for additional rate hikes.

images.alt_text: First Republic had total assets of US$233 billion as of Mar 31, including US$173 billion of loans and US$35 billion of investment securities, according to its first-quarter earnings report.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet shares rise on revenue beat as ad sales recover
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported first-quarter results that exceeded analyst estimates, with sales excluding partner payouts reaching $58.07 billion, topping projections. The company's search advertising business showed resilience, and its cloud unit reported profit for the first time. Alphabet's shares rose 5.9% after the announcement, with the stock gaining 17.7% this year. The company authorized share buybacks of up to $70 billion and attributed its success to a cost-cutting drive and strong search performance.

images.alt_text: French startup Emobot has created a bot that uses AI to track the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns.

site_title: China approves spy law as Xi focuses on national security
summary: China approved a revised anti-espionage law on April 26, 2023, as President Xi Jinping seeks to bolster national security amid tensions with the US. The law will take effect on July 1 and aims to strengthen counterintelligence measures. Xi has emphasized security concerns, including friction over Taiwan, Xinjiang, and China's tech ambitions, during his decade in power. The revised law is part of Xi's efforts to bolster national security and address growing concerns with the US.

site_title: First Republic shares hit record low after report says government unwilling to intervene
summary: First Republic Bank's shares hit a record low after a report stated the US government is unwilling to intervene in the rescue process, adding to concerns about the lender's plans to turn around its business. The bank's shares fell 25% to $6.05, with analysts citing roadblocks that complicate rescue efforts, including selling assets and emerging from a crisis sparked by a $100 billion deposit outflow. Analysts predict the bank's assets will be sold at a discount, with some brokerages cutting price targets on the shares.

images.alt_text: Fed policymakers have signalled they are on track to raise rates by a quarter point at the May meeting and signal a potential pause in June.
First Republic had total assets of US$233 billion as of Mar 31, including US$173 billion of loans and US$35 billion of investment securities, according to its first-quarter earnings report.

site_title: Tesla’s plunge drags valuation below US$500 billion on margin fear
summary: Tesla's stock price plummeted 3.5% to $155.03, marking its lowest level since January 25, as investors fear the company's price-cutting plan will erode profits. The stock has lost over $70 billion in market value over the past five trading sessions. Tesla's first-quarter results showed a significant decline in profit margins, prompting analysts to reduce price targets and warn of risks to the company's premium valuation. The stock's valuation has fallen below $500 billion, a milestone not reached since 2007, as the electric vehicle maker faces increasing competition from Exxon Mobil and LVMH.

images.alt_text: At US$46,990, the base Model Y now costs US$759 less than the average amount paid for a car or truck in the US.

site_title: China Q1 steel demand better than expected, says industry group
summary: China's first-quarter steel demand exceeded expectations, growing 1.9% from a year earlier to 243.42 million tonnes, according to the China Iron and Steel Association. This growth was attributed to the lifting of Covid curbs, which had hampered construction activity. However, steel output rose 6.1% to 261.56 million tonnes, driving down prices. Industry officials attributed the main problem to supply-side issues, with traders and end-users taking a cautious stance in a weakening market. The government-backed association urged domestic steelmakers to cut production to ensure stable cash flow.

images.alt_text: Some mills in top steel producer China now hurting from lacklustre steel demand and a slump in prices “have started to actively limit production”, Sinosteel Futures analysts said in a note.

site_title: BYD lowers starting price for Seagull electric hatchback
summary: BYD has lowered the starting price of its Seagull electric hatchback to 73,800 yuan (S$14,231), a 6.3% reduction from its initial price of 78,800 yuan. The vehicle, which offers a range of 305 km, was initially advertised at 78,800 yuan and 83,800 yuan at the Shanghai auto show. The reduced price makes the Seagull hatchback more competitive in the market, with prices starting from half that of the cheapest new energy vehicles available elsewhere.

site_title: Smaller EV prices to come down as EV sales climb, IEA says
summary: Electric vehicle sales globally are expected to surge 35% this year to 14 million, comprising 18% of the passenger car market. By the mid-2020s, prices of smaller EV models will drop to rival those of combustion engine cars in North America and Europe. The US Inflation Reduction Act is cited as a factor in the increased forecast. China accounts for half of the world's EVs, with 60% of EV sales last year taking place there. Governments are investing in EV expansion to reduce oil dependency and mitigate environmental concerns.

images.alt_text: Kia’s US sales jumped about 22 per cent from a year earlier to 184,000 vehicles.
VinFast's parent Vingroup, Vietnam’s biggest conglomerate, will provide a grant of US$500 million plus a US$1 billion loan with maturity of up to five years.

site_title: German government slightly raises 2023 GDP growth forecast to 0.4%
summary: The German government has raised its 2023 GDP growth forecast to 0.4% from 0.2%, citing a gradual recovery despite a difficult environment. Economy Minister Robert Habeck expects stagnation in the first quarter followed by acceleration in growth. The government also lowered its 2024 growth forecast to 1.6% and adjusted inflation forecasts to 5.9% and 2.7% for 2023 and 2024, respectively. Private consumption is expected to be weak due to inflation-related losses, but will pick up later in the year.

site_title: Xi speaks with Zelenskiy for first time since Russia’s war in Ukraine began
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping spoke with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy for the first time since Russia's invasion in April 2022, with plans to send a delegation to Ukraine. China aims to portray itself as a neutral mediator, following the release of a 12-point cease-fire proposal. However, the proposal was met with skepticism from Ukraine's allies. Xi expressed commitment to promoting peace talks and has expressed concern over humanitarian conditions in Ukraine. The call follows a diplomatic effort to enlist China's help in intervening in the conflict.

images.alt_text: Shinzo Abe, Japan's prime minister, left, and Xi Jinping, China’s president, prepares to take their seats during a bilateral meeting ahead of the Group of 20 (G-20) summit in Osaka, Japan, on Thursday, June 27, 2019. site_title: Malaysia’s Capital A subsidiary secures US$100 million investment
summary: ADE, a subsidiary of Capital A, has secured a $100 million investment from OCP Asia to develop an MRO centre in Sepang, Selangor, Malaysia. The centre, set to start operations in 2024, will have the potential to expand to 20 lines within three years, creating numerous high-value jobs. The investment aims to diversify Capital A's business, with the MRO sector expected to contribute up to 40% of the group's profit in five years. The Malaysian government supports the growth of the MRO sector, estimating it will reach $2.5 billion by 2026.

images.alt_text: Capital A’s subsidiary Asia Digital Engineering inked the partnership agreement with OCP Asia to develop a MRO centre in Sepang, Selangor.

site_title: Iras to reward whistleblowers on private property deals exploiting ‘99-to-1’ loophole to evade ABSD
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) is offering a reward of up to $100,000 to whistleblowers who reveal private property buyers using the "99-to-1" loophole to evade or reduce additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD). This loophole involves selling a partial interest in a home to another buyer within a short period, reducing or avoiding ABSD. The reward is 15% of the tax recovered, capped at $100,000. Iras has identified about 0.5% of private residential properties sold between 2018 and 2021 involved such arrangements.

site_title: Vietnam EV maker VinFast secures US$2.5 billion in fresh funding pledges
summary: Vietnam-based electric vehicle maker VinFast secured US$2.5 billion in fresh funding pledges from its parent company Vingroup, with a US$500 million grant and a US$1 billion loan with a five-year maturity. The funding may signal a delay to VinFast's planned US Initial Public Offering (IPO), which could be pushed into next year due to unfavorable market conditions. VinFast remained committed to its listing process without providing a specific timeline.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of VinFast is pictured at the 2022 Paris Auto Show in Paris, France October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: Former employee of failed oil trader Hin Leong admits she lied to CAD
summary: A former long-serving employee of Hin Leong, Serene Seng, testified as the prosecution's third witness in the trial of Singapore's former oil tycoon OK Lim, accused of cheating and forgery charges. During cross-examination, Lim's defense counsel accused Seng of lying to protect her interests. Seng denied making false statements, stating she would not say anything on the stand that is not in her interest. The trial continues at the State Court.

images.alt_text: Serene Seng, a former long-serving employee of Hin Leong, is Singapore prosecutors' third witness in the trial on cheating and forgery charges against OK Lim at the State Court

site_title: Swedish krona softens on Riksbank dovishness, euro rebounds
summary: The Swedish krona weakened sharply after the Riksbank's less hawkish decision, while the euro rebounded from losses, rising 1.05% against the krona to 11.426, its largest one-day gain since early March. The US dollar remained steady, and the euro also strengthened against the Norwegian krone and the US dollar. The divergence in interest rates between the Riksbank and the European Central Bank is driving currency movements, with market expectations for further rate hikes from the ECB.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A picture illustration of  U.S. dollar, Swiss Franc, British pound and Euro bank notes, taken in Warsaw January 26, 2011. REUTERS/Kacper Pempel/File Photo

site_title: UK gets record demand for bonds hedging against inflation
summary: The UK received a record £46 billion in demand for inflation-linked bonds, exceeding previous sales, amid concerns that rising prices aren't slowing down despite interest rate hikes. Consumer prices accelerated 10.1% in Britain, driven by strong food price increases, outpacing inflation in the euro area and US. This highlights the UK's growing divergence from the global fight against inflation.

site_title: Puma expects Q2 sales growth below full-year target after Q1 beat
summary: Puma expects second-quarter sales to grow at a low- to mid-single-digit percentage rate, below its full-year target, due to high inventory levels and muted consumer sentiment. The company beat first-quarter revenue expectations, driven by strong growth in Greater China, but faces challenges from elevated interest rates and persistently high inflation. Puma plans to normalize inventory levels by mid-year and cut its dependency on off-price channels in the US, with a focus on qualitative growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of German sports goods firm Puma is seen at the entrance of one of its stores in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: Roche Q1 sales decline tempered by swift uptake of new eye drug
summary: Roche's Q1 sales declined 7% due to falling demand for Covid-19 therapies and tests, but beat market expectations thanks to strong revenue growth from its new eye drug Vabysmo. The company reported $15.3 billion in revenue, with pandemic-related sales expected to drop by $5 billion this year. Despite this, Roche's overall performance was seen as a positive sign, with analysts praising the company's ability to adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Le siège du fabricant de médicaments suisse Roche à Bâle. /Photo prise le 1er février 2018/REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks struggle for direction amid uncertain outlook; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,293.91 points on Wednesday, amid concerns over possible contagion in the banking sector. Despite gains from tech giants Microsoft and Alphabet, regional indices were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi down 0.7% and 0.2% respectively. Singapore's banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, fell, while Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust was the biggest gainer.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Microsoft, which has made a huge bet on embracing AI technology from the makers of ChatGPT, reported profit of US$18.3 billion on revenue of US$52.9 billion.
First Republic had total assets of US$233 billion as of Mar 31, including US$173 billion of loans and US$35 billion of investment securities, according to its first-quarter earnings report.

site_title: Boeing plans 737 MAX ramp-up, backs cash-flow goal
summary: Boeing plans to ramp up 737 MAX production to 38 jets per month by year-end, despite manufacturing problems and supply chain disruptions. The company backs its annual cash-flow goal of $3-5 billion, aiming to deliver 400-450 737 MAXs and 70-80 787 Dreamliners. Boeing's first-quarter cash burn slowed to $786 million, a significant improvement from the previous year. The company reported an adjusted loss per share of $1.27, wider than expected, but paid down $1.6 billion in debt, now standing at $55.4 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Boeing Co's logo is seen above the front doors of its largest jetliner factory in Everett, Washington, U.S. January 13, 2017. REUTERS/Alwyn Scott/File Photo

site_title: China’s Ping An Insurance posts 48.9% rise in Q1 profit
summary: China's Ping An Insurance reported a 48.9% rise in Q1 profit to 38.4 billion yuan, driven by improved investment income. The company attributed the growth to the domestic economy's recovery, with household consumption picking up steadily. Gross written premiums rose 2.1% to 133.1 billion yuan, while retail customers increased 0.9% to 228.6 million. The insurer's investment income more than doubled to 29.7 billion yuan from a loss of 26.1 billion yuan in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Ping An Insurance is seen at the Global Mobile Internet Conference (GMIC) at the National Convention Center in Beijing, China April 27, 2018. REUTERS/Damir Sagolj/File Photo

site_title: UK blocks Microsoft’s US$69 billion Activision deal
summary: The UK's antitrust watchdog, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), has blocked Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, citing concerns that the deal would harm competition in the UK. The CMA stated that remedies, such as selling Call of Duty, were insufficient to address its concerns. Microsoft has announced plans to appeal the decision, which may have significant implications for the gaming industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft logo is seen on a smartphone placed on displayed Activision Blizzard's games characters in this illustration taken January 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China unveils plan to boost employment with a focus on youth
summary: China's cabinet has unveiled plans to boost employment, focusing on youth, by issuing subsidies to firms that hire college graduates and unemployed young people until the end of the year. The government will also encourage state-owned firms to expand recruitment and financial institutions to offer loans to small firms to create new jobs. Amid weak private business confidence, the cabinet aims to maintain job hiring of college graduates at government departments and provide at least one million internships to young job-seekers. The move aims to address the rebounding jobless rate for those aged 16 to 24, near a record high in March.

images.alt_text: People attend a job fair in China's southwestern city of Chongqing on April 11, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts 1.3% fall in Q3 NPI to S$38 million
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 1.3% decline in net property income (NPI) to S$38 million in Q3, driven by a weaker Australian dollar and Malaysian ringgit, as well as the divestment of a Tokyo property. However, tenant sales and shopper traffic at Wisma Atria improved by 13.6% and 24.6% year-over-year, respectively. The Reit's Singapore assets contributed 61.8% of its gross revenue, and occupancy stood at 96.7%. Retail rents are expected to grow further in 2023, particularly in Orchard Road.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The Reit's divestment of its Japanese property Daikanyama at a 39 per cent premium over valuation and an exit yield of 2.77 per cent could also be used to pare-down debt, said RHB.
Australian department store chain Myer is claiming a breach of its lease at Myer Centre Adelaide.

site_title: Renting to rent – a new option for home owners
summary: Homeowners can now rent out their properties to co-living operators, who will transform the space into Instagram-worthy accommodations, handle tenant and maintenance issues, and provide a free makeover in the process. This emerging trend benefits all parties involved, offering a win-win arrangement for homeowners and tenants alike. The arrangement typically involves the operator covering costs, providing amenities, and finding suitable tenants. In return, the homeowner receives a rental income and a renovated property.

site_title: China’s MG Motor seeks to take on rivals with India’s cheapest electric car
summary: MG Motor, owned by China's SAIC Motor, launched India's cheapest electric car, the Comet EV, priced at 798,000 rupees (S$13,021.78). The two-door car offers a 230km range on a single charge and aims to compete with local rivals like Tata Motors. The Indian government aims to increase electric vehicle sales to 30% by 2030, while MG Motor expects EVs to account for 25-30% of its sales in the country this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An MG Motor logo is displayed during an electric vehicle launch event in Mexico City, Mexico April 20, 2023. REUTERS/Toya Sarno Jordan/File Photo

site_title: Global financial sector pays tribute as banker Win Bischoff dies at 81
summary: Win Bischoff, a renowned financier, has died at 81. He was a former chairman of Lloyds Banking Group, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Securities, and served as CEO of Schroders. Bischoff was known for his strategic overhauls and repositioning of banks during the 2008 global banking crisis. Tributes have poured in from the industry, with Lloyds chairman Robin Budenberg and JPMorgan chairman Jamie Dimon praising Bischoff's wisdom and influence on the financial sector. He was awarded a knighthood in 2000 for his services to the banking industry.

site_title: Nomura Frankfurt offices raided as part of Cum-Ex probe
summary: German prosecutors have raided Nomura's Frankfurt offices as part of a probe into the Cum-Ex tax dividend scandal, targeting 37 current or former employees. The investigation, which also involves 80 law enforcement officers, is part of a larger probe into the practice, which syphoned off billions of euros in government revenue. This is the latest in a series of raids on international banks, including BNP Paribas, Bank of America's Merrill Lynch, and Barclays, with 1,600 people under investigation.

images.alt_text: A sign is lit up outside a Nomura Securities Co. branch in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, April 23, 2009.  Nomura Holdings Inc., Japan's largest brokerage, is expected to announce earnings today. Photographer: Kimimasa Mayama/Bloomberg News

site_title: Digital Core Reit Q1 2023 distributable income dips 10 per cent to US$10.9 million
summary: Digital Core Reit reported Q1 2023 distributable income of US$10.9 million, a 10% decline from US$12.1 million in Q1 2022. Net property income fell 2.3% to US$17.5 million, driven by higher property expenses. The Reit's weighted average lease expiry is 4.2 years, with occupancy rates at 97%. Digital Core will focus on strengthening its portfolio, managing costs, and exploring accretive investment opportunities to enhance geographic and customer diversification.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Electronics output in Singapore fell 8% in March, a slight improvement from February's 11.4% drop. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects the industry's slump to continue for at least the first half of 2023. Global interest rates have risen, increasing uncertainty and financial stability tail risks in Singapore. The yield on Singapore's 6-month T-bill rose to 3.83%, while HDB rents and volumes rose in March, while condo market volumes fell. The STI fell 0.1% as markets were swayed by a weaker US session.

site_title: Kia aims to lift EV sales after record profit
summary: Kia aims to boost electric vehicle (EV) sales to 9% of revenue by the end of the year, up from 5.5% last quarter, after reporting a 79% increase in operating profit to 2.9 trillion won. US sales jumped 22% to 184,000 vehicles, while global sales rose to 768,251. Kia plans to increase EV production to 1.5 million a year by 2030, following Hyundai's commitment to achieve this goal. The company is also seeking to increase EV sales in China to 20% of revenue by 2025.

images.alt_text: Japanese automakers have struggled to completely shake off the hit from tight global chip and parts supply during the pandemic, though constraints have eased.
BYD sold almost 550,000 cars globally in January-March, more than all of the passenger vehicle registrations in the UK in that period.
At US$46,990, the base Model Y now costs US$759 less than the average amount paid for a car or truck in the US.

site_title: China tourists remain wary of travelling overseas
summary: A survey of mainland Chinese travellers found that just 10% have outbound trips booked for 2023, with 31% saying no to international travel altogether. Safety concerns outside of China have become the top factor in considering a trip, surpassing financial concerns and free time. The slow rebound of international passenger volumes from China is reflected in the survey results, with air travel out of China expected to take another year to recover. Despite this, Chinese travellers remain interested in exploring the world, with 75% preferring Asian destinations and nearly two-thirds opting for all-inclusive packages.

images.alt_text: China kept the PCR testing rule months after it had jettisoned other travel curbs like quarantine partly because other nations were testing passengers from the country due to fears over new variants
GlobalTix co-founders Chan Chee Kong (left), who is chief operating officer, and Chan Chee Chong, who is chief executive officer, aim to work with more payment gateways so more e-wallets can be used.

site_title: Residential rent pressure expected to ease in 2023, sharp rise last year ‘exceptional’: MAS report
summary: Singapore's residential rent pressure is expected to ease in 2023, with a sharp rise last year attributed to an exceptional supply-demand imbalance caused by pandemic-induced delays in housing project completions. Rental demand in 2021 and 2022 was strong due to residents seeking temporary accommodation and non-resident demand recovering after Covid-19 border restrictions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reports that significant housing supply will come on stream, easing further residential rent increases in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
“The rise (in HDB rentals), as opposed to condo rentals, could be reflective of tenants switching to lower rental alternatives in the HDB market,” says 99.co's Luqman Hakim.
Private home prices grew by 3.2 per cent in Q1 2023, after inching up 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter.

site_title: PetroChina signs LNG deal with Malaysia’s Petronas
summary: PetroChina International has signed a sales and purchase agreement with Malaysia's Petronas to buy liquefied natural gas (LNG). The deal, signed on April 17, is the pair's first medium-to-long-term LNG sales and purchase agreement. China, the world's top LNG importer in 2021, is expected to see a rebound in imports this year as the economy recovers, but the timing will depend on spot prices.

site_title: Japan’s Honda Motor in strategic collaboration deal with TSMC
summary: Honda Motor has entered a strategic collaboration agreement with TSMC to secure a stable supply of semiconductors. This move aims to build direct relationships with chip producers for long-term stable chip supply, following the easing of tight global chip and parts supply constraints during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Honda Motor logo is pictured at the 43rd Bangkok International Motor Show, in Bangkok, Thailand, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The Honda Motor logo is pictured at the 43rd Bangkok International Motor Show in Bangkok, Thailand, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: LG Energy Solution Q1 profit more than doubles, in line with forecast
summary: LG Energy Solution's Q1 profit more than doubles to 633 billion won, surpassing forecast, driven by subsidies from the US Inflation Reduction Act and strong EV sales in the US and Europe. The company supplies major EV manufacturers including Tesla and General Motors. This growth is attributed to the increasing demand for EV batteries and the benefits of the US subsidies.

images.alt_text: In its own bid to lower costs, LG Energy Solution is developing lithium-iron-phosphate batteries, which are cheaper than its traditional technology of high-nickel cells.

site_title: Yield on latest Singapore 6-month T-bill rises to 3.83%; demand slips for latest SSB issuance
summary: Singapore's 6-month T-bill yield rose to 3.83% in its latest auction, higher than the previous 3.75%, but demand fell to 2.2 times the S$5 billion allotment. The Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) also saw a decline in demand, with total applications falling to S$11.1 billion from S$12.3 billion in the previous auction. Analysts attribute the decline to rising interest rates globally and concerns about recession.

images.alt_text: Singapore dollar notes in 2, 5, 10 and 50 denomination.
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Poland – a partner in innovation and new technologies
summary: Poland is positioning itself as a key center for investment in new technologies, leveraging its large pool of highly educated professionals in the IT/ICT sector. With a workforce of half a million IT experts and 11,000 fresh IT graduates annually, Poland is well-equipped to capitalize on its natural advantages. Singapore has expressed interest in exploring this market, with the two nations potentially partnering to drive innovation and growth in Central Europe.

images.alt_text: I am also glad to see more and more products from Poland imported by smaller local companies. As our respective phytosanitary agencies share the commitment to remove the last existing administrative barrier and swiftly complete market, says Magdalena Bogdziewicz.
There are many factors that make Poland a good investment destination; these include its stable economic growth and strategic location, among others.

site_title: Electronics ‘insourcing’, fragmented value chain pose challenges, chances for Singapore: MAS
summary: Singapore's hub position in the electronics industry may be challenged by a slowdown in global electronics trade and an increasingly fragmented value chain. Despite this, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) believes the country can maintain its relevance by leveraging its geographical advantage and efficient trade-logistics ecosystem. The US and China's expansion of domestic electronics capacity may intensify the "insourcing" trend, which could dampen cross-border trade flows, but Singapore remains a critical node in the global electronics value chain, with a 6% share of global electronics exports and an attractive location for semiconductor production.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore’s gross domestic product is expected to grow 0.5 to 2.5 per cent this year, moderating from 3.6 per cent in 2022 and with risks tilted to the downside.

“Many semiconductor companies operating in Singapore have manufacturing processes and products that rely on US technology, which may be subject to export controls imposed by the US government,” said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.

site_title: Blueground rides rental market wave to expand in Singapore
summary: Blueground, a rental management company, has expanded its operations in Singapore, operating 100 apartments across the city and Hong Kong. The company's model guarantees landlords full rental income, regardless of occupancy rate, and offers flexible, long-term accommodation options. With a 95% occupancy rate just months after launch, Blueground's general manager Archana Ashar attributes this success to meeting a gap in the local rental market. The company plans to double its revenue in 2023 and expand to 40,000 apartments in 50 cities by 2025.

site_title: US five-year credit default swaps hit new 2011 high
summary: US credit default swaps widened to 62 basis points, a new 2011 high, driven by concerns over the government's debt ceiling. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned of an "economic catastrophe" if the debt ceiling is not raised. This is more than double the level at the start of the year, representing the highest level since 2011.

site_title: Goldman says robust China earnings will re-energise its stocks
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a robust Chinese earnings season will re-energize its stocks. 90% of Chinese companies reporting first-quarter results have given positive profit guidance, surpassing the historical average of 60-70%. Most companies are expected to deliver 20% earnings growth. This encouraging earnings picture offers investors hope after a recent US$446 billion meltdown in domestically traded Chinese stocks, driven by geopolitical tensions. Analysts expect aggregate profits per share to rise 11% in yuan terms for the January-March period.

images.alt_text: A man is reflected in an electronic stock board showing stock information at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, July 14, 2009. China's benchmark stock index, the Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index, rose 0.52 percent at 9:35 a.m. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg News

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Parkway Life Reit to ‘buy’ with lower target price
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB upgraded its call on Parkway Life Reit to "buy" with a lower target price of S$4.50, citing a recent 10% decline in unit price since March 2023. The Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0365 for Q1 met expectations, and analysts highlighted its stability and defensive income structure. Despite a rise in gearing, the Reit's interest coverage ratio remained high, providing income stability to unitholders. The upgrade implies a potential total return of 17% for investors.

images.alt_text: As the healthcare Reit makes distributions on a semi-annual basis, the DPU will form part of the Reit’s distribution for the first half of this year, says its manager.

Mount Elizabeth Hospital, which is under PLife Reit. In addition to the ongoing recycling of its nursing homes properties in Japan and the acquisition pipeline from its sponsor, the manager of PLife Reit is looking to build a “third pillar” for the next phase of growth.

site_title: Standard Chartered beats estimates with higher rates boosting profits
summary: Standard Chartered reported its largest quarterly profit since 2014, beating analyst estimates with US$1.71 billion in adjusted pre-tax profits, driven by higher interest rates and accelerating Asian markets. Net interest income increased 13% and income is expected to grow around 10% this year. The bank remains confident in its financial targets and plans to return over US$5 billion to shareholders by 2024.

images.alt_text: Simon Cooper, CEO of corporate, commercial & institutional banking at Standard Chartered, sees opportunities for the bank to leverage interest in Asean and become a “connector” for investors.

site_title: Sweden’s Riksbank raises rate to 3.50%, says nearly done with hikes
summary: Sweden's Riksbank raised its policy rate to 3.50% as expected, marking nearly the end of rate hikes amid slowing economies and signs of peaking inflation. The central bank stated that monetary policy has a tightening effect on the economy and expects to adjust the rate in smaller steps after the April meeting. This decision was seen as dovish, surprising markets and causing the Swedish crown to tumble, as inflation remains above the 2% target.

images.alt_text: Riksbank governor Erik Thedeen has said that data published ahead of the April meeting is “more important than ever” for determining its course of action.

site_title: Nomura profit falls 76% as banking turmoil hits trading
summary: Nomura Holdings reported a 76% decline in net income to 7.4 billion yen (S$70 million) in the first quarter, citing a spike in market volatility and muted client activity. The decline was attributed to challenges in fixed income trading and deal-making. The company plans to buy back 20 billion yen in shares, less than previously announced. Investment banking deal origination is expected to recover later this year, according to the chief financial officer.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.2% or 4.86 points to 3,291.7. Losers outnumbered gainers 75 to 47 across the broader market, with 40.9 million securities worth S$49.1 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust's decline in distribution per unit for Q1 2023 is mainly due to higher financing costs.

site_title: Credit Suisse crisis plans greenlit by Swiss regulator last year
summary: Credit Suisse came close to bankruptcy despite meeting all regulatory capital and liquidity requirements in March, prompting a review of crisis preparedness by Swiss regulators. The Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (Finma) found that both Credit Suisse and UBS had solid emergency plans, scoring green in the assessment. However, Post Finance scored red due to an inadequate plan, and Zuercher Kantonalbank scored amber. The regulator will contribute to improving crisis preparedness, highlighting the need for lessons to be learned from the crisis.

images.alt_text: This is the first major lawsuit in the public domain to be filed over the Swiss decision to wipe out around US$18 billion of Credit Suisses AT1 debt during the three billion Swiss franc all-share rescue deal.

site_title: EU agrees binding green fuel targets for aviation
summary: The European Union has agreed to set binding targets for airlines to increase their use of sustainable aviation fuels (SAF), aiming to reduce the aviation sector's carbon footprint. Starting in 2025, fuel suppliers must ensure 2% of fuel at EU airports is SAF, rising to 70% by 2050. From 2030, 1.2% of fuels must also be synthetic fuels, made using captured CO2 emissions. Airlines will receive €2 billion in funding to switch to SAF, with some airlines planning to overshoot the targets.

images.alt_text: Lara Wolters, the EU parliament member responsible for ushering CSDDD through the chamber, said she’s bracing for a “tough” battle with the finance industry.

site_title: Airbus shakes up leadership of A320-family jet programme
summary: Airbus has changed the leadership of its A320-family jetliner programme, replacing current leader Michael Menking with Christoph Zammert. The move comes amid industrial pressures and supply chain issues affecting production and deliveries of the A320neo and A350 models. This is the first time Airbus has had fewer quarterly deliveries than rival Boeing since 2018. The company attributes the issue to deliveries of parts rather than internal problems, but sources point to breakdowns at the robotized assembly line in Hamburg, Germany, and ongoing supply pressures that could continue into 2024.

images.alt_text: MYAirline has signed leasing deals for 17 Airbus A320 planes and is very close to obtaining another five, says CEO Rayner Teo.
“For the flights which were erroneously processed, ANA will cancel and fully refund all itineraries,” the Japanese airline said on Tuesday (Apr 25).

site_title: Indonesia’s Panin Bank sale has stalled on valuation, sources say
summary: Indonesia's Panin Bank sale has stalled due to disagreements over valuation, with prospective bidders concerned about deploying capital for a major acquisition amid market volatility. The bank, valued at around $2.1 billion, has seen its shares rise 42% in the past year. Major shareholders, including the Gunawan family and ANZ Group Holdings, have been exploring a potential sale, but talks have hit a snag. The stalemate comes amid global economic uncertainty, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and the emergency takeover of Credit Suisse.

site_title: Alibaba Cloud cuts prices by up to 50% for core, storage products
summary: Alibaba Cloud has cut prices by up to 50% for its core and storage products, aiming to expand its user base and market penetration in China's cloud market. The price cuts, effective Wednesday, apply to elastic computing services using various chip types, including Arm, Intel, and Nvidia's V100 and T4 graphics processing units. The move is part of Alibaba Cloud's efforts to compete with rising competition and increase its share of the cloud market.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. Executive Council Member and the Chairman of HKEX Laura Cha said she was also surprised but was convinced the bill would ensure clarity and stability of the city. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg
Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. offices in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: HDB rents, volumes rise in March as condo market dips: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB rents rose 0.7% in March, with 3,007 flats leased out, a 14.8% increase from the previous month and 1.1% higher year on year. In contrast, condo rentals fell. Analysts attribute the HDB rental growth to tenants switching to lower-priced alternatives.

images.alt_text: Condominiums in the outside of central region continues to see healthy demand.
R
Both HDB and condos register rental increases even as volume declined in February

site_title: Crypto must end anonymity for illicit finance, US regulator says
summary: US Commodity Futures Trading Commission commissioner Christy Goldsmith Romero says cryptocurrencies must end anonymity to prevent illicit finance, citing national security risks. She notes that anonymity makes crypto assets attractive to cybercrime and terrorist financing. Legally compliant crypto companies should not use mixers or software tools that anonymize users. Congress is considering new laws on addressing anonymity and digital identity. Regulators worldwide are working to regulate crypto assets before global norms are agreed upon, with the Financial Stability Board set to issue final recommendations soon.

images.alt_text: FTX filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States on Nov 11 in the biggest crypto firm failure.
Genesis is seeking mediation to take place over a two-day period prior to May 9, and ahead of a mid-May due date on US$630 million of debt owed to Genesis by DCG.

site_title: Making tourism easier with local e-wallet ticket purchases
summary: Singapore's GlobalTix launches GTPay, a platform allowing tourists from one Asian country to purchase online tickets for attractions in another using their local digital wallet. The platform supports e-wallets from countries such as Indonesia, Singapore, and Malaysia. Co-founders aim to expand support to more payment gateways, making it easier for tourists to book tickets without a credit card. This move aims to boost tourism and travel in the region, following the hard-hit industry during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: GlobalTix gets S$3m in fresh funds from Tin Men Capital, SEEDS Capital

site_title: Australia’s home rents surge most in 13 years as crisis worsens
summary: Australia's home rents surged 4.9% in the first quarter, the largest annual increase in 13 years, driven by low vacancy rates and rising immigration. The housing crunch is attributed to a lack of new supply, largely due to rising interest rates and labour shortages. The National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation warned of a 100,000-home shortage over the next five years. Experts predict that capital city rents will continue to rise until 2024, with apartments facing the tightest squeeze. The Australian government's Housing Future Fund, a $10 billion plan to boost supply, is currently before the Senate.

images.alt_text: Looking ahead, MAS expects that about 32,000 public and private residential units will be completed per year between 2023 and 2025.
Miami is attracting plenty of wealthy investors, including Citadel’s Ken Griffin.

site_title: Freddie Mercury’s worldly possessions to be sold at auction
summary: Freddie Mercury's estate, including his London home Garden Lodge, will be auctioned off by Sotheby's London in six auctions starting in September. An estimated 1,500 items, including music memorabilia, artwork, and personal belongings, will be sold, with estimates ranging from £6 million to £10 million. A portion of the proceeds will benefit the Mercury Phoenix Trust and the Elton John Aids Foundation. The auction will feature rare items such as Mercury's handwritten lyrics, a Faberge desk clock, and a Japanese art collection, offering a glimpse into the life of the legendary musician.

images.alt_text: In 2020, a First Folio sold for a record US$9.97 million at auction.

site_title: Sri Lanka pushes debt restructuring presentation to mid-May
summary: Sri Lanka has pushed back the release of its debt restructuring plan to mid-May from April, amid disagreements with foreign creditors and domestic banks.
