The government aims to avoid talks with pre-conditions, while foreign creditors demand that local debt holders share losses. The delay may prolong debt restructuring negotiations until December, according to economists. Sri Lanka will discuss debt restructuring with Paris Club members, India, and China separately, while reviewing banks' asset quality to determine their capacity to absorb losses.

site_title: Teck Resources profit misses estimates as Glencore circles
summary: Canadian miner Teck Resources narrowly missed first-quarter estimates, reporting adjusted profit of C$1.81 per share, lower than the average analyst estimate of C$1.82. The company's quarterly gross profit for its copper business fell 42.1% due to lower sales volumes and average realised copper prices. Teck has repeatedly rejected Glencore's unsolicited takeover bid, instead pushing ahead with a proposed restructuring plan to focus on copper and zinc. The company's annual general meeting will decide the fate of the plan, which could be postponed if it lacks sufficient shareholder support.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Norwegian central bank, where Norway's sovereign wealth fund is situated, in Oslo, Norway, March 6, 2018.  REUTERS/Gwladys Fouche/File Photo
Based on its first-quarter performance, trading profits this year will again beat its guidance range of US$2.2 billion to US$3.2 billion, Glencore says.

Teck investors will vote on the plan to spin off its coal mines in a little more than a week, and Glencore chief executive officer Gary Nagle has said that the company will keep pursuing a deal if Teck’s investors vote down the restructuring plan.

site_title: Hit Japan anime genre offers escape, second chances
summary: The "isekai" anime genre, which originated in Japan, has gained popularity worldwide for its escapist themes of characters being reincarnated into new lives with unique powers. The genre taps into the frustrations of people feeling undervalued and dissatisfied with modern life, offering a chance at a do-over. Popular titles like "That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime" and "Mushoku Tensei: Jobless Reincarnation" have attracted a broad fanbase, including female viewers who identify with underappreciated heroines. The genre's popularity is expected to continue, with over 4,000 works featuring "isekai" in their titles.

site_title: Thai March export fall less than expected, value at a year high
summary: Thailand's exports contracted 4.2% in March from a year earlier, beating expectations for a 14% drop. Despite the decline, the export value reached a year-high of $27.65 billion. The country maintained its target of 1-2% export growth for the year, citing favorable exchange rates and expected growth from farm products and cars shipments. A trade surplus of $2.72 billion was recorded in March, contrasting with a forecast deficit. Exports to the US and Japan rose, while those to China dropped.

images.alt_text: Exports, a key driver of Thai growth, are expected to drop 0.5 per cent this year.

site_title: Singapore factory output falls 4.2% in March; economists expect slump to continue through H1
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output contracted 4.2% in March, marking the sixth straight month of decline. While this was better than expected, economists still expect the industry's slump to continue through the first half of 2023. The electronics cluster, which fell 8% year-on-year, is expected to trend further downwards. China's reopening may boost import demand, but it is unlikely to offset slowing demand from the rest of the world. A turnaround is expected in the second half of the year, with some economists predicting a full-year contraction of 5-6%.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

Industrial production (IP) fell 8.9 per cent year on year in February, down from 3.1 per cent in the previous month, data from the Singapore Economic Development Board showed on Friday (Mar 24). This marks the fifth month of contraction.
On a seasonally adjusted, monthly basis, manufacturing output falls 1.1 per cent in January, reversing from an expansion in December 2022.

site_title: US companies in China grow more pessimistic about bilateral ties
summary: US companies in China have become increasingly pessimistic about bilateral ties, with 87% expressing pessimism, a 14% increase from the previous poll. The American Chamber of Commerce in China attributed this to worsening geopolitical tensions, with Chinese President Xi Jinping criticizing the US for a strategy of "containment and suppression". However, the survey also found that 59% of respondents are optimistic about China's economic recovery, and 73% remain committed to operating their supply chains in China. The chamber calls for high-level engagement to address concerns and improve relations.

images.alt_text: Chinese banks and their overseas branches were encouraged to offer financial support to automobile firms to help the latter expand in foreign turf, the State Council said.

A unified real estate database for the entire country is seen as vital for the central government to regulate the housing market and also force corrupt local officials to disclose multiple properties purchased with illicit funds, industry experts say.

site_title: China pushes largest-ever expansion of nuclear arsenal
summary: China is expanding its nuclear arsenal at the largest scale ever, with estimates suggesting it could have 1,500 warheads by 2035. The country's nuclear modernization drive, under President Xi Jinping, aims to not only deter foes but also counter-attack if deterrence fails. China has ramped up production and upgrade its nuclear triad, including missiles, aircraft, and submarines. The expansion is driven by concerns about the US ability to execute a disarming first strike and to ensure its nuclear deterrent. China's nuclear build-up has significant implications for nuclear planning and stability worldwide.

images.alt_text: The stock upswing is fuelled by optimism that China’s outlook is improving after data from December industrial output to retail sales highlighted the economy’s resilience.
Ties between the two countries have worsened in recent months, with Chinese President Xi Jinping in March criticising the US for what he called a strategy of “containment and suppression”.

site_title: China stock selloff eases after US$446 billion in value wiped out
summary: China's stock market has seen a decline in recent days, wiping out approximately US$446 billion in value, as geopolitical tensions and concerns over US-led curbs on Beijing's tech ambitions have taken a toll. Despite this, sentiment has started to ease, with the benchmark CSI 300 Index trading little changed and the offshore yuan rebounding from a low. Economists expect China to focus on boosting business confidence and jobs, rather than adding extra stimulus, and a strong Golden Week tourism rebound could also lift sentiment.

images.alt_text: Ties between the two countries have worsened in recent months, with Chinese President Xi Jinping in March criticising the US for what he called a strategy of “containment and suppression”.

American depositary receipts of Internet giants from Alibaba Group Holding to JD.com are down Tuesday (Apr 25) and on track to send the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index lower for a sixth straight session.
China’s blue-chip CSI300 Index and the Shanghai Composite Index both closed down 2 per cent.

site_title: Taiwan’s Taoyuan Airport shuts runway for suspected explosives
summary: Taiwan's Taoyuan Airport temporarily shut a runway after Air China flight 185 from Beijing reported a suspected bomb threat. The Aviation Police Bureau received a report at 11:30 am, and the plane was parked in a holding bay while police investigated. Two X-ray cars were sent, and after a search, no explosives were found. The plane's 103 passengers and 15 staff disembarked at 12:40 pm, and the all-clear was given at 1:30 pm.

site_title: Australian dollar falters, bonds rally after core inflation surprises to downside
summary: The Australian dollar fell 0.2% to US$0.6614, its weakest level since mid-March, after core inflation surprised to the downside. This eased pressure on the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise interest rates next month. Inflation eased in the first quarter, and core inflation dipped below forecasts, suggesting the rate hiking cycle may be over. As a result, bond yields eased, with three-year yields falling 18 basis points to 2.975%, and futures now imply a 9% chance of unchanged cash rates in May.

images.alt_text: Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed the consumer price index rose 1.4 per cent in the March quarter, just above market forecasts of 1.3 per cent but the smallest increase since late 2021.

site_title: ChatGPT’s secret weapon is artificial emotional intelligence
summary: ChatGPT's secret weapon is its artificial emotional intelligence, which surpasses its ability to recall facts. The chatbot's empathetic responses, fueled by training data from social media, forums, and emotional intelligence research, have made it a popular choice as a companion for mental health support. However, experts caution that relying solely on chatbots for emotional support can lead to a loss of human connection and the need for more nuanced emotional understanding. Microsoft and Google's attempts to enhance their search engines with ChatGPT's technology may not be effective, as the chatbot's emotional intelligence is its most valuable asset.

images.alt_text: Competition is forcing AI engineers to go too fast and cut too many corners. The technology is too important to be left to a race among Microsoft, Google, Meta and a few other firms.
Brian Gothong Tan's stunning, surreal images were created using an AI tool. Like other artists in Singapore, Tan has been turning to AI for collaboration and inspiration.

The Emobot is a device that continuously monitors the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns using AI to interpret data collected by the Embot’s camera and microphone.

site_title: New Zealand housing slump may be tempered by eased lending rules
summary: New Zealand's housing market may experience a tempered downturn due to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's easing of mortgage lending restrictions. The RBNZ plans to allow lenders to make more low-deposit home loans, potentially reducing house-price declines. The changes, which will come into effect on June 1, could lead to increased credit growth and a slowdown in the rate of house-price falls. The easing of restrictions may also impact the central bank's interest rate tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: The rapid increase in borrowing costs is projected to drive the country into recession.
New Zealand had one of the hottest housing markets in the world, but new government regulations have made it harder for people to get a loan. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong exchange’s Q1 earnings up 28%
summary: Hong Kong's bourse operator, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX), reported a 28% increase in first-quarter profit to HK$3.41 billion. Revenues rose 19% to HK$5.56 billion, driven by higher net investment income. Despite challenging macroeconomic conditions, HKEX's derivatives market has seen significant growth. The exchange also reported lower trading fees and expanded its stock connect calendar. Shares climbed over 1% on the profit jump, with CEO Nicolas Aguzin praising the quarter as one of the best on record.

images.alt_text: IPO applicants will also have to disclose material ESG information in their prospectuses.

site_title: Oil dips 2% on economic woes and stronger dollar
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% to their lowest this month, falling to $80.77 a barrel, due to economic woes and a stronger dollar. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate crude also fell, with Brent crude at $80.77 and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $77.07. The decline was attributed to deepening concerns of an economic slowdown and a stronger dollar, which makes oil more expensive for buyers holding other currencies. OPEC's announcement of plans to cut production also contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: Supply tightness owing to additional supply cuts planned by the Opec+ producer group from May could also lift prices.

site_title: Uncertainty, financial stability tail risks have risen globally and for Singapore: MAS
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 0.5-2.5% this year, moderating from 3.6% in 2022, amid rising global interest rates and uncertainty. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) notes that financial stability tail risks have increased, with the risk of contagion from banking pressures and a potential technical recession in Singapore. The global economy is forecast to grow 2.8%, with the US expected to experience a brief technical recession. MAS maintains its monetary policy stance, but warns of downside risks to growth and financial stability.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Singapore’s economy has grown 0.1 per cent year on year in Q1, advance estimates from the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Friday (Apr 14) show, slower than the 2.1 per cent expansion recorded in the fourth quarter of last year.
MAS says it will maintain the prevailing rate of appreciation of the S$NEER policy band.

site_title: Bankrupt crypto firm FTX to sell LedgerX for US$50 million
summary: FTX, the bankrupt crypto firm, has agreed to sell its crypto derivatives platform LedgerX to Miami International Holdings for $50 million. FTX filed for bankruptcy in November, recovering over $7.3 billion in assets since then. The sale is part of FTX's efforts to monetize assets and deliver recoveries to stakeholders. The company will seek bankruptcy court approval for the sale on May 4. This is the latest in FTX's asset sales, following a $95 million deal to sell its stake in Mysten Labs.

images.alt_text: flag, america, usa
Bankrupt crypto exchange FTX has recovered US$7.3 billion in assets
Sam Bankman-Fried faces trial in October after pleading not guilty to fraud and campaign-finance law charges.

site_title: Netflix loses 1 million users in Spain over password policing
summary: Netflix lost over 1 million users in Spain in the first three months of 2023 due to its password-sharing crackdown, with two-thirds of those users sharing another household's password. The move led to a 3x increase in subscription cancellations and 1/10 of remaining subscribers planning to unsubscribe in the second quarter. Despite the setback, Netflix expects the policy to accelerate growth in the second half of 2023, citing its investment in Spanish-language content and a cheaper ad-supported streaming option.

images.alt_text: Netflix offered a lighter-than-expected forecast last week.
From January through March,  Netflix added 1.75 million streaming subscribers, missing analyst estimates of 2.06 million additions.

site_title: Singapore banks face limited NIM growth, rising asset quality risks in Q1: analysts
summary: Singapore's three major banks, UOB, DBS, and OCBC, are expected to report weaker loan growth and rising asset quality risks in Q1 due to increasing recession risks. Analysts attribute this to limited net interest margin (NIM) growth, despite the US Federal Reserve's rate hike cycle nearing its peak. Funding costs and muted loan growth will also pressure NIMs. Rising risks to asset quality are anticipated, with some analysts downgrading their calls on the banks, citing continued rate hikes, recession risk, and stubborn inflation.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.##########banks##########CHONG JUN LIANG
DBS, OCBC and UOB are the sort of banks to which depositors might flee during periods of heightened risk aversion

The chief executives of the respective banks remained cautiously optimistic of their FY2023 performance, as they expect interest rates will largely remain elevated and continue to boost their net interest margins (NIM), although they warned of costs catching up.

Recently released statistics from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) showed the overall non-bank loan-to-deposit ratio had fallen to 73.3 per cent in February 2023, from 81.2 per cent in February 2022.

site_title: Biden versus Trump: The sequel?
summary: US President Joe Biden has announced his bid for re-election in 2024, despite low enthusiasm among Americans, with only a quarter wanting him to run again. At 80, Biden's age is a concern, with 65% of Americans, including Democrats, agreeing he is too old for another term. However, Biden's organisational and financial resources, as well as his policy achievements, make him a strong candidate. A rematch with former president Donald Trump is likely, with Trump having a better than 50% chance of getting the Republican nomination.

images.alt_text: Former South Carolina governor and former US ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley announces her run for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination at a campaign event in Charleston, South Carolina, Feb 15, 2023.

President Joe Biden delivers his State of the Union speech, with Speaker Kevin McCarthy and Vice President Kamala Harris seated behind him, to a joint session of Congress at the US Capitol in Washington, on Tuesday, Feb 7, 2023.

site_title: Time for a fundamental rethink of the COE
summary: Singapore's certificate of entitlement (COE) system, which controls vehicle ownership through an auction-based pricing mechanism, has become regressive and unaffordable for many Singaporeans. The latest COE price, S$103,721, is 10 times the median monthly household income, making it unsustainable for many. The government should consider a fundamental rethink of the COE framework, potentially introducing a lottery mechanism or market-rate COEs to make ownership more equitable and accessible.

images.alt_text: The COE premium for smaller cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as for electric vehicles (EVs) with up to 110 kilowatts of power, finished at S$103,721, up 7.48 per cent from the previous high of S$96,501.
Wearnes Automotive prestige division MD Victor Kwan with the Aston Martin Valhalla.
"Most luxury car buyers have a high price inelasticity...so they will not be deterred by the increase in taxes" - market observer

site_title: The clock is ticking for Singapore’s pioneer Spacs
summary: Singapore's three Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (Spacs) face a looming deadline with about nine months left to complete a business combination. Despite annual general meetings this month, the Spacs' sponsors have yet to enter a binding acquisition agreement with a target. Global macroeconomic headwinds and the shrinking window for a successful de-Spac are pressing concerns for shareholders. The Spacs' sponsors have expressed optimism but lack concrete progress, raising concerns about the companies' ability to meet the deadline.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
SPAC (special purpose acquisition company) sponsors are hard put to find attractive deals within the allowed time limits and risk having to liquidate.

Chamath Palihapitiya, the founder of Social Capital, at a conference in New York on Oct 26, 2022. Palihapitiya, once a relentless cheerleader of special purpose acquisition companies, blames the Federal Reserve for the end of SPAC mania.

site_title: Top 500 family firms’ revenue up by 10% despite global slowdown: study
summary: The world's 500 largest family enterprises have seen a 10% increase in revenue to US$8.02 trillion, despite a global economic slowdown. 17 family firms from South-east Asia, including two from Singapore, made the list, with Golden Agri-Resources rising from 230th to 177th in 2023. This growth is attributed to the resilience of family firms, which have been able to navigate challenging market conditions.

images.alt_text: A person was classified as an HNWI if that individual has at least US$6 million in investable wealth.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing additional controls for prospecting and marketing of financial products to better protect consumer interests.
A mix of products, services and education are what wealth management platforms are utlising to attract the "sandwich rich."

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank downgrades Venture to ‘hold’ as macro outlook worsens
summary: Maybank Securities downgraded Venture Corporation's rating to "hold" from "buy" and reduced its target price to S$17.32 due to worsening macro headwinds, which are expected to impact the electronics manufacturing services provider's earnings. Analyst Jarick Seet projects a 10.3% decline in net profit after tax for FY2023 and a 10.2% cut for FY2024. Despite this, Seet expects Venture's dividends to remain stable at 4.3% yield.

images.alt_text: Earnings per share for H2 2022 stood at 67.1 Singapore cents per share, up from 59.1 Singapore cents per share in H2 2021.
Venture Corporation said it is in the process of looking for a replacement for the role of chief financial officer, and will make the necessary announcement when a suitable candidate is appointed.
Venture helps companies design and produce high-tech products. Its margins have been consistently been around 10 per cent in the last five years.

site_title: Visa’s payments business helps profit exceed Wall Street estimates
summary: Visa reported a better-than-expected second-quarter profit, with payment volumes rising 10% and net revenue increasing 11% despite a slowest growth in eight quarters. The company's shares rose 2.4% in after-hours trading. CEO Ryan McInerney attributed the growth to a strong dollar and rebounding travel, particularly in China, and expressed confidence in the business's long-term potential. The results follow a similar performance by peer American Express, which missed Wall Street estimates.

images.alt_text: Visa and Mastercard are each being sued by hundreds of claimants at London’s Competition Appeal Tribunal, which is currently managing the various cases together.
Pismo’s investors include SoftBank Latin America Fund, Amazon.com, Falabella Ventures and Redpoint eventures.

site_title: China Evergrande’s unit faces heat for not publishing 2021 annual report
summary: China Evergrande Group's Hengda Real Estate unit faces sanctions from Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges for failing to publish its 2021 annual report by the deadline of April 30, 2022. The company, struggling with a property debt crisis, backed executive director Qian Cheng, stating the disciplinary sanction will not impact the business. Evergrande has over $300 billion in total liabilities and sits at the center of China's property debt crisis, which has seen multiple developers default over the past year.

site_title: Stellantis seeks to cut about 3,500 US jobs, union letter says
summary: Stellantis plans to cut about 3,500 US hourly jobs ahead of the expiration of its US collective bargaining contract with the United Auto Workers. The company, formed in 2021 from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and PSA Group, will offer early retirement and buyout incentives to both skilled and production workers. This move comes as the cost of electrification eats into the company's profit margins, with CEO Carlos Tavares warning of further job cuts in February. Negotiations between the union and Stellantis are set to begin before the September 14 deadline for a new four-year contract.

images.alt_text: SVolt, spun out of BMW partner Great Wall Motor, already has two locations in Germany with one facility set to start supplying Stellantis from 2025.
Stellantis will boost production at its Melfi plant in southern Italy to focus on EVs and plug-in hybrid vehicles.

site_title: Tripartism to lead Singapore in facing post-pandemic challenges: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's tripartite partners, including the Ministry of Manpower, Ministry of Trade and Industry, and National Trades Union Congress, will work together to address post-pandemic challenges. Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng emphasized the need to continue workforce transformation and support Singaporeans in their careers. The Empower Pillar of the Forward Singapore exercise aims to renew the social compact, deliver opportunities and assurance to workers, and build a strong economy with inclusive labor markets. Key priorities include skills training, preventing workplace discrimination, and professionalizing skilled trades.

images.alt_text: The NTUC supports every worker, says labour leaders, highlighting measures to help groups such as senior workers and those with caregiving responsibilities.

site_title: Suntec Reit’s Q1 DPU falls 27.4% on higher financing costs
summary: Suntec Reit recorded a 27.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01737 for the first quarter of 2023, primarily due to higher financing costs. Despite a 9.6% year-on-year rise in gross revenue and a 2.7% increase in net property income, the Reit's gains were eroded by the impact of a weaker Australian dollar and British pound against the Singapore dollar. The Reit's manager expects financing costs to remain high for the year, which may impact distribution. Net asset value (NAV) per unit fell to S$2.09, and the Reit's aggregate leverage ratio increased to 42.8%.

images.alt_text: Higher interest expense for the period results in a 27.8 per cent rise in finance costs for the Reit.
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s (MPACT) Mapletree Business City (MBC) recorded yoy growth in both gross revenue and NPI in H1FY23.
Suntec Reit's gross revenue and net property income rose in Q3 on stronger operational performance.
Suntec reit's DPU grew 15.8 per cent year on year to S$0.0481 for its 6-month period ended Mar 31, 2022, from S$0.04154 last year.

site_title: BAT Singapore pleads guilty to conspiracy over N Korea sanctions; parent to pay US$635 million to US
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) has pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy to commit bank fraud and conspiracy to violate sanctions for selling products in North Korea and misleading banks about the source of those sales. The company agreed to pay $635.2 million to US authorities to resolve the investigations. A Singapore subsidiary also pleaded guilty to similar charges. BAT's actions are part of a US effort to crack down on North Korea's trafficking in tobacco products and counterfeit cigarettes.

images.alt_text: China’s foreign ministry said last month that relations between China and North Korea had entered “a new historic period” in recent years and continued to develop under the “strategic leadership” of both countries.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit Q1 net property income up 78.2% to S$70.4 million
summary: ESR-Logos Reit reported a 78.2% year-over-year increase in net property income to S$70.4 million for Q1 FY2023, driven by contributions from Ara Logos Logistics Trust after its merger in April 2022. The Reit's gross revenue rose 63.9% to S$97.7 million, while net asset value per unit fell to S$0.348 due to a premium paid over ALog Trust's NAV and transaction costs. Despite headwinds in Singapore, the manager expects the logistics segment to remain strong due to demand for storage space and cargo lift assets.

images.alt_text: Ceva Logistics Singapore, the anchor tenant of the property located at 15 Greenwich Drive, occupies approximately 31,230 square metres or 74.2 per cent of the property by net lettable area.
While the analyst believes that the Reit’s fundamentals are healthy, she advised investors to consider taking up the preferential offering to avoid dilution of shares.
ESR-Logos Reit intends to raise S$300 million through the private placement and preferential offering.

site_title: BYD overtakes Volkswagen as China’s best-selling car brand
summary: BYD has overtaken Volkswagen as China's best-selling car brand, selling almost 550,000 cars globally in January-March. BYD surpassed Volkswagen's sales in China, where it sold over 440,000 cars in the first quarter. The trend reflects the growing influence of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, with BYD accounting for two in every five new-energy car sales in China. BYD chairman Wang Chuanfu aims to overtake Volkswagen by the end of 2023, and the company plans to sell at least 3 million vehicles this year.

images.alt_text: Visitors checking out the BYD Seagull car that was on display at the Shanghai Auto Show 2023.

BYD’s sales in China are up almost 69 per cent this year, giving it an 11 per cent share of the overall car market, more than the Volkswagen brand or the Toyota brand, according to an analysis of sales data.

site_title: Mattel unveils Barbie doll with Down syndrome
summary: Mattel unveiled a new Barbie doll representing a person with Down syndrome, in collaboration with the National Down Syndrome Society. The doll aims to promote inclusivity and counter social stigma through play. The toy was designed to accurately represent someone with the condition, ensuring a more diverse and representative representation of children in the popular figure. This move is part of Mattel's efforts to allow more children to see themselves in the Barbie doll, promoting self-acceptance and confidence.

site_title: US: Stocks down as First Republic’s plunge sparks bank fears
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.0% to 33,530.83 and the S&P 500 dropping 1.6% to 4,071.63. The decline was triggered by First Republic Bank's earnings report, which showed a significant loss of deposits and a 40% decline in its shares. Investors are concerned about the financial sector's stability following the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank last month. The market worries about potential contagion and its impact on the overall economy.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 47.06 points, or 0.14 per cent, at the open to 33,828.34.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust manager bullish on leasing demand even as H1 DPU slips 0.1% to S$0.0613
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 0.1% decline in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0613, despite a 6.5% increase in gross revenue to S$187.6 million. The retail Reit's gross revenue and net property income (NPI) improved, while property expenses rose. Committed occupancy for FCT's retail portfolio reached 99.2%, driven by strong demand for prime retail space. The trust's asset enhancement initiative at Tampines 1 showed strong leasing traction, with 90% pre-commitment prior to works commencement.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Jude Chan
Analysts say the joint acquisition makes Frasers Centrepoint Trust the “largest suburban retail landlord” in Singapore.
Frasers Centrepoint and sponsor Frasers Property has acquired a 50 per cent stake in NEX for S$652.5 million
Hong Kong-listed Link Reit won the race to acquire Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza for S$2.16 billion.
Suburban retail S-Reits have smoothest recovery path: Credit Suisse
Frasers Centrepoint Trust reports 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy in Q1 FY21

site_title: Chipmaker SK Hynix’s losses widen after tech slump deepens
summary: SK Hynix, a major memory chip supplier, posted its second consecutive quarterly loss due to a 60% decline in revenue. The company's operating loss was 3.4 trillion won (S$3.4 billion), but CEO Kim Woohyun signaled that the worst is over, expecting sales to rebound in the current quarter. The move comes after Samsung Electronics, the world's largest memory producer, cut production to alleviate the glut in the industry, which has been impacted by a Covid-19 boom and a potential recession.

images.alt_text: The bonds, to be listed in Singapore, have a coupon of 1.75 per cent a year and will mature in 2030.
Employees walk past the logo of SK Hynix at its headquarters in Seongnam, South Korea, April 25, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust posts 59% higher Q1 gross profit
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust reported a 59% increase in Q1 gross profit, driven by stronger operating performance and contributions from new properties. Stable income from master leases and management contracts accounted for 59% of the quarter's gross profit, while management contracts of serviced residences and hotels contributed 41%. The stapled group's net asset value per stapled security stands at S$1.13 as of March 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Changi Airport was the world’s 9th busiest, with a total of 31.9 million travellers passing through in 2022, according to the ranking by ACI World.
CapitaLand Ascott Trust attributes strong performance to higher portfolio revenue per available unit growth and accretive acquisitions.
Net proceeds arising from the issue of the notes will be used for refinancing the existing borrowings of CapitaLand Ascott Reit and its subsidiaries.
Clas has partnered with the IFC to launch IFC’s first sustainability-linked bond in the hospitality sector globally.

site_title: Europe: Spanish stocks clock worst day in a month as Santander leads bank slide
summary: European stocks experienced their worst session in a month, with the IBEX index falling 1.2% and the Stoxx 600 index dropping 0.4%. Santander led the decline, sliding 6.0% after weaker trade in Brazil and the US overshadowed a rise in first-quarter net profit. The European banking index lost 2.2%, with UBS Group shedding 2.2% after setting aside more money for toxic mortgages. Despite this, Novartis and ABB rose, with Novartis gaining 4.0% after raising its full-year earnings outlook and ABB climbing 3.5% after reporting strong first-quarter results.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped 1.0 per cent to 33,530.83, while the broad-based S&P 500 fell 1.6 per cent to 4,071.63 on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong’s private home prices rise for third month in March
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 1.4% in March, the third consecutive month, driven by a reopened border with China and new property launches. This follows a revised 2.4% gain in February and a 5% rebound in the first quarter after a 15% drop in 2022. However, transaction volume is expected to decline 30% in April due to the earlier rush to buy and recent global market volatility. Experts predict further pressure on home prices in the second quarter due to high interest rates and inventory.

images.alt_text: Under the sanctions, both Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges were critical of Hengda Real Estate and China Evergrande Group executive director Qian Cheng for not filing the report by Apr 30, 2022.

site_title: Australia inflation slows in Q1, probably past the peak
summary: Australia's inflation rate slowed to 1.4% in the March quarter, just above forecasts, and the smallest increase since late 2021. The annual pace slowed to 7.0%, from 7.8%, suggesting inflation has peaked. Core inflation, a closely watched measure, rose 1.2% in the quarter, nudging the annual pace down to 6.6%. The Reserve Bank of Australia may pause raising interest rates, with futures now implying only a 13% chance of a quarter-point rise.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the review’s findings “will strengthen (the country's) national security and ensure (its) readiness for future challenges”.
Australia’s deal volume in the first quarter is 3.5 per cent higher than the same period last year.
The green financing is intended to help Australia’s progress to net-zero emissions by 2050 by boosting investment in clean-energy infrastructure.

site_title: Gold steady as investors eye US data for economic cues
summary: Gold prices remained steady at around $2,000 per ounce on Wednesday as investors awaited US economic data for clarity on the Federal Reserve's rate-hike trajectory. Consumer confidence dropped to a nine-month low, while new US single-family home sales rose to a one-year high in March. The US central bank's rate-setting committee meets on May 2-3. Higher interest rates have diminished gold's appeal, but a weaker dollar makes it more attractive for buyers holding other currencies.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty, higher interest rates dim the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Japan’s ispace concedes failure in bid to make first commercial moon landing
summary: Japan's ispace startup failed in its bid to make the first commercial moon landing after losing contact with its Hakuto-R Mission 1 lander. The lander likely crashed on the lunar surface due to rapid speed increase before planned touchdown. This setback is a disappointment for Japan's space technology ambitions, aiming to send Japanese astronauts to the moon by the late 2020s. Only the US, former Soviet Union, and China have successfully soft-landed spacecraft on the moon.

images.alt_text: In December iSpace launched its HAKUTO-R Mission 1 lunar lander aboard a SpaceX rocket which took off Cape Canaveral, Florida, carrying two robotic rovers.

site_title: Miami’s luxury rent surge means your money goes half as far
summary: Miami's luxury rent has surged, with a 50% decrease in prime apartment space over the past three years. A similar decline was seen in Dubai, where $2,000 a week now gets you 2,890 square feet, down from 5,090 square feet in 2019. In Singapore, $2,000 a week now gets you 2,080 square feet, down 29% from three years ago. Global hotspots have shifted towards quality of life and space, with limited rental supply contributing to rising prices in cities like London and New York.

images.alt_text: Real estate agent Emily Young at the Hanover Republic Square, one of the most luxurious apartment buildings in Austin.
The interior of Jaya Thursfield’s remodeled home in Ibaraki, Japan, March 12, 2023. Thursfield, who moved to Japan in 2017 with his wife, Chihiro, bought the abandoned home for 3 million yen in 2019.

site_title: Binance US ends US$1 billion deal to buy bankrupt crypto firm Voyager
summary: Binance US has ended its $1 billion deal to purchase bankrupt crypto firm Voyager, citing a "hostile and uncertain regulatory climate" in the US. The decision comes after federal regulators dropped their efforts to halt the deal and amid significant regulatory pushback. Voyager may pursue a reverse termination fee from Binance US, while the company plans to return value to customers via direct distributions. This marks the second failed deal for Voyager, which has been trying to exit bankruptcy and repay customers since filing for Chapter 11 protection last year.

images.alt_text: Withdrawals of both will remain open, but trading and deposits will close.
Previously, the deposits were sent to either Signature Bank or Silvergate Capital, both seen as crypto-friendly banks.

site_title: Global retailers seek new ways to lure in shoppers as spending slows
summary: Global retailers are seeking new ways to attract customers as spending slows due to high energy bills and inflation. In Europe, discount retailers have benefited, but mid-market names are being squeezed. Luxury retailers continue to perform well, with hopes of China's reopening boosting sales. To combat declining consumer demand, retailers are investing in loyalty programs, price promotions, and improving online customer experiences. Despite slowing price rises, 72% of respondents expect consumers to be more price-sensitive this year, making it harder for retailers to pass on costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Mannequins are displayed with the price in Euros on a showcase of a clothes store, in Ronda, Spain, January 13, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo

site_title: US consumer confidence falls to 9-month low in April
summary: US consumer confidence fell to a 9-month low in April, reaching 101.3, the lowest since July 2022. The Conference Board reported a decline due to a worsening outlook, signaling a potential recession. Consumer expectations of inflation decreased to 6.2%, while views on jobs improved slightly, with 48.4% considering jobs plentiful. Economists warn that the decline may signal a recession in the near future.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK CITY - APRIL 12: People walk by a food cart in Manhattan on April 12, 2023 in New York City. The Consumer Price Index, which measures annual inflation, dropped in March for the ninth consecutive month. Grocery and food prices fell on a monthly basis for the first time since September 2020.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Donald Trump goes on trial, accused of rape
summary: Former US President Donald Trump went on trial in Manhattan federal court on Tuesday, accused of raping writer E Jean Carroll in a department store dressing room in the mid-1990s. Carroll, 79, is seeking unspecified damages for significant pain and suffering, lasting psychological harm, and invasion of privacy. Trump, 76, has denied the allegations, calling them a "hoax" and "complete scam." The trial is expected to last one to two weeks and could be politically damaging as witnesses discuss his alleged sexual misconduct.

images.alt_text: “Let’s finish this job. I know we can,” US President Joe Biden said.

Hoffman said Friday (Apr 21) in a post on LinkedIn that his grant to a non-profit backing E. Jean Carroll’s battery lawsuit against Trump fits with his drive to protect “American values” and “reinforce the importance of the rule of law, equality, and helping the disadvantaged.”
The lawsuit, filed in a US District Court in Florida, seeks US$500 million from Michael Cohen over his alleged breach of attorney-client privileges and a confidentiality agreement.
Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, said nothing as he entered the courtroom or when he left roughly an hour later.

site_title: First Republic Bank to weigh up to US$100 billion in asset sales
summary: First Republic Bank is exploring the sale of up to $100 billion in assets to shore up its balance sheet and avoid being seized by regulators. The bank, which has total assets of $233 billion, is facing a mismatch between its assets and liabilities due to rising interest rates. Potential buyers may receive warrants or preferred equity to incentivize the sale of assets above their market value. The bank's shares have fallen 49% following the announcement, with analysts concerned about the impact on its wealth-management business.

images.alt_text: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 16: A sign is posted on the exterior of a First Republic Bank office on March 16, 2023 in San Francisco, California. A week after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank failed, First Republic Bank is considering a sale following a dramatic 60 percent drop in its stock price over the past week. The bank also received $70 billion in emergency loans from JP Morgan Chase and the Federal Reserve.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Chinese fast-fashion giant Shein plans to focus more on sustainability
summary: Chinese fast-fashion retailer Shein plans to focus on sustainability, according to executive vice chairman Donald Tang. Consumers are no longer just concerned about affordability, and the company will offer sustainable materials and a platform for reselling used clothes. Shein will also prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) efforts, aiming to grow while reducing its environmental impact. The company has taken market share from affordable fashion retailers and has a robust growth trajectory.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Shein logo is pictured at the company's office in the central business district of Singapore, October 18, 2022. REUTERS/Chen Lin/File Photo

site_title: iFast Q1 net profit falls 48% to S$3 million on startup losses from banking subsidiary
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 48.1% fall in net profit to S$3 million for the first quarter of 2023, due to startup losses in its UK-based banking subsidiary. Revenue rose 1.9% to S$53.9 million, driven by a S$4 million contribution from banking operations. The company expects high growth in revenue and profitability between 2023 and 2025 as it executes its three-year plan.

images.alt_text: iFast office in George Town, Penang, Malaysia on Aug 20, 2022.
Renald Yeo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, FCT, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, ESR-Logos Reit, iFast, IReit Global
summary: Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust's Q1 2023 distribution per unit (DPU) declined 27.4% to S$0.01737 due to higher financing costs. In contrast, Frasers Centrepoint Trust posted a DPU of S$0.0613, down 0.1% from the previous year. These developments may affect trading of their securities.

images.alt_text: krsuntec14 - Suntec Tower One on the left.

site_title: Tottenham players to reimburse fans for Newcastle humiliation
summary: Tottenham players have offered to reimburse fans for the cost of their match tickets from a 6-1 defeat to Newcastle on April 23, as a public apology for the humiliating loss. The defeat cost interim manager Cristian Stellini his job after less than a month in charge, and the team acknowledges a "lack of pride" in the performance. The reimbursement is seen as a gesture to show appreciation for fans' support, with the team looking to bounce back against Manchester United on Thursday evening.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - Premier League - Tottenham Hotspur v AFC Bournemouth - Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, London, Britain - April 15, 2023
Tottenham Hotspur manager Cristian Stellini before the match Action Images via Reuters/Matthew Childs/File Photo

 EDITORIAL USE ONLY. No use with unauthorized audio, video, data, fixture lists, club/league logos or 'live' services. Online in-match use limited to 75 images, no video emulation. No use in betting, games or single club	/league/player publications.  Please contact your account representative for further details.

site_title: No plans to erode excess capital given market uncertainty: OCBC chairman
summary: OCBC chairman Andrew Lee stated that the bank has no plans to reduce its capital given uncertain market conditions, citing the need for prudent management amidst geopolitical tensions and macroeconomic stresses. The bank's CET1 ratio stands at 15.2%, higher than its peer banks, but Lee believes being well-capitalized puts OCBC in a good position to act on acquisition opportunities as they arise. The bank also targets a 50% payout ratio for its dividends moving forward.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks out of an OCBC Bank branch in Singapore October 8, 2019. Picture taken October 8, 2019. REUTERS/Feline Lim/File Photo
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Warner brings ‘Barbie,’ Oprah and DC superheroes to CinemaCon
summary: Warner Bros unveiled a packed lineup of new films at CinemaCon, including the live-action "Barbie" starring Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling, and a remake of "The Color Purple" with Oprah Winfrey and Steven Spielberg. The studio also teased a "10-year plan" to relaunch its DC superhero films, including a new Superman movie. David Zaslav, Warner's CEO, emphasized the studio's focus on theatrical releases, contrasting with its previous strategy of releasing films directly on streaming platforms. The presentation featured A-list stars and showcased the studio's ambitious plans for the future.

images.alt_text: Canadian actor Ryan Gosling and Australian actress Margot Robbie arrive for the Warner Brothers Pictures red carpet photocall of “Barbie” during CinemaCon 2023 at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nevada, on April 25, 2023. (Photo by Bridget BENNETT / AFP)

site_title: Housing-market bottom raises hopes that US can avoid recession
summary: The US housing market is showing signs of recovery, with new-home sales jumping in March to the highest level in a year, and home construction projects rising 6% over the past two months. Low mortgage rates and declining home prices are boosting demand, which could help limit the pain in the rest of the economy. Economists are optimistic that the housing market's resilience could prevent a recession, with some predicting a "soft landing." However, others warn that the construction sector remains vulnerable to layoffs and that the economy's overall health is still uncertain.

images.alt_text: US housing Homes in Centreville, Maryland. Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

site_title: Sabana Reit unitholders vote against giving manager authority to issue new units
summary: Sabana Reit's unitholders voted against a resolution allowing the manager to issue new units for fundraising, citing it was unnecessary given the Reit's low leverage. The resolution failed with 57.9% of votes against and 42.1% in favor. The decision is seen as a win for unitholders, who also rejected a resolution endorsing Elaine Lim as an independent non-executive director. The outcome is attributed to activist investor Quarz Capital, which urged unitholders to reject the resolutions.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The manager's decision to spend S$20 million to enhance the Reit’s 1 Tuas Avenue 4 asset is among concerns flagged by activist investor Quarz.
In the first quarter of 2023, Sabana Industrial Reit's aggregate leverage ratio has increased to 33.1 per cent, and its weighted average fixed-debt expiry has fallen to 1.8 years.

site_title: Fire breaks out at TSMC's new chip facility in Taiwan; no injuries reported
summary: A fire broke out at Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's (TSMC) new chip testing facility in northern Taiwan on April 25, 2023, at around 7:30 pm local time. The fire was completely extinguished at 9:10 pm and no injuries were reported. TSMC will assist the contractor in clarifying the cause of the incident and ensuring the construction site's safety.

site_title: Tesla drops Model Y starting price below the average US vehicle
summary: Tesla has dropped the starting price of its Model Y SUV to US$46,990, making it cheaper than the average US vehicle, with a US$759 price gap. This move marks a significant reduction, with the price difference changing by over US$20,000 since mid-last year. The move is seen as a price war by competitors, with Renault calling it a challenge and warning of potential consequences for automakers. Analysts question whether legacy automakers can compete with Tesla's aggressive pricing strategy in an uncertain economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Model Y cars are pictured during the opening ceremony of the new Tesla Gigafactory for electric cars in Gruenheide, Germany, March 22, 2022. Patrick Pleul/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: First Republic, KPMG sued for concealing bank's risks
summary: First Republic Bank has been sued by shareholders accusing the bank of concealing the risks of rising interest rates by misrepresenting its balance sheet and liquidity. The lawsuit, filed in San Francisco federal court, claims the bank and its auditor KPMG downplayed the impact of interest rate increases and deposit outflows following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. First Republic disclosed a $102 billion deposit loss in the first quarter and plans to cut up to 25% of its workforce. The lawsuit seeks class-action status on behalf of First Republic shareholders from January 2021 to March 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Customers line up outside of the Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, U.S. March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Brittany Hosea-Small/File Photo
A bank run is possible as long as there are some deposits that will require a bank to sell longer-term or risky assets quickly in order to pay them.
First Republic came into intense focus after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank collapsed last month.

site_title: AI, cloud computing lift Microsoft’s quarterly profit
summary: Microsoft reported a profit of $18.3 billion and revenue of $52.9 billion for the first quarter of this year, driven by its cloud computing and AI offerings. The company's Intelligent Cloud services increased 16% to $22.1 billion, while revenue from its productivity and business unit, including Office 365, rose 11% to $17.5 billion. Microsoft's AI efforts, including its chatbot Copilot, are gaining traction, with the company pouring billions into OpenAI, the technology behind ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of U.S. company Microsoft is pictured during preparations for the annual industry trade fair Hannover Messe in Hanover, Germany April 16, 2023. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo

site_title: Gucci sales growth sputters as Kering label faces transition
summary: Gucci's sales growth sputtered in the first quarter, rising 1% on a comparable basis, missing analyst expectations of a 2.7% gain. The luxury brand is weathering a transition after naming Sabato De Sarno as creative director, with his first collection set to debut in September. Kering's performance is in contrast to rivals LVMH and Hermes, which posted double-digit sales growth. The company attributes improving demand from Chinese consumers, but notes that Gucci's appeal in China still needs work.

images.alt_text: The Gucci inspection, at a site connected with the manufacture of travel items, handbags and other leather goods, was aimed at possible violations of the European Union’s Article 101.

site_title: China major chipmaker-backed firm set for top Asia IPO this year
summary: China's Semiconductor Manufacturing Electronics Shaoxing is set to raise $1.4 billion in Asia's largest IPO this year, targeting 9.63 billion yuan in proceeds from selling 1.69 billion shares at 5.69 yuan apiece. The firm, backed by top semiconductor firm SMIC, aims to surpass a 7.84 billion yuan real estate investment trust offering last month. The IPO, listed on Shanghai's STAR board, would give the company a market value of 38.5 billion yuan.

site_title: Gap to cut hundreds of corporate jobs in new layoff round
summary: Gap Inc. is cutting hundreds of corporate jobs in a new round of layoffs, following a broader restructuring plan to turn around performance. The company, which has about 95,000 employees, will trim management layers and speed up decision making, saving around $300 million in annual expenses. Cuts will occur in three phases, starting with the international sourcing division this month, followed by headquarters roles and finance in May. This move comes after the company's interim CEO, Bob Martin, took over and aims to reduce costs to stabilize performance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Gap logo is seen on the front of the company's store on Oxford Street in London, Britain, July 1, 2021. REUTERS/John Sibley/File Photo

site_title: Asia’s rising star is facing stiff growth headwinds
summary: Vietnam's post-pandemic economic growth is slowing, with first-quarter GDP growth at 3.3%, the weakest rate since the 2009 global financial crisis. The country is facing stiff headwinds from a global slowdown, export recession, and domestic property sector slowdown, affecting construction and manufacturing, which employ a third of the workforce. Despite these challenges, policymakers have taken action, including monetary interventions and a credit package for social housing development. The authors argue that while the export slowdown is cyclical, the property sector slowdown is a structural issue that requires a longer-term overhaul.

images.alt_text: epa10589067 A man rides a motorbike past the State Bank of Vietnam building in Hanoi, Vietnam, 24 April 2023. Vietnam's central bank plans to restructure loans for struggling businesses amid global slowdown. Vietnam’s gross domestic product (GDP) growth in the first quarter of 2023 slowed to 3.32 percent, according to the General Statistics Office  EPA-EFE/LUONG THAI LINH

site_title: Bankrupt crypto lender Genesis seeks mediator as DCG deal hits impasse
summary: Genesis Global Holdco, a bankrupt crypto lender, is seeking mediation to resolve a deal with its parent, Digital Currency Group (DCG), over $630 million in debt owed to Genesis. A mediator will be appointed over a two-day period prior to May 9, ahead of a mid-May due date. DCG claims a subset of creditors have decided to walk away from a settlement agreement, while Genesis believes mediation should be scheduled immediately to avoid a default. The mediation aims to reach a fair outcome for both parties.

site_title: Trade ties continue to evolve
summary: Poland and Singapore continue to strengthen trade ties, with Polish exports to Singapore tripling since 2019, driven by the country's support for Singapore's supply-chain diversification efforts and its own agricultural surplus. The two nations also cooperate in areas such as digital economy, IT, and space technology, with a memorandum of understanding recently signed between the Polish Space Technology Cluster and Singapore Space and Technology. The Ambassador of Poland to Singapore, Magdalena Bogdziewicz, emphasizes the potential for future growth and cooperation in these sectors, while also highlighting shared goals on promoting a rules-based international order.

site_title: At the heart of opportunities in Europe
summary: Poland's economy continues to grow, with a 30-year record of stable economic growth, making it an attractive investment destination. The country's GDP growth bounced back the fastest from the Covid-19 pandemic, with a 4.9% real growth in 2022. Poland's investment attractiveness is confirmed in both domestic and international rankings, with a record-breaking $3.7 billion in foreign direct investment in 2022. The government is supporting strategic industries and their supply chains with tax exemptions and grants, and is building a regional centre for talents and entrepreneurship.

site_title: India’s Tata Consumer misses profit view as domestic beverages drag
summary: Tata Consumer Products, the owner of Tata Tea and Tata Salt brands, reported a 23% increase in consolidated net profit to 2.69 billion rupees (S$43.9 million) in the fourth quarter ended Mar 31. The result fell short of analysts' expectations, as price hikes failed to offset tepid revenue growth in the domestic beverage business.

site_title: Overcoming the cybersecurity talent shortage together
summary: A global cybersecurity talent shortage hinders companies' efforts to protect their digital space. According to Splunk's 2023 State of Security report, nine in 10 IT leaders face challenges with cybersecurity staffing and/or skills. To overcome this, companies must evolve to tackle cybersecurity adequately, focusing on teamwork, data analytics, and automation tools. A converged platform for various security and IT functions can increase efficiency and reduce incident response time. Additionally, deploying security analytics and operations automation can improve threat detection, identify cyber risks, and automate remediation, making cybersecurity a crucial business priority.

images.alt_text: Cybersecurity, hackers, attacks, networks, concept. Credit: Pixabay

site_title: Kering first-quarter sales lag rivals with 1% rise
summary: Kering's first-quarter sales rose 1% to 5.08 billion euros, beating analyst expectations but lagging rivals such as LVMH and Hermes. Gucci's sales growth was slower than expected, and the brand's creative director left last November. Yves Saint Laurent reported 8% growth, while Bottega Veneta's sales were flat. The "other houses" division saw a 9% decline in revenues, and North America accounted for 27% of group sales in 2022. Kering's chairman and CEO François-Henri Pinault noted that trends improved during the period, but the group's performance remained mixed.

site_title: US dollar higher on earnings, economy worries as euro slips
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% to 101.37 against a basket of currencies, driven by worries about earnings and the global economy. The euro slipped to a 10-month low against the dollar, despite optimism about the eurozone economy. Central banks are set to cut their dollar liquidity operations, indicating the end of March's financial market volatility. The yen rose 0.3% to 133.855 per dollar, while the Swiss franc benefited from its safe-haven status.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit was filed late on Apr 24, about three hours after First Republic startled investors by disclosing it had lost US$102 billion, or 58 per cent, of its deposits in the first quarter.
The euro was up 0.25 per cent against the US dollar at US$1.1015, back above US$1.10 for the first time since it hit a 14-month high of US$1.10755 earlier this month.

site_title: US-listed China stocks see US$100 billion wipe-out in jittery month
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks have lost over $100 billion in market value in April due to geopolitical tensions, eclipsing optimism about the Asian giant's economy. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index is on track to send stocks lower for a sixth straight session, its longest streak of losses in over a year. Investors have trimmed their bets on China's stocks amid clashes with the US over Taiwan, TikTok, and semiconductor chips, with President Joe Biden set to sign an executive order limiting American investment in key parts of China's economy.

images.alt_text: Trader works at the post where Alibaba is traded on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 28, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: China rolls out plan to boost trade amid weakening global demand
summary: China's State Council has issued a plan to boost trade amid weakening global demand. The plan encourages Chinese banks and their overseas branches to provide financial support to automobile firms to expand in foreign markets. This move aims to stabilize the country's vital trade sector, which is crucial for economic growth and employs around 180 million people. The plan also facilitates visas for overseas businessmen to stimulate exports, particularly of electric vehicles, which saw an unexpected surge in March.

images.alt_text: Targeting proceeds of 9.63 billion yuan, Semiconductor Manufacturing Electronics Shaoxing is selling 1.69 billion shares at 5.69 yuan apiece on Shanghai’s Nasdaq-style STAR board, with subscriptions to begin on Wednesday (Apr 25).
China kept the PCR testing rule months after it had jettisoned other travel curbs like quarantine partly because other nations were testing passengers from the country due to fears over new variants

site_title: UK targets Big Tech to boost online consumer rights
summary: The UK has proposed a bill to strengthen consumer rights online, targeting tech giants with a global turnover above £25 billion or a UK turnover above £1 billion, potentially fining them up to 10% of their annual turnover. The bill aims to crack down on subscription traps, online scams, and fake reviews, giving the Competition and Markets Authority greater powers to tackle breaches of consumer rights law. The move also includes measures to prevent excessive dominance by a few tech firms and to protect consumers from unfair practices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logos of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google in a combination photo/File Photo

site_title: McDonald’s whips Q1 sales estimates with higher prices, more visits
summary: McDonald's exceeded Q1 sales estimates with a 12.6% global comparable sales increase, beating Wall Street forecasts. Revenue rose 4% to nearly US$5.9 billion, driven by higher menu prices and more customer visits. Net income increased to US$1.8 billion. The company also announced restructuring efforts, including layoffs and office closures, to improve operations. McDonald's is investing in menu upgrades, including softer buns and saucier Big Macs, and doubling down on meal deals and promotions.

site_title: US new home sales rise more than expected in March
summary: US new home sales rose 9.6% to an annual rate of 683,000 in March, exceeding analyst forecasts. The increase reflects the relative abundance of new home supply, which could last about eight months. New home sales remain 3.4% below the same period last year, while the median sales price increased to $449,800. The property sector has been sensitive to interest rates, which the Federal Reserve has rapidly raised to tackle high inflation.

images.alt_text: CUTLER BAY, FLORIDA - APRIL 20: A 'For Sale' sign advertises a home for sale on April 20, 2023 in Cutler Bay, Florida. In a report by the National Association of Realtors, existing-home sales edged 2.4% lower in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.44 million. In addition, sales declined 22.0% from one year ago..   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US govt is setting up an US$11 billion chips network to bolster national security
summary: The US government is launching a $11 billion network of advanced computer-chip design and engineering facilities to bolster national security and the US economy. The National Semiconductor Technology Center, an independent nonprofit, aims to produce the latest semiconductor technology, reduce design-to-commercialization time, and train workers. The program, authorized by the US Chips and Science Act, will work with industry partners, academia, and government to drive innovations and workforce development. The goal is to have the center operational by the end of the year, with a focus on regaining US leadership in semiconductor research and development.

site_title: Dulux maker Akzo Nobel’s price hikes, resilient volumes boost profit
summary: Akzo Nobel, the maker of Dulux and Flexa paints, reported a 5% decline in first-quarter volumes but beat forecasts with higher prices and better-than-expected demand in Europe and China. The company's adjusted operating income fell to 218 million euros, beating analyst expectations. Akzo reiterated its full-year outlook, citing falling raw material costs that should help profitability. The company plans not to significantly increase prices in the next few months, but may adjust pricing in countries with specific issues.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz launches E-Class, its last new combustion engine model
summary: Mercedes-Benz has launched its last new combustion engine model, the next-generation E-Class, which will go on sale in Europe in the third quarter of 2023. The car features a hybrid option and will be built in Germany and China. Mercedes aims to exclusively sell battery-electric vehicles globally by 2030, with a 40 billion euro investment in electrification between 2022 and 2030. The E-Class will be followed by models built on a new platform adapted for battery-powered cars, but the company will continue to import combustion engines from elsewhere until 2024.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz said it recorded an operating profit of 5.5 billion euros (S$8 billion) in the first quarter of 2023, up from 5.2 billion in the same period last year.
The SL 55 also has active aerodynamics to stabilise it at high speed, which is handy because the snarling V8 can propel it all the way to 295 km/h.

site_title: New voter ID requirement sparks concern ahead of English elections
summary: The UK is introducing a new voter ID requirement for local elections in England, sparking concerns that it may disenfranchise certain groups, particularly those without the right ID. The change, which applies to in-person voting only, has been criticized by campaigners, including the Electoral Reform Society, who argue that it may catch out voters and lead to low voter turnout. The Electoral Commission has stated that there are low risks of voter personation fraud, but groups such as trans people and those with learning disabilities are less likely to have the required ID.

images.alt_text: Barring a major calamity in coming months, it is most likely that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will lead the Conservatives into the next general election next year. But he has a massive political hill to climb.

site_title: What strong gold says about the weak dollar
summary: A weakening US dollar, driven by financial sanctions and rising gold prices, may signal a shift in global currency dynamics. Central banks, particularly in emerging markets like Russia, India, and China, are buying gold in record numbers, seeking a safe alternative to the dollar. This trend is driven by a desire to trade with each other directly, without relying on the dollar, and to challenge US currency supremacy. As the US faces increasing financial pressures, its overconfidence in the dollar's dominance may be misplaced, and a reevaluation of its financial power is necessary.

images.alt_text: The sharp appreciation of the US dollar through 2021 and much of last year caused a lot of problems in developed and developing countries alike; they will be thankful for the respite as the value of the greenback eases.
Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty, higher interest rates dim the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Three floors at Solitaire on Cecil sold for record S$4,300 psf at S$162.8 million
summary: The 17th, 18th, and 20th floors of the 20-storey freehold office project Solitaire on Cecil have been sold for S$162.8 million, setting a new record for strata office space in Singapore's Central Business District with a price of S$4,300 per square foot. This surpasses the previous record of S$4,196 psf. The sale is one of the largest strata office transactions since January 2022, and the buyer is a local company expanding its operations in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The 12th floor of the upcoming project Solitaire on Cecil has been sold for a record-breaking S$4,196 per square foot.

site_title: Trading of GK Goh’s shares suspended after cash offer closes
summary: Trading of GK Goh's shares has been suspended after a compulsory acquisition exercise closed, with the offeror holding 95.03% of the issued share capital. A voluntary unconditional cash offer closed on April 25, and a compulsory acquisition exercise will be held on or after May 22 to acquire the remaining shares, resulting in the company's delisting from the SGX mainboard.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
GK Goh no longer meets the Singapore Exchange (SGX)’s free-float requirement, under which an issuer must ensure at least 10 per cent of its total number of issued shares are held by the public.
The offerer intends to restructure GK Goh’s asset mix if the proposed delisting and privatisation is successful.

site_title: AI lawyers and judges? Not just yet
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) has sparked debate about its potential to disrupt the work of lawyers and judges. However, experts argue that AI, such as ChatGPT, is unlikely to replace human professionals in the near future. While AI can augment tasks like document review and produce rough opinions, it lacks the creativity, nuance, and ability to tackle novel issues that human lawyers and judges possess. AI's reliance on biased datasets and lack of transparency in decision-making processes also pose significant concerns, making it unsuitable for replacing lawyers and judges, at least not anytime soon.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT: Has artificial intelligence come for our jobs?

site_title: Corporate access to capital worsens after bank turmoil: Janus Henderson
summary: Corporate access to capital worsened after bank turmoil in March, accelerating a likely recession, according to a report by Janus Henderson Investors. Lending conditions have tightened for nine months, with debt loads, capital market access, and earnings under pressure. Rate-sensitive sectors, such as real estate and banking, are most vulnerable to recession. Credit spreads are expected to remain volatile, and corporate defaults are likely to rise, with the scale depending on the economic scenario.

images.alt_text: The extent to which ESG investment strategies deliver better returns than their conventional equivalents remains a topic of debate.
The ECB has added at least 50 basis points in six successive meetings but some policymakers remain cautious as past hikes are yet to fully filter into the economy.
The manufacturing sector's Purchasing Managers Indices of 41 economies and regions showed that 60 per cent reported a contraction in March.

site_title: EU singles out 19 tech giants for online content rules
summary: The European Union has designated 19 tech giants, including Alphabet subsidiaries, Meta Platforms units, Microsoft businesses, and Twitter, for implementing landmark online content rules under the Digital Services Act (DSA). The 19 companies, such as Google, Facebook, and YouTube, must adopt risk management, conduct external audits, and adopt a code of conduct by August. The rules aim to make the internet safer, with EU industry chief Thierry Breton stating that these companies have "special responsibilities" to achieve this goal.

site_title: EU seals carbon market reform to speed cuts in greenhouse gases
summary: The European Union has given final approval to a carbon market reform aimed at cutting 55% of greenhouse-gas emissions by 2030. The reform includes a new carbon border tax on imports, a broader emissions trading scheme, and counting of emissions from vehicles and homes. A 88-billion-euro social climate fund will be created to compensate for the cost of the green shift. The tax on imports is expected to raise 14 billion euros annually for the EU budget and will initially cover polluting sectors. The reform supports the EU's goal of reducing emissions to 1990 levels by 2030.

images.alt_text: The energy crisis has raised the prospect of more long term sustainable debt issuance to finance Europe's energy transition.

site_title: Benefiting from the post-pandemic pivot
summary: China's post-pandemic pivot is expected to benefit its domestic economy and have spillover effects on Asia-Pacific economies. The country's removal of zero-Covid restrictions has led to a surge in outbound travel, entertainment, and dining, boosting tourism-dependent markets. China's monetary policy is supportive, with low interest rates and reduced borrowing costs encouraging lending. The country's export sector may be impacted by global economic slowdowns, but local-currency bonds and Asian bonds issued by companies exposed to China's domestic demand growth are expected to benefit. Asia-Pacific economies can expect a 0.4% GDP boost from China's recovery, with tourism and entertainment likely to be the primary beneficiaries.

images.alt_text: Activity in China has gained momentum since the lifting of stringent zero-Covid policy in December, but investors remain cautious as businesses grapple with debt risks, structural woes and a slowing global economy.
Traders continued to cite geopolitical tensions as a key deterrent even as the US plans last week to limit investments in key parts of China’s economy were of little surprise.

site_title: HSBC’s private bank in Asia expects strong net new inflows in 2023
summary: HSBC's private bank in Asia expects strong net new inflows in 2023, with US$15 billion in net new invested assets reported in 2022. Momentum has carried into the first quarter of 2023, driven by efforts to establish an onshore private banking presence in the region. Regional head Siew Meng Tan expects further inflows, citing India's market size as a compelling opportunity, with onshore private banking services to be rolled out in the country later this year.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
HSBC wrote in a letter to shareholders that “the board strongly believes that (the bank) should focus on executing the current strategy that is delivering”.

The war of words between HSBC and Ping An has escalated last week ahead of the bank’s annual general meeting on May 5, at which shareholders will vote on proposals including the strategic review and whether the bank should be forced to boost dividends.

site_title: Russia revives fried chicken chain Rostic’s after KFC owner leaves
summary: Russia's fried chicken chain Rostic's has begun reopening at former KFC locations after the US parent company Yum! Brands sold its Russian KFC restaurants and rights to the Rostic's brand to local franchisee Smart Service. The deal, finalized last week, includes all Russian KFC restaurants and the Rostic's trademark. Smart Service's leader, Konstantin Kotov, announced that the firm will support franchisees who choose to remain as KFC, rather than forcing them to switch to the Rostic's brand.

site_title: Spotify passes 500 million active users, widens Q1 loss
summary: Spotify reported 515 million monthly active users as of March, beating expectations, and 210 million paying subscribers. The company posted a Q1 operating loss of 156 million euros, wider than expected, attributed to higher headcount and changes in social charges. Revenue grew 14% to 3 billion euros, short of analyst expectations. Despite strong subscriber growth, Spotify has yet to post a quarterly profit since its launch.

images.alt_text: “Everything’s looking much better now!,” Spotify Status said in a tweet.
Netflix offered a lighter-than-expected forecast last week.

site_title: Keppel Data Centres, Woodside Energy ink deal that will allow them to develop hydrogen supply chains
summary: Keppel Data Centres and Woodside Energy have signed a non-binding agreement to develop a hydrogen supply chain. The deal includes a potential purchase of 1,000 tonnes of liquid hydrogen per day by 2030, which will be used to cool data centres and reduce emissions. Woodside's proposed facility in Perth, Western Australia, will also be part of the supply chain. The partnership aims to support Singapore's and Australia's green economy goals and accelerate Keppel Data Centres' decarbonisation efforts towards net zero emissions.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Keppel Data Centres and Shell plan to leverage on each other’s expertise to explore the commercial and technical practicalities of establishing a low-carbon energy hub.

site_title: UK car ownership rises for first time since pandemic
summary: UK car ownership rose for the first time since the pandemic, increasing by 0.36% or 124,393 cars to 35.15 million in 2022, slightly less than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. This marks the end of a two-year decline, the first such period in over 100 years. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) reported the data, indicating a return to pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Output in the factory sector has been largely flat since mid-2022, along with the broader economy, with construction the sole bright spot, according to official data.

site_title: UFC owner Endeavor to sell sports school IMG Academy in US$1.25 billion deal
summary: Endeavor Group Holdings, owner of the UFC, is selling IMG Academy to EQT's Asian unit in an all-cash deal valued at $1.25 billion. The deal comes days after the UFC's merger with World Wrestling Entertainment to form a new, $21 billion entertainment giant. IMG Academy will partner with Nord Anglia Education, operating premium international schools in 33 countries. The sale is part of Endeavor's efforts to focus on its core businesses following the UFC and WWE merger.

images.alt_text: WWE executive chairman Vince McMahon will retain his role in the new company, which will be majority owned by Endeavor with a 51 per cent stake, while WWE investors will own the rest.

site_title: 3M to cut 6,000 positions globally to improve cash flow
summary: 3M announced plans to cut approximately 6,000 positions globally to improve cash flow and reduce costs. The restructuring aims to focus on high-growth businesses, including automotive electrification and home improvement.
