The company expects annual pre-tax savings of $700-$900 million and reported an adjusted profit of $1.97 per share for the quarter ended March 31. This move follows interest rate hikes and consumer spending cuts, as 3M raises prices to offset surging commodity costs.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on mixed earnings, First Republic shares plunge
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 47.06 points, or 0.14%, to 33,828.34, due to mixed earnings reports. First Republic Bank's plunge in deposits stoked concerns about the banking sector. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 opening 10.61 points lower, or 0.26%, at 4,126.43, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 68.40 points, or 0.57%, to 11,968.81.

site_title: Sluggish China steel demand drags iron ore lower
summary: China's sluggish steel demand has led to a slump in iron ore prices, with the most-traded September iron ore on the Dalian Commodity Exchange falling 1.9% to 711 yuan (S$137.32) a tonne. Some Chinese steel mills have started limiting production, with 52 of 126 blast furnaces in Tangshan city going into maintenance. This comes despite a 8.8% year-on-year increase in China's infrastructure investment in the first quarter.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) This file photo taken on May 1, 2018 shows a worker handling steel cable at a steel factory in Lianyungang in China's eastern Jiangsu province.
China opened trade in iron ore futures to foreign investors on May 4, 2018 on the market of the north-eastern city of Dalian, aiming to boost its pricing clout for one of its top imports, in one additional signal of opening up amidst a trade row with the US. / AFP PHOTO / - / China OUT

site_title: IReit Global posts 87% occupancy rates for Q1 2023
summary: IReit Global reported 87% occupancy rates for Q1 2023, down from 88.3% in Q4 2022, primarily due to lower occupancy at Spanish properties. Rents rose 3.4% year-over-year, driven by step-up rents and indexing to the consumer price index. The weighted average lease expiry was 4.8 years, while aggregate leverage stood at 32.3%. The company expects the European office market to remain muted in 2023.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Prepping your portfolio to ride through the seasons
summary: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) predict a global economic downturn, or "winter," with a 2.8% growth forecast for 2023, down from 2.9% previously. The manufacturing sector's Purchasing Managers Indices (PMI) show 60% contraction in March, and the Composite Leading Index (CLI) predicts a 5.4% decline in GDP in the second quarter. To protect portfolios, investors should cut exposure to cyclical stocks, increase interest rate-sensitive growth stocks, and stock up on defensive stocks. Emerging markets, government bonds, and alternative assets like hedge funds and precious metals can also provide protection.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 08, 2022 Cars are seen on the assembly line during a tour of the Tesla Giga Texas manufacturing facility ahead of the "Cyber Rodeo" grand opening party on April 7, 2022 in Austin, Texas. - American factory growth sped up in May after slowing in the prior two months, even as employment contracted and firms continue to face supply challenges, according to a business survey released June 1, 2022. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)
Rakuten Bank soared after raising 83.3 billion yen (S$825.8 million) in Japan’s largest IPO since 2018 – though, the pop came after the initial price range had been cut.

site_title: The only way to stop bank runs is to get rid of banks
summary: A bank run can occur as long as a bank has deposits that require immediate payment, forcing it to sell long-term or risky assets to meet the demand. To prevent bank runs, deposit insurance and liquidity coverage ratios can be strengthened, but these measures only protect against economic stresses, not panic-driven runs. The only way to guarantee an end to bank runs is to create a narrow bank system, where deposits are matched with cash-like assets, making banks essentially utility companies that make payments but don't create money. This system could be achieved by increasing deposit insurance limits and indexing them to inflation or money supply growth.

images.alt_text: First Republic came into intense focus after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank collapsed last month.

site_title: Union Power set to scoop up failed Sun Electric’s solar assets
summary: Union Power, a Singaporean electricity retailer, has submitted a "binding offer" to acquire the solar assets of failed Sun Electric group for S$2.2 million. The assets, held by Sun Electric Energy Assets under judicial management, may also include solar panels on JTC rooftops. The sale needs approval from secured creditors, who could receive around S$1.6 million from the sale proceeds. This comes after Sun Electric Power, Singapore's first solar company, went under liquidation in 2020.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Matthew Peloso, CEO of Sun Electric

site_title: Wanda Unit’s HK IPO application lapses for third time
summary: Wanda Group's management unit, Zhuhai Wanda Commercial Management Group, failed to list shares in Hong Kong for a third time, lapsing its IPO application. If the deal doesn't happen by the end of 2023, Wanda may need to repurchase about 30 billion yuan (S$5.8 billion) of equity from pre-IPO investors. The company's billionaire chairman, Wang Jianlin, acknowledged difficulties during an internal meeting, but stated the company can overcome challenges. Wanda is still seeking approval from regulators, despite a previous "received" status marked by the China Securities Regulatory Commission.

images.alt_text: Guo founded Fosun’s predecessor with three university classmates in 1992.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the electric vehicle (EV) factory of China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group in Tianjin, China October 20, 2021. Picture taken October 20, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun/File Photo
Wanda chairman Wang Jianlin told an internal meeting on Friday that the unit’s IPO was facing difficulties, and vowed to cut the company’s debt in the next two years.

site_title: UK factory orders contract again but price pressures ease: CBI
summary: The UK factory sector's output contracted, with orders and production flat since mid-2022, but easing inflation pressures. The CBI's monthly gauge of industrial orders held at -20, while stocks of finished goods rose to +19, indicating weak output ahead. Cost pressures have slowed for four consecutive quarters, and employment expectations have touched their lowest reading since January 2021. This data suggests the Bank of England may ease interest rates, providing relief from inflation concerns.

site_title: ECB set to step down to 25 bps move on May 4, at least one more expected
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to raise interest rates by 25 basis points on May 4, followed by a possible increase to 3.5% or higher in June, according to economists polled by Reuters. This would be the seventh consecutive rate hike, as core inflation remains above the ECB's 2% target. Despite some policymakers' caution, the ECB is expected to continue its "high for longer" approach to combat inflation, with the deposit rate peaking at 3.5% in June.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The building of the European Central Bank (ECB) is seen in fog before the monthly news conference following the ECB's monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, December 15, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: UK borrowing remains “eye-watering” despite beating forecast
summary: The UK's budget deficit for the 2022/23 financial year reached £139.2 billion, exceeding forecasts but still smaller than predicted. Despite this, borrowing remains "eye-watering" due to government support for energy bills, which cost £8 billion in March and £41.2 billion over six months. The figures suggest a slightly better-than-expected performance in recent months, with the economy expected to grow in 2023.

images.alt_text: Britain’s consumer price inflation reached 10.1 per cent in March, coming in stronger than expected as food and drink costs surged.

site_title: China completes landmark national real estate registration system
summary: China has completed a national real estate registration system, a decade-long project aimed at boosting transparency in ownership. The unified database will help regulate the housing market and force corrupt officials to disclose illicit funds. Over 790 million registration certificates have been issued nationwide. A national database is also expected to pave the way for China to implement a property tax in the future, providing the central government with more control over the market. This move is seen as a significant step towards addressing corruption and promoting transparency in China's real estate sector.

site_title: Tokio Marine considers US$1 billion South-east Asia life unit sale
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings, a Tokyo-listed insurance firm, is considering a sale of its life insurance business in South-east Asia valued at approximately US$1 billion. The company is working with an adviser to gauge investor interest in its units in Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand. A formal sale process may commence in the coming months, but no decision has been made. This move aims to focus on core operations and improve profitability, following the company's disciplined mergers and acquisitions strategy.

images.alt_text: Bonds from sovereign and quasi sovereign names, such as Indofood and Pertamina, have seen greater investor interest.
Startups in Japan raised a record 877.4 billion yen in 2022.

site_title: UPS profit falls on lower e-commerce demand
summary: UPS reported a fall in first-quarter profit to US$2.20 per share, down from US$3.05 a year earlier, due to softening e-commerce demand. The global shipping downturn has squeezed margins for most operators, with delivery firms struggling with bloated capacity after the pandemic-driven e-commerce bubble deflated. Despite this, UPS has benefited from a focus on high-margin parcels and cost control measures. The result was in line with analysts' expectations of US$2.21 per share.

site_title: Biden, 80, makes 2024 presidential run official: ‘Let’s finish this job’
summary: US President Joe Biden, 80, has officially announced his candidacy for a second term in 2024, despite concerns over his age. In a video, Biden declared it's his job to defend American democracy and vowed to fight Republican efforts to limit women's healthcare, cut Social Security, and restrict abortion. Biden's re-election bid faces a tough election map, with some Democrats questioning his ability to serve a second term. Trump, a potential Republican opponent, criticized Biden's record on immigration, inflation, and the US pullout from Afghanistan.

site_title: MHA refutes reports of 3,500 high-net-worth individuals becoming Singapore citizens in 2023
summary: The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has clarified that a report stating up to 3,500 high-net-worth individuals from China would become Singapore citizens in 2023 was "highly misleading" and lacked credible basis. The report was based on an interview with Andrew Amoils from New World Wealth, but MHA does not know how he arrived at the figure. MHA noted that SC applications for 2023 have not been decided yet and having high net worth does not guarantee citizenship, with a suite of factors considered for citizenship decisions.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Other cities listed as the world’s top 10 wealthiest include Hong Kong, Beijing and Shanghai – which were 7th, 8th and 9th place respectively.

site_title: PepsiCo raises annual forecasts on buoyant demand, price hikes
summary: PepsiCo raised its annual sales and profit forecasts after beating first-quarter revenue estimates. The company reported a 16% increase in average prices and a 2% decline in organic volume. Sales at its North America beverage unit rose 8%, and organic revenue at its Frito-Lay unit increased 16%. PepsiCo now expects 2023 organic revenue to rise 8%, up from its prior forecast of 6%. The company also raised its annual core earnings per share to $7.27.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bottles of Pepsi are pictured at a grocery store in Pasadena, California, U.S., July 11, 2017.   REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors takes one-time 10.5 billion yen hit from China woes
summary: Mitsubishi Motors will take a one-time loss of 10.5 billion yen ($104.8 million) due to slowing sales at its China unit, attributed to mounting competition in the country's largest auto market. The company made no changes to its full-year results forecast, as the impact had already been incorporated into its previous outlook. The move reflects the challenges faced by foreign carmakers, including Mitsubishi, in China's electric-car drive and growing market for battery-powered vehicles.

images.alt_text: Hyundai reported a net profit of 3.3 trillion won for the January-March period versus a profit of 1.6 trillion won a year earlier.

site_title: The stealth campaign that’s getting kids hooked on chess
summary: Chess.com's website and app have seen a significant surge in popularity, with daily active users increasing from 5.4 million to over 11 million since early November. The game's appeal to teenagers and young adults has been attributed to a stealth campaign by Chess.com to rebrand chess as a fun and accessible game. The company has introduced features such as online influencers, computer opponents with personalities, and a bot called Mittens that has become a viral sensation. While the long-term effects of chess on cognitive development are unclear, many players and parents believe it has benefits for the brain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: TikTok logo is displayed on the smartphone while standing on the U.S. flag in this illustration picture taken, November 8, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Lee Tilghman in Brooklyn neighbourhood on March 24, 2023.

site_title: Nestle beats quarterly sales estimates with price hikes
summary: Nestle reported a 5.6% increase in quarterly sales to 23.5 billion Swiss francs (S$35.4 billion) in the first quarter, beating estimates. The company offset weak sales volumes with price hikes, including a 9.8% increase in Purina pet food prices. Real internal growth, or sales volumes, fell 0.5% during the quarter.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Union Power has submitted a binding offer to acquire Sun Electric's solar assets for S$2.2 million. Commercial shophouse sales in Q1 fell to 28 transactions, the lowest in nearly three years, due to cautious investors. The NTUC prioritizes securing workers' positions in the future economy, while the SBF encourages Singapore firms to attend a Shanghai trade fair. The MAS proposes enhanced safeguards for financial product prospecting and marketing, and the MHA refuted reports of 3,500 high-net-worth individuals becoming Singapore citizens in 2023.

site_title: Public transport fare formula tweaked to make fare changes more predictable for passengers
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) has updated the public transport fare formula to reduce volatility for both operators and commuters. The new formula, effective from 2023 to 2027, removes passenger demand from the calculation, instead using a fixed "capacity adjustment factor" of 1.1% per year to account for network capacity changes. The PTC retained three components that reflect core inflation, wages, and energy prices, while excluding the network capacity factor (NCF) due to its volatility during the Covid-19 pandemic. The changes aim to balance fare affordability and financial sustainability.

site_title: GM raises full-year profit forecast, citing strong pricing, demand
summary: General Motors (GM) raised its full-year profit forecast by $500 million, citing strong pricing and demand. The company expects pre-tax profits between $11 billion and $13 billion, with automotive cash flow ranging from $5.5 billion to $7.5 billion. Higher prices added nearly $1,800 to GM's North American pre-tax profit, offsetting increased costs. However, sales in China fell by 23% due to intense competition from domestic electric vehicle brands. GM reaffirmed its goal of producing 400,000 EVs in North America by mid-2024.

images.alt_text: GM is diversifying its battery vendors to better secure capacity of the crucial components to support its electrification goals, as the Detroit-based company attempts to catch up with Tesla.

site_title: Travellers lose ultra-cheap first-class tickets after ANA about-face
summary: ANA Holdings is cancelling and fully refunding business- and first-class tickets sold at significantly discounted prices due to a currency conversion error on its Vietnam website. The error, caused by a technical issue in a fare quote system, resulted in US$10,000 tickets being sold for a few hundred dollars. The airline will notify affected customers and apologise for the inconvenience, honouring the tickets for those who booked and paid quickly before the error was discovered.

images.alt_text: A member of the ground crew is seen on the tarmac next to a passenger jet from Japanese carrier All Nippon Airways (ANA) at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda on February 2, 2023. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: UK’s biggest fund manager says ESG backlash misses the point
summary: UK's largest asset manager, Legal & General Investment Management (LGIM), says the politicization of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Corporate Governance) investment strategies overshadows their ability to deliver better returns for shareholders. Head of investment stewardship Michael Marks argues that focusing on financially material issues such as people, health, and climate is more effective than using the ESG label. Despite criticism from some Republicans, LGIM continues to support shareholder resolutions and engage with companies on sustainability issues, citing the impact of their scale and investor coordination.

images.alt_text: Lara Wolters, the EU parliament member responsible for ushering CSDDD through the chamber, said she’s bracing for a “tough” battle with the finance industry.

site_title: UBS pulled in US$28 billion in run-up to Credit Suisse deal
summary: UBS attracted $28 billion in new assets from wealthy clients in the months leading up to its acquisition of Credit Suisse, with $7 billion coming in the 10 days after the takeover was announced. This influx of assets provides a significant boost to the combined firms' fee-generating capabilities. However, revenue at UBS' wealth business fell short of estimates due to "subdued" client activity amid market turmoil. The acquisition is part of a broader restructuring effort under new CEO Sergio Ermotti, who aims to integrate Credit Suisse's assets and risk profile.

images.alt_text: During the global financial crisis, it was UBS, not Credit Suisse, that took the lion’s share of support from the state.

“Credit Suisse had such a high capital adequacy ratio and yet, the market gave up on it judging it had a weak business model,” Tomoko Amaya, the Financial Services Agency’s (FSA) vice-minister for international affairs, said in an interview.

site_title: UK mortgage rates triple in 'nasty shock' for homeowners
summary: UK mortgage rates have tripled, affecting over 1.4 million homeowners who must refinance at significantly higher interest rates. The average rate for a two-year fixed mortgage is now 5.35%, while a five-year rate is 4.74%. This is expected to peak in the next couple of months, causing financial strain for many homeowners. Experts warn of a housing affordability crisis, with house prices falling and demand for new loans declining. The UK's economic output has been impacted, ranking it at the bottom of G20 peers, according to the International Monetary Fund.

images.alt_text: Overall in the US, mortgage applications for purchases have declined from early 2022 as borrowing costs rose and sidelined many homebuyers.
Housing prices in Germany had started to decline last year as higher interest rates spooked buyers, but increased construction expenses have slowed the pace of new projects.

site_title: Chinese-owned e-commerce platform Temu expands to Europe
summary: Temu, a Chinese-owned e-commerce platform, has expanded to European markets including France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, and the UK. The platform, which launched in the US last September, sells shoes, jewelry, beauty accessories, and home goods at ultra-low prices directly from Chinese merchants. The expansion marks Temu's entry into new regions, following its previous availability in the US, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

images.alt_text: Temu topped US app download rankings in early April, a spot it held since January.

site_title: In an instant-reaction age, patience will win the day
summary: Investors must adopt a patient approach, as reacting to news too quickly can lead to missed opportunities. The stock market is driven by instant reactions, but this doesn't guarantee success. In contrast, companies like Netflix, which focus on original content, have seen significant growth. Meanwhile, regulatory shifts, such as those related to stablecoins and cryptocurrencies, are emerging in Asia. As a result, investors should consider a long-term perspective, rather than reacting impulsively to market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Netflix offered a lighter-than-expected forecast last week.

site_title: Philippines’ SM Prime aims to raise record US$1 billion in Reit listing
summary: Philippines' SM Prime Holdings plans to raise up to $1 billion by listing its real estate investment trust (Reit) unit in the second half of this year, subject to market conditions. This could be the country's largest on record, rivaling Monde Nissin's 2021 IPO. SM Prime's president, Jeffrey Lim, announced the plan during a news conference, but did not provide a specific timeline for the IPO. The company aims to develop malls and offices, and the listing is expected to provide a significant influx of capital.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid weak regional sentiment; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to 3,296.56 on April 25, amid weak regional sentiment. The broader market saw 326 losers beat 231 gainers, with 1.6 billion securities worth S$1.1 billion changing hands. Japan's Nikkei 225 edged up 0.1%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declined 1.7%. Local banks DBS and OCBC ended the day mixed, with Singtel shedding 3.2% to close at S$2.46.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Over the past quarter year to date, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has delivered 16 vessels, translating to 28 per cent of its delivery target of 57 vessels this year.

site_title: China to scrap PCR test for inbound travellers in latest easing
summary: China has scrapped the requirement for inbound travellers to provide a negative PCR test result, allowing them to show negative rapid antigen test results instead. The move comes as air travel in and out of China recovers slowly, with international flights only reaching 12.4% of 2019 levels. The decision follows other countries lifting testing requirements for Chinese travellers, amid concerns over new variants. However, other travel deterrents, such as high airfares and limited airline capacity, remain, and a full recovery in global air travel is unlikely until at least a year.

site_title: Central banks cut US dollar operations with Fed as market stress eases
summary: The European Central Bank, Bank of Japan, Bank of England, and Swiss National Bank have reduced their US dollar operations with the US Federal Reserve from daily to weekly tenders, effective May 1. This decision follows improvements in US dollar funding conditions, which eased market stress after the failure of Silicon Valley Bank and the sale of Credit Suisse. The central banks will continue to provide liquidity as warranted by market conditions.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank downgrades HRnetGroup to ‘hold’ on economic slowdown
summary: Maybank Securities downgraded its rating on HRnetGroup to "hold" from "buy" due to a slowdown in Singapore's economy, citing weaker-than-expected GDP growth in the first fiscal quarter. The downgrade comes as the company's earnings are expected to decline amid lower placement volumes, particularly in its professional recruitment segment. Analysts anticipate a technical recession in Singapore if China's reopening boost fails to materialize in Q2.

images.alt_text: HRnetGroup said the S$1 million in share capital is being used to fund the increased working capital requirements of the subsidiary, RecruitFirst Taiwan, and its branches in Taipei and Kaoshiung.

HRnetGroup operates two main businesses in professional recruitment and flexible staffing, deriving 75 per cent of revenue from flexible staffing. It is the first recruitment agency to seek a listing on the Singapore Exchange.
Earnings per share for the period stood at 3.30 Singapore cents per share, up from 2.95 Singapore cents per share in the same period of 2021.

The positive outlook comes as the analyst noted how Singapore has shown resilience in the face of the pandemic, global volatility surrounding the Russia-Ukraine war, US-China tensions as well as supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Novartis, helped by cost cuts, raises full-year outlook
summary: Novartis raised its full-year earnings outlook due to cost cuts, a breast cancer drug trial success, and progress in boosting output of a prostate cancer treatment. The company expects group core operating income to grow by a "high single digit to low double digit" percentage, exceeding its previous forecast of a "mid-to-high single digit" increase. First-quarter sales rose 3% to $12.95 billion, driven by strong revenue from psoriasis and arthritis drug Cosentyx, as well as new launches in multiple sclerosis and breast cancer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at the new cell and gene therapy factory of Swiss drugmaker Novartis in Stein, Switzerland, November 28, 2019. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Apple's 'Napoleon' wows movie-theatre bosses at CinemaCon
summary: Apple's historical epic "Napoleon," starring Joaquin Phoenix, wowed movie theatre bosses at CinemaCon on its opening night. The film, directed by Ridley Scott, will be released exclusively in theatres this November, underlining Apple's shift towards big-screen releases for its films. The event marked a significant pivot for the streaming giant, with Sony Pictures chairman Tom Rothman praising the film as "epic" and "old school, big screen." This move is seen as a strategic move to boost awareness of Apple's streaming platform and potentially generate a financial windfall for Hollywood studios.

site_title: UBS first-quarter profit halves as costs of old toxic debt mount
summary: UBS Group reported a 52% slide in first-quarter profit to US$1 billion, due to a US$665 million set aside to cover toxic mortgage-backed securities from the 2007 financial crisis. The bank is preparing to integrate Credit Suisse, which faced significant outflows of assets in the first quarter. Despite this, UBS received US$42 billion in inflows and US$28 billion in net new money for its flagship wealth management division. The bank's CEO, Sergio Ermotti, is making progress in resolving the legacy matter with the US Department of Justice.

images.alt_text: A logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen in Zurich, Switzerland March 29, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: BOJ’s Ueda vows to keep rates low for now, signals chance of future hike
summary: BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda has vowed to keep Japan's monetary policy ultra-loose for now, aiming to achieve a 2% inflation target sustainably. However, he signaled the possibility of raising interest rates if inflation and wage growth exceed expectations. The BOJ is expected to maintain its monetary settings unchanged at its upcoming policy meeting, with Ueda emphasizing the need for a cautious approach to avoid undershooting inflation forecasts.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda participates in a news conference at the Fairmont Washington D.C. Georgetown hotel in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Japan’s business services inflation hits 8-year high in fiscal 2022
summary: Japan's business-to-business service inflation hit an 8-year high in fiscal 2022, rising 1.8% compared to the previous year. This increase is driven by solid domestic demand and a tight job market. The data may prompt the Bank of Japan to phase out its massive stimulus program. Hotel fees, in particular, rose 32.4% due to the removal of Covid-19 curbs. This marks the 25th consecutive month of year-on-year increase, driven by rebounding tourism.

images.alt_text: People walk as they make their way at a shopping district in Tokyo, Japan December 23, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: First Republic Bank deposits tumble more than US$100 billion as it explores options
summary: First Republic Bank's deposits plummeted over $100 billion in the first quarter, exceeding expectations despite beating profit projections. The bank, which received a $30-billion lifeline from major US banks, plans to slash expenses by 20-25% and cut borrowings from the Federal Reserve. Despite stabilizing deposits since March 27, the lender faces a tough road to revive its fortunes, with analysts citing a large mortgage portfolio and less valuable investment portfolio due to rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A First Republic Bank branch is pictured in Midtown Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo/File Photo

site_title:
Piracy declines but violent attacks
and kidnappings continue
summary: Piracy incidents continue to occur in West Africa, despite declining overall levels. Two recent incidents involved small tankers: the Monjasa Reformer, which went missing for six days after being boarded by pirates on March 25, and the Success 9, which was boarded by unidentified persons on April 10. Six crew members from the Monjasa Reformer were kidnapped, while all 20 crew members from the Success 9, including a Singapore citizen, were safely rescued and returned to port on April 16.

images.alt_text:
This undated and unlocated handout picture released by Monjasa shows the Liberian-flagged oil tanker, Monjasa Reformer, owned by Monjasa, and technically managed by Montec Ship Management. - A Danish-owned Liberian-flagged oil tanker was boarded by pirates over the weekend in the Gulf of Guinea, the owner said on March 28, 2023, adding that contact with 16 crew members had been lost.
The 135-metre-long Monjasa Reformer "experienced an emergency situation" on March 25, 2023 about 140 nautical miles west of Port Pointe-Noire in Congo-Brazzaville, owner Monjasa said. site_title: Renault seeks software architecture on par with Tesla by 2026
summary: Renault plans to develop a software architecture comparable to Tesla's by 2026, aiming to reduce complexity and enable remote updates. The "software-defined vehicle" design will be used in its "Ampere" electric-vehicle entity, developed with Google and Qualcomm. This will improve resale value, support pricing power, and avoid 1.5 billion euros in R&D expenses. The new architecture will be introduced in mid-2026 with the "Flexevan" electric van program, followed by the Alpine brand and all Renault models.

images.alt_text: The carmaker is in the middle of a turnaround and is betting on higher-margin and electric cars to boost profits.

The move is part of Renault’s efforts to secure crucial components and seize control of the value chain of its future unit Ampere, dedicated to electric vehicles and software which it plans to list on the stock market by the end of the year.

site_title: MAS proposes stricter standards for prospecting, marketing financial products
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes stricter standards for financial institutions and their representatives when prospecting for customers and marketing financial products. The proposals aim to provide consumers with accurate information, professional advice, and sufficient time to consider their financial decisions. MAS will legislate new notices for investment products and long-term accident and health policies, and issue guidelines for digital prospecting and marketing activities to better protect consumers' interests. The consultation papers are available on the MAS website until June 30.

images.alt_text:
ST20220719-202264388695-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
MAS Building at 10 Shenton Way on July 19, 2022.
Singapore's financial sector went from strength to strength, buoyed by broad-based growth but inflationary pressures, wobbly global growth and global tightening monetary policies have weighed on the central bank's fiscal performance.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Tuesday (July 19) announced at its annual review that it clocked a net loss of $7.4 billion for the financial year ended March 31, 2022 - the first time in nine years. The loss came from lower investment gains, a large negative foreign exchange translation effect, and higher interest expenses.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: More banks join European instant payments pilot from end 2023
summary: The European Payments Initiative (EPI) has acquired two payment firms and secured backing from more banks, scaling back its ambitions to take on US payment giants Visa and Mastercard. EPI plans to launch an instant payments service in Europe by the end of 2023, initially covering France and Germany, with a broader market launch in early 2024. The service will include online and mobile shopping payments, subscription instalments, and buy now, pay later options, and will be developed on a single brand digital wallet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 20 and 50 Euro bank note are seen in front of a cash drawer with Swiss francs in Bern January 16, 2015. REUTERS/Thomas Hodel

site_title: Richard Branson disrespecting Singapore’s judicial system with death penalty allegations: MHA
summary: British billionaire Richard Branson has faced criticism from Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) for making allegations about a court case involving a drug trafficker, Tangaraju Suppiah. Branson claimed in a blog post that Tangaraju's conviction did not meet the standards for criminal conviction, but the MHA stated that the conviction was based on thorough and comprehensive evidence. The MHA also disputed Branson's claims that Singapore's use of the death penalty is ineffective as a deterrent and that the country disproportionately uses capital punishment on minorities.

images.alt_text: Richard Branson, chairman and founder of Virgin Group Ltd., pauses during a news conference in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Oct. 26, 2012. Branson said Virgin Atlantic is applying for more India routes and seeking extra slots at Heathrow Airport. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Richard Branson

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,322.83 points. Global markets closed mixed or flat overnight, with US indices ending mixed. The top-traded counters included Thai Beverage and Genting Singapore, while Singtel fell 0.8%. Local banks traded mixed, with DBS rising 0.2% and OCBC falling 0.3%.

images.alt_text: A man wearing a protective face mask walks past the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in the central business district on 24 February 2022.

site_title: NTUC prioritises future-proofing workers, helping specific groups
summary: NTUC, Singapore's labour movement, prioritizes future-proofing workers by supporting groups such as senior workers, caregivers, and platform workers. The organization aims to ensure workers keep pace with technological change through training and placement ecosystems. Measures include the progressive wage model, career progression models, flexible work arrangements, and advocacy for higher retirement and re-employment ages. NTUC also supports workers' rights, workplace fairness legislation, and mental well-being. The labour movement works with tripartite partners to tackle challenges and translate research into real-world solutions.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
This round of cuts, which will last till Thursday, should bring the total positions eliminated to around 4,000, the company said.
“(The) tripartite partners encourage service buyers to work closely with service providers to renegotiate ongoing contracts where reasonable,” said Zaqy.

site_title: Hyundai Motor finalises US$5 billion US battery venture, doubles Q1 profit
summary: Hyundai Motor has finalized a US$5 billion electric vehicle (EV) battery joint venture with SK On in the US, producing 35GWh of battery cells for 300,000 EVs by 2025. The move follows US requirements for 50% of EV battery components to be produced in North America. The company reported a net profit of 3.3 trillion won, more than doubling its Q1 profit, thanks to a rise in vehicle output and strong demand for its sport-utility vehicles.

images.alt_text: Visitors walk past the logo of Hyundai during a press preview of the 2023 Seoul Mobility Show at the KINTEX exhibition hall in Goyang on March 30, 2023. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Rolex Daytona prices outperform after brand debuts new model
summary: The Bloomberg Subdial Watch Index reports that pre-owned Rolex Daytona prices have outperformed the secondary market, increasing 4% since its discontinuation and unveiling of a new model. This is ahead of other in-demand timepieces from Patek Philippe and Audemars Piguet. The index tracks prices for the 50 most traded pre-owned luxury watches, providing insight into demand in the market. The Rolex Daytona's popularity, driven by its association with actor Paul Newman, contributes to its strong resale value.

images.alt_text: Rolex stores, like this one in Manila’s financial district, are not hurting for customers as demand for the brand continues to be strong.Credit...Eloisa Lopez/Reuters

site_title: Digibank GXS launches personal credit product with interest rates from 3.8%
summary: GXS Bank has launched its first personal credit product, GXS FlexiLoan, with interest rates starting from 3.8% and effective interest rates from 7.15%. The loan offers flexible tenures, allowing customers to borrow sums as low as S$200 and make multiple loan drawdowns without underwriting each time. The product aims to cater to underserved consumers who are thinly served by traditional banks.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Online and mobile shopping payments will be added later on, along with subscription instalments, and services such as buy now, pay later, over time.

site_title: Condo resale prices rise again in March; volumes up 53.9%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose 1.4% month-on-month and 8.6% year-on-year in March, driven by healthy demand in the Outside of Central Region (OCR). Transaction volumes increased 53.9% to 1,133 units, with OCR deals accounting for almost half of all resale condo deals. The OCR saw the highest resale price gain of 2.1%, while District 11 posted the highest median capital gain at S$654,000. Despite concerns about high interest rates, analysts note that Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) rates have stabilized, supporting the resale market.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
About three-quarters of all units at The Sky Eden@Bedok were sold at an average price of $2,100 per square foot during its launch on Sept 7., 2022.
Three of the top five profit-making resale deals by percentage were transactions in the suburbs, with sellers making gains of 82 to 86 per cent.

Marina One Residences had one of the highest number of leasing transactions among private condominium and apartment projects in district 1 last year.


Copyright: M+S Pte Ltd
Private home prices grew by 3.2 per cent in Q1 2023, after inching up 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter.
Flash estimates from SRX and 99.co on Tuesday (Mar 28) show that 756 units were resold in February 2023, a 50.3 per cent increase from the 503 units resold in January.

site_title: From packaging to property, Malaysia’s Scientex eyes ‘affordable homes’ in Indonesia, Thailand
summary: Malaysia's Scientex, a leading flexible packaging manufacturer, is expanding its property division into Indonesia and Thailand. The company has entered a joint venture with Japan's Creed Property and Indonesia's Mustika Land to develop an affordable housing project in Greater Jakarta. This marks Scientex's second venture into the regional property market, following a similar project in Bangkok. CEO Lim Peng Jin sees tremendous potential in the property division, which has grown from RM150 million a decade ago to RM1 billion in 2022, and aims to scale its growth through regional expansion.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng

(From left) Mr Chong Jiun Yeh, CIO, UOBAM, Mr Vana Bulbon, CEO, UOBAM Thailand, Ms Lim Suet Ling, CEO, UOBAM Malaysia and Mr Ari Adil, CEO, UOBAM Indonesia, speaking at a panel during UOB Asset Management’s Annual Investment Outlook 2023 on 28 February 2023.
Mak Joon Nien, CEO, Standard Chartered Malaysia

site_title: Nothing would say forgiveness like an Ant Group IPO
summary: Alibaba's fintech unit Ant Group, valued at around $10 billion, may list shares on a public bourse, potentially signaling regulatory easing. The debut of Ant Group's IPO was initially cancelled two years ago, but a revival is possible amid global economic uncertainty and US-China tensions. Freshippo, a grocery chain, is preparing for a Hong Kong listing with Morgan Stanley, potentially becoming the first Alibaba division to IPO. A successful Ant Group listing could be a significant step towards China's regulatory easing.

images.alt_text: Signage atop the the Ant Group Co. headquarters in Hangzhou, China, on Monday, Feb. 20, 2023. Ant Group is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 24. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding announces year-to-date order wins of US$1.2 billion
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has announced US$1.2 billion in order wins for the year to date, representing 39% of its US$3 billion target for FY2023. The company has delivered 16 vessels, 28% of its 57 delivery target, and has a record high order book value of US$11 billion. Containerships, worth US$7.8 billion, contribute to 71% of the total outstanding order book value. The company aims to upgrade its fleet efficiency and replace aging vessels with new, fuel-efficient ones to meet customer demand and generate revenue.

images.alt_text: Two 24,000 TEU (20-foot equivalent unit) containerships under construction in the dry dock at Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Xinfu Yard. The group has secured its first GTT (Gaztransport & Technigaz) Mark III LNG (liquefied natural gas) carrier order.

site_title: Archaeologists in Peru find adolescent mummy wrapped in bundle
summary: Peruvian archaeologists discovered a 1,100-1,200-year-old adolescent mummy, likely from the Lima or Ichma cultures, wrapped in a funerary bundle. The mummy, found in an underground tomb, was in good condition and accompanied by ceramics, rope, and human remains. The site, Cajamarquilla, features the ruins of four pyramids and was a thriving trading center, possibly occupied by people from the coast and highlands. This discovery sheds light on pre-Inca times in Peru, which was home to various cultures before the Inca empire rose to power.

images.alt_text: The spices would have been a symbol of high status, as only the wealthy could afford goods such as saffron or cloves that were imported from outside Europe.
Scientists confirmed the presence of the corridor using radar and ultrasound, before retrieving images of it by feeding a 6mm-thick endoscope from Japan through a tiny joint in the pyramid’s stones.

site_title: Commercial shophouse sales in Q1 fall to almost 3-year low
summary: Commercial shophouse sales in Q1 2023 fell to nearly 3-year lows, with 28 transactions recorded. This represents a 46% decline from Q1 2022 and a 46% decrease from the previous quarter. The low sales volume was attributed to cautious investors due to high interest rates. This marks the lowest quarterly sales volume in nearly three years, with only 23 shophouses sold in the second quarter of 2020, when pandemic restrictions were in place.

images.alt_text: A row of shophouses at Boat Quay in Singapore, as seen from the 73rd storey Helipad of The Swissotel, Stamford. The Boat Quay is an historical quay that has been transformed into strip of trendy bars and restaurants.

site_title: Bankers chase startups in Japan as funding dries up elsewhere
summary: Japanese banks are increasing funding for startups amid a global slowdown in tech investment, with lenders like Sumitomo Mitsui Banking and Mizuho Bank planning to allocate more staff and loans to support the growth of the startup scene. The government aims to boost startup investment to 10 trillion yen by 2028, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's administration seeking to stimulate entrepreneurship. However, lenders acknowledge the higher risks and lower margins associated with lending to startups, and are taking a more flexible approach in loan screening.

images.alt_text: Rapidly-ageing Japan currently suffers from a shortage of labour in a number of sectors but remains reluctant to allow widespread immigration of foreign labourers.
Despite India’s billion-plus population, food-delivery company Zomato has just 50 million annual transacting users and state-backed digital money transfer service UPI is used by just 260 million.

site_title: Gold prices rise on dollar dip; market eyes Fed rate-hike cues
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,996.99 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar, as investors await the Federal Reserve's next policy move. The dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold more attractive for buyers holding other currencies. Despite being a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty, higher interest rates are dimming gold's appeal. Markets are pricing in a 90.5% chance of a 25-basis-point rate hike by the Fed at its May 2-3 meeting.

images.alt_text: US gold futures edged 0.2 per cent higher at US$1,993.30.

site_title: Indonesia hit by magnitude 7.3 earthquake, tsunami warning lifted
summary: A magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck west of Indonesia's Sumatra Island on Tuesday, triggering a tsunami warning for around two hours before being lifted. The quake, at a depth of 84km, hit at 3am local time and was felt strongly in Padang, with residents evacuating to higher ground. No damage has been reported, but local officials are collecting data from affected islands. Indonesia's geophysics agency initially reported the quake at 6.9 magnitude, with several aftershocks detected, including a 5-magnitude quake.

images.alt_text: Governor of Central Java since 2013, Ganjar is among a generation of provincial leaders from outside of Indonesia’s political elite who have built their voter base on a track record of reform, efficiency and transparency.
Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo said headline inflation was on track to return to target earlier than previously expected.

site_title: SMRT, ComfortDelGro compete to run city train lines in Sweden
summary: SMRT and ComfortDelGro are competing to operate metro lines in Stockholm, Sweden, with the existing contract set to expire in 2025. SMRT has partnered Transdev Group, while ComfortDelGro has partnered Go-Ahead and EuroMaint Rail. MTR, which currently operates the metro lines, plans to re-tender the contract later this year. The new operator will be responsible for the existing three lines, as well as a planned expansion and a fourth line, which are expected to come into service in 2025.

images.alt_text: Analysts remain positive on ComfortDelGro despite the announcement that two of its competitors will be merging.
Strides Holdings will hold a majority stake in the new entity, with Premier Corporation and BS Investors jointly holding  the remaining stake.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly down after mixed session on Wall Street
summary: Asian stocks declined on Tuesday, following a mixed session on Wall Street, ahead of major announcements and economic data releases. South Korea reported 0.3% economic growth, beating expectations, but losses in the broader market persisted. Other Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore, also fell, while Tokyo, Wellington, Jakarta, and Kuala Lumpur rose. Investors await earnings results from US tech companies and a policy meeting of the Bank of Japan, with Moody's Analytics warning that a plan to raise the US debt ceiling could slow growth and cut employment.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust terminates two lease agreements in China over unpaid rent, utilities
summary: Dasin Retail Trust has terminated two leases in its China malls due to unpaid rent and utilities. The Carrefour lease at Ocean Metro Mall was terminated over 7.3 million yuan (S$1.4 million) in arrears, while the Gome lease at Shiqi Metro Mall was terminated over 8.4 million yuan in rental arrears and utilities fees. The trust aims to enhance its assets through initiatives at Ocean Metro Mall, targeting completion in Q4 2023 to improve rental performance.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Ocean Metro Mall, one of seven malls in Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio.

site_title: GuocoLand’s foothold in Lentor may be a boon, but there are potential risks
summary: GuocoLand, dubbed "King of Lentor Hills," has secured its third 99-year leasehold private housing site in the area, in partnership with Intrepid Investments. The site win boosts the total potential supply of housing units to over 3,400. GuocoLand's focus on Lentor raises questions about the risk of rival developers undercutting selling prices, and whether there will be enough buyers to mop up the new homes. The URA's plans for Lentor Hills Estate, unveiled in 2013, aim to create a new neighbourhood with parks, pedestrian connectivity, and commercial amenities. GuocoLand's continued success will depend on getting end-unit selling prices right and avoiding overpaying for land.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Nine bids each for site in Lentor, EC plot in Tampines St 62
URA tender pulls in 8 bids for Jalan Tembusu plot, and 4 for Lentor plot

krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA
GuocoLand-Hong Leong Holdings tie-up is sole bidder for Lentor Gardens site at URA tender

site_title: Europe: Shares flat at start of busy earnings week, Philips jumps
summary: European shares ended flat on Monday at the start of a busy earnings week, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index closing at 468.97 points. Despite this, Dutch health technology company Philips saw its shares jump after strong first-quarter results. Analyst Chris Beauchamp noted that Monday's session seemed to set a tentative tone for the week, with gains that slipped away.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4 per cent, clocking its fifth straight week of gains.

site_title: SpaceX wins approval to add fifth US rocket launch site
summary: SpaceX has received approval to lease a second rocket launch complex at Vandenberg Space Force Base in California, its fifth launch site in the US. The new site will allow the company to handle an increasingly busy launch schedule for commercial, government, and internal satellite launches. The lease, signed by Space Launch Delta 30 commander Col Rob Long, gives SpaceX more room to operate its Falcon rockets and compete for the Pentagon's Phase 3 National Security Space Launch programme.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SpaceX logo and Elon Musk silhouette are seen in this illustration taken, December 19, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: China’s deepening sell-off shows investors are losing confidence
summary: China's stock market continues to decline, with the MSCI China Index losing 2% on Tuesday, marking the sixth day of declines. Foreign investors are accelerating their exodus, with bond yields dropping and sovereign bonds becoming a safe haven. The US plans to limit investments in key parts of China's economy, and geopolitical tensions remain a concern, despite a consumption-driven recovery taking hold. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index has lost over 5% this month, with investors seeking refuge in bonds amid frustration with the sluggish performance of the China markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man wearing a face mask is seen inside the Shanghai Stock Exchange building, as the country is hit by a novel coronavirus outbreak, at the Pudong financial district in Shanghai, China February 28, 2020.  REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: South Korea economy averts recession but faces strong headwinds
summary: South Korea's economy narrowly avoided a recession, posting a 0.3% growth in the first quarter, according to official estimates. Despite a technical rebound, economists see the outlook as clouded by weak exports due to a cooling global economy. Private consumption contributed to the growth, while capital investment declined. The Bank of Korea lowered its growth forecast to 0.8% for the year, and interest rates are expected to remain steady. The economy's reliance on trade makes it vulnerable to global economic trends.

images.alt_text: “Interest rates for one- or three-month terms have fallen a little bit more than I had expected, and so, I think we need to look into it,” South Korea's central bank governor Rhee Chang-yong said.

A woman eats a salad in front of office workers looking at their mobile phones to check the local online banking app Toss at Seoul Museum of Art during a lunch break in Seoul, South Korea, April 13, 2023.

site_title: GM, Samsung SDI plan to build EV battery plant in US: sources
summary: GM and Samsung SDI plan to build a joint venture electric vehicle battery manufacturing plant in the US, as part of GM's efforts to diversify its component suppliers and secure capacity for its electrification goals. The plant, expected to cost more than $2.6 billion, will be announced alongside a visit to Washington by South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, who is meeting with US President Joe Biden. This move aims to help GM catch up with Tesla and meet its goal of building 400,000 EVs in North America from 2022 through mid-2024.

images.alt_text: Cruise said the software in the 300 vehicles was updated on Mar 25 to address concerns the system “may inaccurately predict the movement of articulated vehicles such as buses and tractor trailers”.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CLCT, Parkway Life Reit, First Reit, Dasin Retail Trust, Aims Apac Reit
summary: CapitaLand China Trust's net property income fell 1.6% in Q1 FY2023 due to a retail mall winding down, asset enhancement initiatives, and lagged occupancy handovers. Parkway Life Reit's DPU rose 2.5% to S$0.0365, while First Reit's DPU decreased 6.1% to 0.62 cents. Dasin Retail Trust terminated two leases and reported declining portfolio valuation. Aims Apac Reit divested an industrial property for S$12.9 million, part of its asset management strategy.

site_title: Whirlpool sees appliance demand stabilising as consumers adapt
summary: Whirlpool sees demand for appliances stabilizing as consumers adapt to higher mortgage rates and a shaky housing market. The company's net sales fell 5.5% to $4.6 billion in the first quarter, beating analyst estimates. CFO Jim Peters attributed the decline to normalization of mortgage rates and the housing market, with consumer sentiment on discretionary purchases not deteriorating.

site_title: Low-cost airline kingpin prepares for life after AirAsia
summary: Tony Fernandes, the founder of AirAsia, is stepping back from the airline industry after nearly two decades, focusing on areas like health, education, and private equity. Fernandes, 58, revolutionized budget air travel in Asia with AirAsia, which he founded in 2001. Despite facing challenges, including a UK bribery investigation and the COVID-19 pandemic, Fernandes remains optimistic, saying "Culture is what kept this airline together." He plans to attract a successor from within the company, with a preference for someone from South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: MYAirline has signed leasing deals for 17 Airbus A320 planes and is very close to obtaining another five, says CEO Rayner Teo.
AirAsia said on Tuesday (Feb 28) it expects 150 of its aircrafts to be operational by the end of March, aiming to have its entire fleet in the skies by the end of the third quarter this year.

Capital A CEO Tony Fernandes (from right) and the company’s chief airport and customer experience officer Kesavan Sivanandam as well as AirAsia CEO Bo Lingam at the launching ceremony of the new AI-powered concierge “Ask Bo”.

site_title: In Manhattan’s sluggish home market, cash is greasing the wheels
summary: In Manhattan's sluggish home market, a record 57% of first-quarter purchases were made in cash, the highest share since 2014. This trend is driven by cash buyers taking advantage of deals in a sagging sales market, where borrowing costs have doubled since early 2022 and median closing prices have declined 9.7%. Cash buyers can avoid interest costs and gain an edge in bidding wars, but may also miss out on potential long-term appreciation. The trend is most common among upper-tier buyers, with 80% of transactions in the $3 million to $5 million range made in cash.

images.alt_text: Apartment hunters haven’t been able to catch a break even as more units became available and the borough’s vacancy rate continued to tick up.

site_title: Wealthtechs chase the ‘sandwiched rich’ with curated products, tailored services
summary: Wealthtech companies are targeting the "sandwiched rich" – high-net-worth individuals who qualify as accredited investors but haven't reached private bank client status. These platforms offer curated products, services, and education to attract this segment, which is a growing market in Asia, with the region showing 68% five-year growth in financial wealth. Fintech players like Stashaway, Endowus, and Moonfare are competing to attract this segment, offering private equity funds, venture capital investments, and other alternatives, with a focus on safety and guaranteed returns.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Robo-advisors leveraged on tech and easy passive investing to bring customers on board
Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast, says that the company will benefit from offering digital banking and wealth management services to a global market.

site_title: Britain to take on Big Tech with new legal powers
summary: Britain is introducing a new law to regulate big tech companies such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon, giving the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) new powers to stop them from unfairly disadvantaging smaller businesses and consumers. The law will apply to tech companies with a global turnover of over $41.7 billion or a British turnover of over $1 billion. The CMA will be able to tailor rules for these companies, potentially requiring them to provide more choice and transparency to customers, and imposing fines of up to 10% of global turnover for breaches.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: TikTok logo is displayed on the smartphone while standing on the U.S. flag in this illustration picture taken, November 8, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Previously, Google said that its ad revenue and licencing fees provide needed revenue to news organisations.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q1 DPU up 2.5% to S$0.0365
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 2.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0365 for Q1 2023, driven by 21.7% growth in gross revenue to S$37.3 million and 23.5% growth in net property income to S$35.3 million. The increase was mainly due to contributions from acquired nursing homes and higher rent from new master lease agreements. The Reit's balance sheet and capital structure remain strong, with no long-term debt refinancing needs until 2024.

images.alt_text: Mount Elizabeth Hospital, which is under PLife Reit. In addition to the ongoing recycling of its nursing homes properties in Japan and the acquisition pipeline from its sponsor, the manager of PLife Reit is looking to build a “third pillar” for the next phase of growth.
Parkway Life Reit also records increases in DPU, gross revenue and NPI for the half year ended Dec 31, 2022.
Gross revenue is down 1.3 per cent to S$89 million in the same period.

site_title: Rare outing for six Shakespeare’s First Folio copies in London
summary: Six rare First Folio copies of William Shakespeare's plays will be displayed in London from May 2-26, marking the 400th anniversary of the publication of Shakespeare's First Folio in 1623. The editions, compiled by Shakespeare's friends and published seven years after his death, contain 36 of his 37 plays and will be the largest display in Britain. The copies will then return to their owners after the exhibition.

images.alt_text: The state’s 2020 lawsuit against Sotheby’s for allegedly helping a wealthy shipping executive use a false resale certificate to dodge taxes has expanded to include seven additional collectors and numerous Sotheby’s employees from across the organisation.
Auctions and private sales of non-fungible tokens ( NFTs  ) in the “GRAILS” collection will kick off next month in New York.

site_title: Malaysia’s pandemic-born low-cost carrier MYAirline gearing up for regional routes
summary: Malaysia's low-cost carrier MYAirline is expanding its regional routes, with Thailand set to be its first foreign destination, starting with flights to Bangkok in May. The airline has signed leasing deals for 17 Airbus A320 planes and is close to securing another five. MYAirline aims to operate 80 aircraft in five years, with plans to increase routes and flight ranges, including those exceeding four hours. The airline's CEO, Rayner Teo, believes the pandemic created a perfect window of opportunity for the airline's growth, allowing it to quickly recruit staff and secure aircraft leases.

images.alt_text: Starlux, Taiwan’s newest full-service airline, launched its first flights in 2020 and serves destinations including Tokyo, Bangkok, Macau, Hanoi and Singapore.
The Iata estimates that the worldwide tab for decarbonising aviation will top US$1 trillion.
“I can’t see anything really improving or significantly improving probably until 2025 at the earliest, and it may even go beyond that," says IATA Director General Willie Walsh.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured at the Airbus facility in Montoir-de-Bretagne near Saint-Nazaire, France, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: Interest in South-east Asian bonds grows as China risks weigh on investors
summary: Interest in South-east Asian bonds has grown due to geopolitical risks surrounding China and domestic demand. Analysts attribute this growth to Indonesia as an outperformer, driven by domestic pension and insurance funds seeking government bonds and banks and mutual funds seeking surplus liquidity. Despite modest new issuance, strong demand for good-quality investment-grade names has driven trading volumes, with bonds from Indonesia and Pertamina outperforming US Treasury rates. Experts expect Indonesian government bonds to perform well, followed by Thailand, and warn of potential volatility in the market, particularly if interest rates rise in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Insurers typically hold longer-term assets to match their longer-term liabilities, experts noted.
The tight regulation of EM banks, including those in China, is reflected in the high levels of excess capital they carry on their balance sheets.

site_title: First Reit’s Q1 DPU down 6.1% on higher financing costs, forex losses
summary: First Reit's Q1 DPU fell 6.1% to 0.62 Singapore cents due to higher financing costs and forex losses. Despite a 4.9% increase in rental income from Indonesia and Singapore properties, the decline was offset by the absence of rental income from divested properties and depreciation of foreign currencies. The trust's distributable amount rose 8.3% to S$12.7 million, and its unit base increased 0.8%. The manager believes the Reit is well-positioned to deliver sustainable distributions in the healthcare sector.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
OCBC believes the Reit can benefit through upside sharing with its tenants as the demand for better quality healthcare and aged care grows.

Hikari Heights Varus Fujino, a nursing home in Japan under First Reit's portfolio. The manager of the Reit aims to increase its portfolio in developed markets to more than half of its assets under management by 2027.
First Reit's problematic rent structure with master lessee brought to fore
First Reit to diversify into new markets post-restructuring

site_title: Tycoon once dubbed ‘China’s Warren Buffett’ sells billions in assets to revive Fosun
summary: Chinese billionaire Guo Guangchang, dubbed "China's Warren Buffett," is selling billions of dollars in assets to revive Fosun International, a conglomerate he founded in 1992. Fosun has offloaded over $4.8 billion of assets since May, including a stake in Nanjing Iron & Steel, and is searching for buyers for billions of dollars in assets. Despite the disposals, Fosun's shares and bonds have rebounded, and the company is considered a rare soft-landing case in China's credit crisis. Guo's pragmatism has helped Fosun navigate the crisis, but challenges remain, including a lawsuit with Jiangsu Shagang Group and a modest economic growth target.

images.alt_text: Fosun said the litigation will not affect the group’s operations and it will take appropriate action to defend the claims.
Moody’s withdrew Fosun International’s B2 corporate family and senior unsecured bond ratings, it said in a statement
Fosun is among a handful of Chinese conglomerates that rapidly expanded their business empires at home and overseas in the past decade, mainly via debt-fuelled asset acquisitions.

site_title: Oil prices settle higher on optimism about fuel demand in China
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, reversing losses, as investors became optimistic about fuel demand in China during the upcoming May Day holiday. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate crude settled up 1.3% and 1.1% respectively at $82.73 and $78.76 per barrel. This optimism is partly due to record Chinese customs data in March and bookings for trips abroad during the holiday, which point to a continued recovery in travel to Asian countries. However, supply tightness due to Opec+ supply cuts and refining margins in Asia weakening also contributed to the price increase.

images.alt_text: Brent crude slipped 48 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$81.18 a barrel by 0045 GMT while US West Texas Intermediate crude was at US$77.39 a barrel, down 48 cents, also 0.6 per cent lower.

site_title: Netflix to invest US$2.5 billion in South Korea to make TV shows, movies
summary: Netflix plans to invest US$2.5 billion in South Korea over the next four years to produce Korean TV series, movies, and unscripted shows, doubling its investment since 2016. The announcement follows a meeting between South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol and Netflix co-chief executive officer Ted Sarandos. President Yoon welcomed the investment as a "major opportunity" for South Korea's content industry and Netflix, aiming to increase cultural exports and soft power.

images.alt_text: From January through March,  Netflix added 1.75 million streaming subscribers, missing analyst estimates of 2.06 million additions.
In 2007, the company launched its streaming business, helping to put Blockbuster Entertainment, the largest DVD rental chain, out of business.

site_title: Apple cannot ban links to outside App Store payments, US appeals court says
summary: A US appeals court has upheld a federal court order requiring Apple to change its App Store payment practices, forcing the company to allow developers to provide links and buttons for third-party in-app payment options. This decision follows similar rulings in other countries such as South Korea, the Netherlands, and Japan, which have also ordered Apple to open up its in-app payment systems. Apple has stated that it may appeal the decision, but the ruling could lead to significant changes in the way the company manages payments within its App Store.

images.alt_text: Apple CEO Tim Cook and Deirdre O'Brien, Apple's senior vice president of Retail and People greet people at the inauguration of India's first Apple retail store in Mumbai, India, April 18, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Too early to let guard down on banking risks
summary: A recent banking crisis in the US, triggered by a run on deposits amid a tech sector downturn and crypto market crash, has raised concerns about potential "second-order effects" in Asia. Despite Asia's banking sector having strengthened since the 2007-08 global financial crisis, there are warnings of tightened access to financing and higher risk premia demands for borrowers. The Asian region's credit markets may not be entirely insulated from the US crisis, and policymakers should remain vigilant to prevent any potential spillover.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley does expect some tightening in lending standards to occur in Asia in response to US bank stress.
While Asian bank bonds have outperformed relative to peers recently, that doesn’t make the region’s lenders immune to second-round effects.
Citi said the Credit Suisse move was unlikely to undermine the broader AT1 market in Asia in the long term.

site_title: Britain sets up £100 million taskforce to drive AI
summary: Britain has established a £100 million taskforce to develop foundation models of artificial intelligence (AI) for use in healthcare, education, and other fields. The initiative aims to harness AI's potential to drive economic growth and create better-paid jobs. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said the investment will help lead the way in developing safe and trustworthy AI, shaping a more innovative UK economy.

site_title: Digitalisation is opening up new opportunities for shipping supply chains
summary: The shipping industry is embracing digitalisation to improve efficiency, transparency, and sustainability, but significant challenges remain. Despite advancements in automation and internet-of-things technology, many manual and paper-based processes persist. The industry's vast size and complexity, with over 58,000 merchant ships and 140,000 vessel calls annually, makes digital transformation a daunting task. Industry standards, such as the Digital Container Shipping Association's electronic Bill of Lading, are being adopted, but widespread adoption and 100% digitalisation by 2030 will require continued collaboration among stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Cosco Shipping said the joint venture will create a digital supply chain platform, which will provide customers with more high-quality and diversified digital supply chain products and solutions.

Spot rates from Asia to the US West Coast increased more than 15-fold during the pandemic and have since returned to pre-Covid levels as trade between the world’s two largest economies cools from a frenzied pace.

site_title: Writer, adviser, poet, bot: How ChatGPT could transform politics
summary: ChatGPT, a US-made AI bot, has sparked controversy in politics after being used to write speeches, draft laws, and even generate responses to questions. Experts warn against its rapid adoption, citing concerns over bias, fabrications, and limited added value. Politicians have used the tool to score points, with some creating right-wing and left-wing versions of the bot. While it may be useful for repetitive tasks, its malleability raises concerns about its potential to generate untruths, making it a hazardous ally for the political class.

site_title: US Supreme Court rejects computer scientist’s lawsuit over AI-generated inventions
summary: The US Supreme Court rejected a lawsuit by computer scientist Stephen Thaler, who claimed his AI system, DABUS, created inventions and should be considered the legal creator. Thaler's appeal was turned down after a lower court ruled that patents can only be issued to human inventors, not AI systems. The court's decision upholds US patent law, which requires inventors to be human beings, and rejects Thaler's claim that AI-generated patents are necessary for innovation and technological progress.

images.alt_text: The European Consumer Organisation says content produced by chatbots such as ChatGPT can mislead consumers and also result in deceptive advertising.

site_title: Investing in innovation by SMEs key to managing rising costs: business leaders
summary: Business leaders say Singaporean SMEs can manage rising costs by investing in innovation, particularly through government grants for digitalisation and automation. This can improve the business' bottom line by enabling them to respond to market shifts and changes in customer preferences. SMEs can start by mapping out their purpose, weighing the opportunity cost, and allocating resources according to their risk appetite. Encouraging a culture of innovation within the business by encouraging employees to share ideas and experiment with new approaches can also be beneficial.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
SMEs can tap digitalisation, grants to mitigate rising costs: business leaders

site_title: EU consumer protection bodies urged to investigate ChatGPT, others
summary: The European Consumer Organisation (BEUC) has urged EU consumer protection agencies to investigate AI chatbots, including Microsoft's ChatGPT, due to potential harm to individuals. BEUC claims that content produced by chatbots can be misleading and result in deceptive advertising, posing a risk to younger consumers and children. The group has written letters to the European Commission and consumer protection authorities, calling for urgent investigation and remedial action to avoid consumer harm.

images.alt_text: “Harnessing the potential of AI provides enormous opportunities to grow our economy, create better-paid jobs, and build a better future through advances in healthcare and security,” British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said.
Microsoft has integrated OpenAI’s ChatGPT technology into its search engine Bing, pitting it against market leader Google.

site_title: CLCT posts 1.6% dip in Q1 net property income to 339.1 million yuan
summary: CLCT, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a 1.6% dip in net property income to 339.1 million yuan (S$65.5 million) for its first quarter ended March, primarily due to downtime from asset enhancement initiatives and lag time from committed occupancy handovers. Gross revenue for the quarter decreased 2.9% year-over-year to 475.5 million yuan.

images.alt_text: Analysts believe that the rebounding Chinese economy would continue to benefit CLCT and Sasseur Reit, even though challenges from rising interest rates could still weigh on the broader Reits segment.
CAPITALAND China Trust (CLCT) posted a 30.4 per cent rise in its net property income to 344.5 million yuan (S$72.2 million) for its first quarter ended March 2022, from 264.2 million yuan a year ago.

site_title: China guides banks to further cut deposit rates: sources
summary: China has guided banks to further cut deposit interest rates, with the central bank urging a roughly 10-basis-point cut to weighted average term deposit rates in the quarter from a year earlier. This move aims to channel the country's vast savings pool into spending and more productive investments, as businesses struggle with debt risks, structural woes, and a slowing global economy. Several small and mid-sized Chinese lenders have already lowered their deposit interest rates this month, and larger rivals are expected to follow.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed ahead of tech earnings deluge
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday ahead of tech earnings reports and economic data releases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2% to 33,875.40. Investors are preparing for a potentially dynamic week with reports from tech giants like Amazon and Alphabet, as well as major economic data releases. This comes as investors await updates on corporate earnings and economic data, potentially influencing market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 3.92 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 33,805.04.

site_title: Biden to veto legislation to block solar tariff waivers: officials
summary: US President Joe Biden will veto legislation to block solar tariff waivers on four South-east Asian nations, including Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, which were waived in June to create a "bridge" for US solar manufacturing growth. The White House argues the policy has worked, citing an increase in domestic solar production since Biden's inauguration. The tariff waivers are set to expire in June 2024, after which domestic manufacturing is expected to have taken off, making an extension unnecessary. The veto is expected to block a full House vote on the legislation.

site_title: German house price slump is already over as building costs soar
summary: Germany's housing prices have reversed their decline, rising for the second consecutive month as increased construction expenses slow the pace of new projects. Higher interest rates initially spooked buyers, but rising costs for materials and labor have tightened supply, favoring buyers. Existing home prices are being held back by high modernization expenses, with Europace's CEO stating that the market has turned from a seller's to a buyer's market. This shift is seen as a positive development for Germany's housing market, which had been struggling with affordability issues.

site_title: China Evergrande unit to sell two businesses as part of restructuring
summary: China Evergrande Group announced the sale of two businesses, Flaming Ace and Assemble Guard, to Anxin Holding for a nominal consideration, resulting in a gain of about 24.79 billion yuan. The move is part of the company's restructuring efforts to focus on the new-energy-vehicle (NEV) sector, allowing it to "de-leverage and reduce its holding of the projects". The sale is expected to optimize the structure of the New Energy Vehicle Group, enabling it to take its NEV segment to the next stage of growth.

site_title: Bitcoin could hit US$100,000 by end-2024, Standard Chartered says
summary: Standard Chartered predicts Bitcoin could reach US$100,000 by the end of 2024, driven by factors such as the recent banking sector turmoil, stabilisation of risk assets, and improved profitability of crypto mining. The "crypto winter" is over, and Bitcoin has rallied this year, rising above US$30,000 for the first time in ten months. The bank cites Bitcoin's status as a "branded safe haven" and regulatory developments, including the European Parliament's backing of crypto asset markets rules, as supporting its bullish outlook.

images.alt_text: Zipmex is struggling to pay employees after its investor withheld an injection of cash.
