TrueUSD's share of Bitcoin trading volumes on Binance has risen to 50 per cent from negligible levels.

site_title: Tech investors focus on profits after layoffs; companies to highlight AI
summary: US tech giants Microsoft, Alphabet, Meta, and Amazon are set to report quarterly results, with investors focusing on the impact of layoffs on profits. Despite record layoffs, analysts expect profits to rise 4.5% on average, driven by an 11.8% jump in Meta's bottom line. The companies are also expected to highlight their artificial intelligence (AI) efforts, with Microsoft integrating OpenAI's ChatGPT technology into Bing and Amazon releasing a suite of AI-powered chatbot technologies. Analysts expect companies to prioritize AI growth, despite pressure to improve cash flow in a weakening economy.

site_title: Scientists develop mobile printer for mRNA vaccine patches
summary: Scientists have developed a mobile printer capable of producing thumbnail-sized patches that can deliver mRNA Covid vaccines, offering a potential solution for immunizing people in remote regions. The 2-cm-wide patches, which contain hundreds of tiny needles, can be self-administered, painless, and stored at room temperature for long periods. The printer was tested with Pfizer and Moderna jabs, and the patches produced a similar antibody response to traditional injections. While improvements are needed to scale up production, experts hail the development as an exciting breakthrough that could transform vaccine distribution.

images.alt_text: A visitor leaves GlaxoSmithKline Plc's headquarters in London, U.K., on Wednesday, Feb. 5, 2014. GlaxoSmithKline, the U.K.'s biggest drugmaker, forecast that revenue will rise by about 2 percent this year as it introduces new medicines. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
The rapid spread of the H5N1 bird flu strain is already stoking concerns.

site_title: Setbacks for Sunak as key elections approach
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces a major electoral challenge on May 4, his first as leader, following Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab's resignation. Sunak's government has struggled, with a mixed start to his term and numerous Cabinet resignations for ethics-related reasons. Despite this, he has avoided the catastrophic downfall of his predecessor Liz Truss, who resigned after just 50 days in office. Sunak must now navigate these challenges to lead the Conservatives into the next general election, likely next year.

images.alt_text: Raab is the third Cabinet member to depart during Sunak’s six months in office.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp CEO Martina Merz to quit, in blow to shares
summary: Thyssenkrupp's CEO Martina Merz is leaving the company after a tumultuous tenure, which saw the company's share price nearly halve. Merz, 60, had been in charge since 2019 and had initiated a major overhaul of the German industrial conglomerate. The personnel committee of the supervisory board agreed to terminate her contract by mutual agreement without giving a reason. Thyssenkrupp's shares fell as much as 12% after the announcement, with Miguel Angel Lopez Borrego set to succeed Merz as CEO from June 1.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit divests Yishun property for S$12.9 million
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) announced it will divest its Yishun Industrial Park A in Singapore for S$12.9 million, a 8.2% premium on the property's valuation of S$11.9 million. The divestment is part of the Reit's proactive asset management strategy to optimise its portfolio. The property has limited redevelopment potential and a remaining land lease of 31 years. The sale is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2023, subject to JTC's approval, and will leave AA Reit with 28 properties across Singapore and Australia.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
S-Reits that are scheduled to release their results for the full-year ending March include Aims Apac Reit and the trio of Mapletree Reits.
Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.
RHB downgrades S-Reits to "neutral", while UOBKH maintains "market weight" on Malaysian Reits; DBS recommends investors stay invested in logistics, retail and hospitality sectors.

site_title: 15 deals signed at Singapore-Shanghai Comprehensive Cooperation Council meeting
summary: Singapore and Shanghai strengthened economic ties with 15 agreements signed at the fourth Singapore-Shanghai Comprehensive Cooperation Council meeting. The agreements include memoranda of understanding on the digital economy, tourism, and people-to-people exchanges. Co-chairs Edwin Tong and Shanghai's mayor Gong Zheng expressed hope for increased connectivity and interactions, with Tong looking forward to restored weekly passenger services between the cities. The agreements aim to strengthen trade and investment ties, enhance bilateral cooperation in digital and green economies, and deepen partnerships in financial services and innovation.

images.alt_text: People stand on a tour ship on the Huangpu river in the Huangpu district in Shanghai on April 10, 2023. (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP)

site_title: Swiss finance minister urges voters to back higher corporate tax
summary: Swiss Finance Minister Karin Keller-Sutter urged voters to approve a plan to raise corporate taxes to implement a 15% minimum tax rate, as agreed by almost 140 countries. If Switzerland doesn't pass the ballot, another jurisdiction can collect the difference, threatening the country's competitive edge. The government, parliament, and most parties support a 'yes' vote, but the Social Democrats oppose the plan for distributing the revenue. The vote is set for June 18, with 75% of the extra funds going to cantons and the remainder to the federal government.

site_title: Strong euro nears nine-year high versus yen
summary: The euro reached a near nine-year high against the Japanese yen, up 0.25% to US$1.1015, as the yen softened due to remarks from the new BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda on maintaining monetary easing. The euro is close to its highest level since 2014, and traders are waiting for key central bank meetings, including the BOJ on Friday and the ECB and Fed meetings in early May. Markets are expecting rate hikes and looking for clues on economic strain and inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The euro sign is photographed in front of the former head quarter of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, April 9, 2019. Picture is taken on slow shutter speed while the camera was moved.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: Tiger Woods-backed project to build homes in Florida horse town
summary: A Tiger Woods-backed project, led by international developer Nexus Luxury Collection, aims to build a 600-acre residential community in Wellington, a South Florida equestrian town near Palm Beach. The project, set to begin next month, will feature single-family homes, condos, a hotel, and a revamped golf course. Prices are expected to start around $4 million for completed condos and single-family homes, with sites for custom homes ranging from a quarter-acre to 5 acres. The developers hope to attract families and equestrian enthusiasts, and believe the community will redefine full-time living for families in South Florida.

site_title: Trillium Capital values Getty Images at US$3.95 billion in all-cash buyout bid
summary: Trillium Capital, an activist investor, has made a US$3.95 billion all-cash bid to acquire Getty Images Holdings. Trillium already owns over 500,000 shares and offered to buy the remaining shares at US$10 apiece, a 98% premium to the stock's last close. The proposal comes after Trillium urged Getty Images to consider a sale to private equity or strategic players, aiming to boost the company's shares to over US$12 and add over US$1 billion to its market capitalization.

images.alt_text:
Bloomberg's Best Photos 2012: The World at Work. Bloomberg photographers have documented a breathtakingly diverse world of work in 2012. From the frantic trading floor at the London Metals Exchange to precarious descents into Indian mines; from trudging across the frozen Yamal Peninsula to Gazprom's Bovanenkovo gas field and traveling through the night on West Virginian coal barges to mucking in with the animals at Lehmann Brothers Farms in Illinois, they haven't hesitated to get their hands, cameras and boots dirty, see their work here in The World at Work.
FILE PHOTO: "BEST PHOTOS OF 2012" (***BESTOF2012***): A pedestrian carrying an umbrella passes a U.S. flag on Wall Street in front of the exterior of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, May 9, 2012. U.S. stock futures retreated, indicating the Dow Jones Industrial Average will drop for a sixth straight day, as Greece's political impasse intensified concern about a worsening of the European sovereign-debt crisis. Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

site_title: Silicon Valley startups brace for a summer of pain
summary: Silicon Valley startups are bracing for a summer of financial struggles as investors become increasingly cautious due to a market downturn and decreased venture capital investment. Companies such as Stripe and Blockchain.com have already taken valuation cuts, and many are expected to follow suit with down rounds, which signal a company's growth trajectory has been derailed. Experts warn that more startups will run out of money, and those that can raise new funding will have to accept lower valuations, making it a challenging time for the startup world.

images.alt_text: The withdrawals have attributed to pent-up demand during the period in which the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp took SVB into receivership.
CEO Gregory Becker resigned on April 19, while finance chief Daniel Beck left the company on April 18, SVB said.

site_title: Japan considers widening long-term foreign worker visa scheme
summary: Japan is considering expanding its long-term foreign worker visa scheme to 12 sectors from three, including food service and manufacturing, to address a labor shortage due to Japan's rapidly aging population. The change could allow workers to stay for extended periods and bring their families with them, potentially easing a shortage in sectors such as farming and nursing care. Talks are underway to have the revisions approved by the cabinet as early as June.

site_title: LVMH’s market value surpasses US$500 billion, a first in Europe
summary: LVMH's market value surpassed US$500 billion, becoming the first European company to reach this milestone, thanks to booming sales of luxury goods in China and a strengthening euro. The company's strong performance, driven by a surge in first-quarter sales, has swelled the wealth of its chairman and CEO, Bernard Arnault, to almost US$212 billion. Despite concerns about a potential economic slowdown, LVMH's value has lifted due to the euro's rise against the dollar, with analysts predicting further gains and a stock price target of 1,000 euros in the next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of LVMH is seen at its exhibition space, at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: iFast Global Bank launches personal banking platform in UK
summary: iFast Global Bank, a UK-based subsidiary of iFast Corporation, has launched its Digital Personal Banking (DPB) platform, allowing customers to open a UK digital bank account online without physical presence. The platform offers services such as fixed deposits, notice deposits, and multi-currency accounts. This move aims to provide global customers with digital banking and wealth management capabilities, benefiting from iFast's strong IT foundation and fintech ecosystem. The launch follows other iFast banking services and is seen as a strategic expansion into the global market.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast.
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Super-sized screens, rumble seats draw moviegoers back to blockbusters
summary: Moviegoers are returning to theaters after the Covid-19 pandemic, drawn by enhanced formats such as oversized screens, 3D projection, and immersive experiences like rumble seats and simulated environments. IMAX has signed 62 agreements for new or upgraded screens in 2023, exceeding all of 2022. Theaters are reporting increased revenue from premium formats, with some chains seeing up to half of their multiplex's grosses come from these screens. Film studios are responding by releasing more action-packed blockbusters in IMAX, with some predicting these formats will account for 16.7% of 2023 domestic ticket sales.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People wait for movie screening at an IMAX theatre inside the Wanda Plaza in Xinxiang, Henan province, China March 23, 2018. Picture taken March 23, 2018. REUTERS/Stella Qiu/File Photo

site_title: Disney begins second round of job cuts, affecting thousands
summary: Disney has begun its second round of job cuts, affecting around 4,000 employees, bringing the total positions eliminated to approximately 4,000. The cuts, part of CEO Bob Iger's plan to save $5.5 billion in annual costs, aim to pare the company's commitment to general entertainment and prioritize franchises and well-recognized brands. The reductions will impact various divisions, including Disney Entertainment, and are expected to be completed by Thursday. The third round of cuts is expected to occur before the summer.

images.alt_text: AirAsia said on Tuesday (Feb 28) it expects 150 of its aircrafts to be operational by the end of March, aiming to have its entire fleet in the skies by the end of the third quarter this year.
MYAirline has signed leasing deals for 17 Airbus A320 planes and is very close to obtaining another five, says CEO Rayner Teo.

site_title: Flights grounded at Hamburg, Berlin airports
summary: Flights were grounded at Hamburg and Berlin airports in Germany due to a one-day strike by security workers and ground services over pay. All departures were cancelled at Berlin-Brandenburg airport, and some landings were affected. At Hamburg airport, employees from Aviation Handling Services Hamburg (AHS) also went on strike, canceling 31 flights. The strikes follow a series of disruptions at airports across Germany, with unions pressing for higher wages to offset the cost of living.

images.alt_text: A view shows empty check-in counters during a strike by security employees over pay demands, at the Berlin Brandenburg Airport (BER), in Schoenefeld near Berlin, Germany.  April 24, 2023. REUTERS/Martin Schlicht

site_title: Coca-Cola rides on higher prices, steady demand to upbeat quarter
summary: Coca-Cola reported a strong first-quarter performance, exceeding estimates with revenue and profit growth driven by resilient demand for its sodas and multiple price increases to combat higher commodity and shipping costs. Average selling prices rose 11% and global unit case volumes increased 3%, while the company's shares gained about 2% in premarket trading.

site_title: I was scared for myself and my children: OK Lim’s ex-personal assistant testifies
summary: Former personal assistant Serene Seng testified against Singapore oil tycoon OK Lim, who faces cheating and forgery charges. Seng, 61, stated she was "honestly very scared" for herself and her children after creating false documents for a deal that had not taken place. Lim allegedly cheated HSBC by claiming Hin Leong had entered into two oil transactions, resulting in the bank disbursing $111.6 million. Seng also testified that she created fake documents, including a bill of lading, to support the transactions, and claimed she was misled into believing Lim would close an actual deal.

site_title: MAS launches S$8m scheme to co-fund salaries, tuition of poly students and graduates in financial sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched an S$8 million scheme, the Polytechnic Talent for Finance, to co-fund salaries, tuition, and internships for polytechnic students and graduates in the financial sector. The scheme aims to encourage financial institutions to hire and train polytechnic students, with funding for internships, apprenticeships, and sponsorships. The initiative follows a low hiring rate of 3% of polytechnic graduates in the financial sector in 2021, despite financial sector jobs accounting for 5% of the economy.

images.alt_text: ST20221201_202287636190/pixmas/Jason Quah Generic photos at Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) taken on Dec 1, 2022. // to go with financial stories such as inflation, strengthening of Sing dollar, rise in interest rates
Renald Yeo

site_title: Europe bankers slam ‘excessive’ ESG bill that ratchets up legal risks
summary: European Union lawmakers have advanced a sweeping ESG bill, known as the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD), which would hold companies accountable for environmental and social harm in their supply chains. The bill, which has the potential to be one of the EU's most far-reaching pieces of environmental rulemaking, has drawn opposition from powerful finance industry lobbyists who claim it ignores the unique status of financial firms. The next step for the bill is a formal vote of the parliament committee on Tuesday, after which it will go to the full chamber and the European Council.

site_title: Hong Kong’s January-March unemployment eases to 3.1%
summary: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate eased to 3.1% in the January-March period, marking the eleventh consecutive quarter of improvement. The unemployment rate stood at 3.3% in the December to February period. The Hong Kong government expects the labour market to continue improving alongside the revival of domestic economic activities and inbound tourism.

site_title: Distressed property listings jump in Q1 as bankruptcies rise
summary: Singapore's mortgagee listings increased by 5.6% in Q1 2023, with both Knight Frank and Edmund Tie reporting higher numbers. Bankruptcy applications also rose 5.6% to 959, a 22.2% increase from Q1 2022. Mortgagee listings at auctions more than tripled to 32 at Knight Frank, while residential listings doubled to 18. Experts attribute the rise to a tougher business climate and rising interest rates. As a result, more distress sales are expected in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of properties landscape in Singapore

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as focus turns to tech earnings, economic data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones falling 3.92 points, or 0.01%, to 33,805.04. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, 1.45 and 18.99 points, or 0.04% and 0.16%, respectively. Investors await tech earnings and economic data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy.

site_title: Adani Group starts first bond buyback after Hindenburg attack
summary: Adani Group, led by Indian billionaire Gautam Adani, has started its first debt buyback since being targeted by a short seller in January. The company, Adani Ports & Special Economic Zone, plans to buy back up to $130 million of its bonds in the next four quarters to regain investor confidence. This move aims to trim capital spending and address concerns about its liquidity position. Bond prices for Adani Group companies rose after the announcement, with some notes gaining up to 0.7 cents on the US dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: China’s Wanda chairman quoted on HK IPO challenge, bonds lose more on liquidity concerns
summary: China's Wanda Group chairman Wang Jianlin stated that the company's unit's Hong Kong IPO is facing difficulties and vowed to cut debt in the next two years. This led to a decline in Wanda's US dollar bonds, with notes due in 2023 and 2024 falling to 90.472 cents and 70.571 cents, respectively. The company has agreed to extend its IPO deadline to November 30 to avoid a near-term repayment risk and has halted new property management projects and land acquisitions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of Dalian Wanda Group in China glows during an event in Beijing, China, March 21, 2016. REUTERS/Damir Sagolj/File Photo

site_title: Sias asks Lian Beng to raise ‘lowball’ offer to a ‘fair and reasonable’ price
summary: Sias, a Singaporean investor association, is urging Lian Beng to increase its offer price for minority shareholders from S$0.62 per share, which it considers a "lowball" offer. The association's president, David Gerald, notes that the offer is a 60% discount to Lian Beng's net asset value and compares it unfavorably to the privatisation of Chip Eng Seng, which received a 25% discount. Gerald emphasizes that companies should not short-change investors and that a "fair and reasonable" offer price is warranted given Lian Beng's strong financials.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
As at Mar 10, the total number of shares owned, controlled or agreed to be acquired by Boustead Singapore and its concert parties as well as valid acceptances of the offer amounted to 86.55 per cent.

David Gerald, founder and chief executive of the Securities Investors Association (SIAS), says Golden Energy and Resources shareholders strongly maintain their view that the current exit offer price of S$0.16 per share is too low.

Sias president and chief executive David Gerald says the offer price should be higher after accounting for Stanmore Resources while also ignoring Golden Energy and Resources' Nov 8 closing price of S$0.67.
Boustead Singapore is looking to take Boustead Projects private at S$0.90 per share.

site_title: Staying zen with ‘slow design’ at Milan Furniture Fair
summary: The Milan Furniture Fair showcased "slow design" this year, featuring sustainable creations made from hand-crafted natural materials. Japanese design company Ritzwell, which produces all its furniture by hand, highlighted the importance of design and comfort. The company's factory, located near Fukuoka, Japan, aims to be in harmony with nature, with 20 craftsmen working on site. This approach contrasts with industrial manufacturing and aims to promote a zero-waste future.

site_title: China’s fledgling private pension scheme draws 20b yuan in contributions: sources
summary: China's private pension scheme has drawn 20 billion yuan (S$3.87 billion) in contributions since its inception in November, with 70% of the funds invested. The majority of funds (60%) are in bank deposits, followed by mutual funds (30%). Pension insurance products and bank wealth management products have attracted less than 5% each. The low investment rate suggests hesitation among participants due to unfamiliarity with the system, leading to a wait-and-see approach.

images.alt_text: Visitors checking out the BYD Seagull car that was on display at the Shanghai Auto Show 2023.

Chinese President Xi Jinping speaks as French President Emmanuel Macron listens at a Franco-Chinese business council meeting in Beijing, April 6, 2023. Macron was accompanied by more than 60 business executives on his recent trip to China.
After years of rapid expansion, a weakening electronics market is slowing Apple’s business.
Cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. The container pile-up in China is one of the more visible symptoms of the problems in the shipping industry.

site_title: Goldman sees Bank of England rate hike in May, possibly more ahead
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in May by 25 basis points, with a possibility of further hikes, according to Goldman Sachs analysts. The decision comes as Britain's consumer price inflation remains high at 10.1% in March, prompting the central bank to tighten monetary policy. Analysts predict a 98% probability of a rate hike and a 50-50 chance of two further quarter-point hikes by August, which would take the Bank Rate to 5%. This move aims to combat stubbornly high inflation and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Tesla raises capital spending plan again in midst of price cuts
summary: Tesla has increased its capital expenditure forecast to at least $7 billion for 2023, up from a previous range of $6-8 billion. The company, which is cutting vehicle prices, now expects to spend up to $9 billion in 2023, a $1 billion increase from its January forecast. This marks the third time the company has raised its capex forecast in the last nine months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Germany’s ‘very generous’ pay deal may complicate ECB’s inflation fight
summary: Germany's public sector workers secured a 5.5% permanent pay rise and one-off payments to combat inflation, setting a precedent for other pay talks. This may complicate the European Central Bank's (ECB) fight against inflation, as wages were expected to peak this year. Analysts predict the deal could increase aggregate wage growth, prompting the ECB to raise interest rates. The ECB forecasts wage growth will average 5.3% this year, but the German deal may challenge this target, potentially leading to a more aggressive monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Aviation security staff organized in the public transport sector union Verdi gather for a demonstration during a strike at the airport of Duesseldorf, western Germany, on April 20, 2023. - Travelers at the airports in Duesseldorf, Hamburg, Cologne/Bonn and Stuttgart will have to prepare for delays and flight cancellations over the next few days. The trade union ver.di has called for renewed strikes from Thursday. (Photo by Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)

site_title: China bond sell-off eased in March as global volatility spiked
summary: China's bond sell-off eased in March as global volatility spiked, with foreign investors offloading a net 27.8 billion yuan of sovereign debt but buying a net 42 billion yuan of negotiable certificates of deposit. Total foreign ownership of domestic debt rose 3.5 billion yuan to 3.2 trillion yuan, marking the first increase in 13 months. This stabilization in foreign demand amid concerns over global banking threats helped alleviate the selloff, with holdings of policy bank bonds remaining unchanged.

images.alt_text: China has been a leader among countries that are developing the CBDC – digital tokens issued by central banks, although adoption is still in the early stages.
The province has inked an agreement with China’s state asset regulator, seeking guidance on state-owned enterprise reforms and cooperation between the central and local authorities.

site_title: When did growth become a bad word in the US?
summary: The US is facing a prospect of lower growth, potentially for a decade or longer, due to an ageing population and policies that discourage productivity. Economists and international institutions warn that this could lead to a lower standard of living for future generations, higher taxes, and reduced investment. In contrast to Europe, the US has traditionally chosen more growth over safety, but policymakers are now leaning towards safety, losing sight of the benefits of growth. The author argues that a low-growth future would rob future generations of prosperity and that the government and Federal Reserve should accept that risk is the cost of growth.

images.alt_text: “Our outlook envisions that the acute financial stresses, which last month triggered pressures on both sides of the Atlantic, will continue to recede,” Citi economists led by Nathan Sheets said in a note.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on April 08, 2022 Cars are seen on the assembly line during a tour of the Tesla Giga Texas manufacturing facility ahead of the "Cyber Rodeo" grand opening party on April 7, 2022 in Austin, Texas. - American factory growth sped up in May after slowing in the prior two months, even as employment contracted and firms continue to face supply challenges, according to a business survey released June 1, 2022. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

(FILES) In this file photo taken on September 09, 2021, people receive information as they attend a job fair for employment with SoFi Stadium and Los Angeles International Airport employers, at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, California. - More US workers made new claims for unemployment benefits last week, according to government data released September 16, 2021,, though the metric of labor market health is expected to resume falling. There were 332,000 initial jobless claims, seasonally adjusted, filed in the week ended September 11, above analysts' forecasts and 20,000 more than the week prior, the Labor Department reported. (Photo by Patrick T. FALLON / AFP)

site_title: Citigroup’s Asia Q1 wealth revenue jumps 20% amid new clients, investment gains
summary: Citigroup's Asia Q1 wealth revenue jumped 20% due to new clients and investment gains, despite a global decline in its wealth management business. The number of new clients joining Citi's Private Bank in the region doubled from a year ago, with new private banking assets growing 20% year on year. This growth is attributed to rival private banks benefiting from inflows as some rich clients fled Credit Suisse amid a banker exodus.

images.alt_text: The hiring emerges as a highlight of Citi’s post-earnings conference call, with several analysts asking about the executive and the bank’s plans for wealth management.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation fell in March, with headline inflation in line with economists' expectations at 7.7% compared to 8.1% in February. Food inflation also declined to 7.7% from 8.1% in February, slightly lower than expected. This marks a moderation in headline inflation, which was seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: German business sentiment improves slightly in April
summary: German business sentiment improved slightly in April, with the Ifo institute's business climate index rising to 93.6, following a revised March reading of 93.2. The economy is expected to have expanded in the first quarter, avoiding a recession, but momentum is likely to remain weak. Companies' expectations improved, but their current situation was assessed as slightly worse. Inflation continues to weigh on consumption, and wage settlements may offset the loss in purchasing power, but only partly and gradually.

images.alt_text: The deal comes after several weeks of stalemate and repeated strikes among postal, transport and health workers demanding more money to cope with the rising cost of living.

site_title: China Embassy removes remarks about ex-Soviet states
summary: China's embassy in France removed a transcript of a controversial interview in which Ambassador Lu Shaye questioned the independence of former Soviet Union states, sparking anger across Europe. The remarks, which were removed by the embassy, appeared to contradict China's official stance on recognizing the Baltic states' sovereignty. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning stated that China "respects the status of the former Soviet republics as sovereign countries after the Soviet Union's dissolution," adding that the country's position is "unchanged."

site_title: Singapore stocks flat amid mixed regional trading; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.1% to close at 3,324.55 points on Monday, driven by data showing local inflation rates in March matching economists' median estimates. The STI has been supported by inexpensive valuations and an attractive dividend yield. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 rising 0.1% and South Korea's Kospi falling 0.8%. The consumer staples sector is expected to outperform in a slowing macroeconomic environment.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
By expenditure division, food inflation marks the largest jump, up 7.7 per cent on the year in March, Singstat data shows.

site_title: Credit Suisse shows well capitalised banks can lose trust, Japan official says
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency vice-minister Tomoko Amaya warns that even well-capitalized banks like Credit Suisse can lose market trust due to a weak business model. Credit Suisse's high capital adequacy ratio couldn't reassure investors, highlighting the importance of more than just capital in maintaining trust. The agency is investigating brokerages that sold risky debt issued by Credit Suisse, known as AT1 notes, to Japanese investors.

site_title: Coastal Sustainability Alliance, Ken Energy to deploy electric supply boats in Singapore
summary: The Coastal Sustainability Alliance and Ken Energy will deploy electric supply boats in Singapore, supporting coastal ships' supply deliveries with improved energy and operational efficiency. The boats, designed and built by PaxOcean, will be the first of their kind in the region, with the goal of reducing emissions and promoting a more sustainable environment. The deployment comes amid Singapore's directive for new harbour craft to be fully electric or compatible with net-zero fuels by 2030.

images.alt_text: Ever Given setting sail to leave through the Suez Canal after a settlement in 2021. Decarbonisation of the shipping industry is expected to be a major topic at the Singapore Maritime Week.
The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will collaborate with Shell Eastern Trading to support the adoption of electric harbour craft.

An artist impression of an electric ferry conceptualised under the Keppel Offshore and Marine consortium. An existing 30-pax ferry belonging to Eng Hup Shipping, a harbour craft operator, would be retrofitted to become fully electric under the project.

site_title: Green, social and sustainable bonds set to plug climate financing gap
summary: The market for green, social and sustainable (GSS) bonds is expected to improve in 2023 as inflation subsides and interest rates moderate. After a challenging 2022, the outlook for GSS bond issuance is more upbeat, with sovereign issues on the rise. The European Commission's European Green Bond Standard (EUGBS) and other regulatory developments are helping to increase investor confidence and support growth in the sustainable bond market. The energy crisis has raised the prospect of long-term sustainable debt issuance to finance Europe's energy transition, and companies are increasingly using GSS bonds to help raise capital, particularly in carbon-intensive sectors.

images.alt_text: The green financing is intended to help Australia’s progress to net-zero emissions by 2050 by boosting investment in clean-energy infrastructure.

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the launch of NUS Sustainable and Green Finance Institute on Thursday (April 20) with Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of NUS board of trustees, Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS President and Professor Sumit Agarwal, managing director of the institute.

site_title: Thai central bank chief sees growth at 3.6% this year, inflation risks
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow at 3.6% this year, driven by tourism and domestic consumption, according to Bank of Thailand governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput. Despite turbulence in the first half of the year and global financial uncertainty, there is little need for stimulus measures, as the economic recovery remains intact. Inflation risks persist, and fiscal and monetary policies should be normalized for stability, with growth close to the country's long-term potential of 4%.

images.alt_text: The industries sentiment index of the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) rose to 97.8 in March from 96.2 in February, when it had returned to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Japan’s Nidec posts first quarterly loss in 10 years
summary: Japan's Nidec, a leading electric motor maker, has posted its first quarterly operating loss in 10 years due to restructuring costs, semiconductor and component procurement difficulties, and a decline in the electric vehicle market in China. The company reported a loss of 24.3 billion yen (US$238.5 million) for the January-March quarter, exceeding analyst estimates. Nidec has been investing heavily in electric vehicle production and development, but the business environment remains severe, with a delay in global automobile production recovery and uncertain economic outlook.

site_title: China province steps up effort to seek state help on debt woes
summary: Guizhou province in China has signed agreements with state-owned asset managers and regulators to seek guidance on state-owned enterprise reforms and cooperation between central and local authorities. The move aims to address the province's financial risk and prevent a high-profile default, which hosts some of China's riskiest local government financing vehicles. Despite the efforts, investors remain cautious due to the lack of firm pledges of funding support from the state and central government, highlighting the structural issue of imbalanced revenue and expense sharing between local and central governments.

site_title: I’ve got your back: UK’s Sunak tries to reboot business ties
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak reassured over 200 CEOs at "Business Connect" that the government is "unashamedly pro-business" and needs their help to grow the economy. Sunak aims to turn around the Conservative Party's fortunes before an election expected next year. He made reviving the economy one of his key priorities, following Britain's GDP only regaining pre-pandemic size in February. The event aimed to rebuild the party's relations with business damaged during previous premierships.

images.alt_text: BizUK, an emergency body being created by public affairs firm WPI Strategy after discussions with Conservative and Labour Party officials, will support the representation of business to the main political parties.
The CBI, which says it represents 190,000 businesses including many of Britain’s biggest companies, could face a battle for survival as the number of companies cutting ties with it grows.

site_title: Having a ‘threshold’ for bullying is out of date
summary: Former UK Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab resigned after a bullying probe found him guilty of intimidating and undermining staff, despite not meeting the traditional definition of physical threats or aggressive behavior. Raab argued that his behavior was acceptable as he aimed to push for policy outcomes and set high standards, but critics say this approach sets a dangerous precedent and is out of date. The inquiry found he had humiliated and intimidated individuals through verbal abuse and threats, highlighting the need to redefine bullying in the workplace beyond physical threats.

images.alt_text: Raab is the third Cabinet member to depart during Sunak’s six months in office.
In a letter to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, Raab said the inquiry had set a dangerous precedent, but that he would remain supportive of the government.

site_title: Philips shares jump on recall provision and profit improvement
summary: Philips shares surged 13% on Monday after the company reported better-than-expected first-quarter results and set aside €575 million (S$844 million) for lawsuits related to its respiratory device recall. The recall, announced in 2021, has cost Philips around 70% of its market value since then. CEO Roy Jakobs expressed optimism about reaching a settlement, but analysts warned that the total costs remain unclear. Philips also reported a 50% jump in core profit and 6% sales growth. The company still faces lawsuits with the FDA and individual patients over health problems linked to the devices.

images.alt_text: Philips was recalling the machines as some devices were assigned incorrect or duplicate serial numbers during initial programming, the US FDA said.
Two consumer associations in Italy had sued Philips on behalf of the 100,000 Italian users of the machines for sleep apnea, a disorder in which breathing stops and starts during sleep.

site_title: European firms warn renewables need policy, funding support to stay on track
summary: European companies from the offshore renewable energy sector are urging policy and funding support to meet the EU's goal of quadrupling offshore wind capacity in the North Sea by 2030. The industry currently manufactures 7 gigawatts of offshore wind per year, but needs to add 20 gigawatts per year to meet the target. Companies are calling for increased government and EU funding, inflation-indexed prices in government auctions, and measures to support European manufacturing of renewable energy components. Failure to provide support risks an increased reliance on imported parts.

images.alt_text: None of the Asian asset managers in WWF-Singapore's study have voting policies and expectations on investee companies on urgent issues, such as managing water risks, protecting oceans and ending deforestation.

saclean31 - Jasmine Tang (in white), 28, NEA employee, educating a participant on the proper ways of recycling through a mini game-booth at the Clean Up! South West 2023 event held at Choa Chu Kang Community Centre on 31 December, 2022.
