Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: Lisbon bars cars from driving through city centre
summary: Lisbon will introduce a three-month trial period starting April 26, where cars will be barred from driving through the city centre, but not from entering. A larger zone will restrict access to vehicles over 3.5 tonnes between 8 am and 8 pm. The plan aims to reduce traffic congestion during major construction in the city, which includes a metro extension and storm drain installations. The measures could be permanent and may contribute to Lisbon's goal of becoming carbon-neutral by 2030, following EU guidelines.

images.alt_text: Visitors checking out the BYD Seagull car that was on display at the Shanghai Auto Show 2023.

site_title: Evergrande’s 8.2 billion yuan onshore bondholders to vote on offshore restructuring plan on Wed
summary: Evergrande Group's onshore flagship unit Hengda Real Estate is set to hold a meeting on Wednesday for onshore bondholders to vote on the company's offshore restructuring plan. The 8.2 billion yuan onshore bond, due July 8, could be the first onshore note to offer the same offshore restructuring terms. This move may provide better repayment terms due to onshore debts typically having higher priority. The vote follows a year of defaults by multiple Chinese developers, including Evergrande, which has over $300 billion in total liabilities.

images.alt_text: The debt restructuring for Evergrande is one of the country’s largest ever and carries broad implications for its financial system.

site_title: Link Hotel in Tiong Bahru goes into receivership, put up for sale
summary: Link Hotel in Singapore's Tiong Bahru has gone into receivership after a $50 million loan default, with the Hong Kong-listed parent company Link Holdings putting the hotel up for sale. The loan was granted to a subsidiary, Hang Huo Investment, and was secured by mortgages on the hotel and its land. The site, valued at $140 million, has been open since 2007 and is zoned for hotel use. A receiver and manager has been appointed, and an expression of interest exercise is underway, with submissions closing on May 5, 2023.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Excelsior Hotel and Shopping Complex...

site_title: China, Singapore to hold joint naval drills
summary: China and Singapore will hold joint naval drills from April 30 to May 5. The Chinese People's Liberation Army Navy will dispatch two ships, the frigate Yulin and the Chibi minesweeper, to participate in the exercises around Singapore. This marks the third joint naval exercise between the two countries, following previous drills in 2021. The announcement comes amid heightened tensions in the region, including China's expansive maritime claims in the South China Sea and recent drills in the Taiwan Strait.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr (above) will hold talks with his US counterpart Joe Biden in Washington this weekend, a meeting the White House said would reaffirm its “iron-clad commitments to the defence of the Philippines”.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, UOB, Sembmarine, IReit Global
summary: Keppel Corp's Australian associates have filed a civil claim against three of its subsidiaries for up to A$66.5 million over a solar farm in Queensland, Australia. UOB reported a "very flush" liquidity position, while Sembmarine won an arbitration award against an Awilco Drilling unit. IReit Global secured a 15-year lease with a German federal government body, increasing its portfolio occupancy to 90.3%.

site_title: Artists give new life to Ivory Coast’s neglected Pyramid
summary: International and local artists are reviving Ivory Coast's neglected 15-storey pyramid-shaped building in Abidjan, a symbol of Ivorian prosperity in the 1970s. The "Pyramid 2023, tomorrow is already born" project aims to give the building a second life, highlighting Ivorian creativity and entrepreneurship in the cultural and creative industries. The renovation, led by artistic director Lemon Otto, will respect the original architecture and aims to make Abidjan a West African artistic and cultural hub, according to Minister of Culture Francoise Remarck.

images.alt_text: Ivorian artist Mounou Desire Koffi making an artwork with used telephone keyboards at his residence in Bingerville.

site_title: Jeff Shell out as NBCUniversal CEO after probe into inappropriate relationship
summary: Jeff Shell, CEO of NBCUniversal, has left the company after acknowledging an "inappropriate relationship" with a colleague. The decision comes after a complaint led to an investigation, which Comcast announced on April 23, 2023. Shell, who had been with Comcast for about two decades, takes immediate leave and does not name a successor. His departure follows a similar path of other high-profile executives who have lost their jobs over accusations of improper conduct or sexual harassment.

images.alt_text: Hollywood's problem: How to plan when it doesn't know who's watching what?

site_title: Revolut’s valuation cut by Schroders as fintech funding wanes
summary: Schroders has cut its stake in UK fintech firm Revolut by 46% to £5.4 million, valuing the investment at £4.7 million. This comes as investor caution impacts the fintech sector, following a 15% valuation cut by TriplePoint Venture Growth BDC last month. Despite Revolut's first annual profit in 2021, the company faces challenges, including delayed accounts and declining valuations. The UK's fintech sector saw investment drop by $22 billion in 2022, amid higher interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve last year embarked on an interest-rate hiking campaign that proved deleterious to stocks, bonds, crypto and other asset classes.

“I know about as much about fintech as I did about gin or mobile a few years ago, but Nuvei is impressive. The leadership team is exceedingly intelligent and hard-working and it’s about time a Canadian company got the type of attention American tech companies do.” said Hollywood actor and investor Ryan Reynolds.

site_title: Having a constant pipeline beats a start-stop strategy for housing developers
summary: Singapore's housing market continues to rise, with private home prices increasing 3.2% in the first quarter of 2023. However, developers are cautious in buying land, with only one bid for a state land tender at Lentor Gardens. This strategy may be wise due to rising interest rates, higher debt costs, and economic uncertainty. Constantly replenishing land banks may be a viable alternative, allowing developers to weather market fluctuations. This approach has been taken by groups such as GuocoLand, City Developments Ltd, and UOL Group, which can maintain a competitive edge, build a track record, and adapt to changing market expectations.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) data released on Monday (Apr 17) show that in March, developers sold 492 units, excluding ECs, up 13.6 per cent from the 433 units sold in February.
GuocoLand-Hong Leong Holdings tie-up is sole bidder for Lentor Gardens site at URA tender

site_title: Philippines' Marcos to seek specifics from Biden on US defence commitment
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr will meet with US President Joe Biden in Washington this weekend to discuss the US's commitment to defending the Philippines under the 1951 Mutual Defence Treaty. Marcos is seeking clarification on the circumstances under which the US would defend its ally amid growing regional tensions in the South China Sea. The meeting aims to reaffirm the US's "iron-clad commitments" to the Philippines' defense, following a steady build-up of military assets by China in the region. Marcos wants to manage tension with China and discuss the specifics of their alliance.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the review’s findings “will strengthen (the country's) national security and ensure (its) readiness for future challenges”.
The Pulse Asia survey found that 78 per cent of 1,200 respondents polled in March approved of Marcos’ performance, lower than the 82 per cent he got in November.

site_title: Philippines sticks to its 5-year GDP growth targets on economic momentum
summary: The Philippines has maintained its 5-year economic growth targets, citing domestic demand and labor conditions as key drivers. The country's GDP is expected to grow by 6.0% to 7.0% this year, and 6.5% to 8.0% from 2024 to 2028. Despite external challenges, such as geopolitical tensions and trade uncertainties, the government is committed to keeping inflation within its 2% to 4% target. The peso currency is also expected to remain stable, and the government aims to reduce its fiscal deficit-to-GDP ratio to 3.0% by 2028.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr (above) will hold talks with his US counterpart Joe Biden in Washington this weekend, a meeting the White House said would reaffirm its “iron-clad commitments to the defence of the Philippines”.
FILE PHOTO: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Governor Felipe Medalla poses for a photograph in his office at Manila, Philippines, November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eloisa Lopez/File Photo

site_title: China to test out 3D printing technology on Moon to build habitats
summary: China plans to use 3D printing technology to construct buildings on the Moon, with the goal of establishing a lunar base in five years. The Chang'e 8 mission, set to launch in 2028, will include a robot that creates "lunar soil bricks" using Moon soil. This technology will enable the use of the Moon's own materials for long-term human habitation, as stated by Wu Weiren, a scientist at the China National Space Administration. China's lunar ambitions come as the US and other countries also aim to return to the Moon, with NASA planning a human fly-by mission in 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A screen shows footages of spacecraft for Chang'e-5 Mission, during an event on China’s lunar exploration program, at the National Astronomical Observatories of Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), in Beijing, China, January 18, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan defence stocks emerge as hot trade on tension with China
summary: Taiwan's small-cap defense stocks have surged in response to increasing geopolitical tensions with China. Companies such as Thunder Tiger and Hocheng have seen over 23% gains, while Chenfull Precision and Aero Win Technology have risen 65% and 37% respectively over the past month. Analysts attribute the gains to "geopolitical risks and speculation" and caution against over-chasing the rally, citing signs of profit-taking.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese and Taiwanese printed flags are seen in this illustration taken, April 28, 2022. Picture taken April 28, 2022.  REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore headline, core inflation ease in March as expected
summary: Singapore's headline inflation eased to 5.5% in March, matching economists' expectations, with core inflation also decelerating to an eight-month low of 5%. Food inflation decreased to 7.7%, while private transport inflation declined to 8.6%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry expect core inflation to stay elevated before slowing down in the second half of the year. Economists predict a moderate pace of cost pass-through to consumers, with some expecting inflation to ease below 5% in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Shoppers at the meat section of the NTUC FairPrice Xtra supermarket at NEX on 23 March 2017.
Elysia Tan

site_title: Vietnam remains key beneficiary of supply chain shifts: DBS
summary: Vietnam continues to benefit from global manufacturing supply chain shifts, despite short-term cyclical growth headwinds. The country's foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows rose to the highest level since the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by its extensive free trade agreements, cost-competitive skilled labor, and proximity to China. DBS economist Chua Han Teng expects Vietnam to remain a key beneficiary for foreign manufacturing investment, with trade linkages with China expected to grow further. However, Vietnam's growth volatility and short-term headwinds may limit its ability to hit its 6.5% growth target for the full year, with DBS lowering its 2023 real GDP growth forecast to 5.5%.

images.alt_text: View of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

site_title: Oil prices slide on uncertainty over global economic outlook, rate hikes
summary: Oil prices slid on Monday, with Brent crude falling 48 cents, or 0.6%, to $81.18 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude down 48 cents, or 0.6%, to $77.39 a barrel. Concerns over rising interest rates, global economic uncertainty, and fuel demand outweighed support from Opec+ supply cuts. Weak US economic data and disappointing corporate earnings fueled growth concerns, while China's bumpy economic recovery and planned Opec+ supply cuts could tighten markets and push prices higher.

images.alt_text: A oil worker works on a oil pump "nodding donkey "at an oil field near Baku, Azerbaijan, on Friday, Jan. 30, 2009.  Since gaining its independence with the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union, Azerbaijan has become an important energy exporter and transport hub for Caspian Sea oil and gas. Photographer: Jeyhun Abdulla/Bloomberg News

site_title: Drone firm Aerodyne to pick Citigroup for funding round, sources say
summary: Aerodyne, a Malaysian drone services company, has chosen Citigroup for a funding round ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO). The company aims to raise US$150-200 million, with a potential first close in mid-year. Aerodyne, which uses artificial intelligence for data operations and analytics, will become a unicorn once its Series C round closes. The company had previously secured US$30 million in its Series B investment round in 2019.

images.alt_text: drone, camera, flying

site_title: Chinese digital currency stocks surge amid new efforts to promote e-CNY
summary: Chinese digital currency stocks surged on Monday amid efforts to promote the use of the digital yuan. Changshu, a city in Jiangsu province, will start paying civil servants and state sector employees in digital yuan from May. The move is part of China's trial to promote the e-CNY, with shares in related companies rising. However, some users expressed concerns about the lack of merchants accepting digital yuan, with one doctor saying she immediately converts it to traditional yuan due to a lack of spending scenarios.

site_title: ‘Super Mario’ fights off ‘Evil Dead’ to stay on top in North America
summary: "Super Mario" remains the top movie in North America, with a weekend ticket sales of $58.2 million, surpassing "Evil Dead Rise" ($23.5 million) and "The Covenant" ($6.3 million). The animated film, now in its third week, has accumulated $434.3 million domestically and $437 million internationally. "Evil Dead Rise" showed an impressive opening for its $17 million budget, while "The Covenant" underperformed in its opening weekend.

images.alt_text: Movie still: The Super Mario Bros Movie

site_title: Highest military spending in Europe since Cold War: study
summary: Europe's military spending reached its highest level since the Cold War in 2022, with a 13% increase from the previous year, driven by the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Global military expenditures reached $2.24 trillion, or 2.2% of the world's GDP, with the US and China accounting for over half of the world's military spending. Europe's spending, led by the UK, rose by a third in the past decade, and is expected to continue and accelerate over the next decade, with Ukraine alone increasing its spending seven-fold to $44 billion.

images.alt_text: There are many factors that make Poland a good investment destination; these include its stable economic growth and strategic location, among others.
Brokered by the United Nations (UN) and Turkey, the deal was signed in Istanbul last July, allowing Ukraine to export more than 27 million tonnes of grain from several of its Black Sea ports.

South Korean President Yoon Suk Yoon said his government has been exploring how to help defend and rebuild Ukraine, just as South Korea received international assistance during the 1950-53 Korean War.

site_title: Dubai plot of sand sells for 125m dirhams in luxury island record
summary: A 24,500 sq ft parcel of sand on Dubai's Jumeirah Bay Island sold for a record-breaking 125 million dirhams (S$45.4 million) on April 19, surpassing previous high-end sales. The buyer plans to build a family vacation home on the property, which works out to 5,000 dirhams per square foot. The sale marks a significant milestone in Dubai's booming real estate market, fueled by high oil prices, wealthy buyers, and low-tax, low-crime policies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of residential skyscrapers and a beach in Dubai, United Arab Emirates March 11, 2021. REUTERS/Abdel Hadi Ramahi/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Korea’s governor says some short-term rates have fallen more than expected
summary: South Korea's central bank governor Rhee Chang-yong stated that some short-term interest rates have fallen more than expected, likely due to a shift in funds in search of quick profit. This comes as the central bank's monetary policy tightening since late 2021 has led to a cooling trend in the real estate market and household borrowing. Rhee did not specify what actions the Bank of Korea would take with short-term interest rates, but the fall is seen as a sign that the tightening cycle may be over, with inflation and economic growth continuing to soften.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korea's new central bank governor Rhee Chang-yong speaks during his inauguration ceremony in Seoul, South Korea April 21, 2022. SeongJoon Cho/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: OCBC initiates coverage on First Reit with ‘buy’
summary: OCBC Investment Research has initiated coverage on First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) with a "buy" rating, citing stable income stream and improved financial performance for FY2022. The Reit's fair value estimate is set at S$0.31, implying it's trading at its book value. Analysts highlight the Reit's long weighted average lease expiry and rental escalation clauses, which provide potential rental growth and upside sharing with tenants. First Reit's distribution yield is forecasted to be 9.1% in FY23, making it a potential defensive addition to portfolios.

images.alt_text: Hikari Heights Varus Fujino, a nursing home in Japan under First Reit's portfolio. The manager of the Reit aims to increase its portfolio in developed markets to more than half of its assets under management by 2027.
First Reit's manager said that the proportion of debt tied to delivering social impact will also rise to 76.7 per cent from 26.1 per cent as at Sep 30.
Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta, one of First Reit's properties. The Reit is offering to buy back S$60 million of its perpetual securities at 70 per cent of the purchase price.

site_title: Uniqlo’s success mirrors the growth of Japan’s industrial giants
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese clothing retailer, has seen significant growth, with operating profits rising 48% in the first quarter of 2023 and shares increasing 53% over the past year. The company's expansion in Asia has been particularly rapid, with sales in the region up 71% and now accounting for 16% of total sales. Uniqlo's success mirrors that of Japan's industrial giants, which have also expanded in Asia, and the company is using automation to replace workers, reducing its workforce by up to 90% in some warehouses.

images.alt_text: epa10399419 The logo of Uniqlo clothing company is seen at a store in Tokyo, Japan, 11 January 2023. Fast Retailing, the operator of Uniqlo, announced that it will raise the annual salaries of approximately 8,400 domestic full-time employees by up to 40 percent. This first full-scale wage increase aims to increase the company's global competitiveness.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
Uniqlo plans to open 10 stores during the current fiscal year in North America, which ends in August, followed by 20 to 30 each year in order to reach Yanai’s goal of 200 stores.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust’s portfolio valuation falls; sponsor grapples with litigation, equity issues
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio valuation has declined 14% in renminbi terms and 23% in Singapore-dollar terms as of end-December 2022, due to factors such as a general decline in market performance, lower rental rates, and higher vacancy rates. The decline also poses a risk to the trust's gearing and loan obligations. The trust's sponsor, Zhongshan Dasin Real Estate, is facing litigation and equity issues, including 113 cases and freeze orders on its equity interests, but the trustee-manager believes these matters have not materially affected the trust's operations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Luso Bank on Jan 10 issued a letter of demand to Dasin’s trustee-manager, declaring an event of default and demanding payment.
The trustee-manager is negotiating to extend the loan maturity date of its offshore facilities.
Dasin Retail Trust up 2.8% on news of ARA's potential stake purchase in trustee-manager
Dasin Retail Trust enters into sale and purchase agreement with two subsidiaries of ARA Asset Management

site_title: South African rhino-lover seeks billionaire successor
summary: South African conservationist John Hume, 81, is auctioning off his 30-year-old rhino farm, home to 2,000 southern white rhinos, due to financial exhaustion. The farm, the world's largest, was initially valued at $150 million but is now being sold for $10 million. Hume believes the horns, worth $500 million on the black market, should be sold to fund conservation projects, creating a legal market. Despite increased protection, poaching remains a threat, with 448 rhinos killed in South Africa last year, and the species is now categorized as "near threatened" with around 18,000 remaining.

images.alt_text: Wild white rhinos are seen at an undisclosed location in the North-West Province of South Africa, on April 2, 2023. - South Africa is home to nearly 80 percent of the world's rhinos, making it a hotspot for poaching driven by demand from Asia, where horns are used in traditional medicine for their supposed therapeutic effect. The government said 448 of the endangered animals were killed across the country last year, only three fewer than in 2021, despite increased protection efforts at national parks, such as the renowned Kruger. (Photo by Luca Sola / AFP)

site_title: Manulife US Reit’s manager should invite MAS to act as “special scrutineer” of its strategic review
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) should set out its expectations for managers and sponsor groups of troubled real estate investment trusts (Reits). This comes as MAS considers tougher measures for Reits with foreign sponsors. MAS's decision aims to mitigate risks associated with external Reit managers, who rely on well-resourced local sponsors for support. By setting clear expectations, MAS can ensure Reits prioritize distribution per unit growth and resilience, rather than solely focusing on fee income and asset growth.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Tanasbourne is a 132,851 square foot office campus comprising three flex-office buildings. It was constructed between 1986 and 1995, and was refurbished in 2015, 2017 and 2020.
Manulife US Reit's properties could continue to be marked down with rising interest rates, slowing US economic growth and a continuation of hybrid work arrangements

Manulife US Reit says its unsecured sustainability-linked loan facility has been fully drawn to refinance its US$105 million Phipps mortgage loan, and that it will not have any refinancing requirements until 2024.
The big question now is how much longer it will take the Fed and other major central banks to get inflation under control
RHB lowered its target price for Manulife US Reit to US$0.40 while maintaining its "buy" call, after the Reit divested its Tanasbourne office campus.

site_title: Keppel FELS granted award in arbitration against Awilco Drilling unit
summary: Sembmarine's wholly-owned subsidiary Keppel FELS was awarded in favour in an arbitration against Awilco Drilling's unit, Awilco Rig 1 (AR1), for defaulting on a payment for a mid-water semisubmersible drilling rig. The outcome is not expected to impact Sembmarine's net tangible assets or earnings per share for FY2023.

images.alt_text: Keppel FELS has terminated its contracts with TS Offshore and Crystal Heights Holdings, which amount to over US$585 million in value.

site_title: Investors expect US dollar to keep sliding
summary: Professional investors anticipate the US dollar to slide further due to the Federal Reserve's impending interest rate cuts, with 87% expecting a rate cut to 3% or below. This contradicts market pricing, which puts the implied policy rate at 3.05%. Retail investors are more optimistic about the dollar, with many believing the Fed's rate path is underpriced. Historically, the Fed has diverged from global peers in cutting rates, and investors expect the yuan and yen to appreciate, contributing to the dollar's decline.

images.alt_text: usd, bills, dollars

site_title: South Koreans tap cash-giving apps to help offset rising living costs
summary: In South Korea, people are using cash-giving apps like Toss to help offset rising living costs. The app generates up to 10 cents per tap, with 4.4 million users having used its feature since its January launch. Experts say the trend shows people are going to great lengths to cope with an economic situation marked by high youth unemployment and inflation. While some users have made significant earnings, concerns have been raised about the potential for sensitive personal information to be shared with third parties.

images.alt_text: A woman eats a salad in front of office workers looking at their mobile phones to check the local online banking app Toss at Seoul Museum of Art during a lunch break in Seoul, South Korea, April 13, 2023.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Over US$68 billion withdrawn from Credit Suisse ahead of UBS takeover
summary: Credit Suisse withdrew over US$68 billion from funds in the first quarter of 2023, with 61.2 billion Swiss francs (S$91.7 billion) withdrawn in March alone. The outflows, which began as panic following the collapse of three US regional banks in March, have moderated but not reversed. Despite the significant outflows, the bank's net profit increased to 12.8 billion francs, up from a significant loss a year earlier. The bank's results are likely its final quarterly report before it is merged with rival UBS.

images.alt_text: UBS Group’s takeover of Credit Suisse Group will further diminish the banking sector’s economic importance to the country, newspaper Blick reported.

This is the first major lawsuit in the public domain to be filed over the Swiss decision to wipe out around US$18 billion of Credit Suisses AT1 debt during the three billion Swiss franc all-share rescue deal.

site_title: Sabana Reit fields queries on director independence from activist investor, unitholders
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has responded to allegations from activist investor Quarz Capital regarding the independence of its board director Elaine Lim and its decision to spend S$20 million on asset enhancement. Sabana Reit's manager disputed the claims, stating that the allegations are "false, untrue, and baseless" and that Lim was not acquainted with the sponsor ESR Group prior to her appointment. The manager also defended its decision to issue new units, citing the Reit's low leverage and available debt headroom. Unitholders are set to vote on the resolutions at the Reit's annual general meeting on April 25.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
In the first quarter of 2023, Sabana Industrial Reit's aggregate leverage ratio has increased to 33.1 per cent, and its weighted average fixed-debt expiry has fallen to 1.8 years.
Sabana Industrial Reit saw strong leasing momentum backed by robust demand from third-party logistics providers between January and March this year
The property at 1 Tuas Avenue 4, dubbed 1TA4, will incorporate solar panels that can potentially generate more than 1,000 megawatt-hours of energy per year, says Sabana Reit's manager.
As a result of the offer turning unconditional, the offer’s closing date has been extended by two weeks to 5.30pm on Mar 24, 2023, from the same time on Mar 10.
New Tech Park in Lorong Chuan is among the portfolio properties of Sabana Industrial Reit, which is among the 10 trusts with the lowest gearing ratios reported.
As a result of the offer turning unconditional, the offer’s closing date has been extended by two weeks to 5.30pm on Mar 24, 2023, from the same time on Mar 10.
The independent directors have not appointed an IFA to advise on the partial offer, and have instead consulted a duly licensed financial adviser.

Quarz noted that Volare’s voluntary conditional offer to acquire an additional 10 per cent of Sabana Reit units at S$0.465 per unit is more than 50 per cent above a previous offer that the directors had recommended as “fair and reasonable”.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. The Reit portfolio valuation for its 18 properties is up by 2.3 per cent on-year to S$885.7 million as at end-2022.

site_title: Australia to prioritise long-range strike capability in defence shakeup
summary: Australia's government will prioritize long-range precision strike, domestic production of guided weapons, and diplomacy in a defense shakeup, according to a review released Monday. The review, which recommends the country's biggest defense shakeup since World War Two, notes intense competition between the US and China in the Indo-Pacific region and the potential for conflict. Australia will focus on its northern bases to deter adversaries, protect trade routes, and strengthen engagement with Pacific and South East Asian nations, including increased bilateral military planning with the US. Defense funding will increase over the next decade.

images.alt_text: Europe spent 13 per cent more on its armies in 2022 than in the previous 12 months, in a year marked by the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: SGX Group sees diversification as key driver of resilience
summary: SGX Group delivered a robust performance in its fiscal first half despite volatile market conditions, driven by a well-diversified business model. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributes the resilience to the bourse's diversified revenue streams, with its derivatives business outperforming cash equities. Revenue from the derivatives segment increased, offsetting weaker cash equities revenue impacted by higher interest rates. The company remains well-positioned to capture growth in changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
In 2020, SGX signed a wide-ranging agreement with China Central Depository and Clearing Co, (CCDC) to strengthen and promote Singapore and China’s bond markets.
Earnings per share has risen to S$0.266 in H1 2023 from S$0.204 in H1 2022.

site_title: Gold prices steady as dollar retreats; Fed rate path in focus
summary: US gold futures edged 0.2% higher to US$1,993.30, following a dollar retreat. Spot gold held at US$1,983.68 per ounce, as the dollar index dropped 0.1%, making gold more affordable for international buyers. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike expectations remained unchanged, despite US business activity data backing a potential 25-basis-point rate hike at its May meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars are pictured at the plant of gold and silver refiner and bar manufacturer Argor-Heraeus in Mendrisio, Switzerland, July 13, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Thailand opposition leader says unity needed to beat military
summary: Thailand's opposition leader, Pita Limjaroenrat, urges unity among opposition parties to defeat the military in the upcoming election on May 14. Limjaroenrat, leader of the Move Forward Party, says the military-backed party is the wrong answer to Thailand's challenges. The election is a contest between pro-military conservatives and the populist opposition led by the Pheu Thai Party and its ally, the Move Forward Party. Limjaroenrat believes the opposition bloc is the right answer to face the country's challenges.

images.alt_text: A plane descends towards Chiang Mai International Airport amid high levels of air pollution in Chiang Mai, Thailand, April 10, 2023.
The industries sentiment index of the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) rose to 97.8 in March from 96.2 in February, when it had returned to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s forecasts must be quite strong to consider tweaking YCC: Ueda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that the central bank's inflation forecasts must be "quite strong and close to 2 per cent" in the coming year to consider tweaking yield curve control. Ueda emphasized that current trend inflation is below 2 per cent, requiring the BOJ to maintain monetary easing. However, when trend inflation reaches 2 per cent, the BOJ must normalize monetary policy, according to Ueda.

images.alt_text: The BOJ will examine the reasons undergirding Japan’s stagnant economy so that it can come up with effective policies under newly-appointed governor Kazuo Ueda.
The interior of Jaya Thursfield’s remodeled home in Ibaraki, Japan, March 12, 2023. Thursfield, who moved to Japan in 2017 with his wife, Chihiro, bought the abandoned home for 3 million yen in 2019.

A Tokyo Stock Exchange analysis shows that about half of the 1,800 companies on the exchange’s prime section were trading below their book value in January, meaning that the market is under-pricing the shares.
Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed ahead of tech earnings results
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Monday ahead of US tech earnings and interest rate decisions. Tokyo and Wellington rose, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul fell. Analysts expect US tech companies to provide key insights into the market, but warn that data on growth, inflation, and wages could change forecasts. Meanwhile, swaps markets suggest the US Federal Reserve may peak interest rates soon, followed by cuts, but experts believe a more aggressive cut is unlikely. Global economic data and Bank of Japan policy meetings will also be closely watched.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington and Taipei markets all fell by midday on Friday.

site_title: US-China tensions amplify global trade shifts, shipping CEO says
summary: US-China tensions are contributing to a decline in container shipments between the two largest economies, with a 10 percentage point drop in US imports from China over the past year. This shift is driven by a broad-based slowdown in the global economy and exacerbated by geopolitics, including tensions over Taiwan and the alleged spy balloon. As a result, the US is establishing stronger ties with other trade partners, such as Europe, with container freight rates in Europe remaining less precipitous. The decline is expected to continue, with shipping flows from other regions, including the Mediterranean and South-east Asia, into the US also increasing.

site_title: Millennials in South Korea love whisky so much they drove imports up by a record
summary: South Korea saw a record 78% increase in whisky imports in the first quarter of 2023, reaching 8,443 tonnes, with the majority coming from the UK and US. The surge is attributed to the growing popularity of whisky among millennials and Gen Z, who prefer the darker and heavier grain beverage for mixing with soda or using in cocktails. Whisky sales exceeded soju, the country's national drink, in the first two months of the year, with over half of whisky buyers in their 20s and 30s.

images.alt_text: whiskey, bar, alcohol

site_title: Vietnam hastens measures to shore up property market, fuelling hopes of a faster rebound
summary: Vietnam's property market is experiencing a slump due to a liquidity crunch, soaring interest rates, and tightened rules. The government has introduced measures to boost market sentiment, including a low-interest credit package for social housing projects and easing corporate bond regulations. Analysts expect the market to show a reversal by the middle of 2024, with some predicting a faster rebound. Global investors are taking notice, with CapitaLand in talks to acquire assets from Vietnam's Vinhomes, and foreign investors actively seeking deals in the country.

images.alt_text: The CapitaLand logo on the facade of Funan Centre.

site_title: WealthBT: Cancer cover in shield plans - is it enough? (Ep 25)
summary: The Health Ministry's cancer drug list has been updated, and Integrated Shield plans must now align with it. Riders, which previously allowed coverage for off-list drugs, are no longer available. However, some insurance companies may still offer riders, and premiums may rise. Affluent individuals should review their coverage and consider the implications of the changes, as they may be better off with the current system. The decision depends on individual circumstances and insurance provider policies.

images.alt_text: Howie Lim
Generic pictures of the National Cancer Centre Singapore showing the sign
What holds women back from investing more?

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,317.69. Despite gains in US and European markets, the broader market saw 48 gainers and 40 losers, with 17.8 million securities worth S$21.6 million changing hands. ESR-Logos Reit was the top traded counter, remaining flat despite its high trading volume.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation's Australian associates have filed civil claim proceedings against three of its subsidiaries regarding the group's solar farm in Queensland, Australia.

site_title: US dollar flat to modestly higher as upbeat data backs May rate hike
summary: The US dollar rose slightly against major currencies on April 21, driven by upbeat business activity data that supported expectations of a 25-basis-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The S&P Global US Composite PMI Output Index increased to 53.5, the highest since May last year, indicating growth in the private sector. The eurozone economy unexpectedly recovered in April, with the euro rising 0.1% against the dollar. Investors remain cautious, expecting the end of the Fed's tightening cycle, but rate futures market suggests a quarter-point rate hike next month.

images.alt_text: The euro edged up 0.1 per cent to US$1.0964, not far from a one-year high touched last week against the US dollar.

site_title: Why employers should wake up to the value of naps at work
summary: Employers are being urged to reconsider their stance on napping at work, as research suggests it can boost mental wellbeing and productivity. A study found that taking a 30-minute nap in the afternoon improved workers' psychological well-being, cognition, and productivity by an average 2.3%. In contrast, increasing sleep time by 27 minutes did not lead to significant improvements. Companies like Nike have already incorporated nap pods into their offices, and introducing similar spaces could have a positive impact on employees' well-being and productivity.

images.alt_text: Sleep is particularly important for higher-level cognitive skills that we use to control and coordinate our thoughts and behaviour.
Kawaii. Trailers for the new game suggest it combines a smartphone sleep tracker with gaming.

site_title: Signs of hope for China property market, but boom is over: analysts
summary: China's property market is showing signs of stabilization after a record-breaking slump last year, but analysts warn the sector is still on course to slow down in the long term. Despite a recent increase in property prices in major cities, the sector's growth is expected to rebound briefly before slowing down due to factors such as China's declining population and the government's push for housing as a living space, not for speculation. The sector's recovery is mainly benefiting big cities, while smaller cities continue to struggle, and some homeowners are refusing to pay mortgage payments.

images.alt_text: The property sector sharply slumped last year, but is now being buoyed by a slew of policies aimed at developers and buyers.

site_title: Funds raised by Singapore’s early-stage emerging tech startups down 28% in 2022
summary: Singapore's early-stage emerging tech startups raised US$253 million in funding in 2022, a 28.1% decrease from 2021. The number of funding deals fell 17.2% to 48, largely due to uncertain economic conditions. Amid the tough climate, the average size of seed rounds decreased across three key verticals. Despite these challenges, Singapore is expected to produce a "steady pipeline" of emerging tech startups, according to SGInnovate.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
SGInnovate CEO is driven by his desire for problem-solving
DPM Heng Swee Keat, who spoke at the launch event at SGInnovate’s office on Friday, says talent is a critical resource for innovation, especially in deep tech where very specific expertise is needed.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits still have room to grow as Chinese travellers return
summary: Hospitality S-Reits are expected to experience further growth as Chinese travelers return to the market. In 2022, these Reits saw the strongest distribution per unit (DPU) improvement among S-Reit cohorts, with median DPU rising 31.6%. Analysts believe the return of Chinese travelers will provide the necessary boost for further growth, despite most counters still trading below pre-pandemic levels. This positive outlook is attributed to the easing of global travel restrictions and the increased demand for hospitality services.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Financial stresses on the US office Reits are well documented. Share prices of Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit slumped as the market reassessed their financial stability and tenant risk.
Accelerated global travel recovery saw most of CDLHT’s portfolio markets experience robust performance growth in FY22.

site_title: Keppel faces A$66.5 million civil claim over Australian solar farm project
summary: Keppel Corporation's subsidiaries, Keppel Renewable Energy, KRE Anchorage, and Keppel Renewable Energy Australia, are facing a civil claim of up to A$66.5 million (S$59.4 million) over a solar farm project in Queensland, Australia. The claim, made by Sunshine Energy Australia and Australia Energy Group, alleges a breach of confidentiality and knowingly involved Keppel's subsidiary, KRE Anchorage. Keppel has denied all allegations and stated it will vigorously defend the claim.

Singapore energy-efficiency startup making inroads into Indonesia
Keppel to roll out energy-as-a-service infrastructure for S$50m

site_title: Asia’s asset managers trail Europe in managing ESG risks: WWF-Singapore
summary: Asia's asset managers trail Europe in managing climate and nature-related risks, according to a report by WWF-Singapore. The non-profit environmental group found that Asian asset managers scored an average of 33% on sustainability, compared to 77% in Europe. The region's managers lagged behind in managing nature-related risks, with only 33% recognizing the issue, and none having voting policies and expectations on urgent issues. WWF-Singapore recommended that Asian asset managers integrate nature-related impacts into financial decision-making and set voting guidelines on water risk-related issues.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The European Sustainable Investment Forum, whose most recent estimate put the market at US$12 trillion, is in the process of developing a revised methodology to calculate its actual size.
Rising natural gas prices will further drive countries like Singapore to diversify their energy sources, but challenges - such as space constraints when it comes to solar deployment - remain. PHOTO:

site_title: Media’s climate crisis coverage favours denial and avoidance: study
summary: A Swiss study found that media coverage of the climate crisis tends to focus on broad, long-term projections and narrow threats, potentially provoking denial and avoidance rather than pro-environmental behaviors. Researchers analyzed 50,000 scientific publications and found that mainstream media prioritizes natural science field research and future projections, which may not engage readers. The study suggests that a more solution-oriented approach, highlighting direct consequences on lifestyles and finances, is needed to inspire action.

site_title: South Korea proposes bill to protect victims of rental fraud
summary: South Korea's ruling People Power Party proposes a bill to protect victims of rental fraud, estimated to have lost millions of US dollars. The traditional jeonse rental system, where tenants pay upfront, has led to suspected scams, resulting in apparent suicides and a police investigation. The proposed bill includes state-run Korea Land & Housing buying affected properties and converting them into public rental homes, as well as granting affected tenants a pre-emptive right to buy the property. The government also plans to revise a separate law to add aggravated punishment for specific crimes related to rental fraud.

site_title: HSBC shareholders should vote against Asia spinoff plan, says adviser ISS
summary: HSBC shareholders are advised to vote against a resolution by Ping An, the bank's largest shareholder, which calls for considering strategic options including a spinoff of the bank's Asia business. The proposal lacks detailed rationale, according to ISS, a shareholder advisory group. This is the second major group to side with HSBC, following Glass Lewis, which also deemed the plan lacking merit. HSBC has disputed the plan, saying it would destroy shareholder value and be too costly to implement. The bank and Ping An have been arguing over the proposal ahead of HSBC's annual general meeting on May 5.

site_title: Singapore’s hydrogen strategy must go further
summary: Singapore's National Hydrogen Strategy needs to set concrete targets, establish demand-creation mechanisms, and include risk-mitigation policies to achieve its goal of having hydrogen account for at least half of the country's fuel mix by 2050. The strategy, which aims to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, must address the challenges posed by hydrogen's nascent technology, limited domestic production, and reliance on international imports. A more comprehensive approach is necessary to overcome these headwinds and ensure Singapore's hydrogen transition is successful.

images.alt_text: Hydrogen is already the largest component in the town gas produced at City Energy’s Senoko Gasworks plant, the company said.
An artist's impression of Singapore's LNG Terminal on Jurong Island.
Singapore's leading position in oil and gas should be preserved until the country is ready for the final step of decarbonisation.

site_title: China’s BYD gears up for global electric car race
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD debuted new models at the Shanghai Auto Show, marking its fresh foray into the luxury market. The company posted record sales of 1.8 million vehicles in 2022, with revenue of 424 billion yuan and net profit of 16.62 billion yuan. BYD aims to become China's largest car manufacturer with a sales target of 3.6 million autos in 2023. The company is pursuing a strategy of multiple brands to expand its product portfolio while seeking sales overseas. BYD's vertically integrated supply chain and high degree of self-reliance have helped it avoid disruptions in the global auto industry.

images.alt_text: A GWM executive unveils the B07 Fierce Dragon Max from the company’s export-focused Haval brand.
A Tesla Model X is now priced at US$97,490 in the United States, an increment of about 2.6 per cent.
Zeekr, a premium electric vehicle (EV) brand owned by Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, highlighted how its newly released X model SUV has seats that can massage passengers.
The announcement was made as part of Australia’s first national electric vehicle strategy.

site_title: Top UK firms invited to join new lobby group amid CBI chaos
summary: The UK's largest firms, including banks, retailers, and telecommunications companies, have been invited to join BizUK, a new lobby group created by public affairs firm WPI Strategy following the CBI's exodus amid allegations of sexual assault. BizUK aims to support business representation to main political parties ahead of the January 2025 general election. The group is described as a temporary body, not intended to replace the CBI, which has suspended operations after dozens of major companies resigned. BizUK will focus on supporting businesses to engage with the main political parties.

site_title: Crypto firm Zipmex’s investor pulls plug on US$100 million bailout
summary: Zipmex, a Singapore-based crypto exchange, is facing deeper trouble after its Thai investor, V Ventures, scrapped a US$100 million deal to rescue the company and restore customer funds. The investor demanded a clawback of US$4.6 million, which was used for working capital, and accused Zipmex of failing to fulfill its obligations. This deal termination is another blow to Zipmex's 70,000 customer-creditors, who were holding out for a full return of their crypto assets. Zipmex is now under a court-granted debt moratorium and may seek damages from V Ventures for reneging on the deal.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Zipmex, which fell victim to last year’s bear market in virtual coins, plans to ask the court to extend its creditor protection period in Singapore to give it time to seek alternative investors.
In a lawyer's letter, V Ventures pointed to unresolved matters over Zipmex’s proposed scheme of arrangement.
While the question of recognising crypto as money remains unanswered for now, cases revolving around this issue will be something to watch.

site_title: US, other nations scramble to evacuate citizens as Sudan battles rage
summary: US, France, and Turkey have launched evacuation operations from Sudan amid ongoing deadly fighting between rival generals. Over 400 people have been killed and thousands wounded in the conflict, with ferocious battles between the Sudanese army and a paramilitary group. More than 150 people from various nations have reached safety in Saudi Arabia after a naval rescue operation, and the US has evacuated fewer than 100 embassy staff. The UN and international community are calling for the violence to stop, but the situation remains volatile, with fighting continuing in Khartoum and other parts of the country.

images.alt_text: Saudi Royal Navy officers assist a child onboard their navy ship as they evacuate Saudi and other nationals are through Saudi Navy Ship from Sudan to escape the conflicts, Port Sudan, Sudan, April 22, 2023. Saudi Ministry of Defense/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS PICTURE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY

site_title: What to do when you have a horrible boss
summary: A toxic work relationship can significantly impact job satisfaction and mental health. To address the issue, consider evaluating your boss's behavior and evaluating whether the problems can be solved. If the relationship is salvageable, tactfully point out issues to your manager, focusing on specific actions and outcomes. If not, act quickly and cut your losses, refraining from heated confrontations and prioritizing your mental health and finding a new job with a better organizational culture.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Asia insurers look to asset diversification, new product designs to weather higher interest rates
summary: Asian insurers are diversifying their portfolios and redesigning insurance products in response to rising interest rates. Insurers typically hold longer-term assets to match their longer-term liabilities, but with higher interest rates, they can now earn higher returns from shorter-term, higher-quality fixed income instruments. Some insurers, such as Great Eastern, are adjusting their bond portfolios to take advantage of the improved returns. Others may shift into alternative assets like real estate to generate uncorrelated returns. Insurers are also focusing on protection-based and health products to maintain competitiveness, as customers may prefer longer lock-in periods of insurance contracts over bank deposits.

images.alt_text: accounting, report, credit card
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of April 21, 2023. The market started slow due to a healthy supply of tonnage in the Pacific and limited enquiry, particularly from East Coast Australia to China. However, fresh enquiry emerged from East Coast Australia to China, and rates began to rise. The North Atlantic market was tight on tonnage, with limited activity. Despite a positive paper market, rates lost ground due to profit taking towards the end of the week.

images.alt_text: The VLCC market showed some optimism off the back of a thinner tonnage list, with the exception of the US Gulf to China route.

site_title: Manufacturers hope for AI boost in factories
summary: Manufacturers are optimistic about the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) in boosting factory efficiency. Following the launch of chatbot ChatGPT, AI has been gaining traction across various sectors, including manufacturing. At the Hanover Fair in Germany, companies showcased prototypes that use AI to repair complex machinery and improve factory performance. Aleph Alpha, a German startup, is working with HPE to develop an AI-equipped virtual assistant that can guide repairs and detect problems. Industry leaders believe AI will increase efficiency and alleviate workforce shortages, rather than replace jobs.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 17, 2023 Philip Singer, business architect for data and AI at Hewlett-Packard Enterprises (HPE), operates a robot (developed in cooperation between HPE and German AI startup Aleph Alpha) that is able to speak and answer questions at the HANNOVER MESSE 2023, the Hanover technology fair, in Hanover, Germany. - Manufacturers are hoping for the artificial intelligence revolution to reach their factories, envisaging robots being used to repair complex machinery. (Photo by Axel Heimken / AFP)

site_title: IPO market shows signs of life even as recession fears persist
summary: The global IPO market is showing signs of life, with $25 billion raised in March and April, nearly twice the amount seen in the first two months of the year. Asia led the way, accounting for 80% of new share sales, with Indonesia emerging as a bright spot. However, the US remains challenged, with only $4.1 billion raised so far this year, and concerns about a recession and interest rates continue to deter investors. Despite this, some European companies have managed to raise funds, and analysts predict a gradual recovery in the IPO market.

images.alt_text: Hiroyuki Nagai, president and chief executive officer of Rakuten Bank Ltd., attends the company's listing ceremony at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, April 21, 2023. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: Sotheby’s helped more rich clients dodge sales tax, NY attorney general says
summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James says Sotheby's allegedly helped wealthy art collectors avoid paying sales tax on purchases for their homes. The alleged effort was "far more extensive and serious than previously known," expanding a 2020 lawsuit against the company. Seven additional collectors and numerous Sotheby's employees are now included in the investigation, including those from the tax department. Documents revealed that the alleged tax dodge was just the tip of the iceberg, with the AG seeking permission to depose more people involved in the alleged practice.

images.alt_text: epa10580470 Aurelie Vandevoorde, director of the modern art department at Sotheby's, hosts the auction of the collection "Le Soufle moderne, a Parisian collection" at Sotheby's in Paris, France, 19 April 2023. The collection gathers 13 works of the main avant-garde painters of the 30's and 40's, artists like Pablo Picasso, Joan Miro, Fernand Leger and Georges Braque among others.  EPA-EFE/TERESA SUAREZ

site_title: Loss-making residential resale deals hit five-year low
summary: The proportion of loss-making residential resale deals in Singapore's secondary market hit a five-year low in Q1 2023, with 95% of private home secondary-market deals yielding gains. According to Cushman & Wakefield, the proportion of loss-making deals dipped to 4.2% in Q1 2023, down from 4.5% in Q4 2022 and 18.2% in Q1 2019. Rising interest rates and economic headwinds are expected to add upward pressure on loss-making deals, but analysts predict the proportion will remain relatively low due to strong demand and tight employment market.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: US: Stocks end low-key session with slight gains
summary: US stocks ended a low-key session with slight gains on Friday, April 21, as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 33,808.96. Investors focused on corporate earnings, which were mixed, ahead of a busy week of major earnings reports from tech giants like Apple and Microsoft. Analysts expect these reports to be key catalysts for market movement.

images.alt_text: “Our volumes are starting to stabilise, which is what we wanted to see,” P&G chief financial officer Andre Schulten said.
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Singapore ChatGPT-powered tutoring app seeks funding at US$100 million-plus value
summary: Singapore-based startup Higgz Academia Technology is seeking a $100 million valuation in a fresh funding round, capitalizing on the rise of OpenAI's ChatGPT. The tutoring app developer, founded in Beijing, has attracted hundreds of thousands of monthly users with its TutorEva app, which uses ChatGPT's AI to provide step-by-step math solutions. The company plans to roll out customized math tutoring services and expand into more STEM subjects, competing with established players like Google and Microsoft.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Chipmaker Arm to make its own semiconductor: FT
summary: British chipmaker Arm is developing its own semiconductor to showcase its capabilities and attract new customers, following its IPO later this year. Arm will team up with manufacturing partners to create a new chip, which is considered more advanced than its previous products. The chip will be used in mobile devices, laptops, and other electronics, and Arm has built a solutions engineering team to lead its development. The company plans to produce a prototype chip, but has no intention of selling or licensing the product.

images.alt_text: A smartphone with a displayed Arm Ltd logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: BOJ to review policies from past decades
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) will review and inspect its past policies over the past three decades, starting a two-day meeting on April 27-28 under newly-appointed governor Kazuo Ueda. The goal is to identify the reasons behind Japan's stagnant economy and develop effective policies. The review will consider the BOJ's easing of policy since 1999, including the adoption of zero-interest rates and negative interest rates. The meeting will aim to determine the bank's yield curve control and negative interest rates are still suitable, but also open to a longer-term policy review.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda participates in a news conference at the Fairmont Washington D.C. Georgetown hotel in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond files for bankruptcy protection after long struggle, begins liquidation sale
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in a New Jersey court, listing assets and liabilities of $1 billion to $10 billion. The company has received $240 million in debtor-in-possession financing and will continue to operate its 360 stores and websites. A liquidation sale has begun, and the company had previously planned to raise $1 billion through a stock offering that was later terminated. Bed Bath & Beyond had reported a loss of $393 million and sales plunged 33% in the previous quarter, leading to the company's financial struggles.

images.alt_text: Bed Bath & Beyond has publicly warned of its solvency challenges and said it is considering bankruptcy.

site_title: Credit Suisse crisis ramps up Swiss bank sector decline: Blick newspaper
summary: Switzerland is no longer considered a banking nation as the sector's economic importance continues to decline. Credit Suisse Group's takeover by UBS Group further diminishes the sector's contribution to the country's economy, now accounting for less than 5% of gross domestic product (GDP). Other industries, such as the pharmaceutical and chemicals sectors, have become more significant contributors to the economy, with growth rates of 5.9% per year and 6.3% of GDP, respectively.

images.alt_text: Bloomberg News pix - A customer enters in an automated teller machines (ATM) section of a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch in Geneva, Switzerland, on Thursday, Sept. 1, 2022. Credit Suisse is weighing cutting 4,000 jobs, a significant part of them in Zurich, as the lender overhauls its business after a series of financial and reputational hits, according to Handelsblatt. Photographer: Jose Cendon/Bloomberg News

site_title: SVB still seeing outflows after First Citizens takeover
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), which collapsed after a bank run in March, is still experiencing outflows of deposits under new ownership by First Citizens BancShares. President Peter Bristow attributed the withdrawals to pent-up demand during the period of Federal Deposit Insurance Corp's receivership. Despite this, First Citizens' stock has risen 77% since the takeover, with the bank experiencing "green shoots" of confidence. Bristow also hinted at a potential rethink of SVB's focus on lending to venture capitalists, which may have contributed to the deposits' "lumpiness".

site_title: German public-sector deal sees pay rise for 2.5 million workers
summary: Germany's public-sector workers, including 2.5 million employees, have reached a wage deal with employers after weeks of strikes and negotiations. The agreement includes one-time payments of 3,000 euros and permanent salary increases of 200 euros and 5.5% starting in 2024. The deal aims to alleviate the rising cost of living and follows a similar agreement secured by industrial workers last year.

site_title: Japan has millions of empty houses. Want to buy one for US$25,000?
summary: Japan has an estimated 8.5-11 million empty houses, known as "akiya," which are being purchased by foreigners and renovated at a fraction of their original cost. Akiya are typically abandoned after the previous owner's family refuses to inherit them or the owner dies without naming an heir. To address the issue, municipalities are partnering with private companies to list akiya for sale or rent, and some are offering subsidies for demolitions. The akiya glut has sparked a cottage industry of consultants and real estate firms specializing in the sale of these properties, which are seen as a unique cultural asset.

images.alt_text: The interior of Jaya Thursfield’s remodeled home in Ibaraki, Japan, March 12, 2023. Thursfield, who moved to Japan in 2017 with his wife, Chihiro, bought the abandoned home for 3 million yen, or around $23,000, in 2019 and set about renovating it. (Andrew Faulk/The New York Times)

site_title: ING sues ICBC for copper deal losses, seeks US$170m in damages
summary: ING is suing ICBC for losses sustained in copper deals, seeking $170 million in damages. The Dutch bank alleges ICBC breached contract terms by releasing export documents without collecting payment. The alleged breach led to ING booking losses on metals sold to Maike Metals International by Triway International, a unit of Maike based in Hong Kong. Maike filed for preliminary restructuring in February due to a liquidity crisis, and the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has asked ING about the case.

images.alt_text: Net profit for the three months ended December fell to 94.7 billion yuan from 96.5 billion yuan a year earlier, ICBC said in a stock exchange filing.

site_title: UK gears up for King Charles III’s coronation
summary: King Charles III will be crowned king next month, marking the first coronation in Britain in 70 years and only the second to be televised. The ceremony, set for May 6 at Westminster Abbey, will be attended by 2,000 dignitaries, including Charles's grandchildren, and will feature the Crown Jewels and Coronation Chair. The event comes amid concerns about public apathy and cost, with some 51% of Britons believing taxpayers should not foot the bill. The coronation marks a new chapter for the monarchy, with Charles's wife Camilla set to be crowned queen.

images.alt_text: A YouGov poll found 51 per cent of respondents believe the May 6 ceremony to crown Charles and Camilla should not be paid for by the government.

site_title: When managers try to be therapists, worker mental health suffers
summary: US managers are overstepping their bounds when attempting to address worker mental health, despite well-intentioned efforts. A survey found that 9 out of 10 US adults believe the country is facing a mental health crisis, with employees feeling uncomfortable discussing their mental health with managers. Experts say that managers are often ill-equipped to handle these conversations and may inadvertently increase worker stress. Employers are taking steps to improve, such as training managers and providing employee-assistance programs, but concerns remain about the potential for unintended consequences and cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: Your relationship with your boss can make or break you, so it's important to either keep a good one, or move on quickly.
The version of a CEO on display like Andi Owen in her viral rant clip fits perfectly into post-pandemic worker anxiety: do our bosses think we're whiners?
The reward of a better-quality workplace environment, culture and relationships will make the effort of complaining, or establishing a positive feedback culture, worthwhile.

site_title: S&P Futures expected to be range-bound with bearish bias in medium term
summary: The E-mini S&P 500 Futures contract is expected to be range-bound with a bearish bias in the medium term, driven by hawkish interest rate expectations and a resilient US economy. Despite recent rallies, market expectations for rate cuts have diverged from the Fed, and the contract may see renewed downward pressure if economic data suggests the economy remains strong. A bearish outlook is maintained due to a forecasted poor Q1 earnings season, downbeat forward guidance, and a "good news is bad news" backdrop, where strong economic data could prompt the Fed to continue hiking rates.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MARCH 16: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 16, 2023 in New York City. Stocks fell again in morning trading as investors continue to show concerns over the stability of global banks following the collapse last week of Silicon Valley Bank.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Biden plans to slash planet-warming pollution from power plants
summary: The Biden administration is set to unveil a proposal to slash greenhouse gas emissions from US power plants by 2040, targeting coal- and gas-fired power plants. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has drafted a plan with rate-based limits on pollution, allowing for efficiency gains, carbon capture systems, and cleaner hydrogen. Existing facilities would have flexibility in meeting requirements, and plant closures could help satisfy the limits. The measure aims to accelerate a shift towards renewable sources and dovetails with the administration's goal to reduce US greenhouse gas emissions by at least 50% by 2030.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden plans to sign an executive order that will establish a new Office of Environmental Justice within the White House aimed at coordinating efforts across the government.

site_title: 32 S-Reits release schedule for this reporting season
summary: 32 Singapore Reits and property trusts have released financial results or updates for Q1 2023, with four trusts already reporting. Keppel Reit saw 1.3% year-on-year growth in net property income, while Keppel DC Reit's distributable income and distribution per unit increased by 4.1% and 3.0% respectively. Sabana Industrial Reit reported its highest portfolio occupancy since 2021, at 92.6%, driven by new leases and demand for warehouse properties.

images.alt_text: Jubilee Bridge with the Central Business District (CBD) skyline shot from outside Esplanade on February 18, 2022.

site_title: What if we all work for a ‘Pity City’ boss?
summary: CEO of 11,000-employee company MillerKnoll, Andi Owen, faced backlash after a leaked video clip showed her telling employees not to "worry about" their bonuses, despite the company not having made decisions yet. The clip, which was part of a 75-minute town hall meeting, sparked outrage on social media, with many questioning whether their bosses secretly think they're "whiners." The incident highlights the tension between empathetic public personas and private frustrations, particularly for female CEOs who face pressure to maintain a warm and respectful tone.

images.alt_text: Your relationship with your boss can make or break you, so it's important to either keep a good one, or move on quickly.
It can be tough to make the choice to leave when you're comfortable where you are, and the outside is uncertain.
Those who came into work devoted more time to mentoring others, in formal training and doing professional development and learning activities.
Big tech companies have long been willing to fund efforts with no obvious payoff. But those groups have been hit hard in recent layoffs.

site_title: P&G says consumer demand is stabilising despite higher prices
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has raised its sales projection for the fiscal year, citing higher prices and a slight increase in demand for some products. Organic sales are expected to grow about 6% from the prior year, with total unit sales falling 3% in the quarter ended in March. The company's volumes are starting to stabilise, and while profit outlook remains unchanged, gross margins expanded to 48.2%, exceeding analyst expectations. Despite a US economic slowdown, P&G's results indicate relatively contained economic impact.

site_title: Taiwan's Apple supplier Quanta plans Vietnam factory
summary: Taiwan's Apple supplier Quanta Computer signed an agreement with Nam Dinh province authorities in northern Vietnam to construct a factory at an industrial park. The facility, set to be Quanta's 9th globally, will initially cover 22.5 hectares and is expected to be operational without a specified capacity or timeline for construction.

site_title: Europe: Shares end fifth week higher on earnings boost
summary: European shares ended the week higher for the fifth consecutive week, driven by strong quarterly earnings from SAP and EssilorLuxottica, which boosted the pan-European Stoxx 600 index by 0.4%. SAP reported above-expected revenue and plans to integrate generative AI into its products, while EssilorLuxottica's earnings also exceeded expectations. This offset a slump in miners, marking a positive end to the week for European markets.

images.alt_text: Workers during the morning rush hour in the financial district of Canary Wharf in London. Last year, the UK economy grew by 4.1 per cent, but things look bleaker in 2023.

FILE PHOTO: The building of the European Central Bank (ECB) is seen in fog before the monthly news conference following the ECB's monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, December 15, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Twitter reinstates blue ticks for some media, celebrities
summary: Twitter has reinstated blue ticks on some media, celebrity, and high-profile accounts, despite the fact that these users did not pay for the verification. The move, part of Elon Musk's "Twitter Blue" strategy, was met with protests from many affected users. A small fraction of blue-ticked users subscribed, with less than 5% of the 407,000 affected profiles. Celebrities like Stephen King, LeBron James, and Donald Trump regained their blue ticks without taking action. Twitter has also reinstated gold badges for major media groups, including The New York Times, after previously criticizing the organization.

images.alt_text: Musk made his prediction on the eve of Twitter’s Apr 1 ultimatum that verified accounts with the cherished blue tick that had not forked over cash would lose it.

site_title: SVB CEO, CFO resign, company appoints turnaround expert as interim finance head
summary: SVB Financial Group's CEO Gregory Becker and CFO Daniel Beck resigned on April 19 and April 18, respectively. The company appointed Nicholas Grossi of Alvarez & Marsal as interim CFO. This comes after shareholders sued the two executives for concealing the risks of rising interest rates on the bank. SVB's restructuring committee is working to address the lender's financial struggles.

site_title: US business activity rises to 11-month high in April: S&P Global survey
summary: US business activity surged to an 11-month high in April, according to a survey, with the PMI Output Index reaching 53.5, the highest level since last May. This marked the third straight month of growth above 50, indicating expansion in the private sector. The increase in new orders received by private businesses was the highest since last May, with a reading of 53.2. The data contradicts growing recession concerns due to higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: The services sector is now at the heart of the fight against inflation as services prices tend to be stickier and less responsive to interest rate increases.

site_title: The dollar isn’t losing its dominance: Larry Summers
summary: Former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers rejected speculation that the dollar is losing its dominance, citing China's detractions in providing an alternative reserve currency. Despite the International Monetary Fund's data showing the dollar's share fell to 58% in December, Summers questioned the feasibility of a massive shift to Chinese yuan reserves, suggesting policymakers should focus on shoring up the US's long-term finances and strengthening its appeal. Summers' comments come amid ongoing speculation about the dollar's status as the global reserve currency.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which tracks the currency against a basket of its peers was 0.47 per cent higher at 102.19.
The euro edged up 0.1 per cent to US$1.0964, not far from a one-year high touched last week against the US dollar.

site_title: Emerging market banks are resilient
summary: Emerging market banks are showing resilience amid turmoil in US and Swiss banking systems. Their conservative approach, characterized by high levels of excess capital and tighter regulation, has helped them avoid deposit flight. Unlike US regional banks and Credit Suisse, EM banks have maintained higher capital levels and avoided buying government bonds, reducing their risk of a liquidity squeeze. As a result, EM banks are expected to perform better, with increased fee-based income, credit demand, and mortgage demand driving growth, potentially widening the price-to-book valuation premium for the sector.

images.alt_text: China’s big banks have typically relied on so-called additional Tier-1 and Tier-2 bonds in recent years to replenish capital.
President Lula said the Brics bank has great potential “in that it frees emerging countries from submission to traditional financial institutions, which want to govern us.”

site_title: Exit of Sunak’s No. 2 only deepens battle within UK government
summary: UK Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab has resigned after a probe found he "acted in a way that was intimidating" and "involved an abuse or misuse of power." This marks the third Cabinet member to depart during Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's six-month tenure, escalating a bullying scandal that threatens to destabilize the government. Raab's combative resignation letter criticized the findings, calling for a separate investigation into senior Ministry of Justice officials.

images.alt_text: More than a year of stop-start and sometimes rancorous negotiations between London and Brussels on an overhaul of the 2020 EU exit deal look to be coming to a conclusion, perhaps as early as Monday, with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak saying he was “giving it everything” to get a deal done.
In a letter to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, Raab said the inquiry had set a dangerous precedent, but that he would remain supportive of the government.

site_title: Nasdaq appoints Cohen and Griggs as co-presidents, formalising new structure
summary: Nasdaq appoints Tal Cohen and Nelson Griggs as co-presidents, formalizing the company's new corporate structure. This move comes after CEO Adena Friedman stepped down as president, who also took on the role of chair of the board. The new co-presidents will focus on unlocking the value of Nasdaq's organizational structure and advancing key strategic priorities, working closely with Friedman.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Nasdaq logo is displayed at the Nasdaq Market site in Times Square in New York City, U.S., December 3, 2021. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: Oil rises but post weekly loss as economic uncertainty weighs
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, with Brent futures increasing 56 cents to $81.66 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 50 cents to $77.87 per barrel. Despite this, the week's losses in Brent and WTI crude were significant, with 5.4% and 5.6% declines, respectively. Economic uncertainty and interest rate concerns weighed on the market, leading to the weekly losses.

images.alt_text: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will collaborate with Shell Eastern Trading to support the adoption of electric harbour craft.
Brent crude futures settled at US$81.10 a barrel, shedding US$2.02, or 2.4 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Accountant shortage leaves some US cities without credit ratings
