summary: S&P Global Ratings has withdrawn ratings for 64 US local governments and utility systems due to their failure to submit financial information on time. This affects cities such as Marion, Ohio, which has put a new $10 million firehouse project on hold. The withdrawal is described as "catastrophic" by Marion's auditor, making it difficult for the city to move forward with financial decisions. The lack of credit ratings raises concerns about the financial stability of these local governments and utility systems.

site_title: US inflation down much faster after tighter credit from bank failures
summary: US inflation is expected to come down faster than initially projected due to tighter credit conditions following several bank failures. Economists lowered their projections for the consumer price index and personal consumption expenditures price index for the first half of 2024. The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge, PCE, is now expected to end the year at 3.8% on an annual basis, almost double the central bank's target. Despite this, economists believe a hard landing for the economy is likely, and interest-rate cuts may be necessary later this year.

images.alt_text: Nearly 90 per cent of the economists who participated in the latest Reuters poll, predicted the US central bank would hike its key policy rate by 25 basis points to the 5.00 to 5.25 per cent range at a May 2-3 meeting.

site_title: Deloitte to cut 1,200 jobs in the US: FT
summary: Deloitte is cutting 1,200 US jobs, approximately 1.5% of its workforce, mainly in its financial advisory business due to a slump in merger and acquisition activity. This move follows similar job cuts by rival Ernst & Young, and comes as several financial firms have reduced staff in recent months amidst a turbulent macroeconomic environment.

site_title: Tennis’ Djokovic hoping to hit top gear on clay after Banja Luka exit
summary: Novak Djokovic lost his quarter-final match to Dusan Lajovic at the Srpska Open, falling 6-4 7-6(6). Djokovic attributed his poor performance to playing worse than he wanted to, despite Lajovic's strong play. This loss marks Djokovic's second early exit from a tournament in two weeks, following his defeat at the Monte Carlo Masters. Djokovic remains hopeful of finding his form on clay ahead of the French Open.

images.alt_text: “Our current intention is to accept entries from Russian and Belarusian players subject to them competing as ‘neutral’ athletes and complying with appropriate conditions,” the All England Lawn Tennis Club (AELTC) said in a statement.
“We have not been able to achieve everything we set out for, but we have been in touch with people close to Peng and are assured she is living safely with her family in Beijing,” the WTA said.

site_title: Shrewd and successful Brighton become England's model club
summary: Brighton & Hove Albion, a club from the English football pyramid, has become a model for clubs without significant resources. Despite losing their manager and key players, they are the bookies' favorites to beat Manchester United in the FA Cup final. Manager Roberto De Zerbi has built a strong team through shrewd recruitment and a global scouting network. Brighton's success is a testament to De Zerbi's coaching and the club's business acumen, with their only previous FA Cup final appearance coming in 1983.

images.alt_text: Chelsea co-owner and chairman Todd Boehly watched his team exit the Champions League on Wednesday after a 4-0 aggregate defeat to Spain's Real Madrid.

Soccer Football - Europa League - Play-Off Second Leg - Manchester United v FC Barcelona - Old Trafford, Manchester, Britain - February 23, 2023
General view of a corner flag inside the stadium before the match REUTERS/Carl Recine

site_title: Google Bard can now help write software code
summary: Google has announced that its Bard AI chatbot can now help write software code, playing catch-up in the AI technology race with Microsoft's ChatGPT. Bard can code in 20 programming languages, debug, and optimize code with simple prompts. The update allows Bard to assist users in developing software, expanding its capabilities beyond traditional search functionality. This move aims to further integrate Bard into the tech landscape and provide users with a more comprehensive AI experience.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Google LLC is seen at the Google Store Chelsea in New York City, U.S., January 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo

site_title: Ping An says HSBC just repeating past rebuttals of spinoff plan
summary: HSBC's biggest shareholder Ping An has accused the bank of failing to engage in "deep discussions" over its proposal to spin off the Asia business, after HSBC said the plan was "destructive of shareholder value." Ping An chairman Huang Yong stated that HSBC's repeated rebuttals are merely a continuation of past responses, and that the bank should respect its shareholders' concerns. The spat has intensified ahead of HSBC's annual shareholder meeting on May 5, where investors will vote on a resolution requiring the bank to deliver updates on strategic ideas.

images.alt_text: HSBC wrote in a letter to shareholders that “the board strongly believes that (the bank) should focus on executing the current strategy that is delivering”.
HSBC should separate its Asia business into a Hong Kong-listed entity, Ping An said, in an update to proposals it began urging last November calling for the bank to spin off its Asia business.

site_title: US: Wall St subdued at open, focus on business activity data
summary: US stock indexes opened subdued on Friday, with the S&P 500 rising 0.06% to 4,132.14, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.02% to 33,793.60. Investors digested mixed earnings reports and awaited data on US interest rates and the economy, which may influence interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Cities keep building luxury apartments almost no one can afford
summary: Cities are building luxury apartments at an unprecedented rate, despite efforts to loosen regulations and promote affordable housing. Austin, Texas, has issued nearly 26,000 multifamily housing permits in 2021, with many units classified as luxury. Academics and developers argue that "building, build, build" is the solution to the housing crisis, but critics claim that luxury developments are pricing out low-income residents. The trend is seen in cities worldwide, including London, California, and Singapore, which have implemented policies to promote density and affordable housing. However, the effectiveness of these efforts is disputed, and some argue that wage inequality, not housing, is the root cause of the issue.

images.alt_text: Other cities listed as the world’s top 10 wealthiest include Hong Kong, Beijing and Shanghai – which were 7th, 8th and 9th place respectively.
About three-quarters of all units at The Sky Eden@Bedok were sold at an average price of $2,100 per square foot during its launch on Sept 7., 2022.
Three of the top five profit-making resale deals by percentage were transactions in the suburbs, with sellers making gains of 82 to 86 per cent.

site_title: LinkedIn co-founder defends funding Trump rape accuser’s lawsuit
summary: Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn, defended his funding of E. Jean Carroll's lawsuit against former President Donald Trump, which is set to go to trial next week. Hoffman stated that his grant to a non-profit backing Carroll's lawsuit aligns with his values of protecting "American values" and "reinforcing the importance of the rule of law, equality, and helping the disadvantaged." Carroll's lawyer, Roberta Kaplan, has disputed Trump's claim that the lawsuit was politically motivated, citing Trump's own use of funds donated by supporters to pay for legal fees.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - APRIL 04: (EDITOR'S NOTE: Alternate crop) Former U.S. President Donald Trump arrives for his arraignment at Manhattan Criminal Court on April 04, 2023 in New York City. With the indictment, Trump becomes the first former U.S. president in history to be charged with a criminal offense.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: COE supply for cars to fall in May-July period
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that the supply of certificates of entitlement (COEs) for cars will decrease in the May-July period, with a monthly average of 932 COEs, 7.72% lower than the February-April average. The reduction affects cars with engines up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as electric vehicles with up to 110 kilowatts of power.

site_title: Toyota must do more, faster to meet China market expectations: CEO
summary: Toyota CEO Koji Sato stated that the company needs to increase its speed and efforts to meet customer expectations in China's growing market. The Japanese automaker faces pressure from local brands such as BYD, which have aggressively tapped into the country's demand for battery-powered and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles. Sato's comments come as Toyota struggles to compete in China's rapidly expanding auto market.

images.alt_text: A GWM executive unveils the B07 Fierce Dragon Max from the company’s export-focused Haval brand.
Zeekr, a premium electric vehicle (EV) brand owned by Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, highlighted how its newly released X model SUV has seats that can massage passengers.

Volkswagen said at the Auto Shanghai show it would introduce 10 more electric vehicle (EV) models by 2026 and cut the time to develop new models by almost 40 per cent to keep pace with faster-moving Chinese rivals.

site_title: G7 urges implementation, expansion of Ukrainian grain deal; Moscow retaliates by threatening to cancel accord
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) agriculture ministers urged the implementation and expansion of the Ukrainian grain deal, which allows Ukraine to export over 27 million tonnes of grain from its Black Sea ports. Russia has threatened to cancel the deal if its demands for the lifting of restrictions on its grain and fertilizer exports are not met by May 18. The G7 condemned Russia's attempts to use food as a means of destabilization and reiterate their commitment to supporting Ukraine. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov will discuss the deal with UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres this week, amid reports that the G7 is considering a near-total ban on exports to Russia.

site_title: Comba Telecom leads buybacks; recent Cortina director acquisitions
summary: Institutional investors were net buyers of Singapore stocks, with a net inflow of S$104 million over five trading sessions from April 14 to 20. The Straits Times Index gained 0.6%, while the Hang Seng Index added 1.1%. Singtel, DBS, Keppel Corporation, and Singapore Exchange led the net institutional inflow, while UOB, Wilmar International, and Sats led the net institutional outflow. 16 companies conducted share buybacks, with Comba Telecom Systems Holdings buying back 3,726,000 shares at an average price of HK$1.62 per share. Notable director and substantial shareholder transactions included Cortina Holdings' Victor Yu Chuen Tek acquiring 500,000 shares, Progen Holdings' Lee Ee acquiring 3.27 million shares, and A-Sonic Aerospace's CEO Janet LC Tan acquiring 126,000 shares.

images.alt_text: The SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: UOB ‘very flush’ with liquidity; CRO notes importance of prudent business model for long-term survival
summary: UOB's chief risk officer Chan Kok Seong notes that the bank's liquidity position is "very flush" due to its prudent business model and high capital ratios. This puts the bank in a comfortable position amid recent global banking industry turmoil. Chan declined to disclose the exact amount of its liquidity buffer, but assured shareholders that it has "a lot of excess liquidity" and is well above regulatory minimums. CEO Wee Ee Cheong also mentioned that UOB has significant liquidity residing with central banks.

images.alt_text: 大华银行大厦（UOB Plaza）外观。
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: China’s Fosun faces lawsuit over stake sale in Nanjing Nangang to Jiangsu Shagang
summary: China's Fosun is facing a lawsuit from Jiangsu Shagang Group over a stake sale deal. Jiangsu Shagang alleges Fosun's unit failed to pledge its 11% stake in Nanjing Nangang Iron & Steel United, which was sold to Jiangsu Shagang for 13.58 billion yuan. Fosun maintains the litigation won't affect operations and will take necessary action to defend the claims.

site_title: Alphabet CEO’s pay soars to US$226 million on huge stock award
summary: Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai's pay package increased to $226 million in 2022, largely due to a $218 million stock grant. This makes him one of the world's highest-paid corporate leaders. The 50-year-old CEO has been navigating a competitive industry, with AI products like ChatGPT from OpenAI threatening Google's search dominance. Despite a 39% share slide in 2022, Alphabet's shares have risen 19% in 2023. Pichai's salary has remained steady at $2 million over the past three years.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is hoping the chip will perform better than what it currently buys from other vendors, saving it time and money on its costly AI efforts, the report said.
Google describes Bard as an experiment allowing collaboration with generative AI, technology that relies on past data to create rather than identify content.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Google LLC is seen at the Google Store Chelsea in New York City, U.S., January 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo

site_title: China stocks see biggest daily slump since November’s reopening rally
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 Index and Shanghai Composite Index fell 2% on Friday, marking the largest daily decline since November's rally, amid concerns over the uneven economic recovery. Shares in artificial intelligence, semiconductors, and media firms led the decline, with valuation in China's tech sector deemed "extreme" by UBS. Despite a raised full-year growth forecast, Nomura's chief economist remains cautious on the second half of 2023 and 2024.

site_title: Overconfidence dictates who gets ‘top jobs’ and research shows men benefit more than women
summary: Research shows that men are 19% more likely to overestimate their abilities, affecting career outcomes for both men and women. By age 42, 24% of men and 16% of women hold top jobs, with overconfidence playing a significant role. Factors contributing to the gender gap include university attendance, industry, and having children, with overconfidence explaining up to 11% of the gap. Employers can help by providing regular performance-based feedback and encouraging women to apply for promotions. The solution lies in changing the system, not placing the onus on women to build confidence.

images.alt_text: Gender diversity. Covid-19 has impacted employees across all levels; and the best leaders are those who have adapted leadership and communication styles to show empathy and forge closer bonds with their workforce.

site_title: HCA Healthcare raises 2023 forecasts on improved staffing
summary: HCA Healthcare raised its 2023 forecast due to improved staffing levels, which led to a 2.8% increase in inpatient surgery cases and a 3.5% rise in outpatient surgery cases in the first quarter. The hospital operator's shares rose over 5% in premarket trade. The improved staffing, after a period of pandemic-related staff resignations, has enabled HCA to conduct more surgeries and is expected to continue to benefit the company's operations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: HCA Healthcare Inc logo is seen displayed in this illustration taken April 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Asia-Pacific investors the biggest source of funds for real estate investment in 2022
summary: Asia-Pacific investors raised US$54.8 billion in new capital for real estate in 2022, accounting for 35% of global capital. Non-listed real estate funds attracted 49% of regional capital, with 55% of capital raised going towards riskier investments. The region now surpasses North America and Europe as the largest source of funds for real estate investment. A survey found that single-country strategies and industrial/logistics sectors were the most popular, with investors showing a preference for control and strategy involvement in investments.

images.alt_text: Total investment sales fell 61 per cent to S$4.2 billion in the first quarter of 2023, figures compiled by Knight Frank show.

site_title: More rate hikes on the way after UK’s strong economic data
summary: The UK's strong economic data has led the Bank of England to expect more interest rate hikes, with investors predicting three additional quarter-point increases by September, pushing borrowing costs to a 15-year high of 5%. Inflation remained in double digits in March, and wage growth showed little sign of cooling, with annualised private wage growth above 5%. Consumer confidence and purchasing managers' index also jumped to one-year highs, indicating an accelerating economy.

images.alt_text: Workers during the morning rush hour in the financial district of Canary Wharf in London. Last year, the UK economy grew by 4.1 per cent, but things look bleaker in 2023.

site_title: India’s Reliance Industries profit rises 19% on energy, retail boost
summary: Reliance Industries reported a 19% jump in fourth-quarter profit, driven by strength in its energy and retail businesses. The company's oil-to-chemicals (O2C) segment, accounting for 60% of revenue and earnings, posted its highest-ever operating profit despite global uncertainties. Chairman and managing director Mukesh Ambani attributed the success to the segment's resilience. The diversification of businesses in retail, telecom, and green energy continues to contribute to the company's growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Labourers rest in front of an advertisement of Reliance Industries Limited at a construction site in Mumbai, India, March 2, 2016. REUTERS/Shailesh Andrade/File Photo

site_title: Biden aims to unveil China investment curbs with G7 backing
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to sign an executive order limiting American investment in key parts of China's economy, focusing on high-tech industries such as semiconductors, artificial intelligence, and quantum computing. The move aims to choke off critical funding and know-how that could advance China's military capabilities. The administration has been debating the measure for almost two years and plans to unveil it around the time of a G7 summit in Japan on May 19. China has accused the US of politicizing tech issues, and investors largely shrugged off concerns of more restrictions, saying they would do little to impact actual business.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden plans to sign an executive order that will establish a new Office of Environmental Justice within the White House aimed at coordinating efforts across the government.

The G7 ministers also said they recognised the importance of “engaging candidly” with China and the need to work together on common interests, while calling for a “peaceful resolution” of Taiwan-related issues.

site_title: No place for populism and political opportunism in Singapore: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stated that there is no place for populism and political opportunism in Singapore, emphasizing the importance of honesty and integrity in policymaking. He agreed with Leader of the Opposition Pritam Singh, who also rejected populism and acknowledged the need for the Opposition to work towards the betterment of Singapore and its citizens. The two leaders agreed to hold each other accountable for upholding democratic standards, with Wong expressing concerns about the impact of populism on Singapore's maturing democracy.

site_title: Russia’s Yandex buys Uber’s stake in taxi joint venture for US$703 million
summary: Russian tech giant Yandex acquired Uber's stake in their joint taxi venture for $702.5 million, becoming the sole owner of Yandex.Taxi. This deal marks the end of Uber's involvement in Russia, following a 2021 divestment of its stake in a foodtech and delivery joint venture. The acquisition received regulatory approval, with no discount mentioned. This move comes amid capital outflows and sanctions against Moscow over the conflict in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Russian technology giant Yandex is on display at the company's headquarters in Moscow, Russia December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Evgenia Novozhenina/File Photo

site_title: Twitter drops ‘government-funded’ label on media accounts, including in China
summary: Twitter has dropped the "Government-funded" and "China state-affiliated" labels from the accounts of global media organizations, including NPR, BBC, and CBC. The labels were removed in response to criticism from the organizations, which argued that the labels did not accurately capture their governance structure. Twitter's billionaire owner Elon Musk said the platform was trying to be "accurate" and looking into amending the label to simply "publicly funded".

site_title: UK Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab resigns after bullying probe
summary: UK Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab resigned on Friday after an independent investigation into complaints of bullying found two instances of bullying against him. Raab, who was also justice minister, defended his conduct, saying setting a low threshold for bullying sets a "dangerous precedent" for government conduct. The resignation is the third senior minister to leave the government in six months, damaging Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's efforts to revive the Conservative Party.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's latest Cabinet reshuffle may amount to little more than moving the deckchairs on the Titanic.

site_title: ECB says 16 eurozone banks fall short of climate demands, may face penalties
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has found that 16 eurozone banks, or 15% of those assessed, fail to disclose sufficient information about their exposure to climate risk. The banks must improve their reporting standards, which include identifying material climate risk exposure, impact on business, and plans to address it. Failure to comply may result in fines or higher capital requirements. The ECB urges banks to make "further improvements" by June, when the new reporting standards come into effect, to avoid consequences.

images.alt_text: Lower energy costs and healing supply chains did however mean input prices fell for the first time since July 2020 – just when the coronavirus pandemic was cementing its grip on the world.

site_title: China central bank signals it will dial back pandemic stimulus
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has signaled a potential shift away from pandemic-era stimulus measures, which have fueled the economy's recovery. The PBOC may gradually scale back structural tools, such as targeted lending programs, as the economy grows and credit demand increases. This move is expected to be gradual, with the outstanding amount of the programs unlikely to decline significantly this year. The PBOC's focus may shift back to traditional tools, like one-year policy loans and reserve requirement ratios, as the economy recovers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang//File Photo

site_title: China passes guidance for supporting private sector: state media
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has passed guidance for promoting the private sector, aiming to optimise the development environment and remove institutional barriers. The party will also strengthen and improve management of the state sector. The move is seen as a step towards creating a more competitive and market-oriented economy.

site_title: Tesla abandons Mercedes battle to take on the likes of Ford
summary: Tesla has abandoned its effort to compete with luxury car manufacturers like Mercedes-Benz by cutting prices, instead focusing on volume and expansion. CEO Elon Musk has reduced prices on the Model Y by 29% in the US, prompting Ford to discount its Mustang Mach-E SUV by $4,500. Luxury car makers like Mercedes-Benz remain unwilling to compromise brand value for volume, with CEO Ola Källenius stating the company's strategy is paying dividends. This pricing pressure may impact Ford, which forecasts a $3 billion loss for its electric vehicle business this year.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk's wealth dropped by US$12.6 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, his biggest decline this year.

site_title: Government may regulate insurance IP riders if cost of cancer care continues to escalate
summary: Singapore's government may regulate private healthcare insurance IP riders if the cost of cancer care continues to escalate. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung said the ministry is monitoring cancer drug claims and coverage closely, and will take further steps to regulate IPs and riders if costs continue to rise. The changes aim to curb rising costs of cancer treatments, with riders now capped to only cover treatments on the Cancer Drug List.

images.alt_text: National Cancer Centre Singapore, taken on 9 Jun 2022.

site_title: China’s exports to North Korea rise sharply in March
summary: China's exports to North Korea surged 141.7% year-over-year in March, marking the second consecutive month of significant growth, with major items including rice, artificial wigs, and tobacco. The increase in trade follows China's foreign ministry's statement that relations between the two countries had entered a "new historic period" under strategic leadership. This development comes amid concerns about China's economic slowdown and its impact on policymakers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to remain "relevant and useful" to the world to thrive. Between 2018 and 2021, 0.5% of private residential properties involved 99-to-1 or similar deals. A new training center simulating airport operations was launched at the Institute of Technical Education, while up to 3,500 high-net-worth individuals are expected to become Singapore citizens in 2023.

site_title: Tokyo Stock Exchange plans to extend trading hours from Nov 2024
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange plans to extend its trading hours from November 2024 to 5 hours, from 6:30 AM to 12:30 PM GMT, with a one-hour midday break. This move aims to attract investors and boost trading volumes, comparable to global peers like the New York Stock Exchange (6.5 hours) and the London Stock Exchange (8.5 hours). The five-hour trading day has remained unchanged since 1954.

site_title: Indian banks wary of parking funds with RBI following liquidity swings, say traders
summary: Indian banks are wary of parking funds with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) due to liquidity swings, with subscription to the RBI's 14-day variable rate reverse repo (VRRR) being less than half. Despite a sharp cut in quantum of funds, banks parked only 205 billion rupees, with liquidity concentrated among a few large banks. This has led to elevated rates, with the weighted average call rate and Treps rate above 6.55%. The trend is expected to persist due to skewed liquidity distribution and concentrated liquidity surplus.

images.alt_text: Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), speaks during a news conference in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, Dec. 5, 2019. India’s central bank unexpectedly kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged as headline inflation breached its medium-term target for the first time in more than a year. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: India court rejects Xiaomi’s challenge to 55.51 billion rupees asset freeze: sources
summary: India's court has rejected Xiaomi's challenge to a 55.51 billion rupees (S$902.4 million) asset freeze, which was imposed by the federal financial crime agency for allegedly making illegal remittances to foreign entities by passing off royalty payments as legitimate. The company's assets were frozen last year, and Xiaomi's operations in India are compliant with local laws and regulations, according to the company. This ruling is the latest setback for Chinese companies in India, which have struggled to do business in the country since 2020 due to political tensions and security concerns.

site_title: Major companies quit CBI as crisis at UK lobby group deepens
summary: Major British companies, including NatWest, John Lewis, and Virgin Media O2, have quit the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) amid a crisis over rape allegations and a police investigation. The CBI, which represents 190,000 businesses, faces a battle for survival as more companies cut ties. The organization has announced an urgent review of its culture and will respond to the investigation by law firm Fox Williams. Several other companies, including Aviva and asset managers, have also withdrawn their membership, citing a lack of confidence in the CBI's ability to represent business interests.

site_title: Credit Suisse bondholders sue Swiss regulator over write-down
summary: Credit Suisse bondholders are suing the Swiss regulator, Finma, over the decision to wipe out US$18 billion of their investments in the bank's AT1 debt during the rescue deal. The lawsuit, filed in the Federal Administrative Court, claims the move was unlawful and deprived bondholders of their property rights. The bondholders, representing over 4.5 billion Swiss francs, are seeking redress and aim to strengthen Switzerland's position as a key financial jurisdiction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of an entrance of a Credit Suisse U.K. Limited in London, Britain March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: India looks to buy more LNG as heat wave boosts power demand
summary: India is seeking to purchase more liquefied natural gas (LNG) from abroad amid a record-breaking heat wave and surge in power demand. The country's coal-dominated power mix is being supplemented with gas-fired power generation to meet peak demand. Companies such as Gail India and Petronet LNG have released tenders to buy LNG shipments from early May to June. The move is unusual, given gas's small share in India's power mix, but aims to ensure electricity supply to customers.

site_title: UBS expects yen to rally 10 per cent as BOJ change seen soon
summary: UBS Global Wealth Management expects the Japanese yen to rally 10% against the dollar within the next couple of months, potentially reaching 120 by year-end, as the Bank of Japan is expected to consider adjusting its ultra-loose monetary policy stance. The central bank is seen as unlikely to make changes next week, with 87% of economists surveyed by Bloomberg expecting no change. UBS head of global asset allocation Adrian Zuercher believes the yen's strength will be driven by the BOJ's desire to address elevated inflation and improve the bond market's liquidity.

images.alt_text: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Indonesia's ruling party backs provincial governor Ganjar as its presidential candidate
summary: Indonesia's ruling party, the Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP), has endorsed Central Java Governor Ganjar Pranowo as its presidential candidate for the 2024 election. This decision comes after months of uncertainty and legal manoeuvres by other parties to delay the election. Ganjar, a popular leader known for his reform, efficiency, and transparency, faces competition from former Jakarta Governor Anies Baswedan and ex-special forces commander Prabowo Subianto. The announcement was made by former President Megawati Sukarnoputri, and marks a shift towards a provincial leader from outside the traditional elite.

images.alt_text: Indonesia president's aide named head of opposition party, but turmoil ensues

site_title: Biden to sign executive order on ‘environmental justice’
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to sign an executive order establishing a new Office of Environmental Justice within the White House, coordinating efforts across the government to address environmental injustices in communities. The order aims to prioritize environmental policies that harm communities and require federal agencies to notify communities of toxic substance releases. This initiative comes after recent disasters, such as the East Palestine, Ohio, chemical spill, highlighting environmental damage in communities. The move is part of Biden's efforts to address environmental and racial disparities through executive authority.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden convenes the fourth virtual leader-level meeting of the Major Economies Forum (MEF) on Energy and Climate at the White House in Washington, U.S., April 20, 2023. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque

site_title: Mining M&A spree to keep Australia dealmaking humming after US$37 billion in Q1
summary: Australia's deal volume in the first quarter increased 3.5% compared to the same period last year, driven by US$37 billion in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals. Cash-rich miners are expanding through acquisitions to tap into rising resource demand, while others are divesting fossil fuel portfolios. The trend is expected to continue, with Newmont's US$18 billion bid for Newcrest Mining driving a 192% surge in inbound M&A in Australia this year.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Canadian mining company Teck Resources Limited is displayed as people visit the Prospectors and Developers Association of Canada (PDAC) annual conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada March 7, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren
The Glencore Plc headquarters in Baar, Switzerland. Photographer: Alessandro Della Bella/Bloomberg

site_title: Biggest Bitcoin trading pair uses obscure stablecoin TrueUSD
summary: TrueUSD, a lesser-known stablecoin, has become the largest Bitcoin trading pair on Binance, with its share of Bitcoin trading volumes rising to 50% following the exchange's decision to scrap zero-fee trading promotions for most Bitcoin pairs. The move lifted TUSD's market value to $2 billion, making it the fifth-largest stablecoin. The stablecoin's popularity is seen as a potential long-term trend, despite concerns about the risks posed by stablecoins and scrutiny from regulators.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Souvenir tokens representing cryptocurrency Bitcoin plunge into water in this illustration taken May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic//File Photo

site_title: Luxury fortunes jump US$93 billion on demand boom for Hermes, Dior
summary: Wealth of the world's richest individuals jumped $93 billion in 2023, driven by a global demand boom for luxury goods and beauty products. French billionaires Francoise Bettencourt Meyers (L'Oreal), Bernard Arnault (LVMH), the Hermes Family, the Wertheimer brothers (Chanel), and Francois Pinault (Kering) saw significant gains. The luxury industry's growth is attributed to expansion into international markets, including China, and acquisitions over the decades. This surge in wealth solidifies France's dominance in the luxury and beauty industry, with multigenerational companies built through expansion and acquisitions.

images.alt_text: The Gucci inspection, at a site connected with the manufacture of travel items, handbags and other leather goods, was aimed at possible violations of the European Union’s Article 101.
The transaction, which is expected to close in the third quarter, caps months of negotiations for the asset.
It’s set to be LVMH’s first venture into global debt markets since April 2020, when the company sold debt in the wake of the pandemic.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund posts US$84 billion quarterly profit
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, valued at $1.4 trillion, posted a 5.9% return on investment for the first quarter, despite market turmoil in March, driven by a nearly 8% gain in equity markets. The fund's profit of $84 billion contrasted with a loss of $84 billion in the same period last year. The return worked out to more than $15,000 per person, given the country's population of 5.5 million. The fund's equity portfolio rose due to the technology and consumer discretionary sectors, while its bond portfolio benefited from falling interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the building of Norway’s central bank (Norges Bank) in Oslo, Norway, June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks buck downtrend in key Asian markets; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,321.82 on Friday, bucking the downtrend in other Asian markets. The gains were attributed to Singapore Airlines' 0.5% increase and Genting Singapore's 1.8% rise, driven by the country's post-pandemic record-high tourist arrivals in March. The rally came as Asian markets were hit by Wall Street's sell-off and recession fears, with the US Federal Reserve potentially raising interest rates further.

images.alt_text: A worker wipes a Singapore Airlines logo at the International Tourism Trade Fair (ITB, Internationale Tourismusboerse) in Berlin on March 6, 2023. - The world's largest travel trade show ITB will take place from  March 7 to March 9, 2023. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / AFP)
Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Investors seek to break through Japan Inc’s ‘value trap’
summary: Japan's stock market has seen a significant shift in corporate governance, prompting foreign investors to take notice. About half of the 1,800 companies on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's prime section traded below their book value in January, indicating undervaluation. This change has led to increased activism, with companies like Fujitec ousting its chairman and the Tokyo Stock Exchange threatening delisting for underperforming stocks. Legendary investor Warren Buffett has also increased his stake in Japan's largest trading houses, and foreign investors have poured in, purchasing 1.59 trillion yen in Japanese shares last week.

images.alt_text: A man passes an electronic quotation board displaying the closing numbers of the Nikkei Stock Average at the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on October 18, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: BT Market Focus: A seesaw week but was it good? (Ep 40)
summary: Markets experienced a seesaw week, with fluctuations in various asset classes. The week's volatility was attributed to global economic and geopolitical factors, including ongoing trade tensions and the impact of US dollar movements. Despite the uncertainty, some investors took advantage of the market shifts, while others remained cautious. The episode explores the market drivers and movements in Singapore, the region, and beyond, offering insights into the repercussions and potential benefits of the week's seesaw action.

images.alt_text: Find out why markets had a good week.
Did the markets' mixed week have anything to do with banking fear?

site_title: BuzzFeed says shutting down newsroom: CEO memo
summary: BuzzFeed announced the shutdown of its news division, citing challenges such as the coronavirus pandemic, declining stock market, and recession in the tech sector. The company plans to reduce its workforce by 15% and close BuzzFeed News, but will retain a single news brand in HuffPost. Some BuzzFeed News staff members will be offered jobs at HuffPost and BuzzFeed.com. The decision follows a significant decline in BuzzFeed shares, plummeting over 20% on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 20: A view of BuzzFeed offices displaying the BuzzFeed News and HuffPost logos in the Hollywood neighborhood on April 20, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. BuzzFeed News, which won a Pulitzer Prize in 2021 for reporting on the mass detention of Muslims in China, is shutting down as its parent company, Buzzfeed Inc., cuts costs.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Blackstone sees US real estate boon from tight credit
summary: Blackstone's Jonathan Gray sees a long-term boon in US commercial real estate due to tighter credit, which will limit new supply. Despite vacancy rates of 20% causing "unprecedented weakness" in the sector, particularly office buildings, Gray believes this will be beneficial in the long run. Fundamentals of supply and demand drive value, and with less new supply, Gray has confidence that property values will increase.

images.alt_text: “Despite higher mortgage rates and inflationary pressures, demand improved during the quarter due to normal seasonal factors,” DR Horton chairman Donald Horton said.

site_title: Immigration clearance system disruption lasted 4½ hours, affected 85,000 land and air travellers
summary: An immigration clearance system upgrade trial on March 31 caused a 4½-hour disruption affecting 85,000 air and land travelers, including 21 who missed their flights. The system overload was worse than anticipated, and vendors worked with global support teams to diagnose and reboot servers. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) reviewed its approach to the upgrade, citing a need for a more cautious approach to avoid disruptions. The trial was intended to upgrade the Multi-Modal Biometrics System, which facilitates automated immigration clearance using travelers' biometrics.

images.alt_text: Long queues were seen at the Causeway and at Changi Airport as ICA warns of delays due to "intermittent slowness".

site_title: Bank of America joins others in raising China's 2023 GDP growth forecast after strong Q1
summary: Bank of America raised its forecast for China's 2023 GDP growth to 6.3% from 5.5%, citing stronger-than-expected first-quarter growth. The upgrade follows similar moves by JPMorgan, Citigroup, and UBS, which also increased their forecasts. China's economy is expected to grow driven by investment, rather than private consumption, as policymakers aim to bolster growth following the end of strict Covid-19 curbs. The upgrades come as recession concerns in the US intensify.

images.alt_text: China’s recovery has so far remained uneven, with consumption, services and infrastructure spending perking up but slowing prices and surging bank savings raising doubts about demand.

site_title: BOJ sees ‘sound and resilient’ financial system despite some jitters
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has reported that Japan's financial system remains "sound and resilient" despite heightened jitters in the West due to US bank failures. However, the central bank warns of vigilance against tail risks, citing high credit risk in some loan portfolios. The report notes that future developments are highly uncertain, with financial markets remaining nervous.

images.alt_text: The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food, but includes energy costs, matched a median market forecast.

site_title: Hoi Hup, Sunway launch The Continuum at prices starting from about S$2,580 psf
summary: Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments launched previews for The Continuum in District 15, Singapore, with indicative prices ranging from S$2,580 psf to S$2,800 psf. The freehold development will house 816 units in six blocks, with more than 60% being two- and three-bedroomers. The site, acquired in 2021, was sold for S$815 million. The Continuum is near Paya Lebar and Dakota MRT stations and is part of a growing market in District 15, following recent launches like Tembusu Grand and Liv @ MB.

site_title: Former US Secret Service agent cites crypto crime to back anonymity for FTX creditors
summary: A former US Secret Service agent, Jeremy A Sheridan, supports anonymity for FTX creditors due to risks from cryptocurrency crime. Sheridan cites the potential for identity theft, asset theft, and online victimization. In the FTX bankruptcy, the names of the 50 largest unsecured creditors were initially kept secret, a decision made by a judge under the US Bankruptcy Code. This unusual move aims to protect creditors from potential harm. Sheridan's comments highlight the complexities of handling sensitive information in cryptocurrency cases.

images.alt_text: Amber Group is working on a regulated, open-ended mutual fund that would accept subscriptions in major tokens including Bitcoin.

site_title: A senior’s counsel to self
summary: A Singaporean author, Jeffery Tan, writes about embracing senior age, despite his own initial reluctance. At 60, Tan has noticed some physical signs of aging, but remains active and productive. He cites the example of a friend who, like him, has become a grandparent, but continues to remain active. Tan argues that seniority does not automatically mean a slowing down of lifestyle, and encourages readers to view aging positively.

images.alt_text: Rajalectiumee, 83, is one of 12 individuals who are in the Aging Singapore exhibition.
Minister Indranee Rajah said Singapore’s total fertility rate has been declining for many years, like other advanced societies.

site_title: Norway sovereign fund backs Teck Resources in battle with Glencore
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has backed Canadian miner Teck Resources' plan to spin off its metallurgical coal business, implicitly rejecting Glencore's attempted takeover. The Norwegian fund, which owns 1.48% of Teck's shares, voted in favor of the plan, while Glencore's US$22.5 billion offer remains on the table. The move is seen as a key victory for Teck, which aims to focus on copper and zinc production.

site_title: Rakuten Bank jumps 33% after Japan’s largest IPO since 2018
summary: Rakuten Bank, the banking unit of billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani's Rakuten Group, raised approximately $829.8 million through its initial public offering (IPO) in Tokyo. The shares surged 38% on their debut, closing at 1,930 yen apiece, marking Japan's largest IPO since 2018. The IPO revives the Tokyo IPO market, which had seen no first-time share sale exceed 50 billion yen this year.

images.alt_text: The investor questions, not previously reported, highlight how concerns about the e-commerce giant’s losses and mounting debt cast a shadow on Japan’s biggest IPO in more than four years.

site_title: Britain’s economy grows at fastest pace in a year: PMI
summary: Britain's economy showed the fastest growth in a year, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 53.9 in April, driven by resilient consumer spending in the services sector. However, manufacturing activity declined, and price pressures remained high, leading economists to predict another interest rate hike by the Bank of England to 4.5% next month. This growth momentum is seen as a positive sign for the second quarter, but the economy still faces challenges from elevated inflation.

images.alt_text: Consumers’ expectations for Britain’s economy in the next 12 months hit a 15-month high and they saw the prospects for their personal finances as the brightest since February 2022.

site_title: ITE launches training centre simulating airport operations as aviation recovers
summary: The Institute of Technical Education (ITE) has launched a training centre simulating airport operations, aimed at catering to a new programme in customer service. Minister for Transport S Iswaran launched the facility, noting that Singapore's aviation industry has recovered to 80% of pre-Covid levels. The centre's launch coincides with the growth of the sector, emphasizing the need to recruit, train, and maintain talent. The training centre will provide realistic airport operations simulations, enhancing the skills of students and professionals in the industry.

site_title: Tesla hikes US prices days after sixth price cut this year
summary: Tesla has increased US prices for its Model S and X electric vehicles, with the Model S priced at $87,490 and the Model X at $97,490, a 2.9% and 2.6% rise respectively. This follows the sixth price cut of the year, amid a weak economy and rising competition. Tesla's CEO Elon Musk prioritized sales growth over profit, citing the need to spur demand. The company posted its lowest quarterly gross margin in two years, missing market estimates.

site_title: Mortgage rates in the US increase for first time in six weeks
summary: US mortgage rates increased for the first time in six weeks, rising to 6.39% for a 30-year, fixed loan, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the first increase since March 9. The surge in borrowing costs is exacerbating the housing market's affordability issues, with inventory constrained due to many homeowners opting for lower-rate mortgages. Sales of previously owned homes dropped in March, and unless rates drop below 6%, demand is expected to modestly recover, according to Freddie Mac's chief economist.

images.alt_text: “Consumers appear to be very sensitive to changes in mortgage rates,” says the NAR's Lawrence Yun.

site_title: Beyond staying open, Singapore must remain ‘relevant and useful’ to thrive: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to remain "relevant and useful" to the world to thrive, beyond just staying open and connected. He stressed the importance of unity to secure the country's place in the world, as a global-Asia node, to reap the benefits of government-led efforts in free trade, investment, and research.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
PM Lee Hsien Loong delivering his speech on the report of the Committee of Privileges in Parliament on 15 February 2022.

saclean31 - Jasmine Tang (in white), 28, NEA employee, educating a participant on the proper ways of recycling through a mini game-booth at the Clean Up! South West 2023 event held at Choa Chu Kang Community Centre on 31 December, 2022.

ST PHOTO: SYAMIL SAPARI

By ensuring a productive economy, creating aged-friendly living environments, assuring retirement adequacy, reforming the healthcare system and continuing to practice good governance, Singapore can stay economically vibrant even as it ages, says Healthcare Minister Ong Ye Kung.

site_title: Up to 3,500 high-net-worth individuals to become Singapore citizens in 2023, most from China: report
summary: Up to 3,500 high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) are expected to become Singapore citizens in 2023, with most from China, according to a report by New World Wealth and Henley & Partners. Singapore is ranked as the fifth-wealthiest city in the world, with 240,100 resident millionaires. Each HNWI has at least US$6 million in investable wealth, contributing to the country's growing wealth. This influx of new citizens is part of a larger trend, with other Asian cities such as Hong Kong, Beijing, and Shanghai also among the world's top 10 wealthiest cities.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
According to data from analytics platform Handshakes, out of 63,801 new corporate entities formed here last year, 29 per cent were foreign-owned.
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) and Marina Bay Financial Centre along the Singapore River at night, 29 October 2022.
At least eight mainland-based funds, including billion-dollar yuan quant funds, equity funds and mutual funds, have set up operations in Hong Kong in the past six months.
Singapore's tourism arrivals rose to 1,021,036 in March, up from the 957,839 visitors recorded in the previous month.

site_title: Swedish realtors grow more pessimistic on apartment prices
summary: Sweden's real estate agents expect apartment prices to fall in the second quarter, with 32% of respondents predicting a decline, up from 28% three months ago. The market is expected to trend sideways, with an increase in supply not matched by a rise in demand. This trend is attributed to the Riksbank's rate increases, which have shaved 15% off home values in the Nordic country. Detached houses are also expected to see a decline in prices, with 32% of respondents predicting a drop.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street losses on rate, recession fears
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday due to recession worries and the US economy's slowing down, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The Philadelphia Fed Manufacturing Index fell more than expected, indicating a weakening labor market and inflation concerns. Investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve's rate decision next month, with a 25-basis-point hike expected. Economists warn of a possible recession, citing jobless claims and corporate layoffs, but also note that wage pressures will remain strong in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Markets swung in early Asian trade, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney and Manila up but Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington and Taipei were negative on Thursday.

site_title: Happy 100th birthday, 16-mm film
summary: The 16-mm film format, introduced by Eastman Kodak in 1923, has celebrated its 100th birthday. Initially a boon to amateurs, it's now the choice of filmmakers like Darren Aronofsky and Kelly Reichardt, who value its unique, grainy look. Unlike 35-mm film, 16-mm allows for more portability and lower costs, making it ideal for independent filmmakers and those capturing real-time, gritty scenes. Many directors, including Aronofsky and Todd Haynes, have shot films on 16-mm, often to evoke the analogue past and blur the line between memory and reality.

images.alt_text: New angles on the film industry
Reliving the Kodak moment

site_title: Government to stay out of contract renegotiations linked to Progressive Wage Model costs: Zaqy
summary: Singapore's government will not intervene in contract renegotiations linked to the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) costs, said Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad. Tripartite partners encourage service buyers and providers to renegotiate contracts where reasonable, and the government offers the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme to offset cost pressures for eligible lower-wage employees. However, Zaqy criticized some service buyers for blacklisting service contractors, urging them to work with providers to remain sustainable without government support.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Minister Masagos' Year-End Interview on Malay/Muslim Matters, Minister Zaqy Mohamad.##########stwage##########Khalid Baba
THE OPW will cover general drivers, such as lorry drivers, and specialised drivers, such as bus drivers.
Workers at quick-service establishments, including food courts, will see minimum wages set at S$1,750 from Mar 1 this year.

site_title: Biden to meet Philippines leader amid rising tension with China
summary: US President Joe Biden will welcome Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. to the White House on May 1, amid rising tensions between the US and China over Taiwan. The meeting aims to strengthen the US-Philippines alliance and discuss efforts to uphold international law in the disputed South China Sea. The two leaders will also discuss economic cooperation, clean energy, and human rights. The US has granted greater military access to the Philippines, and the country has allowed the US to use four more military bases, including sites near the South China Sea and Taiwan.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 22, 2022, US President Joe Biden (R) meets with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York City. - The Philippines has performed a diplomatic U-turn on ties with Beijing, and by pressing a defence rapprochement with Washington, it risks sparking China's fury. (Photo by MANDEL NGAN / AFP) / To go with AFP story Philippines-US-China-diplomacy-maritime, FOCUS by Allison JACKSON

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB raises target on Genting Singapore, expects higher earnings after positive MBS results
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price on Genting Singapore to S$1.26 from S$1.15, citing a strong Q1 FY2023 performance similar to Marina Bay Sands, and expecting higher earnings as China's reopening increases flight capacities. The revised target price is based on a 10 times FY2024 enterprise value-to-Ebitda forecast. The analyst maintains its "add" call on Genting Singapore, anticipating continued profitability improvement throughout the year.

images.alt_text: The main casino floor during a media preview of Resorts World Las Vegas in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S., on Tuesday, June 22, 2021. Malaysia's Genting Group developed the 3,500-room hotel with 117,000 square feet of gambling space, 250,000 square feet of meeting space, a 5,000-seat theater, and seven swimming pools overlooking the north end of the Strip. Photographer: Roger Kisby/Bloomberg

site_title: ‘Mild recession’ for UK still a possibility in 2023, but there are enough reasons to be optimistic
summary: The UK economy grew by 4.1% last year, but experts warn of a 'mild recession' in 2023 due to inflation and economic slowdown. The IMF expects a 0.3% contraction this year. However, some analysts remain optimistic, citing the economy's avoidance of recession in the first quarter and recent stock market gains. The FTSE 100 index has risen by 18% in the past seven months, while the FTSE 250 index has gained 16%. The pound has also recovered to a 10-month high.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers walk to work during the morning rush hour in the financial district of Canary Wharf in London, Britain, January 26, 2017.  REUTERS/Eddie Keogh

site_title: Pope loses verified status on Twitter, US basketball star LeBron James remains
summary: Twitter has removed legacy blue checkmarks from user profiles, affecting the Pope, Donald Trump, Justin Bieber, and others. However, some high-profile users, including US basketball star LeBron James and author Stephen King, still have their verified statuses. The change is part of Twitter's shift towards a paid verification system, with Musk stating he's "paying for a few personally" and referring to James, Shatner, and King. The move aims to launch new revenue streams beyond advertising.

images.alt_text: Musk responded to the announcement by accusing Microsoft of using Twitter data “illegally” and threatening a lawsuit.

Since purchasing Twitter last year, Elon Musk has sharply reined in content moderation on the platform, allowing the return of many users who had been banned for posting tweets that incite hate or spread misinformation.
Elon Musk’s founding of a rival to OpenAI came several weeks before he joined experts in signing an open letter urging an overall hiatus in the development of AI technology.

site_title: Sustainability is not good enough anymore
summary: Scientists have delivered a "final warning" for drastic and swift action to address the climate emergency, citing a growing biodiversity crisis and 42% of species in South-east Asia at risk of extinction by 2100. Despite progress in climate consciousness, the climate continues to deteriorate, and a systemic shift is needed to address the root causes of the crisis. Companies must adopt a regenerative approach, focusing on "systems thinking" to protect natural resources and prioritize positive value impacts. This involves articulating a vision for systemic change, mapping systems, and onboarding regenerative practices to deliver value through regenerative outcomes.

images.alt_text: Trees, light, path, forest

site_title: 0.5% of private residential property sales involve 99-to-1 or similar deals: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Senior Minister of State for Finance Chee Hong Tat revealed that 0.5% of private residential property sales in Singapore, or one in 200 transactions, involved 99-to-1 arrangements between 2018 and 2021. These arrangements allow a buyer to purchase a property and then sell a 1% interest to another individual, reducing buyer's stamp duty (ABSD). Chee stated that the impact of such deals on the market is "not significant" and that the government takes a serious view against individuals who facilitate tax avoidance.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

Iras is looking into “various forms of property holding arrangements”, including “scenarios where buyers purchase properties under a contrived or artificial arrangement in order to reduce or avoid the additional buyer’s stamp duty (ABSD) or any other form of stamp duties they have to pay”.

site_title: Wake up to the dangers of digital bank runs
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's collapse, dubbed the world's first "Twitter-fueled bank run," highlights the dangers of social media's influence on lenders. A study of 5.4 million tweets found that social media exposure led to bank run risk, with intense Twitter conversation triggering negative returns in bank share prices. The study's findings suggest that regulators and investors should prepare for a social media-infused world by ensuring 24/7 mobile banking, improving stress signal tracking, and changing liquidity coverage rules. Ultimately, governments may need to backstop the system to quell cyber panics, raising questions about the role of banks and government intervention.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Federal authorities took over Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) last week less than 48 hours after it first announced bad news.
SVB seems to have failed investing in US Treasuries – is this the first time a bank failed because it had too many Treasuries?
SVB’s collapse is inseparable from the long era of low interest rates.
The closed gates of Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. Perhaps we will look back on these few weeks as the time when the era of free market truisms ended.

site_title: UOI profit up 2.4% for Q1 with non-underwriting business back in black
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 2.4% increase in net profit to S$4.7 million for Q1 2023, driven by a rise in non-underwriting income to S$2.2 million, which turned profitable after a loss in the previous year. Despite a 38% decline in net underwriting profit, UOI's non-underwriting income offset the losses, with higher interest and dividends received and lower losses from investments.

images.alt_text: Wee Ee Cheong will take over his father as chairman of UOI on 14 April 2023.
Singapore Budget 2021 generic pictures
Net underwriting profit, however, increased by 1.6 per cent to S$12.4 million, as management expenses lowered.

site_title: Bank of Japan unlikely to move in April, most economists say: poll
summary: The Bank of Japan is unlikely to move in April, with nearly 90% of economists polled saying the yield curve control will remain unchanged at its upcoming meeting. The decision comes as the BOJ awaits more evidence of sustained wage growth and amid global economic slowdown and banking turmoil. Only three economists expect the BOJ to start scaling back its monetary stimulus next week, while 11 expect it in June. The BOJ's most likely first step to roll back its easy policy is a tweak to its forward guidance, followed by an end to the yield curve control.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc
The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food, but includes energy costs, matched a median market forecast.
The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose to a seasonally adjusted 49.5 in April, from a final 49.2 in the previous month.

site_title: Generative AI startup Betterdata raises US$1.7 million in oversubscribed seed round
summary: Singapore-based generative AI startup Betterdata has raised US$1.7 million in an oversubscribed seed round led by Investible and other investors. The funding will support the launch of its programmable synthetic data technology stack, which converts limited real data into limitless synthetic data for faster and more secure data sharing. The startup aims to address the lack of high-quality data meeting privacy requirements in the AI industry, with plans to expand across the Asia-Pacific region over the next one to two years.

images.alt_text: Betterdata founders (from left): Chief executive Uzair Javaid and chief technologist Kevin Yee are aiming to make data sharing faster and more secure, amid increasing data protection regulations worldwide and user awareness on privacy.

site_title: Deloitte Singapore announces new CEO
summary: Deloitte Singapore has appointed Shariq Barmaky as its new CEO, effective June 1, succeeding Cheung Pui Yuen. Barmaky, with over 30 years of experience in public accounting, will join the leadership team under Eugene Ho, the incoming Deloitte South-east Asia CEO. Barmaky previously served as audit and assurance leader and will transition into the role of reputation and risk leader after Cheung's departure.

site_title: Why I am not investing in a buyout for a long time to come
summary: Hunter Lewis, a prominent private equity expert, argues that the industry's popularity is due to artificially low interest rates, not actual outperformance. He claims that buyouts, net of fees and leverage, have not outperformed public markets and that current investment models are "fantasy thinking." Lewis warns that the industry's inflated returns, denial of volatility, high prices, and excessive leverage make it unsustainable, and he expects to avoid investing in buyouts for years.

images.alt_text: Buyout firms with direct lending businesses, such as Blue Owl Capital, Blackstone (above) and Apollo Global Management, disbursed a total of US$151.3 billion in 2022 for so-called middle-market deals – midsized acquisitions by private equity firms.
GM had set a goal of cutting US$2 billion from operating costs by the end of 2024, with 30 per cent to 50 per cent of the total being achieved this year.

site_title: BMW’s Mini apologises over Shanghai Auto Show’s ice cream ‘discrimination’
summary: Mini, a brand owned by BMW, apologized over accusations of discrimination at the Shanghai Auto Show after a video showed staff handing free ice cream to a foreigner while refusing it to a Chinese visitor. The incident sparked online outrage, with some claiming "BMW is hitting people!" Mini said "careless management and staff negligence" caused the unpleasantness and pledged to improve training. The incident highlighted the importance of Chinese customers for BMW, with the company emphasizing its commitment to the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: Zeekr, a premium electric vehicle (EV) brand owned by Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, highlighted how its newly released X model SUV has seats that can massage passengers.

Volkswagen said at the Auto Shanghai show it would introduce 10 more electric vehicle (EV) models by 2026 and cut the time to develop new models by almost 40 per cent to keep pace with faster-moving Chinese rivals.

site_title: The fairytale life of Horacio Pagani
summary: Horacio Pagani, founder of Pagani Automobili, has built a luxury car brand known for its exclusive and rare vehicles that blend art with engineering. With a production rate of just one car a week, Pagani's cars have appreciated significantly in value, with some models selling for 5-10 times their original price. The brand's 25th anniversary tour in Singapore celebrates the success of its flagship model, the Zonda, and marks a milestone for the company, which has remained private and family-owned despite the challenges of the global economy.

images.alt_text: The SL 55 also has active aerodynamics to stabilise it at high speed, which is handy because the snarling V8 can propel it all the way to 295 km/h.
Superwealthy revving up Bugatti and other exotic car sales in Singapore

site_title: Australia plans green bond in 2024 in climate finance reversal
summary: Australia plans to launch a green bond program in 2024 to boost investment in clean-energy infrastructure and help the country reach net-zero emissions by 2050. The program, developed in collaboration with investors, aims to increase investment in clean energy and support the government's climate goals. This move comes after the Labor government set a target to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 43% by 2030 and follows a whole-of-economy revamp. The program will be managed by the Australian Office of Financial Management, marking a shift towards more climate-focused financing in the country.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese tourists pose for a photographer (not pictured) near the Sydney Opera House, Australia April 18, 2018. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Elon Musk’s wealth plunges US$13 billion as drama unfolds across empire
summary: Elon Musk's wealth plummeted by $13 billion due to Tesla's disappointing first-quarter results, which led to a 9.75% decline in its shares. An experimental Starship rocket also failed in a launch in Texas, and millions of Twitter users lost their blue checkmarks. Despite this, Musk's net worth rebounded by $26.8 billion this year due to Tesla's 32% gain. Musk remains the world's second-richest person, behind Bernard Arnault.

images.alt_text: The two-stage rocketship blasted off from the company’s Starbase spaceport and test facility east of Brownsville, Texas, for what SpaceX hoped, at best, would be a 90-minute debut flight into space.
Twitter began the mass removal of its blue ticks on April 20, 2023, as the symbol previously used to signify a verified account vanished from users including the Pope, Donald Trump and Justin Bieber.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk has missed his previous targets to achieve self-driving capability dating back years.

site_title: US existing home sales resume downward trend in March
summary: US existing home sales fell 2.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.44 million units in March, as a reversal in mortgage rates pushed buyers back to the sidelines. Despite the decline, economists believe the housing market slump is nearing its end, citing a recent survey showing a seven-month high in the National Association of Home Builders-Wells Fargo Housing Market Index. Mortgage rates declined in mid-April, which may pull buyers back into the market, but tightened underwriting standards due to recent financial turmoil could hinder recovery.

images.alt_text: US buyers have begun flocking to builders’ sales offices, where offers of discounts and rate buy-downs are so generous that it’s often cheaper to buy new than pre-owned.

site_title: Top Federal Reserve official sees interest rates rising and staying high
summary: Top Federal Reserve official Patrick Harker expects US interest rates to rise further and remain high to combat inflation, which remains above the Fed's 2% target. Since March last year, the Federal Open Markets Committee has raised interest rates nine times, with Harker suggesting additional tightening may be needed to achieve policy goals. He expects inflation to decline, landing between 3% and 3.5% this year, and rates to be held in place after reaching the target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Philadelphia Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker speaks with CNBC's Steve Liesman (not pictured) after an interview in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, U.S., on Aug. 25, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Saphir/File Photo

site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks at slowest pace in six months: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank at the slowest pace in six months in April, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 49.5 from 49.2 in the previous month. The service sector, however, remained solid, expanding for an eight straight month. This suggests a patchy post-Covid economic recovery, with factories facing persistent struggles despite the worst appearing to be over. The service sector's expansion was attributed to gains in new orders and new export business, but manufacturers expressed concerns over rising costs and component shortages.

images.alt_text: The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food, but includes energy costs, matched a median market forecast.
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc
