site_title: SpaceX's Starship rocket successfully launched on first test flight, then explodes
summary: SpaceX successfully launched its Starship rocket on its first test flight from Starbase spaceport in Texas, but the vehicle exploded just over 4 minutes into the flight due to a failure to separate the upper-stage from the lower-stage Super Heavy. The 394-foot-tall rocket reached the sky before flipping end over end and disintegrating. Despite the failure, SpaceX officials deemed the launch a successful test flight, celebrating the achievement of integrating the fully assembled Starship and booster rocket.

site_title: US: Stocks slump after gloomy Tesla and bank results
summary: US stocks slumped on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% and the S&P 500 down 0.6%, following lackluster corporate results from Tesla and regional banks. Tesla's quarterly earnings fell, and the company hinted at further profit pressures from price cuts, contributing to the market's downturn. Regional banks also saw their shares slump due to industry panic after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, with investors on edge ahead of the heaviest earnings period.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MARCH 16: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 16, 2023 in New York City. Stocks fell again in morning trading as investors continue to show concerns over the stability of global banks following the collapse last week of Silicon Valley Bank.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase moderately
summary: US weekly jobless claims increased moderately, rising 5,000 to 245,000 for the week ended April 15, exceeding economists' forecasts. The rise may be attributed to spring breaks and people exhausting severance packages following layoffs in technology and interest rate-sensitive sectors. Despite slowing job gains, claims suggest strong employment growth, allowing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates one more time next month. Economists forecast recession by the second half of 2023, with data on continuing claims to provide further insight into the labor market.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 16, 2022 a “Now Hiring” sign at T.J. Maxx in Annapolis, Maryland. - US job gains eased in March for a second straight month, government data showed March 7, 2023, adding to signs that the world's largest economy is cooling as policymakers push on in their fight against inflation. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower on weak earnings, automakers spooked by Tesla
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Thursday, marking the second straight session of losses, as earnings reports disappointed and automakers tumbled after weak quarterly results from Tesla. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index dropped, with Nordic Semiconductor and Sartorius leading the decline. Tesla CEO Elon Musk suggested further price cuts to lift demand, sparking worries of a potential price war and hurting shares of carmakers. European auto stocks fell 3.7%, their worst one-day drop in five months, amid concerns about thin margins and inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.3 per cent lower at 33,786.62, while the broad-based S&P 500 dropped 0.6 per cent to 4,129.79 on Thursday.

site_title: Some ECB policymakers wanted rate hike pause: minutes
summary: European Central Bank policymakers were divided on whether to pause interest rate hikes in March due to financial market turmoil. Despite growing differences, a "very large majority" agreed to a 50 basis point increase, which was already announced. The minutes showed some members preferred to delay the hike until financial market tensions subsided. The ECB has raised interest rates by 350 basis points since July last year, with inflation still "far above" the 2% target. Analysts expect another rate hike at the upcoming May meeting, but its size is uncertain.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Japan’s March core consumer prices rise 3.1%, stays above BOJ target
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 3.1% in March, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target, as companies pass on rising costs to households. This marks the 10th straight month of acceleration in inflation, driven by global commodity price increases. The BOJ's ultra-loose monetary policy may be reevaluated if wage momentum holds, potentially leading to a phase-out of its massive stimulus program later this year.

images.alt_text: An advertisement notifying the opening of a Uniqlo store, operated by Fast Retailing Co., displayed on a screen outside the Yodobashi Akiba Building in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, April 13, 2023. Fast Retailing said Thursday profit climbed in the fiscal second quarter, topping analysts' projections on improved demand, and raised its forecast for the full year. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: US homebuilder DR Horton’s annual revenue forecast beats estimates
summary: US homebuilder DR Horton forecasts full-year revenue above estimates, driven by elevated property prices and tight supply. Despite higher mortgage rates and inflationary pressures, demand improved during the quarter due to normal seasonal factors. DR Horton chairman Donald Horton attributed the improvement to seasonal factors. Shares rose 3.6% to US$105.5 in premarket trade.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 13 basis points, abruptly ending a five-week slide in borrowing costs, Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data showed on Wednesday (Apr 19).

site_title: Australia’s Optus hit with class action over cybersecurity breach
summary: More than 100,000 Optus customers have joined a class-action lawsuit over a cybersecurity breach that exposed 1.2 million customers' data in September. The breach is alleged to have compromised customer data and failed to protect it, violating Optus' policies and laws. Claimants are seeking compensation for distress, frustration, and financial losses, as well as potential harm from stalking victims. Optus will defend itself in the lawsuit, which is one of several high-profile cyberattacks on Australia's corporate sector in recent months.

images.alt_text: Optus store

site_title: Manslaughter charges against Alec Baldwin to be dropped: lawyer
summary: Alec Baldwin's manslaughter charges related to the 2021 fatal shooting of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins on the set of the film "Rust" are to be dropped, his lawyer announced, as newly appointed special prosecutors take over the case. Baldwin had pleaded not guilty and claimed he was told the gun was safe before it discharged. The decision to drop the charges comes after multiple legal setbacks, and it remains unclear if armorer Hannah Gutierrez-Reed will face charges. Filming is set to resume at a new location.

images.alt_text: Alec Baldwin was holding a Colt .45 during rehearsals for the film in New Mexico when it discharged, killing Halyna Hutchins in October 2021.
Adolf
Alec Baldwin was holding the Colt. 45 during rehearsals for the film when it discharged, killing Halyna Hutchins and wounding director Joel Souza in October 2021.

site_title: Biden urges global carbon cut, pledges US$1 billion to UN fund
summary: US President Joe Biden urged world leaders to strengthen their carbon-cutting ambitions, pledging $1 billion to the UN Green Climate Fund. He also requested $500 million to bolster Brazil's commitment to end deforestation in the Amazon and asked countries to align their emissions-cutting pledges with a bid to keep global warming below 1.5°C. The US will also commit to making half of all light-duty vehicles sold in 2030 emission-free models, and will work to reduce methane pollution in developing countries.

images.alt_text: The auto standards are designed to cap pollution allowed per mile, encouraging the sale of electric vehicles that do not produce tailpipe emissions.

site_title: Sweden’s biggest pension fund apologises after US$2 billion loss
summary: Sweden's largest pension fund, Alecta, has apologized for a US$2 billion loss due to failed investments in US niche banks during the banking crisis. The fund's acting CEO, Katarina Thorslund, acknowledged the mistake and vowed to learn from it. An internal investigation found that the decision to invest was within the fund's mandate, but Alecta will re-evaluate its risk management and benchmarking model. Thorslund assured pension savers that the impact on retirement savings is small and that the fund remains strong.

site_title: Fighting over the kids, the house and now their crypto
summary: In a divorce, couples in Singapore are now fighting over digital assets, including cryptocurrencies and non-fungible tokens (NFTs), in addition to traditional matrimonial assets. A recent court decision considered digital assets held in BlockFi, Binance, and Tokenise Xchange accounts to be matrimonial assets. Locating and valuing crypto assets is challenging due to the pseudonymity of blockchain wallets and the volatility of cryptocurrencies. Courts may treat crypto losses as financial irresponsibility or normal investment losses, and gains may be shared between spouses. The division of digital assets presents unique challenges for individuals in family disputes.

images.alt_text: SVB’s collapse is inseparable from the long era of low interest rates.
Pre-nup agreements: a valuable tool for wealth preservation

site_title: Warren Buffett is shaking Japan’s magic money tree
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has increased its investments in five major Japanese trading houses, boosting shares in three of the companies to record highs. The firm's investments, announced on Buffett's 90th birthday in 2020, have seen share prices rise by 64-202% since then. Berkshire Hathaway's yen-denominated bonds and currency hedging reveal the advantages of investing in Japan, with the yen-denominated bonds offering cheaper interest rates and protecting against currency falls. This trend may draw more American investors to the Japanese market, with other firms such as Elliott Management and Citadel reportedly increasing their presence in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Even after their rally over the past year, the main Japanese stock indices are still well below their historical peaks.
Berkshire Hathaway shareholders walk by a video screen at the company's annual meeting in Omaha May 4, 2013. REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: UK consumer confidence highest since Feb 2022 as ‘green shoots’ emerge: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence reached its highest level in 15 months, with a reading of -30 in April, up six points from March and the highest since February 2022. Despite high inflation, consumers are more optimistic about their finances and the economy, with expectations for the economy in the next 12 months hitting a 15-month high. This "green shoots" of recovery may indicate the UK economy will avoid a recession this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk along a busy shopping street, during the traditional Boxing Day sales in London, Britain, December 26, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Peering into the future of novels, with trained machines ready
summary: Author Stephen Marche collaborated with three artificial intelligence programs to write a novella, "Death of an Author," about an author using AI. Marche used ChatGPT for plot development, Sudowrite for tone and style, and Cohere for creative lines. While AI excelled in dialogue and plot, its results were deemed subpar. Marche sees AI as a tool for writers, but the Author's Guild has raised concerns about job displacement. Pushkin Industries, the publisher, used AI for some aspects of the book, including blurbs and cover art, but hired a human narrator to ensure quality.

images.alt_text: Man, computer, think, digital, chat, communication

site_title: Oil falls 2% on recession fears, swelling US fuel stocks
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$81.10 a barrel, as fears of a possible recession and rising US fuel stocks weighed on the market. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and a moderate increase in unemployment claims fueled concerns about a slowdown in fuel demand. Petrol inventories jumped unexpectedly, and US crude stockpiles dropped, but analysts suggested these declines could be short-lived.

images.alt_text: Oil workers pass a pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, left, at a drilling site operated by Tatneft OAO near Almetyevsk, Russia, on Friday, July 31, 2015. Eleven months of surviving with oil below $100 have left Russia hardened enough to endure a monthlong drop to $40 a barrel, a survey of economists showed. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Friday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,307.75. Despite 36.2 million securities worth S$36.4 million changing hands, the top traded counters included Sembcorp Marine and Thomson Medical. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell, while Keppel Corp rose 0.5% after posting a 9% revenue increase for the first fiscal quarter. The decline follows lower US indices and European shares, which closed lower due to disappointing earnings reports.

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: Mercedes posts higher operating profit in first quarter
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported an operating profit of 5.5 billion euros (S$8 billion) in the first quarter of 2023, a 5.2 billion euro increase from the same period last year. Higher vehicle prices offset higher material costs due to inflation, with strong sales of vans, electric vehicles, and top-end vehicles driving the improvement. Electric vehicle sales more than doubled to 51,600 units, representing 10% of total sales, and sales of top-end vehicles rose 18% year-over-year. The company's finance chief attributed the growth to higher prices "overcompensating" for inflation.

images.alt_text: A GWM executive unveils the B07 Fierce Dragon Max from the company’s export-focused Haval brand.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Climate adaptation, mitigation could add US$4.3 trillion in opportunities in Apac by 2030: WEF
summary: A World Economic Forum report estimates that climate adaptation and mitigation business opportunities in Asia could generate an additional US$4.3 trillion in revenue and 232 million new jobs by 2030. The top 10 business opportunities alone could generate US$2.3 billion in revenue and 133.5 million jobs. Investments in adaptation could return four to nine times the amount put in, while climate mitigation requires investments in clean-energy infrastructure, transport, and agriculture. Asia's ability to combat climate change is critical, with the region producing 51% of global emissions and leading the way in clean-energy investment.

images.alt_text: Generics on sustainabilty and ESG, climate change, climate resilience

site_title: TSMC expects Q2 sales drop as clients struggle to clear inventory
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, expects a 16% drop in sales for the second quarter due to an inventory glut and a weakening global economy. The company forecasts its business to hit a bottom in the second quarter and pick up in the third quarter, with long-term demand expected to improve despite current softness. TSMC's business will outperform the global semiconductor market, driven by its dominance in making high-end chips for customers like Apple.

images.alt_text: Residents at a park in front of residential buildings in the Guanxin district of Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Thursday, Nov. 3, 2022. Taiwan's success in the semiconductor industry is fueling a boom in house prices that is spreading from north to south, with highly paid workers at major chipmakers pushing the property market to buck the trend of a global slowdown. Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, UOI, Lian Beng
summary: Keppel Corp posted a 9% rise in revenue to S$2.3 billion for its first quarter, driven by a disposal gain from the merger between its offshore and marine unit and Sembcorp Marine. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit divested an industrial property for S$35.4 million. United Overseas Insurance's net profit for the first three months of 2023 rose 2.4% to S$4.7 million. Lian Beng Group clarified that its controlling Ong family is not restricted from making another offer within the next 12 months if its current privatisation attempt falls through.

site_title: Big-spending Chelsea head into the wilderness, their next destination unknown
summary: Chelsea, under new ownership by Todd Boehly, has exited the Champions League with a 4-0 aggregate defeat to Real Madrid, ending their top-four hopes in the Premier League. The team is 11th in the 20-team table, having won only two of their past 12 games, and has lost US$600 million since embarking on the largest single-season transfer spending spree in history. Chelsea's interim manager Frank Lampard suggested his team "caused Real a lot of problems" but ultimately fell short. The team's poor performance has raised concerns about Boehly's ability to plot the club's way back to the top, despite his claims of a "modern, data-driven approach".

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - Europa League - Play-Off Second Leg - Manchester United v FC Barcelona - Old Trafford, Manchester, Britain - February 23, 2023
General view of a corner flag inside the stadium before the match REUTERS/Carl Recine
Eight of the 20 clubs in the league currently have betting companies as shirt sponsors, including Newcastle United (Fun88), West Ham United (Betway) and Everton (Stake.com).
Clubs in the top flight and below avoided paying taxes to HM Revenue and Customs via the construction of artificial contracts, according to Tax Policy Associates.

site_title: Yellen calls for 'constructive' US-China economic ties but will protect national security interests
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen called for "constructive and fair" economic ties with China, but emphasized the need to protect US national security interests. Yellen outlined the Biden administration's priorities, including securing national security, fostering healthy competition, and cooperating on global issues such as climate change and debt relief. However, she also warned against China's "no limits" partnership with Russia, citing concerns over material support and sanctions evasion. Yellen stated that the US will not compromise on national security concerns, even if it means trade-offs with economic interests.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said in a statement to the IMF’s steering committee that she wanted the World Bank to implement further reforms to scale up lending for climate and other global needs on a rolling basis.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on downbeat earnings, rate jitters
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Thursday, April 20, 2023, due to disappointing earnings from Tesla, AT&T, and regional banks, amid concerns over further US interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 fell 0.58%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.46% and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.97%.

site_title: Luxury industry under scrutiny as EU targets Gucci and others
summary: European Union antitrust regulators inspected a Gucci facility in Milan as part of an investigation into possible violations of Article 101, which prohibits agreements that restrict competition within the EU. The inspection, aimed at travel items, handbags, and other leather goods, is part of a broader investigation spanning several countries. The EU's luxury goods industry is under scrutiny, with Gucci being one of the companies targeted. The outcome of the investigation is expected to have implications for the industry and its practices.

images.alt_text: Analysts say 2023 will be the “year of the Chinese consumer”, noting that the pandemic restrictions pushed down the share of Chinese consumers in global luxury spending to 17 per cent last year, compared with 33 per cent before the pandemic.
Gucci’s focus on its wealthiest clients is a key element of its growth strategy after the brand’s sales fell 14 per cent in the last three months of 2022.
Gucci’s revenue fell 14 per cent on a comparable basis to 2.73 billion euros to lag an analysts’ consensus for an 11 per cent fall.

site_title: Chinese liquor company ZJLD set to price Hong Kong IPO near bottom of range: sources
summary: Chinese liquor company ZJLD Group is set to price its Hong Kong IPO at HK$10.82 per share, raising HK$5.3 billion, according to sources. The company, which accounts for 69.5% of China's alcoholic beverage market, is backed by US private equity giant KKR. This deal, the largest in Hong Kong so far in 2023, may prompt more IPOs in the near future, with dealmakers hopeful for a positive performance.

site_title: Global wine trade hits record-high value but volumes fall
summary: The global wine trade reached a record-high value of 37.6 billion euros in 2022, driven by a 15% rise in export prices. However, wine volumes fell 1% to 232 million hectolitres due to weaker demand and logistical problems caused by the war in Ukraine and global supply chain disruptions. Wine production was also slightly lowered to 258 million hectolitres, 1% below the previous year's output.

site_title: Saudi Telecom to buy United Group Towers for 1.2 billion euros
summary: Saudi Telecom agreed to buy a portfolio of over 4,800 towers in Bulgaria, Croatia, and Slovenia from United Group for 1.22 billion euros. The deal marks Tawal, a state-backed firm, as its first foray into Europe. The acquisition expands Saudi Telecom's European presence and follows recent investments by Middle Eastern telecom operators, including Emirates Telecommunications Group's US$4 billion stake in Vodafone Group. The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2023.

site_title: US banks face shifting hundreds of billions in assets to EU at ECB request
summary: US banks, including Citigroup, are expected to shift hundreds of billions of dollars in assets and risk transfers to the euro area in response to the European Central Bank's request. This move is part of a "desk mapping" review by the ECB, which aims to strengthen the EU's financial system. The banks are negotiating with regulators over the structure of their business in the bloc, nearly seven years after the UK's Brexit vote. The ECB's findings are set to influence the banks' plans, with Citigroup officials receiving feedback on Thursday.

images.alt_text: London remains the big beast in European finance for now, with headcount vastly outnumbering the rest of Europe.

site_title: AmEx profit misses estimates as it builds up reserves
summary: American Express' first-quarter profit fell 13% to $1.8 billion, or $2.40 per share, missing analysts' estimates of $2.66 per share. The credit card giant set aside $1.1 billion in provisions due to cardholders falling behind on debt repayments amid economic uncertainty. This marks a reversal from a year ago when it had a benefit of $33 million.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation eases to 3.4% in March on falling petrol prices
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 3.4% in March, down from 3.7% in February, primarily due to a decrease in petrol prices. This is the seventh consecutive month of deceleration and the lowest in nine months. The lower inflation rate is seen as a positive sign for the economy, which is facing growth jitters due to tariff threats. The decrease in petrol prices is attributed to a decline in premium grade petrol prices.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's food, restaurants and hotels segments continue seeing higher price growth in February.
Bank Negara governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said the monetary policy remains focussed on ensuring price stability in support of sustainable growth.

site_title: Yellen says FSOC to tighten rules on risk assessment, non-bank firms
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen announced that the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) will vote on a new framework to better identify and respond to stability risks and revised guidance to designate non-bank financial institutions for regulatory supervision. The moves aim to enhance safeguards against financial disruptions and follow recent regional bank failures. Yellen stated that actions taken have stabilized the financial system, but the banking sector remains vigilant and closely monitored. The new framework and guidance are designed to make the designation process easier and more transparent.

images.alt_text: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen discusses "U.S.-China Economic Relationship" during a forum hosted by the Johns Hopkins University at the Nitze Building in Washington, U.S., April 20, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Silbiger

site_title: Amazon launches program to identify and track counterfeiters
summary: Amazon has launched the Anti-Counterfeiting Exchange (ACX), a program to identify and track counterfeiters on its platform. Stores and sellers can anonymously contribute information to a third-party database or use it to avoid doing business with confirmed counterfeiters. The initiative aims to help the industry stop organized crime earlier, as counterfeiters are most common in apparel, home goods, and cosmetics. Amazon is also working with the US Customs and Border Protection to identify and target low-value shipments that may be counterfeit goods.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Small toy shopping cart is seen in front of displayed Amazon logo in this illustration taken, July 30, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Meet the guy who scored US$250,000 of tickets for US$17,000 after airline error
summary: A currency conversion error on All Nippon Airways' Vietnam website listed airfares at ultra-low prices, with one opportunist, Herman Yip, snagging $250,000 worth of tickets for $17,000. Yip, a travel website owner, bought 25 tickets, including first-class flights from Jakarta to Aruba via Tokyo and New York, for $890 each. ANA Holdings has not confirmed if the low-priced tickets will remain valid, and Yip advises others to react quickly and be flexible, as options may be limited.

images.alt_text: The Iata estimates that the worldwide tab for decarbonising aviation will top US$1 trillion.

site_title: MAS bets on transition finance in next phase of its green finance plan
summary: MAS is expanding its green finance plan to include transition finance, aiming to corral capital towards Asia's net-zero transition. The central bank will grow the sustainable-debt market, improve ESG data and disclosures, and ensure financial institutions adopt credible transition plans. MAS will also expand its grant schemes to support brown-to-green projects, top up funds for catastrophe bonds, and develop a code of conduct for ESG ratings and data providers. The move is seen as a key step in driving decarbonisation in Asia, with market players welcoming the expansion of transition finance plans.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the launch of NUS Sustainable and Green Finance Institute on Thursday (April 20) with Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of NUS board of trustees, Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS President and Professor Sumit Agarwal, managing director of the institute.
Janice Lim

site_title: Car companies head for showdown in Shanghai
summary: Top car brands such as Lexus, Maserati, and Porsche showcased new global models at Auto Shanghai 2023, while local brands like GWM, MG, and Xpeng debuted new export-focused cars. Startups HiPhi and Zeekr announced plans to compete with European brands in China's market. The five-day auto show, expected to attract over 1 million visitors, has regained its position as a major industry event after China reopened to foreign visitors. The event highlights the growing competition in China's car market between domestic and international brands.

images.alt_text:
juev19 - Andy Kang, VP of Sales and Innovation, Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Center Singapore, with the Hyundai Ioniq 5 First 100 edition at the Singapore Motorshow



source/copyright/credit: Big Fish Publishing Pte Ltd

site_title: Blackstone profit slides as dealmaking hit by market tumult
summary: Blackstone's first-quarter profit fell 36% to $1.25 billion, or 97 cents a share, due to slowing dealmaking in a tumultuous market. The world's largest owner of commercial property wrote down the valuation of some US offices, as employees continue to resist returning to workplaces after the pandemic. Assets under management rose 8% to $991.3 billion, edging closer to the $1 trillion mark. The decline in dealmaking is attributed to rising interest rates and the Federal Reserve's rate increases.

images.alt_text: Blackstone’s real estate business, which started in 1991, now has US$326 billion of investor capital under management.
Blackstone and many of its rivals are flush with cash to invest from pensions, endowments and insurers.

site_title: Huawei launches in-house software system after being cut off from US services
summary: Huawei has successfully rolled out its in-house Meta-ERP system across 80% of its business, marking a significant victory over US curbs that once threatened its survival. The company's rotating chairperson Meng Wanzhou attended a ceremony in Dongguan, China, to celebrate the switch. Huawei's Meta-ERP is a customized enterprise resource planning system used for managing key business operations, replacing software sourced from US vendors. This move is seen as a defensive play benefiting from the ongoing US-China trade tensions and Huawei's efforts to maintain its independence.

images.alt_text: Huawei was placed on the Entity List, a US trade blacklist, in 2019 to reduce the sale of US goods to the company amid national security and foreign policy concerns.

site_title: Lego, Novo Nordisk agree to buy green methanol for plastic production
summary: Lego and Novo Nordisk have agreed to buy green methanol for plastic production. Lego will use e-methanol in some building bricks, aiming to bring new prototype bricks to the market. The first large-scale plant, developed by European Energy, will produce 32,000 tonnes of e-methanol per year from wind and solar energy, starting next year. Novo Nordisk will also buy e-methanol to substitute fossil-based plastic in medical devices, such as insulin pens. The partnership aims to reduce carbon emissions in the production of plastic.

images.alt_text: “Looking at the US potential, we still have a long way to go,” Lego chief operating officer Carsten Rasmussen said.

site_title: EU parliament backs world’s first comprehensive rules for cryptoassets
summary: The European Parliament voted 517-38 in favor of the world's first comprehensive rules for issuing and trading cryptoassets, such as bitcoin. The regulations, which bring a competitive advantage for the EU, were steered through parliament by Stefan Berger. The approval marks a significant step towards regulating the cryptoasset market, which has been largely unregulated to date.

site_title: US dollar, euro steady after strong US bank results
summary: The US dollar and euro remained steady after strong US banking results, alleviating concerns of a financial crisis. Morgan Stanley's first quarter profit beat expectations, with other major US lenders also reporting rosy results. The euro edged up 0.1% to US$1.0964, near a one-year high, while the US dollar index eased 0.1% to 101.89. This stability in currency markets suggests that the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank will continue to raise interest rates, supporting the economic outlook.

site_title: Ong family not bound by 12-month rule that bars another offer if current attempt fails, says Lian Beng
summary: Lian Beng Group's controlling Ong family is not restricted by a 12-month rule that bars another offer if its current attempt to privatise the company fails. The offer will be unconditional, allowing the family to make another attempt within the next 12 months if the current one is unsuccessful, according to financial adviser UOB.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Lian Beng's chairman Ong Pang Aik and his family are making an offer for the company at S$0.62 per share, which is nearly 60 per cent below book value
Ong Pang Aik is a director of both OSC Capital and Lian Beng.
Lian Beng did not give further details on the new construction project but noted that the order book will provide a sustainable flow of activity through FY2027.

site_title: Keppel Corp posts 9% rise in Q1 revenue to S$2.3 billion
summary: Keppel Corp reported a 9% increase in Q1 revenue to S$2.3 billion, driven by a disposal gain of S$3.3 billion from the merger of its offshore and marine unit with Sembcorp Marine. Net profit was significantly higher year-over-year, excluding discontinued operations and the disposal gain. The company aims to grow its assets under management to S$200 billion by 2030 and has achieved its three-year asset monetization target ahead of schedule. Despite a 43.9% decline in quarterly revenue from its asset management segment, the company remains optimistic about future growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: A generic picture of the Keppel Corporation logo at the Central Business District, shot on December 23, 2022. Can be used for stories on offshore and marine, property, infrastructure and asset management businesses, money, banking, economy, recession, finance, investments, banks and Singapore.
Tan Nai Lun
Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's tourism arrivals surpassed 1 million in March for the first time since 2020, according to the Singapore Tourism Board. The country's economy can remain vibrant by growing its workforce and driving productivity, said Health Minister Ong Ye Kung. In other news, South-east Asia's deal-making slowed in 2022, but the energy transition sparked investor interest. The OCBC SME Index turned contractionary after eight consecutive quarters of expansion, while the MAS set aside S$15 million for sustainable bond and loan grant schemes.

site_title: Ikea plans new US stores in 2 billion euros push to challenge Walmart and Wayfair
summary: IKEA plans to expand its US presence with a 2 billion euro investment over three years, aiming to win market share from Walmart and Wayfair. The company will open eight new big stores and nine smaller stores, upgrading existing locations, and creating 2,000 jobs. This expansion is a response to cash-strapped consumers seeking affordable products and comes as other big-box retailers close stores. The move is expected to increase Ikea's US locations by a third, from 51 stores and two "plan and order points".

images.alt_text: The buyer of Ikea's Novgorod factory, Invest Plus, has retained the backbone of the factory’s workforce and says it will guarantee jobs for at least a year.

site_title: India court denies Rahul Gandhi appeal to suspend conviction
summary: India's Supreme Court has denied Rahul Gandhi's appeal to suspend his defamation conviction, which carries a two-year prison sentence and disqualification from parliament. Gandhi's disqualification means he may not be able to contest national elections next year unless a higher court rules in his favor. The court ruled that Gandhi failed to show that his disqualification and election ban would cause "irreversible and irrevocable damage." Gandhi will appeal to the high court and will remain out of jail until a final decision is made.

images.alt_text: epa10575626 Senior congress leader Rahul Gandhi waves to the attendants during a political rally meeting named 'Jai Bharath' ahead of the Indian Karnataka State Assembly elections, at the Kolar district around 70 kilomerters from Bangalore, India, 16 April 2023. Karnataka State Legislative Assembly elections will be held on 10 May and counting on 13 May 2023 to elect all 224 assembly members.  EPA-EFE/JAGADEESH NV

site_title: CATL first-quarter revenue surges as battery giant cements lead
summary: CATL, the world's largest battery cell maker, reported an 83% jump in revenue to 89 billion yuan ($17.2 billion) in the first quarter, exceeding market expectations. The company's net income rose to 9.8 billion yuan, driven by climbing demand for cleaner vehicles and falling raw materials costs. CATL expects its battery sales volume to grow 40-50% in 2023, driven by China's economic reopening and zero purchase tax to bolster EV sales. The company plans to raise 4 billion yuan in capital for projects in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: CATL announced its targets to achieve carbon neutrality with all its battery making plants by 2025, and across its battery value chain by 2035

site_title: Adaptation is key for Singapore brands entering the US
summary: Singapore brands are making inroads into the US market, but face challenges such as supply-chain issues and adapting to local tastes. Irvins, a salted-egg chips brand, tailored its approach by selling keto-friendly products, while Hainan Jones adapted its chicken rice recipe by cutting water and reformulating chilli sauce. Despite these challenges, companies are finding success, with EnterpriseSG supporting over 190 companies in entering the US market since the pandemic. To stand out, brands can highlight unique aspects, such as ingredients or processes, and EnterpriseSG advises companies on domestic competitors and challenges.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The US is a "difficult and expensive market", but "the biggest fund pool is here, people understand fintechs a lot better here", says Pratik Gandhi, COO of Nium.
Setting up a lab in San Francisco has enabled Engine Biosciences to tap the deal flow among pharmaceutical giants in the US.

site_title: Taiwan March export orders slump nearly 26%, worst drop in 14 years
summary: Taiwan's export orders contracted 25.7% from a year earlier to $46.58 billion in March, the largest drop in 14 years, due to global economic slowdown, inflation, and interest rate hikes. Orders for electronics and telecommunications products fell 29.4% and 26.3% respectively. The Ministry of Economic Affairs expects a continued decline until the fourth quarter, with April orders expected to fall 17.1% from a year earlier.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit to divest industrial building in Macpherson for S$35.4m
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit is divesting its industrial building KA Place in Macpherson for S$35.4 million, a 219% premium to its original purchase price. The sale is part of the manager's proactive asset management strategy to improve portfolio quality and optimize returns. The divestment is expected to result in a S$920,000 fall in net property income and a 0.005 cent decline in distribution per unit. Net proceeds will be recycled to fund investments, repay debt, and distribute to unitholders. The proposed divestment is expected to be completed within the second quarter of 2023.

site_title: Tesla signals more price cuts ahead despite margin damage
summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk has signaled that the company will continue to cut prices to boost demand, despite significant margin damage. The company's operating margin shrunk to 11.4% in the first quarter, a two-year low, following previous price cuts. Musk stated that Tesla prioritizes higher volumes and a larger fleet over higher margins, and walked back its automotive margin forecast for the year. The move is seen as an effort to stimulate demand in a uncertain economic environment.

images.alt_text: Tesla produced 440,808 cars and delivered 422,875 vehicles in the quarter, resulting in excess inventory of about 18,000

site_title: Singapore shares dampened by Fed rate-hike expectations; STI drops 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.3% on Thursday, April 20, as investor sentiment was dampened by expectations of further rate hikes from key central banks. The US Federal Reserve's latest report showed declining lending volumes and loan demand, but analysts expect a 25-basis-point rate hike on May 3. Local stocks like Nanofilm Technologies' 9.1% drop and Venture Corporation's 0.9% decline were among the losers, while Azeus Systems' 3.5% gain was a rare bright spot after the Singapore Exchange amended rules to enable electronic general meetings.

While the company did not specify its net profit figures for the quarter, it noted that net profit was significantly higher year-on-year.
Markets swung in early Asian trade, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney and Manila up but Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington and Taipei were negative on Thursday.
The SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Keppel Reit's distributable income from operations falls 6.7 per cent to S$50.2 million for its first quarter, from S$53.8 million a year earlier.
Brent futures for June delivery fell US$1.65, or 2.0 per cent, to settle at US$83.12 a barrel on Wednesday.
Tesla produced 440,808 cars and delivered 422,875 vehicles in the quarter, resulting in excess inventory of about 18,000

site_title: South Korea announces 20 trillion won investment in advanced battery technologies
summary: South Korea has announced a 20 trillion won ($20.2 billion) investment in advanced battery technologies through 2030, with three major battery companies - LG Energy Solution, Samsung SDI, and SK On - jointly participating. The investment aims to develop solid-state batteries, cylindrical 4680 cell batteries, and cobalt-free batteries, ahead of global competitors. The move is seen as part of South Korea's efforts to strengthen its EV battery market and increase domestic production capacity.

site_title: AT&T quarterly wireless subscriber additions beat estimates
summary: AT&T reported better-than-expected quarterly subscriber additions, adding 424,000 postpaid phone subscribers in the first quarter. The carrier's discounted offers and cheaper plans helped lure more cost-conscious customers in a competitive market. Total revenue rose 1.4% to $30.1 billion, driven by higher revenue in broadband services, partly offsetting lower equipment sales. Income from continuing operations was $4.5 billion, or 57 cents per share, compared to $5.1 billion, or 65 cents per share, a year earlier.

site_title: At Shanghai show, auto rivals lure drivers with in-car karaoke, crystal balls
summary: Automakers at the Shanghai auto show showcased innovative features such as in-car karaoke, crystal balls, and 3D dashboards to attract drivers in China's largest auto market. Chinese brands like Zeekr and Li Auto released new models with features like massage seats and voice-activated interfaces, while foreign brands like Polestar and Genesis also showcased unique technologies. However, industry experts express concerns about the costs and maturity of these innovations, citing the need for more time to develop and refine them.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen said at the Auto Shanghai show it would introduce 10 more electric vehicle (EV) models by 2026 and cut the time to develop new models by almost 40 per cent to keep pace with faster-moving Chinese rivals.

site_title: Three short films about climbing that will inspire you
summary: Reel Rock 17, a collection of three short films about climbing, is showing in Singapore from April 22-23. The films, produced by Reel Rock, follow French climber Sebastien "Seb" Bouin as he tackles an overhanging cave in his backyard, Palestinian climbers as they build a movement in the West Bank, and Barbara "Babsi" Zangerl and Jacopo Larcher as they attempt a free ascent of a 3,000-foot route in Pakistan. The films showcase the human spirit and strength, offering an intimate look into the world of sport climbing.

images.alt_text: In Kill Boksoon, Jeon Do-yeon (right) stars as a renowned assassin whose professional successes are starkly contrasted against her personal struggles as a single mother.

site_title: CDL puts up 62 freehold strata industrial units in Pasir Panjang for sale at S$103 million
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has put up 62 freehold strata industrial units in Citilink Warehouse Complex in Pasir Panjang for sale at S$103 million, with an indicative price of S$997 per square foot. The units range from 947.2 to 2,884.7 square feet and represent about 34% of the development. The sale is seen as an opportunity for buyers to take advantage of the redevelopment potential of the area, which is set to become part of the Greater Southern Waterfront.

images.alt_text: Total investment sales fell 61 per cent to S$4.2 billion in the first quarter of 2023, figures compiled by Knight Frank show.

site_title: Singapore must abandon ‘use and throw culture’, invest now for future sustainability: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore must shift away from its "use and throw culture" and invest in long-term sustainability, said Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu. This includes investing in coastal protection and food security, and making changes to reduce waste through individual and business actions. The government can also nudge behavior through policies like refundable deposits for drink packaging. Fu emphasized the importance of collaboration between the public, private, and people sectors to achieve sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
PM Lee Hsien Loong delivering his speech on the report of the Committee of Privileges in Parliament on 15 February 2022.

The government will invest in Singaporeans “throughout life”, said Education Minister Chan Chun Sing, ith plans to make training more accessible for working adults with competing commitments and support more targeted for mid-career workers, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups.
Singapore will continue to sustain real income growth for the middle, which is why economic growth is “non-negotiable” for the city-state, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: China funds flock to Hong Kong to sate mainland investors
summary: China-based fund managers have set up operations in Hong Kong in the past six months, seeking to offer US dollar-based products and international exposure to Chinese investors. At least eight funds, including billion-dollar yuan quant funds, equity funds, and mutual funds, have established themselves in the territory. These funds aim to diversify investments and generate stronger returns for high-net-worth Chinese families, who are now able to travel and invest abroad after China reopened its borders.

images.alt_text: The loan rates are based on the PBOC’s one-year policy loan rate, which was kept unchanged earlier this week.
China’s economy grew at a faster-than-expected pace in the first quarter, as businesses and consumers came out of crippling pandemic disruptions.

site_title: TSMC expects Japan to share half of US$8 billion local fab cost
summary: TSMC expects Japan to cover half of the estimated US$8 billion cost of a new chip-making facility in Kumamoto prefecture, addressing national security concerns and supply chain shocks. Japan has approved 774 billion yen (S$7.7 billion) in funding for domestic semiconductor investment, suggesting TSMC's effort may be a significant portion of the total. This move aims to strengthen domestic chip-making capacity, particularly for emerging technologies like 5G and autonomous driving.

site_title: Malaysia slams ‘unjust’ EU deforestation law for blocking palm oil
summary: Malaysia strongly opposes the European Union's new law banning imports of commodities linked to deforestation, calling it "unjust" and a "deliberate effort" to increase costs and barriers for its palm oil sector. The law, which applies to palm oil, soy, beef, and other commodities, aims to reduce deforestation in the EU. Malaysia, the world's second-largest exporter of palm oil, fears the law will harm its export revenue and disproportionately affect small farmers. The country is working with Indonesia to consider a response and remains open to talks with the EU.

images.alt_text: A worker collects palm oil fruits at an oil palm plantation in Slim River, Malaysia, Aug 2021.

site_title: Executive condos among top percentage gainers in Q1 resale deals
summary: Executive condominium (EC) homeowners in Singapore's suburbs or outside the central region (OCR) scored significant gains in the first quarter of 2023, with some selling for nearly double their original price. Three EC transactions in the OCR were among the top five profit-making resale deals by percentage, with sellers making gains of 82 to 86%. This trend is attributed to low mortgage rates and the seven-year holding period of some EC units, which resulted in "attractively high profits".

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
With the Chinese government ending its zero-Covid policy from January, further en masse reinvestment in the South-east Asia region is possible. However, buying sentiment will likely remain cautious.
Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) data released on Monday (Apr 17) show that in March, developers sold 492 units, excluding ECs, up 13.6 per cent from the 433 units sold in February.

site_title: 📜 What you need to know about non-compete clauses
summary: The US has moved to ban non-compete clauses from employment contracts, citing restrictions on workers' ability to take better jobs and pay. In Singapore, non-compete clauses can range from three months to two years, but the courts tend to side with employees, requiring employers to prove legitimate interests to protect. Employees may be able to disregard non-compete clauses if they're in junior positions, have non-disclosure clauses, or work for rival companies with limited client interaction.

images.alt_text: Daryl Choo

site_title: Digital verification platform Accredify raises US$7 million in Series A led by iGlobe Partners
summary: Accredify, a digital verification platform, raised US$7 million in Series A funding led by iGlobe Partners and SIG Venture Capital. The company plans to use the funds to expand its Sydney and Japan offices and diversify its use cases across various industries, including human resources, finance, and education. Accredify's blockchain-based technology ensures the authenticity of digital documents. The funding will also help the company leverage global networks to bring its digital trust technology to governments and enterprises across the region.

Temasek Trust joins the Series A round of impact verification provider BlueMark as a new investor.

site_title: Japan PM rules out sales tax hike to fund families, defence
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has ruled out raising the country's sales tax to fund a plan to boost military spending and support families struggling with a declining birthrate. The government aims to double spending on efforts to reverse the decline by 2030, but has not clarified how it will fund the increased defense spending. Kishida emphasized the importance of stable US-China relations for the global economy, while Japan prepares to host G7 events. The ruling coalition is reluctant to raise the sales tax due to its economic impact.

images.alt_text: Japan household spending posts surprise gain in Nov, rises for second month

site_title: B&B Italia’s Le Bambole marks 50th year with Stella McCartney collab
summary: B&B Italia's iconic Le Bambole sofa, designed by Mario Bellini in 1972, celebrates its 50th year with a capsule collection collaboration with Stella McCartney. The pop-up at Taksu Gallery in Holland Village features an immersive display of the limited-edition collection, which includes a sofa, armchair, and ottoman, showcasing 100% biodegradable and toxin-free materials. The collection highlights Le Bambole's evolution and commitment to circular design, with the added feature of disassemblable and recyclable pieces.

images.alt_text: Alcohol not needed - the view from the Bulgari Bar is intoxicating enough

site_title: BOJ open to tweaking YCC this year if wage momentum holds: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is open to tweaking its yield curve control (YCC) policy later this year, but is unlikely to make changes at its next meeting due to concerns about sustained wage growth. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda's appointment has heightened expectations for policy changes, but the bank will wait for more evidence of wage growth before making any moves. The BOJ may consider modifying its 10-year yield target or allowance band if renewed upward pressure on Japanese government bonds makes defending the cap hard to ignore.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda has so far signalled his intent to maintain loose monetary policy conditions, despite telling parliament this week that Japan was still on course to reach the central bank’s 2 per cent core inflation target.

site_title: Nokia quarterly profit misses forecast
summary: Nokia reported a quarterly operating profit below market expectations, with a 479 million euro loss compared to 583 million euros last year. Net sales grew 10% to 5.86 billion euros, beating estimates. The company attributed the shortfall to signs of customer spending slowing down, particularly in low-margin 5G markets. Nokia's comparable gross margin fell to 37.7% from 40.7%. CEO Pekka Lundmark stated that the economic environment is impacting customer spending.

site_title: TSMC profit beats after chip demand fares better than feared
summary: TSMC's profit beat expectations, posting a net income of NT$206.9 billion for the March quarter, surpassing analyst projections. The company's chip margins held up better than anticipated, despite weak electronics demand, with PC shipments crashing 29% in the first quarter. TSMC has already cut capital spending plans for 2023, but investors remain hopeful for long-term growth driven by artificial intelligence development. However, geopolitical uncertainty and concerns over Taiwan's technological reliance on China may impact the company's outlook.

images.alt_text: Residents at a park in front of residential buildings in the Guanxin district of Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Thursday, Nov. 3, 2022. Taiwan's success in the semiconductor industry is fueling a boom in house prices that is spreading from north to south, with highly paid workers at major chipmakers pushing the property market to buck the trend of a global slowdown. Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg
The global economic slowdown has crimped consumer appetite for many products that use TSMC chips, but the company and its customers expect long-term electronics demand to continue to rise.

site_title: Watch-listed Asti says proposed EGM to remove directors invalid
summary: Asti Holdings, a semiconductor company, has deemed a proposed extraordinary general meeting (EGM) by shareholders invalid due to a lack of proper notice. The EGM aimed to remove four directors and appoint five new ones. The proposed meeting was scheduled for May 5 but did not meet the 21-day notice requirement. As a result, Asti's board of directors deemed the proposed meeting invalid, and shareholders are urged not to attend.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Asti CEO retrenched amid 'difficult period' for company
In October last year, Asti said a substantial shareholder has indicated his intention to explore a possible exit offer to other shareholders for their shares.
Michael Loh Soon Gnee (pictured) and Capital Engineering Network Public Company entered into a share purchase agreement on Feb 8.

site_title: UK watchdog to ensure savers benefit from interest rate rises
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) will begin enforcing its "consumer duty" on July 31, giving it stronger powers to ensure banks pass on interest rate increases to savers. The FCA will closely monitor firms' actions, and the consumer duty represents a step change in protecting customers' best interests. The FCA has been monitoring how firms pass through rate changes since 2021, when interest rates rose from near 0% to 4.25%. The regulator is open to revisiting measures to prevent "loyalty penalties" in cash savings markets.

images.alt_text: A logo sits on display in the headquarters of the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in the Canary Wharf business district in London, U.K., on Thursday, Nov. 21, 2013. The FCA is working with regulators including the U.S. Department of Justice and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to investigate the potential manipulation of the foreign-exchange market. site_title: End of tedium? How AI impacts the creative sector
summary: Artificial intelligence is revolutionizing the creative sector, with artists and creatives incorporating AI tools into their work for inspiration and collaboration. Notable examples include actor-playwright-director Liu Xiaoyi, who used AI tools to generate scripts for his theatre plays, and Immanuel Koh, who developed deep neural networks for generating architectural designs. However, concerns about copyright, authorship, and job redundancies persist. Despite these issues, many creatives see AI as a catalyst for new perspectives and ideas, and some, like festival director Natalie Hennedige, believe it has the potential to merge the physical and digital world in exciting ways.

The UOB-NAC  Acceleration Programme For The Arts included a hands-on video-making lesson on creating slick short videos using camera phones and CapCut free video editing tool.

site_title: American single malt whiskey, a freewheeling cousin of scotch, comes of age
summary: American single malt whiskey is gaining recognition as a distinct style, with over 200 distilleries producing it across the US. The Tax and Trade Bureau will release an official definition, allowing distilleries to experiment with various ingredients and aging methods. Unlike traditional scotch, American single malt can be aged in new or used barrels, offering more flexibility in flavor profiles. Distilleries like Tenmile in New York and Cedar Ridge in Iowa are already producing whiskeys that closely approximate single malt scotch, while others, such as Westland in Seattle, are incorporating local ingredients and flavors.

images.alt_text: Good Napa cabernet sauvignon, the Valley’s signature wine, starts around US$100 a bottle retail.

site_title: ‘I honestly didn’t think the company (Hin Leong) would go down just like that’: witness
summary: Prosecutors have charged Lim Oon Kuin, Singapore's former oil tycoon, with 130 forgery and cheating charges, with three going to trial. Former employee Serene Seng testified that Lim was a demanding boss who would often instruct her to take actions without questioning. Seng stated that Lim instructed her to submit fake invoice-financing applications to HSBC, resulting in the bank disbursing US$111.68 million to Hin Leong. Seng also testified that Lim's actions were not unexpected, given the company's financial struggles during the COVID-19 pandemic. The trial continues until July 20.

site_title: Three young entrepreneurs clinch inaugural award at Icon Ball 2023
summary: Three young entrepreneurs, Ho Ren Yung, Victor Tan, and Cynthia Handriani Wijaya, have been awarded "The Next Icon" for their sustainability efforts in family businesses. They were chosen from a shortlist of candidates under 40 years old who have worked in their family businesses for at least five years. The award aims to foster innovation, excellence, and leadership among young entrepreneurs and family businesses in the region. The winners were recognized for prioritizing sustainability as a key component of their business strategy, and their success is expected to inspire and empower the next generation of business leaders.

site_title: Ageing Singapore can stay economically vibrant by growing workforce, productivity: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore can maintain its economic vibrancy as it ages by growing its workforce and increasing productivity, said Health Minister Ong Ye Kung. The country is adapting to its aging population through workforce growth, urban planning, retirement adequacy, and healthcare reform. By 2026, Singapore will become "super aged" with 21% of the population aged 65 and above. The government is encouraging the participation of seniors, women, and foreign labor, while also promoting flexible work arrangements and mentoring programs for youths.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Economic pessimism could be a reason for Singapore’s low total fertility rate (TFR), he said, adding that studies have shown a causal link in Singapore between high home prices and low TFR, which fell to a record low of 1.05 last year.
The government will retain the transitional care facilities for the medium- or even long-term. to support hospital capacity, says Health Minister Ong Ye Kung..

site_title: Iron ore dips on growing supply, worries of more regulation
summary: Iron ore prices fell on Thursday, April 20, due to increasing supply and lower-than-expected steel output. China's state planner warned it would monitor the market and limit price hikes, while Rio Tinto reported a 15.4% jump in iron ore shipments. Brazilian miner Vale also posted a 5.8% year-on-year increase in production. As a result, Dalian iron ore futures fell 2.62% to a two-month low, and Singapore iron ore futures declined 1.5% to a three-month trough.

images.alt_text: The most-traded September iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange ended daytime trade 3.1 per cent lower at 769 yuan (S$148.29) a tonne.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands’ Q1 net revenue rises to US$848 million as casino takings hit new record
summary: Marina Bay Sands' Q1 net revenue reached US$848 million, a 112.5% increase from the same period last year. Mass gaming revenue hit a record US$549 million, driven by casino earnings. The integrated resort's recovery continues to show signs of improvement, with record-breaking gaming revenue.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Las Vegas Sands witnessed a recovery in all gaming and non-gaming segments during the first quarter.
Marina Bay Sands' net revenue contribution nearly doubles for the fourth quarter, up to US$682 million from US$368 in the same period in the year before.

site_title: London rents soar at fastest pace in more than a decade
summary: London's private rents surged 4.8% in March compared to the previous year, the fastest pace in over a decade. This increase underscores the imbalance in the rental market, with 10 prospective tenants competing for each available property. The Office for National Statistics predicts further increases across the UK over the next year, highlighting the ongoing struggle for private renters.

images.alt_text: The first three months of 2023 saw the smallest number of completed new homes since 2014, falling to 3,076.
London remains the big beast in European finance for now, with headcount vastly outnumbering the rest of Europe.

site_title: In Rakuten Bank’s downsized IPO, investors pushed for details on troubled parent, sources say
summary: Rakuten Bank's US$625 million IPO was amended after investors sought details on the risks from its exposure to its money-losing parent, Rakuten Group. Concerns about the e-commerce giant's losses and mounting debt cast a shadow on Japan's biggest IPO in over four years. Investors questioned the lead manager and other banks about risks, including transactions with other Rakuten companies. The IPO ultimately priced at 1,400 yen, valuing the bank at 238 billion yen, with demand from overseas investors exceeding 15 times oversubscribed.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on November 9, 2022 shows people walking past a mobile shop of Japanese e-commerce firm Rakuten in Tokyo. - Rakuten are expected to announce their second quarter results on November 11. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Renault revenues rise 30% in Q1 on higher sales and prices
summary: Renault reported a 30% revenue increase in Q1, driven by a 14.1% sales boost and higher prices. The carmaker's sales rebounded from four consecutive years of declines, with 535,000 units sold. Revenues reached 11.5 billion euros. Renault is betting on higher-margin and electric vehicles to boost profits, with plans to launch 12 new models in 2024. The company confirmed its 2023 targets, including a group operating margin of at least 6% and 2 billion euros in automotive operational free cash flow.

images.alt_text: Worldwide sales for the Renault brand reached 354,545 vehicles in the first three months of the year.

The move is part of Renault’s efforts to secure crucial components and seize control of the value chain of its future unit Ampere, dedicated to electric vehicles and software which it plans to list on the stock market by the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.2% to 3,318.56. Losers outnumbered gainers 52 to 36, with 19.2 million securities worth S$36.6 million changing hands. The decline follows mostly flat or lower global markets overnight.

images.alt_text: Keppel Reit's distributable income from operations falls 6.7 per cent to S$50.2 million for its first quarter, from S$53.8 million a year earlier.

site_title: Japanese firms want stability rather than change from new BOJ governor: poll
summary: Japanese firms favor stability over policy changes from new BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda, with 52% of major companies polled expressing hope for financial stability measures, and a third seeking to maintain previous policies. Ueda has signaled intent to maintain loose monetary policy conditions despite reaching the 2% core inflation target. Few companies see benefits from easing monetary policy, indicating a preference for stability over policy changes.

images.alt_text: The survey results chimed with the BOJ tankan published on April 3, which showed the big manufacturers sentiment index had worsened for a fifth consecutive quarter, hurt by elevated costs of raw and other materials, energy and mixed feed.
Tourists have been flocking back to Japan since it eased pandemic-era border controls in October.

site_title: Hasten Biopharmaceutic raises US$315 million in funding round led by CBC and Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund
summary: Hasten Biopharmaceutic has raised US$315 million in funding led by CBC Group and Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund Mubadala Investment. The pharma company, which acquired five "originator" drugs from Takeda in 2022, plans to use the funds for future acquisitions and developing a pipeline of assets. CEO Summer Xia stated the goal is to create significant commercial synergies and bring valuable healthcare solutions to patients. The funding round demonstrates the growing interest in biotech startups in Asia and the potential for long-term sustainable value in the healthcare sector.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Mirxes would be one of the rare biotech startups to go public on the Singapore bourse, amid a broader push by the government to have tech startups listed locally.

eFishery provides farmers with a dispenser that scatters pellets based on data from thousands of users.

site_title: South-east Asia deal-making slows in 2022, but energy transition sparks investor interest: Bain report
summary: Deal-making in South-east Asia slowed in 2022, with 176 private equity investment deals, a drop from 207 in 2021, and deal value falling from $27 billion to $13 billion. However, the regional energy transition is attracting investor interest, with renewable energy like solar being a bright spot. The decline is attributed to the global macro climate, including increasing interest rates and economic uncertainty, according to Bain & Company.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Global VC funding for the industry fell to US$2.4 billion in the quarter, an 80 per cent decline from its all-time high of US$12.3 billion during the same period last year, according to PitchBook.

site_title: China banks keep lending rates unchanged as economy rebounds
summary: China's commercial lenders kept benchmark lending rates unchanged, with the one-year loan prime rate at 3.65% and the five-year rate at 4.3%, for the eighth straight month. The economy is rebounding, and credit has surged, reducing the need for central bank stimulus. The central bank also reduced its cash injection into the financial system, signaling policymakers are watching the effects of past easing steps. This decision comes as profit growth at Chinese banks is under pressure due to declining loan rates, including on mortgages.

images.alt_text: China’s recovery has so far remained uneven, with consumption, services and infrastructure spending perking up but slowing prices and surging bank savings raising doubts about demand.
China's GDP is tipped to have risen 4.0 per cent in January-March from a year earlier, a Reuters poll showed, quickening from 2.9 per cent in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts rent escalation updates for assets occupied by UK government
summary: Elite Commercial Reit announced rent escalation updates for 136 UK government assets, including 133 DWP-occupied and one MOD-occupied properties. 134 assets will see rent pegged to the UK consumer price index, while two will have open-market rent reviews. The Reit expects 7 assets to see a 21.1% rent increase and 127 to see a 15.3% increase, with revised rents ranging from £1.5 million to £31.2 million per annum.

images.alt_text: Great Western House, Birkenhead, one of the 155 properties in Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio whose valuation stands at £466.2 million as at end-2022, down 9.9 per cent year on year.
The Reit's loan extension adjusts aggregate borrowing to approximately 4.2 per cent, with an improved weighted average debt maturity of 2.2 years and 60 per cent of interest rate exposure fixed.
Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands

site_title: Musk says Tesla likely to launch full self-drive technology ‘this year’
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk stated that the company is likely to launch full self-driving technology this year, despite missing previous targets to achieve the capability. Musk believes the trend is towards full autonomy, with the test version of Full Self-Driving (FSD) software being released in a "two steps forward, one step back" manner. This move is expected to generate significant profits and offset margin pressure due to aggressive price cuts.

images.alt_text: Since purchasing Twitter last year, Elon Musk has sharply reined in content moderation on the platform, allowing the return of many users who had been banned for posting tweets that incite hate or spread misinformation.
Elon Musk’s founding of a rival to OpenAI came several weeks before he joined experts in signing an open letter urging an overall hiatus in the development of AI technology.
Worldwide sales for the Renault brand reached 354,545 vehicles in the first three months of the year.

site_title: MAS sets aside S$15 million with 5-year extension of sustainable bond and loan grant schemes
summary: MAS sets aside S$15 million in grants to support companies in issuing sustainable bonds and loans, with a 5-year extension of schemes until 2028. The grants will also support transition bonds and loans, aiming to promote brown-to-green projects in the region. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of transition instruments in supporting companies to transition to green practices, and MAS will put in place safeguards to mitigate the risk of 'transition-washing'.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Sustainable credit will be key in helping to helping to provide finance to reach the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Oil falls 2% as dollar gains on potential Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Wednesday, reaching a two-week low, as the dollar strengthened on concerns about potential Federal Reserve rate hikes. Despite a decline in US crude inventories, investors were discouraged by high inflation in Europe and uneven economic data in China. The US dollar's strength is expected to curb global demand for oil, while Asian refiners continue to snap up Russian crude.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell US$1.55, or 1.8 per cent, to settle at US$84.76 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped US$1.69, or 2.1 per cent, at US$80.83 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: New Zealand inflation slows more than forecast in first quarter
summary: New Zealand's inflation slowed more than expected in the first quarter, with annual inflation at 6.7%, down from 7.2% in the previous quarter. Economists had forecast 6.9%, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand may not need to raise interest rates as aggressively. The central bank has been raising rates to tame inflation, but softer inflation numbers may not dissuade policymakers from raising rates again, potentially driving the country into recession.

images.alt_text: A cyclist rides past the city's skyline in Auckland, New Zealand. Photographer: Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg
Some economists warn that Australia is taking a risk in not moving to crush prices quicker, with inflation seen by the RBA to return to the top of its 2-3 per cent target only in mid-2025.
New Zealand had one of the hottest housing markets in the world, but new government regulations have made it harder for people to get a loan. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Foodpanda, Tada to jointly offer customer perks in Singapore and Cambodia
summary: Foodpanda and Tada Mobility have partnered to offer joint customer perks in Singapore and Cambodia, starting April 20. The partnership will allow Tada to tap into a larger community of users who frequently use ride-hailing and food delivery services. Users can enjoy discounts, free deliveries, and loyalty programs, including up to 30,000 Tada users in Singapore receiving a complimentary Foodpanda subscription and 25% discount vouchers for Pandapro subscribers. The partnership also includes free rides in Cambodia and discounted rides to SEA Games venues.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
MVL raises US$15m Series B funds to build electric vehicles in Cambodia
foodpanda to expand grocery delivery to Japan, South-east Asian frontier markets

site_title: Japan’s March export growth slows, annual trade deficit widens to record
summary: Japan's export growth slowed in March, rising 4.3% from a year earlier, marking the 25th consecutive month of increase, primarily driven by US-bound car shipments. However, imports outpaced exports, contributing to a record annual trade deficit of 21.7 trillion yen ($215 billion). The yen's depreciation boosted imports, while China-bound shipments of cars and steel declined for the fourth straight month, highlighting concerns about slowing global demand.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda has so far signalled his intent to maintain loose monetary policy conditions, despite telling parliament this week that Japan was still on course to reach the central bank’s 2 per cent core inflation target.
The number of foreign visitors for business and leisure stood at 1.82 million in March, up from 1.48 million in February, the Japan National Tourism Organisation said.

The survey results chimed with the BOJ tankan published on April 3, which showed the big manufacturers sentiment index had worsened for a fifth consecutive quarter, hurt by elevated costs of raw and other materials, energy and mixed feed.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as inflation, rates worry investors
summary: Asian markets experienced a day of fluctuation on Thursday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Manila rising, but Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington, and Taipei falling. The US economy showed little change in recent weeks, according to a Federal Reserve report, and inflation remains high, with the UK's consumer prices index rising 10% on-year. This has led investors to worry that central banks, particularly the Fed, will continue to hike interest rates to tame prices.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass an electronic board showing the numbers for the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong on December 5, 2022. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)

site_title: Seagate to pay US$300 million penalty for shipping  7 million hard drives to Huawei
summary: Seagate Technology Holdings agreed to pay a $300 million penalty for shipping over 7 million hard disk drives to Huawei in violation of US export control laws. The penalty was imposed after Seagate sold the drives to Huawei between 2020 and 2021 despite a rule restricting sales of US technology to the company. Huawei was placed on the US Entity List in 2019 due to national security and foreign policy concerns. The penalty is the largest in the history of the US Commerce Department not tied to a criminal case.

images.alt_text: President Luiz Inacio Lula Da Silva’s decision to visit Huawei followed an invitation made by the company, which has been present in Brazil for over 20 years. In 2021
Huawei has been boosting its presence in Saudi Arabia even as the US pushes allies to avoid the Chinese technology firm.

site_title: Taiwan’s Starlux pushes Airbus on deliveries as it adds long-haul routes
summary: Taiwan's Starlux Airlines, the newest full-service airline, is pushing Airbus to speed up deliveries to meet booming post-pandemic demand. Despite taking delivery of its first 18 A350s in October, Starlux expects to receive only five widebody jets next year, citing Airbus's production rate not returning to pre-pandemic levels. The airline aims to expand to long-haul routes, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, and New York, but faces delays due to Airbus's production constraints.

images.alt_text: The Iata estimates that the worldwide tab for decarbonising aviation will top US$1 trillion.
“I can’t see anything really improving or significantly improving probably until 2025 at the earliest, and it may even go beyond that," says IATA Director General Willie Walsh.

site_title: SMEs turn contractionary after eight consecutive quarters of expansion: OCBC
summary: Singapore's SME Index turned contractionary for the first quarter of 2023 after eight consecutive quarters of expansion, according to data from OCBC. The index fell to 49.9, down from 50.2 in the previous quarter, due to weaknesses in externally oriented industries such as transport and logistics. This marks the first contraction in eight quarters and suggests slowing business momentum.
