images.alt_text: Linus Goh, OCBC's head of global commercial banking, believes there is a chance that SMEs will still remain in expansionary territory for the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Asia chip makers powered by coal and gas imperil climate goals
summary: Asia's chip makers, including Samsung, are projected to increase their electricity consumption by 2030, threatening climate goals. Samsung's electricity consumption from chip production is expected to reach 55 terawatt hours, surpassing Singapore's annual consumption. None of the 13 major companies in the semiconductor industry have climate commitments aligned with the 1.5C global warming limit. Greenpeace warns that without a pivot to clean power, chip production operations will imperil the climate.

images.alt_text: The announcement was made as part of Australia’s first national electric vehicle strategy.
Environmental, protection, natural reserve, ecology
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Snap attracts 3 million paying users to AI-enhanced service
summary: Snapchat has attracted over 3 million paying users to its AI-enhanced Snapchat+ subscription service, exceeding expectations. The service, launched in June, offers early access to features like its new AI chatbot, powered by OpenAI's GPT technology. The company saw a significant boost in sign-ups in February when it added exclusive access to the chatbot, called My AI. Snapchat CEO Evan Spiegel stated that the growth was driven by the excitement around new features, with 1 million paying users added in the past 11 weeks.

images.alt_text: Snap is rebuilding its ad sales team after two key leaders left for Netflix last year.

Snap is adapting the augmented reality (AR) technology behind its popular filters and lenses  – tools that can add glittery makeup or cartoon eyes to someone’s video selfie – to help retailers use AR on their own websites and apps.

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi wins more time to explore possible sale, restructuring
summary: BlockFi, a cryptocurrency lender, has secured more time to explore a potential sale or restructuring deal to exit its Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The company plans to file a bankruptcy-exit plan by May 15. A committee of customers argued they should control the bankruptcy case to return cryptocurrency to creditors immediately, but the judge denied their request. BlockFi aims to return money to customers in a "thoughtful manner" and is working to sell its platform, described as "a bundle of sticks" by the committee.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals surpass one million in March; first time since 2020
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals surpassed one million in March for the first time since 2020, reaching 1,021,036. This marks a 7.3% increase from the previous month and a 7.8% increase from the pre-pandemic level in January 2020. Chinese tourists, in particular, saw a significant jump, with 60,888 visitors, up from 35,312 in February, and accounting for 5.9% of total arrivals. The resumption of outbound group tours and normalization of flight capacity between Singapore and China are expected to further boost arrivals.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Singapore will be the top beneficiary of China’s reopening as it is a preferred destination for high-net-worth Chinese and single Chinese women, Maybank says.
China expects inbound and outbound tourist numbers in 2023 to reach more than 90 million, recovering to 31.5 per cent of pre-pandemic levels.
Hotel occupancy rates climbed to 83.6 per cent in February, from 70.4 per cent the previous month.

site_title: Thailand air pollution leads millions to seek medical help
summary: Thailand's air pollution has led to a significant increase in hospital admissions, with 2.4 million people seeking medical treatment for air pollution-related issues since the start of the year. The most polluted cities include Bangkok and Chiang Mai, with respiratory problems, dermatitis, and eye inflammation being the most common medical issues. Health officials have urged people to take precautions such as using high-quality masks, minimizing time outside, and exercising indoors. The poor air quality has become a hot button issue ahead of Thailand's May 14 election, with the incumbent government accused of not doing enough to tackle the problem.

images.alt_text: The industries sentiment index of the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) rose to 97.8 in March from 96.2 in February, when it had returned to pre-pandemic levels.
The new wealth management unit will provide clients access to international capital markets by using BNP Paribas’ platform in Singapore.
Chedi's tasteful interiors.

Pheu Thai, linked to former premier Thaksin Shinawatra and led by his daughter Paetongtarn (above), was backed by 47 per cent of the participants in the Apr 3-7 survey by the National Institute of Development Administration, known as Nida.

Dressed in the bright Hawaiian shirt traditionally worn at the Thai New Year festival Songkran, Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha showed up unannounced at Bangkok’s famous Khaosan Road and was the instant target of throngs of revellers armed with buckets and water guns.

site_title: Prudential Singapore launches financial advisory firm offering wealth solutions, general insurance
summary: Prudential Singapore has launched Prudential Financial Advisers (PFA), offering wealth solutions and general insurance products. The firm, led by industry veteran Bernard Chai as CEO, aims to provide one-stop solutions to meet customers' needs amid rising life expectancy. PFA's services include unit trusts, travel insurance, and motor insurance, as well as estate planning and tax advisory. The launch follows regulatory approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore in December 2022, and is expected to support Singapore residents' need for financial security and healthcare at every stage of life.

images.alt_text: The new Prudential firm will provide wealth solutions and general insurance such as travel insurance and motor insurance.
The four-storey building at 51 Scotts Road where some of Prudential Singapore's agency offices are located.
Prudential, whose main business is in insurance, made a total of US$23.3 million from gross premiums in FY22, down 3.6 per cent from US$24.2 million in FY21.

site_title: Goldman Sachs hit by further departures in Asia equities
summary: Goldman Sachs has faced additional departures in its Asia equities team, including managing directors Fredrik Grunberger, Tomiyuki Oji, and David Williams, who are joining rival banks and hedge funds. These exits follow previous departures of veterans, including co-head of Greater China equities sales Alexis Tsang and chief operating officer Jig Patel, who are leaving for new roles at Nomura Holdings and Izzy Englander's hedge fund, respectively. The departures highlight Goldman's loss of veteran talent in the Asia equities business, which has made it a prime poaching ground for rivals.

images.alt_text: Goldman booked a US$470 million loss on the sale as the bank rejigs its strategy after a foray into consumer banking.
The new offering will let Apple Card users earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, more than 10 times the national average.

site_title: NFTs tied up in Three Arrows collapse to be sold by Sotheby’s
summary: Sotheby's will sell a collection of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) from the "GRAILS" collection, recovered from the failed cryptocurrency hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, to repay creditors owed over $3 billion. The NFTs, assembled by Three Arrows mostly in 2021, will be auctioned off in New York next month, with pieces including "Chromie Squiggle #1780" by Snowfro and "The Golden Goose" by Dmitri Cherniak. The sales aim to raise funds for creditors and come after liquidators have been struggling to cooperate from Three Arrows founders Su Zhu and Kyle Davies.

site_title: Ascott targets to double fee revenue to over S$500 million in next five years
summary: Ascott Limited, a lodging arm of Capitaland Investment, aims to double its fee revenue to over S$500 million in the next five years, up from S$258 million in FY2022. The company expects an 8-10% annual net room growth rate and has signed over 4,000 units in Q1. To achieve this, Ascott plans to secure more management and franchise contracts for prime properties and upgrade several properties into brand flagship assets. This growth strategy is driven by the company's strong brand equity and direct distribution channels.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Co-living operators, such as LHN's Coliwoo (above), have seen their tenant profile skew towards younger people, who enjoy having shared spaces for a community lifestyle.

The six multifamily assets comprise 428 premium one-bedroom apartments located close to the commercial districts of Umeda and Namba, and within walking distance to the nearest respective subway stations.

site_title: Lawyers seek funder for Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders’ class action
summary: Lawyers representing Singaporean bondholders who bought Credit Suisse's Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds are seeking a litigation funder to support a class-action suit against the Swiss government over the write-down of the lender's AT1 debt. If successful, the bondholders may recover 15-20% of their monies, and the funders will not have to pay for the suit. Talks are underway with third-party sponsors, but none have officially committed to funding the litigation.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Many investors in Credit Suisse's AT1 bonds apparently were not aware of the write-down clauses in the issue documents.
Credit Suisse chairman Axel Lehmann issued an apology, saying he had run out of time to turn the bank around, despite his belief “until the beginning of the fateful week” that the bank could survive.

While MUFG is hardly the only firm to get caught up in the Credit Suisse debacle, the loss tally offers one of the first glimpses into how badly clients of a major investment bank were burned by the writedown.

site_title: Workers’ Party MP Louis Chua queried on housing affordability views
summary: Workers' Party MP Louis Chua faced questioning from PAP MP Saktiandi Supaat over differing views on housing affordability. Chua had co-authored a January 2023 report stating that housing remains affordable, contrasting with his party's stance that public housing is unaffordable. Chua clarified the report was for institutional investors and highlighted an imbalance between demand and supply, while Supaat found it "odd" that Chua took differing positions.

images.alt_text: HDB housing in Toa Payoh on Feb 17, 2022.
Maybe how ABSD is levied on family members who jointly own homes here can be tweaked..

For first-timers and especially young households, BTO flats may make the most financial sense. 
First-timers should choose homes they can best afford, and BTO flats are considered the most affordable housing in today’s market.
A record number of million-dollar four-room flats were sold in March, with 39 such units changing hands.

site_title: Australia central bank to get new rate-setting board under review recommendations
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is set to adopt a new rate-setting board under the recommendations of an independent review. The review suggests creating a specialist board for monetary policy, led by the governor, with a dual mandate of price stability and full employment. The board will retain independence from government control and meet eight times a year. External members will be appointed for a term of five years and expected to discuss decisions in public. The changes are expected to commence from July 1, 2024.

images.alt_text: Some economists warn that Australia is taking a risk in not moving to crush prices quicker, with inflation seen by the RBA to return to the top of its 2-3 per cent target only in mid-2025.

The Australian central bank's decision to keep interest rates unchanged this week doesn't imply an end to its policy tightening cycle, RBA Governor Philip Lowe said, reinforcing his long-held resolve to return inflation to its 2-3 per cent target.

Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia continued to expect that the Australian economy would “slow considerably” later this year but were not currently expecting a recession at home.
Confidence is still 10.4 per cent below the level in April 2022, the month before the RBA began raising rates.

site_title: Barclays to shut 21 ETNs a year after ‘staggering’ note blunder
summary: Barclays is eliminating nearly half of its US-listed exchange-traded notes (ETNs) a year after a paperwork error cost the bank hundreds of millions of dollars. The bank will redeem 21 ETNs, including the $71 million iPath Series B Bloomberg Copper Subindex Total Return ETN, which holds $533 million in assets. The closures come after Barclays suspended issuance of new ETNs and ETNs and disrupted note prices due to the error, which was described by the Securities and Exchange Commission as "staggering."

images.alt_text: The Barclays headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Enough of the carrots, it’s time for the sticks
summary: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change warns that global warming is at 1.1°C above pre-industrial levels, leaving only a 0.4°C headroom to limit the rise to 1.5°C by the end of the 21st century. To achieve this, greenhouse gas emissions must be halved by 2030 and reach net-zero CO2 emissions by mid-century. A major mindset shift is needed to bridge the gap between climate action and inaction, emphasizing the need for holistic economic models that prioritize both human progress and planetary boundaries.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 17, 2021 A polar bear is seen on ice floes in the British Channel in the Franz Josef Land archipelago on August 16, 2021. - Earth is hotter than it has been in 125,000 years, but deadly heatwaves, storms and floods amplified by global warming could be but a foretaste as planet-heating fossil fuels put a "liveable" future at risk.o concludes the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), which has started a week-long meeting to distill six landmark reports totalling 10,000 pages prepared by more than 1,000 scientists over the last six years. (Photo by Ekaterina ANISIMOVA / AFP)

site_title: Federal Reserve to deliver 25-basis-point hike in May, stay on hold rest of year: poll
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to deliver a 25-basis-point interest rate hike in May, followed by a hold in rates for the rest of 2023, according to a Reuters poll of economists. Nearly 90% of the poll participants predicted the rate hike, with only 26 expecting a cut. Inflation remains above the Fed's 2% target, and the labor market continues to show strength, leading to higher interest rates. A recession is forecasted with a 70% probability in the coming two years, with most economists expecting a short and shallow recession.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Keppel Corp, Nanofilm, Oiltek, USP Group
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 6.7% decline in distributable income to S$50.2 million for its first quarter, down from S$53.8 million a year earlier. Keppel Corporation partnered with ExxonMobil Asia Pacific to explore low-carbon hydrogen and ammonia solutions. Nanofilm Technologies saw a 40% fall in revenue to S$33 million for the same period, while Oiltek International won new contracts worth S$17.1 million in Indonesia and Malaysia. USP Group's extraordinary general meeting was ruled invalid due to a lack of qualifying shareholders.

site_title: Vivendi set to win EU green light for Lagardere deal, sources say
summary: Vivendi, controlled by billionaire Vincent Bollore, is set to receive EU antitrust approval to acquire Lagardere after addressing competition concerns. The European Commission has accepted Vivendi's offer to sell its publishing division Editis and celebrity magazine Gala, which will alleviate regulatory worries about the deal. The proposed acquisition, announced last year, would give Vivendi control of Lagardere's flagship weekly publications Journal du Dimanche and Paris Match. The EU's decision is scheduled for June 14.

site_title: Europe’s new energy map
summary: Europe's energy map is transforming due to the war in Ukraine, with the continent increasingly purchasing liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Norway, Qatar, and the US, and natural gas from North African and Central Asian producers. Russia, once the key supplier, is no longer the dominant player. The shift is expected to benefit the Middle East, allowing it to reclaim its market position. The change in Europe's oil and gas imports is a result of EU bans on Russian crude and petroleum products. The natural gas market is more regionally fragmented, making it harder to integrate globally.

images.alt_text: While gas prices in Europe and Asia have plummeted from last year’s highs, they’re still well above the average of the last 10 years, signalling possible concern that the current glut could disappear.
A tanker in front of a fuel depot of Aral at the Ruhr Oel petroleum refineries of BP Gelsenkirchen GmbH in Gelsenkirchen, western Germany in March.  (PHOTO:  Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)

site_title: Australian competition watchdog blocks Qantas’ acquisition of Alliance Aviation
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has blocked Qantas' A$610.8 million acquisition of Alliance Aviation Services, citing that the integration would substantially lessen competition in the charter services sector in Queensland and Western Australia. The decision was made after a much-delayed review, causing Alliance's shares to fall 9.1% and Qantas shares to rise 0.9%. The ACCC's decision aims to maintain competition in the charter services sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Qantas aircraft are seen on the tarmac at Melbourne International Airport in Melbourne, Australia, November 6, 2018. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
SAF is a biofuel used to power aircraft that has similar properties to conventional jet fuel without the need to develop new planes or engines.
Qantas has orders and purchase rights for as many as 299 narrow-body and 12 wide-body aircraft for delivery over the next decade.
Sydney-based Qantas also announced a stock buyback of as much as A$500 million, adding to a A$400 million programme announced in August.

site_title: Microsoft removes Twitter from ad programme; Musk threatens suit
summary: Microsoft is removing Twitter from its ad program due to Twitter's decision to charge for access to its programming interface. Elon Musk, who owns Twitter, responded by accusing Microsoft of using Twitter data "illegally" and threatening a lawsuit. This move affects Microsoft's Smart Campaigns service, which helps advertisers manage social media campaigns on services like Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn. The change will take effect on April 25, and users will no longer be able to create tweets and drafts or view past tweets and engagement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Twitter logo and a photo of Elon Musk are displayed through magnifier in this illustration taken October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: HSBC urges shareholders to vote against proposed split
summary: HSBC has urged shareholders to vote against a proposal by its largest stakeholder, Ping An, to split the business. The bank's board believes that focusing on its current strategy will deliver more value for shareholders in the coming years. HSBC argues that the bank's recent performance improvement is due to rising interest rates, which have now peaked, and that a split would be a risk. The proposal is set to be voted on at the bank's annual general meeting on May 5.

images.alt_text: HSBC should separate its Asia business into a Hong Kong-listed entity, Ping An said, in an update to proposals it began urging last November calling for the bank to spin off its Asia business.
OK Lim, founder of collapsed Hin Leong empire, appears in State Courts for the third day of hearing on cheating and forgery charges levelled against him by Singapore prosecutors
FILE PHOTO: The company logo of Ping An Insurance is seen in Beijing, China, August 27, 2020. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: North Seas energy group shows Europe’s growing multipolarity
summary: The European Union is navigating a complex, multipolar Europe following Brexit, with the North Seas Energy Cooperation and the European Political Community emerging as new organizations. The cooperation aims to facilitate the cost-effective deployment of offshore renewable energy and promote interconnection between member states for a sustainable energy supply. France's President Emmanuel Macron advocates for a "continental partnership" that allows countries to deliver European core values without EU membership. The UK's relations with the EU are evolving, with the possibility of warmer ties with the EU potentially leading to future reform of the EU's institutional architecture.

images.alt_text: Solar panels being installed on a roof in France. The EU risks being outpaced in areas such as clean technology, recent studies have warned.
With the inclusion of 17 non-European Union (EU) members, the new European Political Community could serve as a bridge to a larger EU and a framework for more permanent continental integration.
hands, world, map

site_title: Instagram will cut or relocate its London staff
summary: Meta Platforms plans to cut or relocate its London-based Instagram employees, with around 100 staff members at risk. The move comes as part of a broader efficiency campaign, with the company having already announced plans to eliminate 10,000 positions. Instagram's London office, which opened in 2013, will be affected, with some employees set to be laid off or relocated to the US. The decision is part of a required consultation period with the UK government before a final decision is made.

site_title: List of SGX’s suspended stocks keeps growing; few companies can resolve issues or make exit offers
summary: The number of suspended stocks listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has increased, with nearly 10% of 630 companies suspended, or 61 stocks, as of March. Trading suspensions may persist for a prolonged period, and companies may be directed to delist if they fail to meet conditions or make a cash exit offer. In contrast, other jurisdictions such as Bursa Malaysia and the US have different frameworks for dealing with suspended companies, with some allowing for a maximum duration of trading suspension.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

A trading suspension is a good way for companies to avoid a plunge in their share prices as they iron out problems, whether solvency issues or regulatory investigations, but this comes at the cost of investors.

site_title: Keppel, ExxonMobil to collaborate on low-carbon energy solutions in Singapore
summary: Keppel Corporation and ExxonMobil Asia-Pacific have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop low-carbon hydrogen and ammonia solutions for Singapore's commercial and industrial applications. The partnership aims to support the government's national strategy to meet up to half of Singapore's power needs with hydrogen by 2050. Keppel plans to use low-carbon hydrogen for Singapore's first hydrogen-ready power plant on Jurong Island, currently under construction, and is also conducting a feasibility study on using ammonia as a fuel. The collaboration is expected to provide critical, scalable solutions to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

images.alt_text: Decarbonising the power sector is key in the city state’s race to net zero by 2050 as the sector currently contributes about 40 per cent of Singapore’s total carbon emissions.

site_title: IBM sees modest annual sales growth on strong second half
summary: IBM reported modest annual sales growth, increasing from 3% to 5% in 2023, meeting analysts' projections. The company affirmed a free cash flow forecast of $10.5 billion for the year. IBM's software business, including Red Hat, drove growth, while consulting sales also increased. The company is reorienting around higher-margin services like hybrid cloud computing and expects to achieve $2 billion in annual savings by 2024.

images.alt_text: IBM announced the purchase in October 2015 for an undisclosed amount as part of an effort to extend its move into the then-hot Internet of Things market.
IBM’s current headcount is 260,000.

site_title: Tesla misses estimates as price cuts squeeze profit margins
summary: Tesla missed first-quarter profit estimates, with revenue rising 24% to $23.33 billion but profit excluding items falling to 85 cents a share, below estimates. The company attributed the decline to price cuts and rising inventory, with operating margins falling to 11.4% from 16% last quarter. Tesla's shares slid 4.5% in late trading, despite the company's guidance that output will meet previous growth targets and deliver 1.8 million vehicles this year.

images.alt_text: Tesla also recently lowered prices in Europe, Israel and Singapore as well as in Japan, Australia and South Korea.

Tesla is expected to report auto gross margin of 23.2 per cent for the quarter, according to 17 analysts polled by Visible Alpha, down from a record 32.9 per cent a year earlier and the lowest since the fourth quarter of 2019.
Tesla cut prices on Real-Wheel Drive version of both Model 3 and Model Y by S$4,000 (US$3,020), and Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive version of the two models by S$5,000, the website showed.

site_title: International Investment Bank to relocate headquarters from Budapest back to Russia
summary: Russia's International Investment Bank (IIB) is relocating its headquarters from Budapest back to Russia, citing exhaustion of operations in the European Union. The move comes after the US imposed sanctions on IIB officials in Budapest, leading Hungary to withdraw its representatives and quit the bank. The relocation is seen as a result of Hungary's close ties with Russia, particularly under Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who has avoided criticizing Russian President Vladimir Putin. The IIB's relocation marks a significant shift in the bank's operations and its ties with the EU.

site_title: Gold ticks higher as dollar eases; central bank rate moves in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,995.54 per ounce, as the US dollar eased, making the precious metal less expensive for overseas buyers. The dollar index fell, and investors awaited central bank rate decisions to contain inflation. The US central bank is expected to raise interest rates in May, potentially dimming gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also saw changes, with silver and platinum increasing and palladium decreasing.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, but higher interest rates dim the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Long tethered to Apple, Chinese suppliers seek new options
summary: Chinese component suppliers, including Luxshare Precision Industry and GoerTek, are diversifying their businesses away from Apple, the US tech giant, due to a weakening electronics market and rising labor costs. The suppliers, which have long relied on Apple for a significant portion of their revenue, are exploring options to expand into new markets, such as the automotive and telecom sectors. Analysts predict that Apple will continue to rely heavily on China for its supply chain, but some suppliers, like GoerTek, are already investing in new production lines in India and Vietnam. Despite the challenges, some Chinese suppliers are optimistic about their ability to adapt to the changing market and remain competitive.

images.alt_text: Apple CEO Tim Cook and Deirdre O'Brien, Apple's senior vice president of Retail and People greet people at the inauguration of India's first Apple retail store in Mumbai, India, April 18, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
The roughly US$3,000 headset is set to debut at an event in June, with the product going on sale months later.
This week, Apple introduced a new product with Goldman Sachs Group that will allow Apple Card holders to earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, with no fees or minimum deposit requirements.

site_title: US lending slowed last month on banking concerns: Federal Reserve
summary: US lending slowed in recent weeks due to financial sector troubles sparked by Silicon Valley Bank's collapse on March 10. The Federal Reserve reported that lending volumes and loan demand declined across consumer and business loan types, with banks tightening lending standards amid increased uncertainty and concerns about liquidity. The conditions in New York's financial sector deteriorated sharply, but regulators' swift action to stem bank deposit outflows appears to have paid off, with markets operating with less volatility. Overall economic activity remained little changed.

images.alt_text: A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. Deutsche Bank vowed to increase profit and revenue further this year, after snapping a long streak of market share gains in trading in the final quarter of Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing's turnaround plan. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: The Nasdaq logo is displayed at the Nasdaq Market site in Times Square in New York City, U.S., December 3, 2021. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 13 basis points, abruptly ending a five-week slide in borrowing costs, Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data showed on Wednesday (Apr 19).

“Our outlook envisions that the acute financial stresses, which last month triggered pressures on both sides of the Atlantic, will continue to recede,” Citi economists led by Nathan Sheets said in a note.
Results from Morgan Stanley round out a choppy reporting season for Wall Street’s biggest banks.

site_title: Does indefinite suspension of a stock help or hurt shareholders?
summary: A significant number of Singapore-listed companies (61 out of 630) have been suspended from trading due to various issues, with some lasting years or even decades. The current listing rules allow for prolonged periods, leaving investors in limbo. In contrast, other exchanges such as Bursa Malaysia and Hong Kong have implemented stricter rules with limited suspension periods. Implementing a fixed-cure period could incentivize companies to resolve issues more quickly and provide better protection for investors.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Best World International is set to resume trading on the Singapore Exchange on Monday Nov, 14 after being suspended for 3.5 years
The beauty products distributor said it audit committee is of the opinion that concerns raised on the legality of its sales and distribution business model in China have been satisfied.
Shares of Boustead Projects were last trading at S$0.955 on Mar 27.

SGX Regco told Boustead Projects that it must restore its free float after its shares are suspended at the close of the takeover offer. Otherwise, Boustead Projects would be directed to delist and provide an exit offer which is deemed fair and reasonable.
Boustead Projects must restore free float, or make ‘fair and reasonable’ exit offer: SGX Regco

Boustead Projects said that it was already set out in the independent financial advisor’s letter that shareholders who do not accept the offer will hold shares in the company which may be suspended from trading on the SGX-ST.

site_title: US imposes sanctions on network supporting Iran’s drone, military programmes
summary: The US imposed sanctions on a procurement network supporting Iran's drone and military programmes, targeting companies in China, Iran, and elsewhere. The network, led by Iran's Pardazan System Namad Arman (Pasna), has procured goods and technology for the Iranian government and its defence industry. The US Treasury Department aims to increase pressure on Tehran, enforcing sanctions against military procurement efforts contributing to regional insecurity and global instability.

site_title: Oiltek unit wins RM56.8 million of contracts in Indonesia and Malaysia
summary: Oiltek International's wholly-owned subsidiary has won RM56.8 million (S$17.1 million) in contracts in Indonesia and Malaysia for its edible and non-edible oil refinery and renewable energy segments. The contracts involve the design and construction of new plants, including a crude palm oil pretreatment plant, biodiesel plant, and shortening plant. This brings the company's cumulative contract value for the year to RM157.8 million, accounting for 80.5% of its RM196.1 million contract value for the previous year.

images.alt_text: Oiltek, however, said it is unable to provide a definitive assessment on the financial impact of carrying out the rectification works on the group.
Oiltek cheif executive Henry Yong says that the current order book is one of the highest the group has seen.
Oiltek will assess if the fire incident will have any material financial impact on its results for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: India races to get rich before it gets old as population passes China
summary: India has surpassed China as the country with the largest population, with an estimated 1.428 billion people. To capitalize on its demographic dividend, India needs to advance on four fronts: urbanization, infrastructure, education, and manufacturing. The country must boost its urban population, invest in infrastructure, improve education, and increase manufacturing to become a global growth driver. India's population is expected to reach 1.67 billion by 2050, but may start declining in 2047. With a growing population and a young workforce, India is optimistic about its future, but faces significant challenges to achieve its growth goals.

images.alt_text: Despite India’s billion-plus population, food-delivery company Zomato has just 50 million annual transacting users and state-backed digital money transfer service UPI is used by just 260 million.
An overhaul of the six-decade-old income tax law was first proposed under Modi’s predecessor in 2009 but successive governments have failed to complete it.

In this photograph taken on April 16, 2023, people gather to attend an award ceremony on the outskirts of Mumbai. - Heatstroke killed 11 people in India after an estimated million spectators waited for hours in the sun at a government-sponsored awards ceremony, officials said as early summer temperatures soared. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: US builders are winning as search-weary buyers rush to new homes
summary: US homebuyers, driven by sharply higher interest rates, are flocking to builders' sales offices, where discounts and rate buy-downs are making new homes cheaper than pre-owned properties. This shift has given builders a welcome boost, with new-home sales increasing 5.6% and inventory reaching record levels. Builders, who previously increased prices during the pandemic, are now offering incentives to lure buyers, with some scaling back on perks as demand stabilizes. The trend is expected to continue, with some builders increasing construction starts and others scaling back on discounts.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 13 basis points, abruptly ending a five-week slide in borrowing costs, Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data showed on Wednesday (Apr 19).

site_title: Las Vegas Sands leads casinos higher on signs of Macau recovery
summary: Las Vegas Sands reported a robust recovery in travel and tourism spending in Macau, with positive adjusted property earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation at all Macau locations for the first time since 2019. The company's adjusted property Ebitda rose over sevenfold to $792 million, outperforming peers such as Wynn Resorts and MGM Resorts International. Sands' CEO Robert Goldstein stated that the recovery is underway, benefiting the company more than its peers due to its 38% market share in Macau. This led to a surge in shares for casino operators with Macau locations.

site_title: The costly cyber breaches to come
summary: High-profile cyber breaches continue to occur despite growing awareness of their consequences. Most incidents are avoidable due to negligence, poor access control, and a lack of actionable knowledge. In 2022, a simple phishing campaign affected over 130 organizations, including Coinbase, Twilio, and Cloudflare. The year ahead will see a rise in ransomware attacks, with the average price of access to corporate networks decreasing. Employees will be a key factor in mitigating cyber risks, with phishing frameworks and remote access tools being used to infiltrate companies.

images.alt_text: Cybersecurity, hackers, attacks, networks, concept. Credit: Pixabay

site_title: US: Markets flat as investors mull corporate earnings
summary: US stocks closed mostly flat on Wednesday following mixed company results, including Morgan Stanley's decline in profits and Netflix's drop in stock price. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.2% at 33,897.34, while the S&P 500 remained almost unchanged at 4,154.54. Analysts attributed the flat markets to "pretty mixed" earnings results, with US regional banking stocks expected to be a key focus next week.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Shares end marginally lower as ASML weighs on tech stocks
summary: European stocks closed 0.1% lower on Wednesday, hovering around 14-month highs, due to a warning from ASML weighing down technology stocks. Hawkish comments from the European Central Bank and Goldman Sachs also contributed to the decline. Tech stocks fell 1.9%, with ASML's 3.7% drop, while the European insurance sector rose 1.1%. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 index remains near its highs, and analysts expect improving profit margins in the earnings season.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.2 per cent at 33,897.34, while the broad-based S&P 500 was almost unchanged at 4,154.54 on Wednesday.

site_title: Airlines will hike ticket prices to pay for costly sustainable fuel: Iata
summary: Airlines will increase ticket prices to pay for sustainable aviation fuel, with the International Air Transport Association (Iata) estimating a $1 trillion cost for decarbonizing aviation by 2050. The fuel, which accounts for 65% of needed emissions reduction, is currently too expensive to produce, with prices potentially driving up ticket prices by 22% by 2050. While governments can use incentives to stimulate production, the Iata's director-general, Willie Walsh, suggests consumers will ultimately bear the cost.

images.alt_text: “I can’t see anything really improving or significantly improving probably until 2025 at the earliest, and it may even go beyond that," says IATA Director General Willie Walsh.

A member of the ground crew is seen on the tarmac next to a passenger jet from Japanese carrier All Nippon Airways (ANA) at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda on February 2, 2023. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Apple takes bigger bite out of India with new retail stores, expanded iPhone production
summary: Apple has expanded its presence in India with the opening of two retail stores in Mumbai and New Delhi, marking the company's 25th year in the country. CEO Tim Cook is betting big on India, citing the country's growing middle class and favorable business environment. Apple aims to increase production in India, potentially producing millions of devices, including iPhones, and is committed to contributing 60% of exports under the production-linked incentive scheme for mobile devices. This move is seen as a strategic shift away from China and a boost to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" initiative.

images.alt_text: The roughly US$3,000 headset is set to debut at an event in June, with the product going on sale months later.
This week, Apple introduced a new product with Goldman Sachs Group that will allow Apple Card holders to earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, with no fees or minimum deposit requirements.
People queue outside India's first Apple store before its opening in Mumbai on April 18, 2023.

site_title: German authors, performers call for tougher ChatGPT rules amid copyright concerns
summary: German authors and performers have urged the European Union to strengthen AI regulations, citing concerns over copyright infringement from generative AI like ChatGPT. The letter, signed by 42 associations and trade unions representing 140,000 creators, calls for liability for AI providers and stricter rules to address accountability and remuneration. The European Commission is set to finalize AI rules, which should include regulation of foundation models and central platform services. The groups aim to prevent irreversible harm from unauthorized AI usage and ensure creators' rights are protected.

site_title: L’Oreal posts sales gain that outpaces analysts’ estimates
summary: L'Oreal reported a sales gain of nearly 15% in the first quarter, surpassing analysts' estimates of 9.5%. Like-for-like sales rose 13% and Active Cosmetics surged 31%, with growth in Europe and Latin America exceeding expectations. The company attributes the growth to its consumer-products investment and a strong global footprint. Despite China's economic reopening, L'Oreal's performance remains robust, with the CEO attributing it to the company's "balanced multipolar model".

images.alt_text: The transaction, which is expected to close in the third quarter, caps months of negotiations for the asset.

site_title: Deutsche Bank mulls shrinking executive board in cost drive
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering reducing its executive board from 10 to 9 members to support cost-cutting efforts. The decision comes as the bank aims to reduce expenses by 2 billion euros by 2025, including through job cuts and office space reduction. The bank's CEO, Christian Sewing, has struggled to meet his cost-cutting goals due to inflation and talent competition. A smaller board may be appointed if President Karl von Rohr's successor is chosen before his departure at the end of October. The decision is expected to be made next week.

images.alt_text: Bank sees room to expand its deals business in Asia and is looking to hire selectively, the lender’s regional head of investment banking said in November.

site_title: K-pop star Moonbin dead at 25: music label
summary: K-pop star Moonbin, a 25-year-old member of the boy band Astro, has died in his Seoul apartment, according to his music label Fantagio. The cause of death was not provided. Moonbin was a trainee at Fantagio since an early age and debuted with Astro in 2016. His death is the latest in a string of young K-pop stars to die, including Goo Hara and Jonghyun, who died by suspected suicides in recent years.

images.alt_text: Kōki, wears an oversized sweater, skirt by Kenzo, and a Serpenti Tubogas single spiral watch by Bulgari.
Jamal released about 80 albums, won myriad awards over the course of his career, including France’s prestigious Ordre des Arts and des Lettres in 2007 and a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 2017.
Cast and crew members take a moment after their final performance of the "Phantom of the Opera", which closes after 35 years on Broadway, New York City, April 16, 2023.

site_title: Singapore should avoid further GST hike, as high costs hurt competitiveness: Louis Chua
summary: Singapore's Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike may hurt the country's competitiveness due to high costs, warned Workers' Party MP Louis Chua. He cited stagnant wage growth, rising inflation, and a lack of social protection as concerns. Chua urged the government to avoid further inflationary pressure, particularly if wage growth remains uneven. He also called for legislation to protect job security and address housing affordability issues.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Economic pessimism could be a reason for Singapore’s low total fertility rate (TFR), he said, adding that studies have shown a causal link in Singapore between high home prices and low TFR, which fell to a record low of 1.05 last year.

Workers' Party Member of Parliament Jamus Lim called for a committee comprising government representatives, civil society leaders and academic experts to be set up to decide what the poverty line should be.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on mixed earnings, rising yields
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, April 19, 2023, as Treasury yields rose due to expectations of the Federal Reserve keeping interest rates higher. The S&P 500 fell 0.37%, the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.74%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.26%. The decline was also influenced by mixed earnings from regional banks and weakness in Tesla.

site_title: Spotify back up for most users after global outage
summary: Spotify experienced a global outage affecting tens of thousands of users, with over 20,000 incidents reported in the US and 8,000 in the UK. The company apologized and confirmed the issue had been resolved, stating "Everything's looking much better now!" The outage occurred after two short outages earlier this year, with Downdetector tracking the disruptions.

site_title: Citigroup hikes 2023 global growth forecast, sees US recession only in Q4
summary: Citigroup has raised its 2023 global growth forecast to 2.4% due to solid performances in the US, euro area, and China. The US recession is now expected to occur in the fourth quarter, down from the third quarter previously predicted. Citi economists attribute the revised forecast to decreasing financial stresses, citing a continued recovery.

images.alt_text: China’s economy grew at a faster-than-expected rate in the first quarter, official data showed on Tuesday (Apr 18).

site_title: OrangeTee & Tie fined S$37,000 for data breach affecting over 250,000 customers, staff
summary: OrangeTee & Tie, a real estate firm, has been fined S$37,000 by the Personal Data Protection Commission for breaching its obligation to protect personal data. The firm failed to sufficiently assess security risks and conduct periodic security reviews, resulting in the compromise of over 250,000 customers', employees', and agents' information, which was stolen by hacking group Altdos in August 2021.

images.alt_text: Carousell logo at the office on July 1, 2021. Carousell is holding its first Caroupreneur Awards, which recognise outstanding achievements of Carousell users over the past year.
The Asia Pacific co-location data centre market is projected to be worth US$28 billion by 2024, surpassing North America to become the largest worldwide over the next decade.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate climbs by most in two months to 6.43%
summary: US mortgage rates increased to 6.43% last week, the highest in two months, due to the Federal Reserve's efforts to tame inflation. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate rose 13 basis points, ending a five-week slide in borrowing costs. Mortgage applications for home purchases dropped 10% in the week ended Apr 14, with the index of refinancing applications also declining to its lowest level since early March, further straining the housing market. It's unclear when the market will regain momentum, with high borrowing costs discouraging buyers and sellers.

site_title: Bitcoin drops below US$30,000 again on interest rate fears
summary: Bitcoin dropped below the US$30,000 level, falling as much as 4.5% amid fears of higher interest rates due to stubbornly high UK inflation. The largest token traded at US$29,175, with other cryptocurrencies also experiencing declines. Despite this, experts say the recent interest-rate jitters are unlikely to derail this year's crypto rally, citing positive funding rates and continued allocation to Bitcoin by hedge funds.

images.alt_text: The power-hungry companies that pump new bitcoin into circulation have been thrown a lifeline by the cryptocurrency’s rally to above US$30,000 this year.

site_title: Nanofilm posts 40% fall in Q1 revenue on cyclical reasons, slow China reopening
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a Singapore-based advanced materials and coatings company, reported a 40% fall in Q1 revenue to S$33 million due to cyclical reasons and China's slow recovery since its reopening. The company's advanced materials business unit saw softer demand, while its nanofabrication business unit was impacted by end-consumer demand. Despite the challenges, Nanofilm expects a brighter outlook for the second half of the year, with customer activity and post-China recovery presenting opportunities.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.##########banks##########CHONG JUN LIANG
Venture helps companies design and produce high-tech products. Its margins have been consistently been around 10 per cent in the last five years.
Nanofilm CEO Gary Ho urges investors to take the long view.

site_title: China’s Huayou seeks to build nickel ore processing plant in Philippines: sources
summary: China's Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt is in exploratory talks to build a nickel ore processing plant in the Philippines in partnership with a local nickel ore producer. The move aims to boost the Philippines' value-added exports and follows similar deals signed in Indonesia. Huayou has already signed agreements to build high-pressure acid leach (HPAL) plants in Indonesia. The Philippines seeks to increase domestic processing of nickel ore used in stainless steel and electric vehicle batteries.

site_title: Abbott beats profit estimates on strong medical device sales
summary: Abbott Laboratories reported a quarterly profit above expectations, driven by strong sales of its diabetes care devices and an increase in demand for other medical devices. Sales of medical devices grew 8.5% to $3.90 billion, with glucose monitoring device Freestyle Libre generating $1.2 billion in revenue. The company retained its adjusted profit forecast for the year, citing growth in non-Covid-testing-related revenue to offset declining testing kit sales.

site_title: Silicon Valley 5G chip startup EdgeQ raises US$75 million to boost production
summary: EdgeQ, a Silicon Valley startup, raised US$75 million to boost production of 5G chip technology. The company, which powers base stations and access points for 5G telecom towers and robots, aims to sell its technology to customers. CEO Vinay Ravuri attributed the funding to the cost-effective design of its new 5G chip, which has reduced base station costs by 50% compared to existing options. EdgeQ has a valuation of "hundreds of millions of US dollars" and has gained attention from investors despite the current funding drought.

images.alt_text: Vinay Ravuri, CEO and co-founder of Silicon Valley 5G chip startup EdgeQ shows the company product, in Santa Clara, California, U.S., January 23, 2023. REUTERS/Jane Lanhee Lee

site_title: Switzerland reiterates UBS-Credit Suisse takeover is a done deal
summary: The Swiss government has reaffirmed that state guarantees for the UBS-Credit Suisse takeover are binding, despite parliament's rejection. The guarantees, worth 109 billion Swiss francs (S$162.1 billion), were made to ensure the takeover's completion and stabilize the financial system. The government stated that the guarantees would not be affected by the parliament's rejection, citing a legal opinion that a rejection would have no effect on the Confederation's emergency commitments.

site_title: Court rules USP’s Apr 21 EGM need not proceed, but raps firm for disrupting democratic process
summary: A Singapore court has ruled that USP Group's April 21 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) need not proceed, but has criticized the firm for attempting to disrupt the democratic process. Judicial Commissioner Goh Yihan declared the requisition notice invalid due to the requisitioning shareholders not being recognized as "members" under the Companies Act. The court also stated that USP's actions were "unacceptable" and that the company's CEO, Tanoto Sau Ian, had no basis for bringing an injunction against the requisitioning shareholders.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Minority shareholders of watch-listed USP Group are looking to take the company out of the watchlist by gaining control of its board and injecting it with new projects.

If USP Group does not appoint auditors for an audit of its most recent financial year, release the statements, and either move to exit the watch-list or seek an extension of its cure period, the SGX RegCo will direct it to delist.
Recent boardroom tussles involving SGX-listed companies have seen varying degrees of success for requisitioning parties, and not all cases are straightforward.

site_title: Singapore stocks buck downtrend in Asian markets; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, bucking the downtrend in most Asian markets, as the Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,324.05. The rally was driven by positive sentiment, despite a price war in China's electric car market affecting Nio's share price, which fell 5.8% to US$9.21. The poor performance in the US and Europe was attributed to uncertainty over interest rates and tariffs.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Losers outnumber gainers 59 to 44, after 53 million securities worth S$46.1 million change hands.
In the first quarter of 2023, Sabana Industrial Reit's aggregate leverage ratio has increased to 33.1 per cent, and its weighted average fixed-debt expiry has fallen to 1.8 years.
The Stoxx 600 index ended 0.4 per cent higher on Tuesday, holding at more than one-year highs.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down less than 0.1 per cent to 33,976.63 on Tuesday.

site_title: Ho Chi Minh City feels pressure to reduce drag on Vietnam’s 2023 growth target
summary: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam's largest city and economic hub, faces pressure to boost economic growth in the second half of 2023 after a weaker-than-expected expansion in the first quarter, with a 0.7% growth rate, the lowest among Vietnam's five municipal cities. The city's first-quarter showing was lower than the national average, ranking 56th out of 63 cities and provinces.

site_title: Nasdaq profit beats expectations, helped by anti-financial crime unit
summary: Nasdaq reported first-quarter profits that beat Wall Street estimates, driven by demand for its anti-financial crime software and a significant milestone in signing its first big Tier 1 bank with over $1 trillion in assets. Revenue from the anti-financial crime unit jumped 17% to $84 million, while net trading services revenues rose 1% to $267 million. However, revenue from indexes slumped 9.8% to $110 million. Excluding one-time items, Nasdaq earned 69 cents per share, three cents above analysts' mean estimate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Nasdaq logo is displayed at the Nasdaq Market site in Times Square in New York City, U.S., December 3, 2021. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia’s exports decline 1.4% in March, first contraction in 31 months
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 1.4% in March, marking the first contraction in 31 months, due to lower shipments of electrical and electronic products. The trade surplus expanded 36% to RM26.7 billion, while imports dropped 1.8% year on year to RM103 billion. Economists attribute the decline to a higher base, dimmed economic outlook, and global tech downcycle, with projected growth of 1.5% for 2023.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's total trade rose 11 per cent year on year to RM205 billion, while trade surplus decreased 1.3 per cent to RM19.6 billion.

site_title: Airline capacity constrained until 2025 due to delivery delays, spare parts: IATA
summary: IATA Director General Willie Walsh warns that global airline capacity will be lower than expected this year and remain constrained until 2025 due to aircraft delivery delays and spare parts shortages. Airlines expect travel demand to recover to 2019 levels, but the lack of planes to meet demand could slow growth. Capacity reductions are expected to be in the low single digits range, with Ryanair trimming its July schedule due to Boeing 737 MAX delays. Walsh does not expect airport chaos this summer, citing airlines' efforts to adjust capacity.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific carriers are the hardest hit in terms of air cargo volumes in November 2022.

site_title: Arts and AI
summary: A Berlin-based digital creator, Julian van Dieken, used artificial intelligence to recreate Johannes Vermeer's famous painting "Girl with a Pearl Earring" and displayed it at the Mauritshuis museum in The Hague. This move highlights the increasing use of AI in the arts, following Singaporean creatives who have been using the technology for years. The development marks a significant step forward in the application of AI in art, potentially challenging authorship rights and raising questions about the role of human creativity in the creative process.

site_title: UAE property developer Damac sells US$400 million Islamic bond
summary: Damac, a Dubai-based real estate developer, sold a $400 million Islamic bond, or sukuk, at a 7.75% interest rate, exceeding initial guidance. The sale was part of a strong rebound in Dubai's real estate sector, driven by a property boom post-COVID-19 and Russia's war in Ukraine. The proceeds will be used to fund land acquisitions, maintain debt, and continue relationships with investors. This sale marks a test of appetite for corporate debt issues in the private sector, amidst a resurgence in debt capital markets in the Gulf region.

images.alt_text: UAE opens citizenship to select foreigners to boost economy

site_title: Mitsubishi Power starts natgas turbine operation in Rayong, Thailand
summary: Mitsubishi Power has started operations of a natural gas turbine at a gas-fired power plant project in Thailand's Rayong province. The turbine is the fifth of eight delivered under a 5,300-megawatt contract secured in 2018. The plant, owned and operated by Gulf PD Company, will sell electricity to the state-owned Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand for 25 years. The move marks the successful completion of a full turnkey project, demonstrating Mitsubishi Power's capabilities in the region.

site_title: Alibaba’s grocery arm gears up for Hong Kong IPO
summary: Freshippo, Alibaba's grocery arm, is preparing for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO). The company is working with banks to prepare for the IPO, which may happen next year or later, and is considering a valuation of US$10 billion. Freshippo offers a Sam's Club-like supermarket experience and has turned profitable with its grocery brand Hema Xiansheng. The IPO is part of Alibaba's plan to split its US$250 billion business into six main units, following a surprise announcement last month.

images.alt_text: Alibaba's grocery chain Freshippo considers funding at US$10b value

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit beats estimates on wealth business strength
summary: Morgan Stanley's first-quarter profit beat estimates, driven by a 11% increase in revenue from its wealth management division to $110 billion in net new assets. However, the investment banking unit saw a 24% decline in revenue to $1.25 billion. Despite the beat, Morgan Stanley's shares fell over 2% in premarket trading. The result rounds out a choppy reporting season for Wall Street's biggest banks.

site_title: TikTok could get a lifeline from big tech as a US ban looms
summary: US tech companies are pushing to narrow a proposed legislation that could ban TikTok, citing concerns about national security reviews of even minor pieces of hardware or code. The Information Technology Industry Council, representing companies like IBM, Microsoft, and Apple, is lobbying to limit the bill's scope. This may close the door on a national security review of TikTok, which the Biden administration had aimed to complete. The bill's passage could expose US tech companies to scrutiny over Chinese technology in their systems.

images.alt_text: While calm and eloquent, it appeared that TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi could not sway hostile US lawmakers.

site_title: En bloc sale of Excelsior Hotel and Shopping Complex moves to private talks
summary: The en bloc sale of Excelsior Hotel and Shopping Complex has transitioned to private talks with interested parties. The development, located at 5 Coleman Street, was initially put up for sale at a reserve price of S$458 million on February 28. The sole marketing agent, Cushman & Wakefield, declined to comment on the level of interest or whether any bids were received, citing ongoing negotiations.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Horizon Towers, which was relaunched for collective sale for the second time in February at an unchanged reserve price of S$1.1 billion, closed its tender on Mar 30 with no bids.
Total investment sales fell 61 per cent to S$4.2 billion in the first quarter of 2023, figures compiled by Knight Frank show.
Lakeside Towers (above) is a stone’s throw from Jurong Lake Gardens, near the upcoming Jurong Lake District.

site_title: For Integrated Shield policyholders, trade-offs in cancer drug cover are par for the course
summary: Singapore's cancer drug list (CDL) has successfully reined in the cost of cancer treatments, with prices reduced by 30% on average and 60% for some drugs. The list covers 90% of private medical institution patients and 95% of public healthcare patients, with 340 treatments on the list as of February. However, policyholders with treatments outside the list may still claim from their Integrated Shield Plans until September 2023. Insurers have introduced base plans and riders to fill the gap, but premiums for riders are likely to rise.

images.alt_text: National Cancer Centre Singapore, taken on 9 Jun 2022.
Retiring comfortably is within everyone's reach but we have to take the first step to make retirement planning a priority.

site_title: Google to open app payment options in UK after watchdog probe
summary: Google has agreed to allow Android app makers in the UK to choose between its payment system and alternative billing options, following a probe by the country's competition regulator. The move aims to break the link between app downloads and Google's payment system, allowing users to access new special offers and in-app deals. This decision comes amid mounting antitrust concerns over Google's fees, with the company already allowing some apps to bill users directly in Europe. Google will "continue to listen to feedback" and invest in helping developers thrive on Google Play.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Google LLC is seen at the Google Store Chelsea in New York City, U.S., January 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo

site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 distributable income from operations down 6.7% on higher borrowing costs
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 6.7% decline in distributable income from operations to S$50.2 million in Q1, mainly due to higher borrowing costs. However, the Reit distributed S$55.2 million, including an anniversary distribution of S$5 million, and saw a 5.9% increase in property income to S$57.7 million. Net property income grew 1.3% to S$40.5 million, driven by higher rentals and occupancy.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

Financial stresses on the US office Reits are well documented. Share prices of Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit slumped as the market reassessed their financial stability and tenant risk.
S-Reits that are scheduled to release their results for the full-year ending March include Aims Apac Reit and the trio of Mapletree Reits.
Amid banking-led uncertainties, market watchers say S-Reits with strong sponsors are favoured to outperform their peers.
The full year contribution from Keppel Bay Tower helped increase the distribution per unit for Keppel unitholders.

site_title: US dollar strengthens as US yields rise, high British inflation underpins pound
summary: The US dollar strengthened by 0.47% to 102.19, driven by rising US yields and skepticism about potential rate cuts later this year. British inflation remained above 10% in March, supporting the pound despite expectations of higher interest rates. The pound traded 0.2% lower against the US dollar at 1.2398, while the euro slid 0.48% to 1.0922. Market sentiment turned negative, with European shares and US share futures struggling alongside non-yielding assets, as investors await the Federal Reserve's May meeting and potential rate hikes.

site_title: Research finds that no carbon project checks all the boxes
summary: A recent study by Trove Research found that few carbon projects meet high integrity standards, with only about 47 projects scoring above 4 out of 5 in a scale assessing their integrity. The study, which evaluated over 4,000 projects, also found that projects linked to the United Nations' Redd+ program often fall into the "good integrity, some risk" category. Despite this, prices of Redd+ credits have fallen 19% since intense scrutiny earlier this year, highlighting the need for market participants to prioritize pragmatism over perfection.

images.alt_text: The prices of Redd+ credits have fallen 19 per cent since coming under intense scrutiny earlier this year, Trove noted.
An audit team at the Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve, in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia.

ICVCM states that forestry projects under Redd+ – a UN framework created to guide activities in the forest sector that reduces emissions from deforestation and forest degradation – must also conform to the Cancun safeguards.

site_title: Revised SGX rules for hybrid general meetings to kick in from Jul 1
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has revised its rules for hybrid general meetings, which will take effect from July 1, 2023. Companies must hold general meetings at a physical space in Singapore, unless prohibited by law, and may use virtual meeting technology to allow shareholders to participate remotely. Issuers holding meetings overseas must also conduct information meetings in Singapore. The revised rules aim to ensure shareholders' rights to participate fully in general meetings, regardless of the meeting format, and require companies to implement necessary safeguards to validate votes.

images.alt_text: online, meeting, virtual
Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has also said it will work closely with MAS to provide guidance for listed issuers to have the option to conduct hybrid meetings.
The proposed amendments will expressly clarify that companies can hold fully virtual or hybrid general meetings and provide companies flexibility in holding such meetings

site_title: India's top pregnancy test kit maker Mankind eyes biggest IPO so far this year
summary: Mankind Pharma, India's largest pregnancy test kit maker, is set to launch its largest initial public offering (IPO) this year, seeking a valuation of 432.64 billion rupees (S$7.03 billion). The company, which also manufactures condoms, has set a price band of 1,026-1,080 rupees per share. The IPO, which will consist of nearly 40.1 million shares, is expected to raise 43.26 billion rupees, with proceeds going to existing shareholders. The listing comes amid volatile markets and global economic challenges that have delayed other IPOs in India.

images.alt_text: Indian apparel retailer Fabindia withdraws its plan for an initial public offering due to rough market conditions. Meanwhile, the shares of its listed rivals are down.

site_title: Credit Suisse files long-awaited US$440 million Softbank suit
summary: Credit Suisse filed a $440 million lawsuit against SoftBank Group in London, alleging the company orchestrated the restructuring of Greensill Capital's relationship with Katerra to pull its own money out, knowing Greensill would default on its debt. The lawsuit comes after Credit Suisse froze and wound down a $10 billion group of funds in 2021, with about $6.8 billion returned to investors. SoftBank vows to "vigorously" defend the claim, which follows a series of shadow legal skirmishes between the two companies.

images.alt_text: The judge had ruled in Credit Suisse’s favour without a trial at a hearing last month.

site_title: Temasek-backed fish startup set to join Indonesia’s growing list of unicorns
summary: eFishery, a Temasek-backed fish startup, is in advanced talks for a funding round that could value it at $1.2 billion. The agritech startup, which serves over 30,000 fish and shrimp farmers in Indonesia, is seeking about $100 million in fresh funding. eFishery's previous $90 million Series C round valued it at over $400 million in January last year. The funding round, led by 42XFund, is ongoing and negotiations are still in progress.

images.alt_text: A fish pond equipped with eFishery dispensers in Subang Regency in West Java, Indonesia, on Sunday, June 26, 2022. The fish-feeding firm eFishery provides farmers with a dispenser that scatters pellets based on data from thousands of users. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Stricken Credit Suisse brings forward quarterly results
summary: Credit Suisse is bringing forward its quarterly results, initially planned for April 27, to Monday, ahead of UBS's release on April 25. The move comes as the Swiss bank seeks to address concerns over mass withdrawals in the last quarter of 2022, which led to a 30% plunge in its share price. The results will be closely studied for insights into the bank's restructuring efforts and its handling of the crisis.

images.alt_text: The securities have rebounded in recent weeks from the market-wide losses inflicted by the terms of the Credit Suisse Group rescue.

The logo of Credit Suisse is pictured on a building near the Hallenstadion where took place the Annual General Meeting, two weeks after being bought by rival UBS in a government-brokered rescue, in Zurich, Switzerland, April 4, 2023. REUTERS/Pierre Albouy
A legal expert said parliament’s (top) views should count, but one needs to take into account what legal obligations the government entered into before parliament said “no.”

site_title: Chipmaking machines face a crunch of their own
summary: Chipmaking machine manufacturers face a glut of equipment despite billions of dollars in capital spending, as the complex semiconductor market cycle becomes harder to predict. A 17% drop in front-end process equipment and 9% drop in back-end process equipment are forecasted, following record sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment in 2022. New variables, including export restrictions, Chinese investments, and geopolitical tensions, have disrupted the industry, making it challenging to forecast demand. Companies are adapting by delaying projects, postponing payments, and focusing on lucrative areas like decarbonization transitions, but a deeper reassessment of the industry is needed.

images.alt_text: Residents at a park in front of residential buildings in the Guanxin district of Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Thursday, Nov. 3, 2022. Taiwan's success in the semiconductor industry is fueling a boom in house prices that is spreading from north to south, with highly paid workers at major chipmakers pushing the property market to buck the trend of a global slowdown. Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg
China is looking to build self-reliance in key technology such as semiconductors as it faces increasing pressure from the US.

site_title: Meta prepares more layoffs across Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram
summary: Meta is set to commence companywide layoffs on April 19, impacting Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram, and Reality Labs, as part of a cost-cutting push to reduce 10,000 positions. The move follows a 13% workforce cut in November and a hiring freeze, aiming for greater efficiency and a leaner ratio of technologists to business staff. The layoffs are part of Meta's "year of efficiency" plan, with further cuts expected in May.

site_title: Zara owner buys London office for £82 million to add to prime property portfolio
summary: Inditex founder Amancio Ortega has acquired a London office building for £82 million, adding to his prime real estate portfolio valued at 15.3 billion euros. Ortega, the billionaire founder of Zara, already owns several notable properties worldwide, including The Post building in London, Manhattan's Haughwout Building, and Miami's Southeast Financial Center.

site_title: Online US real estate firm Opendoor cuts 22% of workforce
summary: Opendoor, a US online real estate firm, is cutting 22% of its workforce, approximately 560 jobs, due to a declining housing market. The company cited a 30% drop in new listings and higher mortgage interest rates as factors. Despite nearly doubling sales to $15.6 billion, Opendoor reported a loss of $1.4 billion in 2022, more than double its loss in 2021. The layoffs follow a previous round of 550 job cuts in November.

images.alt_text: Opendoor reported an adjusted net loss of US$467 million in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong interbank liquidity shrinks towards lowest since 2008
summary: Hong Kong's interbank liquidity is expected to drop to HK$49.2 billion on Thursday, its lowest level since the 2008 global financial crisis. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) efforts to maintain the local currency's peg to the US dollar have drained liquidity, leading to a 90% decline from its peak in 2021. This may result in higher lending rates, potentially hurting the nascent property market recovery. Experts warn that a rise in the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (Hibor) could catch up with US rates, affecting borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: The pool of cash has shrunk after the HKMA bought HK$20 billion worth of the local currency this month to keep its value within the 7.75-7.85 per dollar-trading band.
The session will be held jointly by the HKMA and the SFC, the two regulators overseeing stablecoins and crypto exchanges.

site_title: Travellers pounce on airline blunder to buy US$10,000 Asia-US business class tickets at bargain prices
summary: Airlines ANA Holdings mistakenly listed erroneous currency conversion on its Vietnam website, offering US$10,000 business-class tickets for just a few hundred dollars. Travellers quickly snapped up the discounted tickets, with most bookings for travel starting in Jakarta to Japan and then to New York and back to South-east Asia destinations. ANA will honour the discounted tickets, but those who only reserved will have to pay the "just price". The airline is investigating the cause of the bug and its damage.

images.alt_text: United Airlines said it expects an adjusted profit of US$3.50 to US$4 a share in the second quarter, with a 14 per cent to 16 per cent year-on-year jump in revenue.
“Southwest Airlines pause on departures has been fully cancelled,” the FAA said in a statement.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured at the Airbus facility in Montoir-de-Bretagne near Saint-Nazaire, France, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: China’s CATL unveils condensed matter battery to power civil aircraft
summary: Chinese battery giant CATL unveiled a condensed matter battery capable of powering electric passenger aircraft, boasting an energy density of 500 Watt hours per kilogramme. The semi-solid state product, developed with unspecified partners, aims to meet aviation safety and quality standards. CATL also plans to start mass production of the battery for electric vehicles later this year. The company aims to achieve carbon neutrality across its battery value chain by 2035, as part of its efforts to reduce emissions in the battery-making industry.

images.alt_text: M3P batteries will have greater energy density and perform better than lithium-ion phosphate batteries, a market CATL dominates.
CATL has reported net income for the 12 months ended Dec 31 of 30.72 billion yuan (S$6 billion), an increase of 92.9 per cent from the previous year.

site_title: Eat lunch at the edge of space for 120,000 euros
summary: France's Zephalto is offering luxury space balloon flights to the stratosphere, starting at 120,000 euros per person in 2025. The 60-flight-per-year venture will take 6 passengers on board 25km-high balloons for 1.5 hours, with a six-hour round trip. Zephalto's founder, Vincent Farret d'Asties, aims to provide a serene, luxury experience with fine food, wine, and design, while also offering an option to speak with a psychologist before the flight. The company plans to launch with six flights per year, with certification expected to allow flights to land anywhere in Europe.

images.alt_text: Liftoff of the giant rocket was called off just minutes ahead of the scheduled launch time because of a pressurisation issue in the booster stage.

site_title: London’s housing crisis is about to get worse
summary: London's housing market is in crisis, with the first three months of 2023 seeing the smallest number of completed new homes since 2014, at 3,076. Sales of new homes plummeted by 39% compared to the same period last year, to 3,768, with many buyers struggling to afford new homes due to higher interest rates and a cost of living crisis. The government's Help to Buy program has also closed to new applications, and housebuilders are offering incentives to regain sales momentum, but building activity is unlikely to improve in the near future.

images.alt_text: London remains the big beast in European finance for now, with headcount vastly outnumbering the rest of Europe.
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) and Marina Bay Financial Centre along the Singapore River at night, 29 October 2022.

site_title: Julius Baer sees highest growth in Asia in wealth push
summary: Julius Baer sees Asia as its fastest-growing region, with a quarter of its global business and over 500 employees serving clients across Greater China. The Swiss wealth bank expects to benefit from the merger of rivals UBS Group and Credit Suisse Group. Julius Baer plans to grow its own talent and hire external relationship managers to drive growth, with a focus on Asia.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 30, 2018 shows a sign or logo of the Swiss private bank Julius Baer on the top of a building at sunset. - Swiss bank Julius Baer said on September 25, 2020, it would pay about 150 million Swiss francs (138 million euros, $162 million) following a ruling over unauthorised withdrawals at an East German trading company. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: Upskilling for robots
summary: Singaporean robotics companies are finding new applications for existing expertise, taking their technological offerings from one industry to another. Transforma Robotics is introducing its robots to the oil and gas industry for maintenance and inspection, while Kabam Robotics is expanding its indoor robot Co-Lab and outdoor robot Halo to facilities management. Augmentus, a no-code platform, allows non-experts to control robotic arms, simplifying the process for small and medium-sized enterprises. These companies aim to scale up and unlock new markets, particularly in regional markets like China and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
