site_title: China says drafting plans to boost recovery, expansion of consumption
summary: China is drafting plans to boost the recovery and expansion of consumption, following a faster-than-expected economic growth in the first quarter. Despite a sharp rebound in retail sales, policymakers remain concerned about weak demand, citing an uncertain international environment and insufficient domestic demand. The National Development and Reform Commission aims to promote a sustained recovery in consumption, focusing on key areas such as stabilizing big-ticket consumption and expanding rural consumption.

images.alt_text: China’s recovery has so far remained uneven, with consumption, services and infrastructure spending perking up but slowing prices and surging bank savings raising doubts about demand.
The property sector sharply slumped last year, but is now being buoyed by a slew of policies aimed at developers and buyers.

site_title: British Tycoon to sell £75 million mansion that housed JP Morgan
summary: British businessman Mike Jatania is selling his £75 million, 12-bedroom mansion in Denham, Buckinghamshire, just west of London. The Grade I-listed stately home, which has a James Bond-themed cinema room and cocktail bar, was rented by JP Morgan and James Bond co-producer Harry Saltzman. The sale comes 23 years after Jatania bought the property and is expected to attract an international buyer due to the weakness of the pound against the dollar. The sale is one of the UK's biggest ever country house deals.

images.alt_text: RICS’s gauges of buyer demand, sales, new listings and house prices were all in negative territory last month.

site_title: Thai industrial sentiment at decade high as demand and tourism pick up
summary: Thai industrial sentiment reached a decade-high of 97.8 in March, driven by a rebound in domestic demand and tourism, according to the Federation of Thai Industries. The index rose from 96.2 in February, when it returned to pre-pandemic levels. While concerns over high costs, slowing global growth, and baht volatility remain, the group expects the economy to continue recovering, driven by tourism and consumption. The government forecasts 25-30 million foreign tourist arrivals this year, and China's reopening is expected to support Thai tourism and exports in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Headline inflation dropped to its lowest rate in 15 months of 2.83 per cent in March, returning within the Bank of Thailand’s target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent for the first time since 2021.

site_title: UK inflation sticks above 10%, lifting prospect of rate hike
summary: The UK's Consumer Prices Index (CPI) rose 10.1% in March, driven by the strongest increase in food prices in over four decades. This has strengthened the case for further interest-rate hikes by the Bank of England, with economists expecting two consecutive 25-basis-point increases in May and June. The pound edged higher against the US dollar, while gilt yields fell, as investors priced in steeper rate increases. The Bank of England's governor Andrew Bailey had signaled a possible pause in rate hikes if inflation subsides, but the latest reading suggests prices in the UK have more momentum than in the US or eurozone.

site_title: Tesla cuts US prices for sixth time this year ahead of Q1 results
summary: Tesla has cut US prices for its Model Y and Model 3 electric vehicles for the sixth time this year, with price reductions ranging from $2000 to $3000. The company has lowered prices in several countries, including Europe, Israel, Singapore, Japan, Australia, and South Korea, amid concerns about profit margins. The price cuts come ahead of Tesla's Q1 results, which are expected to show a 24.2% year-on-year increase in revenue but a 2.4% decline in profit estimates.

images.alt_text: Tesla is expected to report auto gross margin of 23.2 per cent for the quarter, according to 17 analysts polled by Visible Alpha, down from a record 32.9 per cent a year earlier and the lowest since the fourth quarter of 2019.
Several online posts claimed workers at the Tesla's Shanghai plant were being unfairly penalised for an incident this year at the factory in February where one worker died.

site_title: Man Group shares Warren Buffett’s renewed optimism for Japanese stocks
summary: Man Group's head of Japanese equities, Jeffrey Atherton, expresses optimism for Japan's stock market, citing improved corporate governance standards and potential policy normalisation by the Bank of Japan. Despite the main Japanese stock indices still being below historical peaks, Atherton sees medium-term opportunities, particularly in "unloved" domestic-focused stocks. He notes the government and BOJ's efforts to keep inflation stable and the country's reopening after Covid will drive spending and corporate earnings. Atherton favors insurers, citing lower exposure to liquidity issues, and sees a high chance of policy normalisation by the end of June.

images.alt_text: Passersby walk past an electric board displaying Japan's Nikkei share average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan April 18, 2023.  REUTERS/Issei Kato

A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI
A median estimate of 15 analysts polled on Feb 10-21 expected the Nikkei to be at 30,000 at the end of this year, after rising to 28,000 by end-June.

Travelers in the departure hall at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. With China's 296 million migrant workers on the move this year, factories and local governments are bracing for disruptions during a longer-than-usual holiday period. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan’s March visitors at post-Covid high, lured by cherry blossoms
summary: Japan saw a post-Covid surge in March with 1.82 million foreign visitors, the highest since 2019, with overseas tourists flocking to see cherry blossoms for the first time in four years. This marks a 23% increase from February and a 21% rise from March 2019, before pandemic travel curbs. Despite this, visitor numbers are still down 34% from the pre-pandemic record. The Japan National Tourism Organisation attributes the increase to eased travel curbs and resumed visa-free travel for many countries.

site_title: Heineken boosted by Europe beer drinkers as Asia lags
summary: Heineken's first quarter results show a boost from European beer drinkers despite inflation in key markets, offsetting a weaker performance in the Asia-Pacific region and Nigeria. Volumes fell 3% organically, below estimates, but the company stuck to its outlook for adjusted operating profit growth of mid- to high-single digits. CEO Dolf van den Brink warned of cloudy consumer demand, while the company also bought back 1 billion euros in shares and warned of nationalization risks in Russia. Heineken's shares rose 4% in early trading on the news.

images.alt_text: A Heineken logo sits on the neck of a beer bottle the Heineken Hungaria Breweries Plc Sopron brewery in Sopron, Hungary, on Thursday, Nov. 12, 2015. Heineken reported estimate-beating sales growth boosted by a warm European summer as the world's third-largest brewer prepares to become a distant number two. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: Amid global storms, Singapore must ‘double down’ on staying open: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the country's need to "double down" on staying open and connected amidst global storms, including the decline of globalization, Russia's ongoing war in Ukraine, and tensions between the US and China. The government must prioritize unity, self-reliance, and maintaining its strong reputation to ensure survival. Lee also highlighted the importance of staying ahead in the global economy by transforming and restructuring the economy, upgrading capabilities, and building new ones.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

The government will invest in Singaporeans “throughout life”, said Education Minister Chan Chun Sing, ith plans to make training more accessible for working adults with competing commitments and support more targeted for mid-career workers, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups.
Singapore will continue to sustain real income growth for the middle, which is why economic growth is “non-negotiable” for the city-state, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

The government wants to harness the best of organisations to address the needs of communities, by tapping their assets, expertise and networks, said Minister for Social and Family Development Masagos Zulkifli.

site_title: Sri Lanka GDP outlook slashed as economy struggles to recover
summary: Sri Lanka's economic growth outlook has been sharply cut, with the country's GDP forecast to contract by 9.9% in the first quarter and 0.7% for the full year, more than double the previous estimates. The economic contraction is attributed to US dollar shortages, limited reserves, and ongoing debt restructuring efforts. Despite IMF bailout loans and improved food and fuel imports, economists say the economy is still far from pre-pandemic normalcy, with double-digit inflation expected to persist throughout the year.

images.alt_text: Market scene in Colombo, March 20, 2023. Cash-strapped Sri Lanka was seeking a 10-year moratorium on its foreign debt.
Other officials in the briefing also called for all creditors to participate, without mentioning China by name.
The central bank on Apr 4 held its benchmark rate at a two-decade high of 16.5 per cent in order to keep Asia’s fastest inflation in check while supporting economic recovery.
A general view of the main business district as rain clouds gather above in Colombo, Sri Lanka, November 17, 2020. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: COE premium for smaller cars surges to record S$103,721, open category premium at S$124,501
summary: COE premiums reached record highs, with smaller cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp at S$103,721, a 7.48% increase from the previous high of S$96,501. The Open category premium also set a new record at S$124,501, up 4.63% from S$118,990. Larger car and more powerful EV COE premiums rose to S$120,889, a 2.02% increase. This is the second consecutive record high for COE premiums.

images.alt_text: The COE premium for smaller cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as for electric vehicles with up to 110 kilowatts of power, finished at S$96,501.

site_title: Glencore raises pressure on Teck Resources with promise of higher bid
summary: Glencore has raised pressure on Teck Resources with a promise to improve its US$22.5 billion takeover offer, which would combine and spin off its thermal coal unit and Teck's steelmaking coal business. If Teck's board fails to engage, Glencore may consider taking the offer to shareholders directly. This move comes as Teck's own restructuring plan nears an April 26 vote, and amid growing demand for copper and other metals critical to the green energy transition.

images.alt_text: Teck investors will vote on the plan to spin off its coal mines in a little more than a week, and Glencore chief executive officer Gary Nagle has said that the company will keep pursuing a deal if Teck’s investors vote down the restructuring plan.

site_title: Temasek Trust Capital joins Series A round of impact verification provider BlueMark
summary: BlueMark, a New York-based impact verification and intelligence provider, has secured US$10 million in a Series A funding led by S&P Global, alongside six other investors. Temasek Trust Capital joined as a new investor, citing substantial growth opportunities in impact investing. The funding will accelerate the adoption of BlueMark's services to institutional investors. Founded in 2020, BlueMark has completed 125 verifications for investors with US$206 billion in assets under management, with plans to expand across industries and geographies, particularly in Asia.

site_title: India to have 2.9 million more people than China by mid-2023, UN estimate shows
summary: India is projected to surpass China as the world's most populous country by mid-2023, with an estimated 2.9 million more people, according to a UN estimate. India's population is expected to reach 1.4286 billion, while China's will be 1.4257 billion. India's annual population growth has slowed to 1.2% since 2011, compared to 1.7% previously. This marks a significant shift, with China experiencing a historic decline in population for the first time in six decades.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on March 26, 2023 shows cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports rose in March for the first time in six months, customs data showed on April 13, as the world's second-largest economy continued its recovery following the end of onerous coronavirus curbs late last year. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Beijing hospital fire death toll rises to 29
summary: A fire at a hospital in Beijing's Fengtai district has killed 29 people, with 12 detained in connection to the blaze. The fire, caused by sparks generated during internal renovation, also injured many. A preliminary probe found the sparks ignited flammable paint on the site. The incident has raised questions about hospital safety and renovation procedures.

site_title: Singapore’s foreign policy with US, China driven by principles, not ‘balance’: Sim Ann
summary: Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Sim Ann stated that Singapore's foreign policy with the US and China is driven by principles, not a balance of interests, in a bid to maintain strong ties with both major powers. Singapore supports China's reform and opening up, while having excellent relations with the US, which is its largest investor. Sim emphasized the importance of regional peace, international law, and a stable global order, and warned against misinterpreting Singapore-China relations from a cultural perspective.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
PM Lee Hsien Loong delivering his speech on the report of the Committee of Privileges in Parliament on 15 February 2022.

site_title: Credit Suisse accused of hindering probe into Nazi accounts
summary: US lawmakers accuse Credit Suisse of hindering an investigation into its historical assistance to Nazis, revealing previously undisclosed accounts linked to senior Nazi officials and members of Nazi-affiliated groups. The bank initially agreed to investigate but established a narrow scope, refused to follow new leads, and removed an independent ombudsperson. Reports from the probe indicate that Credit Suisse maintained accounts for at least 99 individuals with ties to Nazi Germany and Argentina, with many remaining open until recently. Credit Suisse denies the allegations, stating that a report by the former ombudsperson contained factual errors and unsupported allegations.

images.alt_text: The securities have rebounded in recent weeks from the market-wide losses inflicted by the terms of the Credit Suisse Group rescue.

site_title: Tribeca Festival unveils a lineup filled with stars turned directors
summary: The 2023 Tribeca Festival lineup features a diverse selection of films, including world premieres of movies directed by performers such as Chelsea Peretti, Michael Shannon, and Randall Park. The festival, which runs from June 7 to 18, boasts 109 films from 127 filmmakers across 36 countries, with 68% of feature films in competition directed by women. The event also includes a Marvel documentary about Stan Lee, live events such as performances by Sara Bareilles and Gloria Gaynor, and a conversation with Dan Rather and Frank Marshall.

images.alt_text: In 2007, the company launched its streaming business, helping to put Blockbuster Entertainment, the largest DVD rental chain, out of business.
The Super Mario Bros. Movie raked in US$87 million in ticket sales in the Friday-through-Sunday period, bringing the movie’s total haul to more than US$347 million, according to Exhibitor Relations.

site_title: Disney is poised to eliminate thousands of jobs next week
summary: Disney plans to cut 7,000 positions, including 15% of its entertainment division staff, starting next week. The cuts will span TV, film, theme parks, and corporate positions, affecting every Disney region. The move is part of a strategy to shave $5.5 billion in annual costs. The entertainment division, which was restructured to focus on franchise properties, will be a major area of cuts. This move follows other media companies trimming their headcounts as they shift focus from subscriber growth to operating costs.

images.alt_text: Disney employed about 220,000 people worldwide as of Oct 1.
Earlier Wednesday, Disney announced upbeat financial results, led by big gains at its theme parks.

site_title: Eurozone yields hit one-month high on expectations of tighter policy
summary: Eurozone government bond yields reached a one-month high due to market expectations of a 25 basis point interest rate hike by the European Central Bank at its May meeting, with a 20% chance of a 50 basis point increase. German 10-year bond yields hit 2.54%, the highest level since March 10, while Italy's 10-year bond yield rose to 4.35%, pushing the spread between Italian and German yields up to 182 bps. Analysts attribute the move to normalizing banking sector concerns and inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde arrives for a EU Summit, at the EU headquarters in Brussels, on March 24, 2023. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)

site_title: Gold prices inch up as US dollar eases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,006.09 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar, while interest rate expectations weighed on the non-yielding asset. The Federal Reserve may raise interest rates just once more in May before pausing, according to market pricing. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank's chief economist backs a further rate increase, but the size will depend on incoming data.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg
Gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, but higher interest rates dim non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: ASML beats Q1 earnings estimates, customers ‘adjusting’ orders due to chip market
summary: ASML Holding reported Q1 earnings that beat estimates, with a net profit of 1.96 billion euros and revenue of 6.74 billion euros, up 91% from last year. Despite signs of weakness in end markets, the company's outlook remains strong, with an order backlog of over 38.9 billion euros. CEO Peter Wennink attributed the adjustment in customer orders to the changing market situation, but expressed confidence in the company's demand. ASML's market capitalization makes it Europe's largest technology firm.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ASML logo is seen in this illustration taken February 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Russian hackers targeting Western critical infrastructure, UK says
summary: The UK's National Cyber Security Centre has warned of an emerging threat to Western critical national infrastructure from Russia-aligned hackers. These "hacktivists" have been plotting ways to cause more real-world damage, including disrupting energy grids and water supplies. While they are ideologically-motivated and not formally controlled by the Russian state, their potential for disruption makes them unpredictable. The threat is considered low but increasing, with some groups already showing capabilities to infiltrate critical infrastructure.

images.alt_text: The EU Cyber Emergency Mechanism will test entities in highly critical sectors such as healthcare, transport and energy for potential vulnerabilities.
In today’s hurried digital world, younger, tech-savvier people are making up a larger proportion of victims.
In June, Western Digital announced a review of strategic alternatives following discussions with activist investor Elliott Investment Management.
Scammers appear to be trying to circumvent IMDA's safeguards to help Singapore residents better identify potential scam calls.

site_title: GoTo scraps talks for US$500 million debt sale to focus on profit
summary: GoTo, an Indonesian ride-hailing and e-commerce provider, has ended talks for a US$500 million debt sale to focus on hitting profitability targets. The company had initially sought US$1 billion but lowered its ambitions amid muted investor interest and reduced funding needs. Talks with potential investors, including BlackRock and the World Bank, were called off as GoTo prioritizes profitability over fundraising. This decision comes after the company downscaled its ambitions and focuses on hitting its targets.

images.alt_text: On-demand services posted positive contribution margin, though GoTo expects the food delivery business to slow down.

site_title: 140 billion yen sale marks first major bank’s AT1 bond offer since Credit Suisse wipeout
summary: SMFG, a major Japanese bank, sold 140 billion yen (S$1.4 billion) of Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds, the first major global bank to do so since Credit Suisse's collapse last month. This deal signals easing global financial turmoil and comes after Swiss regulators imposed significant losses on Credit Suisse AT1 debt holders. AT1 notes are considered the riskiest debt sold by banks, as they can impose losses on bondholders or be converted into equity. The sale price was 171 basis points, a significant increase from existing perpetual bonds.

images.alt_text: While MUFG is hardly the only firm to get caught up in the Credit Suisse debacle, the loss tally offers one of the first glimpses into how badly clients of a major investment bank were burned by the writedown.

site_title: Indian taxi startup BluSmart picks EV fight with Uber
summary: Indian taxi startup BluSmart is challenging Uber and Ola for market share with an all-electric fleet and aggressive bid to lure passengers and drivers. BluSmart has 22 charging hubs and 5,000 vehicles, commanding 9% of Delhi's ride-hailing market. Uber and Ola struggle with driver retention and customer satisfaction issues, while BluSmart uses its clean energy push to gain ground. BluSmart plans to grow its fleet to 100,000 in five years and slash fares with customized, small EVs. Uber aims to have a 100% EV fleet by 2040 globally and is targeting 1 million EVs in India.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man charges an electric vehicle (EV) at the charging hub of Indian ride-hailing BluSmart Electric Mobility in Gurugram, India, December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo
Uber launched the freight division in 2017, pairing trucking companies with those seeking to transport loads in a similar model to the company’s ride-hailing business.
Grab will likely achieve its earlier break-even goal even in a slowing economy.
The announcement was made as part of Australia’s first national electric vehicle strategy.

site_title: Star Entertainment announces job cuts, trims earnings view as conditions worsen
summary: Star Entertainment Group, an Australian casino operator, announced job cuts of about 500 full-time equivalent employees due to worsening operating conditions. The company also reduced its annual earnings forecast, citing a compounding impact of regulatory restrictions and low consumer spending behavior. Star's Sydney and Gold Coast casinos are particularly affected, with earnings expected to be between A$280 million and A$310 million for fiscal 2023, down from prior expectations of A$330 million to A$360 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,311.43, as European markets were upbeat following positive earnings and economic data. Losers outnumbered gainers 59 to 44, with Keppel Infrastructure Trust falling 3.9% and Mapletree Logistics Trust down 0.6%. Banking stocks, including UOB and OCBC, rose in early morning trade, while DBS remained unchanged.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Keppel DC Reit's gross revenue rises 6.5 per cent to S$70.4 million for the quarter, from S$66.1 million a year earlier.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to raise S$299.6 million after private placement closes at S$0.477 per unit
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has closed its private placement at S$0.477 per unit, raising approximately S$183 million. The placement was oversubscribed by about 4.2 times, with the manager increasing the number of placement units to 383,648,000. The trust's equity funding exercise will also include a preferential offering, raising S$116.6 million, and will be used to partially repay bridge facilities and cover fees and expenses.

images.alt_text: For the full year, distributable income was up 15.8 per cent to S$222.5 million, while full-year DPU rose 1 per cent to S$0.0382.
KIT received its first distribution from Aramco Gas Pipeline Company, which helped to boost distributable income for 3Q 2022.
Jopy Chiang assumed the role of chief executive at KIT’s trustee-manager just over a year ago.

site_title: US: Stocks flat after mixed bank earnings
summary: US stocks remained flat on Tuesday following mixed bank earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down less than 0.1% at 33,976.63. Bank of America rose 0.6% after reporting higher profits, while Goldman Sachs dropped 1.7% due to a slowdown in corporate mergers. Despite the mixed results, traders are not seeing "real trauma" from the banking sector, with lingering reservations about the industry evident in declining deposits at many banks.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MARCH 16: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 16, 2023 in New York City. Stocks fell again in morning trading as investors continue to show concerns over the stability of global banks following the collapse last week of Silicon Valley Bank.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: United Airlines sees return to profit on ‘strong’ international travel demand
summary: United Airlines forecasts an adjusted profit of $3.50 to $4 per share in the second quarter, with a 14-16% year-over-year jump in revenue. The company attributes the growth to strong international travel demand, with bookings for international trips growing at twice the domestic rate. CEO Scott Kirby also expressed confidence in the carrier's full-year earnings outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Boeing 767-322ER aircraft of United Airlines takes off during cold winter weather from Zurich Airport near Ruemlang, Switzerland, December 14, 2022.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
“Southwest Airlines pause on departures has been fully cancelled,” the FAA said in a statement.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured at the Airbus facility in Montoir-de-Bretagne near Saint-Nazaire, France, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: An applicant is measured for height during a recruiting session for cabin crew jobs at Hainan Airlines in Beijing, China, March 30, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Former McDonald’s restaurants in Belarus to be renamed Mak.by
summary: Former McDonald's restaurants in Belarus, all 25 operated by KSB Victory Restaurants, will be rebranded as Mak.by, retaining access to McDonald's recipes. The decision comes after McDonald's ended its operations in Belarus due to local supply issues. The new name, suggested by customers and staff, avoids using the word 'Mac' in products, a restriction in Russia. The Belarusian company's statement claims to preserve the "beloved taste" of McDonald's dishes, while President Alexander Lukashenko had previously intervened in the renaming process.

site_title: WHO warns Covid-19 pandemic still volatile
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the Covid-19 pandemic remains volatile, with over 23,000 deaths and 3 million new cases reported in the last 28 days. Despite decreasing numbers, the WHO's emergencies director, Michael Ryan, stated that the virus will not be eliminated and will continue to cause significant respiratory disease in vulnerable people. The WHO's emergency committee will meet in May to assess the pandemic's trajectory and determine if it still constitutes a public health emergency of international concern.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping speaks as French President Emmanuel Macron listens at a Franco-Chinese business council meeting in Beijing, April 6, 2023. Macron was accompanied by more than 60 business executives on his recent trip to China.
China’s recovery has so far remained uneven, with consumption, services and infrastructure spending perking up but slowing prices and surging bank savings raising doubts about demand.

site_title: India weighs higher capital gains tax to curb inequality
summary: India is considering an overhaul of its direct tax laws to address income inequality and standardize capital gains taxes. The proposed changes aim to increase capital gains taxes for top income earners and replace the current patchwork of rules. A panel may be appointed to implement the plans, with the goal of finalizing the changes in 2024. The move is seen as an effort to boost living standards and reduce wealth disparities, as only 3% of India's population invests in the stock market.

images.alt_text: Same-sex couple Sougata Basu (L) and Mayank Kalra take their adopted children for a walk outside their home in Bengaluru. A five-judge bench headed will be hearing appeals to legalise same-sex marriage from Tuesday.
The federal government owns 45.48 per cent of IDBI Bank, and is looking to divest a 30.48 per cent stake in the lender.

site_title: Australia plans fuel-efficiency standards to encourage electric vehicle use
summary: Australia plans to introduce fuel-efficiency standards by the end of 2023 as part of its national electric vehicle strategy to encourage the use of electric vehicles and reduce carbon emissions. The country is one of the last developed economies without such standards. The move comes as part of the government's efforts to toughen its climate change action, introducing emission reduction targets in 2022 and passing legislation to cap major polluters. The new standards will be finalized through consultation with industry and community.

site_title: Apple readies arsenal of apps for new headset, aiming to win over wary users
summary: Apple is preparing a software arsenal for its upcoming mixed-reality headset, aiming to win over wary consumers with a range of apps that utilize the device's novel 3D interface. The $3,000 headset is set to debut in June, with sales to follow later. The offerings will include gaming, fitness, and collaboration tools, as well as optimized versions of existing iPad apps, such as Safari and Apple's services. The company is also developing a version of its Fitness+ service and a collaboration app, Freeform, to appeal to users.

images.alt_text: This week, Apple introduced a new product with Goldman Sachs Group that will allow Apple Card holders to earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, with no fees or minimum deposit requirements.
People queue outside India's first Apple store before its opening in Mumbai on April 18, 2023.

site_title: Musk touts new moderation policy to reassure advertisers
summary: Elon Musk has introduced new content moderation policies on Twitter, aimed at limiting the reach of tweets that spread hate or misinformation. The move follows his sharp reining in of content moderation since purchasing the platform last year. Musk claims the new rules will protect free speech while preventing hateful content, saying "If somebody has something hateful to say, it doesn't mean he should have a microphone." The policy change is intended to reassure advertisers, who have been wary of the platform's recent changes.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk’s founding of a rival to OpenAI came several weeks before he joined experts in signing an open letter urging an overall hiatus in the development of AI technology.

Tesla is expected to report auto gross margin of 23.2 per cent for the quarter, according to 17 analysts polled by Visible Alpha, down from a record 32.9 per cent a year earlier and the lowest since the fourth quarter of 2019.
Several online posts claimed workers at the Tesla's Shanghai plant were being unfairly penalised for an incident this year at the factory in February where one worker died.
Tesla cut prices on Real-Wheel Drive version of both Model 3 and Model Y by S$4,000 (US$3,020), and Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive version of the two models by S$5,000, the website showed.
Twitter owner Musk is assembling a team of AI researchers and engineers, says the FT report.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Sabana Reit, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, Accrelist
summary: Keppel DC Reit's gross revenue rose 6.5% to S$70.4 million for the first quarter, while its manager posted a distribution per unit of 2.541 Singapore cents, a 3% increase. Keppel Infrastructure Trust resumed trading after a trading halt, and Sabana Reit announced a rise in aggregate leverage ratio to 33.1%. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posted an adjusted distributable income of US$13.1 million, down 12.5% from the previous year.

site_title: Big Japanese manufacturers remain gloomy as external demand ebbs: survey
summary: Japanese manufacturers remain pessimistic, with a fourth consecutive month of gloomy sentiment, as external demand slows and global growth concerns persist. The Reuters Tankan survey found the big manufacturers' sentiment index at minus 3, unchanged from the previous month, while the service sector's mood improved to a four-month high. The Bank of Japan's governor vowed to continue monetary easing to support the fragile economy. The outlook for an export-led recovery appears dim, with the manufacturers' index expected to rebound to plus 7 over the next three months.

images.alt_text: Tourists have been flocking back to Japan since it eased pandemic-era border controls in October.
The Yumeshima island in Osaka Bay, Japan, on 2 May 2014. A casino, conference centre and other facilities in 2029 with 1.8 trillion yen (S$17.9 billion) of initial investment are planned.

site_title: Once booming Indian startups set for more pain as funding crunch worsens
summary: India's startup funding is expected to worsen, with a significant decline in funding for the first quarter of 2023, down 75% from the same period last year. This is attributed to stretched valuations and faltering consumption growth, potentially leading to industry consolidation. Startups have raised just $2 billion, a far cry from the record $30 billion in 2021. Experts predict a "fundamental reset" and warn of potential job losses and economic growth impact.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A delivery worker of Zomato, an Indian food-delivery startup, wearing a face mask waits to collect order outside an eatery in Kolkata, India, July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Rupak De Chowdhuri/File Photo

site_title: More US consumers falling behind on payments
summary: US consumers are falling behind on credit card and loan payments as the economy softens, with delinquency rates expected to return to normal levels of 3-3.5% for branded cards and 5-5.5% for retail services by early 2024. Despite this, industry executives note that consumer financial health remains strong, with employment and wages stable. Banks, including Bank of America, JPMorgan, and Citigroup, have seen profits rise due to rising interest rates, but are preparing for potential losses as a recession looms.

images.alt_text: Visa and Mastercard are each being sued by hundreds of claimants at London’s Competition Appeal Tribunal, which is currently managing the various cases together.

site_title: Australia reaps gains of rate pause as RBNZ hawks see kiwi slide
summary: Australia's central bank paused its interest rate hikes, citing a desire to maintain pandemic-era job gains and avoid severe economic pain. This decision contrasts with New Zealand's aggressive rate increases, which have led to a recession. Markets are favoring the Australian dollar, with analysts predicting it will outperform the New Zealand dollar due to the differing policy stances and economic circumstances. The pause is seen as a softer stance by the Reserve Bank of Australia, while the Reserve Bank of New Zealand is considered one of the most hawkish in the developed world.

images.alt_text: The announcement was made as part of Australia’s first national electric vehicle strategy.

The Australian central bank's decision to keep interest rates unchanged this week doesn't imply an end to its policy tightening cycle, RBA Governor Philip Lowe said, reinforcing his long-held resolve to return inflation to its 2-3 per cent target.

Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia continued to expect that the Australian economy would “slow considerably” later this year but were not currently expecting a recession at home.

site_title: Kim Kardashian hires Wall Street talent to bulk up buyout firm
summary: Kim Kardashian's private equity firm, SKKY Partners, has hired six financial industry professionals, including a new chief operating officer, to bolster its team. The firm now has nearly a dozen employees and expects to surpass 15 by the end of the year. SKKY invests in consumer products and media, with a focus on diversity and inclusivity. Co-founders Kim Kardashian and Jay Sammons aim to leverage their diverse teams to make impactful decisions. The firm has already made significant hires, including from Apollo Global Management, Citigroup, and Bain Capital.

images.alt_text: bitcoin, money, decentralized

site_title: Oil prices steady as strong China data offsets US rate worries
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday, with Brent crude settling 1 cent higher at US$85.25 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude futures closing up 3 cents at US$80.86. Strong economic data from China, including a 4.5% growth in the first quarter, offset concerns about potential US interest rate hikes. China's oil refinery throughput reached record levels in March, supporting the price stability.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell US$1.55, or 1.8 per cent, to settle at US$84.76 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped US$1.69, or 2.1 per cent, at US$80.83 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Rapper Michel says Jho Low paid US$20 million for Obama photo op
summary: Grammy-winning rapper Pras Michel testified that Malaysian tycoon Jho Low paid him $20 million to secure a photo with President Barack Obama in 2012. Michel claimed he was hired as a "celebrity surrogate" and initially asked for $1 million, but Low paid him the full amount. Michel denied using straw donors to funnel illegal donations to Obama's campaign, saying the money was a gift. He also claimed he helped lobby the Trump administration to drop probes into Low's alleged 1MDB looting, but made only $18 million from the deal.

images.alt_text: DiCaprio met Low at a party and they bonded over several years and on trips.
Federal prosecutors ask US District Judge Margo Brodie in Brooklyn, New York, to order Ng to forfeit the sum as ill-gotten gains from the conspiracy to loot the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.
Roger Ng was convicted in April of conspiring to violate US anti-bribery laws and taking part in a money-laundering scheme.

site_title: Apple’s 4.15% savings account marks golden age of cash
summary: Apple has partnered with Goldman Sachs Group to introduce a new savings account offering a 4.15% annual yield to Apple Card holders with no fees or minimum deposit requirements. This move comes as high-yield savings accounts experience a resurgence in popularity due to low interest rates and growing concerns about recession. The introduction of this product coincides with Goldman's Marcus account increasing its rate to a record 3.9%. This shift towards cash investments provides investors with a degree of safety and potential returns, potentially shifting focus away from riskier investments in the stock market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Apple Inc. logo is seen hanging at the entrance to the Apple store on 5th Avenue in Manhattan, New York, U.S., October 16, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
People queue outside India's first Apple store before its opening in Mumbai on April 18, 2023.
The new offering will let Apple Card users earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, more than 10 times the national average.

site_title: Global steel demand to bounce 2.3% in 2023 on factory recovery
summary: Global steel demand is expected to rebound by 2.3% in 2023, driven by a recovery in manufacturing activity, according to the World Steel Association. Despite this upgrade, steel consumption is forecast to reach 1.822 billion tonnes, a 3.2% decline from 2022. Economic conditions will continue to hamper growth, but factors such as China's reopening and Europe's resilience will support the recovery. Steel demand is expected to grow 1.7% in 2024, reaching 1.822 billion tonnes.

images.alt_text: The most-traded September iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange ended daytime trade 3.1 per cent lower at 769 yuan (S$148.29) a tonne.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon opens door for possible military aid to Ukraine
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yoon has hinted at extending military aid to Ukraine beyond humanitarian and economic support, suggesting a shift in his stance on arming Ukraine. Yoon stated that his government will provide support to defend and rebuild Ukraine if it faces a large-scale civilian attack, citing South Korea's experience during the Korean War. This marks a significant change in Seoul's stance, as it has previously ruled out lethal aid to Ukraine. Yoon will also focus on strengthening information-sharing and joint contingency planning with the US and Japan to address North Korea's nuclear threats.

images.alt_text: Some Russia-aligned “hacktivists” have been actively plotting ways to do more real-world damage, Britain’s National Cyber Security Centre, part of the GCHQ eavesdropping intelligence agency, said in an alert.

I am also glad to see more and more products from Poland imported by smaller local companies. As our respective phytosanitary agencies share the commitment to remove the last existing administrative barrier and swiftly complete market, says Magdalena Bogdziewicz.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and France's President Emmanuel Macron, meeting with China’s President Xi Jinping, in Beijing, China, April 6, 2023.

The G7 ministers also said they recognised the importance of “engaging candidly” with China and the need to work together on common interests, while calling for a “peaceful resolution” of Taiwan-related issues.

site_title: Fox settles Dominion lawsuit for US$787.5 million over US election lies
summary: Fox Corp and Fox News have settled a defamation lawsuit with Dominion Voting Systems for $787.5 million, averting a trial over false claims of vote-rigging in the 2020 US election. Dominion had sought $1.6 billion in damages. The settlement reflects Fox's acknowledgment of false claims about Dominion's ballot-counting machines. Fox CEO Lachlan Murdoch stated the company's commitment to journalistic standards, while Dominion CEO John Poulos called the settlement "historic" and praised truthful reporting in the media. The settlement is the largest struck by an American media company in a defamation case.

images.alt_text: Justin Nelson, co-lead counsel for Dominion Voting Systems in its defamation lawsuits, speaks at a news conference with colleagues and John Poulo, center, Dominion’s chief executive, following a settlement in their defamation lawsuit against Fox News at the Delaware Superior Court in Wilmington, Del., April 18, 2023. The settlement with Dominion Voting Systems was the latest extraordinary twist in a case that exposed the inner workings of the most powerful voice in conservative news. (Pete Marovich/The New York Times)

Dominion Voting Systems alleges Fox damaged its business by Fox knowingly and repeatedly airing false claims that Dominion machines were used to flip the 2020 US presidential election against former President Donald Trump, a Republican, and in favour of Democrat Joe Biden, who won.

site_title: Sabana Reit’s Q1 leverage ratio inches up to 33.1%
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit's aggregate leverage ratio rose to 33.1% in Q1 2023, up from 32.4% in the previous quarter. The weighted average fixed-debt expiry fell to 1.8 years, with 80% of borrowings at fixed rates. Each potential interest-rate increase of 0.5 percentage points could lead to a 0.9% reduction in distribution per unit. The Reit's total borrowings stood at S$303 million, with debt headroom of around S$151.5 million. The company aims to manage funding sources and interest rates while exercising prudent capital deployment to enhance resilience.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit saw strong leasing momentum backed by robust demand from third-party logistics providers between January and March this year
As a result of the offer turning unconditional, the offer’s closing date has been extended by two weeks to 5.30pm on Mar 24, 2023, from the same time on Mar 10.
The property at 1 Tuas Avenue 4, dubbed 1TA4, will incorporate solar panels that can potentially generate more than 1,000 megawatt-hours of energy per year, says Sabana Reit's manager.
The independent directors have not appointed an IFA to advise on the partial offer, and have instead consulted a duly licensed financial adviser.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. The Reit portfolio valuation for its 18 properties is up by 2.3 per cent on-year to S$885.7 million as at end-2022.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher on China data cheer, travel stocks lead gains
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index ended 0.4% higher on Tuesday, holding at one-year highs, driven by positive earnings from travel and leisure stocks and better-than-expected China economic data. Travel stocks rose 2.1%, with Ladbrokes-owner Entain Plc jumping 7.2% on higher quarterly net gaming revenues. European miners and luxury stocks also gained, while the banks index rose 1.3% after a rough month. The Stoxx 600 has gained 10% this year, outperforming the S&P 500 index's 7.5% gain.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down less than 0.1 per cent to 33,976.63 on Tuesday.

site_title: T-Rex skeleton sells for more than 5.5 million Swiss francs at Swiss auction
summary: A composite T-Rex skeleton, TRX-293 Trinity, measuring 3.9m high and 11.6m long, sold for 5.5 million Swiss francs (S$8.17 million) at a Zurich auction. The skeleton, made from 293 bones from three different T-Rexs, was sold to an undisclosed buyer after a bid of 4.8 million Swiss francs. This was the first time an entire T-Rex skeleton of exceptional quality was sold in Europe and the third worldwide, with more than half of the skeleton's bones being original.

site_title: Tech, banks in focus for Q1 reporting season, with economic weakness likely to weigh on earnings
summary: Economic weakness is expected to impact Q1 earnings, particularly in the tech sector, with weaker sales anticipated. The banking sector is also expected to show resilience, driven by net interest income and modest fee income growth. However, interest rate hikes and economic growth moderation may slow loan growth and impact net interest margins. The outlook for the sector will be closely watched in the aftermath of the recent banking turmoil in the West.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
S-Reits that are scheduled to release their results for the full-year ending March include Aims Apac Reit and the trio of Mapletree Reits.

site_title: Meritocracy based on narrow metrics will hinder Singapore from building resilience: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for a more inclusive meritocracy, as a narrow focus on metrics may hinder the country's ability to build a resilient society. The government plans to invest in working adults and mid-career workers through accessible training programs and fair remuneration for essential services. This shift aims to value diverse abilities and create a more sustainable and resilient meritocracy, prioritizing "heart" and "hand" work alongside "head" work.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Chan gave the commitment that the government will invest in Singaporeans “throughout life”, but added that the government’s efforts alone will not be enough, without the partnership of industry, institutions and individuals.

The government wants to harness the best of organisations to address the needs of communities, by tapping their assets, expertise and networks, said Minister for Social and Family Development Masagos Zulkifli.

Economic pessimism could be a reason for Singapore’s low total fertility rate (TFR), he said, adding that studies have shown a causal link in Singapore between high home prices and low TFR, which fell to a record low of 1.05 last year.
President Halimah Yacob says Singapore would need to strengthen its social fabric to remain united and do well in  an increasingly dangerous and troubled world post-pandemic.
Singapore will continue to sustain real income growth for the middle, which is why economic growth is “non-negotiable” for the city-state, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

Workers' Party Member of Parliament Jamus Lim called for a committee comprising government representatives, civil society leaders and academic experts to be set up to decide what the poverty line should be.
If meritocracy necessarily results in unequal outcomes, the question is: Can we rely on such a system to deliver good outcomes for everyone?
In a broader meritocracy, society would ideally value a wide range of skills, which would likewise engender more open definitions and pathways to success.

site_title: Europe debates ‘de-risking’ challenge with China
summary: The European Union is debating the concept of "de-risking" its relationship with China, rather than "decoupling," to avoid policy failure. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen advocates for cautious engagement with Beijing, which includes reducing dependency, diversifying supply chains, and using existing economic tools to counter China's influence. However, disagreements within the EU and the fast-changing geopolitical landscape make it challenging to secure policy consensus. The EU is planning to introduce new economic tools, such as a Foreign Subsidies regulation and a targeted instrument on outbound investment, to address the imbalance in the economic relationship with China.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron arriving in Beijing, China, April 5, 2023.
Photovoltaic solar panels and windmills in the background around the Spanish Navarre town of Milagro, Apr 2023. Europe is under growing pressure to reduce its import dependency in solar panels.

French President Emmanuel Macron on his first trip to China since 2019, spoke to US President Joe Biden before the visit about trying to engage Chinese President Xi Jinping on hastening the end of the war in Ukraine started by Beijing’s close ally Russia.

site_title: Minority shareholders should hold out against Lian Beng’s lowball offer
summary: Lian Beng Group, a construction and engineering company, has made a lowball offer to minority shareholders to take the company private at S$0.62 per share, a mere 40.3% of the company's net asset value. Minority shareholders should hold out against the offer, as the Ong family behind the offer, who own 69.6% of the company's shares, may try to squeeze out minority investors. However, the Ministry of Finance has accepted proposed amendments to the Companies Act that will change how the 90% threshold is reached, making it unlikely for the Ong family to succeed.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Ong Pang Aik  is a director of both OSC Capital and Lian Beng.
Lian Beng's chairman Ong Pang Aik and his family are making an offer for the company at S$0.62 per share, which is nearly 60 per cent below book value
GK Goh no longer meets the Singapore Exchange (SGX)’s free-float requirement, under which an issuer must ensure at least 10 per cent of its total number of issued shares are held by the public.
The proposed amendments to the Companies Act have yet to be tabled for debate in Parliament.

site_title: EU agrees chips subsidies plan, EU industry chief says
summary: The European Union has agreed on a 43-billion-euro plan to boost its semiconductor industry, aiming to double its global chip output share to 20% by 2030. The Chips Act plan was agreed upon after the US announced its CHIPS for America Act to compete with Chinese technology. The EU's plan covers the entire chip value chain, including older chips and research facilities, and was welcomed by US chipmaker Intel. The EU industry chief, Thierry Breton, confirmed the deal, marking a significant step for the EU to catch up with the US and Asia in the semiconductor industry.

site_title: Banks betting on Paris say there really is life after London
summary: Paris is emerging as the new pre-eminent hub in European finance, with major banks such as JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs relocating to the city. The relocation is driven by the UK's departure from the EU and the desire for a more fragmented landscape. Paris's allure is due to its global city status, business, politics, and culture being in one place, making it an attractive location for financial professionals. The city's assets booked by international banks have increased by almost sixfold to 1.7 trillion euros, with Frankfurt and Milan also gaining significant financial services. Despite London remaining the largest hub, Paris's post-Brexit leadership is predicted to continue, with many executives expecting headcount to keep growing through local hiring.

images.alt_text: London rents have historically been higher than the rest of the UK but in the first quarter of this year, they have sky-rocketed, a SpareRoom study says.
The new service by London Stock Exchange Group and Global Futures and Options is expected to start in the fourth quarter of this year, pending approval from French regulators.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher on earnings optimism
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Tuesday, April 18, driven by optimism about the earnings season, despite concerns about a looming recession. The S&P 500 rose 0.31% to 4,164.26, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.63% to 12,234.56. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.06% to 33,965.16. An upbeat quarterly report from Bank of America boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Accrelist to acquire 51% stake in four medical aesthetic clinics for S$550,000
summary: Accrelist, a Catalist-listed company, will acquire a 51% stake in four medical aesthetic clinics for S$550,000. The clinics, operated by SJY Medical, will be rebranded under Accrelist Medical Aesthetics (AM Aesthetics) and will retain existing doctors. The acquisition is expected to narrow Accrelist's loss per share to S$0.0413 and increase its net tangible assets per share to S$0.1013. AM Aesthetics operates nine clinics in Singapore and one in Malaysia, with plans to open two more clinics in Singapore and expand into Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Accrelist to raise up to S$3.38m via proposed placement of shares, issue of warrants
Jubilee enters MOU to sell electronics unit for indicative US$11m
Accrelist chairman discharged by Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau

site_title: Joe, Jill Biden release tax return, showing US$579,514 in income
summary: US President Joe Biden and First Lady Jill Biden released their joint tax return, showing a gross income of nearly $580,000 in 2022, down $30,000 from the previous year. Most of the income came from Biden's $400,000 standard presidential salary and Jill Biden's $82,335 teaching job. They paid a federal tax rate of 23.8%, resulting in $137,658 in federal income tax. The Bidens also made significant charitable donations, including $5,000 to the Beau Biden Foundation. The White House highlighted the president's commitment to transparency, following a precedent set by his predecessor, Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Justin Nelson, co-lead counsel for Dominion Voting Systems in its defamation lawsuits, speaks at a news conference with colleagues and John Poulo (centre) Dominion’s chief executive, following a settlement in their defamation lawsuit against Fox News at the Delaware Superior Court in Wilmington, Delaware, April 18, 2023.
US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy said in a speech at the New York Stock Exchange that the debt ceiling should be raised but only in tandem with spending cuts to address the national debt.
“We’ll announce it relatively soon. But the trip here just reinforced my sense of optimism about what can be done,” Biden tells reporters at the tail-end of an emotional trip to Ireland.

site_title: Harnessing the potential of generative AI responsibly
summary: Generative AI is expected to expand beyond administrative, creative, and customer experience-related work, marking an inflection point for democratization of AI. According to an IDC report, AI system spending in Asia-Pacific is expected to double by 2026, reaching $46.6 billion. Generative AI will produce 10% of all data within the next two years, generating synthetic data such as blog posts, reports, and artwork. Its capabilities surpass conversational interaction, and its impact is monumental for businesses and society, enabling cognitive generation of new data. This trend is driven by Large Language Models like GPT and OpenAI integrations.

images.alt_text: Generative AI, software that can create text, images, or video based on prompts from a user, has captured the imagination of Silicon Valley, setting off fierce competition to capitalise on the technology.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia QR code payment link a boost to cashless drive
summary: Malaysia and Singapore have launched a cross-border QR code payment linkage, allowing customers to make retail payments in both countries using mobile e-wallets. The system supports in-person payments and online cross-border e-commerce transactions, and is available to customers of select financial institutions. The launch is expected to boost Malaysia's cashless payment drive, with e-payment transactions growing by 31.5% to RM9.5 billion in 2022. The service is seen as a natural progression between the two countries, with potential for expansion to other markets in Asia.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
The central banks of 5 South-east Asia countries, including Bank Negara Malaysia will be running tests of Nexus cross-border transactions on a larger scale.

With pre- pandemic annual traffic between the two countries averaging 12 million visitors, the payment linkage provides merchants and consumers with a more seamless and efficient means to make and receive payments.

site_title: GSK to buy Bellus for US$2 billion to gain cough medicine
summary: GSK agreed to buy Canadian biotech Bellus Health for about US$2 billion, bolstering its pipeline of experimental medicines. The deal includes a cough medicine, camlipixant, that has shown promising results in clinical trials and is expected to yield multi-billion-dollar annual sales. The takeover aims to replenish GSK's product pipeline as the company faces pressure to improve shareholder returns. The transaction is expected to start boosting earnings per share in 2027 and will close in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: GSK has been trying to replenish its product pipeline in recent years as the company faces pressure to improve shareholder returns and keep up with UK rival AstraZeneca.

site_title: Netflix reports mixed earnings as password crackdown set to expand
summary: Netflix reported mixed earnings, adding 1.75 million subscribers in the first quarter, missing analyst estimates. The company expects a password crackdown to expand in the second quarter, which may delay some financial benefits. Despite this, Netflix remains confident in its pursuit of growth and is exploring new revenue streams, such as an ad-supported service. The company's results demonstrate the challenges it faces in a market experiencing saturation.

images.alt_text: In 2007, the company launched its streaming business, helping to put Blockbuster Entertainment, the largest DVD rental chain, out of business.
The glitch was a high-profile failure for Netflix, which is trying to expand into live programming after pioneering the model where consumers could call up shows on demand.

site_title: Broadcom releases chip for wiring together AI supercomputers
summary: Broadcom released the Jericho3-AI chip, which can connect up to 32,000 GPU chips together, addressing the need for high-speed communication in AI supercomputers. The chip competes with InfiniBand technology, currently dominated by Nvidia. Broadcom's decision not to offer a single-source, vertically integrated solution like InfiniBand is due to the competition in the Ethernet market, where multiple vendors offer the same product. This move aims to stay competitive and maintain market share.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Broadcom logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Airbnb adds Starwood to programme offering apartment rentals
summary: Airbnb has partnered with Starwood Capital Group and other landlords to expand its programme offering apartment rentals that are also eligible for short-term stays. This move aims to attract tenants who want to become hosts themselves, potentially making it easier for them to find a legal way to sublease their units. The partnership is a 43% increase from the launch of the programme last fall, allowing renters across 38 cities to browse Airbnb-friendly apartments and estimate potential income through part-time hosting.

site_title: Airbus delays some 2024 deliveries, keeps output goals
summary: Airbus has started notifying airlines about delivery delays for its A320neo family of jets in 2024, with some delays potentially lasting up to three months. The delays primarily affect the A321neo variant, which accounts for over half of Airbus deliveries. Despite confirming the delays, Airbus reaffirmed its 2024 production targets and production plans. Industry sources express concerns over supply chain problems, with some arguing that suppliers should be held accountable for delays and that airlines should be compensated.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured at the Airbus facility in Montoir-de-Bretagne near Saint-Nazaire, France, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
The disruption is a setback for Boeing just as it was regaining its footing following years of turmoil caused by the pandemic and a global grounding of the Max.

site_title: Canadian inflation slows to 4.3%, backing interest-rate pause
summary: Canadian inflation has slowed to 4.3% in March, the lowest pace in nearly two years, according to Statistics Canada. This reprieve for the Bank of Canada comes as the economy continues to defy expectations for a stall. The monthly increase was 0.5%, matching economist forecasts. The news is a relief for the Bank of Canada, which had been considering interest-rate hikes.

images.alt_text: “OSFI is preparing for the possibility, but not predicting, that the housing market will experience sustained weakness through 2023,” said Peter Routledge, superintendent at OSFI.
“You’re seeing a little bit of spillover to Canada, but honestly, it’s really been quite muted,” Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem said.

site_title: Amid macroeconomic uncertainties and greenwashing concerns, ESG investing pushes ahead
summary: Sustainable investing is expected to continue despite macroeconomic uncertainties, with a focus on just transition principles. Panellists anticipate growth in transition finance, with innovative products and services emerging to support low-carbon economies. Key drivers include increased data transparency, real success stories, and active ownership. Regulators are increasing scrutiny over ESG funds, but a balanced approach is needed to stimulate market mechanisms while ensuring transparency and disclosures. Experts expect convergence in ESG regulations, building investor confidence and promoting positive outcomes, while also addressing greenwashing concerns.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

A massive build-out of solar-panel factories and metal refineries are required over the next 20 years to deliver renewable-power generation and electricity-storage capacity to power the global economy entirely with carbon-free energy.
Marsh clients can qualify for the preferential terms by completing Marsh’s proprietary ESG Risk Rating assessment or that of an approved third-party rating methodology.
Rising natural gas prices will further drive countries like Singapore to diversify their energy sources, but challenges - such as space constraints when it comes to solar deployment - remain. PHOTO:

site_title: Over half of British do not want to  pay for King Charles III’s coronation: poll
summary: A YouGov poll found that 51% of British people do not want to pay for King Charles III's coronation on May 6, with nearly a third (32%) in favor of funding it through the government. The remaining 18% were unsure.

images.alt_text: A photograph taken on April 18, 2023 in a shop in central London, shows The official souvenir programme "Crowning of the King" celebrating Britain's King Charles III and Britain's Camilla, Queen Consort ahead of their coronation as King and Queen of the United Kingdom and Commonwealth Realm nations, on May 6, 2023. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)
“The coronation of King Charles III is a momentous occasion for the country,” said Corinne Turner, managing director of Ian Fleming Publications.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on September 5, 2022 Britain's Meghan, Duchess of Sussex and Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, react as they attend the annual One Young World Summit at Bridgewater Hall in Manchester, northwest England. - Prince Harry and his wife Meghan are being evicted from their home on the British royal family's Windsor estate, leaving them without a UK base, reports said on March 1, 2023. Frogmore Cottage, which they refurbished at a reported cost of £2.4 million ($2.9 million), had been a wedding present from the late Queen Elizabeth II in 2018. It has now been offered to Prince Andrew, King Charles III's disgraced brother, reports in The Sun and Daily Telegraph said. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: BNP Paribas' wealth management unit to launch in Thailand
summary: BNP Paribas' wealth management arm is launching in Thailand, providing clients with access to international capital markets via its Singapore platform. The unit, led by Daniel Peter as CEO, aims to expand the bank's presence in Asian markets. This move follows other global banks, such as Credit Suisse, which have established a presence in Southeast Asia to tap into the region's growing wealth.

site_title: US single-family housing starts increase in March
summary: US single-family housing starts rose 2.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 861,000 units in March, exceeding expectations. This uptick, combined with a 4.1% surge in building permits, suggests the housing market slump may be ending. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have pushed the market into recession, but recent data indicates stabilization at depressed levels. Mortgage rates have also declined, from 7.08% to 6.27% in the past few months, potentially easing the impact of tightening underwriting standards.

site_title: Lockheed Martin taps strong defence demand to beat results estimates
summary: Lockheed Martin's first-quarter results exceeded Wall Street estimates, driven by strong demand for its F-35 fighter aircraft, missiles, and other defence equipment amid rising geopolitical tensions in Europe, the South China Sea, and the Indo-Pacific region. The company reported quarterly net sales of $15.13 billion, surpassing estimates of $15.03 billion, and shares rose 2.3% in premarket trading. Lockheed reaffirmed its full-year outlook, projecting net sales between $65 billion and $66 billion and profits between $26.60 and $26.90 per share.

site_title: Netflix to exit the DVD delivery business after 25 years
summary: Netflix is shutting down its DVD delivery business after 25 years, marking the end of an era in home entertainment. The company will ship its final discs on September 29. The decision comes as the business continues to shrink, making it increasingly difficult to provide the best service for its members. Co-CEO Ted Sarandos stated that the goal has always been to provide the best service, but it's becoming difficult due to the decline of the business. This move comes 16 years after Netflix's streaming business, which helped put Blockbuster Entertainment out of business.

site_title: Southwest flights resume after brief ground stoppage due to technical issue
summary: Southwest Airlines flights resumed on April 18 after a brief nationwide ground stoppage due to an internal technical issue. The US Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) stated that the pause on departures had been fully cancelled. The airline has faced criticism over a staffing crisis and technical issues, including a 2022 tech meltdown that cancelled over 16,700 flights. Southwest reported a revenue loss of $410 million in the fourth quarter due to the flight cancellations.

site_title: Fed's Bullard discounts recession talk, favours more rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve President James Bullard expressed skepticism about recession forecasts, citing a strong labor market and persistent inflation. Despite Fed staff anticipating a "mild recession" this year, Bullard believes the economy will continue growing slowly. He favors more rate hikes to control inflation, suggesting a potential 5.50-5.75% benchmark interest rate, and cautions against making forward guidance that could be proven wrong. Bullard argues that models relying on rapid interest rate increases may be flawed, and inflation is coming down but not as fast as expected.

images.alt_text: Sony will shift its European headquarters from Britain to the Netherlands to avoid Brexit-related customs issues, but operations at its current UK company will remain unchanged, a company spokesman said Wednesday.

site_title: Credit Suisse to lose a fifth of wealth assets
summary: Credit Suisse Group is expected to lose around 110-162 billion francs (S$163.2 billion) in assets from its wealth management business following its takeover by UBS Group. This could lead to a loss of $5.4 billion in annual revenue. Julius Baer Group is predicted to benefit from the private banking money leaving the combined entity, capturing at least 10 billion francs. UBS Chairman Colm Kelleher expects the integration to take months to close and up to four years to complete.

images.alt_text: Under the deal, one UBS share will be exchanged for 22.48 shares in Credit Suisse, requiring a maximum of 178 million UBS shares to be used.

site_title: Walking the sustainability talk
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war has accelerated the shift towards greener energy sources as countries diversify their energy supply mix to secure their needs. Despite challenges from rising protectionism and sanctions, the global sustainability study by NielsenIQ found that 69% of global shoppers feel sustainability is more important to them than two years ago. Corporations with sharpened agendas are likely to benefit from investors and banks, with many companies willing to prioritize positive environmental and social impacts over financial returns. However, only 30% have made concrete sustainability commitments, highlighting the need for more tangible actions and leadership in sustainability efforts.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The three Singapore banks’ sustainable finance portfolios have grown at a rapid pace over the past three years and now represent about an eighth of combined gross customer loans.
Palawan

site_title: RBC cuts more than a dozen in US investment bank after recent layoffs
summary: Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) has conducted a second round of layoffs in its US investment-banking arm, affecting more than a dozen employees. The move follows the bank's decision to lay off 1% of the group in September. RBC Capital Markets stated that the changes are part of regular business strategy reviews and resource allocation, despite hiring senior talent from institutions like Credit Suisse Group. The bank expects its total headcount to remain flat or increase this year.

site_title: Microsoft developing its own AI chip: The Information
summary: Microsoft is developing its own AI chip, code-named "Athena", to power AI chatbots like ChatGPT. The chip, being tested by a small group of employees, aims to improve performance and reduce costs compared to external vendors. Microsoft, which partnered with ChatGPT-owner OpenAI, is accelerating the rollout following the success of ChatGPT. The company's own AI-powered search engine, Bing AI, was launched earlier this year, capitalizing on the partnership.

site_title: Disclosure system CDP invites companies to report use, production of plastic
summary: CDP, the largest corporate disclosure system globally, has invited companies to report on their plastic production and use, starting April 19, 2023. The new data fields are backed by over 740 financial institutions with $130 trillion in assets and will impact nearly 7,000 companies. This comes amid rising investor pressure on plastic disclosure, following shareholder resolutions last year from companies like Amazon, ExxonMobil, and McDonald's. Nearly 20,000 organizations disclosed data through CDP in 2022, highlighting the growing importance of plastic transparency.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
A garbage collector gathering recyclable plastic at the Ban Tarn landfill site in Chiang Mai, Thailand.

The phased-in ban on the import, manufacture and sale of plastic items such as store bags, straws, cutlery and beverage ring carriers was introduced last year as part of Ottawa’s commitment to zero plastic waste by 2030.
In their communique, the G7 members pledged to collectively increase offshore wind capacity by 150 gigawatts by 2030 and solar capacity to more than one terawatt.
Environmental activist and artist Rob Arnold setting up the machine he built to help clean up the beach in England’s south-western Cornwall region.

site_title: EU proposes 1.1 billion euro plan to counter growing cybersecurity threats
summary: The European Union has proposed a 1.1 billion euro plan to counter growing cybersecurity threats, including a 1.6 billion euro budget for a European Cybersecurity Shield and a Cyber Emergency Mechanism. The plan aims to detect, prepare for, and respond to significant cybersecurity incidents, particularly in critical sectors like healthcare, transport, and energy. The Cyber Solidarity Act will require EU country and European Parliament agreement before becoming law.

site_title: Housing market downturn among top risks to Canada’s financial system: regulator
summary: Canada's financial regulator, OSFI, has identified a potential housing market downturn and adjusting to rapid interest rate increases as top risks to the country's financial system this fiscal year. The regulator is preparing for sustained housing market weakness and intensifying monitoring of market liquidity. OSFI also warned about climate-related risks, cyberattacks, and emerging technologies. The regulator plans to issue draft guidance on debt management measures to control risk from high levels of consumer indebtedness and examine ways to increase credit quality and mortgage underwriting.

site_title: Goldman Sachs profit falls in first quarter as dealmaking sputters
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 19% decline in first-quarter profit to US$3.09 billion, largely due to sluggish dealmaking and losses from the sale of consumer loans. The bank's investment banking fees fell 26% to US$1.58 billion, while revenue from fixed income and commodities trading declined 17% and equity trading revenue fell 7%. Goldman's CEO, David Solomon, attributed the results to a "real-life stress test" and announced the bank's strategy to focus on traditional mainstays of trading and investment banking.

images.alt_text: The new offering will let Apple Card users earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, more than 10 times the national average.

Goldman Sachs agreed in 2020 to pay US$2.5 billion in cash and guarantee the return of US$1.4 billion in assets to Malaysia to settle a criminal probe into the bank’s alleged involvement in the multi-billion-US dollar scandal.

site_title: Japan’s SMFG plans to go ahead with AT1 bond issuance: source
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG) plans to issue Additional Tier-1 (AT1) debt worth approximately 140 billion yen (S$1.4 billion) to raise funds. The company will decide on the debt terms on Wednesday, according to a source. This comes amid weak investor demand and market conditions, similar to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's decision to put AT1 debt issuance on hold until mid-May. The move is part of a broader trend in the global credit market, where some AT1 bonds have been wiped out as part of rescue deals.

site_title: Safeguarding American secrets
summary: FBI agents arrested 21-year-old US National Guard airman Jack Teixeira for leaking hundreds of classified documents and government secrets onto an online chatroom. Teixeira, who had extremist right-wing views, aimed to impress the group's members by flaunting his access to and exposing US military intelligence. This incident follows previous cases of Americans revealing government secrets, including Edward Snowden and Chelsea Manning, who argued their actions were driven by a desire to expose what they considered to be illegal and harmful worldwide gathering of intelligence.

images.alt_text: FBI agents arrest Jack Teixeira, an employee of the U.S. Air Force National Guard, in connection with an investigation into the leaks online of classified U.S. documents, outside a residence in this still image taken from video in North Dighton, Massachusetts, U.S., April 13, 2023. WCVB-TV via ABC via REUTERS. ATTENTION EDITORS - NO SALES NO ARCHIVES THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY MANDATORY CREDIT
National guardsman Jack Teixeira was an airman 1st class at Otis Air National Guard Base in Massachusetts and worked as a “Cyber Transport Systems Journeyman,” or an IT specialist.

site_title: AI work sparks fierce debate after winning photo award
