summary: A German artist, Boris Eldagsen, won a prestigious photography prize with an entry generated by artificial intelligence (AI), but later rejected the prize after concluding that competitions were not equipped to handle AI entries. The Sony World Photography Awards initially accused Eldagsen of "misleading" behavior, but removed the accusation after a furious reply from Eldagsen. This incident has sparked a debate over the role of AI in art competitions, with many fearing their livelihoods are under threat from AI tools that allow anyone to create striking images.

site_title: Bank of America profit rises as it cashes in on higher interest rates
summary: Bank of America reported a first-quarter profit of 94 cents per share, beating analyst estimates, driven by higher interest payments from customers and strong sales and trading revenues. Despite a challenging economic environment, the company's net interest income rose 25% to $14.4 billion, while consumer debit and credit spending remained resilient. The bank set aside $124 million in reserves in anticipation of a worsening economy. However, investment banking fees fell 20% to $1.2 billion, and global M&A activity declined to its lowest level in over a decade.

images.alt_text: Bank of America firm has worked on 52 deals this year with an average size of US$1.5 billion.

site_title: New York tops world’s richest cities, Singapore is fifth
summary: New York has topped the list of the world's wealthiest cities, boasting 340,000 millionaires in 2023. The US surpassed all countries with 10 of the 50 richest cities, followed by Tokyo, California's Bay Area, London, and Singapore. Singapore's millionaires grew 40% between 2012 and 2022, while China followed the US with five cities in the top 50. The Bay Area had the most billionaires, with 63 calling the region home, followed by New York, Beijing, Los Angeles, and Shanghai.

images.alt_text: Number of ultra-rich living in Singapore rose last year despite pandemic: Knight Frank

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government will invest in citizens throughout their lives, requiring partnerships with industry, institutions, and individuals. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing announced plans to make mid-career training more accessible, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups. Meanwhile, UOB invested over S$500 million in a Punggol Digital District tech centre and Keppel Infrastructure Trust plans to raise S$240 million through an equity funding exercise.

site_title: PSD says ‘no information’ on Menon’s reported impending departure from MAS
summary: PSD denies reports of MAS chief Ravi Menon's impending departure, stating it has "no information to provide". Menon's term ends on May 31, and he is set to speak at the Inclusive FinTech Forum in June. A Bloomberg article suggests his former deputy Chia Der Jiun may succeed him. Despite the uncertainty, Menon has led MAS since 2011, introducing digital banking to Singapore and launching several fintech initiatives.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Monetary Authority of Singapore managing director Ravi Menon said on Thursday expectations that monetary policy tightening will end soon or even start to be eased are “excessively optimistic”.
MAS makes senior management changes
MAS exploring links for cheaper, faster cross-border payments
Coherent policy framework will enhance macroeconomic and macro-financial stability: Ravi Menon

site_title: China land sales revenue falls at slower pace in March
summary: China's land sales revenue declined 27% in the first three months of the year, a slower pace than the 29% decline in January to February. However, a series of stimulus policies have lifted developers' sentiment. Home prices rose at the fastest pace in 21 months in March, but property investment continued to decline. Experts believe the market is gradually recovering, with homebuyers regaining confidence in property developers, and a potential boost in fresh cash flow for developers in 2024.

images.alt_text: The view from the observation deck at Shanghai Tower in Shanghai. Many developers saw a decline in their profit margins as they acquired land at higher prices several years ago when the market was red hot.
Many companies expected that these young consumers would start pouring their money into the financial markets, leading a nationwide shift away from property as a source of wealth.

The view from the observation deck at Shanghai Tower in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, April 9, 2023. China's economic recovery is picking up steam after Covid restrictions were abruptly dropped and the property market stabilizes, although the rebound is still fairly patchy and policymakers have no intention yet of scaling back monetary support. site_title: Singapore to further help private capital, family offices ‘maximise philanthropic impact’
summary: Singapore will further support private capital and family offices in maximizing their philanthropic impact, including extending tax deduction rates for donations until 2026. The government aims to leverage assets, expertise, and networks to enhance opportunities for the vulnerable. Minister for Social and Family Development Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the need for social mobility, citing erosion in other advanced economies, and plans to introduce systematic onboarding processes and raise awareness about startup innovations to accelerate capital deployment.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
President Halimah Yacob says Singapore would need to strengthen its social fabric to remain united and do well in  an increasingly dangerous and troubled world post-pandemic.
Singapore will continue to sustain real income growth for the middle, which is why economic growth is “non-negotiable” for the city-state, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: ‘Far-reaching reforms’ needed to tackle economic pessimism before fertility falls further: Leon Perera
summary: WP MP Leon Perera calls for "far-reaching reforms" to address economic pessimism in Singapore, citing low total fertility rate of 1.05 and 36% of respondents feeling their families won't be better off economically in five years. He proposes a national minimum wage, redundancy insurance scheme, and lowering home prices to boost economic optimism and prevent a brain drain. Perera also advocates for lowering the voting age to 18 and overhauling trades for higher productivity and pay.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore will continue to sustain real income growth for the middle, which is why economic growth is “non-negotiable” for the city-state, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

Workers' Party Member of Parliament Jamus Lim called for a committee comprising government representatives, civil society leaders and academic experts to be set up to decide what the poverty line should be.
President Halimah Yacob says Singapore would need to strengthen its social fabric to remain united and do well in  an increasingly dangerous and troubled world post-pandemic.

site_title: Chinese province plans 30 billion yuan semiconductor fund to promote chip industry: Securities Times
summary: China's Guangdong province plans to launch a 30 billion yuan semiconductor fund to promote the chip industry, aiming to build self-reliance in key technology. The 17-year fund will invest in auto chips and equipment for semiconductor material. The first phase has reached 31 billion yuan and invested in 102 companies, with 19 seeking IPOs in 2023-2024. This move follows China's efforts to accelerate research and development of cutting-edge technologies, including semiconductors, amid increasing pressure from the US.

site_title: US dollar slides after upbeat China data; Aussie dollar, sterling rise
summary: The US dollar fell 0.4% to 101.67 against a basket of currencies after China's GDP growth data beat forecasts, while the euro rose 0.5% and the British pound jumped 0.5% due to strong pay figures. The Aussie dollar and sterling also rose, with the pound expected to prompt a potential interest rate hike by the Bank of England in May. Markets anticipate a 90% chance of a 25 basis point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in May.

site_title: EasyJet raises earnings target again as bookings remain strong
summary: EasyJet has raised its earnings target for the second time this year, citing strong bookings and robust demand during the Easter vacation. The airline now expects to beat revised market expectations of £260 million in pretax profit, up from a previous goal of £126 million. Revenue per seat is expected to rise 20% in the fiscal third quarter. EasyJet expects almost full pre-pandemic capacity during peak summer periods, driven by strong booking momentum and rising fares due to increased costs.

site_title: HSBC investor Ping An says bank’s management has failed on strategy
summary: HSBC's biggest shareholder, Ping An, has criticized the bank's management for failing to address key business model challenges. Ping An has reiterated its proposal to separate HSBC's Asia business into a Hong Kong-listed entity, citing potential benefits to shareholders. However, HSBC has dismissed the proposal, stating that alternative structural options will not deliver increased value. A shareholder advisory group, Glass Lewis, has also urged investors to vote against proposals calling for a strategic review and dividend policy revamp, deepening divisions among HSBC's ownership.

images.alt_text: OK Lim, founder of collapsed Hin Leong empire, appears in State Courts for the third day of hearing on cheating and forgery charges levelled against him by Singapore prosecutors
HSBC’s plans reflect an increasing competition to manage the growing wealth in India among both global and local firms.

site_title: Strong UK pay growth boosts chance of BOE rate rise
summary: The UK's unemployment rate rose to 3.8% in the first quarter of 2023, its highest since 2022, while annual pay growth accelerated to 5.9% and 6.6% excluding bonuses. The stronger-than-expected wage growth may prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates to 4.5% in May to combat inflation, now above 10% in February. This decision could impact the government's plans for pay rises, including a proposed 35% increase for junior doctors.

images.alt_text: Striking junior doctors, civil servants and teachers attend a rally at Trafalgar Square in London, UK, on Wednesday, March 15, 2023. About half a million British workers are striking on Wednesday as unions stage a mass walkout timed to disrupt Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt’s annual budget. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Banks: Testing post-GFC regulatory frameworks
summary: Regulators and policymakers are re-evaluating post-GFC regulatory frameworks to better cope with the digital banking era. Recent bank failures, such as Silicon Valley Bank, highlight the need for improved oversight, particularly for small and mid-sized US banks. The current framework has been tested by global shocks, including the pandemic and energy shock, but lessons from these tests suggest that policymakers must rewrite protocols to guard against bank runs. The lack of effective liquidity measures and oversight of non-bank lenders also pose significant risks to financial stability.

images.alt_text: The largest daily outflows were recorded on Mar 21, two days after the transaction was announced, when US$813 million were pulled.
First-quarter 2023 earnings from JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo beat Wall Street expectations.

site_title: Apple craze draws long queues at opening of first India store
summary: About 200 Apple fans gathered outside India's first Apple store in Mumbai on April 18, 2023, for the store's opening. The 2,600 sqm store was inaugurated by Chief Executive Tim Cook, marking Apple's growing ambitions in the Indian market. The tech giant has previously faced hurdles in opening physical stores in India but has been expanding iPhone assembly via contract manufacturers and boosting exports. A second store in Delhi is set to open on Thursday, as Apple aims to make India a bigger manufacturing base.

images.alt_text: The new offering will let Apple Card users earn a 4.15 per cent annual yield, more than 10 times the national average.
Google has for decades dominated the search market with a share of over 80 per cent, but Wall Street fears the company could be falling behind Microsoft in a fast-moving AI race.

China’s smartphone surge comes after Samsung and Apple both curtailed sales in Russia over the conflict in Ukraine, with Chinese manufacturers Xiaomi and Realme now occupying the market’s top two spots.

site_title: Singapore to boost mid-career support, make training ‘more accessible’
summary: Singapore is set to boost mid-career support and make training more accessible for working adults with competing commitments. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing announced plans to enhance SkillsFuture Credit top-ups and partner with industry, institutions, and individuals to provide targeted support for mid-career workers. The government will also invest in lifelong learning opportunities, such as work-study programs and stackable modules, to help Singaporeans stay relevant and competitive in the job market.

Economic pessimism could be a reason for Singapore’s low total fertility rate (TFR), he said, adding that studies have shown a causal link in Singapore between high home prices and low TFR, which fell to a record low of 1.05 last year.

site_title: EU Parliament backs overhaul of Europe’s biggest climate policy
summary: The European Parliament has approved sweeping reforms to the EU's climate policy, aiming to cut emissions by 62% from 2005 levels by 2030. Factories will lose free CO2 permits by 2034, and shipping emissions will be added to the CO2 market from 2024. A carbon border levy on high-carbon imports will also be phased in from 2026, targeting steel, cement, and other polluting goods. The laws need final approval from EU countries, but the reform is seen as crucial to meeting the bloc's ambitious climate targets.

site_title: Three-day Paddock Club tickets at F1 Singapore GP snapped up despite price crossing five figures
summary: The 2023 Formula One Singapore Grand Prix has sold out its three-day Paddock Club tickets, with prices reaching $11,016, a 10% increase from 2022. Despite the high prices, organizers reported strong sales, with only limited single-day tickets remaining. Other ticket categories, including grandstand seats and walkabout tickets, are still available at various price points. The event will feature a new three-storey atrium structure and award-winning restaurants, and will include performances by Robbie Williams, Post Malone, and Jackson Wang.

site_title: Norway’s wealth fund aims to root out ‘rotten apple’ stocks
summary: Norway's $1.4 trillion sovereign wealth fund plans to intensify efforts to identify and divest from unsound companies amid recent global banking and industry turmoil. The fund's CEO, Nicolai Tangen, stated that identifying problematic investments early can help save money. Notable losses include the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse, with the fund losing a considerable sum on both incidents. Tangen aims to find "rotten apples" and sell shares in companies like Adani Group, which experienced a 51% loss in value this year.

images.alt_text: The transaction is part of Iberdola’s plan to sell minority stakes in renewable developments to finance its climate action plan.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts 12.5% fall in adjusted distributable income for Q1
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported a 12.5% decline in adjusted distributable income for Q1 2023 to US$13.1 million, mainly due to divestments of properties in Atlanta and higher financing costs. The Reit's manager attributed the decline to divestments in the second half of 2022 and rising interest rates. Gross revenue and net property income also fell, with KORE's aggregate leverage at 38.7% and no long-term refinancing requirements until Q4 2024.

Financial stresses on the US office Reits are well documented. Share prices of Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit slumped as the market reassessed their financial stability and tenant risk.
S-Reits that are scheduled to release their results for the full-year ending March include Aims Apac Reit and the trio of Mapletree Reits.
Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's 105 Edgeview property (above) in Denver. The Reit posted a lower H2 2022 DPU of US$0.0278, down 12.6 per cent from its DPU of US$0.0318 a year ago.

site_title: G7 to back Ukraine indefinitely, seeks stability with China
summary: The Group of Seven nations pledged indefinite support for Ukraine in its fight against Russian forces, while also seeking to stabilize relations with China. The G7 condemned Russia's war in Ukraine "in the strongest possible terms" and reiterated support for Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelenskiy's peace plan. The bloc also called for a "peaceful resolution" of Taiwan-related issues and expressed concern about China's growing nuclear arsenal. The G7 ministers emphasized the importance of engaging candidly with China and working together on common interests, while maintaining one-China policies on Taiwan.

images.alt_text: In their communique, the G7 members pledged to collectively increase offshore wind capacity by 150 gigawatts by 2030 and solar capacity to more than one terawatt.

site_title: Netflix scraps ‘Love Is Blind’ live event after technical failure
summary: Netflix delayed its live reunion episode of "Love Is Blind" by 19 hours due to a technical failure, prompting widespread outages and apologies from the company. The glitch, which affected thousands of users, marked a high-profile failure for Netflix as it tries to expand into live programming. The episode was eventually made available to stream, with co-host Vanessa Lachey saying "we're no longer live, but we are now finally here." The incident comes as Netflix prepares to report first-quarter results.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Netflix logo is seen on a TV remote controller, in this illustration taken January 20, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Crypto lender Babel’s creditor protection extended
summary: Babel Finance, a Hong Kong-based crypto lender, has had its creditor protection extended by about three months until July 21, 2023. The company, which owes up to $800 million to creditors, had initially sought a longer period of protection to pursue a restructuring plan that would repay debt using revenue from a new decentralized finance project. The plan was opposed by Deribit, the largest Bitcoin and Ether options exchange, which had requested an independent adviser to monitor the plan. Babel's co-founder, Flex Yang, will oversee the company's restructuring after stepping down from day-to-day operations in 2021.

site_title: Tougher laws mean money mules can’t claim ignorance when selling bank, Singpass accounts to scammers
summary: Singapore is introducing new laws to crack down on money mules and those who sell their bank and Singpass accounts to scammers. The amendments aim to empower the police to prosecute individuals who facilitate criminal activities by making it easier to prove their intent. The new laws will impose stricter penalties, including up to 5 years in jail and fines of up to $250,000, for rash money laundering and up to 3 years in jail and fines of up to $10,000 for obtaining or dealing in Singpass credentials to facilitate criminal activities. This move comes after scammers lost a total of $660.7 million from Singaporeans in 2022.

site_title: JPMorgan, Citi upgrade China’s 2023 full-year GDP growth forecast; Goldman unchanged
summary: JPMorgan and Citigroup have upgraded China's 2023 full-year GDP growth forecast to 6.4% and 6.1%, respectively, citing the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions in December. The stronger-than-expected first-quarter growth of 4.5% year-on-year was driven by a rebound in travel-related consumption and services. Goldman Sachs maintains its forecast at 6.0%. Experts expect growth momentum to soften in the second half of the year due to external sector uncertainty and macro policy support. Policymakers face structural challenges such as youth unemployment and local government debt.

images.alt_text: China’s recovery has so far remained uneven, with consumption, services and infrastructure spending perking up but slowing prices and surging bank savings raising doubts about demand.

site_title: STI down 0.3% as key Apac bourses close in the red
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,309.56 points on Tuesday, with most key Asia-Pacific indices closing in the red. The decline was attributed to uneven Chinese economic recovery data, which showed fixed asset investment and industrial production figures fell short of expectations. Sembcorp Industries was the worst performer, dropping 1.4% to S$4.25. Banking indices, including OCBC, UOB, and DBS, also declined, with OCBC down 0.8% and UOB down 0.7%.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

If the AT1 bondholders are successful, they will not have to pay for the suit and will have a chance of getting perhaps 15 per cent to 20 per cent of their monies back, says WilmerHale partner Jonathan Lim.
Gainers marginally outnumber losers 56 to 54 after 31.3 million securities worth S$31 million changes hands.

DBS analysts believe that Credit Bureau Asia, as the dominant market leader in Singapore and sole market player in Cambodia and Myanmar, is the “leading player” in credit risk and information solutions in Asean.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei and Manila markets all dipped but Tokyo and Jakarta markets edged up at midday on Tuesday.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.3 per cent to end at 33,987.18 on Monday..

site_title: Seven & i says ValueAct’s proposal risks destroying value
summary: ValueAct Capital Management's proposal to appoint four new directors for Seven & i Holdings risks destroying shareholder value, the company said in presentation materials. The nominees have no relevant experience in the rapidly evolving industry, while Seven & i's existing nominees have deep knowledge of the business. ValueAct wants Seven & i to narrow its business focus to 7-Eleven, which could become a global champion as a convenience store franchise and boost the company's value. Seven & i has already revamped its board and agreed to sell several business units, and its shares have risen 6.4% this year.

images.alt_text: ValueAct, which owns a 4.4 per cent stake in Seven & i, is calling for a spin-off of its 7-Eleven convenience store chain and seeks to replace four of the 14 board members at the annual meeting.

site_title: MAS chief Menon set to leave; Chia taking top job
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon is set to leave the central bank this year, with his term ending May 31. Chia Der Jiun, a former deputy, is tipped to succeed him, marking a return to MAS after a stint at the Ministry of Manpower. Chia, a 16-year MAS veteran, will take over as the MAS's top job, succeeding Menon who has been at the helm since 2011.

images.alt_text: MAS-co-chaired private banking industry group PBIG says it noted at a recent meeting that sources of Singapore overall inflows remain diversified, despite public commentary's tendency to focus on inflows from China.
MAS says it will maintain the prevailing rate of appreciation of the S$NEER policy band.

site_title: Once-dominant foreign auto brands pledge comeback in China
summary: Global automakers Toyota and Volkswagen have pledged to make a comeback in China's auto market by introducing new electric vehicle models and cutting development times to keep pace with Chinese rivals. Toyota unveiled two new EVs and a hybrid minivan, while Volkswagen plans to introduce 10 more EV models by 2026. BYD, a Chinese automaker, has already outsold both Toyota and VW in China's first quarter of this year, and has launched a new EV priced under $11,000. Other automakers, including BMW, have also announced plans to launch new EV models in China to compete for market share.

images.alt_text: The Ariya is supposed to be the first of 19 new battery EVs that Nissan has said it plans to roll out by 2030.

site_title: China, HK stocks mixed on uneven recovery trends in Q1 growth data
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index rose 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.23% on Tuesday, driven by a 4.5% year-on-year growth in the first quarter. However, industrial output rose only 3.9% in March, missing expectations, and property investment fell 5.8% year-on-year. The mixed data led to a mixed trading session, with Hong Kong-listed mainland property firms and tech giants declining, while insurance companies and telecom stocks gained. Analysts say the data suggests an uneven recovery trend and structural problems in the Chinese economy.

images.alt_text: China’s recovery has so far remained uneven, with consumption, services and infrastructure spending perking up but slowing prices and surging bank savings raising doubts about demand.
China’s economy grew at a faster-than-expected rate in the first quarter, official data showed on Tuesday (Apr 18).

site_title: Keppel DC Reit Q1 DPU up 3% on contributions from acquisitions, asset management drive
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.541 Singapore cents for its first quarter, driven by contributions from acquisitions, asset management, and tax savings. Gross revenue rose 6.5% to S$70.4 million, while net property income grew 6.3% to S$63.9 million. The Reit's finance costs increased due to refinanced loans and foreign currency depreciation. Despite higher finance costs, the Reit's portfolio occupancy remained stable at 98.5% and weighted average lease expiry at 8.2 years.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
S-Reits that are scheduled to release their results for the full-year ending March include Aims Apac Reit and the trio of Mapletree Reits.
Keppel DC Reit's two data centres in Guangdong, which contributed in part to its growth in distributable income for H2 FY2022.

site_title: Singapore looks ahead with confidence as the shipping industry evolves
summary: Singapore is set to host the Singapore Maritime Week (SMW), a major event for the global shipping industry, next week. The week-long event will feature keynote speeches, panel discussions, and exhibitions on key topics such as decarbonisation and the Maritime Green Transition. The International Maritime Organization's (IMO) Secretary-General, Kitack Lim, is expected to address the challenge of decarbonising shipping. The event also includes the Singapore Shipping Forum 2023, which will focus on current and imminent challenges facing the maritime industry, and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced a new collaboration with Shell to expand maritime decarbonisation efforts in Singapore.

images.alt_text: IMO's legal committee says ship-to-ship transfers on the high seas are high-risk activities that undermine the international regime with respect to maritime safety and environmental protection.

site_title: Luno ceases Singapore crypto exchange, withdraws licence application
summary: Luno Singapore has announced the closure of its cryptocurrency exchange on June 20, 2023, and has advised customers to withdraw all funds by June 19, 2023. The company has also informed the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) of its intention to withdraw its licence application, which received in-principle approval last year. This decision was made as part of a regular evaluation of its global strategy and presence.

site_title: Court documents detail Evercore’s ties with ex-Hwa Hong director and how the investment bank was appointed
summary: Evercore, an investment bank, was hired by Hwa Hong's former director David Ong in September 2021 to sell his shares before a privatisation offer was made. The Securities Industry Council (SIC) had sought information on the fee payable to Evercore if the Sanjuro offer turned unconditional. Documents show that Ong hired Evercore on a personal basis, covering a potential sale of shares by other Ong family members. Hwa Hong is refusing to pay Evercore's fees, leading to a court case. The case was dismissed in March, but the dispute continues, with Hwa Hong suing Evercore and four former directors over S$8.6 million owed.

site_title: What ESG news matters most to markets?
summary: Research conducted by Aaron Yoon and George Serafeim found that ESG investors are primarily motivated by financial factors, reacting positively to positive ESG news and strongly to media coverage of such news. This contrasts with past research, which suggested ESG investors were driven by non-pecuniary factors. The study's findings suggest that investors prioritize financially material ESG news, particularly when it affects a company's fundamentals, over social capital issues.

site_title: City Energy explores importing hydrogen from Malaysia to Singapore
summary: City Energy, a Singaporean gas utility provider, is exploring the feasibility of importing hydrogen from Malaysia to meet its growing demand. The move follows Singapore's launch of an import-reliant hydrogen strategy, aiming to source up to half of its power needs from hydrogen by 2050. City Energy has partnered with Gentari, a Petronas-owned clean energy company, to develop a hydrogen supply chain, which will contribute to Singapore's hydrogen strategy and help the company stay relevant in the industry.

If successful in scaling up the use of green hydrogen, Singapore's maritime, aviation and manufacturing sectors can tap low-carbon hydrogen and decarbonise.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Bitcoin miners escape the bear trap
summary: Bitcoin miners are experiencing a resurgence in profitability after the cryptocurrency's price rally to above $30,000 this year, easing pressure on their operations. The 30-day average mining revenue has risen to $27.34 million, the highest level since June 2022, thanks to falling electricity prices and increased revenues. Many miners, who were on the brink of bankruptcy, have seen their debt-to-equity ratios improve, with some companies restructuring and paying down debt. However, the miners' fortunes are still tied to bitcoin's volatile price, and a potential decline in price could usher in a new cold spell.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of bitcoin is seen in an illustration picture taken on June 23, 2017. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: China Mobile explores acquiring Hong Kong telecom firm HKBN: sources
summary: China Mobile is exploring a potential takeover of Hong Kong telecom firm HKBN, valued at US$1 billion, after infrastructure investor I Squared Asia Advisors submitted a non-binding letter of interest in March. China Mobile sent a request for proposal to a small group of banks to advise on acquiring and taking-private HKBN. The Beijing-based company is still receiving pitches and has yet to decide on making a formal offer.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS initiates coverage on Credit Bureau Asia with ‘hold’; S$1.02 target price
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) with a "hold" call, citing a limited upside to the company's share price despite its defensive business model and strong dividend yields. The analysts forecast a two-stage dividend growth model, with a target price of S$1.02 and a sustainable dividend growth rate of 2% from FY2026 onwards.

images.alt_text: William Lim, CBS’ executive director, said the five digital banks will enrich CBS’ data repository as they use innovative technologies to reach out to more consumers.
Credit Bureau Asia's executive director William Lim said the inclusion of digital banks in CBA's member network will create a multiplier effect.

site_title: Musk says he is out to create ‘truth-seeking’ AI
summary: Elon Musk plans to create "TruthGPT," an AI system that prioritizes truth and accuracy over political correctness, to counter Microsoft and Google's AI efforts. Musk expressed concerns about AI's potential for "civilisational destruction" and worries that OpenAI's ChatGPT is being taught to be politically correct. He has founded X.AI, a rival to OpenAI, and is working to develop an AI system that can understand the nature of the universe and avoid annihilating humans. Musk's move comes after he signed an open letter urging a halt in AI development to ensure safety and regulation.

images.alt_text: The 12 MEPs, all working on EU legislation on the technology, called on US President Joe Biden and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen to convene the meeting, and said AI firms should be more responsible.
Several online posts claimed workers at the Tesla's Shanghai plant were being unfairly penalised for an incident this year at the factory in February where one worker died.
Tesla cut prices on Real-Wheel Drive version of both Model 3 and Model Y by S$4,000 (US$3,020), and Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive version of the two models by S$5,000, the website showed.

site_title: UOB invests S$500 million in Punggol Digital District tech and innovation centre
summary: UOB is investing over S$500 million to build a 300,000 square foot technology and innovation centre in Punggol Digital District, set to be completed in 2026. The centre will house around 3,000 staff in technology, innovation, and digital roles, furthering the bank's digital ambitions. This is UOB's largest commercial investment in Punggol Digital District to date, with the bank becoming one of the largest employers in the district.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The jury is still out on whether smart cities truly live up to their ambition of offering people a better quality of life -- which is more than the promise of easy, safe, and ecological living.

site_title: Wall of worry or another brick wall?
summary: A "wall of worry" refers to a period of improving stock market performance despite logic suggesting it shouldn't be happening. This phenomenon was seen in 2008 after Lehman Brothers' collapse, where investors initially panicked before some noticed market segments becoming cheap. Today, similar concerns over credit, quantitative tightening, and deglobalisation are causing market turmoil. However, the presence of sceptical bears indicates that there are still prospective converts capable of pushing the market to new highs, making it unlikely that the wall of worry will be conquered soon, and potentially beneficial for long-term investors.

site_title: S-Reits losing appeal: Average yield of 6% is not good enough
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are losing appeal due to their average yield of 6%, which is not considered sufficient. Investors are expected to demand a yield of over 7% from S-Reits, based on historical yield spreads and 10-year government bond yields. Financial stresses on US office Reits, such as Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, have also been documented, leading to share price slumps.

images.alt_text: S-Reits that are scheduled to release their results for the full-year ending March include Aims Apac Reit and the trio of Mapletree Reits.
Tanasbourne is a 132,851 square foot office campus comprising three flex-office buildings. It was constructed between 1986 and 1995, and was refurbished in 2015, 2017 and 2020.

site_title: UBS makes changes to buyback programme following Credit Suisse takeover
summary: UBS is modifying its $6 billion share buyback program following its acquisition of Credit Suisse. Under the deal, one UBS share will be exchanged for 22.48 shares in Credit Suisse, requiring a maximum of 178 million UBS shares to be used. The changes come after UBS obtained approval from the Swiss Takeover Board to use some of the shares for the takeover instead of cancelling them.

site_title: Ericsson’s quarterly core profit beats expectations
summary: Ericsson reported first-quarter core earnings that beat expectations, with 4 billion Swedish crowns (S$515.7 million) beating analysts' mean forecast of 3.28 billion. The company's growth now mainly comes from price-competitive markets like India, offsetting lower sales in high-margin countries like the US. Overall margins eroded due to this shift in growth drivers.

site_title: Parliament to debate Bill extending virtual AGMs, shareholder meetings beyond Covid-19 measures
summary: Singapore Parliament is set to debate a Bill that would extend the use of virtual annual general meetings and shareholder meetings beyond July 1, when existing Covid-19 measures are scheduled to be revoked. The proposed changes, part of the Companies, Business Trusts and Other Bodies Bill, would allow companies to hold virtual meetings even after the pandemic measures are lifted. If passed, companies would be able to use virtual meeting technology for various meetings, including annual general meetings, shareholder meetings, and extraordinary general meetings. The Bill aims to provide flexibility for companies to adapt to changing circumstances.

images.alt_text: Physical AGMs have become possible with the removal of pandemic curbs, but retaining a digital option would allow more shareholders to access such meetings.
City Developments Ltd and Wilmar International are offering a virtual format in addition to a physical meeting, giving shareholders the best of both modes.

Yap Jia Rern, who heads Azeus’ division for its virtual meeting platform ConveneAGM, said a physical or virtual AGM costs at least S$5,000 while charges for a hybrid AGM can be 2 or 3 times that amount.
Virtual AGMs on extended run but challenges remain

site_title: Sydney house prices may have bottomed as supply stays tight
summary: Sydney house prices may have bottomed due to a tight supply of homes and a pause in central bank rate hikes. In March, Sydney posted the largest monthly price gain at 1.4%, followed by Melbourne and Perth, resulting in a 0.8% increase for major cities. Analysts attribute the growth to reduced new home and apartment completions, as well as sellers holding out for market stabilization. This may signal a muted property recovery in Australia for 2023 due to ongoing affordability constraints.

images.alt_text: The Australian central bank's decision to keep interest rates unchanged this week doesn't imply an end to its policy tightening cycle, RBA Governor Philip Lowe said, reinforcing his long-held resolve to return inflation to its 2-3 per cent target.
Confidence is still 10.4 per cent below the level in April 2022, the month before the RBA began raising rates.

site_title: Why the global economy is becoming ever more confusing
summary: The global economy is experiencing uncertainty, likened to the enigmatic smile of the Mona Lisa, due to the post-pandemic chaos in the banking industry. Analysts now expect a "hard-landing" recession, whereas just weeks ago, a "no-landing" scenario was considered fashionable. The range of expectations for American GDP growth has widened, with the IMF using the word "uncertainty" over 60 times in its latest global outlook. Key figures, including Christine Lagarde, have expressed uncertainty about future economic paths, making forecasting extremely challenging.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product will likely expand 2.8 per cent this year and 3 per cent next year, each 0.1 percentage point less than forecast in January.
World Bank President David Malpass told a media briefing that the upward revision was due to an improved outlook for China’s recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Merdeka Battery soars 15% on debut as investors drawn to Indonesia’s EV push
summary: Merdeka Battery, a unit of Merdeka Copper Gold, surged 15.1% in its trading debut after raising 8.75 trillion rupiah (S$783 million) in Indonesia's third-largest IPO this year. The company's positive debut signals investors' growing appetite for Indonesia's nickel processing sector, which is part of the electric vehicle supply chain. The IPO was oversubscribed, with strong interest from sovereign wealth funds, insurance firms, and local investors. Merdeka Battery plans to use the proceeds for loan repayment, working capital, and capital expenditure.

images.alt_text: Merdeka Battery is tapping into the surging global demand for electric cars by refining its nickel into battery materials.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds rates, sees inflation cooling sooner
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated that headline inflation is on track to return to the target sooner than initially expected. The bank kept its benchmark interest rates unchanged for a third consecutive meeting, citing a strengthening rupiah currency and a commodities-led export boom. Despite a slowdown in growth expected due to global policy tightening, Bank Indonesia predicted inflation would return to its target of 2-4% sooner. The decision was made as 30 economists polled by Reuters expected the rate change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Indonesia's Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo arrives for a media briefing at Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/File Photo
Indonesia’s tax take rose dramatically in 2022 amid high global commodity prices, and this year’s revenues have remained strong.
Indonesia saw its exports rise to a record high last year on high global commodity prices, but shipments have gradually slowed as prices moderate.

site_title: Hong Kong luxury home sells for HK$577 million after border reopens
summary: A luxury mansion in Hong Kong's Mount Nicholson project sold for HK$577 million (S$98 million) after the city's borders reopened, signaling a resurgence in the luxury property market. The 7,042 sq ft home sold for HK$82,000 per square foot, with records not revealing the buyer's identity.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop but pare losses after China data
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday but narrowed losses after China's economy expanded 4.5% in the first quarter, exceeding expectations and reviving optimism for a recovery. The growth, combined with above-forecast retail sales, suggests a return to normalcy after three years of COVID restrictions. However, inflation data remains sluggish, and investors are still concerned about Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The Wall Street indexes ended slightly higher, with a surprise jump in a New York state manufacturing index adding to buying sentiment.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past an electronic display showing the closing figure of the Hang Seng Index outside the Hang Seng Bank Ltd. headquarters in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, April 9, 2015. Hong Kong stocks surged the most since 2009 amid volume more than four times the average and a frenzy of buying by mainland investors. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg
Asian equities rose in early trade on Friday, with Tokyo leading the way followed by Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Geopolitics meets geoeconomics
summary: The International Monetary Fund warns that fragmented capital flows along geopolitical fault lines could have negative spillovers to the global economy, reflecting a growing rift between China and the West. The IMF's paper notes the emergence of regional economic blocs, replacing the integrated global market of the post-Cold War era. This shift is driven by rival economic alignments, particularly between China and the US, which affects key industries such as high technology. The IMF's warning highlights the challenges in stabilizing the global economy during a time of increasing decoupling.

images.alt_text: The IMF has warned that risks are high, and reducing debt vulnerabilities should be an “overriding priority", especially in low-income developing countries.
Other officials in the briefing also called for all creditors to participate, without mentioning China by name.
Market scene in Colombo, March 20, 2023. Cash-strapped Sri Lanka was seeking a 10-year moratorium on its foreign debt.

site_title: Australia, China agriculture ministers meet amid diplomatic thaw
summary: Australia and China have made progress in improving agriculture ties, with the resumption of trade in barley after a meeting between Agriculture Minister Murray Watt and Chinese Vice Minister Ma Youxiang. The agreement comes after China resumed purchases of Australian coal and beef imports. Australia expects to reach a deal with China on wine tariffs, following the easing of diplomatic tensions since the Labor government returned to power last year. The two countries are working to remove punitive tariffs on Australian wine, which have caused a significant decline in wine exports to mainland China.

images.alt_text: China's GDP is tipped to have risen 4.0 per cent in January-March from a year earlier, a Reuters poll showed, quickening from 2.9 per cent in the fourth quarter.

(FILES) This file photo taken on March 26, 2023 shows cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports rose in March for the first time in six months, customs data showed on April 13, as the world's second-largest economy continued its recovery following the end of onerous coronavirus curbs late last year. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Why is Chartreuse hard to find right now? Ask the monks who make it
summary: The French Alps' Chartreuse liqueur, made by Carthusian monks for over 200 years, is hard to find due to a decline in production to match rising demand. The monks, who produce 1.6 million bottles per year, have capped production to limit environmental impact and focus on solitude and prayer. This decision has led to a global shortage, with US sales doubling in 2020 and reaching $30 million in 2022. Retailers and hospitality professionals are feeling the pinch, but demand shows no signs of waning, raising concerns that Chartreuse's popularity may inflate its price.

images.alt_text: The flavour of cocuy, which is made mostly in the western states of Lara and Falcon, is distinct from tequila and mezcal, as the drink is made from a different type of agave.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 4.49 points to 3,314.77. Despite Wall Street gains overnight, local stocks were affected by the regional market. Gainers marginally outnumbered losers 56 to 54, with Thomson Medical trading flat. Other heavily traded securities included Sembcorp Marine down 0.9% and Dyna-Mac Holdings up 6.3%. Local banks traded mixed, with UOB up 0.1%, OCBC down 0.3%, and DBS also down 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure Trust requested a trading halt on Tuesday morning before it announced plans to raise gross proceeds through an equity fundraising exercise.

site_title: Hong Kong Stock Exchange to tighten climate disclosure rules
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange plans to implement stricter climate-related disclosure rules for listed companies, aligning with the International Sustainability Standards Board's guidelines. Starting in January, companies must report transition plans, measure and disclose Scope 3 emissions, and quantify climate-related risks and opportunities. IPO applicants will also have to disclose material ESG information in their prospectuses. The proposal is open for feedback until July 14, and the exchange aims to consolidate its position as a leading green and sustainable finance hub.

site_title: Gold flat as investors await clarity on Fed policy
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,994.85 per ounce on Tuesday as investors awaited clarity on the US Federal Reserve's interest rate policy. The Fed is expected to hike rates in May, which may reduce gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties. The CME FedWatch tool shows a 91% chance of a 25-basis-point rate hike in May. Investors will monitor comments from Fed officials before the Fed's May meeting, which begins on April 22.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 0.2 per cent at US$1,999.12 per ounce, as of 0121 GMT. US gold futures fell 0.3 per cent to US$2,009.00.

site_title: Australia’s central bank actively considered April rate hike before deciding on pause
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) considered hiking interest rates for an 11th time in April but decided to pause, citing a surprise surge in migration and pay rises for public workers. The decision was a close call, but the RBA felt it was best to hold for now and assess the impact of previous rate hikes. RBA Governor Philip Lowe emphasized that the pause doesn't imply the increases are over and that the central bank may tighten further if inflation and consumer demand remain high.

images.alt_text: Australia expects to reach a deal with China in its dispute over wine tariffs after the agreement on barley.

Chinese tourists pose for a photographer (not pictured) near the Sydney Opera House in a file photo. After three years of struggle and anticipation, the widely expected wave of returning Chinese tourists Down Under has turned out to be a trickle.
The Australian dollar firmed 0.4 per cent to US$0.6713, having rallied 0.6 per cent overnight.
Australia's jobless rate stayed at 3.5 per cent, when analysts had looked for a nudge up to 3.6 per cent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: USP Group
summary: Minority shareholders of USP Group plan to remove the CEO and non-executive chairman, and appoint four new directors, including an executive director. The move aims to inject new projects into the company. Meanwhile, Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has announced plans to raise at least S$240 million through an equity fundraising exercise, including a private placement and preferential offering. The company's shares closed flat on Monday at S$0.515.

site_title: Breaking the debt-relief paralysis
summary: Sri Lanka's economic crisis, which led to widespread shortages and famine, has prompted the International Monetary Fund to seek a 10-year moratorium on foreign debt. This move comes as 21 poor countries are either in default or awaiting loan restructuring. The IMF's approval is conditional on assurances from holdout creditors, including China, that they will agree to a restructuring. The delays are due to the IMF's charter requiring sustainable economic activity to be restored before lending. The government's policy mix will also play a crucial role in economic recovery.

images.alt_text: China said it is willing to implement a debt disposal framework with other countries, People’s Bank of China Governor Yi Gang said in remarks published on Friday.
Other officials in the briefing also called for all creditors to participate, without mentioning China by name.
Kantamanto market in Accra, Ghana, Nov 30, 2022. Ghana recently became only the fourth country to apply for support under the G20's Common Framework facility.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to launch equity funding exercise to raise at least S$240 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) plans to launch an equity funding exercise to raise at least S$240 million, with a private placement and non-renounceable preferential offering to be conducted by joint lead managers and underwriters. The exercise aims to raise gross proceeds of approximately S$125 million and S$115 million, respectively, and will not exceed 15.2% of KIT units in issue. The funds will be used for partial repayment of bridge facilities and payment of fees and expenses. The placement is expected to launch on April 18 and close on April 19, while the preferential offering will begin on May 2 and close on May 10.

images.alt_text: The property player is in talks for the proposed acquisition of the St Katharine Docks (SKD) development in London, United Kingdom.
KIT received its first distribution from Aramco Gas Pipeline Company, which helped to boost distributable income for 3Q 2022.
Jopy Chiang assumed the role of chief executive at KIT’s trustee-manager just over a year ago.

site_title: Katong Shopping Centre up for en bloc sale again at S$638 million
summary: FREEHOLD Katong Shopping Centre, Singapore's first air-conditioned mall, is being offered for collective sale at S$638 million. The 86,924 sq ft corner land plot in District 15 has a dual road frontage and a total GFA of approximately 280,000 sq ft. The existing building comprises 425 strata shop and office units, and a privately-held carpark. The sale price represents a gross plot ratio (GPR) of 3.223. The sale is the second attempt at en bloc sale for the property.

images.alt_text: Haig Road flats sold en bloc above owners' asking price at S$49.3m on 3rd attempt
Meyer Park overlooks a two-storey landed housing estate with a sweeping sea view and is well-connected to several expressways, including the Marina Coastal Expressway.

site_title: Manchester United tanks on report Glazers may avoid sale with new investment
summary: Manchester United's stock fell 13% after a report said the Glazer family is confident of securing an investment to retain ownership. The investment is expected to double the club's value over 10 years, according to ESPN. The Glazers had started weighing options, including new investment or a potential sale, after buying the club for £790 million in 2005. US private equity firm Carlyle Group is in talks about a "major" investment as the auction enters its final stages.

images.alt_text: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe and Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad Al-Thani, the son of the former emir of Qatar, are in the final round of bidding to buy the team from the Glazers, an American family that has owned the club since 2005.

Old Trafford stadium, home ground of the Manchester United football team. The American owners of the team, the Glazer family, said they were willing to listen to offers for the Premier League club last November.
Several offers are understood to have been received in recent weeks but Sheikh Jassim and Ratcliffe remain the front runners to buy Manchester United should the Glazers give up control of the club.
Net profit came in at £6.3 million (S$10.3 million) in the quarter, compared with a loss of £1.4 million a year earlier.

site_title: How businesses should view China in a post-Covid world
summary: China is increasingly taking on a leadership role globally, brokering diplomatic deals, and engaging with world leaders. President Xi Jinping has hosted numerous high-profile business meetings, including a recent gathering of 69 foreign CEOs and 20 international guests. This move underscores China's growing influence and its desire for a symbiotic relationship with other countries, as exemplified by its partnership with Apple. China's growing presence in international affairs suggests a shift in its global strategy, with implications for global politics, trade, and business.

images.alt_text: Chew Shou Zi, TikTok’s chief executive was attacked relentlessly by US lawmakers who were described by TikTok supporters as “old, tech-illiterate, out of touch, paranoid and self-righteous".
Reflecting the decline in confidence in China, almost half of US firms which are already in the market plan no new investments, while another 9 per cent are planning to cut investment.

site_title: Apple, Goldman Sachs debut savings account with 4.15% annual yield
summary: Apple has introduced a high-yield savings account with Goldman Sachs Group, offering a 4.15% annual yield to Apple Card users, more than 10 times the national average. The account has no fees, minimum deposit or balance requirements, and can be set up within the Wallet app. This move aims to attract US financial clients and potentially increase pressure on other financial firms. The account has a maximum balance of $250,000, and Apple plans to generate revenue from services, building on its existing 20% service revenue.

site_title: China’s economic recovery picks up speed as Covid-19 curbs end
summary: China's economy experienced a 4.5% year-on-year growth in the first quarter, beating analyst forecasts, as Covid-19 curbs were lifted. The recovery remains uneven, with consumption and services growing but prices slowing and bank savings surging. Analysts expect a 5.4% growth rate for 2023, and the government has set a 5% growth target. The central bank maintains ample liquidity and focus on expanding demand, and separate data showed retail sales growth quickened to 10.6% and factory output growth sped up.

images.alt_text: Many companies expected that these young consumers would start pouring their money into the financial markets, leading a nationwide shift away from property as a source of wealth.

BYD’s sales in China are up almost 69 per cent this year, giving it an 11 per cent share of the overall car market, more than the Volkswagen brand or the Toyota brand, according to an analysis of sales data.

(FILES) This file photo taken on March 26, 2023 shows cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports rose in March for the first time in six months, customs data showed on April 13, as the world's second-largest economy continued its recovery following the end of onerous coronavirus curbs late last year. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: China’s GDP recovery likely picked up in Q1 on end to Covid-19 curbs
summary: China's GDP is expected to have risen 4.0% in the first quarter, a Reuters poll showed, as the country's economy recovers from the pandemic slump. The growth rate quickened from 2.9% in the fourth quarter, driven by easing Covid-19 curbs. However, some headwinds persist, including slowing inflation and rising bank savings. Analysts expect China's growth in 2023 to speed up to 5.4%, with the government setting a modest target of 5% for this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on March 26, 2023 shows cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports rose in March for the first time in six months, customs data showed on April 13, as the world's second-largest economy continued its recovery following the end of onerous coronavirus curbs late last year. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 170 billion yuan (S$33 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.75 per cent from the previous operation.

Chinese President Xi Jinping speaks as French President Emmanuel Macron listens at a Franco-Chinese business council meeting in Beijing, April 6, 2023. Macron was accompanied by more than 60 business executives on his recent trip to China.

The view from the observation deck at Shanghai Tower in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, April 9, 2023. China's economic recovery is picking up steam after Covid restrictions were abruptly dropped and the property market stabilizes, although the rebound is still fairly patchy and policymakers have no intention yet of scaling back monetary support. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Wells Fargo sells US$3.8 billion debt in first post-SVB big bank sale
summary: Wells Fargo has successfully sold $3.75 billion in unsecured debt, marking the first large US lender to tap the high-grade corporate bond market since Silicon Valley Bank's collapse in March. The 11-year bond, yielding 180 basis points over Treasuries, will be used for general corporate purposes. The sale is seen as a sign that the corporate bond market is starting to thaw, with analysts expecting tighter lending conditions in the wake of the crisis. This move may also encourage other major US banks to seek financing.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo said outstanding CRE loans were US$154.7 billion, or 16 per cent of total loans, with US$35.7 billion in office loans at the end of March.
The layoffs affected top producers, including bankers who exceeded US$100 million in loan volumes last year and some who attended an internal sales conference for high achievers.

site_title: Schwab leaders say firm can weather storm after deposit drop
summary: Charles Schwab's customer deposits dropped 11% to $325.7 billion as of March 31, but the company remains stable despite the turmoil in the US banking industry. Profit climbed 12% to $1.8 billion, beating Wall Street estimates, and customers continued to add to investment products. The company paused stock buybacks due to regulatory uncertainty, but executives say they can withstand the crisis. Shares rose 3.9% to close at $52.77, paring this year's decline to 37%.

images.alt_text: Schwab’s bank faces another problem as interest rates spike.
Schwab errs with US$1.2m account transfer, customer buys house with 'windfall'
Schwab sues former client after US$1.2m accidental transfer

site_title: Chinese millennials look beyond property investments to build wealth
summary: Chinese millennials are shifting away from investing in property as a means of building wealth, with household savings reaching a record high and over 90% of university-educated citizens aged 22-32 viewing investing as a key part of their life plan. Due to regulations and limited investment options, they are looking to professionally managed funds, alternative assets, and direct stakes in small and medium-size enterprises. Many are taking risks, such as investing in cryptocurrencies, venture capital, and electric-car battery swapping stations. This trend is expected to benefit the global investment industry, with interest in professionally managed funds surging and individual fund managers emerging as stars.

images.alt_text: China's GDP is tipped to have risen 4.0 per cent in January-March from a year earlier, a Reuters poll showed, quickening from 2.9 per cent in the fourth quarter.

(FILES) This file photo taken on March 26, 2023 shows cargo ships berthing at Suqian port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports rose in March for the first time in six months, customs data showed on April 13, as the world's second-largest economy continued its recovery following the end of onerous coronavirus curbs late last year. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 170 billion yuan (S$33 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.75 per cent from the previous operation.

site_title: Tightest supply in 18 years boosts copper ahead of industry show
summary: Copper prices are boosted by the tightest supply in 18 years, with stockpiles of less than a week's worth of consumption. Major producers like BHP Group and Glencore are turning to deal-making for growth due to increasing costs and project constraints. Industry experts predict copper will move above $10,000 a ton, driven by China's reopening and supply-side stumbles. However, the outlook is also constrained by environmental and social issues, and permitting is getting tougher, affecting investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Copper rods are seen at Truong Phu cable factory in northern Hai Duong province, outside Hanoi, Vietnam, August 11, 2017. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Shares snap five-day winning streak as banks, chips fall
summary: European shares ended flat, snapping a five-day winning streak, as bank and chip stocks declined. The Stoxx 600 index held near one-year highs, while the Stoxx 50 index dipped 0.1%. TSMC's cost-cutting report led to declines in semiconductor stocks, including ASML, which fell 4%. European bank stocks fell 1.4%, but analysts attributed the decline to "normal profit taking" after a strong US reporting season. Despite this, European shares have risen about 10% this year, outperforming the S&P 500 index.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.3 per cent to end at 33,987.18 on Monday..

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank initiates coverage on Dyna-Mac with ‘buy’
summary: Maybank Securities has initiated coverage on Dyna-Mac Holdings with a "buy" call, citing the company as "significantly undervalued" due to its strong order book and strategic plans for expansion. Analysts expect Dyna-Mac to secure larger orders with potentially higher margins, including an estimated S$600 million worth of orders by the fourth quarter of 2023. The target price is pegged at S$0.35, representing a 30% discount to global-listed peers. Dyna-Mac's strong net cash position and no debt also support the "buy" call.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Dyna-Mac’s Holdings' main yard in Gul Road.
Mainboard-listed Dyna-Mac fabricates topside modules and structures for the offshore oil and gas industry.
The new orders brings the company’s net order book to-date to a record high of S$641.1 million, with deliveries stretching into 2024.
The counter reached a high of S$0.144 on Wednesday, up 17.1 per cent or S$0.021.

site_title: Seedly co-founders’ new healthtech startup raises S$1.7m
summary: Singapore-based healthtech startup Mito Health has raised S$1.7 million in pre-seed funding led by Forge Ventures. Founded by Seedly co-founders Kenneth Lou and Chew Tee-Ming, the platform aims to build personalized health plans using data, focusing on preventive healthcare. The company will initially serve executives in Singapore, guiding users in improving diet, exercise, and supplements. Plans to expand to other developed markets in the region are underway, with the goal of tackling Singapore's aging population and increasing emphasis on healthy years.
