site_title: China’s electric car drive, led by BYD, leaves global brands behind
summary: China's electric car market is accelerating towards an electric future, with local brands leading the way. BYD's sales in China are up 69% this year, giving it an 11% share of the overall car market, surpassing Volkswagen and Toyota. The market shift is driven by new electric-drive models, with BYD unveiling a new hatchback and SUV at the Shanghai auto show. Established global brands are struggling, with sales down and market share declining, while China's exports of EVs and PHEVs are growing rapidly.

images.alt_text: China's GDP is tipped to have risen 4.0 per cent in January-March from a year earlier, a Reuters poll showed, quickening from 2.9 per cent in the fourth quarter.
Worldwide sales for the Renault brand reached 354,545 vehicles in the first three months of the year.

site_title: OCBC’s metaverse branch shows virtualisation is tough
summary: OCBC, a Singaporean bank, has launched its metaverse branch, OCBCx65Chulia, in Decentraland, a virtual world. However, the experience is marred by glitches, a narrow and difficult-to-navigate space, and limited features. Despite being a bold step for a local bank, the virtual branch may struggle to attract customers, with many users finding it unexciting and slow. The metaverse market is also facing challenges, with a 4% decline in the total value of land and a 4.2% drop in average concurrent players over the past year.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Users can customise their own avatar, or chat with other users in the virtual world, much like other metaverse applications.

site_title: Nio plans Europe expansion as China’s EV price war intensifies
summary: Nio plans to expand into the European market, unveiling a new compact car model and launching a fresh brand of vehicles in 2024 at a new factory in China. This move comes as China's electric vehicle (EV) price war intensifies, prompting the company to push further offshore. Nio aims to double overall sales in 2023 to around 250,000 vehicles and break even in core businesses in the fourth quarter. The company has faced challenges in cracking the European market, with a delayed battery-swap station deployment in Norway.

images.alt_text: Nio electric vehicle EV .Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: BlackRock to kick off sales of failed banks’ securities for FDIC
summary: BlackRock will begin selling securities worth $114 billion, acquired by the FDIC from failed banks Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. The sales, starting Tuesday, will be conducted through a mortgage-backed security pool and auctions of other securitized assets. BlackRock aims to sell $1.5-2 billion per week, with the goal of ramping up trading to four days a week. The process is expected to be orderly, with both BlackRock and the FDIC seeking price stability.

images.alt_text: The world’s top asset manager has already seen a boost amid the recent turmoil in the US banking sector, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March.
This is BlackRock’s second sale process this month in structured bonds.
On Monday, the FDIC announced the marketing process for an about US$60 billion loan portfolio retained in receivership following the failure of Signature Bank.

site_title: Renault reviewing prices worldwide after Tesla cuts
summary: Renault is reviewing its pricing policies worldwide after Tesla cuts prices of its electric vehicles in Europe and other regions, sparking a price war. The company's sales rose 9% in the first quarter, but CEO Fabrice Cambolive warns that Tesla's price cuts are a challenge, particularly on the cost side. Renault plans to analyze competitiveness by country and market, aiming to stay competitive in the electric car market. The company's electric vehicle sales rose sharply in March, with the Megane E model being a popular choice.

images.alt_text: Tesla cut prices on Real-Wheel Drive version of both Model 3 and Model Y by S$4,000 (US$3,020), and Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive version of the two models by S$5,000, the website showed.
FILE PHOTO: The logos of car manufacturers Nissan and Renault are seen in front of dealerships of the companies in Etampes, near Paris, France, January 26, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo

The move is part of Renault’s efforts to secure crucial components and seize control of the value chain of its future unit Ampere, dedicated to electric vehicles and software which it plans to list on the stock market by the end of the year.

“The two companies are currently working well together towards the signature of all the definitive agreements. They are confident this will be reached shortly,” Nissan said, a comment echoed in a statement by Renault.

site_title: ETFs killed off by merciless market at double the rate of last year
summary: The US ETF industry has seen a surge in failures, with 62 exchange-traded funds liquidated or delisted so far this year, more than double the number from the same period last year. The industry's volatile markets and fierce competition have put pressure on issuers, with crypto-focused funds and other trendy thematic ETFs being particularly affected. The closures include funds with as little as $289,000 in assets, and issuers such as Invesco and Simplify have announced plans to close multiple funds as part of a broader refinement of their offerings.

images.alt_text: Owning shares in just a few companies can lead to large swings in portfolio performance.
The fund has never caught on with investors, with its last inflow happening in June last year.

site_title: Oil drops 2% on higher dollar, interest rate concerns
summary: Oil prices fell 1.8% and 2.1% on Monday, with Brent crude futures dropping to $84.76 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling to $80.83 a barrel, amid a strengthening US dollar and concerns over a possible May interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The dollar's increase, coupled with traders' expectations of a rate hike, has put pressure on oil prices. A positive China GDP release is expected to boost commodity prices, while Opec+ output cuts may exacerbate an oil supply deficit.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures nudged 17 cents higher to US$86.48 a barrel by 0144 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude was at US$82.66 a barrel, up 14 cents on Monday.

site_title: China to be top world growth source in next five years, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts China will be the top contributor to global growth over the next five years, accounting for 22.6% of total world growth through 2028. This surpasses the US, which is expected to contribute 11.3%. India follows with 12.9% and Indonesia with 8.4%. The IMF warns of a weak global growth outlook, with the world economy expanding about 3% over the next half decade, and urges nations to avoid economic fragmentation and boost productivity.

images.alt_text: “Output gaps for Asian economies are either closing or already closed, and currency depreciation last year is still passing through to domestic prices. These factors suggest that the battle to contain inflation is not yet over,” said Krishna Srinivasan, IMF director of the Asia and Pacific Department.

site_title: Macron defends pension reform, understands ‘anger’
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron defended his unpopular pension reform, stating it was "necessary" and that he understood the "anger" felt by the French. Despite this, protests continue, with thousands gathering outside town halls and setting fire to garbage containers. Macron's speech was met with criticism from various opposition groups, who accused him of ignoring the suffering of the French and failing to address their concerns. The government has promised 100 days of action to ease tensions, but polls remain opposed to the reform, with Macron's personal popularity ratings eroding.

images.alt_text: France’s constitutional court approves Macron’s widely unpopular pensions plan, which has sparked months of protests and strikes.
French President Emmanuel Macron and his government will hope such an outcome would discourage further trade union-led protests, which have at times turned violent.

site_title: Fund outflows of US$4.4 billion at Credit Suisse since deal with UBS
summary: Credit Suisse clients withdrew US$4.4 billion from US and European funds since the lender's acquisition by UBS last month. The largest daily outflows were recorded on March 21, with US$813 million pulled, but redemptions have eased since then, with about US$230 million returned on April 5 and 6. The outflows, about 2.5% of the firm's assets under management, are less than expected, according to an analyst. The combined firm is expected to take months to close the deal and potentially four years to complete integration.

site_title: Jakarta’s EV battery ambitions look promising
summary: Indonesia is poised to become a major player in the global electric vehicle (EV) battery industry due to its abundant nickel reserves. Chinese firms, including Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) and Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt, have relocated their factories to Indonesia, taking advantage of the country's ban on raw nickel exports and EV tax credits under the US Inflation Reduction Act. However, Jakarta faces obstacles from the US environmental lobby, which argues that Indonesia's energy grid remains reliant on coal and its nickel refining process emits high levels of carbon dioxide. Despite these challenges, Indonesia's EV battery prospects look promising, and the country plans to tax exports of semi-processed nickel products to enhance production of battery-grade nickel.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, which has the largest nickel reserves in the world, will step up scrutiny of mining and order companies to manage nurseries to reforest depleted mines, said  President Joko Widodo.

In just three years, Jakarta has signed deals worth about US$15 billion for battery and EV production, while President Joko Widodo – who visited the nickel mining town of Sorowako on Sulawesi island this week – has personally tried to persuade Tesla’s Musk to invest.
Indonesian minister Luhut Pandjaitan, who has been spearheading efforts to attract US companies, told a news conference Jakarta will propose a limited free trade agreement (FTA) with Washington.

site_title: LVMH sells debt for first time since 2020 after stellar results
summary: LVMH, the parent company of Christian Dior and Louis Vuitton, is selling 500 million euros of new bonds for the first time in three years, following strong quarterly results that exceeded market expectations. The company's low leverage and good free cash flow are expected to attract high demand for the bond. This marks LVMH's first venture into global debt markets since April 2020. The deal is being marketed by major banks including Barclays, Deutsche Bank, and JPMorgan Chase.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass the Louis Vuitton luxury clothing boutique, operated by LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis SE, on the Champs-Elysees in central Paris, France, on Tuesday, April 11, 2023. Investors will pay attention to recovery trends in China when LVMH reports 1Q revenue Wednesday after markets close in Paris. Photographer: Cyril Marcilhacy/Bloomberg
LVMH’s soaring sales shows that demand for highly priced goods remains unabated even as a global economic slowdown looms.
Asia, excluding Japan, represented 30 per cent of sales in 2022, compared with 35 per cent in the previous year.

site_title: Opportunities in Asean to drive Standard Chartered’s wholesale banking business
summary: Standard Chartered sees opportunities in Southeast Asia to drive its wholesale banking business, leveraging the region's growing investor interest and its own network and presence in the area. The bank's CEO, Simon Cooper, notes that Singapore's position as a global hub and regional business center gives it a unique advantage in supporting clients in the region. Cooper expects the bank's financial institutions segment to be a key driving force for growth, with clients looking to expand their operations in the region and invest in local assets.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
FILE PHOTO: The Standard Chartered bank logo is seen at their headquarters in London, Britain, July 26, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo
Regional economic activity remains robust in spite of the recent banking crisis, said Bill Winters, group chief executive of Standard Chartered.

site_title: White House accuses Republican leader McCarthy of ‘economic hostage-taking’
summary: The White House has accused US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy of "economic hostage-taking" by attaching conditions to the debt ceiling extension. McCarthy has proposed raising the debt ceiling only in tandem with spending cuts, while President Joe Biden insists on a "clean" debt ceiling increase. The White House sees McCarthy's approach as favoring the wealthy and special interests, and warns that defaulting on debt could harm hard-working Americans' jobs and retirement savings. The dispute is the opening salvo in an expected intense political battle over the debt ceiling.

images.alt_text: Fep. Kevin McCarthy (D-Calif.) speaks after winning the speakership of the House early Saturday, Jan. 7, 2023. McCarthy raced on Monday, Jan. 9, 2023, to line up votes to pass a set of operating rules for the Republican-controlled House, toiling to tamp down defections from rank-and-file members who said he had given too many concessions to the hard right in the desperate and drawn-out process of securing his job. (Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times)

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens flat as investors focus on earnings, Fed cues
summary: The US stock market opened flat on Monday as investors awaited bank earnings and Federal Reserve policy cues. The Dow Jones rose 43.99 points, while the S&P 500 opened flat at 4,137.17. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 15.23 points. Market expectations for the Fed's monetary policy tightening are under review, with some investors seeking guidance on when the central bank may pause its tightening.

site_title: McDonald’s brings back the Hamburglar to promote burger changes
summary: McDonald's is reviving the Hamburglar character to promote minor changes to its burger recipes, including extra Big Mac sauce, softer buns, and hotter, meltier cheese. The changes were initially tested in Australia, Canada, and Belgium and will be rolled out to the US by 2024. This marks the second time the Hamburglar has been revamped to promote a menu item, following a 2015 revamp for a limited-time sirloin burger.

site_title: EU lawmakers call for summit to control ‘very powerful’ AI
summary: EU lawmakers, comprising 12 MEPs, are urging a summit to regulate advanced AI systems like ChatGPT, calling for more responsibility from AI firms. They disagree with some alarmist statements, but agree on the need for significant political action to control the rapid development of powerful AI. The call comes after a letter from over 1,000 tech figures, including Elon Musk, warning of AI's potential to spread misinformation and replace humans if left unchecked.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Competition is forcing AI engineers to go too fast and cut too many corners. The technology is too important to be left to a race among Microsoft, Google, Meta and a few other firms.
The source said member states were not seeking to punish or make rules that will affect Microsoft Corp-backed ChatGPT owner OpenAI, but rather to create general policies that “are transparent.”

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment improves for fourth straight month: NAHB
summary: US single-family homebuilders' confidence improved for the fourth consecutive month in April, with the NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index rising one point to 45. Builders cited a lack of access to building materials, including electrical transformer equipment, as a challenge. Despite this, new home sales have increased for three straight months, driven by falling mortgage rates below 6%. The NAHB chairman noted that further declines in mortgage rates will fuel demand, but the industry remains plagued by material shortages.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A "sold" sign is seen outside of a recently purchased home in Washington, U.S., July 7, 2022. REUTERS/Sarah Silbiger/File Photo

site_title: EY to cut 3,000 jobs in US to eliminate ‘overcapacity’
summary: EY's US arm is cutting 3,000 jobs, about 5% of its workforce, due to "overcapacity" in certain areas. The layoffs are a result of assessing economic conditions, strong employee retention rates, and the impact of current economic conditions. This decision comes after EY's US Executive Committee rejected a plan to break up its audit and consulting units, which was initially intended to address regulatory concerns. The move is part of a wave of layoffs in Corporate America, following the Federal Reserve's quantitative tightening.

images.alt_text: EY’s global management said in a note that the company’s US executive committee “decided not to move forward” with its plan, dubbed “Project Everest”.
The case against turning the big four into a biggish eight is far from open and shut, not least as the commercial logic of the split is in many ways getting more compelling.

site_title: Japan hotels draw foreign investors at scale unseen in years
summary: Foreign investors are buying up Japanese hotels at a scale unseen in almost a decade, with 47% of a 494.3 billion yen (S$4.9 billion) in hotel deals closed in the past 12 months attributed to overseas buyers. The nation's tourism recovery, weak currency, and low interest rates are driving the appetite for Japanese real estate. Despite economic uncertainty, hotels remain a niche but attractive investment opportunity, with investors betting on strong demand from tourists and limited new supply.

images.alt_text: Japan ranked 116th out of 146 countries in the World Economic Forum’s Global Gender Gap report in 2022, the only Group of Seven country failing to make the top 100.
The Yumeshima island in Osaka Bay, Japan, on 2 May 2014. A casino, conference centre and other facilities in 2029 with 1.8 trillion yen (S$17.9 billion) of initial investment are planned.

site_title: US House Speaker McCarthy pitches budget cuts for debt limit vote
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has proposed a federal spending-cut plan to accompany a potential debt ceiling increase, warning that no conditions will pass the House. The plan includes rolling back federal spending to fiscal 2022 levels and 1% annual growth over the next decade. McCarthy's move comes as the federal government faces a possible default on its debt payments this summer. The White House has insisted on a debt limit increase without conditions, citing the need for prompt action to avoid a historic default that could shake the US and world economies.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden talks about his proposed federal budget – seen as a preview of his 2024 re-election platform – at the Finishing Trades Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

site_title: China smartphone sales rise to more than 70% of Russian market
summary: China's smartphone sales surged to over 70% of the Russian market in the first quarter of 2023, surpassing Samsung and Apple. Chinese manufacturers Xiaomi and Realme now occupy the top two spots, following the curtailment of sales by Western brands due to the Ukraine conflict. This shift reflects Russia's growing dependence on China, with increased use of the yuan, energy supplies, and Chinese-branded cars. Demand for Chinese smartphones increased by 42% and their total share reached 70%, as the country tries to wean itself off Western technology.

site_title: Dominant Team Boss win BT Corporate Golf League in style
summary: Team Boss, led by captain Terence Yong, won the BT Corporate Golf League 2023 with a total of 325 points, 11 ahead of second-placed Team Centurion. The team's victory was attributed to careful team selection, rotation of players, and meticulous preparation. Team Boss' consistent player Andre Huber was named the Best Player of the Round, and the team's strong showing earned them the top spot in the leaderboard. This is Team Boss' first championship win after two previous runner-up finishes.

images.alt_text:
Golf - The Masters - Augusta National Golf Club - Augusta, Georgia, U.S. - April 6, 2023
Spain's Sergio Garcia hits his tee shot on the 10th hole during the first round REUTERS/Mike Blake
Woods, then 21, won the first of his 15 major titles in stunning fashion at the 1997 Masters with a record margin of 12 strokes and became the youngest golfer to triumph at Augusta National.
(From left) The CLA Global TS team comprising Tony Mallek, Henry Tan, Sam Chia and William Lau.
Triple winner Stanley Gan with Lim Han Ming, EMTM deputy managing editor, and Ken Sim (right), marketing manager, adidas Golf SEA.
Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng in action at Tanah Merah Conutry Club during the BT Corporate Golf League 2023.

site_title: G7 will stand up to 'any coercion' from China, says senior US official
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) nations have reaffirmed their commitment to standing up against any Chinese "coercion" or efforts to exert control in the Taiwan Strait, according to a senior US State Department official. The G7 foreign ministers have emphasized the need to maintain peace and stability in the region, with Japan expressing deep concerns about China's actions. The US, France, and other G7 nations have also condemned China's increasing attempts to replace international rules with its own, amid rising tensions in the Indo-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: (From left to right) Japanese Finance Vice Minister Masato Kanda, Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki and Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda participate in a G7 press briefing during the IMF and World Bank Spring Meetings at in Washington, DC, on April 12, 2023.

site_title: WTO panel rules against India in IT tariffs dispute with EU, others
summary: A World Trade Organization (WTO) panel ruled against India in a dispute with the EU, Japan, and Taiwan over import duties on IT products. The panel found India's measures to be non-compliant with global trading rules. The report recommended that India bring its measures into conformity with its WTO obligations. This decision is not final, as India can appeal the ruling. The dispute involves India's 7.5-20% import duties on IT products, including mobile phones and components, which were introduced in 2019.

site_title: HSBC shareholder Ping An to vote for bank's break-up at annual meeting
summary: HSBC's largest shareholder Ping An is set to vote in favor of splitting the bank at its annual meeting on May 5, according to a source. Ping An's vote is in support of resolutions calling for HSBC to restore dividends to 51 cents per share and provide regular updates on spinning off its Asia business. Despite this, HSBC has maintained its current strategy, citing its global presence as more valuable than any fragmentation would yield.

site_title: SpaceX postpones test flight of Starship, world's biggest rocket
summary: SpaceX postponed the test flight of its Starship rocket, the world's largest, due to a pressurization issue in the booster stage. The launch was called off just minutes before the scheduled liftoff time. The delay is expected to last at least 48 hours. The Starship, designed to send astronauts to the Moon and Mars, had been scheduled to launch from SpaceX's Starbase in Texas. The US space agency NASA has chosen the Starship for its Artemis III mission to the Moon in late 2025.

site_title: US: Stocks finish higher after choppy session
summary: US stocks finished higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average adding 0.3% to 33,987.18. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced 0.3%. Investors will focus on corporate earnings from Bank of America, Netflix, and others, amid concerns over banking profitability. Prometheus Biosciences surged 70% after a $11 billion acquisition by Merck, while Microsoft climbed 0.9%. The week's earnings reports and housing starts data will also be closely watched.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 14, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: USP Group in second board tussle; minority shareholders want new team at helm and exit from watch-list
summary: Minority shareholders of USP Group, a Singapore-listed company, are seeking to take control of the board and remove the current CEO and chairman to inject new projects and improve financial health. The proposed board composition includes four new directors, including an executive director, and aims to revitalize the company. The shareholders, who collectively control 12.2% of the company, have been pushing for the change after years of financial struggles and difficulties staying afloat. The company is currently on the SGX watchlist due to unaudited financials.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Recent boardroom tussles involving SGX-listed companies have seen varying degrees of success for requisitioning parties, and not all cases are straightforward.
USP Group seeks US$11m in damages from 5 parties associated with acquisition of production plants

site_title: Alphabet falls on report Samsung considering Bing as default search engine
summary: Google's shares fell 4% after a report that Samsung is considering replacing Google's search engine with Microsoft's Bing. The move is seen as a threat to Google's dominance in the search market, which has a 80% share. Google earns an estimated $3 billion annually from the Samsung contract and $20 billion from an Apple contract set to renew this year. The report suggests Google is racing to build an AI-powered search engine to compete with Bing, which has gained prominence with its integration of AI tech behind ChatGPT.

site_title: US dollar hits one-month high against yen as traders bet on Fed rate hike
summary: The US dollar reached a one-month high against the Japanese yen on April 17, rising to 134.22 yen, amid expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Bank of Japan stuck to its easy-money policies, while traders anticipate a 25 basis point rate hike from the Fed in May. The US dollar index was little changed at 101.66. Analysts expect the Fed to hold rates steady for the rest of the year, with investors monitoring comments from Fed officials and bank earnings.

site_title: Ryan Reynolds takes stake in Canadian payments firm Nuvei
summary: Hollywood actor Ryan Reynolds has invested in Canadian payments firm Nuvei, a provider of services to the sports betting industry. Nuvei shares rose 1.6% before trading down 0.7% following the announcement. Reynolds, who has also invested in Mint Mobile, praised the company's leadership team and highlighted the need for more attention to Canadian tech companies. Nuvei went public in 2020 and has since acquired Paya Holdings for $1.3 billion. Reynolds' investment in Nuvei marks a significant boost to the company's market value.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 9, 2022 Wrexham AFC's Co-Chairman, US actors Ryan Reynolds talks to players as they wait on the pitch to greet the King and Queen Consort, during their visit to Wrexham Association Football Club in north Wales. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: Indonesia sets up task force to improve governance in its palm oil sector
summary: Indonesia has established a task force to improve governance in its palm oil sector, aiming to increase compliance with rules such as tax payments and land permits. The task force, led by Deputy Finance Minister Suahasil Nazara, follows an industry-wide audit that identified discrepancies between reported and actual land use. The goal is to improve transparency and protect the forest, with the country's palm oil exports valued at $5.92 billion in the first three months of 2023. The task force aims to address issues that led to a three-week halt in palm oil exports due to a cooking oil supply scarcity.

images.alt_text: “The main goal of having an exchange is transparency and good governance. ” Didid Noordiatmoko, head of commodity futures regulator Bappebti said.

site_title: ChatGPT’s AI to power Chegg study buddy as educators wrestle with tech
summary: US educational software maker Chegg has combined its corpus of quiz answers with the AI model of ChatGPT to create CheggMate, a study aide tailored to students. The software adapts to students by processing data on their classes and exam questions, personalizing practice tests and guiding study. CheggMate will be available for free initially and focuses on math and sciences, avoiding essay drafting that has raised concerns. The release comes as educators grapple with the consequences of AI in education, with some institutions banning ChatGPT due to plagiarism concerns.

images.alt_text: The source said member states were not seeking to punish or make rules that will affect Microsoft Corp-backed ChatGPT owner OpenAI, but rather to create general policies that “are transparent.”
Every piece of data typed into ChatGPT will be used to train the artificial intelligence models.

site_title: Nike, Adidas shoes maker Pou Chen to invest nearly US$281 million in India
summary: Pou Chen, a Taiwanese footwear maker, will invest nearly US$281 million in India through a manufacturing facility in Tamil Nadu, creating approximately 20,000 jobs over 12 years. This investment comes after Taiwanese peer Hong Fu Group signed a similar deal last year. Pou Chen, which manufactures shoes for brands like Nike, Adidas, and Timberland, aims to establish itself as a major player in India's footwear industry, which accounts for 45% of the country's exports. The move is part of the company's efforts to diversify its manufacturing footprint away from China and Taiwan.

site_title: Aliaxis US$2 billion Uponor approach rebuffed by main owner
summary: Belgian company Aliaxis has made a hostile offer to acquire Finnish plumbing equipment maker Uponor for $2 billion in cash. The deal, which would combine Aliaxis and Uponor's complementary piping and plumbing product ranges, would give Aliaxis "critical mass" in the sector. However, Uponor's largest shareholder, Oras Invest Oy, rejected the offer, citing that it does not reflect Uponor's full value and that the company is on track to deliver considerable value to its shareholders as an independent company. Aliaxis plans to set an acceptance threshold above 60% of shares.

images.alt_text: Almarc Engineering’s PTFE/PFA lined pipes are carefully inspected before being fitted into customers’ manufacturing facilities.

site_title: Malaysia to review US$3.9 billion settlement deal with Goldman Sachs: PM Anwar
summary: Malaysia's government is reviewing a US$3.9 billion settlement deal with Goldman Sachs over the 1MDB financial scandal, Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said. The 2020 deal, worth US$2.5 billion in cash and US$1.4 billion in assets, was reached during the administration of Muhyiddin Yassin. Anwar expressed concerns over the settlement's haste, and a government taskforce is scrutinizing the deal to recover public funds. The scandal is believed to have resulted in the theft of approximately US$4.5 billion from 1MDB between 2009 and 2014.

site_title: Volkswagen, Rivian, Nissan, BMW lose access to US EV tax credits
summary: The US Treasury has announced that several major automakers, including Volkswagen, BMW, Nissan, Rivian, and Hyundai, will lose access to a $7,500 tax credit for electric vehicles (EVs) due to new battery sourcing rules. The rules, part of the Inflation Reduction Act, aim to reduce US dependence on China for EV battery supply chains. The affected vehicles will see their tax credits halved to $3,750, while Tesla models will retain the full $7,500 credit. The move is part of President Joe Biden's goal to make 50% of US new vehicle sales EVs or plug-in hybrids by 2030.

site_title: How offshore wind can scale up S-E Asia’s energy transition
summary: Offshore wind is poised to play a significant role in Southeast Asia's energy transition, particularly in countries with long coastlines and limited land availability for solar installations. The region needs to install 2,770-3,400 GW of renewable power capacity to reach net zero by 2050, a significant gap from the current 2,352 GW globally. Countries like the Philippines and Vietnam are already investing in offshore wind, with the Philippines aiming for 21 GW by 2040 and Vietnam seeking to supply 12% of its electricity by 2035. A scalable ecosystem, financial support, and technological advancements are key to establishing offshore wind as a significant part of the region's energy mix.

images.alt_text: This undated handout photograph released by Singapore's national water agency PUB on July 14, 2021 shows an aerial view of Sembcorb energy company's new floating solar power farm at Tengeh reservoir in Singapore. (Photo by Handout / SINGAPORE'S NATIONAL WATER AGENCY - PUB / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO /SINGAPORE'S NATIONAL WATER AGENCY - PUB / HANDOUT " - NO MARKETING - NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS
The UK’s major energy plan announced last week contained no firm plans to loosen planning restrictions that have choked development.

site_title: Tin prices jump after Myanmar’s Wa militia announces plan to suspend mining
summary: Myanmar's Wa militia has announced plans to suspend all mining activities in areas under its control from August, driving up tin prices 12% in China, the world's largest refined tin producer. Most of Myanmar's tin concentrate comes from these mines, accounting for 77% of China's tin ore imports in 2022. The move aims to protect remaining mining resources, with companies able to continue exploration for three more months. This ban has led to a surge in tin prices, with the May refined tin contract jumping 12% on the Shanghai Futures Exchange.

site_title: Tesla margins in focus as EV price war kicks into high gear
summary: Tesla is expected to report auto gross margins of 23.2% for the first quarter, down from a record 32.9% a year earlier, due to price cuts and increased competition. The company has cut prices five times since January, boosting sales but squeezing profit margins. Analysts predict further price cuts and margin pressure, with some predicting margins may not reach the 20% threshold promised by Finance Chief Zachary Kirkhorn. The decline in margins is attributed to rising competition from rivals like Ford and BYD in China, as well as a weak economy.

images.alt_text: Several online posts claimed workers at the Tesla's Shanghai plant were being unfairly penalised for an incident this year at the factory in February where one worker died.
Tesla cut prices on Real-Wheel Drive version of both Model 3 and Model Y by S$4,000 (US$3,020), and Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive version of the two models by S$5,000, the website showed.

site_title: ESG action among Asia-Pacific listed companies driven by financial stakeholders, not regulation: survey
summary: A survey of 255 Asia-Pacific listed companies found that financial stakeholders drive 25% of companies' environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns, while regulators and board management teams are the main drivers for 18% and 23% respectively. The survey suggests that compliance is not the primary driver of ESG action, but rather companies' desire to improve ESG preparedness and disclosure plans. Despite this, companies are still expected to continually improve their ESG preparedness and disclosure plans to meet global standards and expectations.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Photo by Yen Meng Jiin: ESG, socially responsible investing, and impact investing
HKEX on Friday (Apr 14) launched a three-month consultation over the plan, proposed under its ESG framework.

site_title: Indonesia posts US$8.7 billion Q1 budget surplus, stronger rupiah seen cutting deficit outlook
summary: Indonesia posted a US$8.69 billion budget surplus in Q1 2023, driven by strong tax collection and the strengthening rupiah currency. Revenues rose 29% to 647.2 trillion rupiah, while spending increased 5.7% to 518.7 trillion rupiah. The surplus is expected to cut Indonesia's deficit outlook, with officials citing improvement in the domestic economy after pandemic restrictions were lifted.

images.alt_text: Indonesia saw its exports rise to a record high last year on high global commodity prices, but shipments have gradually slowed as prices moderate.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's new private home sales rose 13.6% in March, excluding executive condominiums, after a 24.8% drop in the same period last year. This marks the third consecutive month of increase. A total of 492 units were sold in March, up from 433 units in February. The sales growth is attributed to a recovery in the market after a decline in the previous year.

site_title: Legacy planning: Tackle life decisions first, then look into products
summary: A growing number of individuals are seeking end-of-life, legacy, and estate planning, but often feel that financial products and structures, such as universal life policies, don't address their full needs. Experts emphasize that legacy planning involves not just financial provision, but also ensuring family harmony and cohesion. It's recommended to tackle life decisions first, including family values and objectives, before exploring financial and legal instruments. This holistic approach can help create a lasting legacy that benefits both the individual and their heirs.

images.alt_text: If there are evidence-based instruments that can reliably generate long-term returns - enough for clients to meet their goals - why be exposed to investments with higher risk of loss?
Positive returns do not necessarily mean you have accumulated enough for retirement.

site_title: Lego marks untapped US regions for growth with US$1 billion plant
summary: Lego plans to expand its US presence with a new $1 billion factory in Virginia, its first in the country. The company aims to tap into untapped regions and increase its market share, despite still having a long way to go. CEO Carsten Rasmussen expects strong growth in the American market over the next four to five years, driven by targeted marketing strategies and a stronger execution with retailers. The Richmond facility, set to open in 2025, will employ 1,800 people and support Lego's box sets aimed at girls, such as Lego Friends.

site_title: Buying sentiment turns cautious as Q1 new home sales fall below that of last year
summary: Singapore new home sales rose 13.6% in March to 492 units, excluding ECs, but still 43.8% below the five-year average. Buying sentiment turned cautious amid economic uncertainty, with Q1 sales 30% lower than the same period last year. Analysts attribute the decline to record high interest rates and a slowing economy, with developers preparing for a flood of new launches.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Developers sold 432 units excluding executive condominiums in February, up 9.9 per cent from the 393 units moved in the previous month.

site_title: American jazz piano great Ahmad Jamal dead at 92
summary: Renowned American jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal has died at the age of 92. With a career spanning over seven decades, Jamal released 80 albums, won numerous awards, including France's Ordre des Arts and des Lettres and a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. He was a key figure in transforming jazz, pop, and hip-hop, and his unique playing style, characterized by long empty stretches and romantic flourishes, influenced generations of musicians, including Miles Davis and hip-hop artists.

images.alt_text: Born in June 1914, before the outbreak of World War I and when one of her favourite composers, Claude Debussy, was still alive, Colette Maze practices four hours a day and is about to release her seventh album, 108 Years of Piano.

site_title: Volkswagen to partner on Indonesia EV battery ecosystem
summary: Volkswagen plans to establish an electric vehicle (EV) battery ecosystem in Indonesia, partnering with Vale, Ford, Huayou, Eramet, and several Indonesian firms. The move aims to reduce costs and close the gap with EV market leader Tesla. Indonesia's Investment Minister Bahlil Lahadalia announced the partnership, citing the country's potential as a key supplier of raw materials for EV batteries, which account for 40% of a vehicle's sticker price.

site_title: Teck’s controlling shareholder open to deals after planned split
summary: Teck Resources' controlling shareholder Norman Keevil is open to a deal if investors vote in favor of a plan to split the Canadian miner into two companies. The plan, which would separate the company's coal mines from its metal operations, faces opposition from influential investor advisory groups and has drawn support from Glencore's US$23 billion offer to merge the businesses. Keevil has stated that the company will pursue a deal if investors reject the restructuring plan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Canadian mining company Teck Resources Limited is displayed above their booth at the Prospectors and Developers Association of Canada (PDAC) annual conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada March 7, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Angry Tesla Shanghai workers vent to Elon Musk over bonus cuts
summary: Tesla Shanghai factory workers are upset over cuts to their quarterly performance bonuses, with some claiming they are being unfairly penalized for a fatal accident at the factory in February. The workers, who earn around $110,000-$120,000 per year, had their bonuses cut by around 2,000 yuan, sparking criticism from employees and labor experts who say the deductions are unfair. The cuts come as Tesla slashes prices in multiple markets, raising concerns about its profit margin.

images.alt_text: Tesla will break ground on the plant in the third quarter and start production in the second quarter of 2024.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Tesla China-made Model 3 vehicles are seen during a delivery event at its factory in Shanghai, China January 7, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: ESG debt to play key role in financing sustainability
summary: Sustainable debt issuance is expected to rise this year, driven by the need to finance projects that meet the UN Sustainable Development Goals. ESG-labelled debt, or bonds with environmental, social, and governance considerations, will play a key role in this transition. According to Pictet Asset Management, the market share of ESG-labelled debt is expected to increase, driven by the need for sustainable funding. This shift is expected to be driven by the growing importance of sustainability and the increasing adoption of ESG-labelled debt by investors.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Environmental, protection, natural reserve, ecology
Rising rates drag SE-Asian ESG bond volumes down 36% in Q1 2023, but sustainable loans grow

site_title: Bangladesh to pay Russia in yuan for nuclear plant
summary: Bangladesh has agreed to pay Russia for a nuclear plant in yuan, settling a 90% Russian loan repayable in 28 years with a 10-year grace period. Bangladesh's senior official, Uttam Kumar Karmaker, stated that Russia initially wanted payment in roubles but agreed to yuan due to currency issues. The project aims to alleviate frequent power cuts in Bangladesh, which are expected to worsen this year due to a decline in fuel imports and currency fluctuations.

site_title: CGS-CIMB warns of Telegram groups chats impersonating CEO
summary: CGS-CIMB Securities warned of a scam targeting its CEO Carol Fong, where users were invited to join a fraudulent WhatsApp group impersonating the brokerage through Telegram groups. The scam, involving groups named "CIMB Financial", "US Stock Wealth Institute", and "Carroll Square US Stock Club", was reported to the police. The brokerage has advised users to be cautious of such impersonations and to report any suspicious activity.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Swiss vote against UBS deal could be binding, legal experts say
summary: Switzerland's parliamentary vote against state guarantees for UBS Group's takeover of Credit Suisse Group may have binding effects, according to legal experts. Despite the government claiming the guarantees are binding due to previous financial delegation approval, experts argue that parliament's views should also be considered. The outcome of the vote could influence the interpretation of the government's obligations, potentially leading to changes in the deal. The binding nature of the guarantees remains unclear, sparking debate among experts and lawmakers.

site_title: Jamus Lim renews call for official poverty line in Singapore; suggests ComCare, Workfare tweaks
summary: Workers' Party MP Jamus Lim has called for the establishment of an official poverty line in Singapore, suggesting a committee comprising government representatives, civil society leaders, and academic experts to decide the threshold. He also proposed refining existing assistance schemes, such as ComCare and Workfare Income Supplement, to better support those in need. Lim argues that the current poverty line is outdated and fails to account for the varying needs of Singaporeans.

site_title: Indian government calls same-sex marriage appeals 'urban elitist views'
summary: India's government has dismissed same-sex marriage appeals as "urban elitist views", saying parliament is the right platform to debate the matter. The government, citing the concept of an Indian family unit, opposes same-sex marriages, and a five-judge bench will hear appeals starting Tuesday. The government's stance is seen as a setback for LGBTQ+ rights in the country, where gay couples have been fighting for the right to marry. The Supreme Court will hear the appeals, which challenge the government's opposition to same-sex marriage.

site_title: China property crash would cap growth at 3%: Bloomberg Economics
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow to 2.9% in 2023 and 2.8% in 2024 if a property market crash occurs, according to a Bloomberg Economics analysis. The crash, which could be triggered by a 15% drop in property investment, would deal a "devastating blow" to the economy, even if the government taps stimulus through policy rate cuts and widening the fiscal deficit. This scenario would cap China's growth at 3% over the next two years.

images.alt_text: The view from the observation deck at Shanghai Tower in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, April 9, 2023. China's economic recovery is picking up steam after Covid restrictions were abruptly dropped and the property market stabilizes, although the rebound is still fairly patchy and policymakers have no intention yet of scaling back monetary support. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong’s CK Hutchison aims to raise at least US$1 billion in US dollar bond deal: sources
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings, a Hong Kong-based conglomerate owned by billionaire Li Ka-shing, is planning to raise at least US$1 billion in a two-tranche US dollar bond deal. The company is considering issuing 5- and 10-year bonds, and has mandated seven investment banks ahead of the deal. The decision is subject to financial market conditions, following a 9.5% rise in its 2022 net profit to HK$33.5 billion in March.

site_title: Gold edges down on rate-hike bets, firmer dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,999.12 per ounce, as a firmer US dollar and expectations of another rate hike by the Federal Reserve weighed on the metal. The dollar index rose 0.2%, making gold more expensive for non-US buyers. The Fed's interest rate hike prospects, combined with mixed economic data, reduced gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation.

images.alt_text: Gold is traditionally considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, but higher interest rates dim non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Great shortfall of China: Australia’s biggest tourism market returns with a whimper
summary: China's tourism to Australia has significantly declined since Beijing ended the country's Approved Destination Status (ADS) in January 2023, with only 40,430 short-term visitors recorded in February, one-fifth of the record year's 2019 figure. The decline is attributed to visa rules, high costs, limited flights, and a shortage of Mandarin-speaking guides, as well as geopolitics and trade disputes. Despite this, total Chinese outbound border crossings have reached two-thirds of pre-pandemic levels, and the tourism industry is exploring alternative markets, such as the domestic market and other Asian countries.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar firmed 0.4 per cent to US$0.6713, having rallied 0.6 per cent overnight.
Australia's jobless rate stayed at 3.5 per cent, when analysts had looked for a nudge up to 3.6 per cent.

site_title: Singapore’s exports to remain weak as March data marks half year of contraction: economists
summary: Singapore's exports are expected to remain weak in the months ahead, following a sixth consecutive month of decline in March. Electronics exports plummeted 22.3% and non-electronics exports declined 4.7% year-on-year, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) falling 8.3%. Economists attribute the decline to global economic conditions, tight monetary policy, and vulnerabilities in the financial system following banking turmoil in the US and Europe. This marks the half-year of contraction in Singapore's exports.

site_title: As shadow lenders prep for real estate push, offices are in focus
summary: Shadow lenders are preparing to enter the commercial real estate market, focusing on offices, as regional banks retreat from the sector due to falling values and loan defaults. Offices account for a quarter of the US$10 trillion commercial real estate market and nearly a quarter of the $1.5 trillion in commercial real estate debt due for repayment by 2025. While distress is not yet widespread, default rates for offices remain below those of retail and hotel sectors, and private credit firms are poised to capitalize on opportunities in the market.

images.alt_text: Kyle Bass sees more pain in the office market, which reflects a more widespread view that the pandemic has driven a semi-permanent shift toward remote and hybrid work that imperils lower quality buildings.

site_title: Economic growth ‘non-negotiable’ for Singapore, even with shifts in social compact: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized that economic growth is "non-negotiable" for Singapore, despite shifts in the social compact. The government will continue to promote real income growth for the middle class and maintain a pro-growth and pro-inclusivity approach. To achieve this, the government will focus on skills development, empowering vulnerable workers, and redefining success. A new definition of success will require consumers to bear higher costs for goods and services, with the government striving to keep its overall tax burden low for the middle-income group.

site_title: Emperador’s 2022 net profit rises 0.9% on whisky gains
summary: Emperador's 2022 net profit rose 0.9% to 10.1 billion pesos, driven by a 76.7% increase in its whiskey segment, primarily due to high-margin single malt whisky sales. The brandy segment saw a 25.1% drop in profits. Revenue gained 12.2% to 62.8 billion pesos, while earnings per share increased to 0.64 pesos. The company did not declare a dividend for FY2022 due to unresolved dividend process flow.

site_title: What’s a VC-backable F&B business model?
summary: A successful food and beverage (F&B) business in Southeast Asia requires a sound, scalable, and sustainable model that constantly evolves to meet changing consumer preferences. Venture capitalists assess F&B startups based on their ability to scale, create a strong brand, and cater to the taste-buds of Gen Zs and millennials. Key metrics include payback periods, same-store sales growth, and four-wall earnings, as well as consistent and healthy monthly growth rates, customer retention, and profit contribution margin for online businesses. Founders who are street-smart, resilient, and able to ride the business cycle are also crucial for VC-backed F&B businesses.

site_title: ‘Phantom of the Opera’ ends 35-year record run with final Broadway bow
summary: The Phantom of the Opera, a Broadway musical, ended its 35-year record run with its final performance on April 16, 2023. The show, which opened in 1988, has seen over 20 million people and grossed over $1.4 billion in ticket sales. With 13,981 performances, it is the longest-running show in Broadway history, captivating audiences with its melodrama about a disfigured genius haunting the Paris Opera House. The curtain fell on a sold-out performance at the Majestic Theatre off Times Square, marking the end of an iconic era.

images.alt_text: The Palais Garnier stay will be listed on Mar 1 for 37 euros.

site_title: ‘Gunpowder’ found at home of Japan PM blast suspect: media
summary: A 24-year-old man, Ryuji Kimura, suspected of throwing a smoke bomb at Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, has been found to have gunpowder at his home. Police searched the home for over eight hours after a pipe bomb was tossed at Kishida during a campaign event in western Japan. Investigators believe the explosive was homemade and are analyzing Kimura's phone and computer for clues. Kimura has refused to detail a motive and is under arrest on suspicion of obstruction of business.

images.alt_text: NHK footage showed crowds running away as several police officers appeared to pin a man to the ground before removing him from the scene

site_title: China baijiu maker ZJLD Group seeks up to US$812 million in Hong Kong's largest IPO in 2023
summary: ZJLD Group, a Chinese baijiu maker, is seeking up to $812 million in its Hong Kong IPO, the largest this year. The company, backed by KKR & Co, is offering 490.7 million shares in a price range of $1.82 to $1.82 each. At the top of the range, ZJLD would be valued at $5.4 billion. The IPO, set to start trading on April 27, would see KKR's stake fall to 13.8% after the listing.

images.alt_text: Under the system reform, China's stock exchanges will vet initial public offerings themselves.

site_title: Sotheby's to auction world's largest ruby in New York in June
summary: Sotheby's will auction the world's largest ruby, the 55.22-carat "The Estrela de Fura," in New York on June 8, estimated to fetch up to US$30 million. The gemstone, from Mozambique, was initially a 101-carat rough gemstone discovered in July 2022. If sold, it would break the current record set by the 25.59-carat "Sunrise Ruby" sold for US$30.3 million in 2015. The ruby will be exhibited in several locations before the auction, with estimates suggesting it could set a new record for Mozambique rubies.

images.alt_text: The 10.57 carat rock will go on show in Hong Kong next week and later will be exhibited in Dubai, Singapore, Shanghai, Taiwan and Geneva. It will be up for sale on June 8 in New York as the showpiece lot in a Sotheby’s jewels auction.

site_title: Sega offers to buy Angry Birds creator Rovio Entertainment
summary: Sega has offered to buy Rovio Entertainment, the Finnish company behind Angry Birds, in a deal valued at approximately 706 million euros (S$1 billion). Sega's offer includes 9.25 euros per share in cash and 1.48 euros per option to option holders, backed by 49% of shareholders. Rovio's board has unanimously recommended shareholders accept the offer, which brings to a close talks with multiple parties, including a previous US$810 million offer from Playtika Holding Corp. The deal is seen as Sega's attempt to accelerate its expansion in the mobile gaming market, while Rovio aims to generate stable cash flow.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Angry Birds game characters are seen at the Rovio headquarters in Espoo, Finland March 13, 2019. Picture taken March 13, 2019. REUTERS/Anne Kauranen/File Photo

site_title: Porsche posts record Q1 sales rise boosted by China
summary: Porsche reported a record 18% year-on-year sales increase in Q1, driven by a 21% growth in China sales, where 21,365 cars were delivered. This growth was fueled by the post-pandemic surge in demand in China, the company's largest single market. Worldwide, Porsche delivered 80,767 cars, with increases in every region, led by SUV models like the Macan and Cayenne, and the iconic 911 sports car. The company remains confident for the rest of the year, while remaining vigilant in a challenging environment.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: ‘Second-hand’ policies could help your portfolio (Ep 141)
summary: Analysts suggest that the turmoil in 2022 may lead to opportunities in alternative investments over the next 12-24 months. '2nd-hand' policies, which are not the same as ILPs, are gaining popularity. These policies present potential opportunities in the coming months, with Conservation Capital CEO Trevor Xie discussing the pros and cons. Market trends and outlook for the sector are also being explored, with insights from Howie Lim and Trevor Xie.

site_title: Indonesia’s March trade surplus smaller than expected
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus narrowed to $2.91 billion in March, below expectations of $3.99 billion. Exports rose to a record high last year but slowed as prices moderated, dropping 11.33% year-over-year to $23.5 billion. Imports fell 6.26% to $20.59 billion, also below forecasts. The narrower surplus marks the sharpest annual fall in exports since May 2020.

site_title: HSBC regarded Hin Leong as ‘very good customer’ with ‘good track record’: witness
summary: Singaporean former oil tycoon OK Lim appears in State Courts for the third day of a trial on cheating and forgery charges. HSBC, a major creditor of Hin Leong, is accused of wanting to "keep the profit" on transactions that didn't materialize. The bank had not terminated its discounting agreements despite learning of the transactions, according to the defense counsel. The trial continues to examine the charges against Lim, who is also the founder of the collapsed Hin Leong empire.

site_title: MPA, Shell to expand collaboration on maritime decarbonisation efforts in Singapore
summary: MPA and Shell Eastern Trading have signed a five-year MOU to accelerate maritime decarbonisation efforts in Singapore. The partnership aims to support the adoption of electric harbour craft and develop low-and-zero-carbon fuels. Key initiatives include collaboration on charging infrastructure and research and development of clean fuel technologies. MPA and Shell will also work together to train crew on handling and operating vessels on low-and-zero-carbon fuels, with the goal of achieving net-zero emissions in harbour craft by 2050.

site_title: Reviving KL-Singapore HSR via private investment is feasible, but plenty of hurdles to overcome: analysts
summary: Malaysia is exploring the possibility of reviving the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project, which was scrapped in 2020, through private investment. The Malaysian government has invited five private companies to submit proposals, and analysts believe the project could enhance connectivity between Malaysia and Singapore, as well as open up opportunities for railway connections to other parts of South-east Asia. However, challenges and risks remain, including the need for government support and supervision, and the potential for huge costs and uncertainties.

site_title: The rationale and risks of owning 1 per cent in a Singapore private home
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore is investigating property transactions for tax avoidance, specifically cases of avoiding additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD). The tax agency is looking into "99-to-1" sales contracts where a first-time buyer sells a small share of a home to a relative, allowing them to avoid paying ABSD. This arrangement can create risks, such as disputes over the sale of the minority stake and potential inheritance issues. The government is considering revising the ABSD application for joint purchases of homes by family members to make it more equitable.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as wary traders weigh latest data
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Monday, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, and Taipei stocks edging up, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Manila stocks dipped. The mood was influenced by a bigger-than-expected drop in US retail sales, which could give the Federal Reserve more room to pause interest rate hikes. However, Fed governor Christopher Waller warned that monetary policy needs to be tightened further due to elevated inflation. Analysts expect the Fed to hike borrowing costs 25 basis points next month, despite concerns about a potential recession.

images.alt_text: Asian equities rose in early trade on Friday, with Tokyo leading the way followed by Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Google may lose search on Samsung devices to Microsoft Bing: NYT
summary: Samsung, the world's leading smartphone maker, is considering switching from Google to Microsoft's Bing as its default search service, potentially costing Google $3 billion in annual revenue. The decision comes as Microsoft's Bing gains credibility with the addition of OpenAI's technology, providing ChatGPT-like responses. Negotiations are ongoing, and Samsung may keep Google as its default provider. Google is working on updating its search services with artificial intelligence features to avoid losing ground.

site_title: China central bank boosts liquidity support with roll over of medium-term loans
summary: China's central bank has rolled over maturing medium-term policy loans with a higher cash injection, bolstering liquidity support for the economy. The move, which included keeping the interest rate unchanged at 2.75%, aims to replenish liquidity gaps created by upcoming tax payments and inject momentum to the economic recovery. The operation resulted in a net 20 billion yuan of fresh fund injection into the banking system, with some analysts suggesting the recovery from the Covid-19 slump is on track and lowering the chances for an interest rate cut.

site_title: The surprising thing AI engineers will tell you
summary: AI engineers are desperate for regulation to slow the industry's rapid growth and prevent "cutting corners." Competition among tech giants like Microsoft, Google, and Meta is forcing engineers to prioritize speed over safety and ethics. Proposed regulations, such as the European Commission's Artificial Intelligence Act and the White House's Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights, aim to govern AI systems but have limitations. Key concerns include interpretability, security, evaluations and audits, liability, and the potential for AI systems to become too human-like. Regulators must balance the need for caution with the industry's rapid growth and the potential for imperfect rules to hinder innovation.

site_title: European Central Bank to lift deposit rate to 3.75% peak in July, survey shows
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to raise interest rates three times in May, June, and July, with the deposit rate expected to peak at 3.75% in July, according to a survey. This move aims to combat high inflation, which remains above the ECB's 2% target. ECB officials have expressed a desire to slow the pace of rate hikes, with some suggesting a possible quarter-point increase instead of a 50-basis-point move. The decision is seen as a response to recent financial sector turmoil and efforts to reduce inflation.

site_title: RGE’s Apical in 1 billion euro JV to build largest biofuels plant in southern Europe
summary: Apical, a subsidiary of RGE, has entered into a 1 billion euro JV with Cepsa to build the largest second-generation biofuels plant in southern Europe. The plant, located at Cepsa's La Rábida Energy Park in Huelva, Spain, will produce up to 500,000 tonnes of sustainable aviation fuel annually, reducing carbon dioxide emissions by up to 90%. The facility is expected to begin operating in the first half of 2026 and will be designed with industry advances in AI and data analysis to maximize efficiency.

site_title: SpaceX Starship, world’s biggest rocket, set for first test flight
summary: SpaceX is set to conduct the first test flight of its Starship rocket, the world's largest, from Starbase in Boca Chica, Texas. The rocket, designed to send astronauts to the Moon and Mars, is scheduled to launch at 8:00 am Central Time on Monday. Elon Musk, the founder of SpaceX, has expressed caution, stating that "probably tomorrow will not be successful" and that the rocket's first mission will focus on gathering data to improve future designs. The test flight will involve the rocket separating from its booster and reaching an altitude of nearly 241km before splashing down in the Pacific Ocean.

site_title: Bank of England considers reform of deposit guarantee scheme: FT
summary: The Bank of England is considering reforms to its deposit guarantee scheme, following the recent global banking crisis. The proposed changes include raising the amount covered for businesses from £85,000 to an unspecified limit and forcing banks to pre-fund the system to speed up payouts. The reforms aim to address concerns about depositor protection, particularly for smaller banks. The Bank of England has declined to comment on the plans, which come after Governor Andrew Bailey expressed confidence in the financial system while acknowledging a need to review depositor protection.
