Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in February shrank 15.6 per cent year on year, easing from the 25 per cent tumble recorded in the previous month, data from Enterprise Singapore showed on Friday (Mar 17).

site_title: Is there life after influencing?
summary: Lee Tilghman, a former influencer, has found it difficult to fully transition to a traditional 9-to-5 job after leaving behind lucrative brand partnerships and high follower counts. Despite her enthusiasm for her new role, Tilghman admits to missing her online presence and the flexibility it provided. A coworker warned her about the stark contrast between her old and new life, comparing her former influencer lifestyle to a desk job. Tilghman's experience highlights the challenges of leaving behind a lucrative online career and adjusting to a more traditional work environment.

images.alt_text: “TikTok is kind of rocky right now and the goal of a content creator is to grow yourself across platforms to have a solid community, you don’t just want to focus on one app,” said Cassidy Jacobson, whose TikTok account have 1.5 million followers.
It’s the latest sign that regulators want to increase control on a format popularised by tech giants like TikTok owner ByteDance.

site_title: Arnault’s wealth soars to US$210 billion, leaving Musk in the dust
summary: Bernard Arnault's net worth soared to a record $210 billion, surpassing Elon Musk's $180 billion, after LVMH's quarterly sales exceeded expectations. The luxury conglomerate's shares rose 5.7% in Paris trading, driven by strong sales in China and other regions. Arnault's wealth surge is attributed to the company's growth, while Musk's wealth has dropped since peaking at $340 billion. The French billionaire is now the world's richest person outside the US, joining Musk and Jeff Bezos as the only individuals with a net worth exceeding $200 billion.

images.alt_text: LVMH’s soaring sales shows that demand for highly priced goods remains unabated even as a global economic slowdown looms.
Asia, excluding Japan, represented 30 per cent of sales in 2022, compared with 35 per cent in the previous year.
The billionaire was once dubbed “a wolf in cashmere” by a descendant of the Hermes dynasty after he launched a failed bid to take over the competing luxury group.

site_title: Apple to use only recycled cobalt in batteries by 2025
summary: Apple aims to make all products carbon neutral by 2030 by using recycled materials in its supply chain. The company plans to use only recycled cobalt in batteries by 2025, and will source 100% of its rare earth elements and 95% of its tungsten from recycled materials. Apple has also increased its recycling of cobalt from 13% to 25% in 2022, and now sources over two-thirds of its aluminum from recycled material. This move follows Apple's efforts to reduce its environmental impact and address concerns over cobalt mining in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

images.alt_text: Apple will open its first two retail stores in India next week, one in the financial hub of Mumbai and another in the capital New Delhi.
Apple is gradually diversifying the geography of its manufacturing base as brewing tensions between Washington and Beijing threaten to disrupt its carefully orchestrated supply chain.

site_title: China left out of Sri Lanka debt talks amid angst over delays
summary: Sri Lanka launched debt restructuring talks with major creditors, excluding China, amid growing frustration over Beijing's approach to debt woes in developing countries. The talks, led by the International Monetary Fund, involve finance chiefs from India, Japan, and the Paris Club of sovereign creditors. China, Sri Lanka's largest bilateral lender, was not invited, and its participation is seen as unlikely. The goal is to complete the debt restructure by September, with the IMF urging a speedy resolution. The move is a test case for China's willingness to work with other creditors in providing debt relief.

images.alt_text: ADB’s immediate priority in 2023 is to continue work on overall economic stability and support the banking and energy sectors, the lender's Sri Lanka country director Chen Chen said.
The central bank on Apr 4 held its benchmark rate at a two-decade high of 16.5 per cent in order to keep Asia’s fastest inflation in check while supporting economic recovery.
A general view of the main business district as rain clouds gather above in Colombo, Sri Lanka, November 17, 2020. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally, dollar dips further on easing rate expectations
summary: Asian stocks rallied, led by Tokyo, while the dollar dipped further on Friday after data showed inflation slowing, fueling hopes the Federal Reserve is nearing the end of its interest rate hikes. Producer prices fell, and jobless claims exceeded expectations, leading to a positive mood and a two percent advance for the Nasdaq. Investors now expect the Fed to hike rates 25 basis points in May but possibly hold after that, with some predicting a potential rate cut by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong was dragged by sharp losses in the tech sector after the Financial Times reported that Japan’s SoftBank was looking to unload a majority of its holdings in Alibaba.

site_title: China is willing to implement debt disposal framework: central bank governor
summary: China is willing to implement a debt disposal framework with other countries, according to People's Bank of China Governor Yi Gang, in a move aimed at resolving debt issues with the International Monetary Fund. The framework would streamline debt restructuring efforts, including data sharing and clearer timetables, and would not require multilateral development banks to share in debt restructuring losses. The agreement comes as China haggles with the IMF over development financing, with no specific date set for the meeting. This development could ease pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: China’s big banks have typically relied on so-called additional Tier-1 and Tier-2 bonds in recent years to replenish capital.
Think of “a sound and focal dollar” as a good or service that the US produces, just as China manufactures phones or Japan makes cars.
The economy is rebounding after Covid restrictions were dropped and infection waves eased.

site_title: Why economists are learning to speak human
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is shifting its language and policy emphasis, acknowledging that economics is embedded in politics and society. The fund's managing director, Kristalina Georgieva, has noted that social science can help make sense of economic challenges, using phrases like "cost-of-living crisis" instead of "inflation." This linguistic shift reflects a broader trend of politicization in the Western policy world, as governments intervene more heavily in finance, healthcare, and the energy sector. The IMF is now focusing on issues like climate change, women's rights, and healthcare, and is exploring the concept of "embeddedness" to understand the relationship between markets and society.

images.alt_text: “I am among those who know what are the consequences of a Cold War: it is loss of talent and contribution to the world,” IMF managing director, Kristalina Georgieva said.

“Output gaps for Asian economies are either closing or already closed, and currency depreciation last year is still passing through to domestic prices. These factors suggest that the battle to contain inflation is not yet over,” said Krishna Srinivasan, IMF director of the Asia and Pacific Department.
The IMF has warned that risks are high, and reducing debt vulnerabilities should be an “overriding priority", especially in low-income developing countries.

site_title: Gold edges up on weaker dollar, bets of Fed pause
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,043.16 per ounce, as the US dollar eased and economic data suggested the Federal Reserve may pause interest rate hikes. The dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold cheaper for foreign buyers. Weaker inflation data and signs of a loosening labor market also supported the gold price. This marks the second consecutive weekly gain, with gold up 1.7% so far in the week.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered an inflation hedge, but rising interest rates reduce the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

site_title: China’s mega banks plan funding spree to plug capital shortfall
summary: China's four largest banks, including ICBC, plan to sell at least 40 billion yuan (S$7.7 billion) of bonds to meet global capital requirements by early 2025. The banks will issue total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) bonds, which can absorb losses after other instruments in case of a risk event. The move comes as the banks face a capital shortfall of up to 3.7 trillion yuan to comply with TLAC requirements. The issuance is expected to be smoother for investors and less costly for the issuers, but recent volatility in offshore debt markets may add uncertainty.

images.alt_text: China’s expansion at 5.2 per cent would be substantially lower than its pre-Covid trend rate.

Visitors attend the China Import and Export Fair, also known as Canton Fair, in the southern city of Guangzhou, China, April 16, 2018. This year, 35,000 exhibitors have set up booths over roughly 1.5 million square metres to showcase fridges, gearboxes, anoraks and all manner of products.

At the Annual Economic Briefing, organised by The British Chamber of Commerce Singapore, on Thursday (Apr 13) are (from left): David Kelly, executive director of the British Chamber of Commerce Singapore; David Reynolds, partner at Select Investors; Miles Gooseman, chief executive officer of Select Investors; Michelle Jamrisko, senior Asia economy reporter at Bloomberg; Selena Ling, chief economist and head of treasury research and strategy at OCBC; Alex Holmes, senior economist at Oxford Economics; Chidu Narayanan, Asia FX and rates strategist at BNP Paribas; and Dr Chua Hak Bin, chief economist at Maybank.

site_title: Twitter launches way for users to charge for access to their content
summary: Twitter is allowing users to charge for access to their content, including long-form text and video, in an effort to monetize the platform. Owner Elon Musk announced the move in a post, stating that users will keep at least 70% of their subscription revenue for the first 12 months. The company aims to compete with Substack, a similar platform, and generate revenue through a premium version called Twitter Blue, which has seen only 1% of monthly users sign up.

site_title: Accenture is delaying new-hire starts on top of job cuts
summary: Accenture is delaying start dates for some recent hires due to its efforts to recalculate its massive workforce in a cost-conscious environment. The company had previously announced plans to cut 19,000 jobs over the next 18 months. This delay affects new hires, with some graduates facing start dates pushed back to early 2024. Accenture is offering additional signing bonuses to those whose start dates are delayed, and the decision is seen as a way to create a better new joiner experience.

images.alt_text: More than half of the layoffs will affect staff at its non-billable corporate functions, Accenture said.

site_title: Karl Liew, son of CAG’s ex-chairman, sentenced to 2 weeks’ jail for lying to judge in Parti Liyani case
summary: Karl Liew, son of Changi Airport Group's former chairman, was sentenced to two weeks' jail for lying to a district judge in the Parti Liyani case. Liew, 45, pleaded guilty to giving false information to a public servant in March. He had falsely testified that a cream polo T-shirt and a red blouse belonged to him during the trial of his former maid, Parti Liyani, who was accused of stealing from their household. Liew could have faced up to two years in jail, but was instead given a two-week sentence.

images.alt_text: Karl Liew pleaded guilty to one charge of giving false information to a public servant.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Logos Reit
summary: ESR-Logos Reit saw a positive development as Ceva Logistics Singapore renewed its lease at 15 Greenwich Drive with a 20% rental reversion for a three-year term. This positive rental reversion contributed to the Reit's stable performance, with its units closing flat at S$0.33 on Thursday.

site_title: Western Digital falls on report that hackers are seeking ransom
summary: Western Digital shares dropped 4.5% after a report that hackers are seeking a ransom of at least $10 million for stolen data, including customer information. The company had previously disclosed a security breach, but details were scarce. Hackers shared executive phone numbers and other information to negotiate a ransom, with no response from Western Digital. The incident is part of a 24% decline in the company's shares over the past 12 months.

images.alt_text: In June, Western Digital announced a review of strategic alternatives following discussions with activist investor Elliott Investment Management.

site_title: Oil drops 1% after scaling multi-month highs on Opec’s demand warning
summary: Oil prices fell 1.4% to $86.09 a barrel, with Brent crude dropping $1.24 and US West Texas Intermediate slipping $1.10, after Opec's demand warning highlighted rising inventories and challenges to global growth. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) flagged downside risks to summer oil demand, while a weaker US dollar and signs of a demand recovery in China provided support for oil prices.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 15, 2019 shows an Aramco oil facility near al-Khurj area, just outside the Saudi capital Riyadh. - Saudi Arabia's push for oil production cuts has placed new strain on its stormy relationship with the United States, though analysts say any predictions of an all-out break are premature. The move by OPEC+ -- composed of the Riyadh-led OPEC cartel and an additional group of 10 exporters headed by Russia -- would reduce global output by two million barrels per day from November. (Photo by FAYEZ NURELDINE / AFP)
In a negative for oil demand, the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday trimmed its 2023 global growth outlook, citing the impact of higher interest rates.

site_title: Two individuals convicted of insider trading in shares of Broadway Industrial Group
summary: Two individuals, Tay Yew Khem and Hui Choy Leng, have been convicted of insider trading in Broadway Industrial Group's shares. They received non-public information about the company's impending sale of businesses from its former CFO. Tay was sentenced to 12 weeks' imprisonment, while Hui received a four-month sentence. All profits made from the trading have been paid in full to the state by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

images.alt_text: gavel, auction, law
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Amazon joins generative AI race, targets cloud customers
summary: Amazon has joined the generative AI race by announcing two large-language models, Titan, designed to generate text and power web search personalization. The models will be made available on AWS's Bedrock service, where developers can access AI tools from other companies. Amazon's in-house chips enable cost-effective solutions and performance, and the technology is seen as a response to customer demand. The company has also announced that its predictive code tool, CodeWhisperer, will be free for individual developers.

images.alt_text: Amazon said CEO Andy Jassy’s 2021 award, originally worth US$214 million, was “intended to represent most of his compensation for the coming years”, a reason why it had no plans to bestow more stock in 2023 or last year.
India is a key growth market for Amazon and its Prime Video streaming service.
Amazon has only released one internally developed game — the online role-playing title New World.

site_title: With Q1 GDP up 0.1%, economists see higher risk of technical recession
summary: Singapore's economy grew 0.1% year-on-year in Q1, slower than expected, with manufacturing contracting 6% and services sector growing 1.8%. The contraction in manufacturing and weakness in global trade have led some economists to warn of a technical recession, defined as two consecutive quarters of quarter-on-quarter contraction. This growth rate is lower than the 2.1% expansion in Q4 and below the forecast of 0.6% year-on-year growth.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The gloomy outlook combined with persistent inflation has heightened analyst debate over whether the Monetary Authority of Singapore should tighten policy again at its review on Friday (Apr 14).

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% or 14.62 points to 3,309.16, following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's decision to leave monetary policy settings unchanged. The move came despite a lower-than-expected 0.1% year-on-year economic growth in the first quarter of 2023. Other gains included Sembcorp Marine, AsiaPhos, Singtel, and Thai Beverage, while banking stocks like DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose.

images.alt_text: One of ESR-Logos Reit's top 20 tenants has renewed their lease at a positive rental reversion of 20 per cent.

site_title: Key ESR-Logos Reit tenant renews lease at 20% increase
summary: Ceva Logistics Singapore, the anchor tenant of ESR-Logos Reit's 15 Greenwich Drive property, renewed its lease for a three-year term at a 20% increase. The logistics company occupies 31,230 square meters, or 74.2% of the property. This renewal demonstrates the resilience of the logistics sector and reinforces ESR-Logos Reit's strategy to focus on new economy assets. The leasing market for new-economy assets remains robust, and the company expects positive rental reversion for its portfolio.

images.alt_text: While the analyst believes that the Reit’s fundamentals are healthy, she advised investors to consider taking up the preferential offering to avoid dilution of shares.
Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.
As at 9.15 am, the Reit hits a 4-month low of S$0.325, down S$0.025 or 7.1 per cent from Monday’s closing at S$0.35 before the trust issued a trading halt

site_title: ‘Flash drought’ frequency increasing due to climate change: study
summary: A study published in the journal Science found that flash droughts, characterized by rapid onset and devastating impact, are increasing in frequency due to climate change. Researchers analyzed satellite data and ground moisture readings from 1951-2014 and found that flash droughts are increasing more quickly, especially in Europe, North and East Asia, and the Sahel region. The rapid onset of flash droughts gives humans little time to adapt, and the data suggests a general increase in drought onset speeds, with a "robust transition" from slow to flash droughts at the global scale.

images.alt_text: A jogger runs along a footpath surrounded by parched scrubland at the Bosque Metropolitano city forest site at Cerro Almodovar, in the Vicalvaro district of Madrid, Spain, on Tuesday, April 4, 2023. Extreme weather and tree die-offs have hampered the Spanish capital’s plan to establish a 75-kilometer woodland, turning a “tree cemetery” into a political flashpoint. Photographer: Emilio Parra Doiztua/Bloomberg

site_title: LVMH breaks into world top 10 as market value nears US$500 billion
summary: LVMH, Europe's largest company by market value, has broken into the world's top 10 with a market capitalization nearing $500 billion. The luxury powerhouse's soaring sales, driven by strong demand for high-priced goods, particularly in China, have led to a 5% increase in its share price and a 29% year-to-date rally. This growth is attributed to the rise of wealthy consumers worldwide, with luxury shares outperforming the Stoxx Europe 600 Index.

images.alt_text: Asia, excluding Japan, represented 30 per cent of sales in 2022, compared with 35 per cent in the previous year.
The billionaire was once dubbed “a wolf in cashmere” by a descendant of the Hermes dynasty after he launched a failed bid to take over the competing luxury group.
Louis Vuitton, the world’s biggest luxury brand, last February led the way to a string of price hikes from some of the industry’s biggest names.

site_title: Europe: Luxury shares boost Stoxx 600, French stocks hit new record high
summary: Europe's luxury stocks boosted the Stoxx 600, with LVMH and Hermes hitting record highs after upbeat sales reports. The pan-European index rose 0.4%, inching closer to its 22-year high. France's CAC 40 and Copenhagen's OMX 20 also reached new highs. European stocks have recovered from last month's declines, outperforming the S&P 500, amid reduced fears of a euro zone recession. Investors are taking advantage of perceived undervaluation, driving investment decisions based on fair value plays.

images.alt_text: All three major US stock indices advanced on Thursday, led by the Nasdaq, which packed on two per cent following a rally in Apple, Netflix and other big-name tech companies.

site_title: China’s largest trade fair to reopen in full glory but mood could be sombre
summary: China's largest trade fair, the Canton Fair, is set to reopen after three years with 35,000 exhibitors showcasing products, but the mood is expected to be somber due to a soft outlook for global growth. Sharply higher borrowing costs in the US and Europe have hit demand for Chinese-made goods, with many exhibitors citing weakening external demand and insufficient orders as major challenges. The fair, which attracts thousands of companies from over 200 countries, comes as China's manufacturing sector faces geopolitical tensions and a sharp drop in factory gate prices.

images.alt_text: The view from the observation deck at Shanghai Tower in Shanghai. Many developers saw a decline in their profit margins as they acquired land at higher prices several years ago when the market was red hot.

At the Annual Economic Briefing, organised by The British Chamber of Commerce Singapore, on Thursday (Apr 13) are (from left): David Kelly, executive director of the British Chamber of Commerce Singapore; David Reynolds, partner at Select Investors; Miles Gooseman, chief executive officer of Select Investors; Michelle Jamrisko, senior Asia economy reporter at Bloomberg; Selena Ling, chief economist and head of treasury research and strategy at OCBC; Alex Holmes, senior economist at Oxford Economics; Chidu Narayanan, Asia FX and rates strategist at BNP Paribas; and Dr Chua Hak Bin, chief economist at Maybank.
Asia, excluding Japan, represented 30 per cent of sales in 2022, compared with 35 per cent in the previous year.

site_title: Bank Indonesia forecast to hold rates at 5.75% for rest of 2023: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to maintain its interest rate at 5.75% for the rest of 2023, according to a Reuters poll of 30 economists. The rate, already the highest since July 2019, is expected to remain unchanged for a third consecutive meeting due to cooling inflation, which has been largely below the central bank's target range of 2-4% since September. Economists predict moderate economic growth of 4.9% this year and 5.0% next year, with inflation expected to return to the target range in September.

images.alt_text: A customer scans a QR code to pay a food at a food stall in Jakarta. Indonesia's internet penetration stands at 77 per cent, up from just 13 per cent in 2009.
Harita Nickel's president Roy Arman Arfandy (right) and members of its board at the Indonesia Stock Exchange in Jakarta on Apr 12.

site_title: What de-dollarisation? The dollar rules the world
summary: The US dollar's dominance in international transactions, accounting for 88% of global exchanges, is likely to last due to its stability and branding capabilities. While some nations, such as Russia and Brazil, are exploring "de-dollarisation" strategies, the US has the world's deepest and most liquid financial markets, making it difficult for alternative currencies to gain traction. The dollar's secure future as a safe-haven currency is attributed to its stable value and the US's military might, making it an attractive option for investors and a key driver of global trade.

images.alt_text: Even as the perennial fight over the US debt ceiling ensues in Washington, the greenback's status in global trade may be beginning to lose lustre.

The sharp appreciation of the US dollar through 2021 and much of last year caused a lot of problems in developed and developing countries alike; they will be thankful for the respite as the value of the greenback eases.
Since 2009 China has embarked on a process of currency internationalisation by invoicing more of its trade in yuan. But progress has been slow.

site_title: Another Covid-like pandemic could hit the world within 10 years
summary: A 27.5% chance of a Covid-19-like pandemic occurring within the next decade is predicted by predictive health analytics firm Airfinity. The rapid spread of the H5N1 bird flu strain and climate change contribute to the risk, but effective vaccine rollout can reduce fatalities. In a worst-case scenario, a mutated bird flu virus could kill 15,000 people in the UK daily, highlighting the need for pandemic preparedness measures. The likelihood of a deadly pandemic drops to 8.1% if vaccines are rolled out 100 days after a new pathogen is discovered.

site_title: Boeing to pause some 737 Max deliveries over quality issue
summary: Boeing is pausing deliveries of some 737 Max models due to a manufacturing issue involving two fittings that attach the jet's vertical tail to its fuselage. The problem, discovered by Spirit AeroSystems, affects a portion of 737 jets built since 2019 and may impact undelivered aircraft and those stored at Boeing. Deliveries are expected to decline in the near term as the company inspects affected aircraft. This disruption comes as Boeing was regaining its footing after years of turmoil caused by the pandemic and global grounding of the Max.

site_title: Celine Dion back making music, releasing five new songs
summary: Celine Dion has announced the release of her new album "Love Again," which serves as the soundtrack for a film of the same name. The album includes five new songs and past hits, marking her first music release since being diagnosed with Stiff-Person Syndrome in December 2022. The album will be released on May 5, coinciding with the film's theatrical release, and Dion expressed her excitement to share the music with fans.

images.alt_text: The Foreign Correspondents’ Club of Japan, which hosted a press conference by the accuser, Kauan Okamoto (top), said the company also failed to respond to its invitations to comment.
Huge Titanic replica to open as Chinese tourist destination

site_title: TikTok faces ban in Montana as US backlash continues
summary: The US state of Montana is on the verge of implementing a total ban on TikTok, with a final vote set for Friday. The ban, which would make it the first state to outlaw the app, has been passed by the state's Republican-dominated lower house and faces a governor's signature to become law. The proposed ban would require Apple and Google to remove TikTok from their app stores and impose daily fines of $10,000 on companies found in violation. The move is part of a growing national backlash against TikTok, with the White House reportedly considering legislation that could pave the way for a national ban.

images.alt_text: The world’s most valuable tech startup has rented space in International Finance Centre in Central.
ByteDance’s profit last year came despite mounting losses at fast-growing TikTok.
While calm and eloquent, it appeared that TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi could not sway hostile US lawmakers.
Temu topped US app download rankings in early April, a spot it held since January.
Chew Shou Zi, TikTok’s chief executive was attacked relentlessly by US lawmakers who were described by TikTok supporters as “old, tech-illiterate, out of touch, paranoid and self-righteous".

site_title: Gender equality in farming could add US$1 trillion to world economy
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) report suggests that eliminating discrimination against women in agriculture could increase the global economy by 1% ($1 trillion) and reduce hunger by 2 percentage points, benefiting 45 million people. The report recommends boosting land ownership by women, improving access to childcare, and increasing social protection to enhance employment and resilience in agrifood systems, which are crucial for women's livelihoods.

site_title: Evergrande EV unit fights for survival after vowing to overtake Tesla
summary: Evergrande New Energy Vehicle (NEV) Group, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, is struggling to survive after vowing to overtake Tesla as the world's largest EV manufacturer within three to five years. The company, backed by billionaire Hui Ka Yan, has only delivered 900 units of its flagship model and is seeking a lifeline after warning it would need to stop production unless new funds are secured. Potential investors are deterred by the company's legacy staff, red tape, and concerns over the transfer of its carmaking licence, which would require approval from Beijing.

images.alt_text: Evergrande NEV said it is seeking to cut costs by reducing staff numbers and improving management efficiency.
Having touted the car as early as 2019 and pledging to rival Tesla within three to five years, Evergrande NEV has been plagued by production delays and setbacks.

site_title: BlackRock sells asset-backed bonds from Credit Suisse’s books
summary: BlackRock has sold a portfolio of structured bonds valued at at least $300 million from Credit Suisse's books. This sale, facilitated by BlackRock's Financial Markets Advisory group, comes weeks after Credit Suisse was sold to UBS Group. This marks BlackRock's second structured bond sale process this month, following a similar sale of $114 billion in securities from failed lenders Signature Bank and Silicon Valley Bank. The move is part of Credit Suisse's "new strategy and transformation plan" announced in October, which included significant exposure reduction to securitized products.

images.alt_text: Blackstone and many of its rivals are flush with cash to invest from pensions, endowments and insurers.
On Monday, the FDIC announced the marketing process for an about US$60 billion loan portfolio retained in receivership following the failure of Signature Bank.
BlackRock still hasn’t issued any products under the new programme even though its wealth management joint venture was allowed to join given its experience with a previous trial.

site_title: Cyclone hits Australia with ‘record-breaking’ wind speeds
summary: A record-breaking tropical cyclone, Tropical Cyclone Ilsa, hit north-western Australia, bringing winds of up to 218 km/h and gusts of 288 km/h. The cyclone made landfall near the town of Pardoo, causing significant damage to the Pardoo Roadhouse, but major population centers appeared to escape the worst of the storm. Authorities have issued "red alerts" and warned of a threat to lives and homes, but no major population centers have reported damage. The cyclone has weakened to a category three and is expected to maintain an unusual intensity as it moves across the Outback.

images.alt_text: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear station, about 220 km northeast of Tokyo, was badly damaged by a magnitude 9.0 earthquake and tsunami in March 2011, sparking three reactor meltdowns.
JPMorgan said it expected now that the Turkey central bank would cut interest rates by another 100 basis points at its meeting next week to 8 per cent.
Tens of thousands of homes are without electricity, people are being evacuated and roads are closed in northern regions Tuesday as the cyclone leaves a trail of destruction.

site_title: PayPal slashes outgoing CEO Schulman’s pay 31% to US$22 million
summary: PayPal Holdings has cut outgoing CEO Dan Schulman's pay by 32% to $22 million for 2022, after missing its financial targets. Schulman, who announced his retirement at year-end, had previously earned $32 million. The company failed to meet targets for revenue, adjusted operating margin, and net new active users. Despite this, Schulman was commended for leading the company through challenging times. The company will face shareholder proposals related to its practices, including one that would require a report on law enforcement requests for abortion-related information.

images.alt_text: Blake Jorgensen was CFO only since August after Rainey had decamped for Walmart.
PayPal’s submission said it supported mandatory credit licences for BNPL providers and rules requiring the companies to check a user’s suitability for a loan above an “appropriate threshold”.
In a divergence from prior quarters, PayPal said it will not provide a forecast for full-year revenue growth.

site_title: North Korea says latest test was of ‘solid-fuel’ ICBM: KCNA
summary: North Korea announced its latest test was of a "solid-fuel" intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), the "Hwasung-18," which leader Kim Jong Un said marks a major step in the country's nuclear deterrence capabilities. The ICBM was test-fired on Thursday and flew 1,000 km, detected by Seoul's military. This is the first solid-fuel ICBM North Korea has developed, a key goal for Kim. The test comes ahead of the country's Day of the Sun anniversary on April 15, typically marked with significant military displays.

images.alt_text: A woman watches street TV broadcasting breaking news of a North Korean missile launch in Tokyo on April 13, 2023.

site_title: China, India to drive about half of 2023 global growth: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts that China and India will account for about half of global growth in 2023, with Asia's economy expected to contribute over 70% of global growth. China's expansion at 5.2% is lower than its pre-Covid trend rate, but is still lifting activity in the region. The IMF warns that policymakers must be aware of financial stress and develop contingency plans, as enduring inflation and leverage risks threaten the global economy. The fund's director notes that Asia's growth is largely driven by China's demand for consumption goods.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The skyline of the Beijing's Central Business District rises behind people crossing a street during evening rush hour as the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues in China, April 15, 2020. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Schumacher’s US$9.5 million F1 Ferrari is tip of valuable car market
summary: Michael Schumacher's 2000 Ferrari F1-2000, which helped the team win its first world title in over two decades, sold at a private auction in Hong Kong for an undisclosed amount, estimated to be between $7.5 million and $9.5 million. The sale reflects the growing interest in decommissioned race cars, with prices increasing due to their historic importance and racing history. These cars, built to meet specific racing series requirements, are now gaining traction in the ultra-niche world of high-end car collecting, offering an "ultimate driving experience" for enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: Calvin Lo is considering backing a bid to enter in 2026 and money was not the major hurdle.

The FIA said “security measures and the protocols which were expected to be in place for the event were not enforced, resulting in an unsafe environment for the spectators, drivers and race officials”.

site_title: Digital competitiveness now more equitably spread across Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's digital competitiveness index has seen a significant rise, with a median score of 38.5 in 2023, up from 35.2 in 2022 and 32.1 in 2020. Internet penetration has increased to 77% nationwide, with second-tier and third-tier cities catching up with first-tier cities like Jakarta. The report attributes the improvement to regional governments implementing digital payment systems and initiatives supporting micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. Indonesia's digital economy is expected to reach $360 billion by 2030, with greater inclusiveness of the digital economy expected to drive sustainable economic growth and wealth creation across the country.

images.alt_text: Harita Nickel's president Roy Arman Arfandy (right) and members of its board at the Indonesia Stock Exchange in Jakarta on Apr 12.
China’s reopening distributes benefits to the rest of the Asia region

The cost of the line linking the capital Jakarta with the textile hub of Bandung has overshot, pushing Indonesia to seek a new loan from the China Development Bank to help cover a US$1.2 billion cost overrun.

site_title: North to North-west (and back)
summary: Travelers can explore North-west England's charming countryside, where 60mph speed limits and single carriageway roads await. Cheshire County offers picturesque villages, Roman-era ruins, and period manor houses. The Beatles and Liverpool are closely linked, with a permanent exhibition, statues, and football clubs. The city's revitalized docklands feature the Tate Liverpool gallery, and the nearby Bentley Heritage Garage showcases historic models of the luxury car brand. A road trip through the region also includes stops at The Pig near Bath and Rookery Hall, an elegant 19th-century country house hotel in Cheshire.

images.alt_text:
The revamped dining area of Man
Wah at Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong.

site_title: Global watchdog issues blueprint for banks to report cyberattacks
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) has recommended a blueprint for banks to report cyberattacks in a common format to speed up responses to hacking and limit financial stability fallout. The FSB aims to harmonize incident reporting, removing barriers and using a standardized "cyber lexicon" to increase convergence in reporting, which could help mitigate spill-over effects across borders and sectors.

site_title: Turnover matters in companies’ willingness to trade profits for planet: report
summary: A recent Standard Chartered report, "The Sustainability Commitment Paradox," found that 54% of 300 polled companies worldwide are willing to make lower financial returns for positive environmental and social impacts, while 46% prioritize higher profits. Companies with higher turnover (65%) are more inclined to engage in sustainable practices, driven by stakeholder pressures, business opportunities, and regulatory requirements. In contrast, companies with lower turnover tend to prioritize short-term financial security. The report highlights the need for government and industry support to help Singapore companies fast-track sustainability initiatives.

images.alt_text: While almost all survey respondents agree that 80 per cent of Singapore's buildings should be "green" by 2030, only 38 per cent say they have a full and comprehensive understanding of green buildings.
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: Japan approves Osaka as site of country’s first casino
summary: Japan has approved a plan to build its first casino in Osaka, a 1.8 trillion yen ($17.9 billion) resort complex set to open in 2029. The project, spearheaded by US casino operator MGM Resorts International and local partner Orix Corp, aims to attract 6 million international tourists and 14 million domestic visitors annually, generating 520 billion yen in revenue. The resort, located on Yumeshima island in Osaka Bay, will also feature a hotel, shopping mall, and ferry terminal, and has secured 550 billion yen in project financing from MUFG Bank and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp.

images.alt_text: Building a casino is key to Japan’s hopes of capturing resurgent tourism demand and doubling the number of foreign visitors compared with pre-pandemic levels to 60 million by 2030.

site_title: Property investments can benefit non-property groups
summary: Non-property groups can benefit from property investments, as seen in Metro Holdings and DBS, which have contributed to their bottom-line performance. However, properties are illiquid assets, requiring careful risk assessment and long-term financial capabilities. Investors should consider metrics beyond yield, such as internal rate of returns or compound annual growth rate, to accurately evaluate property investments. By doing so, non-property groups can tap into the benefits of property investments while mitigating potential risks.

site_title: Biodiversity is next big ESG hurdle for banks, as standards and metrics are hard to define
summary: Banks in the Asia-Pacific region are starting to consider biodiversity risks when assessing lending decisions, but challenges persist due to the lack of standardized frameworks and metrics. The absence of unified approaches to assess biodiversity risks and set key performance indicators makes it difficult to accurately measure and manage such risks. Despite efforts to address this, trade-offs between reducing greenhouse gas emissions and biodiversity loss are unavoidable, and lenders face reputational and litigation risks. International efforts to accelerate biodiversity conservation are underway, with the establishment of a landmark biodiversity agreement to protect 30% of land and water by 2030, and the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures set to publish its final recommendations.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

A fire rages in the Amazon rainforest, south of Novo Progresso in Para State, Brazil, Aug 16, 2020. Almost half of the companies most reliant on the commodities responsible for deforestation, and the financial firms that back them, have no policy to rein it in, a report on Wednesday said.

site_title: French pension strikes resume ahead of constitutional ruling
summary: French pension strikes resumed on April 13 ahead of a Constitutional Council ruling on the government's pension reform bill, which aims to raise the minimum retirement age to 64. Unions, backed by left-wing parties, are holding strikes and protests across France, seeking to maintain pressure on the government. The strikes come despite polls showing broad public opposition to the reform, and the government is expected to meet with unions after the Council's ruling. The outcome of the ruling is uncertain, but a decision is due on Friday evening.

images.alt_text: French riot police try to extinguish a fire amid clashes during a demonstration against the French government's pension reform, in Paris, France, March 25, 2023.

site_title: Global bank stress has had ‘muted’ impact on Canada, central bank governor says
summary: Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem stated that global bank stress has had a "muted" impact on Canada's financial system, contrary to expectations. Macklem said that while there is some spillover, the country's system has been relatively resilient. The Bank of Canada has been actively monitoring risks and is prepared to provide liquidity if needed. Macklem's comments came after recent banking stress in the US and Europe, including the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem said he wanted to let the eight previous rate hikes sink in and would hold off on further increases as long as inflation came down as forecast.

site_title: US: Stocks rally, while dollar drops after latest inflation data
summary: US stocks rallied, with the Nasdaq gaining 2% due to a surge in tech companies like Apple and Netflix. The dollar dropped to a one-year low against the euro as traders anticipated a potential shift in Federal Reserve monetary policy. Inflation data showed wholesale prices declining 0.5% in March, with energy prices contributing to the drop. The news sparked optimism about the end of the Fed's interest rate increases cycle, but analysts warned that "wishful thinking" could prevail as markets await crucial earnings reports from top banks.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: US producer prices fell in March by the most since the start of pandemic
summary: US producer prices fell 0.5% in March, the largest decline since the start of the pandemic, driven by a drop in gasoline costs. The core PPI, excluding food and energy, rose 3.4% year-over-year, the smallest gain in over two years. The decline in producer prices may bolster the case for the Federal Reserve to pause interest-rate hikes, but an increase in oil prices could limit progress on wholesale prices.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 16, 2022 a “Now Hiring” sign at T.J. Maxx in Annapolis, Maryland. - US job gains eased in March for a second straight month, government data showed March 7, 2023, adding to signs that the world's largest economy is cooling as policymakers push on in their fight against inflation. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Twitter taps eToro to let users trade in stocks, crypto
summary: Twitter has partnered with eToro to allow users to trade stocks and cryptocurrencies directly within the platform. The trading data will be available through Twitter's Cashtags feature, which was launched in 2012. Users can now click through to eToro's platform to see information about an asset and make an investment. This move is part of a series of changes made by Elon Musk since acquiring Twitter for $44 billion in October.

site_title: Fake bomb causes evacuation of Dutch parliament building
summary: The Dutch parliament building was evacuated on April 13, 2023, after a bomb alert turned out to be false. A package with a teddy bear and wires addressed to anti-Islam politician Geert Wilders was discovered, prompting the evacuation. Wilders confirmed that the package was a fake bomb, stating it was delivered to his mail room. The security measures were a result of death threats Wilders has faced for years, and he was allowed to re-enter the building about an hour after the evacuation.

site_title: IMF urges Asia to keep monetary policy tighter for longer
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Asian countries to maintain tighter monetary policies for longer due to still substantial inflation risks. IMF Director Krishna Srinivasan stated that core inflation remains sticky, driving persistent inflation and wage pressure. The IMF expects the Asia-Pacific region's economy to grow 4.6% this year, mainly driven by China's reopening. However, the IMF notes that the battle to contain inflation is not yet over, and currency depreciation is still passing through to domestic prices.

images.alt_text: The IMF has warned that risks are high, and reducing debt vulnerabilities should be an “overriding priority", especially in low-income developing countries.

IMF trimmed their forecast for world growth, but said there were “plausible” scenarios, flowing from the recent failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in the US and the forced merger of Credit Suisse, that could cut growth even deeper
IMF's Mission Chief for India Nada Choueiri said a “good monsoon” would help reduce food prices that’ll help bring down the overall inflation to under 5 per cent in the current financial year.

site_title: European privacy watchdog creates ChatGPT task force
summary: The European Data Protection Board (EDPB) has established a task force to address concerns about artificial intelligence, specifically ChatGPT, and create general policies on setting privacy rules. The move follows Italy's unilateral action to curb ChatGPT and comes as experts, the US government, and several European governments express concern about AI's impact on safety, privacy, and jobs. The task force aims to foster cooperation and exchange information on possible enforcement actions, with the goal of aligning policy positions among member states.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Google asks judge to toss US antitrust lawsuit, says a ‘superior product’ is not unlawful
summary: Google has asked a US judge to dismiss the Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit, arguing that its dominance in search is not unlawful. The company claims its payments to smartphone makers, carriers, and browsers are legal revenue-sharing deals, not efforts to exclude rivals. Google's lawyer stated that offering a superior product is never unlawful and there is zero consumer harm from the deals. The judge will decide on summary judgement, with the case set for trial in September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed Google logo is seen in this illustration taken April 12, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

The Korea Fair Trade Commission said that Google bolstered its market dominance, and hurt local app market One Store’s revenue and value as a platform, by requiring video game makers to exclusively release their titles on Google Play.

The Alliance of Digital India Foundation (ADIF) filing marks the latest tussle between Google and Indian startups, which have repeatedly criticized the US company for imposing unfair business restrictions that hurt smaller players.

site_title: Tudor’s subtle makeovers
summary: Tudor has released an updated Black Bay lineup featuring subtle makeovers, including a thinner case profile, redesigned screw-down crown, and new bracelet options. The new models are certified as Master Chronometers by Switzerland's Federal Institute of Metrology, offering improved anti-magnetic properties, water resistance, and precision. The updated watches are powered by Tudor's Manufacture Calibre MT5602-U and MT5652 movements, with prices ranging from S$5,780 to S$6,220.

pmluxetudor14 - Black Bay

site_title: CVC mulling sale of stake in Malaysia’s QSR Brands after IPO delays: sources
summary: Private equity firm CVC Capital Partners is considering selling its 21% stake in QSR Brands, the Malaysian operator of KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants in South-east Asia, after multiple failed attempts to list the company on the local stock exchange. The company, which has tried to hold an IPO since 2017, last postponed its plan amid concerns over poor macroeconomic conditions. CVC is in talks with an adviser to explore the sale of its stake worth over RM1.2 billion.

images.alt_text: McDonald's said in January that it planned to cut corporate jobs and eliminate certain initiatives, even as it accelerates new store openings.
The company proposed a restructuring deal with lenders to reduce debt by about US$4.53 billion, mainly through creditors getting equity in the reorganised group.

site_title: WTA to resume tournaments in China this year
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) has announced it will resume operations in China this year, citing the "extraordinary price" of suspending tournaments as the reason for reversing its decision. The suspension was made after Peng Shuai, a former doubles number one, accused a senior Chinese government official of sexual assault in 2021. The WTA has received assurances that Peng is living safely with her family in Beijing, and the organization will resume tournaments in China this September.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as economic data ease rate jitters
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Thursday as moderating producer prices in March and a jump in weekly jobless claims alleviated concerns about interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones rose 22.47 points, or 0.07%, to 33,668.97, while the S&P 500 gained 8.09 points, or 0.20%, to 4,100.04. Investors found relief in the data, which may ease rate jitters.

site_title: IMF chief urges world to avoid a ‘second Cold War’
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that countries must take action to avoid a "second Cold War" and its costly consequences, including loss of talent and economic fragmentation. The IMF predicts that growing trade fragmentation could reduce the global economy by up to 7% if not addressed. Georgieva urged policymakers to work together to reduce budget deficits, improve growth prospects, and invest in digital transformation, renewable energy, and green energy, estimating that $1 trillion per year is needed for these initiatives.

images.alt_text: “Output gaps for Asian economies are either closing or already closed, and currency depreciation last year is still passing through to domestic prices. These factors suggest that the battle to contain inflation is not yet over,” said Krishna Srinivasan, IMF director of the Asia and Pacific Department.

site_title: China’s reopening and engagement with partners can benefit Asean: economists
summary: China's reopening and engagement with its partners, particularly ASEAN, can benefit the region's economies, according to economists. China's trade with ASEAN increased 9.6% year-on-year to $183.3 billion, making it the largest trading partner for the region. The appointment of a "business-friendly premier" has also boosted China's global image, paving the way for increased investment and talent flow. ASEAN countries such as Singapore, Indonesia, and Vietnam are favored by Chinese investors, and China's reopening is expected to drive global growth, benefiting countries like Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Imports increased about 6.3 per cent in March from a year ago, after rising 11.1 per cent in February.
The main driver of China's recovery is likely to be domestic spending rather than exports, said Amro chief economist Khor Hoe Ee.
Li thanked the foreign representatives in the audience for the support they’d offered over the years and urged them to “take a long-term view” amid economic challenges.
“No matter how the international situation changes, China will unswervingly expand its market opening.” Chinese Premier Li Qiang said.

site_title: A time to wow
summary: The Watches & Wonders Geneva 2023 showcased a positive year for Swiss luxury watchmaking, with brands releasing adventurous and innovative products. Trends included a focus on pop culture, vibrant colors, and complications with a twist. Established brands like Rolex and Cartier introduced playful designs, while progressive brands like Hublot and Chanel continued to experiment. The industry's top watchmakers also returned to high complications, with a focus on purity of concept and ease of use. The event highlighted the return of China and Hong Kong's gradual reopening, with many brands catering to this growing market.

images.alt_text: pmluxerolex14 - 1. The 950 Platinum Cosmograph Daytona is Rolex's first Oyster Perpetual model to have a transparent case-back

site_title: Triple treat for watch lovers
summary: Three luxury watch brands, Cartier, A. Lange & Sohne, and Chopard, showcased unique offerings at Watches and Wonders 2023. Cartier introduced the Santos Dumont Micromotor, a skeletonised version of a 1904 model featuring an automatic open-worked movement and a unique micro-rotor. A. Lange & Sohne unveiled the Odysseus Chronograph, a limited edition of 100 pieces powered by a self-winding movement. Chopard showcased the Alpine Eagle 41 XPS, an ultra-thin case with a salmon-colored dial and double chronometer-rated.

images.alt_text: Black Bay

site_title: British miniskirt pioneer Mary Quant dies at 93
summary: Mary Quant, the British fashion designer who popularized the miniskirt and made women's clothes fun and affordable, has died at 93. Known for her iconic bob hairstyle and bold designs, Quant turned the thigh-skimming super-short hemlines into an international trend in the 1960s. Her legacy can still be seen on high-street fashion, and she remains one of the most internationally recognized fashion designers of the 20th century.

images.alt_text: Asia, excluding Japan, represented 30 per cent of sales in 2022, compared with 35 per cent in the previous year.

site_title: India’s Infosys forecasts slower FY24 revenue growth of 4%-7%
summary: Infosys forecasts slower FY24 revenue growth of 4%-7%, lower than analysts' expectations of 10.73%, due to the turmoil in the US banking sector prompting clients to tighten spending. The company's consolidated net profit rose 7.77% to 61.28 billion rupees in the three months ended Mar 31, while revenue rose 16% to 374.41 billion rupees. Infosys expects FY24 operating margin in the range of 20% to 22%.

images.alt_text: TCS is the first among its peers to report quarterly earnings, setting the tone for an industry that is staring at a recession in its major markets, the US and Europe, and turmoil in the US banking sector.

site_title: China home builder Country Garden gets HK$900 million private loan
summary: Country Garden Holdings, China's largest property developer, has secured a HK$900 million private loan to refinance a bank loan. The loan, offered by Hong Kong-based investment company Flow Capital (HK), will be used to repay a HK$700 million loan owed by the developer. The new loan has a two-year tenure and will be backed by guarantees from Country Garden's parent company and a Hong Kong property. This comes after the developer posted its first net loss since listing in 2007 due to the debt crisis in China's property sector.

site_title: Exxon CEO’s pay rose 52% in 2022, highest among oil peers
summary: Exxon CEO Darren Woods' pay rose 52% to $35.9 million in 2022, the highest among oil peers. This increase came as Exxon posted record profits of $56 billion, with Chevron's profit more than doubling to a record $36.5 billion. In contrast, median annual compensation for Exxon workers fell 9% to $171,582, while Chevron's median worker pay dropped 12% to $161,488. The disparity in executive and worker pay highlights the significant earnings disparity within the oil industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of the Exxon Mobil Corp is seen at the Rio Oil and Gas Expo and Conference in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil September 24, 2018. REUTERS/Sergio Moraes/File Photo

Exxon Mobil Corp. signage on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Monday, June 27, 2022. Money managers betting on a sustained global rebound will be left sorely disappointed in the second half of this crushing year as a protracted bear market looms, even if inflation cools. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
The drop was driven by the exploration business, with ExxonMobil signalling operating results from pumping oil and gas would be about US$5.2 billion.

site_title: Bank of England’s Pill says latest UK data is disappointing
summary: Bank of England chief economist Huw Pill described the latest UK economic data as "somewhat disappointing," with GDP stagnating in February and output levels near pre-pandemic levels. Pill said inflation may be "bumpier" than expected, but still expected to fall in the second quarter. The Bank of England has raised interest rates 11 times since 2021, with a possible further rate rise to 4.5% in May, and policymakers are considering the risk of recent high inflation breaking linear relationships between economic variables.

images.alt_text: Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, speaks during the Bank of England's financial stability report news conference, at the Bank of England, London August 4, 2022. Yui Mok/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: China’s Didi Global to roll out self-developed robotaxis by 2025
summary: China's Didi Global plans to launch its self-developed robotaxis by 2025, in collaboration with Chinese carmakers. The company showcased a concept car called "Didi Neuron" with robotic arms for luggage assistance. Didi aims to have 90% of key components domestically produced to control supply chains. This move comes after almost two years of regulatory troubles, including a $1.2 billion fine for data-security breaches. The company is also developing a lidar sensor and car computing device for its autonomous driving plan.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Engine Biosciences' lab in San Francisco allows the company to tap into deal flow among US pharmaceutical giants, providing a significant market opportunity. Singapore biotech startups are also looking to expand into the US market, driven by the large population size and market opportunities.

site_title: Patek Philippe’s new Aquanaut has men all excited
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled 17 new watch models at Watches and Wonders in Geneva, with men and women alike taking notice of the brand's latest novelties. The Aquanaut Luce Annual Calendar, a feminine reinterpretation of the Aquanaut, features a new automatic in-house movement and a patented annual calendar mechanism, drawing attention from both men and women. Other notable releases include the Calatrava 24-Hour Display Travel Time, Handcrafts World Time Minute Repeater, and Calatrava Pilot Travel Time Chronograph. The watches showcase Patek Philippe's commitment to innovative timepieces and craftsmanship.

images.alt_text: pmluxerolex14 - 1. The 950 Platinum Cosmograph Daytona is Rolex's first Oyster Perpetual model to have a transparent case-back

site_title: Time-telling showmanship
summary: Louis Vuitton has unveiled three new watch models, the Tambour Opera Automata, showcasing exceptional time-telling showmanship. These masterpieces combine horological automata with spectacular displays, demonstrating the brand's technical virtuosity. The Tambour Opera Automata features intricate mechanical designs, redefining the art of watchmaking. The luxury fashion house's latest creations are a testament to their mastery in high horology, exceeding expectations with their artistic and technical excellence.

images.alt_text: Vacheron Constantin Overseas Chronograph

site_title: US dollar drops to two-month low on cooling US inflation
summary: The US dollar dropped to a two-month low on Thursday, falling to 101.2 on the US dollar index, as US inflation slowed sharply in March, reaching 5% year-over-year, down from 6% in February. The euro rose to a two-month high, with traders betting that the European Central Bank's fight against inflation is still ongoing. Expectations of lower interest rates in the US and higher rates in the eurozone are making the euro more attractive, analysts said.

site_title: Iron ore futures down as China demand concerns grow
summary: Iron ore futures plummeted 3.1% on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, ending at 769 yuan (S$148.29) a tonne, amid concerns over weakening steel demand and rising recession risks. A strong cyclone in Australia, which could disrupt shipments, was also a factor. China's plan to limit annual crude steel output has further clouded market prospects.

images.alt_text: Fears of government’s crackdown on prices had already pressured down iron ore prices this week, following a weekly rally of 6.3 per cent in the previous week.

site_title: HSBC plans to add 30 private bankers in fresh India wealth push
summary: HSBC plans to hire 30 private bankers in India as part of its expansion into the country's growing wealth management market. The move reflects increasing competition among global and local firms to manage the growing wealth in India. Only a quarter of India's $600-billion wealth industry is professionally managed, presenting an opportunity for HSBC to tap into this growing market. The bank's private banking service is expected to launch in India in the next few months.

site_title: Celebrating the Cosmograph Daytona and new wonders at Rolex
summary: Rolex unveiled its latest novelties, including the 950 Platinum Cosmograph Daytona, marking the brand's first Oyster Perpetual model with a transparent case-back. The watch celebrates the Cosmograph Daytona's 60th anniversary, a milestone in the chronograph watch's history. The brand's focus on perfection and reinvention resulted in deceptively modest changes that have produced astonishing results, offering a lineup of must-have watches.

images.alt_text: The new Daytona features aesthetic adjustments, tweaked colours to enhance contrast, and most importantly, a new movement inside.

site_title: Pakistan government and judiciary in new standoff amid economic turmoil
summary: Pakistan's parliament has ruled against providing funds for snap polls ordered by the Supreme Court, escalating a standoff between the judiciary and government amid economic turmoil. The snap polls, ordered for the most populated Punjab province on May 14, and potentially for the northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, are seen as a way to address months of political and economic instability. The government claims it is not economically viable to hold snap elections, citing a lack of funds, while the judiciary warns of consequences for non-compliance.

images.alt_text: Pakistan's Finance Minister Ishaq Dar was scheduled to attend the meetings from Apr 10 and see top IMF officials and multilateral creditors in a bid to secure stalled funding.
The key rate of the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) now stands at a record 21 per cent but consumer price inflation is also at its highest level recorded to date.

site_title: Scientists unveil new and improved 'skinny donut' black hole image
summary: Scientists have unveiled a new and improved image of the M87 supermassive black hole, using the Primo algorithm technology to enhance the resolution of the 2019 original image. The new image is sharper and clearer, providing a more detailed view of the black hole's surroundings. The improvement was achieved by filling in gaps in the original telescope observations and refining the image reconstruction process. The enhanced image showcases the black hole's massive size and gravitational pull, solidifying its status as a significant scientific achievement.

images.alt_text: An artist’s impression of a black hole in the Milky Way galaxy, which distorts light passing near it creating a phenomenon known as “gravitational lensing”.  One of the largest black holes ever recorded has been discovered using a new technique that could spot thousands more of the celestial monsters in the coming years, according to astronomers.

site_title: Premier League to withdraw gambling sponsorships from shirts
summary: The Premier League has agreed to withdraw gambling sponsorships from shirts starting from the 2026-27 season. Eight clubs, including Newcastle United, West Ham United, and Everton, currently feature betting companies on their kits. The decision comes ahead of the UK government's expected white paper on gambling regulation. This move aims to address growing concerns about the influence of gambling on the sport and its fans.

site_title: Crypto investors face delays in withdrawing funds after Ethereum upgrade
summary: Crypto investors are facing delays in withdrawing funds from the Ethereum blockchain after its major software upgrade, known as "Shapella," which was set to unlock over US$30 billion worth of ether. As of Thursday, around US$1.4 billion was stuck in a withdrawal queue due to the blockchain's processing limitations, which can handle approximately 1,800 validator withdrawals per day. The delays highlight Ethereum's potential shortcomings as it strives to become a widely-used financial infrastructure.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representation of Ethereum, with its native cryptocurrency ether, is seen in this illustration taken November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: London Stock Exchange partners digital trading platform to offer Bitcoin futures and options
summary: London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) has partnered with Global Futures and Options (GFO-X) to offer the UK's first regulated trading and clearing of Bitcoin index futures and options derivatives. The new service, expected to launch in the fourth quarter of this year, aims to reassure investors after recent crypto sector collapses. The partnership involves LSEG's Paris-based LCH clearing unit, which will introduce a segregated clearing service for cash-settled US dollar-denominated digital assets. The move is seen as a step towards establishing Britain as a global hub for crypto technology.

images.alt_text: The network revamp, also known as Shapella, is designed to let people exit an Ether staking investment.
While the question of recognising crypto as money remains unanswered for now, cases revolving around this issue will be something to watch.

site_title: Saudi-led Opec+ cuts prompt brisk buying from top Asia importers
summary: Saudi-led Opec+ output cuts have prompted top Asia importers, including Japan and Thailand, to buy spot shipments of crude at a brisk pace. The cuts, combined with higher selling prices, have supported the region's Dubai benchmark price. Refiners are seeking alternative cargoes as refining margins show signs of strain, with some buying Russian Espo crude at a premium. The global crude market was jolted by the output cuts, with futures hitting a record high, and Saudi Arabia has hiked its May official selling price for flagship Arab Light crude in Asia.

site_title: Amazon awarded CEO Andy Jassy no new stock in 2022
summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy received no new stock in 2022, despite a 2021 award worth US$214 million, which was intended to represent his compensation for years to come. The company awarded more than US$40 million each to recently elevated CEOs and took home a similar amount from his own grants. This move aims to reduce the pay gap between Jassy and rank-and-file employees, with the pay ratio of Amazon's median employee to Jassy at 1 to 38 in 2022.

site_title: India opens new investigation into BBC in widening crackdown
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate has opened an investigation into the BBC for alleged violations of foreign exchange rules, following tax raids on the broadcaster's offices in February. The raids came after the BBC aired a documentary on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's actions during deadly sectarian riots in 2002. The investigation is being conducted under India's Foreign Exchange Management Act and has already led to questions being raised with some BBC employees. The move is the latest in a widening crackdown on the BBC by Indian authorities.

images.alt_text: Activists from the Hindu right-wing organisation Hindu Sena protesting outside the BBC office in New Delhi, India, 15 Feb 2023.

site_title: Brazil’s Lula hails Brics bank for empowering ‘Global South’
summary: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva praised the Brics bank, saying it has great potential to empower emerging countries, freeing them from traditional financial institutions. Lula attended the inauguration of former Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff as head of the multilateral bank, which is headquartered in Shanghai and involves Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. The bank aims to create major social and economic changes, allowing emerging nations to break free from traditional banking systems.

images.alt_text: President Luiz Inacio Lula Da Silva’s decision to visit Huawei followed an invitation made by the company, which has been present in Brazil for over 20 years. In 2021

site_title: Credit investors expect defaults to rise; most anticipate US recession this year
summary: Credit investors expect a rise in corporate defaults in the coming year, with 81% of fund managers anticipating defaults in the next 12 months. The US is expected to experience a recession this year, with 84% of respondents predicting a US recession, compared to 61% in Europe and the UK. Credit spreads are also expected to widen, with North American credit spreads forecast to rise over the next three months. Certain industries, such as healthcare, tech, and commercial real estate, are expected to face tough times.

images.alt_text: Members of the Fed’s policy-setting committee voted unanimously last month to raise its benchmark lending rate for a ninth time in just over a year, the minutes showed.
The IMF forecasts leave UK output just 0.7 per cent higher in 2024 than it was in 2022, the worst performance in the G20.
The vast services sector contracted by 0.1 per cent in February, but was offset by a surge in the much smaller construction sector, which rebounded from bad weather in January.

site_title: The Carrera at 60 lives on
summary: TAG Heuer has unveiled four new models of its iconic Carrera timepiece to celebrate its 60th anniversary. The new models, including the Timeless Carrera Chronograph and Carrera "Glass Box" Chronograph Tourbillon, are inspired by the original 1963 Carrera model and feature a classic design with modern touches. The watches are powered by in-house automatic movements and come in various dial colors and styles, including blue, black, and silver. The new models are part of TAG Heuer's efforts to ensure the legacy of its iconic timepiece for a long time.

images.alt_text: Aquanaut Luce Annual Calendar Ref 5261R-001

site_title: Manhattan rents reach record high with busy season yet to come
summary: Manhattan apartment rents reached a record high of $4,175 in March, with the median monthly rate up 13% from last year and $25 from its previous peak in July. Despite a rise in available units and a vacancy rate of 2.54%, renters have been unable to catch a break, with average lease signings showing a 0.7% discount from listing prices. Experts predict more record highs to come, with the busiest rental period still ahead, but note that an economic downturn or major job losses could potentially shift the trajectory.

images.alt_text: Besides the high inflation rate, Britain’s housing market is also facing the challenge posed by the central bank’s run of interest-rate increases going back to December 2021.

site_title: En bloc offers for Lakeside Towers fall short of S$350 million reserve price
summary: Jurong condominium Lakeside Towers, with 144 units, failed to meet its reserve price of S$350 million after the collective sale tender closed. The best offer fell short, prompting owners to enter private treaty negotiations with potential buyers. The property, located near the upcoming Jurong Lake District, was initially listed at S$305 million in 2018, with a 14.8% increase to the current reserve price. Owners will now discuss terms with interested buyers.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: UK lenders see weak mortgage lending, but no wider credit crunch
summary: UK lenders expect to reduce mortgage lending in the coming quarter due to the slowing housing market, which has been impacted by the Bank of England's interest rate hikes to 4.25%. Despite concerns about a wider credit crunch following global banking system stress, lenders show no signs of a significant tightening of credit conditions. The Bank of England survey, conducted from February 27 to March 17, found that weakness in lending intentions remains centered around the housing market.

images.alt_text: Besides the high inflation rate, Britain’s housing market is also facing the challenge posed by the central bank’s run of interest-rate increases going back to December 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong developers cut housing project prices as outlook dims
summary: Hong Kong developers CK Asset Holdings and Sun Hung Kai Properties are cutting housing project prices by over 10% amid a dimming housing market outlook. The move comes as interest-rate hikes weigh on the market, potentially leading to a decline in prices over the rest of the year. Analysts predict a 5% drop in home prices if mortgage rates reach 4% later this year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's recent intervention to boost the local currency may prompt further interest-rate increases, further dampening the home-price recovery.

images.alt_text: The removal of pandemic restrictions in China and Hong Kong has led to an increase of client interest from north of the border.
Hong Kong is running an uphill battle as the government seeks to kick-start an economy that recorded its third annual contraction in four years.

site_title: Alibaba shares plunge on SoftBank's stake sale report
summary: Alibaba shares plummeted 5.2% in Hong Kong after SoftBank Group reported plans to sell almost all of its remaining shares in the Chinese e-commerce giant, citing a shift to "defensive mode" amid an uncertain business environment. The sale comes as valuations of China's big tech firms recover from regulatory scrutiny. SoftBank aims to reduce its exposure to Alibaba, which it bought for $20 million over two decades ago, as part of its efforts to monetize profitable holdings.

images.alt_text: Alibaba has come under intense scrutiny from the Chinese government in recent years, and its stock price has tumbled.

site_title: Motor racing: Hong Kong billionaire Lo in talks with potential F1 teams
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Calvin Lo is in talks with potential Formula One teams to enter the 2026 season, with money not being the major hurdle. Lo, who already has financial links to Williams, aims to increase Asian presence in F1. He has ruled out involvement in two planned teams, an all-American Andretti Cadillac outfit and a Hitech Grand Prix one. Lo's consideration of backing a bid to enter F1 in 2026 suggests a potential shift in the sport's global dynamics.

images.alt_text: Sunday’s race on the Jeddah Corniche street circuit will be the third grand prix held in the kingdom, where a new track planned for the “entertainment city” of Qiddiya near Riyadh could be ready by 2027.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase as labour market slows
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 11,000 to 239,000 for the week ended April 8, exceeding economists' forecasts. Despite a tightening in credit conditions following regional bank failures, job losses appear to be minimal. Labour market conditions are loosening, with annual revisions showing higher claims this year and moderate wage gains. Job openings fell below 10 million at the end of February, but there were still 1.7 vacancies for every unemployed person. The unemployment rate remains at 3.5%, and the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again at its May meeting.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 16, 2022 a “Now Hiring” sign at T.J. Maxx in Annapolis, Maryland. - US job gains eased in March for a second straight month, government data showed March 7, 2023, adding to signs that the world's largest economy is cooling as policymakers push on in their fight against inflation. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)
The labour market is expected to loosen up in the second quarter as companies respond more to slowing demand triggered by the Federal Reserve’s interest rate increases.

site_title: Low awareness, cost concerns may be hindering green-building adoption in Singapore: report
summary: A joint report by Schneider Electric and the Singapore Green Building Council found that low awareness and cost concerns hinder green-building adoption in Singapore. Only 38% of business leaders have a full understanding of green buildings, while 61% cite cost and return on investment as their biggest concerns. Despite this, 95% of respondents agree that 80% of Singapore's buildings should be green by 2030, and 52% plan to increase investments in green buildings within the next two years. Recommendations include promoting awareness of government support schemes and forging public-private partnerships to accelerate green-building development.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
