Under the newly introduced Mandatory Energy Improvement regime, "energy-intensive" buildings will have to undergo audits on their energy use.

Iris Ng, the business head of middle market for global commercial banking at OCBC, said the bank has in the past two years accorded green loans to more than 500 SMEs. Only one of three of them provided the bank with a green certificate to validate the green criteria.
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience
As well as reducing labour shortages, greater participation by women makes for more diverse teams.

site_title: Switching to cleaner-energy vehicles a priority for Singapore’s net-zero ambitions: Iswaran
summary: Singapore aims to achieve net-zero emissions through the adoption of cleaner-energy vehicles, with plans to phase out diesel-powered cars and taxis by 2025 and internal-combustion-engine cars and taxis by 2030. The Ministry of Transport will encourage cleaner-energy vehicles through regulation, incentives, and infrastructure, while the Ministry of Sustainability and the Environment will focus on accelerating Singapore's low-carbon transition. The government will also work with partners to develop sustainable international aviation and maritime ecosystems.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
MAS will continue to focus on ensuring medium-term price stability as the basis for sustained economic growth.

The Ministry for National Development will continue to “plan boldly for the long-term”, said its minister Desmond Lee, noting that Singapore now aspires to be a “City in Nature” with native flora and fauna thriving amid the metropolis.
President Halimah Yacob says Singapore would need to strengthen its social fabric to remain united and do well in  an increasingly dangerous and troubled world post-pandemic.

site_title: Property crisis pummels Chinese developers’ bottom lines
summary: Chinese developers reported significant losses in 2022 due to a property slump and crisis of confidence, with 24 firms seeing their net income decline and 16 recording losses. The worst performer was Sunac China Holdings, which saw a net loss of 27.7 billion yuan. Only a few stronger developers, such as China Vanke and Longfor Group Holdings, managed to post slight increases in profits. Authorities have introduced policy measures to revive the sector, but many developers continue to struggle, with some exploring new growth areas and others facing significant debt repayment pressure.

images.alt_text: Singapore is mostly seeing higher prices for everything from condos to cars.
The liquidity crunch among Chinese developers over the past two years has disproportionately hit private-sector builders, fuelling record defaults last year.
Home purchases in Singapore, where Chinese are the top foreign buyers, cooled early in 2023 from last year’s torrid pace — but only slightly despite a steep rise in real estate stamp duties.

site_title: Hong Kong woos mainland China crypto firms in push to bolster finance hub status
summary: Hong Kong is aggressively courting mainland China's cryptocurrency companies to rebase in the city, seeking to bolster its status as a finance hub. Despite China's 2021 ban on cryptocurrency trading, Hong Kong has licensed two crypto exchanges and is hosting 100 crypto-related conferences and events through April. Top officials, including Chief Executive John Lee, are promoting the city's support for the industry. However, some remain skeptical due to China's lingering regulatory influence, and several Chinese-founded crypto companies have announced plans to apply for licenses in Hong Kong.

site_title: Uniqlo parent raises full-year outlook; sees China recovering
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, raised its full-year profit forecast to 360 billion yen due to a recovering Chinese market and strong sales growth in Europe and North America. The company reported a 16% jump in first-half profit, driven by a "substantial decline" in first-quarter revenue and profit in mainland China. Uniqlo's China operations began to recover in January, with operating profit increasing to 220 billion yen in the six months through February. The results provide relief to investors concerned about the impact of China's Covid-19 lockdowns on the global economy.

images.alt_text: Uniqlo plans to open 10 stores during the current fiscal year in North America, which ends in August, followed by 20 to 30 each year in order to reach Yanai’s goal of 200 stores.

site_title: North Korea fires missile; South condemns 'grave provocation'
summary: North Korea fired a long-range ballistic missile, prompting South Korea and the US to condemn the "grave provocation." The missile flew approximately 1,000 km and appeared to be less than 3,000 km in altitude, significantly lower than previous tests. The US and South Korean nuclear envoys issued a joint statement, calling for an end to North Korea's "unprecedented levels of provocations and menacing words." Japan also responded, with its defence minister stating that the missile did not fall in its territory. The incident comes days after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un called for strengthening war deterrence.

images.alt_text: People sit near a television showing a news broadcast with file footage of a North Korean missile test in Seoul, March 16, 2023.

site_title: Australia’s March employment jumps 53,000 in show of strength
summary: Australia's jobless rate remained at 3.5% in March, beating expectations of a 3.6% increase, as employment rose 53,000 for the second consecutive month. This strong employment data indicates a tight labor market. Hours worked decreased 0.2% in March, following a 3.8% increase in February. The data contrasts with market forecasts of a 20,000 job gain.

site_title: Apple in talks with suppliers to make MacBooks in Thailand: Nikkei
summary: Apple is in talks with suppliers in Thailand to manufacture MacBooks, expanding its manufacturing presence beyond China. Suppliers with existing complexes in Thailand are discussing assembly and production of MacBook components and modules. This move comes as COVID-19 disruptions and strict restrictions in China have prompted companies like Pegatron and Foxconn to diversify production. Apple has already been mass-producing its Apple Watch in Thailand. The development is part of Apple's efforts to reduce reliance on Chinese suppliers.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB lowers Manulife US Reit’s target price following Oregon property divestment
summary: RHB Research has lowered its target price for Manulife US Reit to US$0.40 from US$0.43, maintaining a "buy" call, following the Reit's divestment of its Tanasbourne office campus in Oregon for US$33.5 million. Analyst Vijay Natarajan attributed the drop to a lower governance score and leaner margin assumptions, while expressing concerns over the proposed sale of the Reit's manager to Mirae. Despite the divestment, Natarajan believes the Reit's unit price correction has been overdone, and Manulife US Reit is undervalued.

images.alt_text: RHB Research analyst Vijay Natarajan notes that Manulife US Reit is trading at a more than 40 per cent discount to its marked-down book value.
Tanasbourne is a 132,851 square foot office campus comprising three flex-office buildings. It was constructed between 1986 and 1995, and was refurbished in 2015, 2017 and 2020.
Manulife US Real Estate Management, had received “multiple queries” on Monday following news of US regional banks’ troubles.

“We're more engaged with our sponsor right now than we ever have been. They're really in the trenches with us at the moment,” said Tripp Gantt, CEO of the Reit manager, at Manulife US Reit's last earnings call on Feb 9.

site_title: Latest 6-month Singapore T-bill offers cut-off yield at 3.75%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill auction closed with a cut-off yield of 3.75%, down from the previous auction's 3.85%. The total value of applications reached S$12.3 billion, a 28% increase from the previous auction, and resulted in a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.6.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

The image of Yusof Ishak, former president of Singapore, is displayed on various denominations of Singapore dollar banknotes in an arranged photograph in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Sept. 18, 2015. Singapore's challenge is to find a way to keep its economy energized and sustainable for the next 10 to 15 years, with low single-digit growth expected to be considered a good performance in the future, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Saturday. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
Singapore currency notes are seen through a magnifying glass among other currencies in this April 12, 2013 file photo illustration. REUTERS/Edgar Su/Illustration/Files

epa10536140 A man walks past the logo of Credit Suisse in Hong Kong, China, 22 March 2023. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said Credit Suisse’s assets in Hong Kong made up 0.5 percent of the banking system’s total assets. Credit Suisse was purchased by rival UBS for over 3 billion US dollar after the collapse of the Switzerland-based investment bank.  EPA-EFE/JEROME FAVRE
OCBC and UOB’s Central Provident Fund Investment Account customers using their ordinary account savings will be able to buy T-bills online.

site_title: New Bank of Japan chief vows to keep stimulus, shuns premature tightening
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda vowed to maintain stimulus until the central bank meets its 2% inflation target, cautioning against premature tightening that could risk missing the mark. Ueda stated that the BOJ must prioritize avoiding premature tightening over delaying interest rate hikes, as the situation in Japan is distinct from other countries experiencing elevated inflation. He emphasized the need for a stable and sustainable approach to achieving the inflation target.

site_title: 😡 Beware the Big Bad Boss
summary: A rare good boss is hard to find, according to Randstad Singapore's associate director Rumi Mohd. Red flags in a bad boss include micromanagement, inappropriate tone and language, and favoritism. Employees should evaluate their work situation before quitting, and instead try to improve communication and build a professional relationship with their manager. If the situation is irreparable, employees should consider leaving the company, researching alternative job opportunities, and prioritizing their mental health.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Germany’s niche firms – a model for life after globalisation
summary: Germany's mid-sized companies, known as "Mittelstand," are adapting better to the new phase of globalisation than big corporations. These hidden champions dominate tiny global niches, often located in small towns, and are rapidly rejigging themselves to meet new challenges. Examples include Herrenknecht, a tunnelling company, Scio Automation, a robotics specialist, and Wafios, a machine manufacturer. These companies have three key qualities: a single-minded focus on their niche, complicated defences against cheaper competition, and a focus on quality rather than quantity. They are adjusting to the new geopolitical landscape by looking beyond China and regionalising their supply chains, making them well-positioned to succeed in a world where globalisation is evolving.

images.alt_text: Supply chain problems, the energy crisis and geopolitical risks are expected to take their toll on exporting companies this year.

site_title: China lifts mask mandate for public transport, offices, schools
summary: China has lifted mask mandates for public transport, offices, and schools, marking a significant easing of its COVID-19 restrictions. Masks will still be required in hospitals, nursing homes, and during outbreaks. The move follows China's pivot from strict COVID policies in December, which has led to a surge in cases and deaths. New immunization guidelines have also been approved, recommending a fresh dose every three months. The changes come as China's economy faces pressure and policymakers look to stimulate growth.

site_title: New year revelry returns to Thai streets as tourism rebounds
summary: Thailand is expected to welcome at least 30 million tourists this year, generating US$43.74 billion in revenue, according to the Tourism Council. Following muted celebrations during the COVID-19 pandemic, traditional New Year festivities like Songkran have returned, with thousands of revellers participating in water fights in Bangkok. The rebound in tourism is helping revive Thailand's economy, making it the second-largest in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Thailand has long been a popular destination for Chinese tourists with more than 11 million visiting Thailand in 2019, nearly a third of the total.

site_title: Australian dollar firms as jobs boom stokes rate risk
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.4% to US$0.6713 after a strong jobs report showed 53,000 net new jobs created in March, beating forecasts. Full-time employment surged by 72,200, and the unemployment rate remained near 3.5%. This data suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia may resume interest rate hikes, despite market expectations of an outside chance. Interest rates futures imply a 18% chance of a quarter-point rise in May, with bond yields rising to 3.30%.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was last at 101.68, down 0.41 per cent on the day.

site_title: Asia: Most markets drop after recession warning, rate hike seen
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday after the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes revealed a US recession at the end of the year and expectations of another interest rate hike. The minutes showed core inflation accelerated to 5.6% and officials considered tightening policy further to bring inflation down to 2%. Hong Kong's tech sector fell, with Alibaba losing over 5% after SoftBank reported plans to unload majority holdings. The decline was also attributed to concerns about the impact of the banking crisis and tightening credit conditions.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney and Wellington rose but Hong Kong, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta fell while Seoul was flat at midday on Wednesday.

site_title: UK economy shows no growth in February as strikes weigh
summary: The UK economy showed no growth in February, with economic output remaining flat, according to the Office for National Statistics. The services sector contracted by 0.1%, while the construction sector rebounded from bad weather in January, offsetting the decline. The revised January growth rate was 0.4%, indicating a stronger economy than initially thought. This data reduces the likelihood of a recession in early 2023, with economists suggesting the economy could avoid contraction if it shrinks by 0.6% in March.

images.alt_text: The IMF forecasts leave UK output just 0.7 per cent higher in 2024 than it was in 2022, the worst performance in the G20.

site_title: China exports unexpectedly rise in positive sign for economy
summary: China's exports unexpectedly rose 14.8% in March from a year earlier, the first gain in six months, in a positive sign for the economy. The rebound was a surprise as early indicators suggested weakness continued. Imports declined 1.4% and left a trade surplus of $88.2 billion. Economists had forecast a drop in exports and a decline in imports. The rebound is seen as a strong support for China's economy, but challenges remain due to high global inflation and geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: Masks will still need to be worn in hospitals, nursing homes and in the midst of Covid outbreaks.

The rocket carrying the Shenzhou-14 mission With three Chinese astronauts lifts off at the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center in Northwest China’s Gansu Province on June 5, 2022. - China on June 5 launched a rocket carrying three astronauts on a mission to complete construction on its new space station, the latest milestone in Beijing's drive to become a major space power. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Hot stock: Beng Kuang Marine surges to a high on news of partial shipyard sale
summary: Beng Kuang Marine's share price surged 75% on April 13 after the company announced the sale of a third of its Batam waterfront shipyard property to a subsidiary of Oil States Industries for S$8.6 million, exceeding its net book value of S$631,282. The sale is part of the company's turnaround strategy, with net proceeds to be used to repay bank borrowings and enhance liquidity. CEO Yong Jiunn Run stated that this move will strengthen the company's balance sheet and financial agility.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Beng Kuang to raise S$3.35m from proposed share placement
Beng Kuang to acquire stake in A*Star spin-off
Overall, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the 5 sessions ended Sep 8, with S$137 million of net inflows.

site_title: KPMG fined £1.25 million for Luceco audit by UK watchdog
summary: KPMG UK has been fined £1.25 million by the UK audit watchdog for errors in its 2016 audit of Luceco, a parent company of lighting and wiring accessory producers. The firm's head of audit, Cath Burnet, expressed regret over the shortcomings. A former KPMG employee, Stuart Smith, was also fined £50,000 for his role in the audit failures. The fines were reduced after KPMG admitted to the errors.

images.alt_text: EY’s global management said in a note that the company’s US executive committee “decided not to move forward” with its plan, dubbed “Project Everest”.
In the wake of the accounting scandal around German payments company Wirecard, auditors have turned cautious and become much more selective, scrutinising potential clients much more closely.

site_title: Singapore biotech startups chase the American dream
summary: Singapore biotech startups are expanding into the US market, leveraging San Francisco's deal flow and large population size. Lucence, a local biotech startup, recently secured Medicare reimbursement approval for its lung cancer blood test, valued at a potential $10 billion market. CEO Dr. Tan Min-Han notes the US market is more complicated than the Asian market, but the potential rewards are worth the challenge. This expansion is part of a growing trend of Singaporean startups seeking to tap into the US market's vast opportunities.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Mirxes would be one of the rare biotech startups to go public on the Singapore bourse, amid a broader push by the government to have tech startups listed locally.
Dr. Tan Min-Han, founder and chief executive officer, Lucence, sees the approval of Medicare as a door opener for other insurance providers in the US.

site_title: Renault plugs into premium EV battery deal with start-up Verkor
summary: Renault has entered a long-term partnership with French start-up Verkor to produce premium EV batteries for its Alpine and electric models, with a targeted capacity of 12 gigawatt hours. This deal aims to secure crucial components and control the value chain of its future unit Ampere, set to list on the stock market by the end of the year. The partnership will power over 100,000 vehicles, with Verkor's planned "gigafactory" in Dunkirk aiming for a total capacity of 16 GWh.

images.alt_text: “The two companies are currently working well together towards the signature of all the definitive agreements. They are confident this will be reached shortly,” Nissan said, a comment echoed in a statement by Renault.

site_title: US documents leaked by young gun enthusiast: US media
summary: A young gun enthusiast leaked highly classified US government documents, sparking a criminal investigation by the Department of Justice. The breach includes information about Ukraine's battle against Russian forces and secret assessments of US allies, with some documents marked "NOFORN" to prevent foreign nationals from accessing them. The leaked documents were shared on social media platforms, including Discord and Twitter, and could potentially put US intelligence sources at risk and give adversaries valuable information. The US is working to have the documents removed from online platforms.

images.alt_text: In a statement on Sunday, the Pentagon said it was reviewing the validity of the photographed documents that “appear to contain sensitive and highly classified material”.

site_title: Chinese battery supplier to Stellantis plans five Europe plants
summary: Chinese battery maker SVolt Energy Technology plans to expand its footprint in Europe to as many as five factories, with talks to supply European carmakers underway. The company aims to increase production capacity to 50 gigawatt-hours by the end of the decade, enough to power 1 million electric vehicles. SVolt is in talks with several European car manufacturers, including Stellantis, and targets smaller production sites to reduce environmental impact. The company's expansion is part of a growing trend of Chinese companies dominating battery production in Europe.

images.alt_text: Artist impression of the proposed SVolt cell factory in Saarland. Source: SVolt
The proposal, if finalised, represents the most aggressive US vehicle emissions reduction plan to date, requiring 13 per cent annual average pollution cuts.
Chalice Mining joins other miners like BHP Group in actively sourcing for nickel supplies as they develop new projects and set up processing plants.
The LG Energy Solution Ltd. booth at the InterBattery exhibition in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, March 16, 2023. The exhibition will run through March 17. Photographer: Jean Chung/Bloomberg

site_title: India central bank begins evaluating potential bidders for IDBI Bank: sources
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has started evaluating potential bidders for IDBI Bank, with at least five firms expressing interest in buying a majority stake. Kotak Mahindra Bank, CSB Bank, and Emirates NBD Bank are among those that have submitted expressions of interest. The federal government, which owns 45.48% of IDBI Bank, aims to divest 30.48% of its stake in the lender. The RBI's evaluation process is ongoing, with no confirmation of the other potential bidders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a branch of IDBI Bank in New Delhi, India, April 5, 2023. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.63% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 331.90 points to 19,977.96, following minutes from the Federal Reserve's meeting showing officials predict a recession. The losses were further exacerbated by tech stocks and economic concerns.

site_title: Rakuten Bank prices shares at 1,400 yen in IPO, top of range
summary: Rakuten Bank priced its shares at 1,400 yen each, the top of its target range, in Japan's largest IPO in five years, raising about 83.3 billion yen (S$828.4 million). The offering comes amid global banking volatility and follows the recent IPO of fellow online lender SBI Sumishin Net Bank. Despite a lower-than-expected price, the listing is seen as attractively priced, with the company offering a substantial discount to the recently listed SBI Sumishin Net Bank.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on November 9, 2022 shows people walking past a mobile shop of Japanese e-commerce firm Rakuten in Tokyo. - Rakuten are expected to announce their second quarter results on November 11. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: IWC goes sporty modern
summary: IWC Schaffhausen has released the Ingenieur Automatic 40, a modern interpretation of its iconic luxury sports watch. The new model features a silver-plated dial and is described as "a very versatile luxury sports watch for the 21st century" by IWC's CEO Chris Grainger-Herr. This updated version aims to appeal to the growing trend of casual street wear and its adoption in formal settings. The Ingenieur Automatic 40 is part of IWC's efforts to reinvigorate its luxury sports watch line and stay relevant in the contemporary market.

images.alt_text: Roger Federer at the Watches and Wonders GENEVA, Switzerland, Tuesday, March 28, 2023. (WWGF/KEYSTONE/Cyril Zingaro)

site_title: Singapore shares inch down at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.1% lower at 3,282.1 points on Thursday, following Wall Street's decline overnight. The Dow Jones fell 0.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.9%. Local stocks, including Genting Singapore and Oceanus Group, also traded lower, while Rex International rose 1.6%. The decline was attributed to US Federal Reserve economists' projection of a "mild recession".

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Regulation issued a "trade with caution" alert on Digilife Technologies on Wednesday.

site_title: SMRT’s Strides Taxi, Premier Taxis merging to form Singapore’s second-largest cab operator
summary: SMRT's Strides Taxi and Premier Taxis are merging to form Singapore's second-largest cab operator, Strides Premier. Strides Holdings will hold a majority stake, with Premier Corporation and BS Investors jointly owning the remaining stake. The merger aims to enhance efficiency and provide better services for vehicle hirers and end-users, while safeguarding the long-term interests of drivers and passengers. The combined entity will offer technical expertise and workshop capabilities to service the expanded fleet of taxis.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Raymond Ng, executive chairman of Enviro-Hub Holdings, has acquired taxi firm Premier Taxis.
Taxi fares in Singapore poised to rise in March
SMRT to progressively replace taxi fleet with electric vehicles within five years

site_title: Finnish businessman Zilliacus drops out of Manchester United bidding
summary: Finnish businessman Thomas Zilliacus has dropped out of the bidding for Manchester United due to delays in the sale process, which he believes will hinder a new owner's ability to build a winning team. Zilliacus was among several bidders, including British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe and Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad al-Thani, who expressed interest in purchasing the Premier League club. The Glazer family, Manchester United's American owners, had launched a formal sale process late last year, with a third round of bids set to be accepted at the end of the month.

site_title: Crypto’s Ethereum network finishes Shanghai software upgrade
summary: Ethereum's Shanghai software upgrade has successfully implemented, allowing investors to withdraw Ether coins after pledging them for network operation rewards. The upgrade, Shapella, enables 1.2 million Ether tokens worth approximately $2.3 billion to be withdrawn over the next five days. Despite investor concerns, digital-asset markets remained steady, with Ether edging up 1% to $1,922. The upgrade follows Ethereum's transition to a proof-of-stake approach in September last year, reducing the network's electricity consumption.

images.alt_text: Global VC funding for the industry fell to US$2.4 billion in the quarter, an 80 per cent decline from its all-time high of US$12.3 billion during the same period last year, according to PitchBook.
While the question of recognising crypto as money remains unanswered for now, cases revolving around this issue will be something to watch.

site_title: Market watchers say no easy way out of conflict-of-interest problems as EY halts break-up plan
summary: Big Four accounting firm EY has halted its plan to break up its audit and consulting businesses, citing resistance from its US branch. The decision comes as no surprise, given the complexities of such a split and the synergies between the two units. Conflict-of-interest problems remain unresolved, with regulatory pressures to mitigate conflicts between auditing and consultancy businesses. The Big Four firms, including KPMG, PwC, and Deloitte, have stated they will maintain their business models, which have been criticized for potential conflicts. The halt does not solve the long-standing issue, and experts suggest that firms may explore spin-offs or operational splits instead.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
EY’s global management said in a note that the company’s US executive committee “decided not to move forward” with its plan, dubbed “Project Everest”.
EY’s official announcement on Friday (Sep 9) has confirmed what the market had been speculating for months: that it would separate into 2 distinct, multidisciplinary organisations.

site_title: The false dichotomy of hand and heart vs head
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob calls for a broader meritocracy, valuing a wide range of skills and promoting open pathways to success. However, this approach may perpetuate a false dichotomy between "hand and heart" and "head" work, devaluing essential jobs. The article argues that society must recognize and reward the value of essential work, such as healthcare and sanitation, and move beyond the assumption that "head" work is more valuable. The government's pledge to professionalize and support trades like healthcare and sanitation is seen as a step in the right direction, but further action is needed to address the issue.

images.alt_text: If meritocracy necessarily results in unequal outcomes, the question is: Can we rely on such a system to deliver good outcomes for everyone?
President Halimah Yacob says Singapore would need to strengthen its social fabric to remain united and do well in  an increasingly dangerous and troubled world post-pandemic.

site_title: Six places to drink wine in Napa Valley and Sonoma
summary: Napa Valley and Sonoma County offer various wine-drinking experiences, with some restaurants prioritizing top local wines and others providing more affordable options. The author, a wine critic, shares six favorite places to find excellent wine with good values, including Glen Ellen Star in Sonoma, The Matheson in Healdsburg, Valley in Sonoma, The Charter Oak in Saint Helena, Compline in Napa, and Torc in Napa. These establishments offer extensive wine lists, ranging from California to European options, with many great values under $100.

images.alt_text: After years of higher temperatures, kabinett riesling producers have a vintage that seems like a throwback to the time when growers battled to ripen grapes.
Gearing adds in yet another reason to have faith in Champagne’s continued investment potential: It remains an icon of luxury in a world where there’s been an explosion of wealth.

site_title: US consumer prices rise moderately in March; underlying inflation still hot
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in March, driven by sticky rents, despite a decline in gasoline costs. The core CPI increased 5.6% in the 12 months till March, the smallest year-on-year gain since May 2021. Inflation remains above the Fed's 2% target, and financial markets predict another 25 basis point interest rate hike at the May policy meeting.

images.alt_text: The US labour market added 236,000 jobs in March bringing the national unemployment rate down to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: Search and deploy
summary: MCI Outsourcing, a recruitment firm under MCI Investment Holding, secured a S$6 million project to deploy safe distancing ambassadors during the pandemic. The company has grown from six employees to 90, with revenue increasing almost tenfold since its founding in 2016. MCI Group plans to expand into China, setting up new operations by early 2024, and has set up a recruitment agency in Qingdao. The company aims to shift some of its Singapore operations to Malaysia and explore ways to raise funds for further expansion into markets like India, Malaysia, and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Having a headstart in e-commerce enabled Adirect Singapore to continue selling its premium meats during the pandemic, said chief executive officer Jackie Goh.
Joe Green Marketing's founder and managing director Boediman Widjaja (right) and marketing director Charlina Lim at the Enterprise 50 Awards in 2021.

site_title: Philippine central bank signals pause in rate hikes in May
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) Governor Felipe Medalla hinted that the central bank may pause interest rate hikes in May due to easing inflation, which reached 7.6% in March. The inflation average for 2023 is expected to be revised downwards from 6% projections. The BSP has raised interest rates by 425 basis points since last year to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Governor Felipe Medalla poses for a photograph in his office at Manila, Philippines, November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eloisa Lopez/File Photo
Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) raised the overnight reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 6.25 per cent.

site_title: Buffett praises BYD and TSMC after selling shares of both firms
summary: Warren Buffett praised electric-car maker BYD as "extraordinary" and chip manufacturer TSMC as a "fabulous enterprise" in an interview with CNBC. Despite selling shares of both firms, Buffett attributed the decision to reduce Berkshire's stake in TSMC by 86% to concerns over geopolitical tensions, not a re-evaluation of the business or management. Buffett's comments follow speculation that one of his deputies picked up the TSMC investment.

site_title: Foreign funds snap up Malaysia bonds on rate bets, yield pickup
summary: Malaysia is attracting foreign bond investors seeking profit from possible peak interest rates and an attractive yield pickup. Last month, international investors poured $983 million into the nation's debt, the largest increase since January 2022. Despite low yields, Malaysian debt is luring investors due to a yield pickup when hedged against the ringgit using forward contracts. Bank Negara Malaysia has kept monetary policy unchanged, indicating key rates may be around terminal levels, but economists still expect a rate hike to 3% based on median forecasts.

images.alt_text: The electrical and electronics products continue to spearhead Malaysia’s factory output in February, followed by food, beverages and tobacco products.
Labour force participation in Malaysia climbed to 69.9 per cent, the highest in records going back to 2010.

site_title: Softbank aims to sell majority of its stake in Alibaba: FT
summary: SoftBank is selling the majority of its stake in Alibaba Group Holding, reducing its ownership to less than 4%, amid the Chinese internet giant's intense scrutiny and declining stock price. SoftBank has sold over $7 billion in Alibaba shares this year through prepaid forward contracts, following a $29 billion sale last year. The sales are part of SoftBank's efforts to cut losses on its investments, including its failed crypto startup FTX.

images.alt_text: ByteDance’s profit last year came despite mounting losses at fast-growing TikTok.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Alibaba Group is seen at its office in Beijing, China,  January 5, 2021. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo
Alibaba Cloud plans to open Tongyi Qianwen to its clients so they can build their own customised large language models.

site_title: Sunac China falls by record as trade resumes after yearlong halt
summary: Sunac China Holdings plummeted by a record 59% in Hong Kong after resuming trading following a year-long suspension. The developer's dollar bonds remain at deeply distressed levels, reflecting investor skepticism about its restructuring plan. Despite meeting stock exchange requirements, concerns linger about its prospects amid a nascent but patchy housing recovery. Sunac has reached an agreement with key bondholders and is implementing a debt-restructuring plan, which could aid its access to equity raising and support its operations. The developer's stock has lost 23% in a broader decline of Chinese property stocks.

images.alt_text: Trading in Sunac’s shares was suspended last year pending the release of its financial results.
The liquidity crunch among Chinese developers over the past two years has disproportionately hit private-sector builders, fuelling record defaults last year.
Sunac is among the many Chinese developers that defaulted last year as the sector reeled under a debt crisis.

site_title: G7 finance leaders pledge financial stability, supply chain diversity
summary: G7 finance leaders pledged to maintain global financial stability and promote supply chain diversity, particularly for low- and middle-income countries, amid recent banking turmoil. They emphasized the need for mutually beneficial cooperation and commitment to shared values, excluding China. The G7 will support joint research, education, and skills development, and encourage private sector diversification through transparent public finance tools. They also vowed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and enhance environmental protections in supply chains, while monitoring financial sector developments to ensure global economic stability.

images.alt_text: The IMF forecasts leave UK output just 0.7 per cent higher in 2024 than it was in 2022, the worst performance in the G20.

Japan's Economy, Trade and Industry minister Yasutoshi Nishimura (L) speaking in Tokyo at the Apr 4 meeting of the 2023 G7 trade ministers, during which economic security, including export controls, was raised.

site_title: US-Saudi oil pact breaking down as Russia grabs upper hand
summary: The US-Saudi oil pact is breaking down, with Saudi Arabia and Russia forming an alliance that could cause trouble for the US economy and President Joe Biden's re-election campaign. Opec+ has cut crude output for the second time since Biden's visit to Saudi Arabia, lifting oil prices by about $5 a barrel. The move is expected to increase recession risks and inflation, benefiting the major exporters but hurting importers like European countries. The US needs oil prices at $50-$55 a barrel to fund its imports, but Saudi Arabia requires higher prices to balance its budget and invest in its non-oil industries. Analysts predict oil prices will average $85-$90 a barrel this year and next, and potentially rise to $100 a barrel in 2024, which could hurt Biden's chances of winning the presidency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The OPEC logo pictured ahead of an informal meeting between members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in Algiers, Algeria, September 28, 2016. REUTERS/Ramzi Boudina/File Photo
Banks from Goldman Sachs to RBC Capital Markets raised their oil-price forecasts immediately after the Opec+ cut.
FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: Yellen urges further World Bank reforms this year
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged the World Bank to take on further reforms this year, building on initial steps to update its mission and boost financing capacity. Yellen emphasized the need for the bank to address global challenges such as climate change, while maintaining its existing focus on poverty reduction and development. The World Bank aims to add $50 billion in financing over the next decade, with reforms expected to be unveiled at the upcoming spring meetings in Washington.

images.alt_text: First Republic saw about 90 per cent of its market cap evaporate as the stock collapsed last month.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen testifies before the Senate Finance Committee on the proposed budget request for 2024, on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC, March 16, 2023. (Photo by Andrew Caballero-Reynolds / AFP)

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on Wednesday will host a roundtable discussion on further steps to evolve the World Bank and other development lenders to tackle climate change and other global crises beyond a US$5 billion annual World Bank lending expansion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Digilife Technologies
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation has issued a "trade with caution" alert on Digilife Technologies, a technology and telecommunication solutions provider, amid a significant surge in its share price and market capitalization. The company's share price rose 157% from January 6 to April 11, but ended 0.7% lower on the day of the alert. The move comes after the company's rapid growth, and investors are advised to exercise caution when trading its securities.

site_title: Gold ticks up as dollar softens after cooler US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,017.19 per ounce, as a softer dollar and cooler-than-expected US inflation data suggested the Federal Reserve might pause raising rates after May. The dollar index fell 0.1%, making bullion cheaper for buyers holding other currencies. Despite being an inflation hedge, rising interest rates reduce gold's appeal. The CME FedWatch tool shows a 70.4% chance of a 25 basis-point hike in May, but with rate cuts seen in the back half of the year.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered an inflation hedge, but rising interest rates reduce the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Federal Reserve economists project ‘mild recession’ at March meet: minutes
summary: US Federal Reserve economists projected a "mild recession" when the central bank raised its benchmark lending rate for the ninth time in a year, with a recovery expected over the subsequent two years. The rate hike lifted the Fed's interest rate target to 4.75-5% to curb high inflation and avert further banking sector upheaval. The economic picture has improved somewhat since the decision, with inflation slowing, but core PCE inflation remains elevated, suggesting more work to be done.

images.alt_text: Earlier, markets digested US data that showed the rate of inflation year-over-year fell to 5.0 per cent in March from 6.0 per cent in February, the smallest 12-month increase since May 2021.
The US dollar index was last at 101.68, down 0.41 per cent on the day.

IMF trimmed their forecast for world growth, but said there were “plausible” scenarios, flowing from the recent failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in the US and the forced merger of Credit Suisse, that could cut growth even deeper
The gold trading chart suggests more interest rate rises are to come, along with an economic slowdown.

site_title: Debt-laden Sunac China seeks resumption in HK trading after a year
summary: Sunac China, a debt-laden property developer, applied to resume trading in its shares in Hong Kong starting April 13. The company is implementing a restructuring plan after publishing its 2022 interim results, showing a core loss of 11.06 billion yuan. Sunac is among Chinese developers that defaulted on debt repayments last year due to losses. The firm reached an agreement with offshore creditors to restructure US$9 billion of debt by converting it to new notes and convertible bonds.

site_title: Dublin office space take-up drops 42% in sign of further stress
summary: Dublin office space take-up dropped 42% in Q1, according to a CBRE report, as stress in Ireland's commercial real estate market continues. Vacancies rose to 13%, while assignment and sub-lease deals accounted for 40% of take-up, the largest quarterly proportion on record. Technology companies, including Google and Twitter, have been laying off staff, contributing to the slowdown. Despite this, tech firms now account for over half of all office space, marking a shift in the market.

site_title: ECB has completed most of its rate-hiking journey, Villeroy says
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has completed most of its interest-rate hikes to combat sticky inflation, according to Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau. Villeroy stated that the strongest economic effect of past increases will be felt in the coming months, and the ECB may still need to raise rates at its next meetings. Policymakers are considering a more "open" approach, guided by headline inflation and underlying prices, rather than a fixed schedule. Some Governing Council members, including Austrian hawk Robert Holzmann, advocate for further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
ECB President Christine Lagarde said the euro area banking sector is resilient because it has strong capital and liquidity positions.

site_title: IBM considering sale of unit that owns Weather Channel, Weather Underground
summary: IBM is considering selling its weather business, which includes the Weather Channel and Weather Underground apps and websites, acquired in 2015 for an undisclosed amount. The move is part of the company's focus on software and cloud services. Early-stage conversations are underway, but no deal is imminent. The weather division was initially part of IBM's effort to expand into the Internet of Things market.

site_title: US broadcaster NPR quits Twitter as Musk admits ‘many mistakes’
summary: NPR, a major US radio broadcaster, has quit Twitter following a week-long row over the platform's labeling of the outlet as a "state-affiliated media". The move comes after Twitter modified its label from "state-affiliated media" to "government-funded media", a tag also applied to the BBC. This decision was seen as a response to Elon Musk's takeover of Twitter, which has been marked by a history of disdain for news media.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk says Twitter is roughly breaking even
It’s unclear what the change means for Twitter, which has seen a sweeping overhaul since Musk bought the company for US$44 billion last year.

site_title: Credit Suisse rescue package rejected by Swiss parliament
summary: Switzerland's parliament rejected a US$120.82 billion aid package for Credit Suisse's merger with UBS, leaving the bank's rescue without parliamentary approval. Despite the upper house's initial approval, the lower house voted down the measure 103-71, citing concerns about Switzerland's image and the government's decision to bypass legislative processes. The government's commitment, made under emergency law, cannot be overturned, but the vote marks a symbolic rebuke to the authorities. A revised proposal was made to reduce risks posed by systemically relevant banks, but was rejected.

images.alt_text: Swiss Federal President Alain Berset at the extraordinary session of the Federal Assembly convened to debate the government's decisions to rescue Credit Suisse and its takeover by UBS.

site_title: UK housing market weakness continues, improvement on the horizon: RICS
summary: The UK housing market continues to feel the effects of higher borrowing costs, with buyer demand, sales, and house prices all in negative territory in March. However, property surveyors expect some improvement over the year ahead, citing interest rates near their peak. The RICS's house price net balance fell to -43, up from -47 in February, and sales expectations balance rose to +1, its highest since March 2022. Rents are expected to rise 4% in the coming 12 months due to demand and supply imbalance.

images.alt_text: Technology companies accounted for more than half of all office space between January and March.

site_title: LVMH sales surge as Chinese consumers start to splurge
summary: LVMH's sales surged in the first quarter as Chinese consumers rebounded from COVID-19 lockdowns, driving a 18% organic sales growth for the fashion and leather goods division. The company is "extremely optimistic" for China in 2023, with Asia excluding Japan representing 30% of sales in 2022. LVMH's selective retailing unit, including Sephora, saw a 28% growth rate, while the US saw an 8% growth, with some slowdown in fashion and jewelry sales.

images.alt_text: Demand for Patek’s timepieces, which start at around US$30,000, still far outstrips supply.
The billionaire was once dubbed “a wolf in cashmere” by a descendant of the Hermes dynasty after he launched a failed bid to take over the competing luxury group.

Dior, the second-biggest brand of billionaire Bernard Arnault’s French luxury behemoth LVMH, and the decision to add India to its seasonal schedule shows a rising interest to tap the nation’s rising wealth.

site_title: Trump sues his former lawyer Michael Cohen for US$500 million
summary: Donald Trump has filed a $500 million lawsuit against his former lawyer Michael Cohen, alleging breach of attorney-client privileges and a confidentiality agreement. Cohen, a key witness in Trump's New York criminal case, is accused of spreading falsehoods about him and causing "vast reputational harm." Trump is seeking compensatory and punitive damages of over $500 million and a jury trial. This is the latest in a long history of lawsuits between the two, with Cohen expected to be a star witness for the prosecution if Trump's case goes to trial.

images.alt_text: Dominion Voting Systems alleges Fox damaged its business by Fox knowingly and repeatedly airing false claims that Dominion machines were used to flip the 2020 US presidential election against former President Donald Trump, a Republican, and in favour of Democrat Joe Biden, who won.

The accounting firm will also hand over all documents and communications “related to any audit, review or compilation engagement” pertaining to several Trump-affiliated entities, according to the agreement.
Former US president Donald Trump arrives for his arraignment at Manhattan Criminal Court on April 04, 2023 in New York City.
Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, said nothing as he entered the courtroom or when he left roughly an hour later.

site_title: Goh Cheng Liang’s Nippon Paint seeking acquisition deals, backed by debt
summary: Nippon Paint Holdings, backed by 1.29 trillion yen in debt, is seeking acquisitions overseas to drive growth. Co-president Yuichiro Wakatsuki expects low borrowing costs in Japan, even if interest rates rise, citing a 2-3% range. The company has been on a four-year push to buy assets abroad, with Wakatsuki advising Goh Cheng Liang's Wuthelam Holdings on a $12 billion deal in 2021. Wakatsuki declined to comment on current acquisition plans.

images.alt_text: At the time of offences, the older Shae was a senior vice president of corporate planning and development at a Nippon Paint Holdings subsidiary.

site_title: As competition intensifies, Hong Leong Finance should consider a sale
summary: Hong Leong Finance's strong growth in 2022, driven by rising interest rates, has led to a 54% increase in net profit to S$131 million. However, its share price remains flat, trading at a 45% discount to its NAV. Analysts suggest the company may consider a sale to a larger financial group, such as one of the three locally-listed banks, to boost its share price. A sale could yield an upside of over S$2 per share, and would allow the company to leverage the stronger platforms and growth prospects of a larger group.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
CGS-CIMB notes that Singapore banks do not share the same risks which led to the event due to strong corporate governance and risk management.
In 2022, Hong Leong Finance saw strong loan growth and an uplift in its asset yields, which outpaced a higher cost of deposit amid the ongoing interest rate hikes.

site_title: Snap hires Google ad executive to help improve ad performance
summary: Snapchat hires Darshan Kantak, a former Google executive, as senior vice-president of revenue product to improve ad performance. Kantak joins a rebuilding ad sales team after two key leaders left for Netflix last year. Snap aims to boost ad effectiveness and measure sales, amid a 10% revenue decline forecast due to weaker ad demand. The hire follows the recent addition of Rob Wilk, a Microsoft ad executive, to lead ad sales in the Americas region, to counteract the impact of Apple's 2021 privacy changes.

site_title: Asset enhancements could bring some warmth to S-Reits amid acquisition winter
summary: S-Reit acquisitions have slowed down due to rising interest rates, making accretive acquisitions less likely. Analysts expect Reit managers to focus on asset enhancements instead, citing the benefits of higher returns for investors. Despite a lack of deals, asset enhancement initiatives have shown promising results, with some industrial S-Reits guiding NPI yields of 6-8%. Experts warn that S-Reits should remain cautious and selective in acquisitions, with interest rates needing to peak and correct before deal-making can resume.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
MLT is considering buying up to 10 properties in Asia Pacific, and divesting one in Hong Kong.
The last time there were no S-Reit IPOs was in 2008 and 2009, in the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis.

site_title: Bankrupt crypto exchange FTX has recovered US$7.3 billion in assets
summary: Bankrupt crypto exchange FTX has recovered over US$7.3 billion in cash and liquid crypto assets, with US$6.2 billion of this total valued at crypto prices from November 2022. The company's new CEO, John Ray, has detailed improper fund transfers and poor accounting. FTX is negotiating with stakeholders about restarting its crypto exchange, potentially in the current quarter, and is working on a preliminary Chapter 11 plan to file by July. The company's future plans are uncertain, and it is unclear whether it will use its own funds to restart the exchange or seek outside funding.

site_title: Norway wealth fund faces claims of wage discrimination
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, Norges Bank Investment Management, faces an employment lawsuit over alleged wage discrimination and a hostile work environment. Former head of trading analytics, Elisabeth Bull Daae, claims she was underpaid compared to male colleagues and felt bullied. The fund has rejected the claims, but the case comes as the fund seeks to use its influence to address pay gaps and other issues. The lawsuit also involves a workplace romance and a job swap to reduce conflict of interest. The case is ongoing in Oslo's district court.

images.alt_text: The transaction is part of Iberdola’s plan to sell minority stakes in renewable developments to finance its climate action plan.

site_title: UK house sales at pre-Covid levels after mini-budget shock: Rightmove
summary: UK house sales rebounded to within 1% of pre-pandemic levels in March, according to Rightmove. The number of sales agreed between sellers and buyers was 1% lower than in March 2019, as borrowing costs decreased after the September "mini-budget". The housing market faces challenges from high inflation and interest-rate increases, but has seen a significant upswing in buyer demand for apartments. London saw the most pronounced recovery, with overall agreed sales increasing 11% from 2019.

images.alt_text: The BOE’s bid to curtail inflation has increased mortgage costs, prompting Britons to turn to other corners of the home-loan market in an attempt to cut bills.
The construction PMI’s slowdown has been driven by a fourth consecutive monthly fall in house-building, which declined at the fastest rate since May 2020.

site_title: India’s growing population and rising consumption present investment opportunities
summary: India is expected to surpass China as the world's most populous country by April 15, with a projected population of 1.425 billion by 2030 and 1.7 billion by 2064. This growth is expected to fuel a surge in consumption, driving India's rapidly expanding economy. The country's consumer sector is projected to expand at a compound annual growth rate of 9-10% over the decade, reaching $2 trillion by 2032. Young, digitally connected, and aspirational Indians are driving the growth, with the online shopper base forecasted to double to 350 million by 2026.

images.alt_text: A Jan 2023 photo showing employees at a car assembly line in a Beijing factory in Qingdao, in China's eastern Shandong province.
The United Nations has projected India’s population could touch 1,425,775,850 on Apr 14, overtaking China on that day.

site_title: India inflation falls below RBI target as high rates nip demand
summary: India's retail inflation fell to 5.66% in March, below the Reserve Bank of India's target of 6%, as high interest rates slowed demand. This marks the first time the inflation rate has fallen below the target in three months. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to consider interest rate cuts later this year, supported by a forecast of a normal monsoon and easing prices. Economists also note the International Monetary Fund's guidance for ultra-low rates in the US and other industrial countries.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on recession worries
summary: US stocks ended the day lower on Wednesday due to concerns over a mild recession, as reported by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.1%, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The recession projection, made in March, suggests a mild recession starting later this year with a recovery over the next two years. Despite a decline in inflation to 5.0% in March, analysts believe the Fed will still raise interest rates in May, with a pause possible in June.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Europe: Blue-chip index hits 22-year high, US inflation eases
summary: The blue-chip Stoxx 50 index in Europe reached its highest level since 2001, driven by investor optimism over US inflation easing and potential pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. The index initially touched a 22-year high before closing with marginal gains. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index also rose 0.1% following the news.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 0.6 per cent higher on Tuesday,  extending gains for the second straight day.

site_title: Harry Potter TV series announced, Rowling to executive produce
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery has announced a Harry Potter TV series, with JK Rowling serving as an executive producer. The series will be a faithful adaptation of the books and air on the rebranded streaming service Max. The show will feature a new cast and cover the stories from each of the books, becoming a decade-long series. Rowling, who has faced controversy over her comments on trans issues, emphasized the importance of preserving the integrity of her books. No timeline was given for when the show will be filmed.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 29, 2022 British writer JK Rowling poses on the red carpet after arriving to attend the World Premiere of the film "Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore" in London. - The first Harry Potter television series is set to be made, with author JK Rowling acting as an executive producer, Warner Bros. Discovery announced on April 12, 2023. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)
Warner Bros has been eager to do more with one of the best-selling book series of all-time.
Aubrey Plaza in the second season of The White Lotus, which was filmed at San Domenico Palace, a Four Seasons resort hotel in Taormina, Sicily.

site_title: Nvidia enhances mid-range video gaming chip with AI technology
summary: Nvidia is releasing the RTX 4070 chip, a mid-range gaming chip with enhanced AI features, starting Thursday. The $599 chip uses AI to predict pixel values, generating entire frames more quickly for realistic game rendering. This update comes as gaming revenue accounts for about a third of Nvidia's $26.9 billion in fiscal 2023 revenue, despite a 27% decline in gaming revenue due to a sagging PC market. The new chip will be the cheapest available with Nvidia's latest AI technology.

site_title: China’s Zeekr launches electric SUV, targets Europe
summary: China's Zeekr has launched an electric SUV, the Zeekr X, targeting the premium market in China, where it competes with German automakers. The vehicle offers features like facial recognition and an in-vehicle refrigerator, starting at 189,800 yuan (S$36,689.24) in China. Zeekr plans to deliver 40,000 units in China this year and expand to Western Europe and Asian markets without specifying timelines. The company has partnered with Waymo for a robotaxi and aims to double annual sales to 140,000 vehicles in 2023.

site_title: Netflix sensation ‘The Glory’ spurs bullying crackdown in South Korea
summary: South Korea has announced strict measures to combat bullying in schools, following the success of Netflix series "The Glory," which was based on true acts of bullying that occurred more than two decades ago. The series was the most-watched show on Netflix for two weeks, performing in over 90 countries. As a result, students with records of bullying will have their incidents reflected in their college application process starting in 2026. The country aims to establish a "zero-tolerance policy" for school violence, with records of serious cases being doubled in length.

site_title: India’s TCS beats Q4 profit view on strong deal momentum
summary: India's top IT exporter, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), reported a 14.8% rise in Q4 profit to 113.92 billion rupees, beating analyst expectations. The company's order book for the period stood at US$10 billion, up 28% sequentially, with an "all-time high number of large deals." Revenue from operations rose 17% to 591.62 billion rupees. The strong earnings report sets the tone for the industry, which is facing a recession in major markets and turmoil in the US banking sector. TCS is also transitioning to a new CEO.

site_title: US dollar drops as inflation below economists’ expectations
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.41% to 101.68 on April 12, 2023, following data showing US consumer prices rose 0.1% in March, below economists' expectations. This decrease suggests the Federal Reserve may stop hiking interest rates after a possible increase in May, as the 5.0% year-on-year gain in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) is the smallest since May 2021.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues ‘trade with caution’ alert on Digilife Technologies
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has issued a "trade with caution" alert on Digilife Technologies, citing a 157% surge in its share price from S$1.12 to S$2.88. The regulator notes that share buybacks contributed to 70.6% of the stock's buy volume, resulting in a S$38.6 million market capitalization surge. This is similar to a 2021 alert issued for Sevak Limited, Digilife Tech's predecessor, which also involved share buybacks. SGX RegCo will continue to review and monitor trades, potentially referring the case to statutory authorities if necessary.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers
Digilife Tech and seller TG Holdings HK mutually agreed to terminate the sale and purchase agreement without liability to either party.

site_title: Sun, wind power make record 12% of world electricity: survey
summary: Solar and wind power surged to make a record 12% of the world's electricity in 2022, according to a climate think tank, helping slow the rise in planet-heating emissions. This marks a significant increase from 5% in 2015, and 10% in 2021. Renewable sources, including nuclear power, accounted for 39% of world electricity, while fossil fuels, particularly coal, remained the leading source at 36%. The growth is seen as a step towards meeting emissions targets and securing alternative power sources, with scientists and the International Energy Agency calling for a sharp reduction in fossil fuel use to limit global warming to 1.5°C.

images.alt_text: Wind and solar output jumped 21 per cent last year to 1,190 terawatt-hours of electricity.

site_title: Asian Development Bank mulling cheaper funds for Sri Lanka, support for green bonds
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is considering providing cheaper funds to Sri Lanka, including support for green bonds, as part of its assistance to help the country recover from its worst economic crisis in decades. ADB Sri Lanka country director Chen Chen stated that the lender's immediate priority is to continue work on overall economic stability and support the banking and energy sectors. Sri Lanka has recently secured a $3 billion loan program from the International Monetary Fund and has been working to ease its debt obligations. The ADB has already disbursed $334 million and has approximately $3.7 billion of previously approved loans.

images.alt_text: The central bank on Apr 4 held its benchmark rate at a two-decade high of 16.5 per cent in order to keep Asia’s fastest inflation in check while supporting economic recovery.
A general view of the main business district as rain clouds gather above in Colombo, Sri Lanka, November 17, 2020. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: Mining giant makes debut in Indonesia’s biggest IPO this year
summary: Indonesian mining firm Trimegah Bangun Persada, also known as Harita Nickel, made its debut on the Jakarta stock exchange with a successful initial public offering (IPO) of 10 trillion rupiah ($897 million). The shares rose 4% to 1,300 rupiah, attracting investors seeking to profit from the electric-vehicle (EV) supply chain. Harita Nickel is the first company in South-east Asia's largest economy to process low-grade nickel ore into battery-grade metal using high-pressure acid leaching, a method not largely represented in Jakarta's stock exchange.

images.alt_text: Weakness in Indonesia’s secondary market is a  concern as the benchmark Jakarta Composite Index is down 0.7 per cent this year.
Harita Nickel’s Halmahera Persada Lygend processing facility on Obi Island. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Harita operates the country’s first high-pressure acid leaching (HPAL) smelter on Obi island in North Maluku.

“Armed with substantial nickel reserves, Indonesia’s ambition to be the EV hub of South-east Asia will help drive its economic growth,” said Henry Wibowo, JP Morgan’s head of Indonesia research and strategy.
Merdeka Battery is tapping into the surging global demand for electric cars by refining its nickel into battery materials.

site_title: EL Development to launch Blossoms By The Park in S$2,200-S$2,400 psf range
summary: EL Development will launch Blossoms By The Park in Singapore, a 99-year leasehold condominium project in District 5, with 275 residential units priced between S$2,200 and S$2,400 per square foot (psf). The project, which sits on 85,648 sq ft of land, will also feature three floors of commercial lots. Previews are set to start on Apr 14, with sales bookings expected to begin on Apr 29. The project is expected to achieve its temporary occupation permit on Dec 31, 2026.

images.alt_text: Some 38 per cent of Terra Hill's 270 units was sold at a booking exercise on Feb 24 and 25.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as inflation data eases rate-hike worries
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 rising 12.78 points, or 0.31%, to 4,121.72, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 78.99 points, or 0.66%, to 12,110.87. The positive start is attributed to easing inflation data, which has raised hopes that the Federal Reserve may pause its interest rate hiking cycle. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 79.42 points, or 0.24%, at the open to 33,764.21.

site_title: IMF sees slowing consumption hitting India’s growth momentum
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its growth outlook for India, cutting its forecast to 5.9% for the current fiscal year from 6.1% previously. The IMF attributed the downgrade to slowing consumption and a near-catch-up with pre-pandemic economic growth. A "good monsoon" is expected to help reduce food prices and bring inflation under 5%. The IMF also trimmed its global growth projection to 2.8% for this year, citing reduced trade uncertainty and a slowdown in consumption.

images.alt_text: A farmer checking his wheat crop damaged by unseasonal rain and hailstorms in Bagli village on the outskirts of Bhopal in March.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as Asia markets close mixed; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to close at 3,286.12 points, following mixed trading across Asia. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.1%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and South Korea's Kospi rose between 0.1% and 0.6%. Local stocks were led by Hongkong Land, with five gainers among the STI stocks. Losers, including Sembcorp Industries and the trio of local banks, outpaced gainers 282 to 260.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney and Wellington rose but Hong Kong, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta fell while Seoul was flat at midday on Wednesday.

site_title: Inflation trumps financial risks as central bank tightening set to continue
summary: Global central banks are prioritizing inflation control over financial stability, despite recent banking sector stress, as they prepare to continue raising interest rates. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) trimmed its forecast for world growth, citing "plausible" scenarios that could cut growth deeper, but central bankers say inflation remains the greater risk. The Bank of England and European Central Bank are set to raise interest rates, while the US Federal Reserve is expected to follow suit, despite concerns about a potential recession. Policymakers believe a normalizing global economy won't lead to easy returns to pre-pandemic inflation trends.

images.alt_text: “The pace of price hikes is expected to slow towards the middle of this fiscal year due to government steps to curb energy prices and as the effects of companies passing on costs wane,” BOJ deputy governor Shinichi Uchida said.
IMF's Mission Chief for India Nada Choueiri said a “good monsoon” would help reduce food prices that’ll help bring down the overall inflation to under 5 per cent in the current financial year.
China’s reopening distributes benefits to the rest of the Asia region

Philadelphia Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker joined his fellow US central bankers last month in voting for a quarter of a percentage point increase in the benchmark overnight interest rate, taking it to a range of 4.75 per cent to 5.00 per cent.

site_title: Italy sets end-April deadline for OpenAI to meet demands on ChatGPT
summary: Italy's data protection agency, Garante, has set an April 30 deadline for OpenAI to address concerns over data protection and privacy for its ChatGPT chatbot service. The agency accused OpenAI of failing to check user ages and storing personal data without a legal basis. To lift restrictions, OpenAI must meet concrete demands by the deadline, including implementing age verification and data protection measures. If met, the agency will suspend restrictions, allowing ChatGPT to resume in Italy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
SenseTime CEO Xu Li took to the stage on Monday (Apr 10) to show the capabilities of its large AI model SenseNova and a user-facing chatbot called SenseChat.
ChatGPT, which has wowed some users with quick responses to questions and caused distress for others with inaccuracies, is made by California-based OpenAI and backed by Microsoft Corp.
Alibaba Cloud plans to open Tongyi Qianwen to its clients so they can build their own customised large language models.

site_title: Manchester United bidding process goes to third round
summary: Manchester United's bidding process has advanced to the third round, with Sheikh Jassim and Jim Ratcliffe remaining front-runners to buy the club should the Glazers give up control. Several offers have been received in recent weeks, but the Qatari banker and British billionaire remain the top contenders. The third round of bids is due by the end of April, with the Glazers having purchased the club in 2005 for £790 million.

images.alt_text: Net profit came in at £6.3 million (S$10.3 million) in the quarter, compared with a loss of £1.4 million a year earlier.
Qatari banker Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani (left) and British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe (right) have summitted second bids for Manchester United.

site_title: Oil rises 2% on lower-than-expected US inflation data
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday, driven by cooling US inflation data, which sparked hopes that the Federal Reserve may end its interest-rate hikes. The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased 0.1% last month, the smallest year-on-year gain since May 2021. A weaker US dollar and reduced recession concerns also supported oil prices. Despite a small build in US crude oil stocks, the market shrugged off the news, with hedge funds buying oil futures anticipating improving demand.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.43, or 1.7 per cent, to US$85.61 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Intel to work with Arm on chip manufacturing compatibility
summary: Intel announced a partnership with UK-based chip designer Arm to ensure that products using Arm's technology can be manufactured in Intel's factories. This move is part of Intel's turnaround strategy, which includes opening up its factories to other chip companies, particularly those in mobile phones. The partnership aims to improve compatibility and expand Intel's customer base. Intel's contract manufacturing division will work with Arm to produce mobile phone chips and other products that use Arm's technology.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Intel logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: OCBC joins in the push to preserve mangroves in Singapore
summary: OCBC Bank has committed funds and resources to preserve mangroves in Singapore, aiming to reclaim lost territory and combat climate change. The bank's initiatives, launched in 2017, include habitat-enhancement projects, tree planting, and research on mangrove ecosystems. These efforts have resulted in the planting of over 18,000 trees, which can absorb more than 30 million kg of carbon dioxide. OCBC's #OCBCCares programme encourages community involvement in climate change mitigation, with a focus on sustainable projects and education.

images.alt_text: Bill Winters (second from left) and Patrick Lee (third from left), with Standard Chartered Bank's staff volunteers at Mandai Wildlife Reserve

site_title: BT Luxe goes to Tokyo
summary: BT Luxe magazine releases its latest issue featuring an exclusive interview with Japanese model-actress Kōki, daughter of actor Takuya Kimura and singer Shizuka Kudo. Kōki discusses building her career despite her parents' fame. The issue also highlights young talents and entrepreneurs, including Singaporeans Theodoric Chew and Sara Ang, and showcases the latest watch novelties from Watches and Wonders in Geneva. Additionally, the magazine features design ideas for holiday homes, fashion tips, and a spotlight on the Bulgari Hotel in Tokyo.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate drops a fifth week to two-month low
summary: US 30-year fixed mortgage rates dropped 10 basis points to 6.3% for the fifth consecutive week, reaching a two-month low. This decrease in rates, attributed to investors seeking safety in Treasury bonds following bank collapses, boosted demand for home purchases. However, borrowing costs remain high, and limited housing inventory continues to curb homebuying activity. The Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications also increased 7.8% to its highest level since mid-January.

site_title: BOE's Bailey says bank reforms worked, but questions about liquidity buffers
summary: Banking reforms enacted after the 2007-09 global financial crisis have worked during recent turmoil, but there are questions about the size of liquidity buffers required of banks to tide them over short-term shocks, according to BOE Governor Andrew Bailey. The recent failure of Silicon Valley Bank and other lenders led to a global banking crisis, but markets have since calmed. Bailey says banks are well-capitalized, liquid, and able to serve customers, but there may be a need to reassess liquidity buffers to prevent similar crises in the future.

images.alt_text: The BOE said it has been concerned that banks may be overly reluctant to draw on their so-called Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR), a buffer of cash and high quality bonds to withstand a month of outflows.

site_title: Singapore’s Q1 GDP growth likely slowed, complicating central bank’s task
summary: Singapore's economy likely expanded 0.6% in Q1, slower than the 2.1% growth in Q4 2022, due to weaker external demand. Manufacturing contracted for five consecutive months, while the services sector is expected to help offset this decline. Analysts debate whether the Monetary Authority of Singapore should tighten policy again to contain inflation, which remains at a 14-year high at 5.5%. The central bank's review on Friday will determine the direction of monetary policy.

images.alt_text: As recession risks rise in the US, a contraction in US' GDP is expected, as higher interest rates sap economic activity.
The BOT last month raised interest rates a quarter a percentage point to 1.75 per cent.

site_title: Buffett: Do not panic about US banking industry
summary: Warren Buffett reassured the public that the US banking industry is not in crisis, stating that people "do not need to be panicked" about it and their deposits are safe. Despite recent failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, Buffett said the industry's problems do not resemble those that led to the 2008 global financial crisis. He expressed confidence that the industry will recover and deposits will remain secure.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett has received US$401,589 in compensation for 2022, up 8 per cent from 2021, comprising his usual US$100,000 salary plus personal and home security.

site_title: Crypto VC funding plunges by 80% in dire quarter for startups
summary: Global venture capital funding for the crypto industry plummeted 80% to $2.4 billion in the first quarter, the lowest level since 2020. This decline is attributed to rising interest rates, regulatory uncertainty, and the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, which was widely relied on by venture-backed companies. The drop is in line with a broader decline in venture investing this year, with experts citing uncertainty about the macro environment as a major factor.

site_title: Britain’s remortgaging pain is only getting started
summary: The Bank of England's efforts to curb inflation have led to increased mortgage costs, prompting British households to seek alternative home-loan options. As 56,220 two-year fixed-rate mortgages are set to expire in September, many are opting for tracker deals, which typically follow interest rates. This shift marks a reversal of the trend towards fixed-rate mortgages, as households bet on the central bank's potential interest-rate cut at the end of the year. The move is expected to impact the UK's home-loan market.

images.alt_text: Cambridge is a crucial part of the UK’s goal to become a science and technology superpower by 2030.
The construction PMI’s slowdown has been driven by a fourth consecutive monthly fall in house-building, which declined at the fastest rate since May 2020.

site_title: Berlin’s housing market rebounds after brief price drop
summary: Berlin's housing market has rebounded after a brief price drop, with the cost of buying a newly-built apartment rising 0.8% in the last quarter, reversing a 5.3% decline in the previous quarter. The average price per square meter now stands at 6,093 euros, nearly double the level seven years ago.
