Existing apartment prices also fell, but the decline is expected to reverse soon, with the Europace house price indicator posting a month-on-month increase in February, breaking a seven-month streak of declines.

images.alt_text: “The German real estate investment market is in a very challenging phase,” BNP Paribas Real Estate Germany head Marcus Zorn said in the report.

site_title: Sustainable finance isn’t as complex as it seems, OCBC tells SMEs
summary: OCBC has simplified sustainable finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, allowing them to access green loans without a certification. The bank has given over 500 SMEs green loans in the past two years, with only one-third of them providing a green certificate. OCBC uses a framework that assesses a company's business activities, product features, and government grants to qualify for a green loan. This approach aims to lower barriers to entry and reduce consultancy fees. The bank also offers subsidies for SMEs to develop a sustainability strategy and adopt sustainability standards.

images.alt_text: The enhancements to the EFS include trade loans, working capital loans and support for domestic construction projects via project loans, which saw extensions from Mar 31 this year to Mar 31, 2024.
OCBC's head of global consumer financial services, Sunny Quek, says the take-up rate for the bank's Eco-Care loans is better than expected.
In February, BIDV issued a Sustainable Loan Framework in consultation with global climate consultancy Carbon Trust
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience
Singapore Manufacturing Federation president Lennon Tan took office last May.
Last year, the Singapore Exchange mandated climate reporting for listed companies and the Monetary Authority of Singapore launched a portal for companies to report ESG data.

site_title: NCSS rallies partners to better engage volunteers
summary: The National Council of Social Service (NCSS) hosted the inaugural Volunteer Management (VM) conference in Singapore, drawing 2,000 attendees from various sectors. The event aimed to discuss the importance of having volunteer managers and incorporating VM practices to retain volunteers. Keynote speakers emphasized that corporate social responsibility is a form of employee engagement, highlighting the need for clear volunteer role descriptions to meet organizational needs. The conference aimed to increase companies' chances of retaining volunteers and foster a culture of volunteer engagement.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
From left: Team members of Change X, Seph Chen, Suhana Gupta, Peyton Choo, Asmita Mitra and Mitra Sachi.

site_title: China to close airspace briefly due to falling object from satellite launch
summary: China plans to close airspace north of Taiwan for about half an hour due to a falling object from a satellite launch vehicle. The "no-fly zone" will fall within Taiwan's air defense identification zone, approximately 85 nautical miles north of its shores. This decision reduces the original three-day closure period.

images.alt_text: The rocket carrying the Shenzhou-14 mission With three Chinese astronauts lifts off at the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center in Northwest China’s Gansu Province on June 5, 2022. - China on June 5 launched a rocket carrying three astronauts on a mission to complete construction on its new space station, the latest milestone in Beijing's drive to become a major space power. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Bank of Canada keeps rates on hold, sees stronger 2023 growth
summary: The Bank of Canada (BOC) kept its key overnight interest rate at 4.50% on Wednesday, holding off on further increases as inflation is expected to fall to 3% in the middle of this year and reach the 2% target by 2024. The BOC raised its growth forecast for 2023 to 1.4%, citing tight labour market conditions and demand exceeding supply. Despite previous warnings of a possible recession, the BOC dropped language suggesting negative growth, saying it remains prepared to raise rates if necessary.

site_title: BOC Aviation awarded US$406.2 million over planes stuck in Russia
summary: A US judge ordered Russia's largest cargo airline, AirBridgeCargo, to pay US$406.2 million to aircraft lessor BOC Aviation after being declared in default on leases for three Boeing 747-8F planes due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The airline was unable to maintain required reinsurance coverage, and the planes remained in Russia despite EU restrictions and Russian sanctions. BOC Aviation was able to recover one plane and engines, but two planes and engines remain in Russia.

images.alt_text: Foreign aircraft owners risk billions of losses in Russia

site_title: Thai panel weighs risk of low real interest rate on stability
summary: Thailand's central bank considers the potential risks of low real interest rates on economic stability, with a report warning of the possibility of "economic imbalance." The Bank of Thailand Assistant Governor suggests that real interest rates should not be negative when the economy grows at 3-4% annually. Stronger-than-expected tourist arrivals and associated boosts to labor income and domestic demand also pose upside risks to 2023 GDP growth, according to the report. The central bank is expected to maintain a gradual tightening of monetary policy amid lingering inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: Headline inflation dropped to its lowest rate in 15 months of 2.83 per cent in March, returning within the Bank of Thailand’s target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent for the first time since 2021.

site_title: Fears of global sugar shortage drive prices to decade high
summary: Global sugar prices have surged to a decade-high due to persistent worries about tight supplies, with raw sugar rising 1.9% in New York. Concerns about limited exports from India and reduced production in key growers, such as Wilmar International Ltd., are driving the market higher. A lack of deliverable sugar ahead of the May white-sugar contract expiry on Friday is also contributing to the price increase.

site_title: US calls for end to Northern Ireland assembly impasse
summary: US President Joe Biden and UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak have called for an end to the Northern Ireland assembly impasse, which has halted the region's devolved government since February 2022. The impasse was sparked by the Democratic Unionist Party's boycott of the administration over post-Brexit trading arrangements. Biden expressed hope that the assembly will be restored "as soon as possible," while Sunak's office echoed this sentiment. The lack of a functioning government has resulted in delayed decisions on key issues like healthcare and the cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text:
On Tuesday (Apr 11), UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (above)  will welcome US President Joe Biden to Northern Ireland.
The pair will “undertake a programme of engagements”, including a bilateral meeting, says Downing Street.

site_title: China's Sinopec to take 5% share in Qatar's North Field East
summary: China's state-owned oil and gas giant Sinopec will take a 5% stake in Qatar's North Field East expansion, a part of the world's largest liquefied natural gas project. This follows a 27-year LNG supply deal signed in November, where QatarEnergy agreed to supply 4 million tonnes annually. QatarEnergy plans to retain a 75% stake in the expansion, valued at at least $30 billion.

images.alt_text: Sinopec announced this year it would build a green hydrogen plant in the Inner Mongolian city of Ordos, with a planned annual capacity of 30,000 tonnes.

site_title: Twitter working on AI despite Musk call for global pause: report
summary: Elon Musk is reportedly working on an artificial intelligence project at Twitter, despite calling for a global pause in AI development. The project involves training a language model to create written content, and Musk has invested in powerful computing processors and AI talent. This contradicts his recent letter to experts urging a six-month pause in AI development, citing concerns over the technology's risks to society. Musk's AI project at Twitter remains unclear in purpose, with potential applications in search and advertising tools.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Cloud plans to open Tongyi Qianwen to its clients so they can build their own customised large language models.

Chatbots in China mostly focus on social interactions whereas ChatGPT, which learns from vast amounts of data how to answer prompts by users in a human-like manner, performs better at more professional tasks.
SenseTime CEO Xu Li took to the stage on Monday (Apr 10) to show the capabilities of its large AI model SenseNova and a user-facing chatbot called SenseChat.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas to restart operations at LNG terminal by Q1 2024
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, plans to restart one of its liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals by the first quarter of 2024. The restart is subject to local authority approval after a pipeline leak caused a force majeure in October. Petronas aims to complete an investigation into the disruption by mid-2023 and continues to provide alternative supplies to customers, including Japanese utilities. The company seeks to extend its long-term contracts with Japanese customers, with discussions ongoing.

images.alt_text: Petronas operates oil and gas fields within Malaysia’s 200-mile exclusive economic zone and has in recent years had several encounters with Chinese vessels.

site_title: Truck maker Volvo posts record Q1 as sales, margins beat forecasts
summary: Volvo, a truck maker, reported a record first-quarter profit of 18.4 billion Swedish krona, a 45% increase, beating analyst forecasts. Despite supply bottlenecks and cost inflation, Volvo's revenue and margins rose, with adjusted operating profit and net sales surpassing expectations. The company attributed its turnaround to better supply chain management and price increases, and will report full first-quarter earnings on April 20.

site_title: Taylor Swift fans grapple with breakup reports
summary: Taylor Swift fans are grappling with reports of her possible breakup with boyfriend Joe Alwyn, after outlets such as Entertainment Tonight and People magazine cited unnamed sources as saying the couple had split weeks ago. Fans are divided, with some accepting the reports as true and others expressing skepticism, citing the lack of confirmation from Swift or her representatives. Some fans are also taking to social media to analyze Swift's lyrics and stage performances for clues about her relationship status.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift performs during the iHeartRadio Jingle Ball concert at Madison Square Garden in the Manhattan borough of New York City, U.S., December 13, 2019.

site_title: IMF says public debt is growing faster than pre-Covid projections
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that public debt is growing faster than pre-Covid projections, with risks high, particularly in low-income developing countries. Global public debt soared to almost 100% of GDP in 2020, with a significant number of large economies, including the US, China, and Brazil, experiencing rapid growth in their debt-to-GDP ratios. The IMF urges reducing debt vulnerabilities as an "overriding priority," especially for low-income countries, to mitigate potential risks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo at its headquarters in Washington, U.S., May 10, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: SoftBank sells early stage VC arm to entity led by Taizo Son
summary: SoftBank is selling its early-stage venture capital arm SoftBank Ventures Asia to an entity led by Taizo Son, the younger brother of SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son. The Seoul-based venture capital arm has about $2 billion in assets under management and has invested in companies such as Socar and Super. The sale comes after SoftBank suffered billions of dollars in losses from failed startup bets. The exact terms of the sale have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SoftBank Corp's logo is pictured at a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, February 4, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Swiss parliament grapples with compromise on UBS guarantees
summary: Switzerland's parliament is struggling to find a compromise on guarantees for UBS Group's takeover of Credit Suisse Group. The lower house rejected the measure, but the upper house approved it earlier. If no compromise is reached, the bill will fail, but the takeover deal is still expected to proceed as the government has already secured approval from a small group of senior lawmakers. The standoff highlights the anger among lawmakers ahead of national elections later this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse are seen in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo/File Photo
Swiss Federal President Alain Berset at the extraordinary session of the Federal Assembly convened to debate the government's decisions to rescue Credit Suisse and its takeover by UBS.
Some 11,000 jobs could be cut from the giant bank formed following UBS' takeover of its cross-town rival Credit Suisse.

site_title: Singapore Prestige Brand Award 2023 to celebrate ‘creativity, courage and confidence’
summary: The Singapore Prestige Brand Award 2023 was launched on April 12, recognizing local brands that embody "creativity, courage and confidence". The award celebrates transformative and fearless brands, with four categories: promising brands, established brands, heritage brands, and special merit. The judging panel comprises representatives from statutory boards and multinational corporations. This year's theme aims to acknowledge the creativity and ingenuity of local brands in the face of the pandemic-induced economic downturn, with over 470 unique local brands having received the award in the past.

images.alt_text: (From left) Ong Chu Poh , Eexecutive Chairman of ECON Healthcare overall winner of Heritage Brands; Andy Kueh, chief operating officer (COO) of elemen, overall winner of Promising Brands; and Peh Yi Han, COO of Mulberry Learning's parent company Global Eduhub..
Over 760 business leaders and VIPs attended the gala dinner held at the Resorts World Convention Centre on November 23, 2022.
Success may come in different forms, and at different stages of life. Yet, having a university degree remains a basic aspiration, not least in Singapore.

site_title: Former teen idol alleges sex abuse by Japan music mogul
summary: A former teen idol, Kauan Okamoto, has publicly alleged that Japan music mogul Johnny Kitagawa repeatedly sexually assaulted him between the ages of 15 and 19. Okamoto claims Kitagawa, who founded Japan's biggest boyband empire, used his position to exploit and abuse young talents. Okamoto is one of the first people to publicly address Kitagawa's long-alleged history of sexual abuse, which has resurfaced after a recent BBC documentary.

images.alt_text: 'New world order': Asia's virtual influencers offer metaverse glimpse

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders await key inflation report
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday as traders awaited US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision-making. Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, and Wellington rose, while Hong Kong, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta fell, with Seoul flat. The Fed is split on the best approach, with some urging caution and others advocating for a rate hike. Analysts expect the next few days to shape market sentiment, with data on consumer prices and the corporate reporting season on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rose more than one per cent, as did Tokyo and Sydney at midday on Tuesday.

site_title: BOJ to continue monetary easing to achieve inflation target
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) will continue its monetary easing to achieve a 2% inflation target, with Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida stating that the pace of price hikes is expected to slow in the middle of the fiscal year. The central bank will also support the economy with wage hikes in a sustainable manner. This decision comes as global markets remain cautious about the risk of contagion from Western banking sector troubles, but Japanese financial institutions are seen as well-equipped to handle any potential impact.

images.alt_text: “As a result of appropriate policy from both the BOJ and the government we’re now in a situation where we’re not in a state of deflation,” Ueda told reporters in Tokyo on Monday (Apr 10) after meeting with Kishida at the prime minister’s office.

site_title: Tencent slumps most in seven weeks on Prosus selling speculation
summary: Tencent Holdings tumbled 4.9% to HK$358, its largest drop in seven weeks, amid speculation that Prosus may speed up selling its shares in the Chinese internet giant. Prosus plans to deposit an additional 96 million shares, potentially accelerating its selling pace. Despite Tencent's share buybacks, negative news has caused concern. The company's share price has rebounded 90% from its October low, boosted by its plans to develop a ChatGPT-like bot and Beijing's resumption of game approval.

images.alt_text: The stock exchange said in December it will introduce a new dual counter trading model from the first half of 2023.

Chatbots in China mostly focus on social interactions whereas ChatGPT, which learns from vast amounts of data how to answer prompts by users in a human-like manner, performs better at more professional tasks.

site_title: More Apac insurers integrating ESG criteria into their investment strategies
summary: Seventy percent of Asia-Pacific insurers have integrated ESG criteria into their investment strategies, with company branding being the most crucial motivation. Regulatory expectations were a key driver, but 80% of respondents rated branding as "important" or "very important". Most insurers believe local ESG regulations will be tightened in the next three years, especially in Australia, Malaysia, and Hong Kong. This trend signals a growing willingness among insurers to align their ESG integration with global standards, with 22 Apac insurers now signatories of the United Nations Principles for Sustainable Insurance.

images.alt_text: Marsh clients can qualify for the preferential terms by completing Marsh’s proprietary ESG Risk Rating assessment or that of an approved third-party rating methodology.
Rising natural gas prices will further drive countries like Singapore to diversify their energy sources, but challenges - such as space constraints when it comes to solar deployment - remain. PHOTO:

site_title: Mercedes posts rise in Q1 sales boosted by EVs, premium cars
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a 3% increase in Q1 sales to 503,500 vehicles, driven by electric vehicles (EVs) and premium cars. EV sales nearly doubled to 51,600 units, while the top-end segment grew 18% to 91,800 units. Despite supply chain disruptions and economic headwinds, Mercedes-Benz achieved its best Q1 result for the Vans division, with a 12% growth to 98,900 units. The company attributed the strong performance to the resilience of its EV and premium segments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Mercedes-Benz logo is seen at the 43rd Bangkok International Motor Show, in Bangkok, Thailand, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo
The SL 55 also has active aerodynamics to stabilise it at high speed, which is handy because the snarling V8 can propel it all the way to 295 km/h.
Mercedes aims for 70 per cent of its energy demand from vehicle production to be covered by renewable sources by 2030.

The pricey ownership rights are the result of a quota system that controls the number of autos allowed on the nation’s streets, helping limit congestion and pollution, through the twice-a-month bidding process.

site_title: MAS stands ready to provide liquidity in times of global stress: Tharman
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is ready to provide liquidity to ensure financial stability amid global stress and volatility. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for medium-term price stability to drive sustained economic growth. MAS will continue to focus on safeguarding the financial sector and conducting regular stress tests to maintain liquidity positions. The government also plans to support the financial services sector to achieve net job creation of 3,000 to 4,000 per year, while strengthening international partnerships and digital transformation initiatives.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The current Parliament, Singapore's 14th, now consists 103 members of Parliament: 92 elected MPs, 2 Non-Constituency MPs and 9 Nominated MPs.
If meritocracy necessarily results in unequal outcomes, the question is: Can we rely on such a system to deliver good outcomes for everyone?
President Halimah Yacob says Singapore would need to strengthen its social fabric to remain united and do well in  an increasingly dangerous and troubled world post-pandemic.

The Ministry for National Development will continue to “plan boldly for the long-term”, said its minister Desmond Lee, noting that Singapore now aspires to be a “City in Nature” with native flora and fauna thriving amid the metropolis.

site_title: China says Taiwan heading for 'stormy seas' under Tsai
summary: China has accused Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen of pushing the island into "stormy seas" after she met with US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, prompting Beijing to hold military exercises. China views Tsai as a separatist and has rebuffed calls for talks. Tsai, however, says her government will defend Taiwan if attacked. Despite the drills ending as scheduled, China has continued military activities around Taiwan, detecting 35 aircraft and eight navy vessels in the previous 24 hours, with 14 crossing the median line of the Taiwan Strait.

site_title: Cars@Expo to feature a new ‘School of EV’ zone
summary: Cars@Expo, an automotive show in Singapore, will take place this weekend with 29 exhibitor booths and 35 brands. The event will feature a "School of EV" zone, allowing visitors to learn about owning electric vehicles in Singapore. Buyers of new or pre-owned cars will receive up to S$500 worth of SPC vouchers, while the first 100 pre-owned car buyers will receive an SPC SpeedyCare car servicing voucher. The event runs from 10 am to 8 pm on both days and admission is free.

images.alt_text: HyperFocal: 0

site_title: Shenton House sale in private talks after S$590 million tender closes without bids
summary: The collective sale of Shenton House in Singapore's Central Business District has entered private treaty negotiations after its tender closed without bids. The 99-year leasehold building was put up for sale with a reserve price of S$590 million, and several interested buyers, including local and foreign developers, have expressed interest. The site is eligible for a 25% bonus gross floor area under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's CBD Incentive Scheme, allowing for a mixed-use or hotel development. Private treaty negotiations are ongoing, with no further updates provided.

images.alt_text: The six-storey building has a site area of 2,784 sq ft which is zoned for commercial use under the Urban Redevelopment Authority’s Master Plan.
It is understood that the 99-year leasehold commercial development at 6001 Beach Road has been valued at S$598 million.
Built in 1959, the 5-storey building on Lim Teck Kim Road currently has 5 commercial units on the ground floor and 20 residential units above.
Spanning 36,350 square feet (sq ft), the 99-year leasehold development along Shenton Way comprises 203 commercial units and a carpark.
Horizon Towers, which was relaunched for collective sale for the second time in February at an unchanged reserve price of S$1.1 billion, closed its tender on Mar 30 with no bids.

site_title: OpenAI to offer users up to US$20,000 for reporting bugs
summary: OpenAI is launching a bug bounty program, offering up to $20,000 to users who report vulnerabilities in its AI systems. The program, which went live on April 11, rewards users based on the severity of the bugs reported, starting from $200 per vulnerability. The move comes after ChatGPT was banned in Italy for a suspected breach of privacy rules, prompting regulators to study generative AI services more closely. This program aims to encourage programmers and ethical hackers to report bugs in OpenAI's systems, ensuring the accuracy and security of its AI models.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: SPH Media, Nikkei tie up on editorial, AI tech initiatives
summary: SPH Media and Nikkei have partnered on several initiatives, including editorial knowledge exchange, AI technology applications, and regional audience development. They have signed a memorandum of understanding, which includes regular exchanges of editorial personnel to share best practices and discuss digital transformation. SPH Media will explore AI technology on Nikkei's scoutAsia product, and the companies will implement joint initiatives utilizing their networks for events, marketing, and sales cooperation. The partnership aims to leverage both companies' AI technology utilization and digitalization expertise, particularly in Asean audiences.

images.alt_text: Nikkei & SPH Media explore strategic collaboration on newsroom exchange, new digital products
Neo served as chief commercial officer of Nikkei FT ScoutAsia Limited (Hong Kong) until the business was transferred to the parent company Nikkei Inc. earlier this year.

site_title: Asia likely to grow 5% faster than developed economies by year-end: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts Asia's economic growth will outpace developed countries' by 5% by year-end, driven by China's reopening, strong domestic demand, and less restrictive interest rates. This would be the strongest growth differential since 2017. The US and Europe's recent banking stress and aggressive rate hikes may weigh on domestic demand, but Asia's internal demand is expected to continue to support growth. China's reopening benefits the rest of the region, while other Asian economies like Japan, India, and Indonesia have their own driving factors.

images.alt_text: “The pace of price hikes is expected to slow towards the middle of this fiscal year due to government steps to curb energy prices and as the effects of companies passing on costs wane,” BOJ deputy governor Shinichi Uchida said.
Commuters walk on a platform after disembarking from a suburban train at a railway station in Mumbai, India, January 21, 2023. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni
Inflation in the Muslim-majority country typically rises during Ramadan, which this year started in late March, and leading up to the Eid al-Fitr celebrations.

site_title: Taiwan ruling party picks VP William Lai as presidential candidate
summary: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has nominated Vice-President William Lai as its candidate for the 2024 presidential elections. Lai, 63, has been outspoken on Taiwanese independence and has declared that "appeasement cannot buy peace." The nomination comes after China formally ended massive war games around Taiwan, and Lai is seen as a strong candidate to succeed incumbent Tsai Ing-wen, who is barred from running again. Lai's views on Taiwanese independence have been met with hostility from Beijing, adding to the pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Australia tells exporters to diversify from top trade partner China
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong urged exporters to diversify markets, particularly from top trade partner China, amid a thaw in their trade dispute. The two countries reached a consensus to end the dispute over barley, with Australia suspending a case at the World Trade Organization and China hastening a review of tariffs on Australian exports. Wong emphasized that while Australia values its strategic relationship with China, it cannot separate economic and strategic ties, and that diversifying export markets is crucial for national resilience. Trade worth A$285 billion annually continues between the two nations.

images.alt_text: In the latest sign of thawing tensions between the countries, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia would be temporarily suspending its complaint after China had agreed to review its barley tariffs.

site_title: Drone delivery startup gets approval in New Zealand. EU and Australia could be next
summary: A US startup, SkyDrop, has received approval from New Zealand's Civil Aviation Authority to operate drones over people and beyond the view of their operators, a key regulatory step for commercial drone delivery. The approval allows SkyDrop to fly drones up to 5 km with packages weighing up to 3.6 kg. This milestone could pave the way for broader commercial use of drones in the EU, Australia, and Canada. The company's drone has successfully delivered packages in the US and expects to expand its services in New Zealand to include restaurants, auto parts stores, and pharmacies.

images.alt_text: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg said the grants would “foster innovations that improve people’s day-to-day lives, making transportation safer, more reliable, more efficient, and more sustainable.”

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, will focus on maintaining medium-term price stability for sustained economic growth. The country's financial system is ready to provide liquidity during global stress, according to Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. Seventy percent of Asia-Pacific insurers have integrated ESG criteria into their investment strategies, and SPH Media and Nikkei have partnered on editorial and AI initiatives. The STI fell 0.4% on Wednesday, closing at 3,286.12 points, as Asian markets closed mixed. The collective sale of Shenton House has entered into private treaty negotiations after its tender closed without bids.

site_title: IMF spring meetings will be sanguine on the surface
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank spring meetings will take place in Washington, DC from April 10 to 16, focusing on the global economic outlook. While the outlook has improved, with greater resilience in the US and Europe, global growth is expected to be down relative to 2022, below 3% in 2023. Risks and unknowns abound, including the real economic impact of US rate hikes, concerns over commercial real estate lending, and persistent stubbornness in core inflation. The World Bank may take center stage, with a focus on global public goods and debt relief, but progress is uncertain.

images.alt_text: World Bank President David Malpass told a media briefing that the upward revision was due to an improved outlook for China’s recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns.
Gross domestic product will likely expand 2.8 per cent this year and 3 per cent next year, each 0.1 percentage point less than forecast in January.

Pakistan's talks with the IMF for a delayed US$1.1 billion loan tranche, part of US$6.5 billion bailout agreed in 2019, have dragged on and foreign exchange reserves have fallen to less than four weeks of imports.

site_title: Vietnam’s sustainable finance market gains steam as banks boost green lending
summary: Vietnam's banks have increased green lending efforts, with the Bank for Investment and Development of Vietnam (BIDV) launching a sustainable loan framework to boost green and sustainability-linked loans to $3 billion by 2025. The framework aims to design incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and startups, and involves large multilateral institutions such as the Asian Development Bank. This move follows other banks, like VPBank, introducing green loan frameworks, and comes as the demand for environmental financing in Vietnam has surged, driven by the government's commitment to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s largest pawnshop operator F88 Investment is under investigation after allegations surfaced that the company had used extortion methods in its debt collection activities.

site_title: Japan, Germany and the challenge of excess savings
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan governor, Kazuo Ueda, has reaffirmed the country's ultra-loose monetary policies, citing the need to manage chronic excess savings. The private sector's savings rate has averaged 29% of GDP since 2010, while corporate retained profits have exceeded 20% of GDP annually. To address this structural issue, policymakers have employed negative interest rates, yield curve control, and increased government investment. Alternative approaches, such as Germany's net foreign asset acquisition, are deemed unfeasible due to trade tensions and currency pressures. Instead, Japan's economy is left to "pick up the pieces," with policymakers relying on monetary and fiscal policies to manage the excess savings.

images.alt_text: “As a result of appropriate policy from both the BOJ and the government we’re now in a situation where we’re not in a state of deflation,” Ueda told reporters in Tokyo on Monday (Apr 10) after meeting with Kishida at the prime minister’s office.
Ueda has the chance to drop hints of any intention to shift policy at his inaugural press briefing expected later on Monday.
With inflation in Japan exceeding the central bank's 2 per cent target, the outlook for the economy and wages will be key to how soon the Bank of Japan could phase out its massive stimulus programme.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower as geopolitical tensions weigh, US CPI in focus
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.9% on April 12 as heightened Sino-US tensions weighed on sentiment, while investors await the US consumer price index (CPI) release. China shares were mixed, with the CSI300 Index down 0.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.4%. Geopolitical tensions, including China's naval exercises around Taiwan, continue to influence investment decisions, with tech stocks slumping 1.9% and AI-related themes driving gains. Investors also await the US CPI, which may impact the Federal Reserve's monetary policy path.

site_title: Hong Kong shared office firm sees leases surge on China demand
summary: Mainland Chinese companies are driving demand for upscale shared office space in Hong Kong's Central business district, with The Executive Centre seeing a fivefold increase in new leases in March. About 70% of new tenants were Chinese companies, led by online travel agency Tongcheng Travel Holdings. The removal of pandemic restrictions has sparked interest from north of the border, with emerging industries like technology and media setting up in Hong Kong. This trend is expected to continue, with flexible workspace landlords adapting to the changing needs of businesses.

site_title: OK Lim’s lawyer questions prosecution witness’ recollection of 2 key transactions in cheating, forgery charges
summary: Singapore's former oil tycoon OK Lim is on trial for cheating and forgery charges, with prosecutors alleging he misrepresented transactions to HSBC to secure $111.68 million in funding. The trial's second day saw Lim's defense counsel question the recollection of HSBC's senior vice-president, Chua Pei Pei, regarding two key transactions. Chua initially testified to a phone conversation on March 19, 2020, but later admitted her recollection had changed. The defense is casting doubt on the prosecution's case, with the trial set to continue over several dates in April, May, and June.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Singapore's fallen oil legend Lim Oon Kuin or OK Lim, as he is better known, arrives in the State Courts on Apr 11.

site_title: Residential plots at Lentor Central, Lentor Gardens for sale under H1 GLS programme
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority has launched residential plots at Lentor Central and Lentor Gardens under the H1 2023 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme. Lentor Central, a 14,703.2 sq m site, is expected to yield 475 homes, while Lentor Gardens, a 20,640.8 sq m site, is expected to yield 500 units. However, industry watchers expect weak developer interest due to a potential glut of condo projects in the area, with some predicting only one or two bids for the Lentor Central site.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Lentor Modern is the largest private non-landed residential launch in 2022, said Huttons Asia.
GuocoLand-Hong Leong Holdings tie-up is sole bidder for Lentor Gardens site at URA tender
The 14 residential projects will supply some 5,300 private homes in Q1 2023, said Huttons senior research director Lee Sze Teck.

site_title: High Philippine inflation dents Marcos’ approval ratings
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s approval ratings decreased to 78% in March, down from 82% in November, due to public dissatisfaction over inflation. The Pulse Asia survey found 63% of respondents considered controlling costs of living a top concern. 52% disapproved of the government's handling of inflation, while 25% approved. Marcos remains popular, with 80% of respondents trusting him, and 61% approving of his government's defense of the country's territory.

images.alt_text: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) has raised its benchmark interest rate by a total 425 basis points since May last year to 6.25 per cent.

site_title: Bytedance moves into iconic Hong Kong tower as banks depart
summary: ByteDance, the world's most valuable tech startup, has rented 20,000 square feet of space in International Finance Centre in Hong Kong, valued at $20.36 per square foot. This move comes as foreign banks scale back to trim costs, with firms like BNP Paribas and Julius Baer Group giving up space in the tower. ByteDance's expansion aims to establish a presence in the Asian finance hub, a favored place for Chinese tech listings, amid regulatory scrutiny. The company's revenue surged 30% to over $80 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: The International Finance Centre in Hong Kong. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg
ByteDance’s profit last year came despite mounting losses at fast-growing TikTok.
Tencent had long been upset over how some Douyin users would create short videos using copyrighted material in long videos without obtaining approval.

ByteDance's pace of expansion underscores the resilience of its business at a time Washington is threatening to join India in banning TikTok, which a growing a number of government agencies across the world are wiping from official phones.

site_title: Manulife US Reit divests Oregon property for US$33.5 million; still in talks with Mirae for sale of manager
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Manulife US Reit) has divested its Oregon property, Tanasbourne, to John Hancock Life Insurance Company for US$33.5 million. The sale is part of Manulife US Reit's efforts to lower its leverage, which stood at 48.8% as of December 2022. The Reit continues to explore asset sales despite near-term challenges in the US market due to limited credit availability. Manulife US Reit's manager is still in talks with Mirae for the potential sale of the manager.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit's properties could continue to be marked down with rising interest rates, slowing US economic growth and a continuation of hybrid work arrangements

“We're more engaged with our sponsor right now than we ever have been. They're really in the trenches with us at the moment,” said Tripp Gantt, CEO of the Reit manager, at Manulife US Reit's last earnings call on Feb 9.
Manulife US Real Estate Management, had received “multiple queries” on Monday following news of US regional banks’ troubles.

site_title: HSBC hires Silicon Valley Bank bankers to focus on tech, healthcare
summary: HSBC has hired over 40 Silicon Valley Bank bankers, led by David Sabow, to establish a dedicated banking practice focused on technology and healthcare. The new practice will be within HSBC's US commercial banking business, with key hires including Sunita Patel, Katherine Andersen, and Melissa Stepanis. The move aims to serve companies in these sectors and investors who support them. HSBC acquired the UK arm of Silicon Valley Bank last month for a symbolic one pound, rescuing a key lender for technology start-ups in Britain.

images.alt_text: Mark Tucker told shareholders a restructuring or spin-off of its Asia business would create a major period of uncertainty for clients, and employees and shareholders would be disrupted.
Pedestrians walk past the logo for HSBC outside a local branch bank in Hong Kong on August 2, 2021. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: Elon Musk says Twitter is roughly breaking even
summary: Elon Musk stated that Twitter is "roughly breaking even" in an interview with BBC, citing a decline in employees from 8,000 to 1,500 and a return of most advertisers. Despite recent outages and a negative cash flow situation of $3 billion, Musk believes the company can become cash-flow positive this quarter if things go well. Twitter has seen a significant decline in advertising since Musk's acquisition, but has seen an increase in user numbers. Musk has no plans to step down as CEO and has not mentioned a successor.

images.alt_text: It’s unclear what the change means for Twitter, which has seen a sweeping overhaul since Musk bought the company for US$44 billion last year.
Elon Musk's fledgling AI project at Twitter was said in the Insider report to involve training a language model to create written content.
Elon Musk terminated former CEO Parag Agrawal, Vijaya Gadde and Ned Segal from their posts in late October after closing his contentious US$44 billion takeover of Twitter.

site_title: Thai economy gradually recovering; inflation poses risk: central bank
summary: Thailand's economy is gradually recovering, with tourism expected to drive growth. The Bank of Thailand reported inflation at a 15-month low of 2.83% in March, returning to its target range. The central bank will continue to monitor inflation and adjust policies as needed, maintaining a target of 28 million tourist arrivals for 2023. Despite a strong rebound in tourism, core inflation is expected to remain high, prompting the central bank to hike interest rates and implement measured policy normalization.

images.alt_text: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, the youngest child of exiled former premier Thaksin Shinawatra and niece of Yingluck, is one of the favourites to be PM.

site_title: China will support Sri Lanka’s debt rework, Weerasinghe says
summary: Sri Lanka expects China to support its debt restructuring efforts, according to central bank governor Nandalal Weerasinghe. The country aims to complete negotiations with creditors, including China, and begin repaying its obligations. The IMF has approved a $3 billion loan to help Sri Lanka recover from its economic crisis. Weerasinghe stated that completing the debt restructuring process is in the best interest for both Sri Lanka and China, and the country will unveil its restructuring blueprint by end-April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past the main entrance of the Sri Lanka's Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka March 24, 2017. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo
A general view of the main business district as rain clouds gather above in Colombo, Sri Lanka, November 17, 2020. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte
Supporters of President Ranil Wickremesinghe light firecrackers after the IMF's approval of a US$3 billion bailout package.

site_title: US proposes 56% vehicle emissions cut by 2032, requiring big EV jump
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed a sweeping emissions reduction plan for new cars and trucks through 2032, requiring 13% annual average pollution cuts. The plan, if finalized, could mean two-thirds of new vehicles sold will be electric by 2032, with automakers forecast to produce 60% EVs by 2030 and 67% by 2032. The proposal is more ambitious than President Biden's 2021 goal of 50% EVs by 2030 and aims to cut over 9 billion tons of CO2 emissions through 2055, with estimated net benefits ranging from $850 billion to $1.6 trillion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: New Lexus automobiles are shown for sale after California Governor Gavin Newsom announced the state will ban the sale of new gasoline powered passenger cars and trucks starting in 2035 in a dramatic move to shift to electric vehicles to curtail greenhouse gas emissions, in Carlsbad, California, U.S., September 23, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
The auto standards are designed to cap pollution allowed per mile, encouraging the sale of electric vehicles that do not produce tailpipe emissions.

site_title: From Patek to Oris, big Swiss watch brands see slowdown after boom
summary: Big Swiss watch brands like Patek Philippe and Oris are seeing a slowdown in demand after an unprecedented industry boom during the pandemic. Despite this, luxury watchmakers still face challenges due to supply constraints and anticipation of new models. Oris reported softer retailer orders, while Patek Philippe's chairman noted that the market is slowing down but not severely. The luxury watch sector may be cooling as consumers become more cautious, with European countries experiencing a more challenging market.

images.alt_text: Millennials (born between 1980 and the late 1990s) and Generation Z (born between 1997 and 2010) are taking an early interest in luxury goods, according to a study by management consultants Bain company and the Italian luxury brands association Altagamma Foundation.
With China reopening, many financial analysts have sharply raised their growth forecasts for the luxury sector as a whole in 2023.

site_title: Vietnamese education startup MindX bags US$15 million in Series B funding
summary: Vietnamese education startup MindX has secured US$15 million in Series B funding led by Kaizenvest, with other investors including Aksorn, Mynavi, and Wavemaker Partners. The funding will be used to develop its products and services, as well as connect Vietnamese tech talents with employers globally. MindX, which was founded in 2015, has already graduated over 35,000 students and partnered with over 200 companies in several countries. The investment comes a year after its Series A funding round.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Singapore shares edge down at open after Wall Street ends mixed; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.1% to 3,293.80 at the open, following a mixed Wall Street close and a one-month high for European shares. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 42, with Sembcorp Marine and Samudera Shipping leading the gains, while banking stocks, including DBS and OCBC, declined. The mixed market sentiment was attributed to investors watching inflation data for its impact on central bank decisions.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Muted trading for Singapore stocks as caution reigns ahead of key data; STI up 0.1%

site_title: A large voucher rollout to spur China’s consumption
summary: China plans to issue 300 billion yuan (S$58 billion) in consumption vouchers to boost domestic spending, aiming to raise consumption by up to 1 trillion yuan. This measure, aimed at addressing challenges such as youth unemployment and shaky consumer confidence, is expected to have a multiplier effect, stimulating economic growth through increased spending and employment. The vouchers are seen as a feasible stimulus to spur domestic spending, with the potential to boost China's 2023 GDP growth by 0.62 percentage points.

images.alt_text: The city is looking to kickstart its economy as it sees rising competition from Singapore to be Asia’s top destination for business, talent and capital.
Top policymakers want to work towards harvesting the consumer power of China’s 1.4 billion people, after economic growth in 2022 slumped to one of its weakest levels in nearly half a century.
An index measuring construction activity surged in March to its highest level in more than a decade.

site_title: Metalpha raising US$100 million fund to woo Chinese Bitcoin buyers
summary: Metalpha Technology Holding, a licensed digital asset wealth manager based in Hong Kong, is raising a US$100 million fund to invest in Bitcoin and other crypto products, targeting Chinese investors seeking a regulated channel to access the Web3 space. The firm secured US$20 million since March and plans to provide a compliant way for Asian investors from traditional finance backgrounds to access the crypto market. Metalpha believes interest in crypto is returning after the FTX collapse and sees its regulator-compliant offering as a key selling point.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is planning to roll out a revamped virtual asset exchanges framework as of Jun 1 that allows exchange operators to open to retail investors.
The session will be held jointly by the HKMA and the SFC, the two regulators overseeing stablecoins and crypto exchanges.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to start transaction banking operations in Japan
summary: Goldman Sachs is launching transaction banking services in Japan through its Tokyo branch, marking the first country in Asia where the firm offers this service. The US bank's banking arm gained a license in 2021 for corporate cash management operations and has since expanded to the UK, Germany, and the Netherlands. The platform provides global companies in Japan with treasury services, including cash management and cross-border payments, to help them manage accounts efficiently. This expansion aims to generate stable revenue streams for Goldman Sachs.

site_title: China, World Bank exploring solutions to debt-distress deadlock
summary: China and the World Bank are exploring a potential compromise on restructuring debt held by poor nations, which has been stuck due to disagreements over how to treat various forms of debt. The proposal would see the World Bank provide low-interest loans and grants to countries on the verge of default, in exchange for China dropping its demand for a "haircut" or loss on what's owed. The talks, which began in Washington, aim to end the deadlock and unlock desperately needed aid for countries facing debt distress, with over 70 nations facing a collective $326 billion burden.

images.alt_text: The central bank on Apr 4 held its benchmark rate at a two-decade high of 16.5 per cent in order to keep Asia’s fastest inflation in check while supporting economic recovery.
Gross domestic product will likely expand 2.8 per cent this year and 3 per cent next year, each 0.1 percentage point less than forecast in January.
Several small and mid-sized banks in China have lowered their deposit rates, a move that could help ease costs as loan growth faces more pressure amid rising economic risks.
World Bank President David Malpass told a media briefing that the upward revision was due to an improved outlook for China’s recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Lula to visit Huawei site in Shanghai, potentially irking US
summary: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva plans to visit Huawei's innovation centre in Shanghai, China, on April 13, following an invitation from the company. The trip may irk the US, which has accused Huawei of posing a threat to national security. Lula's visit to China, after meeting with US President Joe Biden, aims to strengthen ties with Brazil's largest trading partners. The trip is seen as a message that Brazil won't take sides in the US-China tech dispute, and Lula will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on April 14.

site_title: Fed’s Kashkari says recession possible, but high inflation would be worse
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari warned that a recession could occur due to the Fed's interest-rate hikes and tightened credit conditions, but high inflation would be worse for the labor market. He expects inflation to reach "the mid threes" by the end of the year, still above the Fed's 2% target, and believes the Fed needs to bring inflation down to protect job prospects. A yield curve inversion, a sign often associated with a recession, is currently present, but Kashkari remains cautious about inflation falling quickly.

site_title: Binance.US to delist digital asset tokens Tron, Spell
summary: Binance.US will delist Tron and Spell digital asset tokens on April 18, closing trading and deposits but allowing withdrawals. The move follows a periodic review by Binance, considering factors such as trading volume and liquidity. Tron's price fell nearly 5% and Spell's price dropped more than 5% after the announcement. Justin Sun, Tron's founder, downplayed the impact, citing low trading volume on Binance.US. The delisting comes amid ongoing regulatory scrutiny, with the US SEC accusing Sun of fraud last month.

images.alt_text: Previously, the deposits were sent to either Signature Bank or Silvergate Capital, both seen as crypto-friendly banks.
Bloomberg News reported in November that Sun allegedly paid about US$1 billion through a Hong Kong-based asset manager for a controlling stake in Huobi.

site_title: Liberty House at 51 Club Street being sold for S$92.2 million
summary: Liberty House, a five-storey corner office building in Singapore's central business district, is being sold for S$92.2 million to Union Property Holding, a Singapore incorporated company owned by a Chinese permanent resident. The property, with a gross floor area of 28,876 sq ft, has premium office specifications and a private parking facility. It is located near several MRT stations and has a 999-year leasehold plot. The sale price works out to S$3,193 per square foot, according to CBRE.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The five-storey commercial building has a 999-year tenure and was extensively refurbished in 2011.

site_title: A fresh take on traditional medicated oil
summary: Tai Tong Ah Company, a traditional Chinese medicine manufacturer, has collaborated with Senses International to develop YnL, a range of botanic aromatherapy medicated oils. The product combines fragrances such as magnolia, bergamot, and lime with medicated oil, targeting a younger demographic. The range has been launched in Singapore and is set to be exported to Hong Kong, Cambodia, the Philippines, and Qatar. Enterprise Singapore's Centre of Innovation for Complementary Health Products provided technical analysis and support, while an external consultant was brought in for branding and marketing. The product has received positive feedback and plans are underway to expand the YnL range.

images.alt_text: Networking opportunities from the consortium leaders allowed Environsens to pitch its solutions and secure multiple water filtration projects with state governments there, said chief executive Shailesh Kharkwal.

site_title: Banking sector stress: 5 key wake-up calls for investors
summary: The US banking sector is facing stress due to recessionary risks, tighter credit conditions, and a higher-rate regime, prompting investors to reassess their portfolios. Central banks have intervened with liquidity measures to calm the markets. Key takeaways include: 1) investors expect the Fed to cut rates and reverse quantitative tightening, 2) beware weak links and US debt ceiling risks, 3) portfolio diversification and resilience are crucial, 4) liquidity ebbs can lead to volatility and vulnerabilities, and 5) quality companies with strong cash flows and balance sheets are likely to benefit.

images.alt_text: World Bank President David Malpass told a media briefing that the upward revision was due to an improved outlook for China’s recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Japan proposes industrial hub in Bangladesh with supply chains to India
summary: Japan has proposed developing an industrial hub in Bangladesh with supply chains to India's northeastern states, Nepal, and Bhutan. The plan includes a deep-sea port in Matarbari, which is expected to be operational by 2027. The project, valued at $1.27 billion, aims to boost development in the impoverished region of 300 million people. The initiative is seen as a win-win for both India and Bangladesh, with the potential to increase trade and attract foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Kishida also said Japan wanted Russia’s invasion of Ukraine to end as soon as possible and called on the “Global South”, a broad term referring to countries in Africa, Asia, Oceania and Latin America, to “show solidarity” after his talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Lian Beng, USP
summary: Manulife US Reit has divested its Hillsboro, Oregon property for $33.5 million. The Reit's shares fell 12.3% to $0.172 after the announcement. Lian Beng Group's Ong family made a voluntary offer to take the company private at S$0.62 per share, below the group's net asset value. USP Group received a notice of compliance from the Singapore Exchange after failing to audit its financial statements. Trading halted for Beng Kuang Marine pending an announcement.

site_title: Michael Jordan sneakers sold for record-setting US$2.2 million
summary: A pair of Michael Jordan's Air Jordan 13s from his 'Last Dance' season sold for a record-setting US$2.2 million at Sotheby's, becoming the most expensive sneakers known to have sold. The final pair of Air Jordan XIII Breds, worn by Jordan in game two of the 1998 NBA Finals, exceeded the estimated US$2 million to US$4 million price range. This sale surpasses previous sneaker records, including a US$1.8 million private sale of Nike Air Yeezy 1 sneakers and a US$1.5 million public auction sale of Michael Jordan's game-worn Nike Air Ships.

site_title: Biden’s EV-boosting emission rule will save US$1.6 trillion
summary: The Biden administration's proposed emission rule for cars and light trucks aims to cap pollution per mile, encouraging electric vehicle sales. The plan, set to be unveiled in 2027, is forecast to generate up to $1.6 trillion in savings through 2055, including $4,000 in consumer savings and $850 billion in fuel savings. The standards, expected to be the toughest in US history, will drive consumer benefits, public health, and climate change mitigation, compelling two-thirds of new US car sales to be electric models by 2032.

site_title: New consumer CEOs are about to clean up
summary: The consumer goods sector is experiencing its largest management shake-up in decades, with numerous leadership changes at major brands. Unilever's new CEO, Hein Schumacher, is seen as the best candidate to create value, having simplified the company's structure and improving its underperformance. Meanwhile, Reckitt Benckiser is searching for a replacement after its outgoing CEO quit to join Starbucks. Other companies, such as Diageo and Carlsberg, are also undergoing changes, but Schumacher's appointment at Unilever looks most promising. The shake-up could lead to potential breakups or significant strategic moves, but Nestle's stability under CEO Mark Schneider provides a contrast to the sector's turmoil.

images.alt_text: Unilever reported on Thursday that full-year underlying sales in China fell 1 per cent as people stayed home.
Laxman Narasimhan will take over Howard Schultz (pictured) as Starbucks CEO on April 1, 2023.
Nestle said it targeted organic sales growth – which cuts out the impact of currency moves and acquisitions – in a range of 6-8 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong’s ZA Bank offers crypto conversions, accounts in city’s push
summary: Hong Kong's ZA Bank, a virtual bank, is expanding its services to include crypto conversions and accounts for the city's digital asset sector. As of June 1, licensed exchanges will be able to open to retail investors, allowing for token-to-fiat currency conversions and withdrawals in Hong Kong, China, and US currencies. This move aims to revive Hong Kong's status as a financial center, overcoming access to banking hurdles. ZA Bank has already partnered with two licensed exchanges and plans to provide services to other exchanges as they become licensed, despite traditional banks' reluctance due to strict know-your-customer and anti-money laundering rules.

images.alt_text: The session will be held jointly by the HKMA and the SFC, the two regulators overseeing stablecoins and crypto exchanges.

Global crypto firms scrambled to move funds away after the US banking crisis, with local companies such as crypto hedge fund MaiCapital — which held funds with Signature — urgently sought to open bank accounts in Hong Kong.

site_title: Twitter company ‘no longer exists’, is now part of Musk’s X
summary: Elon Musk's X, a newly formed shell firm, has merged with Twitter, effectively making the social media platform "no longer exist". The move is part of Musk's vision to create an "everything app" similar to China's WeChat, owned by Tencent Holdings. The merged entity is now under Musk's control, with him serving as president of both X and its parent, X Holdings. The implications of this change are unclear, with some analysts expressing concerns about the potential integration of Twitter's services with Musk's other companies, including Tesla.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the Twitter logo at its corporate headquarters in San Francisco, California, U.S. November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
Elon Musk's fledgling AI project at Twitter was said in the Insider report to involve training a language model to create written content.
Elon Musk terminated former CEO Parag Agrawal, Vijaya Gadde and Ned Segal from their posts in late October after closing his contentious US$44 billion takeover of Twitter.
Twitter had previously announced that from Apr 1 several accounts will lose the check marks as the social media company begins winding down its legacy verified programme.

site_title: EY halts plan to split audit, advisory firms
summary: British financial services giant EY has halted its plan to split its audit and advisory units, dubbed "Project Everest", after opposition from its US branch. The decision comes after a vote on a country-by-country basis was delayed on several occasions. EY's global executive said the split faced challenges, including giving both organisations the capabilities to compete effectively in the market, and that more time was needed to make necessary investments. The company remains committed to creating two world-class organisations that advance audit quality, independence, and client choice.

images.alt_text: Focus is now on the release of inflation figures later this week, which will play a crucial role in the Fed’s decision-making when it meets early next month.

site_title: Judge says Fox News has ‘credibility problem’ after Murdoch disclosure
summary: A US judge has stated that Fox News has a "credibility problem" as it prepares for a $1.6 billion defamation trial over false election-rigging claims. The trial centers on Dominion Voting Systems' allegations that Fox knowingly aired false claims that Dominion machines were used to flip the 2020 US presidential election. The judge criticized Fox for disclosing Rupert Murdoch's role as an officer of the company for the first time in nearly two years, just days before the trial. Murdoch is expected to testify and defend the network's coverage.

images.alt_text: During his deposition in a US$1.6 billion defamation case, Murdoch said the journalist in him liked “to be involved” in news stories. He meant it.
Documents in the case in Delaware state court show Rupert Murdoch and other Fox executives believed Joe Biden fairly beat Donald Trump and that the results were not in doubt.

site_title: Big banks that shored up First Republic pushed to boost reserves
summary: The US' largest banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, Citigroup, and Bank of America, are setting aside $100 million each in reserves as part of their efforts to shore up First Republic Bank, which saw 90% of its market cap evaporate after its stock collapsed last month. The move aims to demonstrate confidence in the banking system and acknowledges that depositing money with First Republic for 120 days was not risk-free. The provision will have minimal impact on the lenders' earnings.

images.alt_text: Fitch Ratings lowered First Republic Bank’s long-term issuer default rating to ‘B’ from ‘BB’, citing its new more costly funding profile.
First Republic last week staved off a potential collapse after 11 of the biggest US banks agreed to park a combined US$30 billion in deposits with the California lender.
First Republic has lost more than 80 per cent of its stock market value this year as customers pulled their money.

site_title: Investing lessons from Credit Suisse and Hyflux
summary: Many investors in Credit Suisse's AT1 bonds failed to read the issue documents, unaware of write-down clauses that ultimately led to the bank's bailout. This lack of due diligence is a recurring issue in the financial markets, as seen in the bankruptcy of water treatment firm Hyflux. Investors, even those considered sophisticated, often fail to thoroughly review product details before investing, highlighting the need for rigorous due diligence to mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: Hyflux announced the Tuaspring project in 2011, and issued S$400 million worth of preference shares that year
Lawyers advised investors to read the fine print in bond instruments carefully before buying.

site_title: IMF trims world growth outlook as financial risks raise pressure
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has trimmed its global-growth projections, predicting 2.8% expansion in 2023 and 3% in 2024, down 0.1 percentage points from its January forecast. The downgrade is due to high financial risks, tighter monetary policy, and the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war. The IMF warns of high uncertainty and risks, particularly in a scenario where financial instability worsens, potentially slowing growth to 2.5% in 2023.

images.alt_text: World Bank President David Malpass told a media briefing that the upward revision was due to an improved outlook for China’s recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Blackstone raises more than US$30 billion for giant real estate fund
summary: Blackstone has raised over $30 billion for its largest global property drawdown fund, Blackstone Real Estate Partners X. The fund, which started in 1991, now has $326 billion of investor capital under management. This is the largest of its kind, according to PitchBook data. The real estate market has faced pressure due to high borrowing costs and uncertainty, but Blackstone's latest fund aims to capitalize on opportunistic deals across sectors such as rental housing, hospitality, and data centers. The fund's closing marks a significant milestone for the company.

images.alt_text: Blackstone and many of its rivals are flush with cash to invest from pensions, endowments and insurers.
Growth slowed last year as rising interest rates undercut real estate values and the tide of investor inflows reversed into a torrent of redemption requests.

site_title: Gold ticks higher in run-up to US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,005.18 per ounce, driven by a weaker dollar and anticipation of US inflation data later in the day. Investors are monitoring the Federal Reserve's rate-hike path, with markets pricing in a 68.9% chance of a 25 basis-point hike next month. Despite gold's inflation-hedge appeal, rising interest rates reduce its appeal. The US consumer price index data is expected to provide clues on the Fed's interest rate path, with Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker suggesting rates should exceed 5%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars are seen at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo
The opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion rises when interest rates are increased to bring down inflation.

site_title: Australian economy not immune to global slowdown: treasurer
summary: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers stated the country's economy is expected to slow considerably later this year, but a recession is not anticipated. The Reserve Bank of Australia and the Treasury share this expectation, despite the global economy facing a slowdown due to higher interest rates. The International Monetary Fund has trimmed its global growth outlook, warning of a severe flare-up of financial system turmoil that could lead to near recessionary levels.

images.alt_text: In the latest sign of thawing tensions between the countries, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia would be temporarily suspending its complaint after China had agreed to review its barley tariffs.
Confidence is still 10.4 per cent below the level in April 2022, the month before the RBA began raising rates.

site_title: US dollar dips as European markets return from break
summary: The US dollar declined against the euro and pound on Tuesday, following a long Easter weekend, as traders focused on US inflation data due on Wednesday for signs of how close US rates are to peaking. The euro rose 0.52% to US$1.0918, while the pound rose 0.52% to US$1.2439. The US dollar also fell against the Japanese yen, dropping 0.4% to 133.03, amid expectations that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates again in May.

images.alt_text: The greenback is up 1 per cent against the yen at 133.45, the highest since Apr 3.

site_title: Walmart halves Chicago stores to just four as losses mount
summary: Walmart is closing four stores in Chicago, halving its footprint in the city after years of mounting losses. The four stores, including three Neighborhood Market formats and one Supercenter, will close by April 16. Despite investing $70 million in store upgrades and localizing merchandise, Walmart attributed the closures to the challenges of replicating suburban Supercenter success in urban areas, particularly in the face of tough competition from other retailers. This marks a retreat for the nation's largest retailer as it seeks to adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Walmart’s plan comes as US President Joe Biden has committed to building a network of 500,000 public EV chargers by 2030.
Walmart, which operates more than 5,000 US stores, did not immediately respond to questions about whether the moves will result in any near-term layoffs.

site_title: Regulation a key aspect of the prosperity of Singapore’s banks and their top executives
summary: Singapore's top bank executives, including DBS' Piyush Gupta and OCBC's Wee Ee Cheong, received significant pay packages in 2022, with Gupta receiving S$15.4 million and Wee Ee Cheong S$14.2 million. These figures are 13.3% and 30.2% higher than the previous year, respectively. The high pay packages are seen as a reflection of the banks' prosperity and the importance of regulation in maintaining stability in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

UOB chief executive officer Wee Ee Cheong's annual remuneration is made up of a base pay of S$1.2 million, a bonus of S$13 million, as well as benefits-in-kind and other transport-related benefits amounting to S$37,577.
DBS group CEO Piyush Gupta's pay comprises a salary base of S$1.5 million, a cash bonus of S$5.8 million, about S$8 million in deferred remuneration, and a non-cash component amounting to S$80,529.
Helen Wong’s salary in FY2021 has been reported at S$7.6 million, after she was appointed the group CEO on Apr 15, 2021.
From left to right: Tony Tan, CEO of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial T

site_title: Renminbi becoming anchor currency in commodity trading, investments: market watchers
summary: China's renminbi is gaining ground as a settlement currency for select commodities, potentially becoming an anchor currency in commodities trading. Cross-border payments in yuan rose to 18% of China's total value of goods traded in 2022. China National Offshore Oil Corp and France completed the country's first yuan-settled trade in liquefied natural gas in March. Market watchers expect commodities like gold and copper to be traded in renminbi next, driven by growing demand and geopolitical tensions. This trend is expected to continue, solidifying renminbi's position in global trade.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Banks from Goldman Sachs to RBC Capital Markets raised their oil-price forecasts immediately after the Opec+ cut.

FILE PHOTO: The OPEC logo pictured ahead of an informal meeting between members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in Algiers, Algeria, September 28, 2016. REUTERS/Ramzi Boudina/File Photo
Miner BHP expects the world to need twice the amount of copper by 2030 than what is produced this year.

site_title: China chemical groups seek Beijing nod for US$10 billion Indonesia refinery: sources
summary: China's Tongkun Group and Xinfengming Group are seeking Beijing's approval to build a $10 billion refinery and petrochemical complex in Indonesia's North Kalimantan province. The project, which includes a 200,000 barrels-per-day refinery and an 800,000 tonne per year ethylene unit, aims to produce feedstocks for chemical fibre. The move comes as China ramps up investments in Southeast Asia under President Xi Jinping's Belt and Road Initiative, despite limiting approvals for new domestic refineries to cut carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: Aramco said on Monday it had agreed to acquire a 10 per cent stake in privately controlled Rongsheng Petrochemical for about US$3.6 billion.

site_title: UK to see worst economic performance among G7 peers in 2023: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has forecast that the UK economy will experience the worst performance among G7 peers in 2023, with a 0.3% decline in output and a 0.7% increase in 2024 compared to 2022. The UK is expected to see a one-percentage-point rise in the jobless rate to 4.7% in 2024, with unemployment levels expected to rise due to double-digit inflation and the government's efforts to restore fiscal credibility.

images.alt_text: A company offering early-finish Fridays signals that they are flexible in their attitude to working hours and care about their employees’ well-being – two factors of utmost importance in today’s jobs market.
The construction PMI’s slowdown has been driven by a fourth consecutive monthly fall in house-building, which declined at the fastest rate since May 2020.

site_title: ‘Unidentified persons’ board Singapore-registered oil tanker off the Ivory coast; one Singaporean on vessel
summary: Unidentified persons boarded a Singapore-registered oil tanker, the Success 9, approximately 300 nautical miles off the Abidjan Coast, Côte d'Ivoire, on April 10. One Singaporean crew member is on board, with 19 other crew members of various nationalities. Authorities, including the Maritime and Port Authority, the shipowner, and rescue coordination centers, are working together to monitor the situation and assist.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Credit Suisse job cuts must be frozen, union says
summary: Credit Suisse and UBS, following their emergency merger, are facing opposition from the Swiss Bank Employees' Association (SBPV) to freeze planned job cuts. The union, representing 6,000 workers, is urging lawmakers to consider the staff affected by Credit Suisse's collapse and halt any job losses until the end of 2023. The Swiss parliament is set to discuss the rescue of Credit Suisse, with some reports suggesting a 20-30% workforce reduction, including 11,000 job cuts in Switzerland.

images.alt_text: Karin Keller-Sutter says that the government had acted in the country’s best interests in swiftly arranging the takeover of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank by its larger domestic rival UBS.
The banking system will reach that point with “monitoring, changing a few things,” JPMorgan Chase chief executive officer Jamie Dimon said.

site_title: US begins study of possible rules to regulate AI like ChatGPT
summary: The US government has initiated a public comment period on potential rules to regulate artificial intelligence (AI) systems, particularly those like ChatGPT, which has gained widespread attention for its capabilities. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration is seeking input on accountability measures to address concerns over AI's impact on national security and education. This move comes as ChatGPT has grown to have over 100 million monthly active users, making it the fastest-growing consumer application in history. The Biden administration aims to establish an "accountability mechanism" for AI systems.

images.alt_text: Chatbots in China mostly focus on social interactions whereas ChatGPT, which learns from vast amounts of data how to answer prompts by users in a human-like manner, performs better at more professional tasks.

site_title: Malaysia lists Sulu heir as a terrorist in claim over Sabah
summary: Malaysia has classified Muhammad Fuad Abdullah Kiram, a self-styled descendant of the Sulu sultanate, as a terrorist to safeguard national sovereignty amid a territorial dispute over Sabah. The move comes after the Sulu group secured a RM62.59 billion (S$18.8 billion) award against Malaysia in 2022. Kiram is one of eight members claiming to be the heirs of the Sulu sultan. The classification is under the country's anti-money laundering and terrorism laws, aiming to protect Malaysia's territorial claims.

site_title: Credit Suisse takeover will turn UBS into wealth management ‘powerhouse,’ JPMorgan says
summary: JPMorgan analysts say UBS's acquisition of Credit Suisse for $3.3 billion will turn it into a wealth management "powerhouse" with an attractive business model. The deal is considered "attractive" despite potential losses and costs. UBS is expected to generate $7 billion in wealth-management pre-tax profit by 2027. However, job cuts at Credit Suisse's Swiss operations could be delayed if they become a "political issue."

images.alt_text: Swiss Federal President Alain Berset at the extraordinary session of the Federal Assembly convened to debate the government's decisions to rescue Credit Suisse and its takeover by UBS.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as markets try to shrug off downturn fears
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.3% to 33,684.79 and the S&P 500 remaining flat at 4,108.94. Investors are awaiting inflation data this week, which may influence central bank decisions. The International Monetary Fund trimmed its global growth forecast, and a Federal Reserve official cautioned against raising interest rates too aggressively. Analysts believe lower global growth is already priced into markets, with some predicting a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: China’s weak inflation fuels calls for more policy stimulus
summary: China's consumer inflation slowed to 0.7% in March, down from 1% in February, missing economists' expectations. Producer prices contracted 2.5% in March, following a 1.4% decline in the previous month.
