site_title: India's Tata Motors hits 7-month high on strong Q4 JLR sales
summary: Tata Motors' shares rose 8.15% to a seven-month high after Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) reported strong fourth-quarter sales, with wholesale volumes up 24% and retail sales growing 30%. JLR forecast free cash flow of about $1 billion, contributing nearly 60% of Tata Motors' revenue. Analysts lifted their target price on Tata Motors' stock to 550 rupees, citing improving volume outlook and margin potential.

images.alt_text: The global semiconductor shortage has undermined Jaguar Land Rover’s turnaround as it struggles to work through a debt reduction plan.
Improving semiconductor supplies and rising demand have helped Tata’s luxury car unit, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), turn profitable.
The fresh capital could help online platform Tata Neu, which went live last April, to strengthen its digital offerings, fix technical glitches and meet any new spending needs

site_title: Rising demands make it harder to lean on learn-on-the-go sustainability chiefs
summary: Singapore's largest companies have appointed chief sustainability officers (CSOs) with varying levels of experience, with only 13 holding sustainability-related roles when hired. Despite a lack of qualified candidates, companies often prioritize internal candidates over external hires, potentially hindering the effectiveness of the CSO role. Research suggests that the issue may be a result of poor hiring practices rather than a shortage of qualified candidates, with the sustainability field becoming more complex and technical over time.

site_title: Big post-Brexit breakthrough in Biden visit unlikely
summary: US President Joe Biden's four-day visit to Ireland is unlikely to break the post-Brexit political impasse in the country. The trip, which coincides with the 25th anniversary of the Good Friday peace agreement, has drawn parallels with John Kennedy's 1963 visit. Biden, proud of his Irish ancestry, is seeking to strengthen US-Irish ties. However, the trip is expected to be low-key, with no major policy announcements or breakthroughs on the Brexit issue. The visit is seen as a historic occasion, but its impact on the Brexit stalemate remains uncertain.

site_title: Centurion selling South Korea property for 21.3 billion won
summary: Centurion Corporation, a property player, is selling a Seoul, South Korea property for 21.3 billion won (S$21.5 million) as part of rationalising its asset portfolio. The disposal aims to "align and focus" on countries where the company can expand and scale up its operations. This move is part of Centurion's efforts to streamline its portfolio and align with its business strategy.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Revenue for the period was up 15 per cent to S$89.9 million from S$78.3 million, which the group attributed to the stronger demand for workers and student accommodation across all geographies.
Centurion Corporation also  operates other student accommodation properties in Australia under Dwell Adelaide Student Living.

The lease and development of the land is in line with Centurion’s strategy to grow its workers accommodation business in Singapore, and represents an opportunity to enlarge its portfolio to 35,550 beds here.

site_title: US: Stocks open news-jammed week in the red
summary: US stocks opened the week in the red, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 33,424.06, following the release of March employment figures showing 236,000 jobs added, slightly less than expected. The unemployment rate inched down to 3.5%. The decline comes ahead of key inflation updates and bank earnings, amidst a news-heavy week.

images.alt_text: Traders on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, US, March 31, 2023.
Markets will be closed Friday to mark Good Friday, meaning that investors will have to wait until Monday to trade on important March employment figures.

site_title: Blinken to visit Vietnam, Japan as Asia tensions flare
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to visit Vietnam this week, amid growing tensions with China over Taiwan. Blinken will discuss a shared vision for a connected and prosperous Indo-Pacific region with Vietnamese officials, and participate in a groundbreaking ceremony for a new US embassy in Hanoi. The visit aims to strengthen US-Vietnam relations, which have largely reconciled despite bitter war memories. Blinken's trip comes as China completes military drills around Taiwan, and follows a meeting with Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin and Philippine officials.

images.alt_text: In a statement on Sunday, the Pentagon said it was reviewing the validity of the photographed documents that “appear to contain sensitive and highly classified material”.
A China Coast Guard ship approaches the area where Beijing said it would conduct live firing exercises north-east of Pingtan island, the closest point in China to Taiwan, on Monday (Apr 10).

site_title: Four key priorities for Singapore’s government as Parliament reopens
summary: Singapore's government has set four key priorities for the rest of its term, including expanding opportunities for all, strengthening social safety nets, and promoting inclusivity. President Halimah Yacob emphasized the need to strengthen the country's social fabric to remain united and thrive in a challenging post-pandemic world. The government aims to address economic headwinds and great power rivalry while promoting liveability and inclusivity.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
If meritocracy necessarily results in unequal outcomes, the question is: Can we rely on such a system to deliver good outcomes for everyone?
The current Parliament, Singapore's 14th, now consists 103 members of Parliament: 92 elected MPs, 2 Non-Constituency MPs and 9 Nominated MPs.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% in early trade on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 2.09 points to 3,292.34. Despite US indices gaining overnight, losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 48, with Sembcorp Marine and Rex International among the most actively traded counters. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB traded mixed, while US stocks closed mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Sabana Reit reported a rise in portfolio occupancy to 92.6 per cent after the first quarter of the year.

site_title: Japan’s three megabanks to face votes on climate change: sources
summary: A coalition of climate groups in Japan is pressing Japan's top three megabanks to cut financing linked to fossil fuels, filing shareholder resolutions to be voted on in June. The groups, led by Australia's Market Forces and Japan's Kiko Network, target Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Mizuho Financial Group, citing their lagging efforts to slash carbon emissions. The move comes as institutional investors increasingly pressure companies to combat global warming, following similar resolutions filed last year that prompted policy changes at the targeted companies.

site_title: Samsung’s cut in chip production is good news for industry
summary: Samsung Electronics cut its chip production to a "meaningful level" after reporting its smallest profit in over a decade. The move is seen as positive for rival manufacturers, potentially easing a supply glut that has driven down prices across the industry. Chipmakers Micron Technology and Western Digital rose in response, with prices of DRAMs expected to fall around 10% in the current quarter. The cut is believed to help turn around the largest memory supply imbalance in decades, adding "light to the tunnel" for the industry, according to analyst Brian Chin.

site_title: President Biden says he will run again in 2024: NBC
summary: US President Joe Biden announced he plans to run for reelection in 2024, but has not made a formal announcement. In an interview with NBC's Today show, Biden stated, "I plan on running... but we're not prepared to announce it yet." He expressed intention to be the Democratic candidate alongside Vice-President Kamala Harris.

site_title: Tackling illicit trade in alcohol will put Asean on a growth trajectory
summary: Illicit alcohol trade in Southeast Asia poses significant economic, public health, and safety risks. According to the World Health Organization, unrecorded alcohol accounts for 26% of total alcohol consumed in Asia, with some countries like Myanmar, Vietnam, and Indonesia experiencing rates of over 60%. The global economy loses over $2.2 trillion due to counterfeiting and illicit goods. To address this issue, governments and businesses must work together to develop taxation policies, protect consumer safety through legislation, and enhance enforcement cooperation to fight transnational crimes. A multi-stakeholder approach is necessary to bring illicit alcohol into the regulated sphere, which is crucial for Asean's projected growth in 2023.

images.alt_text: Covid-19, e-commerce fuel illicit trade in Asean: EU-Asean Business Council

site_title: US online prices decline for a seventh month on annual basis
summary: US online prices declined 1.7% in March from a year earlier, the seventh-straight annual drop, with steep drops in discretionary categories and flat prices in others. This suggests consumers are being more cautious and spending more on services. The decline reflects a competitive selling environment for online merchants, bolstering a Federal Reserve model that suggests inflation persistence eased early this year.

images.alt_text: Temu topped US app download rankings in early April, a spot it held since January.
JD largely avoided a direct hit from China’s 2020 and 2021 crackdown on the country’s biggest Internet companies.

FILE PHOTO: People carrying shopping bags walk inside the King of Prussia shopping mall, as shoppers show up early for the Black Friday sales, in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, U.S. November 26, 2021.  REUTERS/Rachel Wisniewski/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Investors need a crystal ball for risk, not returns
summary: Switzerland's bailout of Credit Suisse has raised concerns over the erosion of shareholder rights and corporate seniority, potentially leading to legal action. Investors are advised to focus on seismic shifts in the global system, including the rising risk of war, the weaponization of the US dollar, and the collapse of the rule of law and protection of individual property rights. The Credit Suisse bailout highlights the need for investors to diversify and avoid big risks, rather than chasing yields, and the shift towards a new global economic landscape is underway, with potential consequences for investors and the financial system.

images.alt_text: Karin Keller-Sutter says that the government had acted in the country’s best interests in swiftly arranging the takeover of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank by its larger domestic rival UBS.
The banking system will reach that point with “monitoring, changing a few things,” JPMorgan Chase chief executive officer Jamie Dimon said.
Last month, Swiss authorities announced that UBS would buy Credit Suisse in a shotgun merger to stem further banking turmoil after the smaller lender had come to the brink of collapse.

site_title: US: Wall Street  stocks end mostly higher after latest US jobs data
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Monday following solid US jobs data, which showed the economy added 236,000 jobs in March, slightly less than expected. The unemployment rate inched down to 3.5%. Analysts considered the jobs report solid, potentially leading to further Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The Dow and S&P 500 finished positive, while the Nasdaq ended slightly down. Investors await key inflation updates and corporate earnings season, which may impact interest rates and the market's outlook.

images.alt_text: About 20 minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.2 per cent at 33,424.06.  The broad-based S&P 500 and the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index were also down.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Centurion, GK Goh
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) reported a 92.6% portfolio occupancy as of March 31, 2023, a 0.4% increase from December 2022. Centurion, a property manager, will sell its Seoul property for $21.5 million. Meanwhile, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are deepening their collaboration on green and transition finance.

site_title: Trump’s new accounting firm agrees to respond to New York AG subpoena
summary: Donald Trump's new accounting firm, Whitley Penn, has agreed to respond to a New York Attorney General's subpoena in a $250 million civil suit over the former president's asset valuations. The firm will hand over documents related to Trump's financial statements and audit engagements, as well as allow one of its employees to be questioned by the AG's staff. The case is set for trial in October, with the AG seeking penalties, including a permanent ban on Trump's companies in the state.

images.alt_text: Former US president Donald Trump arrives for his arraignment at Manhattan Criminal Court on April 04, 2023 in New York City.
Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, said nothing as he entered the courtroom or when he left roughly an hour later.

site_title: EV battery stocks in Korea add to this year’s sharp gains
summary: Korean stocks linked to electric vehicle (EV) battery production surged, extending this year's rally. Positive developments in the sector include better-than-estimated results from LG Energy Solution and reports of Chinese firms cutting back lithium production. This has sparked renewed interest among Korean retail investors. Shares of cathode-active materials supplier Ecopro BM Co and its parent Ecopro Co rose over 20% on Monday, with the supplier planning to expand its manufacturing presence in South Korea. The sector's gains have added to this year's sharp gains in EV battery stocks in Korea.

images.alt_text: Workers are seen at the production line of lithium-ion batteries for electric vehicles (EV) at a factory in Huzhou, Zhejiang province, China August 28, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: Japan’s Octopus Energy unit aims to increase renewables in energy source mix
summary: Octopus Energy's Japanese arm aims to increase the use of renewable energy in its supply mix, driven by a more stable purchasing price compared to liquefied natural gas (LNG). The company, which has around 160,000 customers, currently relies on LNG-fired power generation for 80% of its electricity supply. The move is expected to provide a more sustainable option for Japanese households.

site_title: Alibaba-backed SenseTime unfurls China’s latest ChatGPT rival
summary: SenseTime, backed by Alibaba, unveiled its large AI model SenseNova and user-facing chatbot SenseChat, rivaling ChatGPT. CEO Xu Li demonstrated SenseChat's capabilities, including storytelling, code writing, and translation, showcasing its potential as a Chinese AI challenger. The move highlights SenseTime's efforts to develop its AI capabilities with access to vast data and computing power.

images.alt_text: The Beijing-recognised newspaper Economic Daily has called for regulators to strengthen monitoring and crackdowns on share-price manipulation and speculation, to create “a well-disclosed and well-run market”.
Alibaba has opened up registration for businesses to conduct testing for its AI application, STAR Market reported without specifying details.
The Chinese artificial intelligence software maker joined a list of technology companies that have seen insiders selling their shares after a strong rebound since mid-March.
SenseTime jumps on debut after IPO delayed by US sanctions

site_title: Indonesia expects to clinch US$560 million Chinese loan for high-speed train soon
summary: Indonesia is close to securing a US$560 million loan from the China Development Bank to cover a US$1.2 billion cost overrun for a high-speed rail project linking Jakarta and Bandung. The project's total cost has exceeded US$7 billion, making it the most high-profile Belt and Road Initiative in Indonesia. The loan is part of negotiations expected to be concluded in coming weeks, addressing a significant cost overrun that has pushed the project's original budget into the red.

site_title: Sabana Industrial Reit’s portfolio occupancy rises to 92.6% in Q1
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit reported a 92.6% portfolio occupancy as of March 31, up from 91.2% as of December 31, 2022. Strong leasing momentum was driven by robust demand from third-party logistics providers, particularly for warehouse and logistics properties. The Reit's total portfolio occupancy excludes a property undergoing asset enhancement initiatives. This growth is attributed to the Reit's manager citing significant demand for its properties between January and March this year.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The property at 1 Tuas Avenue 4, dubbed 1TA4, will incorporate solar panels that can potentially generate more than 1,000 megawatt-hours of energy per year, says Sabana Reit's manager.
Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.
As a result of the offer turning unconditional, the offer’s closing date has been extended by two weeks to 5.30pm on Mar 24, 2023, from the same time on Mar 10.

site_title: Intel’s foundry bet may split the market in three
summary: Intel's plan to enter the custom chipmaking industry may split the market in three, leaving the US giant stuck in the middle. The company aims to become the No 2 foundry in the world by the end of the decade, but it faces a challenging path. Intel needs to advance manufacturing technology and research the latest chip technology to produce high-volume output with minimal defects. However, the pace of development is accelerating, and Intel may drop back by a few development cycles within half a decade, leaving it in a "mushy middle" that could be difficult to navigate.

images.alt_text: Intel had originally estimated that the project in Germany would cost 17 billion euros but now expects to spend 30 billion.
Reducing its payments to shareholders undermines Intel’s standing in a growing competition among chipmakers to offer higher returns.

site_title: Ueda, Kishida agree no need to revise government-BOJ accord for now
summary: New Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Kazuo Ueda and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida agree that there's no need to revise their joint accord on monetary policy, citing a situation where Japan is no longer in a state of deflation. Ueda stated that the joint statement's thinking is appropriate, and there's no immediate need for a review, suggesting that the BOJ's easy policy will continue.

images.alt_text: Ueda has the chance to drop hints of any intention to shift policy at his inaugural press briefing expected later on Monday.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up as traders weigh US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, driven by the US jobs data, which suggested the Federal Reserve would likely hike interest rates again but alleviated concerns about a possible recession. Inflation figures later this week will play a crucial role in the Fed's decision-making. Some analysts believe the Fed may end its hiking cycle earlier than expected, with some predicting cuts by the end of the year. Trading was light due to the Easter break, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and other cities rising, while Jakarta fell.

images.alt_text: While traders have long hoped for a tightening of the labour market and an economic slowdown that would allow the Fed to stop lifting rates, there is now a rising concern of a deep recession.

site_title: Japan’s current account swings back to black on overseas investment
summary: Japan's current account swung back to a surplus in February, with a surplus of 3.4407 trillion yen, driven by record returns on securities investments and easing concerns about weakening purchasing power. The trade deficit of 604.1 billion yen was offset by the income surplus, as a weak yen and rises in global interest rates fueled Japanese investments abroad. Economists predict a gradual expansion of the current account surplus as imports decline and inbound tourism recovers.

images.alt_text: Ueda has the chance to drop hints of any intention to shift policy at his inaugural press briefing expected later on Monday.

Japan's Economy, Trade and Industry minister Yasutoshi Nishimura (L) speaking in Tokyo at the Apr 4 meeting of the 2023 G7 trade ministers, during which economic security, including export controls, was raised.

site_title: Chinese firms join global craze for developing ChatGPT-style technology
summary: Chinese tech giants Baidu and Alibaba, along with smaller start-ups, are developing ChatGPT-style technology, following the global trend sparked by Microsoft-backed OpenAI's ChatGPT. Unlike ChatGPT, which excels at professional tasks, Chinese chatbots focus on social interactions. This development is driving AI-related stocks in China and prompting local companies to announce rival projects.

images.alt_text: SenseTime CEO Xu Li took to the stage on Monday (Apr 10) to show the capabilities of its large AI model SenseNova and a user-facing chatbot called SenseChat.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek has acquired a 41% stake in Bengaluru-based Manipal Health Enterprises for a reported US$2 billion, increasing its total stake in the hospital chain to 59%. The acquisition marks a significant move by the Singaporean investment firm in the Indian healthcare sector.

site_title: Hot stocks: Healthcare-related counters rise amid heavy trading
summary: Healthcare-related stocks surged in heavy trading on the Singapore Exchange, with Medtecs International jumping 23.9% to a three-month high. Biolidics and Disa, manufacturers of Covid-19 test kits, also saw significant gains. The increase in trading coincides with a surge in local Covid-19 cases, with 28,410 cases reported between Mar 26 and Apr 1.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

site_title: Thai central bank sees policy focus on stability, maintains 2023 GDP forecast
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput maintained Thailand's 2023 GDP forecast at 3.6% and emphasized policy focus on stability rather than economic stimulus. The central bank raised interest rates a quarter of a percentage point to 1.75% last month, with policy normalization continuing but with caution. The BOT has the tools to support the financial system in case of any problems and prioritizes stability over stimulus, citing the economy's resilience.

images.alt_text: The Thai central bank has raised its policy rate for a fifth straight meeting, and says that its policy tightening will continue.
In the January-March period, foreign investors sold 23 billion baht net of Thai bonds, but they were still holding 1.05 trillion baht of debt, or 6.5 per cent of the total market.

site_title: China AI stocks sink on state media’s call to stem bubble risk
summary: China's AI stocks plummeted, with CloudWalk Technology falling 20% and 360 Security Technology dropping 10%, after a state media outlet urged regulators to strengthen supervision of share-price manipulation and speculation. The Economic Daily called for a "well-disclosed and well-run market," warning that the ChatGPT concept sector showed signs of a valuation bubble. Regulators are advised to crack down on speculation and ensure companies develop their AI capabilities before investors speculate.

images.alt_text: Alibaba has opened up registration for businesses to conduct testing for its AI application, STAR Market reported without specifying details.
European authorities including those of France, Ireland and Germany have since approached their Italian counterpart to try to establish a common position on ChatGPT.

site_title: Wall Street bank earnings under pressure after crisis
summary: Wall Street banks, particularly JPMorgan Chase & Co, are expected to report lower quarterly earnings due to the regional banking crisis and a slowing economy. Analysts predict a 10% decline in earnings per share (EPS) for the six biggest US banks, with the largest banks benefiting from access to cheap deposits. The crisis and economic slowdown are expected to hurt profitability for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried faces trial in October after pleading not guilty to fraud and campaign-finance law charges.
More than half of the world’s low-income countries are at high risk of debt distress or already in it, and several have defaulted.

site_title: Indonesia to propose limited free trade deal with US on critical minerals
summary: Indonesia plans to propose a limited free trade agreement with the US, focusing on critical minerals such as nickel, to attract US companies in the electric vehicle (EV) battery supply chain. The move aims to benefit from US tax credits for companies producing EV batteries in Indonesia. The country's nickel reserves, the world's largest, have become crucial in the supply chain. Indonesia will propose a limited FTA similar to the one with Japan, requiring processing and trade requirements for critical minerals.

site_title: Japan Display forms alliance with China’s HKC on chip fabs, auto displays
summary: Japan Display has formed an alliance with China's HKC Corporation to cooperate on next-generation OLED technology, chip fabrication, and auto displays. The partnership aims to target mass production in 2025 and will involve multiple fabrication plants. Japan Display, which is majority-owned by Ichigo Trust, is restructuring to turn around its struggling businesses, and the tie-up will bring together its technology and HKC's cost competitiveness. The company's shares rose 10.5% following the announcement.

site_title: China to attend IMF meeting in Washington after Covid hiatus
summary: China will send its top officials to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) spring meetings in Washington for the first time in three years, following COVID-19 curbs. Governor of the People's Bank of China, Yi Gang, and Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank chief, Jin Liqun, will attend. The move comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The meetings will also include Finance Minister Liu Kun, although his travel plans have not been confirmed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People's Bank of China (PBOC) Governor Yi Gang attends a news conference in Beijing, China March 3, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: SP Group acquires rooftop solar assets in China
summary: SP Group has acquired up to 150 megawatts-peak of rooftop photovoltaic (PV) assets in China, generating over 150 gigawatt-hours of green electricity annually and helping China avoid 88,000 tonnes of carbon emissions each year. The assets are installed at over 50 industrial sites in four provinces, covering the food and beverage, automobile, and textiles industries. The acquisition is part of SP Group's strategy to support China's clean energy expansion and sustainable development, with the remaining 70 MWp transaction likely to be completed by mid-year.

images.alt_text: Thanh Long Phu Yen Solar Power Plant is one of the two first utility-scale solar assets SP have secured in Vietnam.
China is the global leader in the production and installation of solar power, although it’s facing growing challenges.
Solar panels on the roof of Blk 278A Compassvale Bow in Sengkang. To date, about 3,300 HDB blocks have been equipped with solar panels.

site_title: Malaysia unemployment rate drops to 3-year low on broad recovery
summary: Malaysia's unemployment rate dropped to 3.5% in February, the lowest in three years, as the labor force participation rate reached 69.9%, the highest since 2010. The country's economy is expected to continue recovering, with a forecasted growth of 4-5% in 2023. This follows a spurt in export values of electrical and electronics products, which rose 12% to RM44.3 billion in February. The nation's semiconductor exports to the US remain a key driver of growth.

site_title: Sinopec to build China west-to-east green hydrogen transmission pipeline: Xinhua
summary: China's Sinopec to build a 400km green hydrogen transmission pipeline from Inner Mongolia to Beijing, with an initial capacity of 100,000 tonnes per year. The pipeline will support the country's goal of producing 100,000-200,000 tonnes of green hydrogen annually and is China's first 'West to East' green hydrogen transmission line. State-owned oil and gas giant Sinopec is China's largest hydrogen producer, with a planned annual capacity of 30,000 tonnes at a new green hydrogen plant in Ordos.

site_title: US searches for source of highly classified intel leak
summary: The US is investigating a highly classified intelligence leak after classified documents containing sensitive information on Ukraine, China, and Israel appeared online. The documents, marked "Secret" and "Top Secret," suggest the leak may have originated from within the US, rather than an ally. US officials are reviewing the documents, which include battlefield casualty estimates altered to minimize Russian losses, and have opened a criminal investigation. The leak has raised concerns about the potential motivations of the leaker, including an insider threat or a disgruntled employee.

images.alt_text: Lockheed added the contract offers three additional follow-on awards which will start in late 2023, allowing for a total contract value of up to US$4.5 billion over the next four years.

site_title: FTX failure rooted in ‘hubris’ and ‘greed’, debtors report finds
summary: A report by FTX debtors reveals that the company's collapse was rooted in "hubris, incompetence, and greed" by CEO Sam Bankman-Fried and top executives. The report states that FTX lacked fundamental financial and accounting controls, stifled dissent, and commingled corporate and customer funds, leading to its rapid collapse into bankruptcy. The investigation analyzed over 1 million documents and interviewed 19 employees, finding that the company's control failures were widespread and led to billions of dollars in customer funds being lost.

images.alt_text: The new charges add to the pressure on Bankman-Fried, who faces a possible sentence of decades in prison if convicted at a trial set to start on Oct 2.
One irony of the FTX saga is that founder Sam Bankman-Fried was trying to disrupt traditional finance, but might end up making crypto look more like mainstream finance.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Jokowi-backed presidential hopeful’s rating falls on soccer remark
summary: Indonesia's presidential hopeful Ganjar Pranowo's support has dropped to 26.9% after his comments against Israeli participation in the Under 20 FIFA World Cup led to Indonesia's hosting rights being removed. Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto is now the most popular candidate, followed by former Jakarta governor Anies Baswedan. The move is seen as a blow to President Joko Widodo's favored candidate, who would provide continuity for his policies, including the relocation of Indonesia's capital city.

site_title: Super Mario tops box office with year’s biggest opening
summary: Super Mario topped the box office with a global haul of $378 million, becoming the biggest opening of the year. The animated feature, released during spring break and Easter holidays, earned $146 million domestically and $205 million over the five-day period. This surpasses Marvel's Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania, which held the previous record. The film's success is a victory for Nintendo and Illumination, the studio behind the film, and may help theatre chains recover from the slow cinema industry recovery.

images.alt_text: In one of the movies, Daisy Ridley wll reprise her role as Rey, the heroine of the last trilogy, which wound up in 2019 to mixed reviews.
India is a key growth market for Amazon and its Prime Video streaming service.

site_title: Tennis’ Medvedev says balance key as he adapts game for clay
summary: Daniil Medvedev, the world No 4 tennis player, is adapting his game for the claycourt swing without compromising his style. He has won 18 of his 19 titles on hardcourts, but acknowledges that clay presents a different challenge, requiring a balance between his game and the surface. Medvedev aims to tweak his strokes to counter the flat shots that don't travel well on clay, while maintaining his playing style. Winning a title on clay would boost his confidence before the French Open, but he prefers playing on hardcourts.

images.alt_text: WWE executive chairman Vince McMahon will retain his role in the new company, which will be majority owned by Endeavor with a 51 per cent stake, while WWE investors will own the rest.
With the win Medvedev earned his fifth Masters 1000 title and improved to 6-0 lifetime against Sinner.

site_title: The TikTok paradox of power and precarity
summary: TikTok owner ByteDance posted a record $25 billion in earnings in 2022, despite facing geopolitical and trust concerns. The company's US business remains vulnerable due to the threat of a ban if its Chinese owners do not divest their stake. Fears over user data collection and algorithm manipulation have surfaced, as well as concerns over the app's addictiveness and mental health impact on teenagers. Despite efforts by CEO Chew Shou Zi to address these concerns, hostile US lawmakers expressed skepticism, leaving ByteDance at a critical juncture to navigate these challenges.

images.alt_text: ByteDance’s profit last year came despite mounting losses at fast-growing TikTok.
Temu topped US app download rankings in early April, a spot it held since January.

site_title: Closing date for Halcyon Agri mandatory unconditional offer extended to Apr 24
summary: The closing date for Halcyon Agri's mandatory unconditional cash offer by China Hainan Rubber has been extended to 5.30 pm on Apr 24. China Hainan Rubber, a subsidiary of China Hainan Rubber Industry Group, launched the offer in February at S$0.413 per share and received valid acceptances of 495.8 million shares, or 31.1% of the company. The offeror now owns 67.1% of the company, making it unlikely for Halcyon Agri to be delisted and privatised.

images.alt_text: Core earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) was at US$10.2 million, up year-on-year from US$9.4 million in Q3 2021, but down quarter-on-quarter from US$16.2 million in Q2 2022.
Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.

site_title: China's car sales stay flat in March amid price war
summary: China's passenger vehicle sales remained flat in March at 1.61 million units, down 13.4% from the same period last year. New-energy vehicle sales rose 21.9% to 34% of total sales, led by BYD with 35.5% market share and Tesla with 14%. The price war, initiated by Tesla, has led to discounts and tumbling battery costs, with over 40 brands participating. Local governments have also rolled out buyer subsidies to drive demand, with some programs extending to automakers to spur manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The HiPhi brand currently sells its X SUV and Z sedan in China, with a range of up to 430 miles (692 km) and prices starting at around 620,000 yuan (S$119,791.26).
Battery swapping allows drivers to replace depleted packs quickly with fully charged packs, rather than plugging the vehicle into a charging point.
FILE PHOTO: The BYD Atto 3 EV car is displayed at the 39 Thailand International Motor Expo, in Bangkok, Thailand, November 30, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: Opec’s gamble: Can the global economy cope with higher oil prices?
summary: Saudi Arabia, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has surprised the oil market by pledging to cut more crude from supply, aiming to shore up oil prices despite global economic concerns. The move, made by energy minister Abdulaziz bin Salman, has sparked volatility in the geopolitics of energy and raises the risk of higher inflation and a potential global recession. Analysts warn that the cut could lead to a price surge, benefiting Russia's economy, and deepen the rift between Saudi Arabia and the US administration of President Joe Biden, who has sought to dictate the price Moscow earns from its oil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo
Banks from Goldman Sachs to RBC Capital Markets raised their oil-price forecasts immediately after the Opec+ cut.

site_title: Incoming World Bank chief will get a honeymoon, but not for long
summary: The World Bank is set to undergo significant change with the expected confirmation of former Mastercard CEO Ajay Banga as its president. Banga aims to bring a new sense of urgency to the bank's mission to alleviate global poverty, addressing issues like climate change, inequality, and conflict. He will face high expectations and urgent questions about the bank's lending model, private investment, and addressing global crises. Critics argue the bank is insufficiently focused on climate change and lacks ambition, while the US seeks to counter China's influence in the developing world.

images.alt_text: More than half of the world’s low-income countries are at high risk of debt distress or already in it, and several have defaulted.

site_title: ByteDance’s profit surges 79%, exceeding Alibaba and Tencent: FT
summary: ByteDance's profit surged 79% in 2022, exceeding Alibaba and Tencent for the first time, reaching $25 billion in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA). The company's revenue grew over 30% to $80 billion, matching rival Tencent's figure. Despite mounting losses at TikTok, Douyin remains ByteDance's biggest cash cow. The company's valuation has decreased to $220 billion, down from $300 billion in a recent investment. This growth has boosted investor confidence despite global events and concerns over data access.

site_title: China’s first batch of bluechips under new IPO system surge in debut
summary: China's first batch of blue-chip stocks listed under its new registration-based IPO system surged in their debut, with some companies opening up by as much as 161% and 239%. The new rules eliminate daily trading limits for shares in the first five trading days, allowing for more market-oriented public share sales. Despite this, the overall stock market slipped 0.3% due to concerns over China's economic recovery and ongoing drills around the Taiwan Strait. The move marks the full roll-out of China's US-style IPO mechanism, designed to increase market-oriented public share sales.

images.alt_text: Pragmatic and effective measures will be introduced at the opportune time to further stabilise market expectations, Chinese Premier Li Qiang said.
China’s foreign exchange reserves – the world’s largest – rose US$51 billion to US$3.184 trillion last month.

site_title: Apple’s 40% plunge in PC shipments is steepest among major computer makers
summary: Apple's PC shipments plummeted 40.5% in the first quarter, the steepest decline among major computer makers. The global PC market combined saw a 29% drop to 56.9 million units, with Lenovo, Dell, and HP also experiencing significant declines. The slowdown is attributed to the end of pandemic-era remote work and a glut of unsold inventory. Apple is diversifying its manufacturing base due to brewing tensions between the US and China, which may disrupt its supply chain. The IDC forecasts a potential rebound in PC shipments in 2024 driven by ageing hardware and an improving global economy.

site_title: Ueda kicks off BOJ governorship in first transition in a decade
summary: Kazuo Ueda took over as Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor, succeeding Haruhiko Kuroda, who implemented aggressive easing efforts over a decade. Ueda aims to achieve a soft landing for the massive stimulus program, rather than expanding it, as signs of its side effects pile up. He has a neutral tone on monetary policy, unlike Kuroda, and will hold his first policy meeting between April 27-28. Economists expect some policy tightening by June, and Ueda is seen as a good choice for governor, with 94% of economists polled saying he is a good pick.

images.alt_text: Handing the reins of the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to academic Kazuo Ueda, Haruhiko Kuroda pointed to progress under his radical easy-money policy, which featured a push to change public perceptions with a wall of money and Peter Pan metaphors.
The BOJ was forced into massive bond buying to defend its policy cap on the 10-year Japanese government bond yield.

A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI

site_title: Aramco to supply full volumes to Asia despite Opec+ oil cuts: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco has confirmed that it will supply full contract volumes of crude oil to at least four customers in North Asia in May, despite an Opec+ output cut of 1.16 million barrels per day for the rest of the year. This move comes as several Asian refiners plan maintenance in May, potentially weakening oil demand. The Opec+ cut aims to shore up oil prices, but its impact on actual supply remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

Crown Prince Mohammed Salman’s willingness to act to secure stability, while coordinating energy policy with Russia and even sidelining the US in favour of its No 1 rival China, underscores Riyadh’s growing geopolitical influence as a fossil fuel superpower.

site_title: Temasek acquires majority stake in India’s Manipal Health Enterprises for reported US$2 billion
summary: Temasek, a Singapore sovereign wealth fund, has acquired a 41% stake in Manipal Health Enterprises, a Bengaluru-based hospital chain, for approximately US$2 billion. This deal raises Temasek's total stake in the company to 59%. The acquisition is from investors including private equity firm TPG and India's National Investment and Infrastructure Fund. Manipal's founder, Ranjan Pai, will see his family holding decrease to 30% from 50%. Both TPG and the National Investment and Infrastructure Fund will exit their holdings, with TPG re-investing via a new fund.

site_title: Stocks to watch:  Sembmarine, EC World Reit, Raffles Education, CDL
summary: Sembmarine has increased its market cap post-merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine, making it a candidate for STI inclusion. EC World Reit seeks a time extension for its annual general meeting due to a delay in divesting assets. Raffles Education has been awarded S$2.9 million in damages against Educomp founder and lawyer. CDL sold 340 units of its Tembusu Grand project at an average selling price of S$2,465 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: ST makes organisational changes in push to accelerate digital transformation
summary: ST makes organisational changes to accelerate digital transformation, consolidating editorial operations and audience functions under two associate editors. Zakir Hussain oversees reporting teams and ST Now, a team of first responders, while Ong Hwee Hwee leads product and audience growth across all platforms. The changes aim to enhance digital workflows and responsiveness to audience needs, with a focus on constant evolution and innovation.

images.alt_text: ST editor Jaime Ho also wants grow the spirit of diversity and openness in his newsroom by having alternative viewpoints.
‘I hope, at the very least, I bring a fresh set of eyes, to make changes not for the sake of making changes,' says Jaime Ho, ST editor.
Clockwise from top left: Wong Wei Kong, Jaime Ho, Chen Huifen and Warren Fernandez.
Making change work is harder than change itself

site_title: China rehearses 'sealing off' Taiwan, US deploys naval destroyer
summary: China simulated "sealing off" Taiwan during live firing exercises around the self-ruled island, amid heightened tensions with the US. China's military also deployed one of its two aircraft carriers, the Shandong, and dozens of planes practiced an aerial blockade. The US responded by deploying a naval destroyer, the USS Milius, through contested waters in the South China Sea. The exercises were seen as a response to Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen's meeting with US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, and China views democratic Taiwan as part of its territory.

images.alt_text: A China Coast Guard ship sails towards the zone where China said it would conduct live fire exercises northeast of Pingtan island, the closest point in China to Taiwan, in China’s southeast Fujian province on April 10, 2023. - China was due to hold live-fire drills on April 10 to round off three days of military exercises in response to Taiwan's president meeting with the US House speaker. (Photo by GREG BAKER / AFP)

site_title: TSMC talking to US about Chips Act ‘guidance’ amid subsidy concerns
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) is communicating with the US government about the "guidance" for the Chips Act, a law aimed at boosting US semiconductor manufacturing. The law includes conditions for subsidies, such as sharing excess profit with the US government, sparking concerns about confidential corporate strategy. TSMC is investing $40 billion in a new plant in Arizona, supporting Washington's plans for more chip-making at home, with the plant set to receive subsidies from a $52 billion research and manufacturing fund.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix parent SK Group plans to invest US$15 billion in the US chip sector, including to build an advanced chip packaging factory, and has said it is considering applying for funding.
In Taiwan, TSMC is widely regarded as the “sacred mountain protecting the country”, because of its economic importance.

site_title: Europe needs to put its money where its mouth is to stop deforestation in South-east Asia
summary: The European Union has introduced a regulation banning the import of products made from agricultural commodities such as palm oil, timber, and rubber grown on recently deforested land. The regulation, set to take effect in 2024, requires companies and farmers in Indonesia and Malaysia to certify their products are not linked to deforestation. However, critics argue that this places responsibility on the farmers and governments in the Global South, rather than the EU and other Northern countries, which are major consumers of these commodities. The regulation's impact on small-scale farmers in South-east Asia is also a concern, as they may struggle to comply with the new requirements and face financial pressure.

images.alt_text: As business environment gets tougher, Malaysia palm oil producers are turning to tech solutions to improve crude palm oil yield as well as exploring opportunities in dowstream segment.

“The regulation’s unilateral and unrealistic demands on traceability and geolocation will prevent small farmers from accessing the European market,” a group of six smallholder associations said in a joint statement.
Indonesia and Malaysia have accused the EU of implementing discriminatory policies targetting palm oil.

Deforestation is a major source of greenhouse gas emissions that drive climate change and will be in focus at a UN COP15 conference this week, where countries will seek a global deal to protect nature.

site_title: Gold dips on stronger dollar after US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $2,000.57 per ounce after the US dollar strengthened following a tight labor market and expectations of another interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Non-farm payrolls increased by 236,000 jobs in March, raising bets on a rate hike in May. Higher interest rates dim gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation, making it expensive for overseas buyers.

images.alt_text: On the technical charts, bullish signals are present for gold in both the short and long term.

site_title: Oil edges higher on prospect of tighter supplies
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Monday, supported by the prospect of tighter supplies from Opec+ producers starting in May. Brent crude futures rose 0.2% to $85.25 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.2% to $80.84 a barrel. The announcement by Opec+ of more production cuts, mostly from Middle East producers, is expected to cap gains. The US inflation report this week could influence interest rates, and concerns about the global economic outlook also impacted gains.

images.alt_text: Prices drew support from a steeper-than-expected drop and a second consecutive weekly drawdown in US crude inventories last week.

site_title: Bond market is overplaying the risk of a deep recession
summary: The bond market is experiencing a significant shift in reaction to Silicon Valley Bank's collapse, with yields rising sharply despite concerns of a deep recession. The market is absorbing the shock with relative ease, and some experts argue that the rise in yields may be a false alarm, driven by bearish positioning among speculators. While stocks are still showing signs of trouble, the gap in market reactions between the bond and stock markets is historic, with the Treasury market displaying a more cautious tone.

images.alt_text: Rupiah is set to gain from higher oil prices — especially following Opec+’s decision over the weekend to trim output.

Signage at the UBS flagship office in New York, US, on Tuesday, March 21, 2023. UBS Group AG jumped as much as 10%, on track for its biggest gain since March 2020, as investor optimism about the takeover of its largest rival gathered pace. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg
The new Citrix bonds will refinance most of a US$3.95 billion unsecured bridge loan.

site_title: Japan’s G7 economic agenda emerges in face of geopolitical gale
summary: Japan's G7 presidency will focus on promoting energy transition ahead of COP28 in Dubai this November, a priority of the country's chairing of the event. Economic security, including export controls, will also be a key feature of the G7's agenda this year, with the body seeking to enhance its outreach to international partners to boost supply chain resiliency. Geopolitical tensions, including the ongoing Ukraine conflict, will also dominate discussions, with Japan and the US pushing for joint economic action to counter Chinese economic coercion.

images.alt_text: Japan’s G7 focus will be geopolitics, not economics
A Gazprom Neft gas station outside the Gazprom Neft MNPZ refinery in Moscow, Russia, Dec 30, 2022.
Japan’s government has urged its gas importers to continue investing in overseas supply and emphasised the potential role of technologies like carbon capture and storage to help limit emissions.

site_title: Editors Talk: Evolve or die - ST’s transformation journey (Ep 1)
summary: The Straits Times editor Jaime Ho discusses the newspaper's transformation journey to become future-ready, moving beyond its reputation as the Government's mouthpiece. Ho aims to bring fresh perspectives and encourage journalists to take collective ownership of the newsroom. The conversation touches on the challenge of talent retention and the need to forge a new culture in the modern news industry. Ho emphasizes the importance of encouraging journalists to speak up and take ownership of their work, rather than just making changes for the sake of change.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times staff working in the newly renovated newsroom on Jan 23, 2019.
ST editor Jaime Ho also wants grow the spirit of diversity and openness in his newsroom by having alternative viewpoints.

(Clockwise from bottom left) Wong Wei Kong, editor-in-chief of SPH Media's English/Malay/Tamil Media group, BT podcast editor Claressa Monteiro, SPH Media Trust chairman Khaw Boon Wan and SPH Media CEO Teo Lay Lim inside the newly built BT podcast studio.

site_title: Singapore shares open muted on Monday; STI up 0.01%
summary: Singapore shares rose marginally by 0.01% to 3,300.91 on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending the trading day flat after a holiday-shortened week. Banking stocks opened mixed, with DBS falling 2.4% and UOB climbing 0.6%. Global markets concluded the week mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average ending flat and the S&P 500 gaining 0.4%. Sembcorp Marine, the largest counter on the STI reserve list, remained the most actively traded counter.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine is now a candidate for STI inclusion after its market cap rose post merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine.

site_title: Chinese shopping app Temu wows US amid TikTok fears
summary: Chinese shopping app Temu has topped US app download rankings, selling low-cost products and gaining popularity amid growing scrutiny of platforms with Chinese links, including TikTok. Temu's success contrasts with concerns over fast fashion waste and worker exploitation, echoing issues with Shein. Despite security concerns, many US consumers, like Stephanie Wolfe, use virtual private networks and other precautions, shrugging off worries. Temu's rapid rise marks Chinese e-commerce giant Pinduoduo's first US market foray, and its success may be attributed to data-driven strategies, similar to those employed by Shein.

images.alt_text: ByteDance’s profit last year came despite mounting losses at fast-growing TikTok.
Tencent had long been upset over how some Douyin users would create short videos using copyrighted material in long videos without obtaining approval.
Australia's ban underscores growing worries that China could use the Beijing-based company to harvest users’ data to advance its political agenda, undermining Western security interests.

site_title: Huawei looks to move Middle East HQ to Saudi Arabia
summary: Huawei is exploring the possibility of moving its Middle East headquarters to Saudi Arabia, amid growing diplomatic and business ties between the two countries. The company, which already has offices in Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern cities, is in talks with Riyadh authorities to upgrade its presence. This move comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to position itself as a regional business hub and limit leakage from its economy. The decision has not been finalized, and Huawei currently has regional headquarters in Dubai and Bahrain.

site_title: Iron Mountain sells Jurong West building to ARA-Kenedix VCC for S$47 million
summary: US-based information management and storage group Iron Mountain has sold its 14-storey warehouse building in Jurong West to ARA-Kenedix VCC for S$47 million, with a long leaseback arrangement in place. The 20-year-old building has a 30-year leasehold tenure remaining and redevelopment potential under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan. The sale yields a net property yield of approximately 6.5%. CBRE brokered the deal, which was completed in early March 2023.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Keppel divests data centre in Frankfurt for 76m euros

site_title: Should non-property groups avoid buying property?
summary: Non-listed property companies may benefit from asset-light strategies, such as working with co-investors to manage multiple projects and properties. This approach can help boost return on equity (ROE). However, listed companies like Singtel, which is redeveloping its headquarters, can also benefit from owning property. The article highlights the potential drawbacks of buying property in Singapore, including low yields and high interest rates. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's decision to buy a freehold commercial building in the CBD for S$399 million is seen as a one-off exercise, with the company aiming to preserve its core shipbuilding business.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Yangzijiang executive chairman and chief executive officer Ren Letian said buying 39 Robinson Road allows the group to deepen its roots in Singapore.

site_title: DBS and NEA work together with young adults to combat food waste
summary: DBS and the National Environment Agency (NEA) partnered with young adults to combat food waste through a competition. Five winning teams, including Divert for 2nd Life (D2L.sg), received $25,000 each to implement and scale up their innovations. The initiative aims to reduce food waste in Singapore, which generated 817,000 tonnes in 2021. The teams will run a six-month pilot program, with support from DBS and NEA, to improve operational efficiencies and research and development efforts.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
From left: Team members of Change X, Seph Chen, Suhana Gupta, Peyton Choo, Asmita Mitra and Mitra Sachi.

site_title: Dockworker shortage shuts California ports
summary: The ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, the second-largest gateway for maritime trade in the US, were shut down on Friday due to a dockworker shortage. The shortage, caused by a dispute between shippers and the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, resulted in a lack of ILWU members to operate the terminals. The Pacific Maritime Association reported that cargo operations continued, but the shutdown effectively halted the ports' operations, which move 20 million shipping containers worth $300 billion annually.

images.alt_text: The IMF has long warned of increased costs, economic friction and GDP output losses associated with the global economy fragmenting into geopolitical blocs.
epa10182552 Containers are stacked at the Los Angeles and Long Beach Ports in Long Beach, California, USA, 13 September 2022.  EPA-EFE/CAROLINE BREHMAN

site_title: Gold shines as dollar & Treasury yields ease
summary: Gold prices rose to a 13-month high above $2,000 per ounce, driven by the US dollar and Treasury yields easing. The US economy's manufacturing and job data weakened, sparking concerns about the health of the US economy. The US Dollar Index briefly touched 101.5, and the two-year Treasury yield retreated below 3.8%, contributing to gold's gain. Bullish signals are present on technical charts, with gold trading above the golden cross level and breaking out of a bullish flag-type consolidation pattern.

images.alt_text: While gold is traditionally considered a hedge against inflation, higher interest rates dim non-yielding bullion’s appeal.
Spot gold declined 0.4 per cent at US$2,012.50 an ounce as of 1:59 pm in London, after this week surging to the highest since March 2022

site_title: Crypto hearings in Singapore throw up quirks, legal novelties
summary: Singapore's courts are grappling with the novel technology of cryptocurrencies, raising questions about their recognition as money and potential implications for the law. In a recent High Court hearing, the judge questioned whether a blockchain company's claim in crypto could be considered a sum of "money," sparking a colorful exchange. The case was dismissed, but the issue remains unresolved, with experts expecting more sticking points to surface as crypto companies face insolvency and disputes. The courts are navigating uncharted territory, including novel issues related to decentralized autonomous organizations, metaverse ownership, and crypto mixers.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Claudia Chong

site_title: Asian banks luring investors who think they’re a safer bet
summary: Asian banks are attracting investors who believe they are safer bets amid US-led banking turmoil. China's easing monetary policy and re-opening from Covid are driving investment, with over 70% of $5.5 billion in funds flowing into Chinese equities. The region's emerging economies, led by China, are expected to grow faster and experience slower inflation this year, while advanced economies contribute to a global downturn. However, risks remain, including the potential for financial instability to spread from Europe and North America, and the impact of a strong US dollar on external finances.

images.alt_text: Traders on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, US, March 31, 2023.

site_title: Binance’s US arm struggles to find bank to take its customers’ cash: WSJ
summary: The US arm of cryptocurrency exchange Binance is struggling to find a bank to handle its customers' cash after the failure of Signature Bank. Binance.US had previously relied on Signature Bank and Silvergate Capital, but both have failed. The company is now using an intermediary to store funds, slowing down transactions. Binance has tried to establish relationships with Cross River Bank and Customers Bancorp but has been met with reluctance due to concerns over regulatory risk. The company is working to onboard new partners and upgrade its systems.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies are placed on keyboard in this illustration taken, November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

“Vara wants to turn Dubai into a capital for the digital-assets economy while safeguarding its business ties with Western jurisdictions like Europe that are adopting more muscular crypto regulations,” said Sam Blatteis, CEO of The MENA Catalysts.
As Binance has faced mounting scrutiny from regulators, the exchange has lost some banking partners needed for so-called on-ramp, off-ramp transactions to fiat currencies.
Since the lawsuit, Binance has seen US$1.6 billion of overall withdrawals and US$852 million in the last 24 hours.

site_title: Twitter and 100-year-old cases are a crypto lawyer’s best friends
summary: Cryptocurrency lawyers are finding it challenging to keep up with the rapidly evolving field of crypto law, requiring them to revisit fundamental principles and think creatively. To stay current, lawyers are turning to Twitter and other social media platforms to stay informed about the latest developments. The intersection of law and technology has forced courts to become more progressive in formulating innovative solutions, often using unorthodox methods, such as serving court papers over Twitter. As the field continues to evolve, lawyers must constantly learn and adapt to address new challenges.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
While the question of recognising crypto as money remains unanswered for now, cases revolving around this issue will be something to watch.
Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore and the police have been helping banks to fine-tune their vetting approach when opening accounts for service providers across all types of digital assets.
Ong's new firm will focus on taking up cases within the digital asset space.

site_title: Malaysia’s move to break monopolies will encourage innovation, boost investments: observers
summary: Malaysia is reviewing monopolies in various sectors, including Touch 'n Go's cashless payment system for highway tolls, to boost innovation and attract investments. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced the review, citing the need to eliminate chaotic and obsolete systems that favor vested interests. Analysts say the move will encourage competition, reduce costs, and attract global fintech companies, ultimately accelerating Malaysia's transition to a cashless economy. The review comes after the end of Puspakom's 30-year monopoly on commercial vehicle inspection services in August 2024.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Touch ‘n Go Group CEO Effendy Shahul Hamid said:”The collaboration will bring next-level value propositions to users and merchant bases across the Lazada and Touch ‘n Go ecosystem.”

site_title: Bank takeover prevented Swiss economy collapse: finance minister
summary: Switzerland's Finance Minister Karin Keller-Sutter says the government prevented a potential economic collapse by swiftly arranging the takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS. Without intervention, Credit Suisse would have gone bankrupt, causing a probable collapse of the Swiss economy. The government provided 109 billion Swiss francs in guarantees and liquidity to support the takeover, which was completed in just four days. Keller-Sutter acknowledged that the bank's culture and scandals contributed to its downfall, but it's too early to discuss potential executive accountability.

images.alt_text: Last month, Swiss authorities announced that UBS would buy Credit Suisse in a shotgun merger to stem further banking turmoil after the smaller lender had come to the brink of collapse.

site_title: Editor Jaime Ho says ST wants to encourage journalists to speak up and take collective ownership of their newsroom
summary: ST's new editor Jaime Ho aims to transform the national institution by encouraging journalists to speak up and take collective ownership of their newsroom. He seeks to inject efficiency, integration, and communication across teams and build a culture that attracts talent. Ho also aims to grow the spirit of diversity and openness, allowing for alternative viewpoints. He believes that the government's significant presence in ST's headlines can be balanced by focusing on stories that matter to Singaporeans' daily lives, not just government policies. Ho's door is open to collective decision-making and fostering a culture of openness and diversity.

images.alt_text: ‘I hope, at the very least, I bring a fresh set of eyes, to make changes not for the sake of making changes,' says Jaime Ho, ST editor.
The Straits Times staff working in the newly renovated newsroom on Jan 23, 2019.
Making change work is harder than change itself
While news is still our core, the new structure places audience strategy and product development as equally important elements and co-dependent with quality journalism.
Cross-functional BT stakeholders collaborating at a product design workshop in September 2022
Being a trusted news source is not enough. So what makes journalism worth paying for?

To cultivate these talents, media and journalism programmes in schools will need to make a culture shift towards developing audience-centric, product thinking mindsets and digital product management capabilities in students.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Stocks running but check your FOMO (Ep 30)
summary: The recent bank failures in the West are attributed to tighter monetary policy, but the Federal Reserve does not appear ready to cut interest rates immediately. The S&P500 and STI have shrugged off the bad news, and the Fed's latest comments suggest rate projections remain unchanged. Weaker REITs may succumb to financial stress, but investors should not chase the market at this point, as it could be a bad idea due to the lingering impact of interest rate rises.

site_title: Popular emerging market FX trade back with global rates peaking
summary: Emerging market currencies are poised to benefit from carry trades as investors seek higher yields amid a slowing US economy and peaking global interest rates. A Bloomberg gauge of US dollar-to-emerging currency borrowing has returned almost 5% this year, with some currencies like Brazil's and Mexico's offering attractive yields. The International Monetary Fund predicts that developing economies, particularly in Asia, will be a bright spot, and the right ingredients for carry trades to succeed are finally in place.

images.alt_text: In mid-morning trading, the US dollar index rose 0.2 per cent to 102.05.

site_title: Making the green transition just and welcome by all
summary: A just transition to net-zero greenhouse gas emissions is crucial as the world moves closer to 2050, but walking away from financing "dirty" businesses could deprive them of needed cash flow. A just transition requires a fair and inclusive approach to greening the economy, ensuring livelihoods remain secure and no one is left behind. Banks must balance commercial viability with societal needs, and clarity on transition pathways is essential for funding. UOB's approach emphasizes a whole-ecosystem approach, engaging with stakeholders to discuss transition pathways and shape regulations. The bank aims to lean into the challenge of transition, helping customers drive action and deliver real-economy decarbonisation in an inclusive way.

images.alt_text: A truck carries coal in Tabalong, Indonesia. Fitch expects the country's coal production levels to remain stable or grow moderately in the medium term.
Generic of UOB bank, at Raffles Place on Feb 23, 2023

United Overseas Bank announcing their decarbonisation targets on Monday (Oct 31). From left: Frederick Chin, UOB’s head of group wholesale and global markets, Wee Ee Cheong, UOB's chief executive officer, Eric Lim, UOB's chief sustainability officer, and Chan Kok Seong, UOB's chief risk officer.

site_title: Heroes or villains: Short sellers' role in the US bank crisis
summary: US short sellers' role in the recent bank crisis has sparked debate over their impact. While some argue that short sellers exacerbated the crisis by increasing bets against banks, others claim they were warning the markets about balance sheet issues. Data shows that short interest in some regional banks, such as First Republic and Silicon Valley Bank, increased before the crisis, but it was not the primary driver of the decline. Experts say the crisis was largely driven by depositor flight and underlying issues, with short sellers playing a smaller role.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: US election in 2024 won’t change Aukus plans, Australia PM says
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese stated that the country's agreement with the US to purchase nuclear-powered submarines will proceed regardless of the outcome of the 2024 US election. The Aukus security agreement, signed in 2021, will see the US and UK assist Australia in obtaining a fleet of nuclear submarines, with the first US Virginia-class vessels expected to arrive by the early 2030s. Albanese emphasized that the relationship between Australia and the US is based on shared values and not just between leaders, and that he is not concerned about the agreement being impacted by a potential Trump presidency.

site_title: Mirae should think twice about Manulife deal
summary: Mirae Asset Global Investments' proposed acquisition of Manulife US Reit's manager could lead to a dilutive placement and rights issue, potentially harming unitholders. The Reit's struggling property portfolio, excessive gearing, and discounted unit price make selling assets a more sensible option. Manulife US Reit's manager may lose its source of income if the deal goes through, and regulatory scrutiny is warranted. The deal could be a sign of rising standards for Reits, as seen in other Singapore-listed Reits that have successfully repositioned themselves with the support of their sponsor groups.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

“We're more engaged with our sponsor right now than we ever have been. They're really in the trenches with us at the moment,” said Tripp Gantt, CEO of the Reit manager, at Manulife US Reit's last earnings call on Feb 9.
Manulife US Real Estate Management, had received “multiple queries” on Monday following news of US regional banks’ troubles.

site_title: McDonald’s reduces some employees’ compensation amid job cuts
summary: McDonald's has reduced some employees' compensation as part of a restructuring that cost hundreds of workers their jobs. The company offered alternative pay packages to remaining employees, including bonuses and equity awards. This move follows a January announcement to cut corporate jobs and eliminate initiatives, with job cuts expected to be finalized by April 3. The restructuring affects approximately 150,000 McDonald's employees, who had about 150,000 employees at the end of 2022.

site_title: World Bank to advocate for changes to speed debt restructuring
summary: The World Bank will present concrete proposals to address debt restructuring roadblocks at the Global Sovereign Debt Roundtable. The proposals include sharing debt sustainability analysis with all creditors, accelerating restructuring with clear timelines, and suspending debt service payments to incentivize deals. The World Bank aims to resolve mounting debt problems of low-income countries, where over half are at high risk of debt distress or already in it, and several have defaulted. The proposals follow delays due to disagreements with China and other developed nations.

images.alt_text: Pakistan's Finance Minister Ishaq Dar was scheduled to attend the meetings from Apr 10 and see top IMF officials and multilateral creditors in a bid to secure stalled funding.

The World Bank says the reopening of Ukraine’s Black Sea ports and resumption of grain trade, as well as substantial donor support, are helping support economic activity this year, helping it grow by 0.5 per cent this year.
Banga is now in the final stages of the World Bank executive board’s selection process after emerging from a March nomination period as the sole candidate.

site_title: Philippine tycoon seeks up to US$125 million to expand hotel foray
summary: Philippine entrepreneur Edgar "Injap" Sia is seeking up to $125 million to expand his hotel chain, Hotel 101 Global, with plans to open properties in Madrid, the US, and other countries. The funds will be raised through private placement, and the company aims to have 25 properties in 25 countries by 2026. Hotel 101 Global's standardization of rooms at 21 square meters with a double bed and kitchen will be its selling point, with room rates typically 25% lower than competitors.

images.alt_text: Dolce & Gabbana said it would join forces with JDS Development Group in Miami and Sierra Blanca Estates in Marbella for the residential projects.

site_title: Fed traders eye CPI after jobs data boost odds of a May hike
summary: The US economy showed resilience despite recent banking turmoil, with a drop in unemployment and stronger-than-anticipated payrolls figures boosting the odds of a May interest-rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Swaps now show a more than two-in-three chance of a quarter-point rate increase, with Treasury yields advancing as the amount of policy tightening priced in increased to around 19 basis points. The upcoming consumer price index (CPI) reading will be closely watched to see if the Fed can beat back inflation, and concerns about the health of banks and the pace of credit creation will also be uppermost in investors' minds.

site_title: Enel agrees to sell two Peruvian assets to China’s CSGI for US$2.9 billion
summary: Enel, Italy's largest utility, has agreed to sell its Peruvian assets to China's CSGI for $2.9 billion. The deal will reduce Enel's consolidated debt by 3.1 billion euros this year and positively impact its reported net profit by 500 million euros. The sale includes Enel's 83.15% stake in power distribution and supply company Enel Distribucion Peru and 100% of Enel X Peru, which provides advanced energy services. The deal needs clearance from Peruvian and Chinese authorities before closing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Electric power transmission pylon miniatures and Enel logo are seen in this illustration taken, December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US Supreme Court justice defends lavish trips as ‘personal hospitality’
summary: US Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas has defended accepting luxury trips from Republican billionaire Harlan Crow, calling them "personal hospitality" that didn't need to be reported. Over 20 years, Thomas joined Crow for trips to a California wilderness resort, private jets, and stays at Crow's properties in the US, with one trip to Indonesia costing $500,000. Crow has made over $10 million in donations to Republican groups, including to a conservative lobbying group founded by Thomas' wife. The revelations have sparked outrage and calls for changes in the Supreme Court's operations.

images.alt_text: The charges could reshape the 2024 presidential race.

site_title: Bumitama Agri pays record dividend; expects higher palm oil prices in 2023
summary: Bumitama Agri, a palm oil company, has paid a record-high double dividend payout of S$0.0442 and S$0.0213 for its 2022 financial year, despite a 47.7% decline in earnings. The company's executive director, Christina Lim, attributed this to a "year of two halves" in 2022, with a price rally in the first half but a normalization of crude palm oil prices in the second half. Lim expects higher palm oil prices in 2023 due to factors such as rising input costs and a potential La Nina weather phenomenon, which could impact production.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The Indonesian palm oil producer

site_title: O&G industry’s clean-energy M&A takes back seat to shareholder rewards: Deloitte
summary: The oil and gas (O&G) industry's focus on mergers and acquisitions (M&A) related to clean energy has decreased as companies prioritize returning excess cash to shareholders. Despite a record $32 billion in clean-energy M&A deals in 2022, O&G companies spent more on rewarding shareholders, with $500 billion returned through dividends and buybacks. The industry's cash priority has shifted from investing for growth to sustainability-related factors, with a growing emphasis on ESG profiles and partnerships. Clean-energy deals now account for 15% of overall hydrocarbon M&A activity, with a focus on energy transition, energy security, and operational excellence.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Generics of DBS building
Petronas says it will continue to exercise prudent financial management and firm discipline in reinvesting.
Exxon energy transition plans lean heavily on reducing carbon emissions from its own operations, which it is spending US$10 billion by 2027 to implement.
Neste produces renewable fuels, mainly from waste and residues such as used cooking oil and animal fat from food industry waste.

site_title: S-Reits in STI end Q1 with 10% gains, outperform Index
summary: S-Reits in Singapore's STI index ended Q1 with 10% gains, outperforming the index. Despite a 0.7% decline in the iEdge S-Reit Index in March, S-Reits' year-to-date total returns remained at 4.3%, surpassing the STI's 0.8% YTD total returns. Key factors contributing to the outperformance include S-Reits' exposure to the US market and fund flows, with retail investors accumulating S$142 million and institutional investors net selling S$245 million in March.

images.alt_text: Cromwell European Reit (CEReit) is a pure-play Pan-European Reit with light industrial/logistics and office assets.

site_title: Opec+ shock revives oil bulls even as demand warnings flash
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) has implemented a surprise oil-production cut, sending shockwaves through financial markets and boosting crude prices to their highest in a year.
