Critics argue that the system benefits those with more resources, allowing them to "game the system" and widen the gap between the haves and have-nots. Researchers suggest that the system's assumptions, such as the idea that talent and capital are randomly distributed, no longer hold true. To address these issues, Singapore politicians propose improving the system by making it "open and compassionate," with a focus on providing equal opportunities and valuing everyone across society. However, some experts warn that attempting to reform the system too quickly could lead to unintended consequences, and that a more gradual approach may be needed.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Explaining the need to refresh Singapore’s social compact, Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said a social compact, broadly, is a shared understanding of how everyone in society relates to each other, as well as the respective roles and responsibilities of various groups.
Broaden and enhance meritocracy to give Singaporeans hope and opportunity: Ravi Menon

site_title: US: Stocks end quiet session higher
summary: US stocks ended a quiet session mostly higher on Thursday, closing at 33,485.29 for the Dow Jones Industrial Average, 4,105.02 for the S&P 500, and 12,087.96 for the Nasdaq Composite. Weakening economic data, including softening labor market and slowing growth in services, drove the gains. Investors remain hopeful that the Federal Reserve will hold off on additional interest rate hikes, fueling a rally. Markets will be closed on Friday for Good Friday, with March employment figures to be released on Monday.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: Russian companies snap up prize assets at bargains as western companies exit
summary: Western companies are exiting Russia due to sanctions and threats from the Kremlin, resulting in Russian companies snapping up prized assets at bargain prices. Deals include Renault selling its majority stake in Avtovaz to the Russian state, Societe Generale selling its Russia business Rosbank, and BASF taking a 7.3 billion euro writedown from its Wintershall Dea energy business. The moves are part of a broader corporate exodus, with companies such as Shell, AB InBev, and Inditex also selling their Russian businesses.

site_title: Musk puts US$14 trillion price tag on fossil fuels, US$10 trillion for clean energy
summary: Elon Musk estimates that transitioning to entirely carbon-free energy would require a $10 trillion investment, while continuing to rely on fossil fuels would cost approximately $14 trillion over the next 20 years. To achieve this, Tesla envisions a massive build-out of solar-panel factories and metal refineries, as well as a retooling of heavy industries and widespread adoption of heat pumps. Musk believes the investment is feasible, representing just 0.5% of the global economy over two decades.

images.alt_text: The UK’s major energy plan announced last week contained no firm plans to loosen planning restrictions that have choked development.

site_title: Shell comes clean on its new fuels
summary: Shell has introduced an improved fuel formulation, FuelSave, designed to clean engine interiors and restore efficiency. The new fuel can scrub an extra 300m from every liter on average, equivalent to 15km from a 50-liter tank. It works by clearing deposits from fuel injector nozzles and intake valves, reducing friction, and preventing corrosion. The reformulated fuel is available in 98, 95, and V-Power grades, with the latter containing three times the active ingredients. Shell aims to win market share from rivals by offering a product that can make engines use less fuel.

images.alt_text: This is the first wagon version of the M3 from BMW, and the result is a rocket with a huge payload.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on slowdown worries after jobless claims data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, April 6, 2023, due to concerns over a slowdown in economic growth. The Dow Jones fell 61.76 points, or 0.18%, to 33,420.96, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. A stronger-than-expected weekly jobless claims report pointed to the Federal Reserve's rapid interest rate hikes having a slowing effect on the economy.

site_title: Airbus to open 2nd plane assembly line in China, double output
summary: Airbus plans to open a second final assembly line in China, doubling its production capacity, with operations set to begin in late 2025. The new site in Tianjin will produce Airbus' popular A320 medium-haul jets. The move comes as demand for air travel grows in the Chinese market, driven by an expanding middle class. The existing Tianjin site currently produces four A320s a month, with plans to increase output to six a month this year.

site_title: ‘Powell’s curve’ plunges to new lows, flashing US recession warning
summary: The Federal Reserve's "Powell's curve" has plummeted to new lows, signaling a strong possibility of a US recession. The curve, which compares the 18-month Treasury yield with the current three-month Treasury bill yield, has been in negative territory since November and has dropped to nearly minus 170 basis points. This inversion, the most since 2007, has led market participants to bet on rate cuts later this year, citing tighter monetary policy's negative impact on growth.

images.alt_text: Global growth almost halved last year to 3.4 per cent as the impact of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine rippled through the world economy, abruptly halting the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

“Our assessment finds that illicit actors, including criminals, scammers, and North Korean cyber actors are using DeFi services in the process of laundering illicit funds,” the Treasury’s Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence, Brian Nelson, said in the statement.
The labour market is expected to loosen up in the second quarter as companies respond more to slowing demand triggered by the Federal Reserve’s interest rate increases.

site_title: Gold eases from 13-month high as US shows signs of slowdown
summary: Gold prices eased from a 13-month high as traders digested US economic data, including higher-than-expected initial jobless claims and slower-than-expected service sector growth. The data raised concerns of a looming recession, leading traders to increase bets on rate cuts later this year. This boosted non-yielding gold, which typically benefits from looser monetary policy. Spot gold declined 0.4% to $2,012.50 an ounce, while silver declined and palladium gained.

site_title: Australia cancels licence for Binance’s derivatives business
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has cancelled Binance's licence for its derivatives business in Australia, effective April 14. Binance will wind down its derivatives exchange, while the spot platform will remain open. The move follows a targeted review of the group's local operations, including the classification of retail and wholesale clients. ASIC Chair Joe Longo stated that it is "critically important" for licence holders to classify clients correctly. This decision comes after Binance faced regulatory warnings and action from overseas regulators, including the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

images.alt_text: “Vara wants to turn Dubai into a capital for the digital-assets economy while safeguarding its business ties with Western jurisdictions like Europe that are adopting more muscular crypto regulations,” said Sam Blatteis, CEO of The MENA Catalysts.

site_title: China must show it can play by world debt-revamp rules, says IMF chief
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says China must demonstrate its ability to operate within established international debt-relief processes for poor nations. China, the biggest bilateral creditor, has been slow to recognize the need for multilateral debt restructuring and has been reluctant to grant relief. Georgieva urged China to play by the rules in the Common Framework, a roadmap for restructuring debt from poor countries, during her visit to China. The issue is set to feature at the IMF and World Bank Spring Meetings next week, amid criticism from western nations, including the US, of Beijing's slow pace.

images.alt_text: New data shows that China is providing ever more emergency loans to countries, including Turkey, Argentina and Sri Lanka.

site_title: Data centre boom spreads across S-E Asia amid rising demand, Singapore moratorium
summary: Data centre operators in South-east Asia are capitalizing on the region's growing digital needs, with demand projected to grow 10-15% annually. Hotspots such as Batam, Indonesia, and Johor, Malaysia, are attracting investments as enterprises digitalize and move workloads to the cloud. However, Singapore's moratorium on new data centres has led operators to look elsewhere, with Batam and Johor emerging as key locations. The moratorium has driven up demand for power infrastructure, with data centres acting as anchor customers to make power projects viable, and governments and industry collaborating to site developments.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Equinix South Asia managing director Leong Yee May welcomed the increased capacity as larger data centres can benefit from economies of scale when employing advanced cooling techniques.
A groundbreaking ceremony at Singtel's new hyperscale data centre in Kabil Industrial Estate in Batam, Indonesia. The ceremony was jointly held by Singtel and partners Telkom and Medco Power.

site_title: The Finnish secret to happiness? Knowing when you have enough
summary: Finland, ranked the world's happiest country for six consecutive years, has a complex reality behind its top spot. Finns describe themselves as "quite gloomy" or "a little moody," and express concerns about threats to their way of life, including a far-right party's rise and climate change. Experts attribute Finland's happiness to its strong social safety net, nature's psychological benefits, and the freedom to pursue creative passions. However, Finns also acknowledge the pressure to live up to the national reputation and the potential risks of a warming planet. Ultimately, Finns seem to be more content than "happy," persevering in the face of challenges with a spirit of "sisu."

images.alt_text: Finland is world's happiest country despite Covid-19 pandemic: report
Finland's and Nato's flags fly in front of the Finnish Foreign Ministry building in Helsinki, Finland after the country became the 31st Nato member on 4 Apr 2023.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; layoffs jump in March
summary: US initial jobless claims fell 18,000 to 228,000 for the week ended April 1, despite a revision to prior data showing 48,000 more applications received. Economists had forecast 200,000 claims, and layoffs jumped 319% in March, with 89,703 job cuts announced. The labour market is expected to loosen up in the second quarter as companies respond to slowing demand triggered by the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases, potentially allowing the Fed to pause rate hikes.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - DECEMBER 02: A 'now hiring' sign is displayed in a window of a store in Manhattan on December 02, 2022 in New York City. The Labor Department reported Friday that non-farm payrolls increased by 263,000 for the month of November keeping the unemployment rate at 3.7%. Despite the Fed's attempt to cool inflation and the economy by gradually increasing interest rates, the U.S. economy continues to surge ahead.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The largest declines in vacancies were in business services, healthcare and social assistance, and transportation, warehousing and utilities.

site_title: World Bank says Ukraine, Russia boost Eastern Europe, Central Asia growth outlook
summary: The World Bank has lifted its 2023 economic growth forecast for Eastern Europe and Central Asia to 1.4%, citing improved outlooks for Russia and Ukraine despite their ongoing war. Ukraine's economy is expected to grow 0.5% this year, while Russia's economy is forecast to contract by 0.2%. The positive outlook is attributed to the reopening of Ukraine's Black Sea ports and resumption of grain trade, as well as substantial donor support. This revised forecast is a significant upgrade from the initial 0.1% prediction.

site_title: Robinhood to pay US$10 million to settle operational deficiency charges
summary: Robinhood Financial agreed to pay up to $10.2 million in penalties to several US states for operational deficiencies and platform outages in March 2020, which affected customers during pandemic-related volatility. The company also settled a proposed class action lawsuit filed by customers over the same outages. Robinhood neither admitted nor denied the states' findings, but stated it has since invested in improving customer care and technology. The settlement comes after an investigation by state securities regulators in multiple states.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Robinhood Markets, Inc. is seen at a pop-up event on Wall Street after the company's IPO in New York City, U.S., July 29, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Mercedes-AMG SL 55 review: Million-dollar monster
summary: The Mercedes-AMG SL 55 is a high-performance, two-tonne car with a 4.0-litre V8 engine producing 476 horsepower. It features four-wheel steering and four-wheel drive, as well as an active aerodynamics system to stabilize at high speeds. The car corners aggressively and blasts out of corners with surefootedness. With a price tag of over $1 million, the SL 55 is a million-dollar monster that demands a firm, skilled hand to drive. It stacks up against rivals like the BMW M850i Convertible and Audi R8 V10 Spyder, offering a unique blend of performance, tech, and luxury.

images.alt_text: This is the first wagon version of the M3 from BMW, and the result is a rocket with a huge payload.

site_title: India startups call for antitrust probe of Google in-app billing fee
summary: Indian startups have filed an antitrust complaint with the Competition Commission of India (CCI) against Google, alleging the US company is bypassing an antitrust directive by charging high service fees for in-app payments. The Alliance of Digital India Foundation (ADIF) claims this policy hurts smaller players and imposes unfair conditions. Google previously said the service fee supports investments in its app store and operating system, but ADIF argues it's detrimental to users and developers.

images.alt_text: In the US, companies can announce widespread job cuts and let go of hundreds if not thousands of workers within months — and many have.
Google has designed its own custom chip called the Tensor Processing Unit, or TPU.

site_title: IMF's Georgieva sees global growth below 3% in 2023,  robust recovery 'elusive'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has forecast global economic growth to dip below 3% in 2023 and remain around 3% for the next five years, the lowest since 1990. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva attributed this to high inflation and rising geopolitical tensions, making a robust recovery "elusive." India and China are expected to account for half of global growth, but 90% of advanced economies will see a decline in growth rate this year. Georgieva called for major steps to boost growth and productivity, including increased spending on renewable energy and measures to avoid global fragmentation.

images.alt_text: Pakistan's talks with the IMF for a delayed US$1.1 billion loan tranche, part of US$6.5 billion bailout agreed in 2019, have dragged on and foreign exchange reserves have fallen to less than four weeks of imports.

site_title: Honda recalls SUVs in cold weather US states over rust risk
summary: Honda is recalling 563,000 2007-2011 CR-V SUVs in cold-weather US states due to a risk of frame corrosion caused by road salt. The recall affects 22 states and the District of Columbia, and dealers will inspect and install a support brace or repair the rear frame free of charge. Honda may repurchase vehicles depending on the extent of damage, and no reports of fatalities or injuries have been reported. This is not the first recall for the issue, having affected nearly 84,000 Canadian vehicles in 2019.

images.alt_text: The NHTSA said owners of those vehicles should not drive them until they get repairs, warning “the risk to vehicle occupants is dire”.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as banking gains offset US recession jitters
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, posting its third consecutive weekly gain, driven by real estate and travel stocks. Despite US recession jitters triggered by lacklustre data, European equities remain under pressure due to ongoing banking turmoil. The European Central Bank is expected to continue rate hikes in its next policy meeting, with ECB chief economist Philip Lane warning of rising food price inflation. Markets will be closed on Friday and Monday due to Easter holidays.

site_title: UK antitrust regulator looks at Amazon’s takeover of vacuum maker iRobot
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is reviewing Amazon's planned $1.7 billion acquisition of iRobot, a maker of robot vacuums, to determine if it could reduce competition in the connected device market. The deal is also being reviewed by the US Federal Trade Commission. The CMA is now open to comments on the acquisition, which aims to expand Amazon's smart home devices.

site_title: Raffles Education units awarded S$2.9 million in damages against defendants in India Educomp case
summary: Raffles Education Group has been awarded S$2.9 million in damages by the Singapore High Court against Educomp founder Shantanu Prakash and Singapore lawyer Dennis Lui. The defendants were found liable for fraudulent misrepresentation and conspiring to injure Raffles Education. The judgement also ordered Prakash and Lui to pay S$221,080 and S$2.65 million respectively, with interest. The case revolves around a 2006 joint venture between Raffles Education and Educomp that never materialized.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
In its filing, the group said it intends to “rigorously defend its position”. There is also a “good chance” of having the case quashed, according to its legal counsel in India.
Raffles Education has said that is it in compliance with board diversity policies in a response to SGX Regco queries

site_title: Macron calls on Xi to reason with Russia for Ukraine peace
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron urged Chinese President Xi Jinping to reason with Russia and help end the Ukraine war, warning that the conflict has dealt a blow to international stability. Xi responded by calling for Ukraine and Russia to resume peace talks and find a political solution. Macron also asked Xi to press Russia to comply with international rules on nuclear proliferation. The EU leaders' visit to China comes amid strained relations between Europe and Beijing, but Macron emphasized the need to resist reducing trade and diplomatic ties with China.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron on his first trip to China since 2019, spoke to US President Joe Biden before the visit about trying to engage Chinese President Xi Jinping on hastening the end of the war in Ukraine started by Beijing’s close ally Russia.

site_title: Domestic coffee prices edge higher in Vietnam on scarce supplies
summary: Vietnam's domestic coffee prices have reached their highest level in years due to a scarcity of beans, with prices ranging from 48,800 to 51,000 dong per kilogram. This follows higher prices in London, where traders are tracking the limited stocks. The increased prices are attributed to the limited supply of beans in Vietnam's central highlands, the country's largest coffee-growing area.

site_title: House of Progress offers peek at future of luxury
summary: Audi's House of Progress pop-up in Singapore showcases the brand's vision for the future of luxury mobility, featuring self-driving electric vehicles. The space highlights Audi's focus on design, performance, digitalization, and sustainability. The Audi grandsphere concept car, on display, hints at a future where cars are fully self-driving and purely electric, with a sleek, cigar-shaped silhouette and a lounge-like interior. The concept's design elements could potentially influence production cars, offering a more sophisticated and beautiful driving experience.

images.alt_text: The Niro EV, a pure electric version, not only ticks all the boxes on the list of things you expect from a family crossover, it zips around without tailpipe emissions (which is hardly surprising since it doesn’t even have a tailpipe).

site_title: Tannat: Uruguay’s ‘unlikely’ wine hit
summary: Uruguay has become a global wine destination with the success of its Tannat grape, a red wine known for its harshness. Originating from France, Tannat thrived in Uruguay's mild, humid climate and carnivorous inhabitants. High in astringent tannins, the grape was once considered undesirable but has now gained popularity, thrusting Uruguay onto the global wine map.

site_title: Iras probing property transactions for stamp duty tax avoidance
summary: Iras is investigating property transactions for potential stamp duty tax avoidance through "various forms of property holding arrangements", including contrived or artificial arrangements to reduce or avoid buyer's stamp duty (ABSD). The agency is looking into scenarios where buyers purchase properties under such arrangements to avoid paying additional stamp duties. The investigation is a response to reports of a "99-to-1" sales contract being used to avoid ABSD.

images.alt_text: All taxpayers, including sole-proprietors and partners, will be required to file their income tax returns before Apr 18 this year to avoid the higher penalties for late filing.

PropNex is urging for the additional buyer’s stamp duty remission treatment for married couples upgrading from HDB flats to private homes to be aligned with that of those upgrading to new executive condominiums from developers.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH initiates coverage on RH PetroGas with ‘buy’
summary: UOB Kay Hian initiated coverage on RH PetroGas with a "buy" call, citing the company's growth of oil and gas reserves without acquisitions and plans to drill three wells this year. The brokerage set a target price of S$0.255, implying a 27.5% upside from the last traded price. Analysts noted the company is trading at a discount to regional peers.

images.alt_text: RH Petrogas CEO and executive director Francis Chang Cheng-Hsing
RH Petrogas, Rex International actively traded as oil prices surge

site_title: UK house-building falls by most since 2020 as interest rates bite: PMI
summary: The UK's construction PMI slowed down in March due to a fourth consecutive monthly fall in house-building, the fastest rate since May 2020. The S&P Global-CIPS construction PMI fell to 50.7, down from 54.6 in February, indicating modest growth. Despite concerns about the near-term outlook, expectations for total construction output were relatively upbeat for the year ahead.

images.alt_text: epa10498611 A row of houses in London, Britain, 02 March 2023. UK house prices in February dropped by the most in more than 10 years according to mortgage lender Nationwide showing signs of a slowdown in the housing market due to high inflation and rising borrowing costs.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL
While demand for homes is far weaker than this time last year, it’s on the road to recovery from the shock rise in mortgage rates after September’s mini-budget.

site_title: Up to US$520 billion in debt write-offs needed for emerging nations’ climate goals
summary: A Boston University report estimates that up to $520 billion in debt needs to be written off to help developing nations meet climate and development goals. This debt write-off is essential to avoid "cascading defaults" among 61 debt-distressed nations, including Pakistan, Ethiopia, and Malawi. The debt relief is crucial to avoid financial strain and allow these nations to implement projects to cut emissions and bolster climate resilience, which is critical due to the correlation between debt distress and climate vulnerability.

site_title: Sembmarine a candidate for STI inclusion as market cap rises post merger
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a subsidiary of Sembcorp Group, has increased its market cap to S$8.2 billion after acquiring Keppel Offshore & Marine, making it the largest counter on the Straits Times Index (STI) reserve list. With a market capitalization of S$8.2 billion, Sembmarine is a strong candidate for inclusion in the STI, pending its performance in the coming months. If included, the smallest index counter would face deletion, with Keppel DC Reit and Sats being potential candidates for removal.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
A signage of Sembcorp Marine.

Seatrium is a combination of the words “sea” and “atrium”, which reflects the business and its aspiration to be a premier global player providing innovative engineering solutions for the offshore, marine and energy industries, said Sembmarine.
Since mid-March, Sats shares have been rebounding. It closed Monday (Apr 3) at $2.78, representing a 16.8 per cent gain from its Mar 14 close.

site_title: Aviation leasing watchdog issues warning on Vietnam after jet dispute
summary: A UK-based aviation watchdog has issued a warning about Vietnam's compliance with international aircraft leasing norms, citing a dispute over the repossession of four jets. The Aviation Working Group placed Vietnam on a watchlist after a Hanoi court blocked an attempt to seize jets due to an alleged rental payment default. Vietnam is one of the world's fastest-growing air travel markets, with hundreds of jets on order. The warning raises questions over the cost of financing future deliveries under the Cape Town Convention treaty.

site_title: India pauses rate hikes in surprise decision, but door open for more
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) surprised markets by holding its key repo rate steady for the first time in six consecutive hikes, citing close monitoring of global financial turbulence. RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das stated it's a "pause, not a pivot," leaving the door open for further rate hikes if necessary. This decision is seen as a signal that the central bank may remain on hold, with many economists now expecting no further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Some analysts expect the United States to continue hiking rates to curb inflation, while others believe that the ongoing crisis may prompt the Federal Reserve to either slow down or hit the brakes temporarily.

site_title: RBA says banks are strong, households resilient to higher rates
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has released a stability review stating that Australia's lenders are "unquestionably strong" and well-positioned to cope with higher interest rates and inflation. The global banking sector is stronger than a decade ago, and higher rates are a trigger, not a cause, of stress. The RBA highlights that Australian households and firms are resilient to higher rates, and banks are well-regulated, capitalized, profitable, and liquid.

images.alt_text: Australia last week passed legislation targeting 4.9 per cent annual cuts in emissions from its most-polluting industrial facilities, including from the massive LNG plants.
The country is expected to face a shortage of more than 100,000 homes over the next five years.

A person enters the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Feb. 6, 2023. Australia's central bank is all but certain to increase interest rates at its first meeting of the year, with some observers pointing to the risk of a resumption of outsized moves to counter a surprising surge in inflation. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia open to reviving high-speed rail project to Singapore, says minister
summary: Malaysia is open to reviving a high-speed rail project to Singapore, but it must be led by the private sector, according to the country's trade minister. The project was previously abandoned in 2021 after Malaysia and Singapore failed to agree on changes, with Malaysia paying US$77.30 million to Singapore for its termination. The US$17-billion project aims to connect Kuala Lumpur to Singapore, spanning 350km. The revived project's details are yet to be disclosed.

images.alt_text: Former Malaysian prime ministers Mahathir Mohamad (left) and Muhyiddin Yassin have been accused by a Malaysian man of negligence and tort of misfeasance in public office.

site_title: US dollar bobs near 2-month low ahead of pivotal US jobs data
summary: The US dollar index hovered near a two-month low ahead of Friday's highly anticipated US jobs data, which may impact Federal Reserve policy. Economists expect non-farm payrolls to have grown 239,000 in March, following February's 311,000 gain. A miss could lead to market volatility and potentially boost the US dollar's appeal as a safe-haven currency, with some analysts advising traders to "steer clear" of markets on Good Friday.

site_title: China officials flock to Twitter to defend TikTok
summary: Chinese officials have taken to Twitter to defend TikTok, attacking US lawmakers as "old, tech-illiterate, out of touch, paranoid and self-righteous" after a congressional hearing criticized the app's ties to China. The hearing, where TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi testified, was met with a surge of tweets from Chinese diplomats and state media outlets, accusing the US of hypocrisy and xenophobia. China's Commerce Ministry also rebuked the Biden administration's push for a sale of TikTok. The campaign reflects the deteriorating relations between the US and China.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - MARCH 23: TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew testifies before the House Energy and Commerce Committee in the Rayburn House Office Building on Capitol Hill on March 23, 2023 in Washington, DC. The hearing was a rare opportunity for lawmakers to question the leader of the short-form social media video app about the company's relationship with its Chinese owner, ByteDance, and how they handle users' sensitive personal data. Some local, state, and federal government agencies have been banning the use of TikTok by employees, citing concerns about national security.   Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by CHIP SOMODEVILLA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: ‘A new starting point’: EU and Chinese leaders begin talks
summary: European Union leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, began a series of talks with Chinese leaders in Beijing, aiming to set a new course for EU-China relations. The talks come after strained ties over issues such as human rights abuses, investment pacts, and Russia's Ukraine invasion. Macron and von der Leyen met with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang, respectively, with a focus on economic and trade cooperation, as well as efforts to persuade China to use its influence to bring about peace in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and French President Emmanuel Macron attend a signing ceremony at the Great Hall of the People, in Beijing, China, April 6, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes

site_title: Seven & i board promises to continue strategic review amid investor pressure
summary: Seven & i Holdings' board has announced it will continue reviewing strategic alternatives, including a possible initial public offering or spin-off, amid pressure from shareholders, particularly ValueAct Capital. ValueAct is seeking a spin-off of its 7-Eleven convenience store chain and replacement of four board members at the upcoming annual meeting. The eight independent directors stated that the board will examine optimal group structure and strategic alternatives to address shareholder concerns.

site_title: The ‘social’ element in the ESG puzzle
summary: Unilever launched an online platform to gather ideas on how to improve its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance, highlighting the "social" element in the ESG puzzle. Companies like Nike and Jardine Matheson are also engaging with stakeholders to understand their needs and concerns, and leveraging community input to drive positive change. Measuring the social element's impact is challenging due to its qualitative nature, but companies can identify proxies such as employee satisfaction, word-of-mouth reputation, and community engagement to gauge success. By fostering diversity and inclusion, engaging stakeholders, and demonstrating transparency and accountability, companies can advance the social element of the ESG story.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Unilever is seen at the headquarters in Rotterdam, Netherlands August 21, 2018. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw/File Photo

site_title: The financial turmoil is not over
summary: Financial turmoil is expected to persist in 2023, with a focus on reducing capital quantity rather than repricing it. The recent bank failures have raised concerns about systemic risk, which is seen as multiplicative. Policymakers' emphasis on large institutions has led to a blind spot for smaller, less regulated entities that are more vulnerable to crisis. The real estate market is also a potential flashpoint due to the impact of higher interest rates on residential property prices. Investors should be cautious and prepared for potential systemic risks.

images.alt_text: Vice chair for supervision of the Federal Reserve Michael Barr (L), with chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) Martin Gruenberg (R), testify during the House Committee on Financial Services hearing on the recent bank failures on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC,  March 29, 2023.

“We must ensure that our bank regulatory policies and supervision are appropriate for the risks and challenges that banks face today,” Nellie Liang (far right), the Treasury undersecretary for domestic finance, said in her testimony to the committee.
The big question now is how much longer it will take the Fed and other major central banks to get inflation under control

site_title: Norway housing prices extend gains, adding to rate pressure
summary: Norway's housing prices rose 0.5% in March, defying Norges Bank's forecasts. This is the fourth consecutive month of gains, as the central bank tries to control inflation. Despite expected interest-rate hikes, chief economist Marius Gonsholt Hov predicts a "soft landing" for the housing market this year. In contrast, Sweden and Denmark are experiencing housing market downturns, with declines of up to 25%. A limited supply of new homes and elevated wages are cited as factors cushioning the blow in Norway.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: Jardine Strategic’s appeal to strike out claims from shareholders seeking arbitrage profit dismissed
summary: The Bermuda Court of Appeal dismissed Jardine Strategic's appeal to strike out claims from shareholders seeking arbitrage profit, ruling that arbitrage is a legitimate part of the marketplace and contributes to liquidity. Arbitrageurs bought Jardine Strategic's shares after its US$33 price was announced, hoping the fair value would be higher later. The court upheld the fair value as at the date of amalgamation, not the date of purchase. The decision allows shareholders to seek arbitrage profit from the buyout.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Jardine Strategic acquisition completed; shares to delist from three exchanges
Jardine Strategic acquisition to go ahead; resolution passed at special general meeting
Boards should address undervaluation of their shares to ensure fairer treatment of minorities
Offer price for Jardine Strategic will not be raised: Jardine Matheson
Minority shareholders, independent directors can do more to oppose lowball buyout offers
Sias organising representation for Jardine Strategic shareholders in Bermuda court
Jardine Strategic acquisition: A shortfall of corporate governance
Jardine Matheson's offer for Jardine Strategic has room to be improved
Jardine Strategic offer is 30% off net asset value; deal could affect ST Index
Offer price for Jardine Strategic at significant discount to NAV

site_title: Hong Kong’s Fung Group weighs retail unit IPO in Singapore, say sources
summary: The Fung Group, a Hong Kong-based consumer goods company, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore for its retail brands unit, Branded Lifestyle Asia. The IPO could value the business at around $500 million and raise over $100 million. Branded Lifestyle Asia operates 446 stores in South Korea and Taiwan and plans to expand across Southeast Asia. This would be Singapore's first IPO of the year, following a sluggish start, and could catalyze the city-state's market.

images.alt_text: SGX welcomed 11 new listings in 2022. The companies raised a total of S$580.3 million, according to bourse data.

site_title: Switzerland to cancel, cut top Credit Suisse executives’ bonuses
summary: Credit Suisse Group executives will have outstanding bonuses cancelled or cut by up to half, according to a step ordered by the Swiss government following the state-backed takeover by UBS Group. This affects around 1,000 employees and bonuses worth between 50 million and 60 million Swiss francs. The measures include cancelling variable remuneration for top executives, reducing it by 50% for those one level below, and 25% for those two levels below. The changes aim to address the discrepancy between bonuses and profits at the firm.

images.alt_text: The judge had ruled in Credit Suisse’s favour without a trial at a hearing last month.
Chairman Colm Kelleher told UBS shareholders the merger also meant “a new beginning and huge opportunities ahead for the combined bank and for the Swiss financial centre as a whole.”
Bank sees room to expand its deals business in Asia and is looking to hire selectively, the lender’s regional head of investment banking said in November.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS has contributed US$60 million to a syndicated loan to Santos, an Australian energy company operating the Barossa project. This move highlights the growing litigation risks for banks over environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues. Meanwhile, HDB resale prices rose 0.5% in March after easing in February, and economic growth in Asean plus China is expected to be "robust" in 2023, with China leading the rebound, according to the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office.

site_title: DBS’ inclusion in Australian human rights complaint spotlights banks’ rising ESG litigation risks
summary: DBS, along with 11 other international banks, is facing a human rights complaint in Australia over its role in financing the Barossa gas project, which has caused environmental and human rights impacts. The complaint, filed by indigenous Australians, seeks the banks to withdraw a $1 billion syndicated loan to Santos, which operates the project. DBS contributed $60 million to the loan, while UOB provided $50 million. The complaint highlights the growing ESG litigation risks for financial institutions, with experts warning that banks may face costly litigation if they fail to address human rights and environmental concerns.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Generic of UOB bank, at Raffles Place on Feb 23, 2023

site_title: China deploys warships near Taiwan after Tsai-McCarthy meeting
summary: China has deployed warships near Taiwan after US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy met with Taiwan leader Tsai Ing-wen, despite China's repeated warnings against the meeting. Three warships were detected in waters separating Taiwan from mainland China, and an anti-submarine helicopter crossed Taiwan's air defense identification zone. China views Taiwan as part of its territory and has vowed to seize it by force if necessary. The US has reaffirmed its support for Taiwan, with McCarthy vowing to continue US arms sales to the island.

images.alt_text: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen met with a delegation of US politicians from the Republican and Democratic parties during a stopover in the United States on Wednesday.

site_title: German industrial output rises more than expected in February
summary: German industrial production rose 2.0% in February, exceeding expectations of a 0.1% increase. Manufacturing of motor vehicles, the largest industrial sector, posted a 7.6% month-on-month increase. The revised January figure showed a 3.7% increase, bringing the adjusted index of production since December 2022 to a 5.8% gain. Despite this, industrial production remains slightly below its pre-pandemic level. Analysts expect further growth in the coming months due to a high backlog of orders, lower energy prices, and easing supply constraints.

site_title: Iran, Saudi Arabia sign statement on re-establishing ties
summary: Iran and Saudi Arabia have signed a statement to re-establish diplomatic ties, with the agreement stipulating a two-month period for the restoration of relations. The two countries will resume flights, bilateral visits, and facilitate visa issuance for citizens. The agreement, facilitated by China, focuses on stability, sustainable security, and regional development. Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian described the meeting as "positive" and emphasized the importance of cooperation on these issues. The move marks a significant shift after years of hostility between the two nations.

site_title: DBS faces pressure from green activists
summary: DBS faces a human rights grievance complaint from a group of indigenous Australians regarding its role in financing the Barossa gas project in Australia's Northern Territory. The project, operated by Santos, involves drilling and pipeline construction in waters off the Tiwi Islands, threatening sacred sites and cultural practices, as well as causing environmental harm. The complaint, filed through Equity Generation Lawyers, calls for banks to withdraw the $1 billion syndicated loan to Santos. This comes weeks after UOB was reported to have refinanced a $350 million loan to a coal miner's subsidiary, highlighting growing ESG litigation risks for financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Generics of DBS building
Generic of UOB bank, at Raffles Place on Feb 23, 2023

site_title: China plans US$500 million subsea Internet cable to rival US-backed project
summary: China is developing a $500 million undersea Internet cable network, known as EMA, which would link Asia, the Middle East, and Europe, rivaling a similar US-backed project. The network, to be built by China's HMN Technologies, will connect Hong Kong to China's Hainan island and then to Singapore, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and France. The project is seen as a strategic move by China to counter US influence in the global Internet infrastructure, with the three main Chinese telecom firms expected to own more than half of the network.

images.alt_text: US recommends approving Google, Meta undersea data cable to Asia

site_title: European golf tour wins legal battle against rebel LIV players
summary: The DP World Tour has won a legal battle against 12 golfers who played in LIV Golf events without permission. The arbitration panel ruled that the players committed "serious breaches" of the DPWT's code of behavior by competing despite denied release requests. The players were initially fined £100,000 and suspended from the Scottish Open. The decision was made by Sports Resolutions UK in February, and the players have been ordered to pay the fines. DP World Tour CEO Keith Pelley welcomed the decision, stating it upholds the tour's regulations and fair process.

site_title: Singapore imports of Russian naphtha surge as EU ban shifts flows
summary: Singapore's imports of Russian naphtha nearly tripled to 741,000 tonnes in the first quarter of 2023, accounting for 23% of the country's total imports, after the European Union banned oil product imports from Russia. The EU cap on Russian naphtha trade and a US$45 price cap have shifted global oil trade flows. Meanwhile, Singapore's total exports of naphtha rose to 946,000 tonnes, a 26% increase from the previous quarter, with South Korea, China, Taiwan, and Japan being key buyers.

images.alt_text: Russian crude oil and fuel flows to Asia and the Middle East have surged since Moscow’s war in Ukraine prompted western buyers to turn away in retaliation. Such shipments have increasingly made their way to blending and redistribution hubs like Singapore and Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Hong Kong’s dining scene plays catch-up with lifting of mask mandate
summary: Hong Kong's dining scene has rebounded after the lifting of the city's mask mandate, with restaurants buzzing again as tourists and locals flock to both established names and new ones. Bookings at Grand Hyatt Hong Kong have grown, and hotels like Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong are expecting a significant bump in international leisure travel. Local diners have noticed a return to pre-pandemic normalcy, with many restaurants reporting increased business. However, the industry still faces challenges, including a shortage of staff, with many restaurants struggling to find and retain talent. Despite this, restaurateurs remain optimistic, citing the city's strong dining variety and concepts.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: Chudaree (Tam) Debhakam, Pichaya “Pam” Utharntharm, Tamara Chavez, Natsuko Shoji, Vicky Lau and Kim Bo-mi.

site_title: Art mirrors luxury: NFTs are out, Warhol is back in
summary: Global art sales reached $67.8 billion in 2022, a 3% increase from 2021, driven by the US market. Notably, Andy Warhol's "Shot Sage Blue Marilyn" sold for $195 million in New York, becoming the second-most expensive work ever sold at auction. The art market's focus on luxury and high-end items mirrors the global luxury sector, with wealthy individuals collecting art alongside expensive items like Dior handbags and Cartier watches.

images.alt_text: epa10558008 A visitor looks at 'EG, 1984-1985' (L) and 'Bananas, 1985' by American artists Jean-Michel Basquiat and Andy Warhol on display at the 'Basquiat x Warhol' exhibition at the Louis Vuitton Foundation in Paris, France, 04 April 2023. The exhibition of works created by two American visual artists Andy Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat showing their collaboration, runs from 05 April to 28 August 2023.  EPA-EFE/MOHAMMED BADRA

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Nordic Group, OCBC
summary: Several Singaporean companies saw new developments affecting their securities. Singtel halted trading pending an announcement, while Nordic Group secured contracts totaling S$22.6 million, expected to have minimal impact on its earnings. OCBC launched a metaverse initiative, OCBCx65Chulia, to improve financial literacy and access its banking services. These developments may impact trading of Singtel, Nordic Group, and OCBC shares.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Stripe says volume growth slowed even with more large customers
summary: Stripe's payments volume growth slowed to 26% in 2022, down from 60% in 2021, despite a surge in large business clients. The company now handles over $817 billion in payments annually, with more than 100 companies reaching this milestone. Stripe's growth has been impacted by the post-pandemic normalization of e-commerce, with the company expressing satisfaction with its 2022 performance.

images.alt_text: Stripe emphasised that it “does not need this capital to run its business”.

site_title: UK house prices rise for 3rd month in a row
summary: UK house prices rose for a third consecutive month in March, with a 0.8% increase, according to Halifax. This marks a calming of the market after the turmoil caused by former Prime Minister Liz Truss's "mini-budget" last September. House prices are 1.6% higher than a year ago, and mortgage costs are unlikely to decrease in the short-term due to the Bank of England's interest rate hikes. Experts expect the housing market to continue slowing down this year.

images.alt_text: While demand for homes is far weaker than this time last year, it’s on the road to recovery from the shock rise in mortgage rates after September’s mini-budget.

site_title: Iran oil snapped up by Chinese private refiners as market shifts
summary: China's private refiners, also known as "teapots," are increasing their imports of Iranian oil amid rising competition from Russia. In March, China's imports of Iranian crude and condensate jumped 20% month-on-month to 800,000 barrels a day. This trend is expected to continue as Russian supplies become more expensive. The shift is driven by mainstream buyers such as state-owned Chinese refiners and Indian processors taking a larger share of Russian supplies.

images.alt_text: Opec+ has fixed production quotas for the year ahead after making sharp output cuts.

site_title: STI snaps 4-day winning streak ahead of Good Friday holiday
summary: The Singapore Stock Index (STI) fell 18.39 points or 0.6% to 3,300.48 on Thursday, snapping a four-day winning streak ahead of the Good Friday holiday. The decline was attributed to weak US data prints and concerns over the Federal Reserve's tightening trajectory. Most regional markets also fell, except for China and Hong Kong, which posted marginal gains. Despite this, Singapore's market is considered a "safe harbour" with forecasted earnings growth of 15.8% and 4.3% for 2023 and 2024, respectively.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
While traders have long hoped for a tightening of the labour market and an economic slowdown that would allow the Fed to stop lifting rates, there is now a rising concern of a deep recession.
The weak data helped push the US 10-Year Treasury yield under 3.30 per cent.

site_title: Robert Kennedy Jr files to run for US president
summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a 69-year-old environmental lawyer and vaccine skeptic, has filed paperwork to run for US president as a Democrat. He has set up a website to solicit donations and volunteers, but has not made a formal announcement. Kennedy's campaign is seen as a long-shot challenge to President Joe Biden, despite his past criticism from the Democratic mainstream and public rebuke from his family. Kennedy's top priority, if he becomes a candidate, will be to "end the corrupt merger between state and corporate power."

images.alt_text: Former US president Donald Trump arrives for his arraignment at Manhattan Criminal Court on April 04, 2023 in New York City.

site_title: US recession signal sets off global rush into Indonesian bonds
summary: Indonesia's bonds have seen a surge in inflows as investors bet on a potential US recession and a dovish pivot at the Federal Reserve, boosting the rupiah's value. Global funds snapped up $3.5 billion of Indonesian debt last quarter, the most in four years. The rupiah is expected to gain from higher oil prices following Opec+'s output trim. Analysts see a constructive outlook for the rupiah-government-bond market due to benign inflation, a comfortable fiscal position, and sufficient domestic bond demand.

site_title: Singapore plans new guidance for banks on vetting crypto clients
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority and police are working with banks to establish uniform standards for vetting crypto and digital assets clients. The project, which has been ongoing for six months, aims to improve due diligence and risk management practices. An industry report outlining best practices is expected to be published in the next two months. The move follows global industry fallouts and aims to enhance financial stability in the sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is pictured at its building in Singapore in this February 21, 2013 file photo.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo/File Photo
Bloomberg News reported in November that Sun allegedly paid about US$1 billion through a Hong Kong-based asset manager for a controlling stake in Huobi.
US authorities seized the assets of SVB, after a run on deposits made it unsustainable on its own. Its failure sparked a run on First Republic and other smaller regional US banks.
Sydney-based Independent Reserve has just officially launched a new platform, Bitcoin.com.au, after purchasing the domain name in a A$3 million deal last year.
Changpeng Zhao, who has an estimated net worth of almost US$28 billion, bought a home in Dubai in 2021 in what he said was a show of support for a city he describes as “very pro-crypto”.

site_title: IMF warns geopolitical fragmentation could raise financial stability risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that rising geopolitical tensions and the fragmentation of the global economy into blocs could increase financial stability risks, reducing cross-border investments and asset prices. This could lead to reduced trade, competing technology systems, and higher interest rates on government bonds, ultimately driving up funding costs for banks and reducing lending. To mitigate these risks, the IMF recommends that policymakers strengthen crisis management frameworks, build stronger regional safety nets, and encourage international cooperation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) headquarters building is seen ahead of the IMF/World Bank spring meetings in Washington, U.S., April 8, 2019. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

site_title: Art sales surpass pre-pandemic levels to hit record highs
summary: The global art market surpassed pre-pandemic levels, reaching an estimated $67.8 billion in 2022, with a 3% year-over-year growth. High-end art sales drove the growth, with luxury items such as Wassily Kandinsky's Murnau Mit Kirche II selling for approximately $45 million. In contrast, the NFT art market declined by 50%. This report, published by Art Basel and UBS, marks a significant recovery for the art market, defying expectations and ending on a higher note than in 2019.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Art Basel Hong Kong's sizzling sales figures reaffirm the city's pole position as an art hub.
Spectrosynthesis III at Tai Kwun is one of the best exhibitions in Hong Kong right now.

site_title: China tax department says economy’s rebound to be further consolidated
summary: China's tax department expects the country's economy to continue its rebound, with tax revenues growing faster in the second quarter due to low base and concentrated tax credits from last year. The government has cut fees and taxes by over 1.8 trillion yuan, and will extend these favorable policies until the end of 2024. Despite the economic growth, the country still faces uncertainties at home and abroad, with a modest target of 5% economic growth for this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view shows traffic during evening rush hour at the central business district (CBD) in Beijing, China, January 15, 2021. Picture taken January 15, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Rising labour and raw material costs pushed up input prices at the end of the first quarter.
Former chairman and party chief of state-owned China Everbright Group Li Xiaopeng is suspected of “serious violations of discipline and law”.

site_title: Japanese investors flock to foreign stocks as banking fears ease
summary: Japanese investors purchased 390.3 billion yen (S$3.94 billion) worth of foreign equities last week, marking the biggest weekly net buying in eleven weeks. This surge is attributed to easing concerns about banking sector troubles and hopes that the Federal Reserve may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking cycle. Following a US regulator-backed sale of Silicon Valley Bank's assets, market worries about the banking system have decreased.

images.alt_text: Foreign investors bought a net 4.096 trillion yen (S$41.7 billion) worth of Japanese government bonds (JGB) with maturities of more than one year in the week ended March 18 – the largest amount since the ministry began publishing data in 2005.

site_title: HDB launches largest solar leasing tender
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched its largest solar leasing tender, aiming to install solar panels in over 1,075 HDB blocks and 104 government sites across Singapore. The tender, valued at 113 megawatt-peak (MWp), will cover sites including 55 schools, 22 Ministry of Defence sites, and 14 heartland malls. This marks the largest solar leasing tender by the HDB to date, building on the existing 3,300 HDB blocks equipped with solar panels.

images.alt_text: Commissioned in six months, the Sembcorp ESS (energy storage system) is Southeast Asia’s largest ESS and is the fastest in the world of its size to be deployed
Alpina unit bags S$117 million HDB project to build solar panels

site_title: Jeon Wick: South Korea takes on assassin action with Kill Boksoon
summary: South Korean filmmaker Byun Sung-hyun's "Kill Boksoon" stars Jeon Do-yeon as Gil Bok-soon, a renowned assassin struggling with personal struggles as a single mother. The Netflix film features stylish but overstuffed action sequences, drawing comparisons to the "John Wick" series. With its hitwoman premise, "Kill Boksoon" makes its debut weeks after its world premiere at the 73rd Berlin International Film Festival, offering a unique take on the genre.

images.alt_text: Kill Boksoon (L to R) Lee Yeon as Kim Young-ji, Jeon Do-yeon as Gil Boksoon in Kill Boksoon Cr. No Ju-han/Netflix © 2023

site_title: Will the media ever quit Trump?
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has returned to the spotlight after a brief absence, following his arraignment in Manhattan Criminal Court on April 4, 2023. The world is currently dealing with various global crises, including the ongoing war in Ukraine and rising tensions between the US and China. Trump's return serves as a reminder that even in times of global turmoil, he remains a dominant figure in American politics, capable of disrupting the status quo and sparking controversy. His next move remains uncertain, but his impact on global affairs is likely to be significant.

images.alt_text: Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, said nothing as he entered the courtroom or when he left roughly an hour later.
Former US President Donald Trump is expected to surrender to the authorities in New York on Apr 4 to face charges over a hush-money payment to porn star Stormy Daniels.

site_title: Morgan Stanley a step closer to setting up futures company in China
summary: Morgan Stanley has received approval from China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) to set up a futures company in China, potentially becoming the second foreign bank to wholly own a futures business in the country. This move comes after JPMorgan Chase & Co became the first foreign bank to achieve this in 2020. China's State Council had announced plans to launch more futures contracts and attract overseas investors in 2021. Morgan Stanley's application is seen as a step forward in the bank's domestic business expansion in China.

site_title: Gold slips on firmer dollar ahead of US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $2,014.79 per ounce as the dollar strengthened ahead of the US non-farm payrolls report, which is expected to show around 240,000 new jobs. The stronger dollar makes gold more expensive for overseas buyers, reducing its appeal. Investors are also watching for signs of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, which could further dim gold's traditionally inflationary hedge appeal.

images.alt_text: While gold is traditionally considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, higher interest rates dim the appeal for non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Toyota looks to overhaul EV strategy as new CEO takes charge
summary: Toyota is reportedly considering a major overhaul of its electric vehicle (EV) strategy under new CEO Koji Sato, who may confirm a new dedicated EV architecture at his first briefing on Friday. The move aims to match Tesla's design and manufacturing innovations, drive down production costs, and turn Toyota's EV business into a higher-margin one. A new EV platform would replace the current e-TNGA system, which has been criticized for its inability to provide cost savings. The shift is long overdue, with critics arguing that Toyota has underestimated the growing demand for EVs, which are expected to represent over half of total vehicle production by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Toyota Motor Corp. incoming President and Chief Executive Koji Sato attends a news conference in Tokyo, Japan February 13, 2023.  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Turning businesses into prosumers can strengthen Singapore’s energy resilience
summary: Singapore aims to strengthen its energy resilience by encouraging businesses to adopt solar energy. The city-state has set a goal of 2 gigawatt-peak of solar energy by 2030, but faces challenges due to high upfront costs and limited land area. To overcome these hurdles, corporations are being incentivized to become "prosumers," consuming and producing energy, with excess sold back to the grid. This mindset shift, combined with advancements in grid technologies and industry collaborations, is crucial to achieving a low-carbon future and ensuring Singapore's energy resilience.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, steps have been taken to facilitate solar energy deployment and support a future where solar energy forms a greater portion of the country's energy mix.
Vietnam, which has the highest solar power generation capacity in the region, is facing setbacks in its clean energy transition due to inadequate grids and regulations.

site_title: Rethinking public debt as positive investment in sustainable development
summary: Public debt in developing Asia-Pacific economies is expected to worsen due to the global economic slowdown, record-high inflation, and rising interest rates. However, a new approach to public debt sustainability suggests that high debt levels can be a positive investment in sustainable development, rather than a cause for concern. The proposed approach assesses public debt viability based on a country's sustainable development goals, government policies, and national financing strategies, and finds that public debt can decline over the long term when socio-economic and environmental benefits are incorporated.

images.alt_text: A bus stop display showing the US national debt. A standoff between the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, President Joe Biden and Democratic legislators could lead to a fiscal crisis.
The World Bank estimates that governments in developing countries and the private sector would need to spend US$2.4 trillion a year on average through 2030.

site_title: Swedish real estate unexpectedly extends rebound in realtor data
summary: Swedish real estate data shows an unexpected rebound in home prices, with apartments rising 2% and single-family homes 1% in March, marking the first time both categories increased in the same month in over a year. This contrasts with gloomy forecasts, including a 20% decline in home values, and most economists' views of a quarter of home values being wiped out. The rebound suggests a pent-up demand for housing, with sellers and buyers finding each other at a new price level.

site_title: China March services activity accelerates on new orders: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity accelerated in March, with the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 57.8, the highest since November 2020. Job creation surged, the fastest in 28 months, driven by robust new orders and a post-Covid consumption-led recovery. However, business confidence dropped to a three-month low, and rising labor and raw material costs pushed up input prices. The stellar economic recovery remains uncertain amid geopolitical tensions and financial concerns.

images.alt_text: Former chairman and party chief of state-owned China Everbright Group Li Xiaopeng is suspected of “serious violations of discipline and law”.
A convincing manufacturing rebound has been lacking, dragging on the economy’s near-term outlook.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as recession talk builds
summary: Asian markets declined as recession fears grew, following US data showing a slowdown in the services sector and private hiring pace. The Federal Reserve's year-long interest rate hike campaign may have gone too far, sparking concerns of a deep recession. Investors shifted to safe-haven Treasuries and gold, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the red. Key jobs data is expected to determine the Fed's next interest rate decision, with some analysts predicting no recession this year.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Tokyo led losses by shedding more than one per cent, with a strong yen adding to the downward pressure. Sydney and Jakarta also fell while Singapore, Seoul, Manila and Wellington rose.

site_title: The bank reform that will harm the American economy and US politics
summary: US lawmakers are debating a proposal to expand deposit insurance guarantees to unlimited sizes, but this move would harm the American economy and US politics. Current limits of $250,000 per person are more than sufficient, and an unlimited guarantee would give banks an incentive to print money at the expense of taxpayers. The history of banking guarantees shows that they lead to increased supervision, which is often eroded by banks and their lobbyists. Instead, lawmakers should focus on protecting small businesses and extending guarantees to $2 million, while dropping the protection for wealthy individuals to $200,000.

images.alt_text: The basic function of banks is to provide money and credit, but depositors cannot monitor the soundness of banks in real time.
Whatever the source of concern behind a bank's failure, it is the loss of asset value which triggers the failure of the institution.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday tracking global slowdown; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 0.4% to 3,305.04 as of 9:02 am on Thursday, tracking a global slowdown. The market saw 92 losers compared to 36 gainers, with Sembcorp Marine rising 0.8% and ComfortDelGro trading flat. Banking shares, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, declined. The decline follows a similar trend in US and European markets, which fell due to weak data on employment and economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Several of the group’s divisions have bagged contracts totalling about S$22.6 million with new and repeat customers

site_title: A tumultuous Kuroda era reverberated way beyond Japan
summary: Haruhiko Kuroda's two-term tenure as Bank of Japan governor ends on April 9, leaving a legacy of reflating Japan's economy. Kuroda's innovative policies, including negative interest rates and yield-curve control, helped to ease deflation and achieve inflation above 2%. His successor, Kazuo Ueda, faces a challenging task to unwind these measures, which have stored up trouble for the future. The BOJ's balance sheet has ballooned, and Japan's heavy debt pile poses significant fiscal challenges. Kuroda's tenure marked a significant shift in Japan's monetary policy, which may influence the global economy.

images.alt_text: Haruhiko Kuroda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), during a panel session on the closing day of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 20, 2023. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 16 to 20. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: A man walks in front of the headquarters of Bank of Japan in Tokyo, Japan, January 18, 2023.   REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Four Asian countries are leading in US chip diversification move
summary: The US has diversified its semiconductor supply chain, with four Asian countries - Thailand, Vietnam, India, and Cambodia - emerging as early winners. US imports of chips grew 17% to $4.86 billion in February, with Asia accounting for 83% of the total. India saw a 34-fold increase in semiconductor shipments, while Cambodia's growth was 698%. The diversification move comes as deteriorating relations between the US and China have forced nations to rethink their supply strategies. The US is seeking to reduce its reliance on Taiwan and South Korea for advanced chipmaking.

site_title: Google and Amazon struggle to lay off workers in Europe
summary: Google and Amazon are struggling to implement layoffs in Europe due to strict labor protections, which require prior consultations with employee interest groups before dismissing employees. In France and Germany, where labor laws are among the strongest in the EU, negotiations with works councils are lengthy and often result in confidential severance packages. In contrast, Google is reportedly planning layoffs in the UK, where labor protections are less stringent. Amazon is also laying off employees in Germany and Luxembourg, but with varying severance packages. The situation highlights the differences in treatment of tech workers between the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: In January, Google’s parent company Alphabet announced it was laying off 12,000 employees worldwide, equivalent to 6 per cent of its global workforce.
Amazon has only released one internally developed game — the online role-playing title New World.

site_title: Amro upgrades Asean+3 outlook, expects growth to be ‘robust’ with China leading rebound
summary: The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) has upgraded its 2023 forecast for economic growth in the region to 4.6%, citing a robust recovery in China and Japan, with China expected to lead the rebound despite a challenging global environment. Domestic spending is expected to drive China's growth, with goods exports weakening due to the US and Europe's slowdown. However, services exports are expected to strengthen with the reopening of the economy. The region's growth is expected to moderate to 4.9% in Asean, with inflation remaining elevated at 4.5% this year.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Asean held up valiantly in 2022 as the COVID-19 pandemic lingered and the Russia-Ukraine conflict led to a supply shock

site_title: Philippine toy maker creates life-like pet plushies for grieving owners
summary: A Philippine toy maker, David Tan's Pampanga Teddy Bear Factory, creates life-like pet plushies using photos of deceased pets and synthetic fur. The process differs from taxidermy, resulting in 100% genuine stuffed toys. Each plushie costs around $85 and has brought comfort to grieving owners like Jaja Lazarte, who paid the price for a replica of her deceased Shih Tzu. Tan's factory has received numerous orders, with customers seeking to memorialize their pets.

site_title: Australia’s commercial property sector at risk after banking turmoil: RBA
summary: Australia's central bank warns that the country's commercial property sector is at risk due to falling valuations, weak demand, and rising borrowing costs. With Australian banks holding 6% of total assets in commercial property, the Reserve Bank of Australia is monitoring the sector for potential financial stability risks. Global real estate investment trust valuations have slumped by 30-50% since 2022, and some landlords may become financially distressed if rental income falls sharply in an economic downturn. The RBA is also concerned about refinancing difficulties for commercial property investors who borrow in international capital markets.

images.alt_text: “The German real estate investment market is in a very challenging phase,” BNP Paribas Real Estate Germany head Marcus Zorn said in the report.
Horizon Towers, which was relaunched for collective sale for the second time in February at an unchanged reserve price of S$1.1 billion, closed its tender on Mar 30 with no bids.

site_title: Europe: shares slip as data signals slower economic recovery, defensives cap losses
summary: European shares slipped 0.2% as data showed a slower-than-expected economic recovery in the eurozone, with industrial goods and services falling 2.1%. Utilities and healthcare indexes rose, however, and hit their highest levels since August 2022. Investors are cautious amid growing economic uncertainty and recession fears, with defensives like utilities and healthcare stocks benefiting from repricing of rates.

images.alt_text: Energy stocks had clocked their biggest one-day gain since November on Monday.

site_title: FDIC retains BlackRock unit for Signature Bank, SVB securities portfolio sale
summary: The FDIC has retained BlackRock's Financial Market Advisory to sell the securities portfolios of Signature Bank and Silicon Valley Bank, which were retained in receivership after the banks' failures. The portfolios have a combined face value of about US$114 billion, consisting of agency mortgage-backed securities, collateralized mortgage obligations, and commercial mortgage-backed securities. The sale is part of the FDIC's efforts to recover from the biggest banking crisis since 2008, which has also triggered volatility in the sector and raised concerns about an imminent recession.

site_title: Singtel to integrate Indonesian telco IndiHome into Telkomsel via conditional spin-off
summary: Singtel has agreed to integrate its Indonesian associate Telkomsel into Telkom Indonesia's subsidiary IndiHome through a conditional spin-off. The deal provides Telkomsel with a 75.2% market share in Indonesia's fixed broadband market, allowing it to enter the market. The consideration for the integration is 58.3 trillion rupiah (S$5.1 billion), and Singtel's effective equity interest in Telkomsel will be reduced from 35% to 29.6%.

images.alt_text: ST20220324_202242242590 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singtel logo on the facade of the Singtel Pickering Operation Complex located at Pickering Street on 24 March 2022.##########x##########KUA CHEE SIONG
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Singapore construction firm’s swings stand out among tiny IPOs
summary: Singapore's Multi Ways Holdings, a construction equipment supplier, surged 553% in its debut on the NYSE American exchange, making it one of the top-performing stocks to debut in 2023. The company's stock price dropped 40% over two days after its listing, echoing the volatility seen in tiny new stocks. This trend is attributed to ongoing market volatility, with US IPOs and secondary offerings raising just $23 billion last quarter. Analysts predict that investor confidence will return once the market stabilizes, leading to more IPOs from prominent companies.

images.alt_text: IPO activity in South-east Asia continues to be encouraging, with Indonesia seeing the most activity.
Weakness in Indonesia’s secondary market is a  concern as the benchmark Jakarta Composite Index is down 0.7 per cent this year.

site_title: US: Stocks wobble after being hit with another round of dour data
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday as weak economic data raised concerns about a potential recession. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell, with a majority of sectors closing lower. The 10-Year Treasury yield hit its lowest level since early-September, falling below 3.30%. The data also pushed the yield on track to end down for a sixth-straight day, its longest run of lower closes since the 2020 pandemic. Markets await the latest jobless claims and non-farm payroll report, which will be released on Thursday and Friday, respectively.

images.alt_text: A Wall Street street sign in front of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Monday, Jan. 4, 2021. In a historic year that marked a rapid plunge into bear market territory and a swift recovery into the bull zone, high-flying technology stocks and electric-vehicle pioneer Tesla Inc. were standout trades.

site_title: Macau casinos shut thousands of hotel rooms amid labour crunch
summary: Macau casinos are struggling due to a severe labour shortage, with over 44,000 non-local employees leaving the region since 2020. The shortage has forced casinos to close thousands of hotel rooms and reduce guest services like housekeeping. Despite China's reopening and a surge in tourists, Macau's slow hiring process for foreign workers is a key hurdle to fully reopening. This is triggering room rate inflation and a drop in hospitality quality, potentially deterring visitors. The labour shortage also strains casino operators, which saw a combined loss of $1.6 billion during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Philippine gaming industry has attracted foreign and domestic firms to set up sprawling casino-resorts, creating tens of thousands of jobs in the past decade.
People walk past the Casino Lisboa operated by SJM Holdings during Lunar New Year in Macau, China, Jan 24, 2023.

site_title: Amazon signs pact to promote Indian state content
summary: Amazon has signed an agreement with India's federal government to promote state-run movie and TV show content through its Prime Video streaming service. The partnership will also provide internships to students from government film institutes and promote books and journals from the ministry's publication arm. This move aims to showcase India's creative talent and stories globally, strengthening Amazon's commitment to promoting Indian content. The partnership comes ahead of national elections next year, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi is likely to seek a third term.

site_title: AI bot ChatGPT faces growing scrutiny in Europe
summary: European authorities, including France, Ireland, and Germany, are scrutinizing AI chatbot ChatGPT due to concerns over data collection and handling. Italy banned ChatGPT after questioning its massive data gathering and handling practices. France's data regulator has received two complaints, with one alleging a lack of consent and another finding personal information about the complainant. European authorities are seeking a common position on ChatGPT, and Canada's data regulator is investigating OpenAI, the chatbot's creator.

images.alt_text: Google has designed its own custom chip called the Tensor Processing Unit, or TPU.
A jobs market is mushrooming around the technology behind ChatGPT. Prompt engineers coax the AI to produce better results and help companies train their workforce to harness the tools.
The Rome-based watchdog gave OpenAI 20 days to respond, after which it could be subject to a fine of as much as 20 million euros (S$28.9 million) or up to 4 per cent of its annual revenue.
Others turned to alternatives simply because OpenAI has trouble keeping up with the rising demand.

site_title: IMF urges nations to use fiscal tightening to tame inflation
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is urging countries to tighten fiscal policy to combat the fastest inflation in three decades. The IMF suggests that tax and spending policies can help reduce dependence on monetary policy and alleviate pressure on central banks to raise interest rates. To support vulnerable groups, countries should implement transfer programs. According to the IMF, reducing public spending by 1% of GDP can lower inflation by 0.5%.
