Biden called for bipartisan legislation to regulate AI, particularly in regards to data collection and product development.

images.alt_text: Governments and society will have to grapple with the issue of how to regulate artificial intelligence and who should do so.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Tesla Inc CEO Elon Musk attends the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China August 29, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Crypto exchange Binance expands in Argentina
summary: Crypto exchange Binance is expanding services in Argentina, allowing users to buy and sell digital currencies directly with local pesos. This move comes as the exchange faces mounting scrutiny from regulators, having lost banking partners needed for fiat currency transactions. Binance will now operate in Argentina as a direct platform, following public demand and marking a key market for the exchange.

images.alt_text: Since the lawsuit, Binance has seen US$1.6 billion of overall withdrawals and US$852 million in the last 24 hours.
Binance called the CFTC’s lawsuit “unexpected and disappointing”.
The derivatives regulator said Binance shirked its obligations by not properly registering with it.

site_title: International law enforcement seizes dark web market
summary: International law enforcement agencies have seized Genesis Market, a popular dark web marketplace used by cybercriminals. The FBI, along with European, Canadian, and Australian police organizations, and cybersecurity firm Qintel, were involved in the operation. A notice posted on the site announced the seizure of domains, stating that anyone in touch with the marketplace should contact the FBI for information. The FBI's seizure notice expressed interest in gathering information from individuals who had interacted with the site.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An FBI logo is pictured on an agent's shirt in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S. October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo
“The FBI has for quite some time now assessed that the origins of the pandemic are most likely a potential lab incident in Wuhan,” Christopher Wray, director of the intelligence agency, says.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, GuocoLand, Parkson Retail Asia
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit has received provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority to make additions and alterations to its Tuas property, with a development cost estimated at around S$20 million. GuocoLand emerged as the sole bidder for a 99-year leasehold private housing site in Lentor Gardens, with a bid of S$486.8 million. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: Gold hovers near 2020 record highs on softer dollar, weak US data
summary: Gold prices hovered near 2020 record highs at $2,020.39 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar and weak US economic data, which may prompt the Federal Reserve to loosen monetary policy. The dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold cheaper for international buyers. Higher interest rates traditionally reduce the appeal of non-yielding bullion, but the current market dynamics favor gold as a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Gold prices had dropped on Monday after a surprise cut in Opec+ crude production was announced during the weekend.

site_title: A Gerhard Richter show finds a home for now
summary: Gerhard Richter's 100 works, including the highly-regarded "Birkenau" cycle, are set to be displayed at the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin until 2026. The artworks, including large abstract paintings and photographs from the Nazi death camp at Birkenau, are on long-term loan from the Gerhard Richter Art Foundation, with the possibility of becoming permanent. The exhibition is part of a new modern art museum, currently under construction and now nearly three times over budget, with a projected completion date of 2027. Richter, 91, is not expected to attend the show's opening.

images.alt_text: Gallerists manning one of the over 170 booths at Art Basel Hong Kong selling modern and contemporary art.

site_title: UK business confidence rises, but cost of living weighs on sales
summary: UK business confidence has increased, with 52% of surveyed businesses expecting sales to rise over the next 12 months, up from 44% in the third quarter of 2022. Despite this, the high cost of living continues to weigh on sales, with stubbornly-high inflation adding to costs for companies. This is creating a challenge for Chancellor Jeremy Hunt, who relies on economic growth to boost tax revenues and reduce government borrowing.

images.alt_text: Container ships on the dockside at the Port of Felixstowe, owned by a unit of CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd., in Felixstowe, UK, on Friday, Jan. 13, 2023. Britain's trade deficit narrowed sharply after a slump in natural gas prices reduced import costs and a flurry of exports of aircraft and cars. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

The Bank of England said this month that Britain’s weak productivity growth means the economy can probably only grow by about 0.7 per cent a year in 2024 and 2025 without generating inflationary heat.

site_title: IMF warns of ongoing financial risks following banking turmoil
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned of ongoing financial risks following banking turmoil in the US and Europe, which could spread to non-bank institutions like pension funds. The IMF urges policymakers to use robust surveillance and regulation, and force companies to share data on risks taken. Banking risks are expected to intensify in coming months amid global monetary policy tightening, complicating central banks' efforts to combat high inflation. The IMF emphasizes the importance of addressing these risks to maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva attends a news conference following a meeting at the Federal Chancellery in Berlin, Germany November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Michele Tantussi/File Photo

site_title: Diversity and inclusion metrics absent from executive remuneration: How worried should we be?
summary: A study by global advisory WTW found that none of the Singapore companies in its sample had diversity and inclusion metrics in their executive remuneration plans, despite much talk about recognizing diversity in the workplace. However, some Singapore companies have DEI and gender-representation goals as part of their annual balanced scorecards, but they are not disclosed as explicit measures linked to executive incentives. The lack of DEI metrics in Singapore companies' incentive plans is concerning, but having such metrics does not necessarily mean a company is taking these issues seriously.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

For equitable progress for all, we need to implement initiatives on diversity that target equitable opportunities for all, regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, socio-economic background, says Valerie Mantot-Groene, regional managing director, Asean, Apex Group. PHOTO:

Incorporating ESG metrics into executive remuneration is not a simple matter of merely selecting some measures and linking them to executive remuneration; ESG must be integrated into strategies, policies and practices of a company, says Prof Mak Yuen Teen
Getting whittled down? Women make up almost half of the population entering the workforce, but only a third end up in senior management and even fewer in board seats. PHOTO:

site_title: Nintendo Switch owners in Europe get free repairs
summary: Nintendo is offering free lifetime repairs for defective Nintendo Switch consoles in the European Union, Switzerland, and Britain due to "Joy-Con Drift," a recurring technical problem causing controllers to malfunction. The issue affects nearly 9 out of 10 consoles, with nearly 25,000 complaints by January 2021. The European Commission and consumer organizations pushed Nintendo to address the issue, aligning with the EU's goal to reduce built-in obsolescence and e-waste. Repairs are available at no charge until further notice.

site_title: Toronto office vacancies hit 28-year high as remote work lingers
summary: Toronto's office vacancy rate reached a 28-year high of 15.3% in the first quarter, driven by technology companies "rightsizing" their space amid layoffs and muted leasing activity from other sectors. Remote work has persisted, prompting firms to reexamine real estate costs and reduce office space. The national office vacancy rate climbed to a record high of 17.7%.

site_title: China slows reviews of mergers involving US companies: WSJ
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation has slowed reviews of proposed US acquisitions, including Intel's $5.2 billion takeover of Tower Semiconductor and MaxLinear's $3.8 billion purchase of Silicon Motion Technology. This move is seen as a response to US curbs on China's tech industry. Chinese regulators have asked the companies to make products available in China, a precondition to approving the deals. The review slowdown is part of Beijing's tit-for-tat fight with Washington over access to advanced technology.

site_title: In-person AGMs now the preferred format for STI constituents
summary: Straits Times Index (STI) issuers are moving away from virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) ahead of a regulatory deadline requiring a physical, in-person meeting to be the default mode from July. As of April 3, 21 out of 30 STI companies had announced their AGM formats, with 18 opting for physical meetings and two, including City Developments Ltd and Wilmar International, offering a hybrid format. The shift is attributed to the importance of in-person interactions for driving engagement and developing rapport with shareholders.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Post-pandemic, allowing hybrid AGMs demonstrates that the board is flexible in meeting shareholders’ preferences, whether they value face-to-face interactions or the convenience of virtual sessions.
Listed companies are reminded to make preparations for physical general meetings.
Sembmarine shareholders will not be able to raise questions about the deal in person or vote at a physical extraordinary general meeting, as the meeting is being held virtually.
Sembmarine said it “had considered various options” for the EGM and found that a fully virtual EGM addresses difficulties faced by other options.
Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has also said it will work closely with MAS to provide guidance for listed issuers to have the option to conduct hybrid meetings.
MAS and Acra will propose legislative amendments to allow general meetings to be held electronically
ACRA and MAS would be proposing legislative amendments to provide groups with the option to conduct general meetings electronically after the orders are revoked.

site_title: Decarbonisation business could outgrow oil: Exxon executive
summary: ExxonMobil's Low Carbon unit has the potential to generate hundreds of billions of US dollars over time and outperform the company's traditional oil and gas business, according to top executive Dan Ammann. The business aims to reduce carbon emissions from operations, with a 10-year investment plan costing US$17 billion. Exxon foresees a future with predictable, long-term contracts with customers striving to reduce their own carbon footprint, resulting in a more stable profile. Regulatory and policy support for carbon pricing are crucial for the vision's realization.

site_title: GM buyouts cut 5,000 jobs: CFO
summary: General Motors (GM) has cut approximately 5,000 salaried jobs through buyouts, exceeding its goal of reducing US$2 billion in operating costs by the end of 2024. CFO Paul Jacobson said demand for GM's trucks and SUVs remains strong in the US, but the company will need to be more urgent around cost-cutting. GM will take a US$1 billion charge in the first quarter and allocate 75% of its annual capital spending towards electric vehicle projects.

images.alt_text: GMC Hummer electric vehicles on the production line at General Motors' Factory ZERO all-electric vehicle assembly plant in Detroit, Michigan. Photographer: Emily Elconin/Bloomberg

site_title: East Asia on a knife-edge over Tsai-McCarthy meeting
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen's upcoming meeting with US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy is on high alert in East Asia, with Beijing warning it would be a provocation that "undermines peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait." The region is already on edge, with North Korea testing record numbers of missile tests and China asserting its territorial claims in the South China Sea. The stakes are high, with a small misstep potentially catastrophic for East Asia, and the US and China engaging in a regional power struggle that could escalate tensions.

images.alt_text: The Republican McCarthy, the third-most-senior US leader after the president and vice president, will host a meeting in California on Wednesday with Tsai.

A Vietnamese sinking boat (left) which was rammed and then sunk by Chinese vessels near disputed Paracels Islands, is seen near a Marine Guard ship (right) at Ly Son island of Vietnam's central Quang Ngai province, May 29, 2014.

site_title: Ford's quarterly US auto sales jump 10.1% on pent-up demand, easing supply chain
summary: Ford's US auto sales rose 10.1% in the first quarter, driven by pent-up demand for electric vehicles, SUVs, and trucks amid easing supply chain disruptions. The Detroit automaker's sales were fueled by strong demand for crossover SUVs and trucks, which accounted for over 95% of sales. Electric vehicle sales increased 41%, and F-150 Lightning pickup truck sales rose to 4,291 units. Analysts say the numbers should ease concerns about demand despite rising interest rates and a looming recession.

images.alt_text: Ford says production is on track to resume Monday with a “clean stock of battery packs.”

site_title: US factory orders post second straight monthly decline in February
summary: US factory orders declined 0.7% in February, marking the second straight monthly drop, amid weak demand for civilian aircraft and equipment spending. Orders increased 3.0% on a year-on-year basis, but fell short of economists' forecasts. The decline in factory orders follows the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat high inflation, which has cooled demand for goods bought on credit. The Institute for Supply Management reported a manufacturing PMI drop in March, the lowest since 2009, further indicating a slowdown in the manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: The gold trading chart suggests more interest rate rises are to come, along with an economic slowdown.

site_title: Europe: Shares ease as oil stocks fall on demand concerns
summary: Europe's stocks slipped 0.1% on Tuesday as heavyweight energy stocks fell due to concerns about US demand for oil after weak economic data and declining eurozone producer prices. Oil majors such as Shell and TotalEnergies shed 1-2% after crude prices gave up early gains. The Stoxx 600 index closed lower, with energy stocks reversing early gains and weighing on the pan-European index.

site_title: The Chief Zero Trust Officer: a new role for a new era of cybersecurity
summary: A new role, the Chief Zero Trust Officer (CZTO), is emerging to address the growing need for cybersecurity in today's digital landscape. With traditional perimeter-based models insufficient, Zero Trust architecture is gaining traction, requiring a holistic approach to verifying user identities, devices, and systems. The CZTO will drive Zero Trust adoption, overcome technological and organizational barriers, and ensure a smooth rollout. This new C-level title commands attention and authority, emphasizing the importance of Zero Trust in companies. Organizations that appoint a CZTO will be better equipped to navigate the challenges of Zero Trust implementation and stay ahead of cyber threats.

images.alt_text: The demand for tech talent beyond the Information and Communication sector is strong, particularly in roles such as cybersecurity and artificial intelligence.
Bittrex is the latest digital-asset firm leaving the country amid heightened regulatory scrutiny over the industry.

site_title: Fed’s Mester sees more rate rises ahead
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Loretta Mester stated that the economy is likely to slow down, and the central bank will likely have more rate rises ahead to control inflation. Mester projects the fed funds rate to move above 5% and the real fed funds rate to stay in positive territory for some time to put inflation on a sustained downward trajectory. The Fed has already raised rates by a quarter percentage point, and officials expect a single additional rate rise for the year. Mester expressed confidence that banking sector woes will be contained and inflation pressures will ease.

site_title: US job openings fall below 10 million for first time since 2021
summary: US job openings fell to 9.9 million in February, the lowest since May 2021, indicating a cooling labor market. The decline was most significant in business services, healthcare, and transportation, with openings rising in construction and recreation. The ratio of openings to unemployed people, a key indicator for the Federal Reserve, decreased to 1.67, the lowest since November 2021. The data suggests labor supply and demand are moving into balance, but wage pressures remain a concern, and further progress is needed to alleviate inflation.

site_title: BNP Paribas reopens market for bank unsecured bonds with 1 billion euros sale
summary: BNP Paribas successfully sold a 1 billion euro senior non-preferred bail-in bond, marking the first such sale since the Credit Suisse-UBS merger in March. The eight-year green bond priced at 4.358% and was oversubscribed by 1.85 billion euros. The deal indicates a strong demand for bank funding in the market, with analysts citing the need for a "strong name" to reopen the market. The sale is seen as an important milestone for bank funding markets, particularly in an uncertain market backdrop.

site_title: ESG asset recount in Europe to axe all ‘vague’ fund strategies
summary: The European Sustainable Investment Forum (Eurosif) is developing a revised methodology to calculate Europe's sustainable investing market, estimated to be around $12 trillion. The new methodology will exclude "vague" ESG-integration strategies and funds that simply exclude controversial sectors, focusing on more ambitious strategies that actively support a sustainable economy. This change aims to ensure sustainable funds have a real-world impact, potentially making the market smaller than the US market, which is valued at $8.4 trillion. The revised methodology will be ready later this year.

site_title: Sabana Reit gets URA nod for S$20 million enhancement works at Tuas warehouse
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has received provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) for a S$20 million enhancement project at its 1 Tuas Avenue 4 property. The project will incorporate solar panels, potentially generating over 1,000 MW hours of energy per year. The 156,000 square foot warehouse and production facility will be completed by mid-2024, with the Reit currently in talks with prospective tenants. The enhancement project aims to maximize the use of the existing building structure and achieve a shorter project timeline.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.
As a result of the offer turning unconditional, the offer’s closing date has been extended by two weeks to 5.30pm on Mar 24, 2023, from the same time on Mar 10.

site_title: Global air cargo demand rises above pre-pandemic levels for first time in 8 months as decline slows
summary: Global air cargo demand rose 2.9% in February, surpassing pre-pandemic levels for the first time in 8 months, according to IATA. Despite the increase, demand still fell 7.5% compared to February 2022, with a year-on-year decline of 7.5%. Cargo capacity rose 8.6% compared to the previous year, driven by the recovery of the passenger business. IATA director general Willie Walsh noted that the slowing decline suggests a possible improvement trend, leading to market stabilization and normal demand patterns.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Asia-Pacific carriers are the hardest hit in terms of air cargo volumes in November 2022.
Thailand has attracted the most forward bookings by the mainland Chinese for outbound travel in the Labour Day holiday period around May.

site_title: GM overtakes Ford as the No 2 seller of electric vehicles
summary: General Motors has overtaken Ford as the No 2 seller of electric vehicles in the US, with GM selling 20,670 plug-ins in the first quarter, nearly twice the 10,866 EVs sold by Ford. Despite a 19.7% decline in Ford's electric Mustang Mach-E sales, Ford's overall light vehicle deliveries rose 10%. Ford plans to spend $50 billion on EVs through 2026 and expects to lose $3 billion on battery-powered models this year, with CEO Jim Farley aiming to eventually surpass Tesla, the US EV market leader.

images.alt_text: GM is designing the on-board navigation and infotainment systems for future EVs in partnership with Alphabet’s Google.

site_title: GuocoLand-Hong Leong Holdings tie-up is sole bidder for Lentor Gardens site at URA tender
summary: GuocoLand-Hong Leong Holdings submitted the sole bid for the Lentor Gardens site, with a price of nearly S$985 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), the lowest unit land rate among five sites in the Lentor Hills Estate. The 99-year leasehold site can yield about 530 private housing units. Developers are cautious due to a potential oversupply in the area and the recent release of multiple sites. The site is expected to be awarded to the sole bidder, with some analysts predicting a launch price of S$1,950 to S$2,050 psf.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

CMG20220831-HoPY01/韩宝镇/何炳耀/URA launches tender for two residential sites at Bukit Timah Link and Hillview Rise[Bukit Timah Link & Hillview Rise]

Location:Hillview Rise Site
The residential site at Lentor Gardens is launched for sale under the confirmed list, while the residential site at Lentor Central is available for application under the reserve list.
krtender2 - Aerial view of Pine Grove (Parcel A).
krtender2 - Aerial view of Dunman Road site
Latest GLS tenders see firm land prices, keener interest from developers

krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA

site_title: Trump pleads not guilty to 34 criminal charges in New York
summary: Former US President Donald Trump pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records and violating election laws in New York, as prosecutors accused him of paying two women to suppress accounts of sexual encounters. Trump, the front-runner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, sat with his lawyers at the defense table and entered a "not guilty" plea. The charges carry a maximum sentence of over 100 years in prison, but experts say a trial is unlikely to occur for at least a year. Trump faces other criminal probes, including a separate investigation in Georgia and two US Justice Department investigations.

images.alt_text: Trump was taken in a motorcade to Trump Tower, where at least four helicopters hovered.
Former US President Donald Trump is expected to surrender to the authorities in New York on Apr 4 to face charges over a hush-money payment to porn star Stormy Daniels.

site_title: Pakistan central bank raises rate 100bps to 21% to curb inflation
summary: Pakistan's central bank raised its key interest rate by 100 basis points to a record 21% on April 4 to combat soaring consumer prices, which hit a record annual level of 35% in March. The move aims to curb inflation, which is also fueled by a weakening currency, energy tariff increases, and elevated food prices. The decision comes as the country seeks to unlock its next IMF bailout tranche worth $1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: The March inflation number eclipsed February’s 31.5 per cent, the bureau said, as food, beverage and transport prices surged up to 50 per cent year-on-year.

site_title: Oil steady as markets weigh Opec+ surprise cuts amid demand woes
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday as investors weighed Opec+ planned production cuts against weak US and Chinese economic data. Opec+ announced 1.66 million barrel per day production cuts from May to the end of 2023, bringing the total cuts to 3.66 million barrels, equivalent to 3.7% of global demand. Brent crude futures rose 1 cent to $84.94 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures closed 29 cents higher at $80.71 a barrel. Analysts forecast Brent oil prices to reach $100 per barrel by year-end.

images.alt_text: Brent and WTI notch their third-biggest weekly percentage gains this year.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on weakness in industrial, bank shares
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index declining 0.6%, 0.6%, and 0.5%, respectively. The drop was attributed to weak manufacturing numbers and a decline in US job openings, as well as concerns over slowing economic growth. Financial and industrial shares, including Caterpillar and JPMorgan Chase, were major losers, with some banks experiencing significant losses. The market's reaction to former President Donald Trump's historic courtroom appearance was deemed minimal.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed ahead of jobs data; Tesla gains
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Tuesday ahead of jobs data, with the Dow Jones falling 6.36 points and the S&P 500 rising 3.52 points. Tesla gained after sales of its China-made electric vehicles rose in March. The Nasdaq Composite also increased. The mixed opening comes as investors await the jobs data that could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening path.

site_title: JPMorgan strategist warns stocks are in ‘calm before the storm’
summary: JPMorgan strategist Marko Kolanovic warns that the recent surge in stocks, fueled by a risk-on mood, is likely to falter due to headwinds from bank turbulence, an oil shock, and slowing growth. He expects a reversal in risk sentiment and a market retesting of 2022 lows in the coming months. Kolanovic attributes the current market backdrop as "the calm before the storm," citing the low VIX and inflows into stocks as driven by systemic investors and a short squeeze.

images.alt_text: The gold trading chart suggests more interest rate rises are to come, along with an economic slowdown.

site_title: Banks pull off biggest junk bond issue since banking crisis
summary: A Goldman Sachs-led group of 33 banks successfully completed the largest junk bond issuance since the banking crisis, raising $3.8 billion for software maker Citrix Systems. The 9% coupon, 14% yield, and call protection through September 2025 were met with investor appetite, indicating a recovery in junk-rated debt. This sale refines most of a $3.95 billion unsecured bridge loan that helped private equity firms acquire Citrix in 2022, amid a market that had largely shut down following the failures of regional banks and the forced sale of Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Citrix Systems logo is seen on smartphone placed on U.S. Dollars in this illustration taken, January 31, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia faces ‘significant doubt’ in ability to operate as going concern, says independent auditor
summary: Independent auditor Foo Kon Tan has raised concerns about Parkson Retail Asia's ability to operate as a going concern due to significant doubt cast by material uncertainties. The auditor noted that the company's current liabilities exceeded its current assets by S$19.8 million as of December 31, 2022, and S$59.3 million for its subsidiaries. Despite a net profit of S$44.1 million, the auditor emphasized that these events indicate a material uncertainty that may impact the company's ability to continue operating. This has led to a 3.2% decline in Parkson Retail Asia's shares.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Consumers are also faced with decades-high inflation, rising interest rates and fears of a recession.
Vincom Retail, Vietnam’s biggest shopping mall operator, which is nearly 60 per cent controlled by Vingroup, commands a market value of US$2.8 billion.

site_title: Google workers in London stage walkout over job cuts
summary: Google workers in London staged a walkout over job cuts, following the company's announcement in January that it was laying off 12,000 employees worldwide. The move comes amid a wave of job cuts across corporate America, with over 290,000 workers shed since the start of the year. Trade union Unite accused Google of ignoring employee concerns and failing to engage properly in the consultation process, demanding full union representation and respect for staff. The walkout is the latest in a series of protests by Google employees in Europe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Google name is displayed outside the company's office in London, Britain November 1, 2018.  REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: China will step up supervision of iron ore markets: state planner
summary: China will step up supervision of iron ore markets, with the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) instructing futures companies to not exaggerate price increases and strengthen market risk alerts. The move follows a 6.3% weekly rally in iron ore prices, with prices falling 2.06% on Tuesday. The NDRC also expects iron ore prices to fall in the second half of the year due to increased global and domestic supply. This comes as fears of a government crackdown on prices have already pressured down iron ore prices.

site_title: What fast-growing oil demand in Asia means for the rest of the world
summary: China and India are driving global oil demand growth, with China accounting for about half of the growth, reaching a record 102 million barrels daily. OPEC forecasts strong demand growth in China and India, with India expected to become the leader in oil demand growth in less than 20 years. Asia's growing demand for oil and gas is also driving a shift away from coal, with natural gas demand projected to more than double by 2050 in the region. This trend is expected to lead to higher oil prices and a tightening of global supply.

images.alt_text: Long-term, however, demand for energy could slump if oil refiners lower activity to counter rising input costs.

site_title: Why Dutch farmers turned their flag upside down
summary: Dutch farmers, upset by government plans to cut nitrogen emissions in half by 2030, have protested by flying their national flag upside down. The movement, led by the Farmer Citizen Movement (BBB), has gained widespread support and has unexpectedly triumphed in provincial elections, making the government's plan uncertain. The Netherlands is seen as a test case for similar plans in other countries, with tractor blockades in Dublin, Berlin, and Brussels. The protests have become a symbol of resistance, with some on the far right praising the farmers' courage.

images.alt_text: Europeans – both officials and non-governmental organisations – are quite open about the rules they want to see. These will apply not just on paper in a cold and rainy Brussels

site_title: Credit Suisse chairman is 'truly sorry' as fury grows
summary: Credit Suisse chairman Axel Lehmann apologized for the bank's near collapse, citing he "ran out of time" to turn it around despite his earlier confidence in its survival. The bank's takeover by Zurich-based UBS was facilitated by emergency legislation, bypassing shareholder approval and wiping out their value. Shareholders and investors expressed outrage, with one major investor voting against Lehmann's re-election. The bank's collapse also resulted in significant job losses and losses for shareholders, with some calling for greater accountability from management and regulators.

images.alt_text: Switzerland’s criminal law is also known for having few protections for whistleblowers.

site_title: China will safeguard yuan and financial stability, central bank governor says
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang stated that the country will safeguard the yuan and maintain financial stability. Yi emphasized that if financial risks emerge, they could harm the general public and cause social problems. China has taken measures to curb financial risks and guard against systemic risks. The country's foreign exchange conversion quota of $50,000 per person per year is sufficient to meet most people's demands.

site_title: The Social Kitchen sets up shop at Bank of Singapore
summary: The Social Kitchen, a social enterprise, has launched its ninth outlet at the Bank of Singapore, marking its first corporate partnership. The cafe sources coffee beans from Yunnan, China, managed by People with Disabilities (PWDs) and focuses on a farm-to-table concept. Its menu features "clean meals" with clinically proven nutrition and anti-inflammatory properties. The cafe's dining tables are made from recycled wooden chopsticks, aligning with its sustainability goals. The partnership aims to create a sustainable future for all stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

Runners taking off for the 5km Zero Waste Run in 2019. This year, participants are encouraged to wear their own orange T-shirts or past Income Eco Run race T-shirts so as to promote reusing and recycling of existing clothes.

site_title: China commits to investing nearly US$39 billion in Malaysia, says PM Anwar
summary: China has committed to investing nearly US$39 billion in Malaysia, with Rongsheng Petrochemical investing RM80 billion (S$20.07 billion) in a petrochemical refinery and Geely investing RM2 billion initially and ramping up to RM32 billion. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim discussed plans to reduce Asia's dependency on the US dollar and proposed establishing an 'Asian Monetary Fund'. China's President Xi Jinping welcomed the idea, and the two countries are exploring ways to conduct trade using the ringgit and renminbi currencies.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s favourable regulatory and business environment have bolstered the development of the country's Islamic fintech sector, say analysts.

site_title: Thailand to continue investment in industrial east as election approaches
summary: Thailand's government plans to continue its 2.2 trillion baht ($85.3 billion) investment in the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) despite a potential change in government after the May election. The EEC, a high-tech industrial zone east of Bangkok, is expected to attract investors with its growth and investment potential. The EEC's chief, Chula Sukmanop, stated that the EEC is a law and would not be scrapped by a new government, ensuring the investment's continuation.

images.alt_text: “Songkran this year should be bustling due to pent-up demand,” Thanavath Phonvichai, president of the commerce university said.
Economic activity was seen rebounding, alongside rising tourist arrivals, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) said.

site_title: Shanghai Futures Exchange cuts margin requirement for nickel, other metals
summary: The Shanghai Futures Exchange (SHFE) has cut margin requirements for nickel, copper, aluminum, zinc, lead, and stainless steel, effective April 6. The moves aim to improve trading liquidity, particularly for nickel, which has seen significant price volatility and low trading volumes. Margin requirements for nickel will decrease from 19% to 12%, while daily movement limits will be tightened to 10% for nickel and 7% for copper, aluminum, zinc, and lead. Analysts expect the changes to attract more participation and better reflect market supply and demand.

site_title: US$2 billion loss at Sweden’s pension fund has stocks chief put on leave
summary: Alecta, Sweden's largest pension fund, has taken action after a US$2 billion loss in investments in US banks. The fund's equities chief, Liselott Ledin, has been placed on leave, and the fund is scaling back large stakes in companies far from its home market. Alecta has launched an internal investigation into its investment processes and received a summons from the country's financial authority. The move aims to rebuild trust with customers and prevent them from switching to rival funds, following the collapse of two US lenders and a third struggling to survive.

images.alt_text: People walk by the closed branch of Silicon Valley Bank in San Francisco, Calif., on Friday, on March 10, 2023. The implosion of the Silicon Valley bank led to finger-pointing, as executives and investors jumped on the crisis for their own messaging. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

site_title: French electronic music pioneer Jean-Michel Jarre headed to China
summary: French electronic music pioneer Jean-Michel Jarre is visiting China as part of a cultural delegation accompanying French President Emmanuel Macron on an official state visit to Beijing. This marks Jarre's first concert in China since 1981, when he performed in Beijing and Shanghai, becoming the first Western musician to do so after Mao Zedong's death. The visit aims to celebrate cultural ties between the two nations and is seen as a return to normal cultural exchange after three years of limited foreign celebrity visits due to Covid-19 measures.

images.alt_text: French composer and producer Jean-Michel Jarre poses on stage during a photo session at the Ircam music studio in Paris, on January 13, 2023. (Photo by STEPHANE DE SAKUTIN / AFP)

site_title: Marsh to vary director and officer insurance terms based on ESG performance
summary: Marsh, an insurance broker, is offering preferential terms in director and officer (D&O) insurance policies in Asia based on the strength of companies' environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risk frameworks. Clients can qualify by completing Marsh's proprietary ESG Risk Rating assessment or an approved third-party rating methodology. The terms will vary depending on countries and risk profiles, addressing growing ESG concerns as stakeholders increasingly focus on these matters.

images.alt_text: Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience
The rise of the Singapore CSO

site_title: Finland joins Nato, Russia warns of counter-measures
summary: Finland officially joined NATO on April 4, 2023, becoming the 31st member of the alliance. The move follows Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which prompted Finland to seek security under NATO's collective defense pact. Russia has threatened "counter-measures" in response, with Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu warning of the possibility of the conflict escalating further. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg welcomed Finland's accession, saying it marks a significant shift against Russia's justification for the invasion. Sweden, which applied to join NATO with Finland last year, is also expected to become a member in the near future.

images.alt_text: Finnish President Sauli Niinisto (left) and Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson. The two leaders' countries "have a very close military relationship outside of Nato".

site_title: China open to dialogue with Malaysia on South China Sea, says foreign ministry
summary: China is open to dialogue with Malaysia on the South China Sea, according to the Chinese foreign ministry. Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stated that an exploration project by Petronas in the area was within Malaysian waters, despite overlapping claims. China claims sovereignty over the entire South China Sea, where $3 trillion worth of trade passes annually. China's foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said the country will work with Malaysia through dialogue and consultation to resolve differences. Malaysia is open to negotiations, with the Association of South-east Asian Nations (ASEAN) advocating for negotiations to resolve overlapping claims.

images.alt_text: Petronas operates oil and gas fields within Malaysia’s 200-mile exclusive economic zone and has in recent years had several encounters with Chinese vessels.

site_title: Sri Lanka keeps key rate at 16.5% after clinching IMF loan
summary: Sri Lanka's Central Bank kept its benchmark interest rate at a two-decade high of 16.5% to control inflation, which is Asia's fastest. The decision supports economic recovery after securing a $3 billion IMF bailout. The central bank expects price gains to decelerate and inflation to slow to single-digit levels by end 2023. This move maintains tight monetary conditions to facilitate disinflation and stabilize inflation at desired levels in the medium term.

site_title: Capital market reforms in China are key for the yuan to become a global reserve currency
summary: China is poised to become a major player in the global reserve currency market, with the yuan being the obvious candidate to replace the US dollar. The country has been gradually internationalizing its currency through trade invoicing, Belt and Road Initiative investments, and other measures. However, progress has been slow, with only 15% of Chinese trade invoiced in yuan. To accelerate yuan internationalization, China needs to implement capital market reforms, including liberalizing its domestic financial markets and promoting wider international use of the yuan.

images.alt_text: CBIRC and the CCDI called in top executives from at least six big state-owned banks to address the probe of Bank of China’s former chairman Liu Liange (above).
China’s reopening looms large in the group’s projections, with the ADB anticipating further knock-on effects to growth, including via boosts to tourist arrivals throughout the region.

site_title: An alternative paradigm for Singapore jurisdiction in cross-border insolvency?
summary: Singapore is considering becoming a more "debtor-friendly" jurisdiction to support its ambitions as a restructuring hub. The city-state's Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act 2018 (IRDA) allows for cross-border restructuring and insolvency cases, but critics argue that the law requires foreign companies to have a "substantial connection" to Singapore to seek bankruptcy protection. A recent court case, Zipmex, established that a company's "centre of main interests" (COMI) can be used to determine its connection to Singapore, but this approach may not be suitable for complex corporate structures. To become a more debtor-friendly jurisdiction, Singapore may consider allowing recognition of foreign orders or judgments, as seen in a recent court decision involving Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust.

images.alt_text: A 2019 survey found that Singapore law was the second most widely adopted governing law in cross-border transactions in Asia after English law.

Amid the rise of restructuring, other tools have also emerged that help struggling debtors find a way forward. These are important as a complete liquidation may be more beneficial in some circumstances.
Lessons from Singapore restructuring attempts
In a lawyer's letter, V Ventures pointed to unresolved matters over Zipmex’s proposed scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Sterling hits 10-month peak, euro up as US dollar under pressure
summary: The British pound reached a 10-month high against the US dollar, rising 0.84% to US$1.2521, after breaching a significant resistance level. The euro also rose, reaching its highest in two months against the US dollar. The US dollar weakened against most European currencies, amid bets that the end of the US rate-hiking cycle is near. Market analysts attribute the currency shifts to a decline in US bond yields and a decrease in rate hike expectations, with the US Federal Reserve likely to keep interest rates steady by July.

site_title: Swedish housing rout is only halfway to trough, says Danske Bank
summary: Sweden's housing prices are expected to fall 25% from their peak, compared to an earlier forecast of a 20% decline, according to Danske Bank economists. The prices have already declined 12% from their peak last February. The Riksbank is set to extend its monetary tightening, leading to a couple of years before housing prices return to the previous trend. Housing prices are only halfway through their projected slump, with a stabilization expected over the summer and a sideways trend for some time.

site_title: UK watchdog fines TikTok £12.7 million for child data misuse
summary: The UK's Information Commissioner's Office fined TikTok £12.7 million for unlawfully using children's personal data without parental consent. Despite its own terms of service preventing children under 13 from creating an account, TikTok had 1.4 million users under 13 in the UK in 2020. The fine comes amid concerns over the social media platform's use of data and links to its Chinese-backed parent company, ByteDance. The regulator estimated that children's data may have been used to track and profile them, potentially delivering harmful content.

images.alt_text: TikTok is especially popular among younger audiences. A report by online marketplace Oberlo has found that nearly 40 per cent of the app’s users are between the ages of 18 and 24.

site_title: Thai property tycoon quits CEO job amid premiership speculation
summary: Thai property tycoon Srettha Thavisin, a key adviser to the Pheu Thai Party, has quit his position as CEO and president of Sansiri amid speculation that he will be named a prime ministerial candidate. His resignation took effect on Monday, and shares of Sansiri rose 2.3% on Tuesday. Thavisin had also sold his stake in the company and was set to attend a meeting of the Pheu Thai board to choose its three prime ministerial nominees.

images.alt_text: The EEC, which covers three provinces east of the capital Bangkok, is a centrepiece of government efforts to boost growth and encourage investment, particularly in high-tech industries.
“Songkran this year should be bustling due to pent-up demand,” Thanavath Phonvichai, president of the commerce university said.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Citibank Singapore CEO Brendan Carney stated that Singapore's political stability, transparent government policies, and pro-business environment remain intact. Wealth managers expect a premium in Singapore's financial system due to its strength amid banking industry turmoil. The payment performance of local firms in Q1 2023 worsened slightly, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. The Charity Council introduced a revised code of governance with a board-term limit and ESG concept. UK software company Quantexa raised US$129 million in a GIC-led round, valuing the company at US$1.8 billion.

site_title: Malaysia’s Islamic fintech sector on the rise, set to hit US$12 billion by 2026
summary: Malaysia's Islamic fintech sector is expected to reach $12 billion by 2026, driven by the country's favorable regulatory environment and market dominance in Islamic finance. The sector has seen a 60% increase in value from 2021 to 2023, with a third of the world's Islamic fintech companies headquartered in Malaysia. The government's support and investment in the sector have attracted foreign funds, with a new RM45 million fund established to invest in startups in insurtech and Islamic fintech. Analysts attribute the sector's growth to Malaysia's large Muslim population and well-developed policies.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Grab-Singtel is among 5 winners of Malaysia's digital bank licences.
Andrew Tan, group managing director at Silverlake Axis

site_title: Rents double in India’s Silicon Valley as engineers fight for flats
summary: Rents in Bangalore, India's Silicon Valley, have nearly doubled since the start of 2023, with landlords charging the highest proportion of property value as rent. The city, home to over 1.5 million workers, experienced a surge in demand after the pandemic pushed staff to remote work or departure. With a shortage of supply, estate agents and homeowners demand LinkedIn profiles and resumes from prospective tenants, leading to a highly competitive housing market. Bangalore now tops India's rent yield, with a 3.9% yield, as landlords seek to recoup lost revenue.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Godrej Infinity, a project by Godrej Properties, in Pune, India. Luxury condominiums, defined as those selling above 15 million rupees (US$183,000), accounted for 17 per cent of all housing launches in 2022, touching an at least five-year high.

site_title: Foreign cash streaming back to China after Alibaba’s plans
summary: Foreign investors are pouring into China's markets following Alibaba's plans to restructure, with net foreign buying reaching a record quarterly total of 186 billion yuan. Alibaba's shares have surged 14% in the past five days, and the company's breakup is seen as a sign of a policy shift towards a more business-friendly environment. The move has been welcomed by investors, who are optimistic about China's economic growth and the potential for capital raising. Analysts believe the restructuring may signal a shift in sentiment among foreign investors, who have been absent from China's markets in recent years.

images.alt_text: Fitch said that it expected Alibaba’s new governance structure to enhance its ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and competition, improve management accountability and increase transparency to regulatory authorities.

site_title: Fitch says Alibaba’s new structure will not impact credit profile
summary: Fitch Ratings has stated that Alibaba's new governance structure will not immediately impact its credit profile. The new structure aims to enhance the company's ability to respond to market changes, improve management accountability, and increase transparency to regulatory authorities. Fitch also believes that the structural subordination of Alibaba's debt will not pose a significant credit risk, allowing the company to unlock value through spin-offs or IPOs.

site_title: US recession potential: Mixed signals from Nasdaq and gold
summary: US interest rates are expected to rise further due to a gold price chart indicating economic slowdown. However, the Nasdaq chart suggests an end to rate hikes and a burst of economic growth. This contradiction highlights significant uncertainty in the financial markets, making it challenging to make long-term investment decisions. The gold price chart projects a decline to US$2,400, while the Nasdaq chart indicates an upside target near 14,500, potentially signaling a trend reversal.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq index saw a double bottom in October 2022 and January 2023, then recovered above the 12,000 level.
Gold prices had dropped on Monday after a surprise cut in Opec+ crude production was announced during the weekend.

site_title: Trump arrives in New York for an arraignment that will make history
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is set to make history with his arraignment in Manhattan on Tuesday, marking the first indictment of a US president. Trump, who has denied any wrongdoing, will be arraigned in the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building after being whisked away by police and Secret Service agents from Trump Tower. The indictment, related to a payment made during the 2016 election to buy the silence of Stormy Daniels, has roiled the national political landscape. Mayor Eric Adams warned Trump's supporters to keep the peace, while President Joe Biden expressed confidence in the New York authorities' ability to handle any potential disturbances.

images.alt_text: Former US President Donald Trump is expected to surrender to the authorities in New York on Apr 4 to face charges over a hush-money payment to porn star Stormy Daniels.
Trump is under criminal investigation in Georgia and Washington, DC, for his attempts to subvert the outcome in the 2020 race.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday as O&M counters actively traded; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% or 16.47 points to 3,297.55, driven by offshore and marine counters following Opec+ plans to cut oil production by 1.2 million barrels per day. Marco Polo Marine led with 34 million securities traded, while Sembcorp Marine and Rex International also saw gains. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose, following a mostly positive US market overnight.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Its subsidiary is pricing a A$100 million (S$90 million) five-year fixed rate sustainability-linked bond (SLB) at 4.577 per cent per annum.

site_title: Thailand sees 125 billion baht spending with water festival to return with gusto
summary: Thailand's consumer spending is expected to rise 17% to 125 billion baht (S$4.8 billion) during the Thai New Year, a four-year high, driven by pent-up demand and the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions. The figure surpasses the pre-pandemic 2019 spending of 136 billion baht, indicating the economy and tourism sector are recovering. Political rallies ahead of the general election are also boosting business and consumer activities.

site_title: UK telecoms firm Virgin Media suffers widespread outages
summary: Virgin Media, a UK telecoms firm, is experiencing widespread outages affecting its broadband services, with over 28,000 reports on Downdetector. The issue began in early hours, causing internet disruptions for thousands of customers. Virgin Media apologized and stated its teams are working to identify and fix the problem as quickly as possible. The company, owned by Liberty Global and Telefonica, has not specified the cause of the outage.

site_title: Risks loom over China’s top tier banks from property downturn, higher costs
summary: China's top-tier banks face near-term revenue and margin pressures due to a persisting property sector downturn, higher costs, and a worsening global macro outlook. The country's banking sector is estimated to slow further in the first quarter, with net interest margins expected to continue shrinking in 2023. Analysts warn that asset quality risks persist from the property market, and banks may struggle with credit risks and losses from pandemic-era loans.

images.alt_text: Net profit for the three months ended December fell to 94.7 billion yuan from 96.5 billion yuan a year earlier, ICBC said in a stock exchange filing.

FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past the logo of China Construction Bank at the bank’s Dongguan branch office in Guangdong province, China July 5, 2019. Picture taken July 5, 2019.  REUTERS/Shu Zhang/File Photo

site_title: US, EU vow to combat any attempts at disrupting energy markets
summary: The US and European Union have pledged to cooperate on energy and confront any attempts to destabilize global energy markets, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The US and EU have intensified their cooperation since Russia reduced petrol deliveries to Europe, leading to record-high prices and a crisis over energy supplies. The two sides will intensify cooperation to cut reliance on Russia for nuclear fuel and services, and hold a joint meeting to promote advanced technologies.

images.alt_text: An oil refinery operated by Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd in Mumbai, India, April 4, 2023. A surprise cut in oil production from OPEC+ is now setting the stage for other producers to vie for markets in Asia.
Long-term, however, demand for energy could slump if oil refiners lower activity to counter rising input costs.

site_title: Dogecoin rises as much as 30% after Twitter home button becomes Doge meme
summary: Dogecoin surged 30% after Twitter's home button changed to a Dogecoin meme, with the cryptocurrency reaching 10.2 US cents from 7.7 cents. The change occurred days after Twitter's verification system changes, which affected some accounts. Twitter owner Elon Musk posted a photo of a previous tweet urging him to make the change, sparking the surge. The meme's popularity led to Dogecoin trending on Twitter.

site_title: Singapore seen tightening monetary policy as inflation remains elevated
summary: Singapore is likely to tighten monetary policy for the sixth time in a row as inflation remains elevated at 5.5% due to global supply chain disruptions. Eleven analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to adjust its policy, with five expecting a steepening of the slope and six expecting a re-centering of the midpoint. The decision is seen as a response to persistent price pressures, with core inflation remaining at a 14-year high.

images.alt_text: Economists barely change 2023 forecasts for Singapore’s growth, inflation: survey

Barclays and DBS do not expect monetary policy tightening in April. Meanwhile, the Bank of America predicts a steepening of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate, and Maybank, UOB and HSBC expect re-centring.

site_title: KKR closes its largest ever European buyout fund at US$8 billion
summary: KKR has closed its largest European private equity fund at $8 billion, surpassing its previous record. The fund, targeting investments in Western Europe, was raised in a challenging market environment with rising interest rates and inflation. KKR is now managing $28 billion in assets on its European platform, with $1 billion committed from its balance sheet and employee commitments. The fund's closure demonstrates strong investor confidence in KKR's European team and platform, according to a partner.

site_title: Charity Council introduces board-term limit, ESG concept to code of governance
summary: The Charity Council in Singapore has introduced a revised code of governance for charities, taking effect from January 1, 2024. The new code recommends a maximum term limit of 10 consecutive years for board members, with reappointment allowed after a two-year break. The revised code also introduces the concept of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) to the charity sector, emphasizing sustainability, stakeholder relationships, and governance standards. The aim is to encourage succession planning and strengthen leadership renewal processes in charities.

images.alt_text: Last year, women accounted for nearly 40 per cent of all new director appointments made by statutory boards and the largest Singapore Exchange (SGX) listed companies, according to an annual study by The Council for Board Diversity (CBD) published on Thursday (Mar 2).

site_title: Global art market up slightly at US$67.8 billion in 2022
summary: The global art market rose 3% to $67.8 billion in 2022, driven by high-end and digital art sales, particularly those backed by non-fungible tokens (NFTs). Despite economic uncertainty and the return of war to Europe, the market showed resilience, with the US market experiencing a significant rebound. Digital art sales increased from 1% to 5% of dealer sales, and wealthy collectors remained optimistic about the future, with 77% expecting the market to grow in 2023.

images.alt_text: Spectrosynthesis III at Tai Kwun is one of the best exhibitions in Hong Kong right now.

More than 86,000 visitors poured through the halls of the fair, reflecting a return to pre-pandemic numbers, with reported sales of more than US$98 million, double those of 2019, according to Hong Kong’s Art Basel fair organisers.

site_title: STI extends gains, finishes 0.9% up
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.9% to 3,311.12, extending gains from the previous day, as investors seemed reassured by regulators' prompt actions on the banking crisis. However, a surprise move by Opec+ to slash oil output raised concerns about inflation, potentially offsetting recent declines in core inflation. The STI's gains were led by Singapore's banking trio and transport giant ComfortDelGro, with analysts warning of higher oil prices adding to inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

The grouping Opec+, which comprises members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) as well as major non-Opec oil producers such as Russia, on Sunday (Apr 2) announced it would cut oil output by about 1.2 million barrels per day (bpd).
Offshore and marine counters are top traded by volume in the morning, following news of Opec+’s plans to cut more production.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence shows some positive developments: think tank
summary: New Zealand business confidence showed some positive developments in the first quarter, with both business confidence and trading activity recovering slightly. On a seasonally adjusted basis, 61% of firms expected business conditions to worsen, down from 74% pessimism in the previous period. The survey's capacity utilisation measure rose to 94.0%, indicating easing capacity pressures. The Reserve Bank's tightening monetary policy since November 2021 appears to be dampening demand in the economy.

site_title: China warns US House Speaker not to meet Taiwan president
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy will meet Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen in California on Wednesday, prompting China to warn that it will not help regional peace and stability, and will instead unite the Chinese people against a common enemy. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and staged war games around the island after a similar visit by a US speaker last year. The US says such stopovers are common practice, but China's consulate in Los Angeles calls the meeting a "political show" that will harm feelings and relations.

images.alt_text: Tsai left Taipei on Wednesday (Mar 29) bound for New York on a plane that was guarded by F-16 fighters as it headed over the Pacific.

site_title: Walmart sees more than 2,000 job cuts in e-commerce warehouses
summary: Walmart is planning to cut more than 2,000 jobs at its US e-commerce warehouses, with reductions of nearly 600 jobs in Pennsylvania, 400 in Florida, and about 200 in New Jersey. The losses include over 1,000 positions at a Texas warehouse. Despite these cuts, the company may allow some workers to be reassigned to other roles, potentially offsetting the impact on total employment. This move comes as Walmart adjusts its stores and warehouses to handle more online orders.

site_title: Indonesia’s Pertamina to spend nearly US$2 billion to improve safety
summary: Indonesia's state oil firm Pertamina plans to spend nearly US$2 billion by 2026 to improve safety at its facilities following a series of fires and explosions. The company has already started implementing improvements at its refineries since a fire at its Balongan refinery in 2021. Pertamina has spent US$980 million in 2022 and 2023 on safety improvements, including installing equipment to protect against lightning and training workers. The company aims to secure fuel supplies ahead of the Eid al-Fitr holidays despite the incidents.

images.alt_text: Pertamina said in a statement that the cause is still being investigated and evacuation is ongoing.
FILE PHOTO: A view of state-owned oil giant Pertamina's refinery unit IV  in Cilacap, Central Java, Indonesia January 13, 2016. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia says Beijing concerned about its energy projects in South China Sea
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stated that Beijing has expressed concerns over Malaysian state firm Petronas' energy activities in the South China Sea, despite Kuala Lumpur believing the projects are within its 322 km exclusive economic zone. China claims the South China Sea as its own, with overlapping claims from Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Anwar emphasized that Malaysia sees the area as its territory and will continue exploration activities, but is open to negotiations if China feels it has the right to do so.

images.alt_text: Kuala Lumpur, the capital city of Malaysia, continued to achieve a high hotel occupancy rate of over 60 per cent in February this year.
A logo of Petronas is seen at their office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, April 27, 2022. Picture taken on April 27, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain
A logo of Petronas is seen at their office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, April 27, 2022. Picture taken on April 27, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: Investment banking fees in Asia ex-Japan down 26% to US$5.9 billion in Q1: Refinitiv
summary: Investment banking fees in Asia-Pacific excluding Japan dropped 26% to $5.9 billion in Q1 2023, the lowest start to a year since 2020. Fees accounted for 24.4% of total global fees, with the materials sector driving deal-making activity, increasing 164% to $41.6 billion. Private equity-backed deals targeting the region declined 58.6% to $19.7 billion, while underwriting fees fell 18% to $1.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Deal-making activity in Asia, excluding Japan, slows to US$980.3 billion in 2022.

site_title: SK Hynix raises US$1.7 billion convertible bond amid chip glut
summary: SK Hynix, the world's second-largest memory chipmaker, raised US$1.7 billion in a convertible bond deal amid a global semiconductor glut. The bonds, listed in Singapore, have a 1.75% annual coupon and will mature in 2030. The money will be used for operational funds, and the company plans to convert 20.1 million Treasury shares into bonds. This deal is the largest convertible bond in the Asia-Pacific region, excluding Japan, and demonstrates investor appetite despite recent market volatility.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix parent SK Group plans to invest US$15 billion in the US chip sector, including to build an advanced chip packaging factory, and has said it is considering applying for funding.
Employees walk past the logo of SK Hynix at its headquarters in Seongnam, South Korea, April 25, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Australia bans TikTok from government devices over security concerns
summary: Australia has banned TikTok from all federal government-owned devices due to security concerns, citing potential Chinese data harvesting to advance Beijing's political agenda. The ban, effective "as soon as practicable," follows similar moves by US-allied countries, including Canada, Britain, and New Zealand. TikTok has denied sharing data with the Chinese Communist Party, and its Australia and New Zealand general manager has called for the app not to be singled out. The ban risks renewing diplomatic tensions between Australia and China, its largest trading partner.

images.alt_text: Australia has not received advice from its security agencies to follow the example of the United States, the European Parliament and Canada to ban Chinese video-sharing app TikTok from government devices, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said on Wednesday.
The TikTok logo is displayed outside TikTok social media app company offices in Culver City, California, on March 16, 2023. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)
TikTok is especially popular among younger audiences. A report by online marketplace Oberlo has found that nearly 40 per cent of the app’s users are between the ages of 18 and 24.
Lawmakers take turns battering Chew with inquiries for more than four gruelling hours, questioning TikTok’s ownership by Beijing-based ByteDance.

site_title: South Korea inflation softens to one-year low of 4.2% in March
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation eased to a one-year low of 4.2% in March, according to official data. This marks the slowest annual rise since March 2022, with prices of petroleum products and livestock falling 14.2% and 1.5% year-over-year, respectively. The data has prompted investors to bet that the South Korean central bank's tightening cycle is over, with the Bank of Korea's pause in late February seen as a sign of the end of its tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: New orders in South Korea shrank for the seventh straight month in January, although the rate of decline was a little slower than a month earlier, a business survey showed on Wednesday.
South Korea is the first major exporting economy to release trade data each month.

site_title: Richard Branson’s Virgin Orbit files for bankruptcy, to seek buyer
summary: Richard Branson's Virgin Orbit Holdings filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on April 4, citing a failed rocket launch in January and inability to secure long-term funding. The company, which launched satellites from beneath a Boeing 747 plane, listed assets of $243 million and total debt of $153.5 million. Virgin Orbit CEO Dan Hart said the Chapter 11 process is the best path forward to identify and finalize an efficient sale. The company's bankruptcy filing comes after the layoff of 85% of its 750 employees and previous failed funding talks.

images.alt_text: Virgin Orbit went public in 2021 through a blank-check deal, where it raised US$255 million less than expected.

site_title: Malaysia, China to discuss ‘Asian fund’ to cut dollar dependency
summary: Malaysia and China are set to discuss forming an Asian Monetary Fund to reduce reliance on the US dollar and the International Monetary Fund. The idea, first proposed by former finance minister Anwar Ibrahim in the 1990s, has gained traction as the US dollar's dominance continues to be a concern. Anwar stated that China welcomed discussions on the proposal, which could enable regional economies to negotiate trade matters using their own currencies, such as the ringgit and renminbi. The talks come amid growing impatience with the King Dollar's dominance in the region.

images.alt_text: Petronas operates oil and gas fields within Malaysia’s 200-mile exclusive economic zone and has in recent years had several encounters with Chinese vessels.

site_title: UK software company Quantexa raises US$129 million in GIC-led round
summary: UK software company Quantexa has raised US$129 million in a Series E round led by GIC, increasing its valuation to US$1.8 billion. The capital will be used to accelerate growth in the company's decision intelligence category, with a focus on technology innovation and strengthening its platform capabilities. Quantexa plans to boost its go-to market efforts with major partners like Google and Deloitte, and aims to expand into new markets and industries. The company's annual recurring revenue has doubled, and it now has over 600 employees across multiple offices.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Stripe emphasised that it “does not need this capital to run its business”.

site_title: US welcomes World Bank reforms, pushes for more ambitious changes
summary: The US has welcomed the World Bank's plan to boost lending by $5 billion annually for the next 10 years to address global challenges such as climate change. The US, the bank's largest shareholder, has been pushing for more ambitious reforms, including a timeline for implementation. The bank's reforms aim to increase funding for developing countries, with estimates suggesting $2.4 trillion a year is needed to address global needs. The US is pushing for further reforms, including a work plan and timeline for implementation, to give greater voice to African countries and other developing nations.

images.alt_text: Not accounting for China, developing East Asia and the Pacific are anticipating a slower rate of growth in 2023, compared to 2022 and an earlier forecast.
The World Bank estimates that governments in developing countries and the private sector would need to spend US$2.4 trillion a year on average through 2030.

site_title: South-east Asian tech salaries set to cool in 2023, but specialists still in demand
summary: South-east Asian tech salaries are expected to grow more slowly or even fall in 2023, after a surge in the past few years. Despite this, demand for specialists like software engineers and product heads remains strong. The report, based on data from Glints and Monk's Hill Ventures, notes that salary increments will be smaller, around 5-7% per annum, due to inflation. However, startups still prioritize "revenue-generating roles" and are looking to invest in engineering, business development, and sales, and marketing and public relations.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Despite a slowdown in hiring, the hunt for top software engineers drove salaries to a record high last year.
Roles in the technology sector remain highly sought after, as ongoing digitalisation trends have led to a “sustained demand for technological skills”, said the Manpower Ministry in its report.
A jobs market is mushrooming around the technology behind ChatGPT. Prompt engineers coax the AI to produce better results and help companies train their workforce to harness the tools.

site_title: The US$9 trillion oil king’s climate solution is his hand-picked oil exec
summary: Sultan Al Jaber, the CEO of Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc), has been tasked with organizing COP28, the United Nations climate summit, despite criticism over his role as a key figure in the world's largest oil producer. Al Jaber, who has made significant investments in renewable energy, aims to achieve "transformational progress" and has proposed phasing out oil and gas in the final communiqué. However, critics argue that his role as a major oil executive undermines the summit's credibility, and that his company's increasing emissions will hinder efforts to reduce greenhouse gases. The summit will take place in Dubai in November, with Al Jaber facing pressure from green groups and lawmakers to address the conflict of interest.

images.alt_text: The city and port of Haifa in northern Israel. Economic and trade cooperation – a key driver of the UAE’s 2020 normalisation of relations with Israel, which broke with decades of Arab policy towards the Palestinian cause – has deepened.

Crown Prince Mohammed Salman’s willingness to act to secure stability, while coordinating energy policy with Russia and even sidelining the US in favour of its No 1 rival China, underscores Riyadh’s growing geopolitical influence as a fossil fuel superpower.
OPEC+ have tried to balance markets through changes in supply this year, which since October involved cuts

site_title: China Vanke defies property woes with 22.6 billion yuan in profit
summary: China Vanke, the nation's second-largest property developer, reported a 22.6 billion yuan (S$4.36 billion) profit for 2022, defying industry woes. The company's stabilisation underscores the importance of state-backing amid China's record property market slump. Chairman Yu Liang forecasts housing demand to sustain sales at 1.2 billion square meters, contrasting with smaller rival Greenland Holdings' expectations of a market slump. Vanke's shares fell 3.3% in Hong Kong trading, taking this year's decline to 21%.

images.alt_text: The industry has also seen some gradual recovery in recent weeks, as homebuyers look to make a return after Beijing abandoned its stringent “zero-Covid” policy in December.
Home purchases in Singapore, where Chinese are the top foreign buyers, cooled early in 2023 from last year’s torrid pace — but only slightly despite a steep rise in real estate stamp duties.
Sunac is among the many Chinese developers that defaulted last year as the sector reeled under a debt crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong’s workforce sees its biggest drop in almost 40 years
summary: Hong Kong's workforce has seen its largest drop in nearly 40 years, with a 2.4% decline of 94,100 people in 2022, according to the Census and Statistics Department. The city's labour market challenges include an ageing population and outflow of talent, with tens of thousands of people, including lawyers and bankers, leaving following strict pandemic curbs and the national security law. The government has launched a global talent programme to attract high-income workers and top university graduates, but most applications so far have come from China.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping still has a firm grip on power, but a surge of criticism has revealed cracks in the ruling Communist Party.

More than 86,000 visitors poured through the halls of the fair, reflecting a return to pre-pandemic numbers, with reported sales of more than US$98 million, double those of 2019, according to Hong Kong’s Art Basel fair organisers.
The rise in home prices in February followed a revised 1 per cent gain in January and was the biggest since May 2020.

site_title: Australia pauses rate increases, waters down tightening bias
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), paused its interest rate hikes, keeping the cash rate at 3.6% and downplaying the need for further tightening. The decision, made on April 4, reflects a slowdown in household spending and a "substantial" slowdown in the economy, with Governor Philip Lowe citing bank stress in the US and Europe as a factor. The RBA has raised rates by 3.5 percentage points since May, and economists expect the cash rate to remain at 3.6% until May next year.

images.alt_text: The RBA meets after the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank pushed ahead with policy tightening irrespective of financial volatility caused by banking collapses.

site_title: L’Oreal to buy cult skincare brand Aesop in US$2.5 billion deal
summary: L'Oréal has agreed to acquire luxury skincare brand Aesop for US$2.53 billion, marking the end of months of negotiations. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter and will help Brazilian beauty giant Natura reduce its debt burden. Aesop, known for its natural and ethically sourced cosmetics, has a cult global following and reported revenue of 880 million reais for the fourth quarter. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move for L'Oréal to tap into Aesop's growth potential, particularly in China and travel retail, and will allow Natura to focus on its core Latin America business.

images.alt_text: Investors will have to weigh L’Oreal’s slowing momentum even as it continues to beat expectations.

site_title: Food for thought: Consumer staples to fortify your portfolio in recession
summary: The consumer staples sector has shown resilience in a volatile US equity market, with the S&P 500 Consumer Staples Index falling just 3% compared to the broader index's 14% decline since 2022. This sector is expected to be less affected by a potential US recession due to its low product elasticity and predictable earnings. Companies in the sector have displayed strong pricing power and have benefited from the "trade-down" trend, with many displaying robust analyst estimates and company guidance. The sector's stable gross margins and potential for cost cuts make it a defensive name that can buffer portfolios against a recession.

images.alt_text: Consumers are also faced with decades-high inflation, rising interest rates and fears of a recession.

CORTE MADERA, CALIFORNIA - DECEMBER 15: Women carry shopping bags while visiting the Village at Corte Madera on December 15, 2022 in San Francisco, California. According to a report by the U.S. Commerce Department, retail sales fell 0.6% in November as consumers pulled back on spending due to rising prices brought on by inflation.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Sats is rallying after months in doldrums as investors look past dilution from rights
summary: Sats' shares have rebounded 16.8% since mid-March, closing at $2.78 on April 3, after a turbulent six months marked by a decline from $4.09 to $2.38 following the announcement of a potential acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Worldwide Flight Services is being acquired by Sats, pending regulatory approval.
