Rights issue is expected to launch in Q1, 2023. Temasek, which holds 39.7 per cent of Sats through subsidiary Venezio Investments, has indicated it intends to subscribe for its pro-rata entitlement.
Sats’ acquisition of WFS is expected to cost the company S$1.8 billion.
Sats' recent share price trajectory has been an accurate barometer of the financial implications of its proposed acquisition of WFS

site_title: Toyota quarterly auto sales fall 8.8%
summary: Toyota's first-quarter auto sales fell 8.8% to 469,558 vehicles, compared to 514,592 vehicles in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to inflationary pressures and chip shortages affecting the company's ability to deliver vehicles to dealers. Toyota plans to improve its vehicle inventory to meet customer demand and introduce more electrified vehicles throughout 2023.

site_title: Gold prices ease as US dollar regains some ground
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,962.36 per ounce, as the US dollar regained some ground, making bullion more expensive for overseas buyers. The dollar index was 0.1% higher, while softer US economic data heightened expectations of less-aggressive Federal Reserve moves. The surprise Opec+ crude production cut earlier in the week had initially boosted gold prices, but the dollar's recovery countered this effect.

images.alt_text: The opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion rises when interest rates are increased to bring down inflation.

site_title: Australia to ban TikTok on government devices
summary: Australia is set to ban TikTok on government phones following a review by the Home Affairs department, with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese agreeing to the move. The ban is amid concerns over user data potentially being shared with the Chinese government, undermining Western security interests. Victoria state is also expected to follow the federal government's guidance, effectively banning the short video app from government phones.

images.alt_text: TikTok is especially popular among younger audiences. A report by online marketplace Oberlo has found that nearly 40 per cent of the app’s users are between the ages of 18 and 24.

site_title: EU’s twin track to zero-carbon shipping is complicated
summary: The European Union has adopted the world's first green shipping fuels law, requiring at least 2% of the bloc's shipping fuels to come from e-fuels derived from renewable electricity by 2034. However, the effectiveness of this policy depends on how one defines "green," as the International Maritime Organization already has regulations in place to reduce shipping's carbon dioxide emissions. Environmental campaigners are generally happy with the EU's new policies, but warn that "loopholes" could allow biofuels and low-carbon fuels to slip through, and urge the EU to close these loopholes in the future.

images.alt_text: Travelers prepare to board a passenger aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, June 23, 2021. While losses at airlines globally from Covid-19 are set to surpass $174 billion by the end of 2021 -- wiping out half a decade of profits -- Qantas has become one of the most financially secure carriers anywhere in the world. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia set for faster growth, easing inflation in 2023: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) forecasts Asia's developing economies, led by China, to grow at 4.8% in 2023 and 2024, faster than the 4.2% last year. Inflation is expected to moderate to 4.2% this year, with China's reopening contributing to boosts in tourist arrivals. However, inflation risks are skewed to the higher side due to Opec+ production cuts. Excluding China, the ADB expects the region's inflation to accelerate to 6.2% this year and 4.5% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Regional economic activity remains robust in spite of the recent banking crisis, said Bill Winters, group chief executive of Standard Chartered.
Home purchases in Singapore, where Chinese are the top foreign buyers, cooled early in 2023 from last year’s torrid pace — but only slightly despite a steep rise in real estate stamp duties.

site_title: StanChart completes planned redemption of US$1 billion shock-absorbing bond
summary: Standard Chartered has redeemed a $1 billion additional tier one bond, exercising its option before holders of similar securities were affected by the recent rescue of Credit Suisse. The move was made in response to the banking sector turmoil, which saw Swiss authorities write down $17 billion of Credit Suisse securities. This is the first major redemption in the US$275 billion global market for AT1 bonds.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered upgraded its performance forecast, saying it now expected to achieve a return on tangible equity – a key profitability metric – of 10 per cent this year and 11 per cent in 2024.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s Singapore-based Asean M&A head to exit bank
summary: Credit Suisse's Singapore-based Asean M&A head, Lim Zi-Kuan, is leaving the bank after over 20 years. His departure adds uncertainty in a region where Credit Suisse is a major deal adviser. The move comes as the bank grapples with retaining talent following its emergency rescue by UBS. Credit Suisse has seven pending deals worth about $3 billion in South-east Asia, and bankers are calling headhunters and rival firms to ask about job opportunities.

site_title: Japan aims to treble sales of domestically made microchips by 2030
summary: Japan aims to triple its domestic microchip sales to 15 trillion yen ($150.33 billion) by 2030, aiming to strengthen its economic security. The country's industry ministry plans to provide subsidies to companies like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing to build plants in Japan or expand existing facilities. This move follows the decline of Japan's share in the global microchip market from 50% in the late 1980s to around 10%, outperformed by rivals like South Korea's Samsung Electronics.

site_title: Visa, MasterCard tell UK tribunal to block new mass actions
summary: Visa and Mastercard are fighting a new set of lawsuits in London over fees charged to retailers, with their lawyers telling a tribunal that the proposed collective cases serve no purpose. Hundreds of claimants are suing the two firms, which already face a litany of lawsuits over multilateral interchange fees. The cases are being managed together by the Competition Appeal Tribunal, and Visa and Mastercard are arguing that the collective cases are unnecessary.

site_title: Warner Bros nears deal for Harry Potter video series
summary: Warner Bros Discovery is close to a deal for a new online TV series based on the best-selling Harry Potter book series. Each season will be based on one of JK Rowling's seven books, allowing for fresh content and delving deeper into the world of the books. The series will debut on HBO and online, with Rowling involved to ensure the material remains loyal to her original work. The move is part of Warner Bros' new streaming strategy, which will also include a flagship online service called Max.

images.alt_text: Warner said it paid Paramount and “South Park” creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone more than US$500 million in 2019 for the exclusive right to stream 333 episodes domestically on HBO Max.
Peter Jackson’s original three "Lord of the Rings" movies grossed nearly US$3 billion at theatres, and won 17 Oscars, including best picture for 2003 trilogy finale "The Return of the King".

site_title: Dolce & Gabbana plans US, Spain and Maldives real estate projects
summary: Luxury fashion group Dolce & Gabbana plans to enter the real estate sector with two residential projects in the US and Spain, and a hospitality project in the Maldives. The company will partner with JDS Development Group in Miami and Sierra Blanca Estates in Marbella, and DarGlobal in the Maldives. No financial details were disclosed. This move follows other luxury brands expanding into real estate, such as Armani and Versace.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Centurion Corp
summary: Singtel's subsidiary priced a A$100 million five-year fixed rate sustainability-linked bond at 4.577% per annum. The bond matures on Apr 12, 2028. Meanwhile, Centurion Corporation received approval to increase bed capacity at its dormitory sites, with market rates ranging from S$380 to S$520 per bed.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Dwayne Johnson says a live-action version of ‘Moana’ is in the works
summary: Dwayne Johnson announced at Walt Disney's annual shareholder meeting that a live-action version of the 2016 animated movie 'Moana' is in development. The new film is set in ancient Polynesia and follows a teenage girl's epic journey to save her tribe. Johnson, who voiced Maui in the original, expressed his gratitude to bring the story to the big screen, stating it's a representation of his Samoan culture and people's strength. No release date has been announced for the live-action adaptation.

site_title: Evergrande signs restructuring agreement with major creditors
summary: Evergrande Group has signed a major offshore restructuring deal with a key creditor group, marking a significant step in the developer's debt-overhaul process. The agreement allows creditors to receive a 0.25% consent fee on outstanding principal if they agree to the proposal by April 27. This deal is one of the country's largest ever and has broad implications for China's financial system. It also serves as a reference point for other defaulted Chinese builders working to revamp their leverage loads.

site_title: Chinese unicorn XTransfer expands in Hong Kong amid fintech recovery
summary: XTransfer, a Shanghai-based fintech startup, is expanding in Hong Kong to attract 300,000 small and medium-sized enterprise clients. Valued at over $1 billion, the company aims to reduce fees for cross-border transactions by 95% and exchange costs by 20%. XTransfer, backed by D1 Capital Partners, will provide payments services to Hong Kong merchants buying from mainland suppliers. The move follows China's fintech companies emerging from a lull, with trade imports from mainland China accounting for 49% of Hong Kong's total in 2022.

site_title: Luxury watchmakers woo Generation Z with Snapchat and bitcoin
summary: Luxury watchmakers are targeting Generation Z with innovative marketing strategies, including Snapchat and bitcoin, as this generation is taking an early interest in luxury goods. According to a study by Bain and Altagamma Foundation, millennials and Gen Z are expected to increase their spending on luxury goods three times faster than other generations by 2030, driven by their desire for unique experiences and exclusive products. This trend is expected to boost sales growth for top-end timepieces.

site_title: Singtel’s Australian unit prices A$100 million 5-year fixed rate sustainability-linked bond at 4.577%
summary: Singtel's Australian unit, Singtel Optus, priced a $100 million 5-year fixed rate sustainability-linked bond at 4.577% per annum. The bond will mature in 2028 and will be used to fund Optus' ordinary business activities. The issue is guaranteed by Optus and certain subsidiaries, with the proceeds drawn from a $3 billion Australian Debt Issuance Programme.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

site_title: Brazil targets Asian e-commerce giants, local companies in tax push
summary: Brazil is set to unveil tax measures targeting Asian e-commerce giants and local companies, aiming to raise over 100 billion reais (S$26.2 billion). Finance Minister Fernando Haddad says these companies are hiding e-commerce as person-to-person remittances to avoid paying taxes, generating an estimated 7-8 billion reais in new revenue. The government also plans to release a fiscal framework to eliminate the budget deficit by next year, supported by measures such as disallowing tax breaks on operating expenses and taxing online sports betting.

images.alt_text: Central bankers warn about “high” levels of household debt in their latest inflation report.

site_title: Europe: Muted start to new quarter for shares as inflation fears resurface
summary: European shares started the new quarter flat on Monday, despite a global banking crisis, as inflation fears resurfaced. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended the day unchanged, while oil and gas shares rose 4% following Opec+'s announcement to cut oil output further. Technology shares fell 1% due to rising US and European bond yields. Concerns about higher interest rates and potential recession persisted, with some analysts warning that a tighter monetary policy could drag on demand and curb spending.

images.alt_text: Eurostat data showed inflation in the eurozone dropped by the most on record in March.

site_title: Rubbish in Paris, rules in Brussels
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's decision to push through pension reform by decree has sparked widespread protests and strikes in Paris. The measure, which aims to lower the retirement age, has been met with anger and frustration from the public, who feel the president is disregarding democratic processes. The protests have also raised concerns about the tone of engagement in the European Union and the potential impact on Macron's leadership. The far-right faction of Marine Le Pen is seen as gaining ground, further complicating the situation.

images.alt_text: TSMC holds a ceremony to start mass production of its most advanced 3-nanometre chips in the southern city of Tainan, Taiwan, Dec  29, 2022.
Passengers arriving at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Jan 8, 2023, the day the country ended its zero-Covid policy.
An electric vehicle battery factory in Alabama. Electric vehicles only qualify for incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act if critical components are made in the US.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly rise as oil prices jump
summary: US stocks mostly rose on Monday, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.4% to 4,124.51, despite weak US manufacturing data and concerns about slowing growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.0% to 33,601.15, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.3% to 12,189.45. The gains were attributed to easing worries about more interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 6, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Local firms’ payment performance worsens slightly in Q1: SCCB
summary: Singapore's local firms saw a slight deterioration in payment performance in Q1 2023, with prompt payments down 0.1 percentage point to 41% and slow payments up 0.1 percentage point to 44.2%, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. This marks a slight improvement from the fourth quarter of last year. The construction, manufacturing, services, and wholesale sectors saw increases in slow payments, while retail saw a decrease. SCCB CEO Audrey Chia noted that firms should exercise greater credit vigilance due to tighter cash flows.

images.alt_text: Slow payments inched up 0.1 percentage points to 44.2 per cent in Q3, from 44.1 per cent in Q2.

On a quarter-on-quarter (q-o-q) basis, prompt payments inched up slightly by 0.1 percentage points while a year-on-year (y-o-y) comparison shows an improvement of 0.4 percentage points to 41.2 per cent in Q2 2022.

site_title: UAE plans long-term economic ties with Israel despite political strains
summary: The UAE plans to maintain its long-term economic ties with Israel despite recent political strains, with the two countries deepening their economic and trade cooperation. A Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) has entered into effect, removing or reducing tariffs on over 96% of products. Economic and trade cooperation has been a key driver of the UAE's normalization of relations with Israel, and analysts say it will continue despite political turbulence. The UAE has invested in Israeli energy and finance sectors, and bilateral non-oil trade volumes between the two countries reached over $2.5 billion in 2022, with the UAE aiming to grow this to $10 billion by 2030.

images.alt_text: The funds are expected to buy a 25 per cent to 30 per cent stake in Phoenix, in partnership with Gallatin Point Capital, according to a statement.

site_title: Billionaire blocked from his new palace blasts ‘socialist’ India
summary: Billionaire Cyrus Poonawalla, owner of the Serum Institute of India, has expressed frustration over an eight-year wait to move into his $120 million Mumbai mansion, citing a dispute over land ownership between the Indian government and the US defense ministry. Poonawalla, 81, claims the government is withholding the sale due to "political and socialist decisions," despite his fortune being worth about $17 billion. The issue has sparked tension between India and the US, with former US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo lamenting the situation.

images.alt_text: India, which aims to turn net zero by 2070, recently awarded the second tranche of production-linked grants for solar modules.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: Leonardo DiCaprio recounts parties with fugitive Jho Low
summary: Leonardo DiCaprio testified at the trial of rapper Pras Michel, where he discussed his relationship with fugitive financier Jho Low, who underwrote DiCaprio's 2013 film "The Wolf of Wall Street." DiCaprio met Low at a party and bonded over several years, with Low lavishing gifts on him. DiCaprio acknowledged that he considered Michel a friend but focused on Low, saying he was a "prodigy" in the business world. The actor testified that his company vetted Low before striking business deals and that he was given a green light to accept financing from Low.

images.alt_text: Najib was jailed last year after Malaysia’s Federal Court upheld a guilty verdict and 12-year prison sentence handed down to him by a lower court.
Rohana Rozhan, the former chief executive officer of Astro Malaysia Holdings, has returned US$10 million related to the troubled state fund 1MDB.
Federal prosecutors ask US District Judge Margo Brodie in Brooklyn, New York, to order Ng to forfeit the sum as ill-gotten gains from the conspiracy to loot the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Time for Singapore premium to outshine Swiss finish
summary: Singapore's financial system is gaining a premium amid the turmoil in the global banking industry, particularly the collapse of Credit Suisse. Wealth managers and private banks expect a step-up in client requests and fund movements, driven by Singapore's political stability, transparent government policies, and pro-business environment. The country is seen as a safe haven for investors, with Citibank Singapore CEO Brendan Carney noting its "Swiss finish." However, some experts warn that there may be outflows of wealth, and banks are adapting by focusing on high-net-worth clients and diversifying investments.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The big question now is how much longer it will take the Fed and other major central banks to get inflation under control
Logos of Swiss bank UBS and Credit Suisse in Zurich, Switzerland
The 3 billion Swiss franc deal for UBS to take over Credit Suisse has resulted in the writedown of Credit Suisse's perpetual subordinate debt. This has caused widespread dismay.
Morningstar data of bond fund allocations shows Credit Suisse’s AT1 debt makes up for very little of each individual fund’s portfolio.

site_title: Saudi Arabia emboldened on world stage underpins Opec decision
summary: Saudi Arabia's decision to cut Opec+ oil production has bolstered the country's influence as a fossil fuel superpower, with Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's willingness to act to secure stability and coordinate energy policy with Russia. The move, which saw a 1 million barrel-a-day reduction, reflects Riyadh's growing geopolitical influence and economic expediency, as crude prices slumped to a 15-month low. The decision is seen as a "Saudi-first" policy, with the US and other leading consumers having to adapt to a shift in priorities, as Riyadh prioritizes its own economic interests over those of its allies.

images.alt_text: OPEC+ have tried to balance markets through changes in supply this year, which since October involved cuts

site_title: Right-sizing Singaporeans’ housing aspirations
summary: Singaporeans' housing aspirations are being reassessed due to the high demand for public housing. With 80% of the population living in over 1 million HDB flats, the availability and prices of flats significantly impact the private property market. As Parliament reconvenes on April 10, the Government will address concerns on public housing affordability and accessibility, as well as other pressing issues like costs of living and post-pandemic economic revitalization. The Government aims to strike a balance between affordability and sustainability, ensuring a fairer and more just society for all.

images.alt_text: Both HDB and condos register rental increases even as volume declined in February
Generic photo of condos and private properties
HDB will pilot the initiative at the former Anderson Junior College hostel in Ang Mo Kio Avenue 8, which comprises two 11-storey blocks.

site_title: China warns top bankers of deepening crackdown on corruption
summary: Chinese authorities warned top banking executives that a crackdown on corruption in the $60 trillion industry is far from over, following the probe of Bank of China's former chairman Liu Liange. Officials from the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) and the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI) called in executives from at least six state-owned banks to address the probe. The CCDI announced the investigation of Liu, suspecting him of "serious violations of discipline and law," in a one-sentence statement.

images.alt_text: Fan Bao has sprawling connections and is privy to information related to the country’s biggest entrepreneurs.

site_title: Apple to make small number of job cuts in some corporate retail teams
summary: Apple is eliminating a small number of roles within its corporate retail teams, marking its first known internal job cuts since last year's belt-tightening effort. The positions being eliminated are in development and preservation teams, responsible for store construction and upkeep. The exact number of positions is unknown, but the move represents a new step for the company amid a shaky economy and sluggish consumer spending. This marks a departure for Apple, which has traditionally maintained a large workforce.

images.alt_text: VirnetX separately won a US$302 million verdict against Apple in East Texas in 2016.
GM is designing the on-board navigation and infotainment systems for future EVs in partnership with Alphabet’s Google.

site_title: As US politicians rail against TikTok, politicians in Singapore are using it to their advantage
summary: Singapore politicians are leveraging TikTok to their advantage, despite US politicians' concerns over the app's security. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's video of taking off his mask garnered 1.9 million views, with over 3,000 comments praising his style and "swag". Wong's TikTok account has 71,300 followers. This trend suggests that Singapore's politicians are successfully utilizing TikTok to connect with younger audiences, unlike their US counterparts who are critical of the app.

images.alt_text: Lawmakers take turns battering Chew with inquiries for more than four gruelling hours, questioning TikTok’s ownership by Beijing-based ByteDance.
Politicians and cybersecurity experts have repeatedly raised concerns that TikTok’s parent company has too much insight into its 150 million monthly US users.
Zhang Yiming’s estimated net worth has fallen to $42.3 billion after a US testimony detailed a smaller ByteDance ownership stake than previously known.

site_title: EV maker Rivian misses first-quarter production estimates; shares drop
summary: Rivian Automotive missed first-quarter production estimates, producing 9,395 vehicles compared to a consensus estimate of 10,030 vehicles. The electric vehicle maker cited supply chain constraints as its "biggest constraint." Despite this, Rivian reiterated its annual production target of 50,000 units. Shares dropped 4% in early trade following the news. The company has been losing money on every vehicle it builds and narrowly missed its annual production target of 25,000 units last year.

site_title: Centurion looks to raise bed capacity amid dormitory supply crunch
summary: Centurion Corporation, a mainboard-listed dormitory operator, has received approval to increase the bed capacity at two of its quick-build dormitories. The company will add 888 more beds at Westlite Jalan Tukang and Westlite Tuas Avenue 2 dormitories, two sites that began operations in 2021. This move comes amid a dormitory supply crunch, allowing Centurion to meet the growing demand for temporary accommodation for migrant workers.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Revenue for the period was up 15 per cent to S$89.9 million from S$78.3 million, which the group attributed to the stronger demand for workers and student accommodation across all geographies.
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: UBS and Credit Suisse shares drop as Swiss prosecutor investigates takeover
summary: Switzerland's federal prosecutor launched an investigation into the emergency merger of Credit Suisse and UBS, looking into potential breaches of the country's criminal law by government officials, regulators, and executives. The investigation led to a 4% drop in UBS shares and a 1.8% drop in Credit Suisse shares, underperforming the European banking index. The investigation's outcome is unclear, but it has raised concerns about the takeover's legitimacy.

images.alt_text: US authorities seized the assets of SVB, after a run on deposits made it unsustainable on its own. Its failure sparked a run on First Republic and other smaller regional US banks.

site_title: US manufacturing sector weakest in nearly three years in March: ISM
summary: US manufacturing activity slumped to its lowest level in nearly three years in March, according to the Institute for Supply Management, with its manufacturing PMI falling to 46.3 from 47.7 in February. This marks the fifth straight month the PMI remained below the 50 threshold, indicating contraction in manufacturing. Economists had forecast the index to dip to 47.5. Despite this, hard data suggest moderate growth in the sector, which accounts for 11.3% of the economy.

site_title: Japan to scrap virus tests on arrival from China
summary: Japan will end COVID-19 testing for travelers arriving from mainland China, effective Wednesday, requiring proof of vaccination or a negative test result obtained before departure. This decision follows a spat over COVID border measures, which began in January, and comes after China suspended issuing short-term visas to Japanese citizens. The move aims to end "discriminatory practices" and align with other countries' travel policies.

site_title: Oil leaps 6% as Opec+ shocks markets by cutting output target
summary: Opec+ shocked markets by cutting its production target by 1.16 million barrels per day, causing oil prices to jump 6% on Monday. Brent crude reached its highest since March 7 at $86.44, while West Texas Intermediate crude rose to a two-month high. The move raises fears of tightening supplies, but some warn that reduced demand could follow if oil refiners lower activity to counter rising input costs.

site_title: US to build US$300 million database to fuel Alzheimer’s research
summary: The US National Institute on Aging (NIA) has funded a $300 million, 6-year project to build a massive Alzheimer's research database to track the health of 70-90% of the US population, enabling researchers to gain new insights into the brain-wasting disease. The database will combine data from medical records, insurance claims, pharmacies, and government agencies to track patients before and after symptoms develop. The platform aims to increase representation of underrepresented groups in clinical trials and help identify healthy individuals at risk for Alzheimer's for future drug trials.

site_title: US dollar trims gains as markets weigh impact of Opec+ cuts
summary: The US dollar index trimmed its gains against a basket of six currencies, down 0.4% to 102.49, as investors focused on diverging central bank policy and the impact of Opec+ oil production cuts on inflation. Oil prices surged 8% following the announcement of further output cuts, putting pressure on global inflation and leading to a stronger euro. The euro rose 0.2% to $1.0865, while the US dollar index and euro were influenced by central bank policy, with traders pricing in around 60 basis points of further tightening from the ECB and 15 basis points from the Fed.

site_title: Glencore’s US$23 billion offer rebuffed by Canadian miner Teck
summary: Glencore's $23 billion offer to buy Canadian miner Teck was rejected by the company's board and controlling Keevil family, who stated that Teck is not up for sale. The proposal, made on March 26, represented a 20% premium at the time and would have been worth $23.2 billion. The decision comes as the mining industry shifts focus towards metals like copper and nickel, while still relying on coal for profits.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Canadian mining company Teck Resources Limited is displayed as people visit the Prospectors and Developers Association of Canada (PDAC) annual conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada March 7, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren

site_title: Hotel rooms at over US$500 a night too much – even rich travellers
summary: High-end travelers are scaling back on holiday spending, with 69% saying their maximum budget per hotel room night is $500, and only 2% willing to spend $3,000 or more. This trend is attributed to diminishing consumer confidence and complaints about inflated pricing not being accompanied by a proportionate increase in service quality. The findings also suggest that luxury hotels, restaurants, and airlines will face increasingly irritated consumers this summer, with over half of professional investors predicting negative economic factors will undermine airline stocks.

images.alt_text: Hotel occupancy rates climbed to 83.6 per cent in February, from 70.4 per cent the previous month.
Shanghai-based Shimao, in the process of restructuring US$11.8 billion of offshore debt, is among the many Chinese developers that defaulted last year.
Kuala Lumpur, the capital city of Malaysia, continued to achieve a high hotel occupancy rate of over 60 per cent in February this year.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as oil output cut reignites inflation worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, April 3, as oil prices surged, reigniting inflation worries and fueling bets of another interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones fell 28.37 points, or 0.09%, to 33,245.78, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The market reaction is in line with concerns about the Fed's potential next move to combat inflation, which has been a major focus for investors and policymakers.

site_title: US citizen extradited to Singapore charged with alleged role in S$18 million forex scheme
summary: An American man, Michael Philip Atkins, 50, has been charged in Singapore with allegedly being involved in a $18 million forex scheme. Atkins, a director and shareholder of Aureus Capital, is accused of knowingly carrying on a business for a fraudulent purpose. The scheme collected $18 million from over 1,000 investors between 2013 and 2014, but it's alleged that Aureus Capital didn't operate substantive trading activities. Atkins faces up to 7 years imprisonment and a fine of up to $15,000 if convicted.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
There were 31,728 scam cases reported in 2022, up from 23,933 cases in 2021, an increase of 32.6 per cent.
Data from the Singapore Police Force shows that the number of scam cases rose to 6,492 in 2022, up 42.7 per cent from 2021.

site_title: Is globalisation over?
summary: Globalization, not dead, is a natural process driven by technological changes reducing distance's importance. It has its roots in human history, with examples of intercontinental interactions and interdependencies since the spread of humans across the planet. Economic globalization, while unevenly shared, has become a global phenomenon with modern technology. Despite concerns of decoupling, global trade and investment have shown resilience, with the US and China maintaining strong economic ties. Ecological globalisation, driven by shared environmental challenges, ensures continued interdependence, regardless of economic shifts.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye
A robotic arm picks up sorting containers at an Amazon fulfillment centre in the United States.

One hot spot for zones is Dubai, with “legal bubble-domes” dedicated to different activities: Healthcare City is next to Media City is next to Internet City, each with a bespoke set of laws drawn up with foreign investors in mind.

site_title: Opec+ cuts put US$100 a barrel of oil back in sight
summary: OPEC+ announced a surprise 1.16 million barrel per day production target cut from May through the end of the year, bringing the total cuts to 3.66 million barrels per day. The move, which could push oil prices towards $100 a barrel, signals unity within the group despite US pressure on its Gulf allies to weaken ties with Russia. Analysts predict the cuts will add to tightness in the oil market, lifting prices and potentially boosting revenue for Russia to fund its war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Oil prices last month fell towards US$70 a barrel, the lowest in 15 months, on concern that a global banking crisis would hit demand.

site_title: 10-year average return for latest tranche of Singapore Savings Bonds falls to 3.07%
summary: The 10-year average return for the latest Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) tranche has fallen to 3.07%, down from 3.15% in the previous month. Despite a spike in yields last month, interest has waned due to lower rate hike expectations. The May tranche, offering a 10-year average return of 3.07%, saw a rise in demand amid turmoil in the banking industry. The SSBs drew strong investor interest last year as coupon rates rose alongside rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Singapore currency notes are seen through a magnifying glass among other currencies in this April 12, 2013 file photo illustration. REUTERS/Edgar Su/Illustration/Files
The April tranche of the Singapore government-backed bonds received a total of S$758.1 million in applications, as compared to the total of S$261.1 million in applications for the March issuance.
The April tranche of SSBs is offering a first-year interest rate of 3.01 per cent and a 10-year average return of 3.15 per cent.

site_title: Saudi Arabia invests US$38 billion to become a video-game hub
summary: Saudi Arabia has invested $38 billion to become a major player in the global gaming market, with a focus on diversifying its economy away from oil. The country's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has established Savvy Gaming Group, a subsidiary that aims to develop, publish, and acquire top-tier games. With a growing population of 21 million gamers, Saudi Arabia is poised to capture a significant share of the $184 billion global gaming market, with analysts predicting a 56% growth in the Middle East and North Africa market by 2026.

images.alt_text: The surge comes after the UK Competition and Markets Authority narrowed the scope of their merger probe, putting the stock around 11 per cent below Microsoft’s US$95-per-share offer.
Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund now owns 8.3 per cent of Nintendo, building up a position that stood at just above 6 per cent at the start of the year.

This photo taken on September 23, 2022 shows people playing video games at the GiGO Akihabara Building number 4, previously known as the Sega Akihabara Building number 4, which was filled with floors of arcade and video games, in the popular electronics shopping area of Akihabara in Tokyo. - With the arcade industry struggling with fewer visitors due to Covid-19 and a trend to online gaming, the arcade - located directly opposite the train station - closed its doors on September 25 after the lease expired. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: WWE, Endeavor-owned UFC to merge into US$21 billion entertainment giant
summary: WWE and Endeavor-owned UFC are merging to form a US$21 billion entertainment giant. WWE executive chairman Vince McMahon will retain his role, while Endeavor will own a 51% stake. The deal caps a months-long sale process for WWE and marks a "transformational step" for Endeavor, according to CEO Ari Emanuel. The combined company will be a major player in the sports and entertainment industry, bringing together two leading brands in wrestling and mixed martial arts.

site_title: Australian F1 chief vows investigation after fans invade track
summary: Australian Grand Prix officials vowed a full investigation after fans invaded the track before the race finished, citing an "unsafe environment" for spectators, drivers, and officials. The FIA, the sport's governing body, condemned the breach, stating security measures were not enforced. The incident occurred after a "large group" of fans broke through barriers and fences near speeding cars. Organizers, led by Andrew Westacott, admitted the breach was unacceptable and will review security footage to determine the cause.

images.alt_text: Yin became just the second player from China to win on the LPGA tour, after 10-time winner Feng Shanshan.
With the win Medvedev earned his fifth Masters 1000 title and improved to 6-0 lifetime against Sinner.

site_title: Banks too reluctant to tap cash buffers in a crisis, Bank of England says
summary: The Bank of England has expressed concern that banks are reluctant to tap their liquidity buffers, known as the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR), in volatile markets, fearing adverse reactions from regulators and markets. This reluctance could lead to destabilizing actions that harm the wider economy and financial system. The BOE suggests that banks should feel able to draw on their LCRs to reduce this risk and proposes that regulators spell out during market stress the extent to which LCRs can fall and how much time banks have to rebuild them.

images.alt_text: The BOE warned for the first time that private-equity owned and highly-indebted companies may struggle to refinance their debts as rising interest rates force investors to make sharp changes in the way they value assets.

site_title: Asia holds promise for banks amid China reopening, says StanChart CEO Bill Winters
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters sees growth opportunities in Asia as China reopens, despite the recent banking crisis. Regional economic activity remains robust, and trade is picking up within the Asian region. The bank aims to increase its penetration of the financial institutions market and help institutionalize savings in China. Winters notes that the banking crisis may lead to increased competition for deposits and reduced profits, but the bank is in good shape from a credit perspective.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Bill Winters, group CEO at Standard Chartered Bank  speaking during the UK-Asean Business Forum in London.
Standard Chartered upgraded its performance forecast, saying it now expected to achieve a return on tangible equity – a key profitability metric – of 10 per cent this year and 11 per cent in 2024.
on Thursday, British bank Standard Chartered won an approval to set up a new securities brokerage unit in China, the CSRC said.
While First Abu Dhabi Bank said it is no longer evaluating a possible offer, the news sent shares in Standard Chartered higher as investors weighed the prospects of any deal.

site_title: Teachers in England reject pay offer, announce further strikes
summary: Teachers in England have rejected a pay offer from the British government, citing an "astounding lack of judgement and understanding" of the education system. The National Education Union's 98% vote to reject the offer, which includes a £1,000 payment and a 4.5% pay rise, will lead to two further days of strike action on April 27 and May 2. The union urges the government to return to negotiations with a better proposal, as the dispute continues to leave classrooms empty and pressure the Prime Minister to intervene.

images.alt_text: An empty platform at Berlin’s main central station on March 27, 2023.  Transport employees are pressing for higher wages to blunt the effects of inflation, which reached 9.3 per cent in February.

site_title: SIA’s Chin Yau Seng to helm SIA Engineering from October as CEO Ng Chin Hwee retires
summary: SIA Engineering Company announced that CEO Ng Chin Hwee will retire on October 1, after guiding the company through the Covid-19 pandemic. Ng will be succeeded by Chin Yau Seng, senior vice-president of Singapore Airlines' cargo division, who will take over as CEO-designate on June 1. The company praised Ng's contributions and expressed confidence in Chin's experience in aviation, business, and operations. Shares of SIA and SIAEC rose following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The new services agreement will start on April 1, 2023, and is for a term of two years.
The agreement, commencing on April 1, is for a term of two years, with an option to extend for an additional year.

site_title: Malaysian MPs vote to axe mandatory death penalty
summary: Malaysia's parliament passed a Bill on Monday to remove mandatory death sentences, granting judges the option to impose lengthy prison sentences of 30-40 years under certain conditions. The move, welcomed by rights groups, does not scrap death sentences but aims to reduce arbitrariness in convictions. The Bill still needs to clear the senate, but is expected to pass without major opposition. The reform is seen as an important step forward for Malaysia and could have a knock-on effect in South-east Asia, with some nations re-evaluating their use of the death penalty.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Minister for Law and Home Affairs K Shanmugam was a guest on the BBC's HARDtalk show, which aired on June 29, 2022.

site_title: Philippines set to receive first-ever LNG cargo for power generation
summary: The Philippines has purchased its first-ever liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo, bound for a 1,200-megawatt power plant, after spot LNG prices in Asia fell sharply due to Russia's reduced gas supplies to Europe. The LNG cargo will be delivered in mid-April to Singapore-based Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific's (AG&P) import terminal in the Philippines. This purchase comes as the country seeks alternative fuel supply for its power plants due to declining output from its Malampaya natural gas field.

site_title: Indonesia graft agency arrests tax official at centre of wealth scandal
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency arrested Rafael Alun Trisambodo, a senior tax officer, on corruption charges. He allegedly received US$90,000 in kickbacks from taxpayers via a consultancy group, sparking public outrage over government officials flaunting wealth. The agency confiscated luxury items and cash worth 32.2 billion rupiah, charging Rafael with receiving kickbacks, which carries a maximum 20-year prison term. This case comes amid public distrust of tax officials and calls to boycott taxes, prompting Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati to probe civil servants and taxpayers whose accounts were overseen by Rafael.

images.alt_text: A majority of tax officials support the plan that would remove the agency from under Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati’s watch.

site_title: UBS Credit Suisse deal unseats JPMorgan as Latin America’s top wealth manager
summary: UBS has acquired Credit Suisse's Latin American wealth management business, surpassing JPMorgan as the top wealth manager in the region with $230 billion in assets under management. The deal adds $80 billion to UBS' existing $150 billion from clients in Latin America. UBS will expand its global wealth-management platform, focusing on growth in South-east Asia, the Middle East, and Latin America, and will dominate Brazil equity trading. The acquisition, brokered by the Swiss government, is expected to accelerate UBS' organic growth by 5-7 years.

images.alt_text: UBS' deal to buy Credit Suisse has raised concerns over the size of a new bank with US$1.6 trillion in assets and more than 120,000 staff worldwide.

site_title: India needs to double share of clean power to meet climate goals
summary: India aims to double its share of clean power to 90% by 2047 to meet climate goals, according to federal Power Secretary Alok Kumar. The country needs to reduce coal's share and accelerate clean power plant deployment. To achieve this, India will focus on domestic manufacturing of green technologies, such as solar modules and battery storage. The government has awarded production-linked grants for solar modules and is looking to acquire critical mineral assets abroad. Meeting its climate goals will require significant investment and domestic capacity, with Kumar stating "there is no alternative."

site_title: Singapore’s steep rentals not be-all, end-all issue for expats: analysts
summary: Singapore's steep private home rents, which rose 29.7% in 2022, may not be a major concern for expats and companies considering the city-state as a business hub, according to analysts. Rising rents, which have surged 41.7% in the past three years, are just one factor in Singapore's attractiveness, with low mortgage rates also being a consideration. Despite concerns from expats, experts believe the city-state's business appeal remains strong, driven by other factors such as its economic outlook and skilled migrant workforce.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Marina One Residences had one of the highest number of leasing transactions among private condominium and apartment projects in district 1 last year.


Copyright: M+S Pte Ltd
In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.
Reality check for landlords as rents may have peaked; viewings decline

site_title: US Army awards Lockheed up to US$4.5 billion missiles contract
summary: The US Army has awarded Lockheed Martin a multi-year production contract for Joint-Air-to-Ground Missiles (JAGM) and HELLFIRE missiles, worth up to $4.5 billion over four years. The contract, including follow-on awards, will start in late 2023 and is part of the Pentagon's efforts to build stocks of precision munitions to deter China. The deal is among the first multi-year awards for precision munitions and anticipates a "significant increase" in international demand for the JAGM programme.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's overall sale transaction volume fell 8% quarter-on-quarter and 38% year-on-year in Q1 2023. Private home prices rose 3.2% in Q1, driven by lower sales volume. Oil prices boosted Singapore's oil and gas stocks, but economists warn of higher oil prices adding to inflationary pressures. Sembmarine proposes changing its name to Seatrium, while HDB resale prices climbed 0.9% in Q1.

site_title: Airbus in talks for new China jet order ahead of Macron visit
summary: Airbus is in talks for a new order of dozens of jets from China ahead of French President Emmanuel Macron's visit to the country. The potential deal comes as China's relations with the US worsen, causing a shift in airplane imports towards Airbus. This follows a July order of 292 jets from China's "Big Three" state airlines, the largest since the Covid-19 pandemic. Negotiations are ongoing, with details not yet finalized, and the deal could serve as a barometer of diplomatic ties between Europe and China.

site_title: ByteDance matches Tencent’s US$80 billion sales after TikTok boom
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, reported a 30% surge in revenue to surpass $80 billion in 2022, matching archrival Tencent Holdings. This marks the company's fastest growth among global internet leaders, with Douyin, its Chinese cousin, driving the expansion. Despite global recession risks and regulatory challenges, ByteDance's robust growth has boosted investor confidence, with its valuation reaching $220 billion in a recent private investment.

images.alt_text: Zhang Yiming’s estimated net worth has fallen to $42.3 billion after a US testimony detailed a smaller ByteDance ownership stake than previously known.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise as markets leave banking woes behind; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to close at 3,281.08 points, driven by a strong performance from blue-chip stocks like Genting Singapore and Thai Beverage. Analysts believe the market has left behind banking woes, with a focus shifting to "what's next," such as the impact of OPEC's supply cut. The STI saw 2.26 billion securities worth S$1.44 billion traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 374 to 229.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Singapore shares rise at Monday’s open, tracking global rally; STI up 0.6%

The grouping Opec+, which comprises members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) as well as major non-Opec oil producers such as Russia, on Sunday (Apr 2) announced it would cut oil output by about 1.2 million barrels per day (bpd).

site_title: Investing lessons from the banking turmoil
summary: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Credit Suisse has highlighted the importance of risk management and due diligence in investing. Investors should diversify their portfolios to minimize losses and consider the cost factor, as higher fees can significantly reduce returns over time. The article advises against making emotional decisions based on market volatility and instead recommends staying invested in a core, diversified portfolio with an evidence-based approach. By following these lessons, investors can achieve peace of mind and ride out market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The upshot of regulatory intervention is that crypto companies are now being disenfranchised from the US banking system.
First Citizens BancShares has made an agreement with US banking regulators to acquire Silicon Valley Bank. SVB's risk management practices were an outlier but its vulnerabilities weren't unique.

site_title: HSBC brushes aside Hong Kong investor's Asia spin-off proposal, fixed dividends
summary: HSBC has rejected a proposal by activist shareholder Ken Lui to spin off its Asia business, citing significant cost and disruption to clients, employees, and shareholders. The bank's Chairman Mark Tucker stated that a restructuring would create uncertainty and material execution risks. The bank has instead restored quarterly dividend payments and plans a special $0.21 dividend after selling its Canadian unit later this year, citing substantial dividend distribution capacity and a year expected for the best returns in a decade.

images.alt_text: HSBC veteran Justin Chan will take up his new role at the start of next month, the memo said.

site_title: US first-quarter auto sales set to rise on better inventory
summary: US auto sales are expected to rise for the second consecutive quarter, driven by improved inventory levels as supply chain disruptions ease. Automakers like General Motors are increasing production, while Toyota's sales are forecast to decline nearly 10% due to ongoing inventory shortages. Overall, Edmunds predicts 3,502,324 new vehicles to be sold in the US in the first quarter, a 1.8% decrease from the previous quarter, with trucks and crossover SUVs accounting for the majority of sales.

site_title: Eurozone factory downturn deepened in March
summary: The Eurozone's factory downturn deepened in March, with activity at struggling factories falling further due to consumers cutting back on spending amid rising living costs. The S&P Global manufacturing PMI fell to 47.3, below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction for a ninth month. However, a composite PMI measuring output rose to a 10-month high of 50.4, indicating economic health. Input prices fell for the first time since July 2020, allowing factories to increase charges at the slowest pace in over two years, and prices rose 6.9% last month.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Japan’s SMBC CEO is watching out for chances to expand US assets
summary: Japan's SMBC CEO, Akihiro Fukutome, has stated the bank is watching for opportunities to expand US assets, despite the recent banking crisis. Fukutome ruled out buying a US bank whole, but will examine assets for sale and manage them through a team of bankers. The bank has already teamed up with Jefferies Financial Group and plans to increase its stake in the investment bank. Fukutome believes the US market will remain attractive and that Japanese banks' stability in the US has been highlighted by the SVB crisis.

images.alt_text: The SVB collapse earlier this month has put Japanese regional banks’ foreign bond portfolios under investor scrutiny.

site_title: UK extends trading plan to sell NatWest stake by two years
summary: The UK government has extended a trading plan to sell its remaining 41.5% stake in NatWest by two years, until August 11, 2025. The plan involves small sales of shares and will only consider bigger chunks to private investors or NatWest when they achieve value for taxpayers. The government aims to fully privatize NatWest by 2026. Since the plan's inception in 2021, around £3.7 billion has been raised, with each sale below the bailout price and crystallizing losses for taxpayers.

images.alt_text: The NatWest Group says this is the first social bond from a European financial institution where the proceeds are dedicated to funding loans to women-led enterprises.

site_title: SVB fallout: Implications from Fed policy to geopolitics
summary: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and subsequent US Treasury and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) actions to cushion the financial system's spillover have raised concerns about contagion risk. Hundreds of millions of savers and tens of millions of small businesses were at risk due to unrealised losses on securities holdings and uninsured deposits totaling US$10 trillion. Policymakers' actions, including a Treasury-backed emergency facility and guarantees for uninsured depositors, were necessary but may not be sufficient to stem contagion risk. The episode's implications include a possible shift in Fed policy, increased regulation for regional banks, and a renewed focus on institutional credibility and geopolitics.

images.alt_text: Whatever the source of concern behind a bank's failure, it is the loss of asset value which triggers the failure of the institution.
US authorities seized the assets of SVB, after a run on deposits made it unsustainable on its own. Its failure sparked a run on First Republic and other smaller regional US banks.

site_title: Thai poll hopefuls register as opposition vows constitutional reform
summary: Thai opposition parties have begun registering for the upcoming general election, where Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha faces a tough challenge from a resurgent opposition fronted by Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of billionaire former PM Thaksin Shinawatra. Pheu Thai and the Move Forward Party are leading in the polls, with the opposition vowing to rewrite Thailand's army-scripted constitution. The election is set for May 14, and if Pheu Thai wins, it aims to hold public hearings to redraft the constitution, with Paetongtarn potentially becoming the country's first female prime minister.

images.alt_text: epa10556485 Youngest daughter of exiled former deposed Thai leader Thaksin Shinawatra and Pheu Thai Party's key figure, who is expected to be nominated as prime minister candidate Paetongtarn Shinawatra leads the party's candidates to the constituency candidates registration in Bangkok, Thailand, 03 April 2023. Thailand starts the registration of constituency candidates nationwide to kick off the general election which is scheduled to be held on 14 May 2023.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT
Recent surveys have showed Prayuth’s (centre) support slipping and his main rival, political neophyte Paetongtarn, far ahead.
CGS-CIMB thinks Pheu Thai Party is likely to win half of the House of Representatives in the upcoming election.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting rises 4.5% to S$1.17, nearly a five-year high
summary: Genting Singapore shares surged 4.5% to a five-year high of S$1.17 on April 3, after a married deal was recorded at S$1.13. The integrated resort operator's counter reached a high of S$1.18 in the midday break.

site_title: China tightens regulation in US$580 billion bond fund market: sources
summary: China's securities regulator has tightened regulations in the US$580 billion bond fund market, reducing the proportion of riskier debt mutual funds can hold. New bond funds can now invest up to 20% in AA+ bonds, down from 50%, and must hold at least 80% in AAA bonds. This move aims to curb leverage and mitigate risks amid a slowing business environment and government efforts to restructure the economy. Existing funds will not be affected by the new rules.

site_title: Swedish home prices resume slide, led by detached houses
summary: Sweden's single-family home prices declined 1.5% in March, driven by stubbornly high inflation and rising borrowing costs. This follows a 0.8% decline in underlying trend figures, with apartment prices remaining unchanged. Forecasters expect prices to fall an additional 5% from the peak, driven by the Riksbank's key rate hikes to cool core inflation, which is at its fastest pace in over 30 years.

site_title: China's faltering March factory activity weighs on GDP outlook
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed a lackluster rebound in March, with the Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI falling to 50.0, below expectations. The sector's slowdown is expected to weigh on the country's near-term economic outlook, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) slashing its first-quarter GDP forecast to 3.8% from 4.5%. Despite signs of a recovery in services, external demand remains fragile, posing a risk to domestic demand, according to economists. China's GDP growth is expected to slow further, with some predicting a 4.0% year-on-year growth in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: A non-manufacturing gauge of activity in both the services and construction sectors surged to 58.2 in March, the highest level since May 2011.

site_title: Trump’s indictment: Legal requirements versus political concerns
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is expected to surrender to New York authorities on April 4 to face charges related to a hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels. This marks the first criminal indictment of a former US president, sending a message that no one is above the law. However, the indictment falls short of allegations against Trump in other investigations, including his role in the January 6, 2021, US Capitol assault. Trump's supporters have called the indictment a "witch hunt" and may use the media attention to fuel his 2024 presidential campaign, potentially igniting political unrest and polarization in the US.

images.alt_text: The charges could reshape the 2024 presidential race.
Trump is under criminal investigation in Georgia and Washington, DC, for his attempts to subvert the outcome in the 2020 race.

site_title: Capital adequacy approach to bank soundness is fundamentally flawed
summary: A widely held approach to bank soundness is flawed due to its reliance on capital adequacy standards, which fail to account for market fluctuations. Loss of asset value, rather than capital, often triggers bank insolvency. The author argues that prompt regulatory support and a comprehensive, interdependent assessment of financial health are necessary to mitigate the impact of financial crises. The current system, with its inconsistent and poorly informed guidelines, undermines the financial system's stability and efficiency.

images.alt_text: The basic function of banks is to provide money and credit, but depositors cannot monitor the soundness of banks in real time.
The World Bank estimates that governments in developing countries and the private sector would need to spend US$2.4 trillion a year on average through 2030.

site_title: As bank crisis fears ease, gold prices set to stabilise for now
summary: Gold prices are expected to stabilize in the short term due to easing bank crisis fears, but may break through the March peak of $2,010 an ounce in the next six to nine months if banking and geopolitical uncertainties persist. Analysts predict an average gold price of $1,860-$1,880 this year, with potential for a surge to $2,500 an ounce in 2024. Central banks, particularly in emerging markets, are expected to continue buying gold, driving prices higher, despite concerns about inflation and stagflation.

images.alt_text: Gold is set to end the quarter and the month higher on expectations that the Fed might consider a rate-hike pause after the collapse of two US regional banks.
A worsening and prolonged banking turmoil and sooner-than-expected pivot by the Fed amid persistent fear could set the bullion on a historic surge

“Armed with substantial nickel reserves, Indonesia’s ambition to be the EV hub of South-east Asia will help drive its economic growth,” said Henry Wibowo, JP Morgan’s head of Indonesia research and strategy.

site_title: Cineworld ditches sale of US, UK businesses after failing to find buyer
summary: Cineworld has abandoned plans to sell its US, UK, and Ireland businesses after failing to find a buyer, citing a lack of an all-cash bid exceeding the proposed restructuring deal's value. The company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in the US, will instead reduce debt by $4.53 billion through a deal with lenders, who will receive equity in the reorganized group. Shares plummet 35% following the decision. Cineworld will continue to consider proposals for its 'Rest of World' business, which includes operations outside the US, UK, and Ireland.

images.alt_text: Cineplex is in early talks with Cineworld’s lenders about taking over Regal in exchange for debt and stock backed by the combined business.

site_title: Dungeons & Dragons finds N America moviegoers are game
summary: Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves, a fantasy heist film, opened in North American theatres with an estimated $38.5 million, beating competition. The film's performance is seen as a promising start for potential sequels, particularly in foreign markets. Industry watchers expect the film to be profitable and generate sequels due to its high production budget. In second place was John Wick: Chapter 4, while Scream VI and His Only Son also performed well in their opening weekends.

images.alt_text: Cast member Keanu Reeves attends the premiere for the film "John Wick: Chapter 4", in Los Angeles, California, U.S., March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni

site_title: Nomura taps ex-Citi banker as head of wealth for north Asia
summary: Nomura Holdings has appointed Rudolf Hitsch, a former Citi Private Bank executive, as head of its north Asia wealth management business. Hitsch, with 25 years of experience in private banking serving Chinese clients, will oversee client relationship management teams in Hong Kong and report to Ravi Raju. This move is part of Nomura's efforts to build its wealth management operations in Greater China, South and South-east Asia, and the Middle East, where it has hired around 50 private bankers over the past 2.5 years.

site_title: Japan’s business mood sours to 2-year low as global slowdown bites: survey
summary: Japan's business sentiment has reached a 2-year low, with the service sector showing a slight recovery, according to the Bank of Japan's tankan survey. The big manufacturers' sentiment index fell to plus 1 in March, the lowest since December 2020, due to rising raw material and fuel costs, and slowing overseas growth. Despite this, big non-manufacturers' index rose to plus 20, driven by hopes of a rebound in tourism and service demand. The survey's findings will influence the central bank's growth and inflation estimates at its next meeting.

images.alt_text: A Japanese flag flutters atop the Bank of Japan building in Tokyo May 22, 2015. The Bank of Japan maintained its massive stimulus programme and offered a slightly more upbeat view of the world's third-largest economy on Friday, as a modest rebound in consumption helped service-sector sentiment improve to a one-year high. REUTERS/Toru Hanai
The Japanese government's move to boost childcare comes  as the country faces a relentless drop in its birth rate.

site_title: China urges Japan to refrain from joining US chip curbs
summary: China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang urged Japan to refrain from joining US efforts to restrict the Chinese semiconductor industry, warning that such actions would strengthen Beijing's resolve for self-reliance. Qin also pressed for the swift release of a detained Japanese citizen and urged Japan to avoid issues related to Taiwan that could harm China's sovereignty. The visit comes amid strained bilateral relations and a long-running standoff over disputed islands in the East China Sea.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Micron logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
China faces a shortage of an estimated 200,000 industry workers this year.

site_title: Surprise Opec+ crude cuts trigger fresh inflationary jolt
summary: Opec+ unexpectedly announced a surprise 1 million barrel per day crude output cut, exceeding 500,000 barrels from Saudi Arabia, starting next month. This move is expected to tighten the market, triggering a fresh inflationary jolt and complicating central banks' efforts to tame price pressures. Crude prices surged, with West Texas Intermediate reaching an 8% gain, and the White House described the decision as ill-advised.

images.alt_text: Oil prices last month fell towards US$70 a barrel, the lowest in 15 months, on concern that a global banking crisis would hit demand.

site_title: Australia PM Albanese boosted by historic by-election win
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's Labor party won a historic by-election in Melbourne's eastern suburbs, with a swing of over 6% in favor of Mary Doyle. The result boosts Albanese's government ahead of its one-year anniversary, with high approval ratings and a 58% lead over opposition leader Peter Dutton in a recent poll. Albanese said the win was a "significant victory" but urged caution, citing global supply chain problems linked to Russia's war in Ukraine as a cause of rising living costs.

images.alt_text: Prices were still down 8 per cent from a year earlier.
Stubborn inflation has posed a challenge for the RBA, which last month lifted its cash rate to its highest level in more than a decade.

site_title: Vietnam faces challenge in meeting 2023 growth target: planning ministry
summary: Vietnam's economy is facing challenges in meeting its 2023 growth target of 6.5%, with the first quarter's GDP growth slowing to 3.32% due to weakening global demand. Exports fell 11.9% from a year earlier, impacting domestic growth and business activities, particularly industrial production and exports. The Ministry of Planning and Investment has forecast 6.0-6.5% growth for the year, aiming for the higher figure.

site_title: Wind’s future is looking more turbulent than ever
summary: The global wind energy industry is experiencing a surge in demand, with the US, Europe, and China aiming to increase offshore wind capacity significantly by 2030. However, the supply side is hindered by planning restrictions, regulatory challenges, and supply-chain bottlenecks. The UK's major energy plan failed to address these issues, and companies like Orsted have backed out of projects due to regulatory and financial concerns. As a result, wind power installations have fallen short of forecasts, and the industry's growth may continue to disappoint unless these issues are addressed.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is seen as a potential major player in the offshore wind energy sector because of its strong winds in shallow waters near coastal, densely populated areas.
Mercedes aims for 70 per cent of its energy demand from vehicle production to be covered by renewable sources by 2030.

site_title: Japan factory activity shrinks at slowest pace in five months: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted at the slowest pace in five months in March, with manufacturing output and new orders declining for a ninth consecutive month. The au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 49.2, marking an improvement from the previous month's 47.7. Weak demand conditions, including a global slowdown and rising food prices, continue to affect the economy, with inflation remaining a concern.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy narrowly averted a recession in the final three months of 2022.

site_title: Singapore O&G stocks up after Opec+ cut, but economists warn of higher oil prices adding to inflationary pressures
summary: Singapore-listed oil stocks rose after Opec+ announced a 1.2 million barrel-per-day cut in oil output, boosting Brent crude futures by 5.1% to US$83.96. However, economists warn that high oil prices could add to inflationary pressures, particularly in Singapore, a net oil importer, where higher oil prices could negatively impact the economy, particularly the transport and aviation sectors. Economists predict higher oil prices will remain intact, with Brent crude trading around US$80 per barrel in Q2 and Q3, and potentially rising to US$90 per barrel in Q4 and Q1 next year.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Oil prices last month fell towards US$70 a barrel, the lowest in 15 months, on concern that a global banking crisis would hit demand.
Costlier crude prices threatens to spur still-elevated inflation, complicating the task facing central banks including the Federal Reserve to tame price pressures.

site_title: Mitsubishi UFJ to postpone AT1 bond issuance in Credit Suisse fallout
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will postpone the issuance of Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds to mid-May or later due to market volatility following Credit Suisse's bond wipeout. The decision takes into account investor appetite and market conditions. AT1 bonds, valued at $275 billion, can be converted to equity or written off if a bank's capital level falls below a certain threshold. The postponement aims to stabilize the market amid the Swiss regulator's decision to wipe out Credit Suisse's AT1 bonds.

site_title: Seymour Stein, record industry giant who signed Madonna, dies at 80
summary: Seymour Stein, a renowned record industry executive who signed Madonna, the Ramones, Talking Heads, and the Pretenders, has died at 80. Stein, born Seymour Steinbigle in 1942, began his music career in the 1950s and went on to found the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Foundation. He signed Madonna to Sire Records in 1982, leading to her massive success, and worked with other notable artists, including the Smiths, the Cure, and Brian Wilson. Stein's legacy as a music industry giant and his colorful personality have been celebrated through his memoir, "Siren Song: My Life in Music."

images.alt_text: The Yomiuri newspaper has reported that Ryuichi Sakamoto has died.

site_title: Economists split on whether Australia to pause tightening cycle
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is set to decide on interest rate hikes amid cooling economic momentum. Economists are divided, with 16 forecasting a pause at 3.6% and 11 predicting a quarter-point hike to 3.85%. A pause would be the first by a major developed-world central bank since the crisis began, but Governor Philip Lowe may signal further hikes ahead. The RBA's own forecasts show inflation returning to target in mid-2025, and the decision may be influenced by the impending expiry of fixed-rate home loans and the need to balance inflation and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Stubborn inflation has posed a challenge for the RBA, which last month lifted its cash rate to its highest level in more than a decade.

Newly built houses in the Denham Court suburb of Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, May 3, 2022. One of the developed world’s last remaining doves turned hawkish as Australia’s central bank rocked markets with a bigger-than-expected interest-rate hike in the middle of an election campaign. site_title: Indonesia’s inflation slows more than expected in March
summary: Indonesia's inflation slowed more than expected in March, reaching 4.97%, the lowest rate in seven months. This is lower than the 5.2% predicted by a Reuters poll. The annual core inflation rate was also below expectations at 2.94%. The statistics bureau attributes the slowdown to lower-than-expected price pressures during Ramadan, which began in late March. Experts predict inflation will continue to slow, with annual inflation rates forecast to range between 3.2% and 3.4% by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: There was a brighter outlook in South-east Asia, where the region’s biggest economy, Indonesia, ticked up to 51.9 from 51.2, the best showing since September.
Weakness in Indonesia’s secondary market is a  concern as the benchmark Jakarta Composite Index is down 0.7 per cent this year.

site_title: Regulating AI will be essential. And complicated
summary: The US government should regulate artificial intelligence (AI) to prevent potential harm, with a crucial threshold question being who should regulate AI. The author suggests that government regulation is necessary, especially if AI poses an existential threat to human society. Similar to nuclear weapons, AI companies should be heavily regulated, staffed by security-cleared scientists, and linked to the national security state. Moderate regulation options include statutory civil regulation, administrative rules, and lawsuits, each with their own flaws. A new federal agency could be created to regulate AI, balancing innovation with safety, and addressing concerns about industry capture and bureaucracy.

images.alt_text: Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Elon Musk, whose carmaker Tesla is using AI for an autopilot system, has been vocal about his concerns about AI.
The Rome-based watchdog gave OpenAI 20 days to respond, after which it could be subject to a fine of as much as 20 million euros (S$28.9 million) or up to 4 per cent of its annual revenue.
The rapid development and increasingly pervasive use of generative AI systems has alarmed many.

site_title: China new home sales rise sharply in March: survey
summary: China's new home sales surged 55.7% month-over-month in March, driven by support policies and a relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions. Sales in tier-one cities rose 73%, while tier-two and tier-three cities saw 54.7% and 28.6% growth, respectively. The data marks a gradual recovery for the sector, which has been impacted by crises since mid-2021. Policymakers introduced a comprehensive bailout package last year, and local governments continue to ease property curbs and roll out stimulus policies to boost buyer sentiment.

images.alt_text: Home purchases in Singapore, where Chinese are the top foreign buyers, cooled early in 2023 from last year’s torrid pace — but only slightly despite a steep rise in real estate stamp duties.
The Asian neighbours face a raft of bilateral problems including a long-running standoff over disputed islands in the East China Sea.
Officials from the People’s Bank of China say that authorities should strengthen supervision of financial institutions’ date accuracy to prevent risks.

site_title: The woes of Credit Suisse and Cyxtera may portend trouble for landlords
summary: Dark clouds may be looming for office buildings and other property types as concerns arise over tenants' ability to meet rental obligations amid a weaker economy. Recent woes at Credit Suisse and Cyxtera Technologies, a data centre operator, signal greater turbulence ahead for landlords. Investors should worry about the creditworthiness of tenants, with some landlords facing reduced single-tenant concentration and higher vacancy rates. Landlords need to have strong products and asset management teams to survive in a tougher leasing environment, and may see a silver lining if space vacated can be filled up at a higher rental rate.

UBS' deal to buy Credit Suisse has raised concerns over the size of a new bank with US$1.6 trillion in assets and more than 120,000 staff worldwide.

site_title: Missing Chinese banker’s firm delays 2022 results, halts trading
summary: China Renaissance Holdings, a Chinese investment bank, has delayed the release of its 2022 audited results and halted trading after chairman Bao Fan, who was cooperating with an investigation, went missing. The firm cited auditors' inability to complete the audit due to Bao's unavailability. The company posted an unaudited loss of 563.8 million yuan for 2022. The board will consider splitting Bao's roles as chairman and CEO. The firm's shares have plummeted 32% since Bao's disappearance.
