site_title: China’s Yin claims first LPGA title at Los Angeles Open
summary: China's Yin Ruoning won her first US LPGA title at the Los Angeles Open, claiming a one-stroke victory over Georgia Hall with a 15-under-par 269. Yin, 20, overcame an early bogey burst to card four straight birdies from the sixth through ninth holes, securing her first LPGA title and becoming the second player from China to win on the tour, following 10-time winner Feng Shanshan.

images.alt_text: Triple winner Stanley Gan with Lim Han Ming, EMTM deputy managing editor, and Ken Sim (right), marketing manager, adidas Golf SEA.
Salif Samake, president of Ouagadougou's Golf Club, tees off at one of the club's three courses. Here, the fairways comprise earth, stones and sinewy shrubs rather than manicured lawns.

site_title: Asia’s factories encounter hurdles in further North-South split
summary: Asia's factories faced challenges in March as the Chinese economic recovery gained momentum, despite a brighter outlook in South-east Asia. Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan remained in contraction territory, while Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines showed expansion. China's manufacturing activity eased to 51.9, driven by services sector growth and consumer spending. The divergence between North and South Asia highlights the region's ongoing economic disparities, with South-east Asia benefiting from healthier export orders and reduced inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: An undated photo of a VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) manufactured by the Universal Shipbuilding Corporation sailing off the coast of Japan. Source: Universal Shipbuilding Corporation via Bloomberg News.

site_title: Private home prices accelerate in Q1, rising 3.2% on low volume
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 3.2% in Q1 2023, driven by lower sales volume despite economic headwinds. New home sales accounted for 33.4% of total sales, while resales made up 62.4%. Prices climbed 11.3% year-over-year, with non-landed homes increasing 2.5% quarter-over-quarter. Luxury units, particularly those priced over $2 million, saw significant sales. Analysts expect prices to continue rising, albeit at a slower pace, with forecasts ranging from 3-5% growth for 2023.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Developers sold 432 units excluding executive condominiums in February, up 9.9 per cent from the 393 units moved in the previous month.

The benefits of a landed home came to the fore with the advent of Covid-19.

site_title: South Korea March factory activity contracts at sharpest pace in six months: PMI
summary: South Korea's factory activity contracted at the fastest pace in six months in March, according to a survey by S&P Global, with the PMI index declining to 47.6 from 48.5 in February. The contraction in output and new orders suggests weaker global demand will continue to drag on the domestic economic recovery. The sector has now experienced nine consecutive months of contraction, with input price inflation accelerating for the first time in five months.

images.alt_text: South Korea is the first major exporting economy to release trade data each month.
The sluggish factory output in February was led by semiconductors and automobile.

site_title: Endeavor nears deal to buy Vince McMahon’s WWE: sources
summary: Endeavor Group Holdings is in advanced talks to acquire World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) in an all-stock deal. The deal, which could be announced as early as this week, would see Endeavor shareholders owning 51% of the combined company and WWE shareholders getting 49%. The acquisition would value WWE at around $6.8 billion, with Endeavor's market value standing at $11.3 billion. This deal comes after WWE's CEO Vince McMahon returned to the company and initiated a strategic review, exploring options including a sale.

images.alt_text: Vince McMahon, the former chairman and chief executive of World Wrestling Entertainment, previously said he would retire as head of WWE
Vince McMahon’s daughter, Stephanie announced her resignation as co-CEO in a statement posted on Twitter.

site_title: Luxury London homebuyers want discounts, but sellers won’t budge
summary: Wealthy London homebuyers are demanding discounts on luxury properties, with over half expecting a 5% discount, but sellers are unwilling to budge. This gap in expectations, combined with a tougher market, has led to flat house-price growth in prime central London. Despite this, luxury sales have outperformed the wider market since mortgage rates soared in October last year, with new sales instructions for £5 million+ homes 74% higher in the final quarter of 2022. Sellers are standing firm on prices, citing limited supply of comparable properties, making deals harder to secure.

images.alt_text: Prices in Sydney have risen 1.4 per cent in March after advancing 0.3 per cent in February.

site_title: Medvedev beats Sinner for first Miami Open title
summary: Daniil Medvedev won the Miami Open, defeating Jannik Sinner 7-5 6-3. Medvedev, the fourth seed, secured his fifth Masters 1000 title and improved to 6-0 lifetime against Sinner. He praised the faster surfaces in Miami, saying they suited his playing style, and acknowledged Sinner's struggles in the hot and humid conditions. Medvedev's win marked his fourth title of the year and 19th overall, while Sinner remains searching for his first Masters 1000 title.

Nadal was forced to skip the Masters 1000 event in California, as he continues his recovery from a hip issue that ended his Australian Open title defence in the second round in January.

site_title: Sembmarine proposes changing its name to Seatrium
summary: Sembmarine Ltd has proposed changing its name to Seatrium Limited, a combination of "sea" and "atrium," reflecting its business and aspiration to be a premier global player in the offshore, marine, and energy industries. The name change is subject to shareholder approval and will not affect the company's identity or operations. Sembmarine has also recorded pre-tax losses for three consecutive years but meets the financial entry criteria to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday’s open, tracking global rally; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,279.28 on Monday, tracking a global rally. The market saw 79.1 million securities worth S$77.8 million trade, with gainers outnumbering losers 93 to 30. Key gainers included Sembcorp Marine, Genting Singapore, and Dyna-Mac, while banking stocks also rose. The rally follows a positive close on Wall Street and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index on Friday, as investor fears over the banking industry ease.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
SIA Engineering is providing Scoot maintenance, repair and overhaul and fleet management support services under a new S$120.8 million agreement.

site_title: China ready to speed up talks with Asean over South China Sea
summary: China is prepared to speed up talks with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) over a South China Sea code of conduct, according to Chinese Premier Li Qiang. China aims to jointly maintain peace and stability in the area, while Asean nations, including Malaysia, have been working with China for nearly 20 years to establish the code. Li also expressed willingness to advance negotiations on the Asean-China Free Trade Area and promote regional economic cooperation.

images.alt_text: Philippine peso bills inside a money changer in Manila. The majority of Filipinos say they support the proposed Maharlika Investment Fund.

site_title: McDonald’s temporarily shuts US offices, prepares layoff notices: WSJ
summary: McDonald's is temporarily shutting its US offices starting Monday to inform corporate employees about potential layoffs as part of a company restructuring. The fast-food chain had previously announced it would review corporate staffing levels as part of an updated business strategy. Employees are being asked to work from home during the week to facilitate virtual communication of key decisions. The exact number of layoffs is unclear, but the move is expected to begin with announcements on Monday.

images.alt_text: Convenience store 7-Eleven suspended the sale of some egg products in January following the first confirmed case of bird flu last October. The disease has spread to over half the nation’s prefectures, forcing the cull of some 15 million birds.

site_title: HDB resale prices flatten in Q1; up 0.9% in slowest quarterly growth since 2020
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore experienced a 0.9% increase in the first quarter of 2023, the slowest quarterly growth since Q2 2020. This is attributed to buyers exercising restraint due to higher cash over valuation and lower loan-to-value limits. Despite this, HDB resale volume remains 1% higher than the same period last year. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) also plans to launch 5,400 Build-To-Order flats in May.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Analysts expect about 16,000 flats to reach their minimum occupation period in 2023. In comparison, over 30,000 flats reached their minimum occupation period in 2022.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA Engineering, CapitaLand Investment, Sembmarine, Alpina
summary: SIA Engineering signed a S$120.8 million agreement with Scoot to provide maintenance services, while CapitaLand Investment acquired six Japanese multifamily assets for S$141.4 million. Sembcorp Marine reported consecutive losses but avoided the watch list due to sufficient market capitalization. Alpina Holdings won a solar photovoltaic contract with a provisional value of S$117 million. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: Sembmarine files notice of 3 straight years of losses again
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singapore-based rig builder, has filed a notice of three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. Despite this, the company meets the financial entry criteria to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list, with a six-month average daily market capitalisation of S$4.77 billion. This is a requirement to avoid delisting, but the company must record a consolidated pre-tax profit and maintain an average daily market cap of S$40 million or more within 36 months.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Don’t let emotions harm your investments (Ep 140)
summary: BT Money Hacks podcast discusses how to keep emotions out of investment decisions, especially during uncertain times. Stephanie Leung, chief investment officer of StashAway, shares insights on how to distinguish between noise and information, and avoid biased information. She also highlights high-growth areas to consider. The conversation emphasizes the importance of maintaining a level head when making investment decisions to avoid emotional harm and achieve long-term financial success.

site_title: Swiss prosecutor opens probe into Credit Suisse takeover
summary: Switzerland's Attorney General's Office has launched an investigation into the government-brokered takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS Group. The probe aims to identify possible crimes, including breaches of law by government officials, bank executives, and journalists. The investigation follows previous reports on the closed-door negotiations and allegations of corporate espionage and violations of banking secrecy laws. The Swiss criminal law has limited protections for whistleblowers, raising concerns about potential lack of accountability in the probe.

site_title: NYT won’t pay for Twitter verified check mark
summary: The New York Times and Politico will not pay for Twitter's verified check mark status, which is now only available through a paid subscription. The monthly fee for organizations is $1,000, while individuals can get blue checks for $7. The NYT's spokesperson stated they will not reimburse reporters for Twitter Blue, except in rare cases. This decision comes as Twitter begins winding down its legacy verified program, which had previously been free for accounts.

images.alt_text: Musk made his prediction on the eve of Twitter’s Apr 1 ultimatum that verified accounts with the cherished blue tick that had not forked over cash would lose it.

site_title: Green guru or strategic savant: Singapore companies make tough choices in CSO hires
summary: Singapore's largest listed companies are struggling to find ideal Chief Sustainability Officers (CSOs) due to the multi-faceted nature of the role. Only half of CSOs have prior sustainability experience, with many holding operational or strategic backgrounds. This has led to a debate on whether a candidate with sustainability expertise is more important than those with strong leadership and strategic skills. Companies are advised to look outside their industries or find candidates with related skill sets, and to provide the right conditions for their CSOs to succeed.

site_title: Chinese cash trickling back to Asia’s property markets
summary: Chinese individuals are starting to invest abroad as the country relaxes its Covid-19 border controls, prompting a small but noticeable flow of cash into Asia's property markets. Real estate agents in Singapore, Australia, and Thailand report increased interest from Chinese buyers, with some agents saying demand has doubled since the borders reopened. This trend suggests a desire to diversify investments and move wealth abroad, despite a fragile real estate confidence in China and criticism of wealth accumulation.

site_title: Pakistan posts highest-ever annual inflation; stampedes for food kill 16
summary: Pakistan's inflation rate surged to a record 35.37% in March, exceeding February's 31.5%, with food, beverage, and transport prices rising 50% year-on-year. The high inflation led to at least 16 deaths in stampedes for food aid, with thousands of bags of flour looted. This is the highest ever inflation recorded by the statistics bureau since monthly records began in the 1970s.

images.alt_text: Locking in a rollover had been critical for Pakistan, where reserves have dipped to just four weeks’ worth of imports and talks over an IMF bailout tranche of US$1.1 billion have hit a stalemate.
“Now we are being told that the commitments from friendly countries be fulfilled and God willing we will,” Pakistan's Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif told parliament in a live telecast speech.

site_title: Australia’s March home prices rise for first time in a year: CoreLogic
summary: Australia's home prices rose 0.6% in March, the first month-on-month increase in almost a year, according to CoreLogic. Despite the 8% decline from last year, the gains were driven by Sydney's 1.4% rebound and Melbourne's 0.6% increase. Experts attribute the rise to low listings, a tight rental market, and increasing migration levels, with some speculating the RBA may pause its tightening campaign, which could lead to a floor in the property market. However, caution is advised due to headwinds from higher interest rates and an impending economic slowdown.

site_title: India regulator probing some Adani offshore deals for possible rule violations: sources
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) is investigating Adani Group's offshore dealings with entities linked to Gautam Adani's brother, Vinod Adani, for possible rule violations. The probe focuses on transactions with three offshore entities, including Mauritius-based Krunal Trade and Investments and Gardenia Trade and Investments, over the last 13 years. If proven, the violations could lead to monetary penalties and refer the matter to India's Ministry of Corporate Affairs.

Adani Transmission and Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone “would be capped at current rating level of ‘BBB-/Stable’ till alleged concerns are ironed out,” Fitch said in an emailed statement.

site_title: China’s March new home prices rise at fastest pace in 9 months: survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.02% in March, the fastest pace in 9 months, according to a private survey. This follows a flat reading in February. 41 cities reported price increases, up from 26 in February. The property sector, accounting for a quarter of China's economy, rebounded after Beijing lifted its zero-Covid policy. However, consumer confidence remains uncertain, and a sustainable recovery is uncertain, with Moody's citing pent-up demand as a key factor in the rebound.

images.alt_text: New home sales by floor area in 16 selected Chinese cities rose 31.9 per cent month on month in February, compared with a fall of 34.3 per cent in January, according to China Index Academy.

site_title: Alpina unit bags S$117 million HDB project to build solar panels
summary: Alpina Energy, a subsidiary of Alpina Holdings, has secured a S$117 million contract to design, install, and commission solar panels for an HDB project. The contract was jointly awarded to Alpina Energy and Digo Corporation, a subsidiary of Alpina Holdings, along with Terrenus Energy. The project is expected to be completed by end-2024, with no material impact on Alpina Holdings' earnings per share and net tangible assets. The final contract sum may vary based on the final design stage and implementation phase of the project.

site_title: Tesla posts record deliveries but misses estimates as competition weighs
summary: Tesla posted record deliveries of 422,875 vehicles in the first quarter, but missed analyst expectations of 430,008 vehicles. Despite a 36% year-over-year increase in deliveries, the company's efforts to boost demand with price cuts failed to meet projections. The company produced 440,808 vehicles, indicating a manufacturing surplus. Investors are concerned about eroding margins and the impact of a weakening economy, with some analysts predicting further price cuts to sustain growth.

site_title: Fund-disclosure regulations, energy policies to shape ESG investing in Asia in 2023: report
summary: Investors in Asia will focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) disclosures and climate issues in 2023, driven by growing financial regulation and the need for alternative energy sources due to rising natural gas prices. Regulatory pressures will push for accurate fund labelling and broader taxonomy approaches, while energy diversification will become increasingly important for countries like Singapore, Japan, and South Korea. Despite challenges in solar deployment and infrastructure funding, the overall momentum for alternative renewable energy sources and low-emissions technologies is expected to continue in the medium to longer term.

site_title: HSBC Asia spin-off, dividend proposals in focus at Hong Kong shareholder meet
summary: HSBC Holdings will hold a shareholder meeting in Hong Kong to discuss its 2022 results and potential spin-off of its Asia business, a proposal made by activist investor Ken Lui. Lui's group, "Spin-Off HSBC Asia Concern Group", has called for the bank to split its Asia operations and increase dividend payouts to at least 51 US cents per share. The proposal has garnered support from over 100 investors, but HSBC's management has recommended shareholders vote against the resolutions, citing the current strategy as the fastest and safest way to deliver returns.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment to acquire six multi-family assets in Japan for S$141.4 million
summary: CapitaLand Investment has entered into a forward purchase agreement to acquire six multi-family assets in Osaka, Japan for S$141.4 million, marking the fund's entry into the multi-family sector. The 428 premium one-bedroom apartments are located near commercial districts and are expected to benefit from Osaka's growth potential and its integrated resort project. The acquisition is part of CLI's efforts to diversify its investments and increase demand for rental properties in Japan.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand logo on the facade of the Funan mall on Jan 6, 2023.

site_title: CDL raises expected cost of climate inaction by half to S$120m in 2030
summary: Singapore property giant City Developments Ltd (CDL) has raised its expected cost of climate inaction to S$120 million in 2030, up from S$82 million two years ago. The group identified three new risks: loss of green rental premium revenue, labour cost increase due to heat stress, and climate-related insurance premium increase. CDL will need to tackle these risks to future-proof its business, with a focus on green finance and improving existing developments' resiliency to extreme events.

site_title: Fuel-tanker demand is booming as Asia, Middle East refine more oil
summary: A boom in fuel-tanker demand is driving the construction of new vessels, with 38 mid-range tankers ordered this year, the busiest quarter since 2013. The shift in the global oil-refining complex to Asia and the Middle East has led to increased shipping rates, making it more profitable for existing vessels. New refineries are being built to meet growing demand, with the total amount of fuel at sea increasing to over 200 million barrels. The trend is expected to continue, with around 60 new ships planned for 2025, but vessel availability will still be short of long-term average levels.

images.alt_text: Oil prices last month fell towards US$70 a barrel, the lowest in 15 months, on concern that a global banking crisis would hit demand.

The UAE said it would cut production by 144,000 bpd, Kuwait announced a cut of 128,000 bpd while Iraq said it would cut output by 211,000 bpd and Oman announced a cut of 40,000 bpd. Algeria said it would cut its output by 48,000 bpd.

site_title: Why Europe’s big bounce is bullish for the STI
summary: Europe's stock market has rebounded 27.2% from its September low, defying dire predictions of recession and stagflation. Despite concerns over natural gas shortages and Russia's military actions, the eurozone's economic data shows minimal impact, with flat GDP growth and mild recession forecasts. This positive trend is expected to benefit Singapore's stocks, with a 0.68 correlation with world stocks, and is seen as a sign of a global bull market. Bank contagion fears are overblown, and the strong rebound in Europe suggests that markets can recover from setbacks without requiring perfection.

images.alt_text: Badly timed central bank moves can cause recessions and hurt markets.
Recessions wring out excess to build a base for future growth.
Singapore property stocks, hit hard by rising rates, would have greater upside in a recovery.

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw adds to his stake in UOL
summary: Wee Cho Yaw, chairman of UOL Group, increased his stake in the company after acquiring 300,000 shares at an average price of S$6.74 per share, taking his total interest to 38.34%. This follows previous acquisitions in May 2022. UOL Group reported a 60% growth in FY22 net attributable profit to S$491.9 million, driven by strong locational attributes of its residential inventory and higher progressive revenue recognition from new projects.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Tech giants could see more speed bumps ahead
summary: Tech giants' dominance is being questioned by regulators and telcos, with Orange CEO Christel Heydemann seeking regulation to compel companies to pay for bandwidth they consume. The companies are facing disruptions from AI-generated text, social media platforms losing attention to TikTok, and smartphones failing to spark innovation. Despite huge investments, tech giants are implementing layoffs to appease shareholders and facing stronger FTC scrutiny over acquisitions. Investor sentiment has also taken a hit as interest rates rise, and it's unclear if these companies can stay ahead of the competition and justify past optimism.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
VirnetX separately won a US$302 million verdict against Apple in East Texas in 2016.
In New York, Meta has already opted not to renew leases for Park Avenue offices and newer space in Hudson Yards.
GM is designing the on-board navigation and infotainment systems for future EVs in partnership with Alphabet’s Google.
The Rome-based watchdog gave OpenAI 20 days to respond, after which it could be subject to a fine of as much as 20 million euros (S$28.9 million) or up to 4 per cent of its annual revenue.

site_title: Collapsing banks, Reits hint at trouble ahead
summary: The US Federal Reserve has adopted a less certain posture on further tightening monetary policy, suggesting rates may not peak until 2024, despite median projections indicating rates could reach 5.1% by end-2023. The market has responded positively, with the S&P 500 delivering a 6.9% return since October. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) have also seen significant gains, with some experiencing losses. The Fed's decision and rising interest rates are weighing down the value of safe assets and rendering some financial structures unviable, highlighting the looming trouble for the markets.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Amid banking-led uncertainties, market watchers say S-Reits with strong sponsors are favoured to outperform their peers.

There were at least three data points for SVB that worried depositors: the speed at which the bank’s deposits had grown, the high percentage of uninsured deposits it had, and the magnitude of losses relative to its equity.
Michael S Barr, US Federal Reserve vice-chair for supervision, and FDIC chair Martin Gruenberg testify during a hearing on the recent bank failures in Washington, DC on Mar 29.

site_title: Ready-to-eat meals a growing business for restaurant group Tung Lok
summary: Singapore-based restaurant group Tung Lok has seen significant growth in its ready-to-eat meal business, with sales increasing 400% in the first year of the pandemic. The company has expanded its offerings to include plant-based, Western, and halal options, and now supplies its network of restaurants with over 64 items. Tung Lok's central kitchen has helped boost productivity, allowing staff to focus on serving customers. The company has also diversified its revenue streams, with revenue nearly doubling to S$39.1 million in the half-year ended September 2022. CEO Andrew Tjioe expects the return of tourists to boost financial performance, driven by conferences and corporate events.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The first outlet to be set up under the joint venture will be located at Safra’s Choa Chu Kang clubhouse, which is set to open in May.

site_title: Opec+ announces surprise oil cuts; US calls move inadvisable
summary: Opec+ oil producers, including Saudi Arabia, announced a surprise 1.16 million barrel per day cut in oil output, bringing the total to 3.66 million barrels per day, equivalent to 3.7% of global demand. The move is expected to lift oil prices by $10 per barrel, with analysts predicting an immediate jump. The US has called the move inadvisable, citing market uncertainty and concerns over economic growth. The cuts will start in May and last until the end of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Flames emerge from flare stacks at Nahr Bin Umar oil field, north of Basra, Iraq March 9, 2020. REUTERS/Essam Al-Sudani/File Photo

site_title: Dutch refinery to feed airlines' thirst for clean fuel
summary: Neste, the largest global producer of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), is significantly boosting production at its Dutch refinery to meet the European Union's plan to impose a minimum of 6% SAF usage by 2030 and 63% by 2050. The company aims to increase production from 100,000 tonnes to 1.5 million tonnes next year, with another site in Singapore set to start production in April. Airlines such as Air France-KLM have secured agreements for the supply of millions of tonnes of SAF, with prices ranging from $2,000 to $5,000 per tonne, depending on the market.

images.alt_text: SAF is a biofuel used to power aircraft that has similar properties to conventional jet fuel without the need to develop new planes or engines.

site_title: Shifting interest rate expectations suggest tailwinds for S-Reits
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are gaining traction after a dismal 2022 performance. A tapering of aggressive interest rate hikes is expected to support prices this year, with S-Reits with strong sponsors favored to outperform peers. However, analysts warn of potential volatility and a bumpy ride ahead for investors, with the US Federal Reserve expected to ease off rate hikes to alleviate balance sheet stress. Despite this, observers recommend investors be selective and focus on sectors like industrial and hospitality, with Reits backed by strong sponsors seen as top picks.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
New Tech Park in Lorong Chuan is among the portfolio properties of Sabana Industrial Reit, which is among the 10 trusts with the lowest gearing ratios reported.
RHB downgrades S-Reits to "neutral", while UOBKH maintains "market weight" on Malaysian Reits; DBS recommends investors stay invested in logistics, retail and hospitality sectors.

site_title: Gold dips as stronger dollar dampens appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,962.36 per ounce due to a stronger US dollar, making the metal less affordable for foreign buyers. The dollar index rose 0.3% amid concerns about inflation, with the Federal Reserve potentially raising interest rates again this year. Oil prices surged after OPEC+ producers announced output cuts, potentially impacting inflation. Despite a slowdown in US price data, inflation remains high enough to allow the Fed to raise interest rates, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Gold is set to end the quarter and the month higher on expectations that the Fed might consider a rate-hike pause after the collapse of two US regional banks.

site_title: Japanese musician Ryuichi Sakamoto dies, aged 71
summary: Japanese musician Ryuichi Sakamoto, a renowned composer and Oscar winner, has died at 71 after battling cancer. His management team confirmed his passing on March 28, with a private funeral held at his request. Sakamoto was famous for his scores for films like "The Last Emperor" and "Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence," and co-founded the electronic music band Yellow Magic Orchestra. He was also an anti-nuclear campaigner and environmental activist, and recently livestreamed what may have been his final concert in December 2022.

images.alt_text: Japanese composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, 70, won an Academy Award for his score in the movie, The Last Emperor.

site_title: Swiss prosecutor probes Credit Suisse takeover
summary: Switzerland's Federal Prosecutor has launched an investigation into the state-backed takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS Group, examining potential breaches of the country's criminal law by government officials, regulators, and executives. The probe aims to identify any criminal offenses related to the emergency merger, which was agreed upon last month to avoid a meltdown in the country's financial system. The investigation's outcome and duration have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: UBS' deal to buy Credit Suisse has raised concerns over the size of a new bank with US$1.6 trillion in assets and more than 120,000 staff worldwide.

site_title: Booming Jakarta IPO market leaves major global venues behind
summary: Indonesia's Jakarta market is thriving with the highest total funds raised in the first quarter, surpassing major global venues such as Hong Kong, Tokyo, and London. The South-east Asian market raised US$1.45 billion in IPO proceeds, with state-owned enterprise listings and electric vehicle sector interest driving demand. However, demand may be tested with Chinese tech behemoths preparing to list in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Almost two-thirds of the 21 companies that listed in Jakarta over the past decade finished their debut session higher than the listing price.
The government is divesting stakes in state companies to fund expansion and reduce reliance on the state budget.

site_title: China’s central bank calls for stronger defences against financial crisis
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has called for strengthened defenses against financial crisis. Officials recommend accelerating the Financial Stability Law legislation, improving date accuracy supervision, and allowing the insurance deposit system to deal with problematic banks swiftly. The authors emphasize the need to consolidate capital reserves to ensure sufficient resources to manage financial risks. Despite concerns, China's commercial banks are considered sound and stable.

site_title: US$335,000 pay for ‘AI whisperer’ jobs appears in red-hot market
summary: A jobs market is emerging for "prompt engineers" who help companies optimize AI technology, including ChatGPT. These roles can pay up to $335,000 per year and often require expertise in computer engineering. Prompt engineers coax the AI to produce better results and help companies train their workforce to harness the tools. The demand for these skills is growing as the technology behind ChatGPT continues to expand.

images.alt_text: The Rome-based watchdog gave OpenAI 20 days to respond, after which it could be subject to a fine of as much as 20 million euros (S$28.9 million) or up to 4 per cent of its annual revenue.

site_title: Barcode turns 50 but its days might be numbered
summary: The barcode, invented 50 years ago, is facing competition from the QR code, a newer technology used in smartphones. The barcode is used globally, with around 70,000 items sold every second, and is recognized by a trademark beep that is heard six billion times daily. Despite its widespread use, the barcode's days might be numbered as it struggles to keep up with the evolving technology landscape.

images.alt_text: With pre- pandemic annual traffic between the two countries averaging 12 million visitors, the payment linkage provides merchants and consumers with a more seamless and efficient means to make and receive payments.

site_title: Sydney house prices climb ahead of central bank rates decision
summary: Sydney house prices rose 1.4% in March, the second consecutive month of gains, ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate decision. Despite this, prices remain 12.1% lower than the 12 months prior. The central bank is expected to pause tightening, but economists are divided on the outcome. Low supply and increased demand from overseas migration are supporting prices, but elevated borrowing costs are expected to remain until late 2024. Affordability and supply challenges are likely to persist.

images.alt_text: Demand for housing in Australia is set to swell further, as international students return to study there, and the pace of immigration roars back to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Saudi Arabia, other Opec+ producers announce voluntary oil output cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia and other Opec+ producers announced voluntary oil output cuts ranging from 40,000 to 211,000 barrels per day until the end of 2023. The UAE, Kuwait, Iraq, Oman, and Algeria also joined in, with Saudi Arabia cutting 500,000 barrels per day. The move aims to support the stability of the oil market, with Russia extending its 500,000 barrel per day cut. The production cuts are seen as a precautionary measure to address market concerns.

site_title: South Korea exports fall for sixth consecutive month in March
summary: South Korea's exports fell for the sixth consecutive month in March, with a 13.6% year-on-year decline to $55.12 billion, due to a cooling global economy and a semiconductor sector slump. This marks the longest losing streak in exports since August 2020, with exports not falling as much as expected.

images.alt_text: The sluggish factory output in February was led by semiconductors and automobile.
South Korea’s policy authorities are faced with the double task of keeping the economy from cooling too fast.

site_title: Three S-Reits poised to benefit from tailwinds in Europe’s logistics sector
summary: Three Singapore-listed Reits, Cromwell European Reit, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, are poised to benefit from tailwinds in Europe's logistics sector. A Savills report suggests the region's logistics market will experience a recovery due to European GDP outperforming forecasts, record low vacancy rates, and consumer sentiment remaining strong. These factors are expected to drive rental growth and support the Reits' exposure to European logistics real estate properties.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.

site_title: UBS to cut up to 30% of enlarged staff force
summary: UBS is planning to cut up to 30% of its enlarged staff force, approximately 11,000 jobs, as part of its post-merger restructuring. The move comes after the bank's acquisition of Credit Suisse, which has raised concerns over its massive size with $1.6 trillion in assets and over 120,000 staff worldwide. Incoming CEO Sergio Ermotti has downplayed the issue, stating that the combined bank will maintain a successful UBS strategy and has a "good position" globally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Swiss bank UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti addresses a news conference in Zurich, Switzerland February 20, 2020.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Volkswagen not planning new combustion engine Golf
summary: Volkswagen has confirmed it will not develop a new combustion engine generation of its Golf car, marking the end of a vehicle on sale since 1974. The Golf 8, currently in production, will be the last combustion engine version, with one more series of updates expected next year. According to brand chief Thomas Schaefer, the decision is based on the expected development of the segment by 2026 or 2027, and the company does not anticipate a need for a new vehicle at that time.

images.alt_text: German carmaker Volkswagen presents its new electric ID. 2all model, an electric vehicle that costs less than 25,000 euros, in Hamburg, Germany, March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: US bank deposit outflows decelerated in second week after SVB collapse
summary: US commercial bank deposits fell to their lowest since August, dropping $125.7 billion in the week ended March 22, with deposits nearly $860 billion below the record high from last April. Deposit outflows slowed from the previous week, after a record $174.5 billion outflows following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. Deposits at small US banks edged up, while those at the largest 25 banks fell. US finance officials have said deposit flows have stabilized, but policymakers remain concerned about the potential for a credit crunch.

images.alt_text: The Fed has also launched an investigation into the events that led to the collapse of SVB.

There were at least three data points for SVB that worried depositors: the speed at which the bank’s deposits had grown, the high percentage of uninsured deposits it had, and the magnitude of losses relative to its equity.

site_title: Squeezed by high costs, US tenants grapple with eviction
summary: US tenants are facing eviction risks due to high inflation, elevated rents, and the end of pandemic-era aid. According to Peter Hepburn, associate director of Eviction Lab at Princeton University, 3.6 million eviction cases are typically filed in a year, but slowed during the pandemic. Laine Carolyn, a 32-year-old US tenant, is struggling to pay her rent after a sudden health issue forced her to stop work, highlighting the increasing number of US tenants confronting eviction risks.

images.alt_text: Estate agents advertising signs ‘For Sale’ and ‘To Let’ outside properties at a housing development in London, UK, on Thursday, Nov. 17, 2022. Finding a rental property in London can feel like an impossible quest, with prices surging as demand vastly outpaces the number of available units.Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: The Fed is doing too much, all at once
summary: The US Federal Reserve is facing criticism for its multi-pronged approach to managing inflation, employment, and financial stability. Tightening financial conditions to curb inflation has contributed to bank failures, while also potentially exacerbating financial instability and rising unemployment. Regulators and economists blame a combination of poor bank management, inadequate supervision, and the Fed's own monetary policies, including its emergency bailout program. The Fed's efforts to control inflation may lead to a credit crunch, which could be beneficial for its inflation goals but detrimental to the broader economy.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq index saw a double bottom in October 2022 and January 2023, then recovered above the 12,000 level.
Revisions to the prior week’s data showed deposit outflows in that first week of bank sector turmoil was almost double the US$98.4 billion initially estimated.

site_title: EU agrees on new powers to hit back against trade coercion
summary: The European Union has agreed on new powers to counter economic coercion by third countries against its member states. The new instrument, which still needs formal adoption, allows the EU to impose punitive measures like export controls and increased duties in response to trade restrictions. The move aims to boost the EU's trade defenses, following the US imposing tariffs on the bloc's exports and China restricting Lithuanian goods. The legislation, proposed in 2021, gives more say to national governments in confirming coercion and stipulates that response measures must be commensurate to the level of injury.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde speaks to reporters following the Governing Council's monetary policy meeting, in Frankfurt, Germany February 2, 2023. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach

site_title: Running towards a zero-waste future
summary: Income Insurance launched the Income Eco Run (IER) event to mark the International Day of Zero Waste on March 30, 2023. The event encouraged runners to participate by downloading GPS tracking apps and clocking their distance, with Income Insurance matching $1 for every kilometre. This year, participants are encouraged to reuse and recycle existing orange T-shirts or past Income Eco Run race T-shirts. The event aims to promote zero-waste practices and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
Data from the Singapore Police Force shows that the number of scam cases rose to 6,492 in 2022, up 42.7 per cent from 2021.

site_title: Europe’s era of agitation heralds more clashes on spoils of work
summary: Europe is experiencing a surge in public-service strikes and protests, driven by a cost-of-living crisis and declining wages. Strikes in Britain, Germany, and France have resulted in gridlock in healthcare systems, transportation shutdowns, and mass protests. Workers are demanding higher wages and better labor entitlements, targeting government finances and private companies. Experts predict years of charged disputes, with union membership growing and public support for strikers increasing. The fight centers on the hearts, minds, and wallets of citizens, with implications for inflation and labor markets.

images.alt_text: Protesters take part in a students' demonstration after the French government pushed a pensions reform through parliament without a vote, using the article 49.3 of the constitution, at the Pantheon in Paris, on March 30, 2023. - France continues to see strikes and protests nearly two weeks after the president bypassed parliament to pass a pensions overhaul, which includes raising the retirement age from 62 to 64. Unions have vowed no let-up in mass protests to get the government to back down since protests started in mid-January against the law. (Photo by Thomas SAMSON / AFP)

site_title: US banks have US$620 billion of unrealised losses on their books
summary: US banks have $620 billion of unrealised losses on their books, primarily from investments in low-yielding bonds. This issue affects the entire US financial system, but most banks have manageable risks. The recent Treasury bond market rally is helping to reduce the losses. The largest banks, perceived as "too big to fail," have smaller risks. The losses will be reported in the first-quarter data, which is expected to be released soon.

images.alt_text: Investor confidence in the global banking sector has been shaken in recent weeks by the demise of Silicon Valley Bank, the collapse of a large US regional lender and the emergency rescue of Swiss giant Credit Suisse.
US regulators said on Monday they would backstop the deal for First Citizens to buy Silicon Valley Bank, triggering an estimated US$20 billion hit to a government-run insurance fund.

site_title: VW pledges to double down on EVs in China, urges extension of NEV tax breaks
summary: Volkswagen China has pledged to increase the number of charging posts for electric vehicles to 17,000 by 2025, with a planned investment of 15 billion euros. Despite intense competition and weak demand, the company remains committed to electrification, citing innovation and improvement as motivators. VW also urged China to extend the purchase tax exemption on new energy vehicles beyond 2023, citing policy support for the sector.

images.alt_text: epa10521707 A worker cleans an ID.Buzz Volkswagen car prior to the beginning of the annual press conference of the automotive group Volkswagen, at the Volkswagen Group Forum showroom in Berlin, Germany, 14 March 2023. Volkswagen hosted the company's 2023's annual press conference in Berlin.  EPA-EFE/CLEMENS BILAN

site_title: Chinese FM says Japanese chip curbs to drive Beijing's self-reliance
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang told Japanese Foreign Minister Yoshimasa Hayashi that Tokyo's export controls on semiconductor equipment will drive Beijing's self-reliance. Qin accused Japan of being the US's "minion" and called the controls "bullying tactics". The two ministers discussed China's detention of a Japanese national and a disputed group of islands. Qin stated that China will deal with the detained individual according to the law, while Hayashi called for his immediate release. The meeting comes amid deteriorating bilateral ties and China's growing regional assertiveness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Micron logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks eke out gains in March amid banking jitters; market cap rises to S$819 billion
summary: Singapore's stock market ended March with a total market capitalization of S$819.1 billion, a 0.5% gain from the previous month. Despite a decline in banking and finance-related counters amid global banking woes, the market saw gains in manufacturing stocks, led by Sembcorp Marine, Wilmar International, and Nio. The three local lenders, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were among the biggest losers, with DBS and OCBC shedding S$3 billion and S$1.4 billion, respectively.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The Fed has also launched an investigation into the events that led to the collapse of SVB.
Hong Kong was nearly two per cent lower in Monday morning trade, with Shanghai down 0.7 per cent.

site_title: Britain’s digital banks need support amid banking turmoil: trade body
summary: Britain's digital banks require support in the coming weeks and months due to market fallout from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The UK government and Bank of England facilitated a deal to buy Silicon Valley Bank's UK arm, which focused on tech start-ups, after over 250 UK tech executives warned of an "existential threat" to their sector. This move aims to mitigate potential losses to the UK fintech industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 19, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Philippines’ proposed sovereign wealth fund faces bumpy road in the Senate
summary: The Philippines' proposed Maharlika Investment Fund (MIF) faces resistance in the Senate, with lawmakers debating its feasibility and implementation. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has deemed the MIF Bill as urgent and seeks Senate approval before June, believing it will benefit the heavily-indebted country. Despite public support, opposition from senators threatens to delay or block the fund's establishment, which aims to generate 275 billion pesos (S$6.7 billion) for the country.

images.alt_text: The gathering of finance leaders of Asean, a region of about 650 million people, comes amid a backdrop of recent global banking turmoil after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and the bailout and takeover of Credit Suisse.
FILE PHOTO: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Governor Felipe Medalla poses for a photograph in his office at Manila, Philippines, November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eloisa Lopez/File Photo

“They were proposing that we begin talks again on oil and gas. I think we will begin in maybe around six weeks but...at a technical level,” Foreign Affairs Secretary Enrique Manalo said in an interview with local network GMA News.

site_title: Dubai’s latest boom is pricing out the expats it once coveted
summary: Dubai's rental market has experienced a resurgence, pricing out many expats who moved into previously unaffordable areas during the pandemic. As prices skyrocket, some residents, like Ghida, are struggling to afford their homes. She was evicted from her villa after her landlord doubled the rent, now asking $6,000 a month. Ghida is suing for breaking rental rules, citing a staggering backlog of similar cases. This reflects Dubai's shift from an affordable haven to a more exclusive market, making it harder for newcomers to enter.

images.alt_text: Among the most commonly cited reasons for house prices to remain elevated were crimped supply, made worse during the pandemic, when construction activity came to a near-halt, and ever-rising demand.

site_title: Swiss watchmakers counting the clock until Chinese tourists return
summary: Swiss luxury watch brands are cautiously optimistic that Chinese tourists will boost sales this year if they return to Europe in large numbers after China's easing of domestic Covid restrictions. Exports to China rebounded 8.2% in February, and many financial analysts have raised their growth forecasts for the luxury sector. Luxury goods lovers in China made up 60% of the sector's growth between 2000 and 2019, with nearly three-quarters of their spending done abroad. However, Chinese luxury consumers have become more accustomed to buying domestically, and some brands remain cautious about the short-term evolution of the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: Dior, the second-biggest brand of billionaire Bernard Arnault’s French luxury behemoth LVMH, and the decision to add India to its seasonal schedule shows a rising interest to tap the nation’s rising wealth.

site_title: China now spurning ‘ugliest buildings’ that symbolised its meteoric rise
summary: China is abandoning its "ugly" buildings, symbols of its rapid economic growth, as local governments become more cautious with debt. The structures, including a Shanghai mall and Anhui museum, were among the 2022 winners of the annual Ugliest Buildings Survey. The hyperspeed urbanization of the past two decades led to an overbuilding, according to survey judge Zhou Rong. As China's GDP growth slows, policymakers face pressure, prompting a shift towards more restrained development. The move reflects a change in priorities for China's economy and infrastructure.

images.alt_text: An index measuring construction activity surged in March to its highest level in more than a decade.
Instead of buying land and owning projects from scratch, a growing number of Chinese property developers has begun providing construction services as contractors.

site_title: Unhappy at work? Yes, you should complain
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of speaking up about workplace unhappiness, but notes that the approach is crucial in achieving positive change. Raising complaints can improve a bad situation, but it's essential to handle the issue delicately and validate the employee's feelings. Following due process, focusing on facts, and providing data can help make a complaint more convincing. Effective communication, considering the person's working style, and bringing plausible solutions to the table are also key. By managing complaints constructively, companies can foster a better workplace culture, improve talent retention, and nurture trust among team members.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
teamwork, cooperation, brainstorming
Providing feedback to drive change

This year’s zeitgeist tune Break My Soul by Beyoncé  is a dance-based rallying cry for workers rejecting old constraints in new times. The song is an anthem not so much for The Great Resignation as The Great Resentment.
Making change work is harder than change itself

site_title: Malaysia, China ink partnership to stabilise palm oil supply chain
summary: Malaysia and China have signed a memorandum of understanding to promote sustainable palm oil in China and implement new technologies such as artificial intelligence in oil palm plantations. The partnership aims to enhance palm oil trade and cooperation, with Malaysia seeking to regain market share in China. The move is seen as a step towards stabilizing Malaysia's palm oil supply chain, with China being the world's second-largest buyer of palm oil. The partnership is expected to benefit both countries, with Malaysia's sustainable palm oil being promoted in China and new technologies being developed for the oil palm industry.

site_title: Australian PM says inflation numbers ‘pleasing’ amid cost of living pressures
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese expressed relief over the country's slowing inflation, which fell to an eight-month low in February. The Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) cash rate, lifted to its highest level in over a decade, may pause its rate-hike cycle, with investors cutting bets on a rate hike. Despite the positive inflation data, Albanese cautioned that cost of living pressures remain nationwide, and the issue remains a "real challenge" and "global phenomenon".

images.alt_text: Newly built houses in the Denham Court suburb of Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, May 3, 2022. One of the developed world’s last remaining doves turned hawkish as Australia’s central bank rocked markets with a bigger-than-expected interest-rate hike in the middle of an election campaign. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
The RBA will welcome the inflation result, while likely retaining a tightening bias given consumer-price growth is still well above the central bank’s 2-3 per cent target.

site_title: Cargill’s big beef bet falters as food inflation hits demand
summary: Cargill, the US's third-largest beef processor, is facing a decline in its beef business due to food inflation and reduced demand. The company's animal protein business is experiencing challenging beef margins, with profits expected to go negative in the next two years. Despite this, Cargill's profits remain higher than in recent years, and the company sees opportunities in health and nutrition, renewable diesel, and chicken production. Global beef consumption is expected to stall this year and fall in the US, but is expected to recover at a slow pace of 1% per year over the next two decades.

images.alt_text: Jamie Miller will also be CFO of EY's “proposed new public entity” as the company undergoes a split.
Cargill in talks to exit global sugar trading business
Cargill heads to record profits on booming agricultural markets
Cargill backs cow masks to trap methane burps

site_title: Nasdaq 100 may see potential correction before rebound
summary: The Nasdaq 100 index may experience a potential correction before rebounding, according to analysts. Despite recent volatility due to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and rate hikes, investors are injecting more liquidity into the markets, leading to a recovery in technology stocks. A double bottom in October 2022 and January 2023, and a possible golden cross, indicate a bullish scenario with potential upside to 13,600-13,800 levels. However, a correction to 12,500 may occur before the rebound, and a bearish scenario suggests another drop below 12,000 if the index fails to break above 13,000.

site_title: Everton post £45 million loss amid financial breach investigation
summary: Everton FC has reported a £44.7 million loss for the 2021/22 season, despite being under scrutiny for alleged breaches of financial rules. The club's losses for the three years prior to last season were £371.8 million. Everton has denied any non-compliance with Premier League rules, citing the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on player trading and matchday income. A points deduction could threaten the club's survival bid, with a potential ruling possible before the end of the season.

images.alt_text: Qatari banker Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani (left) and British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe have rival bids on the table.
Liverpool's Roberto Firmino celebrates after scoring the 7-0 goal during the English Premier League soccer match between Liverpool FC and Manchester United in Liverpool, March 5, 2023.

site_title: Twitter to take 10% cut on content subscriptions after 12 months
summary: Twitter will take a 10% cut on content subscriptions after the first year, according to CEO Elon Musk. The move aims to diversify revenue sources and follow the introduction of subscription-based content. Initially, the cut was set to be 0% for the first 12 months, but it will drop to 15% in the second year. This change comes as the platform seeks to boost revenue after advertising income dropped last year following Musk's $44 billion acquisition in October.

site_title: Reputation is a risk businesses cannot afford to ignore
summary: A company's reputation is increasingly indelible online, with digital platforms serving as the first point of engagement for stakeholders. Reputational crises have been a recurring theme, with recent examples including Adidas, Credit Suisse, and Meta. Despite this, 87% of executives rate reputation risk as "more important" or "much more important" to their business, according to a 2015 Deloitte survey. As the digital landscape continues to evolve, maintaining a strong online presence is crucial for businesses to protect and build their reputation.

site_title: Musk defends paid Twitter as blue tick ultimatum looms
summary: Elon Musk defended Twitter's paid verification model, claiming that without it, social media platforms will be overrun by bots. The model, which costs $8/month or $84/year, requires a reputable phone number and credit card for verification. However, the change has led to a loss of advertisers and has raised concerns about imposters and fake accounts. Celebrities and journalists are also affected, with some, like The New York Times, opting not to pay for verification. Musk's ability to find a sustainable business model for Twitter remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The company said in a blog post it uploaded the code in two repositories on code-sharing platform GitHub.
Elon Musk says the platform faced such grave financial difficulties that at one point it was on the verge of bankruptcy.

site_title: US lawmakers introduce bipartisan bill to help news media negotiate with Big Tech
summary: US lawmakers have reintroduced a bipartisan bill to allow news organizations to jointly negotiate ad rates with tech giants like Google, addressing financial struggles faced by many news outlets. The bill, introduced by Senator Amy Klobuchar, would enable news broadcasters and publishers with fewer than 1,500 full-time workers to negotiate ad rates. This move comes as news organizations have complained about insufficient compensation for readers attracted to their content. The bill was previously introduced in the last Congress but failed to become law.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT set off massive investment because “ninety-plus per cent of venture capitalists are actually very risk averse. Until you see a real application, people don’t really dive in,” Samir Kaul, a founding partner at Khosla Ventures said.

Meta’s LLaMA, short for Large Language Model Meta AI, will be available under non-commercial license to researchers and entities affiliated with government, civil society, and academia, it said in a blog.

site_title: Tencent applies for dual counter trading on Hong Kong exchange
summary: Tencent Holdings has applied for a dual currency counter trading model on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, allowing investors to trade its shares in both the Hong Kong dollar and the yuan. The move is part of the exchange's plan to further internationalize the Chinese yuan, which is expected to be implemented from the first half of 2023. Other Hong Kong-listed companies, such as AIA Group, have also applied for similar arrangements.

site_title: Divided world needs new ground rules so that global trade can continue apace: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong calls for new ground rules to ensure global trade continues without decoupling, amid rising tensions between the US and China. He hopes countries can work together within the World Trade Organisation framework while recognizing national security considerations and securing supply chains. Lee warns that failure to establish new rules could lead to significant economic costs and regrettable consequences, citing the long-term cost of trade fragmentation as potentially as high as 7% of global GDP.

images.alt_text: PM Lee and Xi met during the third and final leg of the Singapore leader’s official visit to China.
PM Lee is on an official visit to China, his first to the country in four years.

site_title: The pianist who's been playing for more than 100 years
summary: French pianist Colette Maze, born in June 1914, has been playing piano for over 100 years, practicing four hours a day. She is set to release her seventh album, "108 Years of Piano". Maze's enthusiasm remains youthful despite her advanced age, and she draws thousands of fans on social media.

images.alt_text: Japanese composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, 70, won an Academy Award for his score in the movie, The Last Emperor.

site_title: World’s richest man eyes India’s luxury market with landmark Dior show
summary: Christian Dior showcased its Fall 2023 collection in Mumbai, becoming the first fashion house to unveil its latest lines in India, as luxury brands tap the nation's rising wealth. The event marked a significant move by Dior, the second-biggest brand of LVMH, to enter the Indian market, where 119 billionaires reside. The decision is seen as an opportunity to tap into the country's growing middle class and rising number of millionaires, with LVMH's shares rising 1% to a record high.

images.alt_text: Bernard Arnault, chairman and CEO of LVMH, speaks during a news conference on the company's 2022 annual results in Paris, France, Jan 26, 2023.

site_title: Trudeau points to 'slave labour' in China lithium production
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau linked China's lithium production to "slave labour" during a speech in New York, citing the country's strategic choices as the reason for its dominance in the global market. Canada, with significant lithium sources, aims to increase domestic production, but faces higher costs due to environmental and social responsibility standards. The US has also alleged forced labor in China's mining and construction sectors, with some automakers exposed to products made with forced labor.

site_title: Singapore and China to elevate ties following meeting between PM Lee and Xi Jinping
summary: Singapore and China have agreed to upgrade their bilateral relationship to an "all-round high-quality future-oriented partnership", according to a statement from Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The move follows a meeting between Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Chinese President Xi Jinping, marking the first upgrade since 2015. The two countries aim to broaden cooperation and pursue new areas of collaboration, including the digital and green economies. Xi described the relationship as "forward-looking, strategic and exemplary", while PM Lee expressed hope for "fresh momentum" in bilateral cooperation.

images.alt_text: PM Lee is on an official visit to China, his first to the country in four years.

With pre- pandemic annual traffic between the two countries averaging 12 million visitors, the payment linkage provides merchants and consumers with a more seamless and efficient means to make and receive payments.

site_title: Swiss National Bank seeks banking regulation review after Credit Suisse crash
summary: Swiss National Bank chairman Thomas Jordan announced a review of Swiss banking regulation following the collapse of Credit Suisse, warning against "quick fixes." The review will focus on requiring banks to hold sufficient assets as collateral to allow for the use of existing liquidity facilities. Jordan stated that the central bank is at the limit of its ability to provide emergency liquidity, and the money must be repaid with interest. The review aims to prevent future crises and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Elon Musk seeks to end US$258 billion Dogecoin lawsuit
summary: Elon Musk has asked a US judge to dismiss a $258 billion lawsuit accusing him of running a pyramid scheme to support Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency. The lawsuit claims Musk deliberately drove up Dogecoin's price over 36,000% before letting it crash. Musk's lawyers argue the lawsuit is a "fanciful work of fiction" based on vague and innocuous tweets about Dogecoin. They claim the investors failed to explain how Musk intended to defraud anyone or what risks he concealed. Musk seeks to end the lawsuit, which accuses him of racketeering and securities fraud.

images.alt_text: Musk made his prediction on the eve of Twitter’s Apr 1 ultimatum that verified accounts with the cherished blue tick that had not forked over cash would lose it.

site_title: Only fools rush in: Pitfalls of hasty problem-solving
summary: Research into "mindless maths" reveals that rushing into decision-making can lead to misunderstandings and suboptimal solutions. Delving headfirst into complex tasks without taking the time to properly understand the problem can result in incorrect or less optimal outcomes. A study by Asher Lawson and co-authors found that the presence of numbers in a problem can tempt people to perform mathematical operations when they are not necessary, highlighting the importance of taking a thoughtful approach to problem-solving.

site_title: Thailand cuts GDP growth outlook as exports weaken
summary: Thailand has lowered its 2023 economic growth outlook to 3.6% due to a 0.5% drop in exports, driven by a global slowdown. Exports are expected to fall, while public consumption is forecast to decline 2.1% due to a delayed fiscal budget. However, tourism and domestic consumption are expected to prop up the economy. The baht is expected to average 33.17 US dollars per dollar this year, and inflation is predicted at 2.6%.

site_title: The first Trump indictment is here, and it matters
summary: US President Donald Trump has been indicted in New York on more than two dozen counts related to hush money payments to his paramours, Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal, ahead of the 2016 election. The charges, which include campaign finance crimes and tax evasion, are seen as directly tied to the 2016 election and Trump's attempts to subvert its outcome. The indictment marks a significant development in Trump's long history of alleged law-breaking, including his campaign's acceptance of Russian help and his impeachment over attempts to extort Ukraine's president.

images.alt_text: The charges could reshape the 2024 presidential race.
Anti-Trump protestors hold a banner in a park near the Manhattan Criminal Court in New York City, March 23, 2023.
Trump at the NCAA wrestling championships in Tulsa, Oklahoma on Saturday; the probe comes as he seeks the Republican nomination for the presidency in 2024.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for the country to stay united and self-reliant amidst global storms. He urged Singapore to maintain its strong reputation and continue to thrive as a global city and international hub, despite the decline of globalization.

site_title: Hindenburg says Block response confirms it inflated Cash App user counts
summary: US short seller Hindenburg Research alleges that payments firm Block's Cash App overstated user numbers and understated customer acquisition costs. Block confirmed that 44 million of its 51 million monthly active users are verified through its identity program, but its internal estimates show that this number is 16-31% inflated. Hindenburg also claims that 40-75% of accounts reviewed by former Block employees are fake or involved in fraud. Block's response to the allegations confirms the inflated user counts, which could have implications for the company's financial reporting.

images.alt_text: Cash App allows users to transfer money through a mobile application and is touted by the company as an alternative to traditional banking services.
Cash App allows users to transfer money through a mobile application and is touted by the company as an alternative to traditional banking services.

site_title: IMF approves US$15.6 billion Ukraine loan, part of US$115 billion in global support
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved a $15.6 billion loan program for Ukraine, part of a $115 billion global package to support the country's economy amid Russia's 13-month-old invasion. The four-year loan requires Ukraine to implement ambitious reforms, particularly in the energy sector. The IMF also announced a two-step debt treatment process, backed by international financial institutions and private-sector firms, to provide adequate financing assurances on debt relief and concessional financing. The program aims to enhance stability and early post-war reconstruction, with quarterly reviews starting as early as June.

site_title: US officials lead urgent rescue talks for First Republic: sources
summary: US officials are coordinating urgent talks to rescue First Republic Bank, which has been struggling due to deposit outflows and a regional banking crisis. The government, including the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Treasury Department, and Federal Reserve, is bringing together financial companies, including banks and private equity firms, to discuss a potential lifeline. A private-sector deal is seen as preferable to a government takeover, but negotiations have yet to yield a deal. The proposed solution involves a special purpose vehicle to carve out assets for other banks to buy, with the goal of covering losses on First Republic's loan book and fixed-income portfolio.

images.alt_text: First Republic has been struggling to find a rescuer for weeks, and any steps to raise capital or sell holdings quickly could be painful for current shareholders.

site_title: SBF holds joint conference with organiser of China state-backed expo to encourage Singapore attendance
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) held a joint conference with the organiser of the China International Import Expo (CIIE) to encourage Singaporean firms to attend the event later this year. The conference highlighted the business value of the expo, which aims to support trade liberalisation and economic globalisation. SBF noted that with China's reopening, there is renewed interest in the Chinese market, with many new exhibitors looking to explore collaboration and business partnerships. The conference aims to promote Singapore's participation in the expo.

images.alt_text: PM Lee and Xi met during the third and final leg of the Singapore leader’s official visit to China.

Passengers on a tour ship on the Huangpu river in Shanghai. Tourism is one of the areas of collaboration under the 15 agreements signed at the fourth Singapore-Shanghai Comprehensive Cooperation Council.

site_title: Bentley Flying Spur Hybrid review: Spur of the moment
summary: The Bentley Flying Spur Hybrid is a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle that combines an electric motor with a petrol engine, delivering 40km of emissions-free travel on its 18kW lithium-ion pack. Despite its impressive acceleration and smooth ride, the Flying Spur Hybrid feels somewhat last-generation, with a limited battery range and higher fuel consumption once the battery is depleted. Its V6 engine is also less refined than the petrol-only Flying Spur V8. However, the Flying Spur Hybrid's presence and grandeur make it a desirable option, even if it doesn't excel in its eco-friendly credentials.

site_title: From HDB to condo: Upgrading quest has become more challenging
summary: Data suggests HDB dwellers are struggling to afford private property upgrades, with only a quarter of units sold at affordable prices. Condominiums in the outside central region (OCR) are now attracting a wider range of buyers, not just HDB owners. This shift may indicate that buyers who can wait may have an advantage in the market, as prices continue to rise.

site_title: Province – Two young local chefs drive home the eco dining message at new Joo Chiat restaurant
summary: Young chefs Law Jia-Jun and Wong Wei Xiang have launched a new eight-seater restaurant, Province, in Singapore's Joo Chiat, emphasizing local and regional ingredients to reduce carbon footprint. The seven-course tasting menu at S$138 features dishes such as smoked snapper sashimi, tubers, and aged coral trout, showcasing the chefs' experimental approach to farm-to-table cooking. While still in its development stage, Province scores high on effort, talent, and authenticity, offering a promising dining experience.

site_title: Thief who stole US$3.4 billion in Bitcoin deserves prison, US says
summary: A US federal judge is set to decide whether James Zhong, a 32-year-old Georgia man, should receive prison time for stealing over 50,000 Bitcoins valued at $3.35 billion in 2012. Zhong pleaded guilty to the crime and wants leniency, citing his help in recovering the stolen crypto. However, prosecutors argue that Zhong's actions warrant imprisonment to send a "strong and clear message" to others that cryptocurrency thefts and frauds will be prosecuted. Federal sentencing guidelines recommend 27-33 months in prison, and probation officials recommend 24 months.

site_title: Eden aims to raise the bar on hotel dining
summary: The Pullman Singapore's new restaurant, Eden, offers a mod-Asian menu with mixed results. The restaurant serves dishes such as garlic fried rice, stir-fried vegetables, and crab cakes, as well as a refreshing lemongrass jelly dessert. Eden's conservatory-like interiors provide a unique dining experience. The restaurant's menu shows promise, but may be limited by its need to cater to hotel guests with all-inclusive stays, potentially stifling innovation and creativity.

site_title: Is orange wine really orange?
summary: Orange wine, made from white grapes using red winemaking techniques, has gained popularity since the 1990s. Originating in ancient Georgia, this style of winemaking involves leaving juice and grapes to macerate with their skins, creating an orange hue. Notable winemakers Stanko Radikon and Josko Gravner have pushed this style to the forefront of modern winemaking, producing wines with minimal intervention and no added sulphur. Orange wines display oxidative flavors and aromas, making them versatile for pairing with various foods, and can be aged in unique vessels like Qvevri and amphora.

images.alt_text: 'Black' champagne is made from black grape varieties of Pinot Noir and/or Pinot Meunier.

site_title: IReit Global secures 15-year anchor lease at Darmstadt Campus
summary: IReit Global has secured a 15-year anchor lease at Darmstadt Campus, occupying about 25% of the office space, with an annual rental income of approximately 1.2 million euros. The lease will commence on June 1 and has two five-year prolongation options. This deal is expected to improve the long-term stability of IReit Global's portfolio performance, increasing its portfolio occupancy to 90.3% and weighted average lease expiry to 5.2 years.

site_title: Rent your home to a co-living operator and get a free property makeover
summary: Co-living operators are transforming rundown properties into desirable homes for tenants, with landlords enjoying a free upgrade and increased property value. Savvy landlords are partnering with co-living operators, who handle maintenance, marketing, and tenant management, saving on property agent commissions. To make business sense, all parties must win – the landlord, operator, and sub-tenants. Co-living operators focus on working professionals and offer amenities like communal spaces, air-conditioning, and cleaning services. Landlords must agree to a longer lease and renovations, but can still sell their property while leased to an operator.

images.alt_text: The Light House is an intermediate terrace house that's part of an original cluster of four staggered placement brick houses.
Co-living operators, such as LHN's Coliwoo (above), have seen their tenant profile skew towards younger people, who enjoy having shared spaces for a community lifestyle.

site_title: Sumitomo Metal Mining supports Teck’s coal spinoff
summary: Sumitomo Metal Mining has reaffirmed its support for Teck Resources' plan to split its coal assets into two separate, independent companies. The Japanese company's main shareholders, including Sumitomo, have committed to voting in favor of the proposal, set for a shareholder vote on April 26. This comes after Glencore proposed a US$23 billion buyout bid, which could be raised and presented directly to Teck's shareholders. Sumitomo's support for the split aims to create two world-class independent companies.

site_title: SVB collapse weighs on Biden’s search for Federal Reserve vice chair
summary: US President Joe Biden is narrowing his search for a Federal Reserve vice chair, with Northwestern University professor Janice Eberly seen as a frontrunner. The nomination comes after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, prompting the administration to backstop deposits and call for tighter banking regulations. Biden is under pressure from progressives and lawmakers to nominate a candidate with a strong voice on banking regulations, with some calling for a Latino candidate. The Fed has launched an investigation into the SVB collapse, and the nominee will join the Fed as it grapples with interest rate increases and banking instability.

site_title: Glencore expects another bumper year of commodity trading
summary: Glencore, a mining company, expects another bumper year of commodity trading, with trading profits likely to beat its guidance range of $2.2 billion to $3.2 billion. The company's first-quarter performance indicates it will exceed its range for the fourth straight year. Glencore's trading and production update was released early to support its proposal to buy Canadian rival Teck Resources, which has faced rejection from Teck's board and controlling shareholder. The company maintains production targets and highlights energy products as performing well.
