site_title: BlackRock’s assets seen topping US$15 trillion in five years’ time
summary: BlackRock's assets under management are projected to reach $15 trillion in five years, driven by growth in fixed income, cash management, private markets, and its investment-management technology platform, Aladdin. The firm has seen a boost amid the US banking sector turmoil, with $110 billion in net inflows in the first quarter. Analysts predict annual organic asset growth of 5% over the next three years, with BlackRock's shares rebounding after a 2.4% decline this year. The stock's price target has been raised to $861, according to Morgan Stanley analyst Michael Cyprys.

site_title: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire sells S$1.6 billion of yen debt after big Japan bets
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway sold $1.6 billion of Japanese yen debt, paying record-high costs, amid speculation about the Bank of Japan's policy tightening. The firm, one of the largest overseas issuers of yen debt, paid a yield of 1.135%, nearly seven times higher than its 2019 debut. Berkshire's move comes after the billionaire investor increased holdings in Japanese trading houses, and traders expect the BOJ to exit negative rates. The proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing debt.

images.alt_text: The billionaire investor took credit for Berkshire’s investment in TSMC amid speculation that one of his investing deputies picked the stock.

site_title: Swiss watch exports keep climbing as Hong Kong orders surge
summary: Swiss watch exports rose 13.8% in value to 2.4 billion Swiss francs (S$3.6 billion) in March, driven by a surge in orders from Hong Kong after the territory reopened from COVID restrictions. Shipments to Hong Kong increased by almost 62% to 2.1 billion Swiss francs (S$3.1 billion). This marks the latest in a series of strong export performances, with global demand for luxury timepieces remaining robust despite economic headwinds, reaching a record 24 billion francs in 2022.

images.alt_text: Prices for discontinued luxury watch models often increase in value because they represent a now limited supply of product.

Cooling demand would be a mixed blessing for Patek and other top watch brands like Rolex as it might reduce the time that customers must spend on waitlists before getting the call from authorised dealers.

site_title: Paving the way to greener wardrobes
summary: The latest IPCC report emphasizes the urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. In response, the fashion industry is shifting towards sustainable materials, with alternative materials now mainstream. Brands are incorporating eco-friendly materials, such as recycled plastics and plant-based fabrics, into their designs. This move aims to reduce the industry's carbon footprint and contribute to a more sustainable future. The industry's efforts come as the IPCC report calls for halving emissions by 2030.

site_title: After all the hype, LIV Golf stars ready to strut their stuff at Sentosa
summary: LIV Golf, backed by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, is set to make its debut in Singapore with its fifth leg of the 14-event series. The tournament, featuring 48 golfers, including household names like Phil Mickelson, Ian Poulter, and Brooks Koepka, will take place at the Sentosa Golf Club's Serapong course. Fans can participate in the "Longest Putt to LIV Golf" challenge, with prizes including tickets to RWS attractions and LIV Golf Singapore tickets. The event aims to promote LIV Golf's innovative format, which combines simultaneous team and individual championships.

site_title: Debunking the myth of market efficiency
summary: The Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) remains a widely-held concept, but its assumptions are questionable. Perfect information, investor rationality, and perfect competition are far-fetched, and the theory fails to account for manipulation, insider trading, and disparate data access. The EMH also neglects factors such as trade execution, price setting, and investor behavior, which can lead to inefficiencies in the market. Behavioral economists argue that investors are emotional and prone to overreaction, contradicting the theory's assumption of investor rationality. The EMH's limitations have led to the development of alternative theories, such as adaptive markets, which acknowledge the complexity and imperfections of financial markets.

site_title: Bidding frenzy expected at sale of world’s largest private jewellery collection
summary: Billionaire art collector Heidi Horten is set to auction off her world's largest private jewelry collection, valued at over $150 million. The collection features exemplary pieces from top names such as Bulgari, Cartier, and Tiffany, including a 46.56-carat diamond necklace. The sale is expected to be a bidding frenzy, with some of the jewels coming to Singapore. The auction is the largest and most valuable private jewelry collection to come to auction, making it a highly anticipated event in the jewelry world.

site_title: Volkswagen’s Cariad to establish software joint venture with China’s ThunderSoft
summary: Volkswagen's software unit Cariad is establishing a joint venture with Chinese technologies provider ThunderSoft to develop connectivity and infotainment systems in China. ThunderSoft holds a 51% stake, while Cariad has a 49% stake. The partnership aims to create software products for car cockpits, infotainment systems, and cloud development. This move reflects Volkswagen's focus on meeting Chinese customers' needs and retaining control over valuable data. The joint venture is part of Cariad's expansion into consumer-facing areas, where carmakers compete to differentiate themselves.

site_title: Nissan unveils new EV designed for Chinese market
summary: Nissan unveiled a new electric SUV, the Arizon, at the Shanghai auto show, targeting the Chinese market. The vehicle features a virtual personal assistant and a low center of gravity, offering a spacious interior. The Arizon is part of Nissan's 19 planned battery EVs by 2030. The move aims to revitalize the company's presence in China, where it faces increasing competition from homegrown auto companies. Nissan's chief operating officer, Ashwani Gupta, emphasized the importance of software-defined vehicles in the future.

images.alt_text: BYD’s sales in China are up almost 69 per cent this year, giving it an 11 per cent share of the overall car market, more than the Volkswagen brand or the Toyota brand, according to an analysis of sales data.

site_title: Asean 'strongly condemns' Myanmar air strike
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has strongly condemned recent air strikes in Myanmar, killing dozens of people, with at least 100 fatalities reported. The strikes, carried out by the Myanmar junta, drew swift condemnation from the UN and Western powers. Indonesia, as Asean chair, issued a statement calling for an end to violence, particularly against civilians. The junta had launched limited air strikes after receiving a tip-off about a local defence force office. Asean's efforts to implement the "five-point consensus" agreed upon in 2021 have largely failed, with mediation attempts to solve the crisis so far unsuccessful.

images.alt_text: A seat for Myanmar's delegate is left empty during the opening session of the 32nd Asean Coordinating Council meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, Feb 3, 2023.

site_title: China, HK stocks drop as doubt over economic recovery weighs
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 Index dropped 1.2% to a one-month low, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.8% on concerns over the sustainability of economic recovery. Despite beating expectations with a 4.5% first-quarter growth, investors are cautious due to an uneven pace of recovery and uncertain external demand outlook. This weighed down Hong Kong's Hang Seng, which fell 0.6%, and China's STAR Market, which dropped 1.8%. However, Chinese digital currency-related stocks jumped amid efforts to promote the use of digital yuan.

site_title: India's passenger vehicle sales up 26.7% in FY23, according to industry body
summary: India's passenger vehicle sales rose 26.7% in FY23, driven by improved chip supply, higher incomes, and pent-up demand for SUVs. Wholesale passenger vehicle volumes reached 3.9 million units in FY23, up from 3.1 million units in FY22. Two-wheeler sales also increased 16.9% in FY23. Despite inflation, sales growth is expected to taper to a low single-digit percentage in the current fiscal due to inflation, price hikes, and regulatory changes.

images.alt_text: Jaguar's F-Pace SVR, a product of Tata's luxury-car unit, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR). JLR last week reported a 24 per cent jump in its wholesale volumes, excluding from China, in the January-March quarter, while retail sales grew 30 per cent as chip and other supply constraints eased.

site_title: S-Reits lead Singapore stocks higher amid US recession fears; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,294.54 points, driven by S-Reits, amid US recession fears. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes revealed a "mild recession" starting later this year, eroding the soft-landing scenario. Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit were top gainers, while Sats was a notable loser. Most key Asian markets also gained, with Japan's Nikkei 225 Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 0.2-0.4%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
In early Asian trade, Hong Kong was dragged by sharp losses in the tech sector after the Financial Times reported that Japan’s SoftBank was looking to unload a majority of its holdings in Alibaba.
The Straits Times Index was down 0.1 per cent or 4.02 points, to 3,282.1 points as at 9.01 am.

site_title: Why we fall for scams (and it’s not because we’re stupid)
summary: Younger, tech-savvier individuals are increasingly falling victim to scams due to the digital world's rapid pace. Contrary to the assumption that older, less educated people are more susceptible, research shows that younger, more tech-savvy individuals are now making up a larger proportion of scam victims. This trend is attributed to the ease of online interactions and the reliance on digital platforms, making it easier for scammers to target and deceive.

site_title: Chanel reaches for the stars with its Interstellar collection
summary: Chanel has unveiled its Interstellar Capsule Collection, a line of watches inspired by the cosmos and science fiction. The collection includes seven unique watches, each with its own distinct design, and is available in various materials such as white gold, diamonds, and ceramic. The watches mimic celestial events like eclipses and feature pixelated motifs, phosphorescent effects, and star charms. Limited editions of Haute Horlogerie pieces are also available, priced from $11,050 to $330,750. The collection is designed to evoke the sense of time passing and the boundaries between reality and fantasy.

images.alt_text: The Tambour Opera Automata, a mastery of horological automata.

site_title: Cards on the table at 3 of Cups
summary: A tarot-themed bar, 3 of Cups, offers free tarot readings with every three cocktails ordered. The bar features 10 signature cocktails inspired by tarot cards, each with its own unique flavor profile and name. The bar's co-founder, Shamini Dass, and bar manager, Selvakumar Manimaran, drew inspiration from tarot card meanings and imagery to create the cocktails. The bar also serves classic cocktails, wines, and Asian-inspired food.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
Pez Dispenser is one of several cocktails at Underdog Inn named after paintings by 1980s New York City artist Jean-Michel Basquiat, prints of which adorn the walls.
Nighthawks, the bar's signature drink, is a hot-and-cold variation on the espresso martini.

site_title: A taste of Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's dining scene is rebounding, with new restaurants opening, including Cafe Bau by celebrity chef Alvin Leung and Forty-Five, a multi-concept destination with high-profile restaurants like The Cristal Room by Anne-Sophie Pic. Modern French Chinese restaurant Mora, led by chef-proprietor Vicky Lau, offers a soy-driven menu, while Rosita brings fresh takes on Latin American cuisine with Asian influences. Clarence, a modern French restaurant, presents lighter French classics with Asian cooking methods. Upscale Cantonese restaurant Man Wah has undergone a major revamp and offers creative presentation of traditional dishes.

images.alt_text: Majestic sunsets add allure to wintry seascapes of the Antarctic.

site_title: Apple triples India iPhone output to US$7 billion in China shift
summary: Apple tripled its iPhone production in India to $7 billion, tripling its output in the world's fastest-growing smartphone market. The company now makes around 7% of its iPhones in India, up from 1% in 2021, as it shifts production from China amid escalating tensions between the US and China. Apple's retail stores are set to open in Mumbai and New Delhi, with CEO Tim Cook scheduled to inaugurate the stores, highlighting the domestic market's growing importance.

images.alt_text: The Apple store in Mumbai. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

site_title: Journey to the end of the earth
summary: Antarctica, the world's seventh continent, is a destination unlike any other. Visitors can explore majestic whales, jaw-dropping icebergs, and penguin colonies on a guided expedition. The National Geographic Resolution, a luxury cruise ship, offers a unique experience with its well-appointed cabins, hot tubs, and Zodiacs. Expeditions begin with an overnight stay in Santiago, Chile, and a charter flight to Ushuaia, the southernmost city. The journey takes two days, crossing the Drake Passage, and offers opportunities to kayak, hike, and witness the Antarctic Convergence. With a focus on wildlife, science, and history, the trip provides a unique perspective on the fragile and majestic continent.

images.alt_text: Alcohol not needed - the view from the Bulgari Bar is intoxicating enough

site_title: Malaysia’s pension fund refutes speculation of cash crunch crisis
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has denied speculation of a cash crunch crisis in its retirement fund, stating it maintains sufficient liquidity to meet all obligations. The EPF attributed the concerns to a Bloomberg article that warned Malaysians could run out of savings by age 58 due to low wages, high debt, and premature withdrawals during the pandemic. The pension fund emphasized that it is prioritizing rebuilding retirement savings and exploring further reforms to improve retirement adequacy.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank said the current monetary policy stance is “slightly accommodative and remains supportive of the economy.

site_title: A better approach to de-risking trade
summary: The European Union's efforts to de-risk trade are flawed, as policymakers have not addressed the varying risks associated with different types of trade. A more nuanced approach would distinguish between essential inputs (e.g., raw materials) and inputs needed for future production (e.g., solar panels). Stockpiling and substitution can mitigate risks, but the EU's plans to subsidize domestic solar panel production may not be economically sound. Instead, the EU should invest in research on next-generation green technologies to reduce its reliance on imports.

images.alt_text: Global investment in the green transition is set to triple by 2030 from US$1 trillion last year, President Ursula von der Leyen told the European Parliament on Wednesday, declaring “the race is on”.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has called for changes to EU state aid rules to address "distortions" created by America's Inflation Protection Act.

A farmer drives a combine harvester to collect soybeans under hanging solar panels on an agrivoltaic site in Amance, eastern France, Oct 2022. Rather than offering inefficient subsidies to existing technologies, governments should be funding R&D for new ones.

site_title: Designer home in Niseko that’s one of a kind
summary: Hong Kong-based architect Steve Leung has designed and built his own unique holiday home, OOAK Niseko, in Japan's skiing capital. The 66-year-old architect took two years to design and build the house after buying the land, incorporating his personal aesthetics and lifestyle. The house boasts a spectacular view of Mount Yotei and features a minimalist design, sustainable materials, and practical touches. Leung collaborated with Japanese architect Makoto Nakayama on the project, and the interior is styled with a mix of Japanese and modern furniture. The house is a reflection of Leung's love for nature, privacy, and his family values.

images.alt_text: Beautiful Cheshire countryside

site_title: Experiencing Tokyo, the Bulgari way
summary: Bulgari has opened its new luxury hotel in Tokyo, marking the brand's eighth hotel since entering the hospitality industry 19 years ago. The hotel is part of the Italian jeweller's ultra-posh portfolio, offering an exclusive experience with a focus on fine jewellery and craftsmanship. The Bulgari Bar features an intoxicating view, making it an attractive destination for those celebrating Japan's cherry blossom season. The hotel's limited availability is a testament to Bulgari's high standards, setting it apart from other hotel chains.

syluxeoman13 - oman FH8A2254

credit stefanie yuen thio

site_title: GM’s Cruise recalls 300 self-driving vehicles after bus crash to update software
summary: GM's Cruise unit is recalling 300 self-driving vehicles after a recent crash into a San Francisco bus. The incident occurred on March 23, when a Cruise vehicle inaccurately predicted the movement of the bus, causing moderate damage. The software was updated on March 25 to address concerns of inaccurate predictions of articulated vehicles like buses and tractor trailers. The crash was deemed unique, but Cruise CEO Kyle Vogt said it was worthy of immediate study and determined that the issue would not recur after the software update.

site_title: TSMC sales miss for second straight quarter on tepid tech demand
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chip manufacturer, missed sales estimates for the second consecutive quarter due to a global economic slowdown and weak demand for electronics. First-quarter revenue fell shy of forecasts at NT$508.6 billion, with sales down 15% in March compared to the prior year. The company has cut capital spending plans to $32-36 billion and expects sales to decline 5-10% in the first half before picking up in the second half. Rival Samsung Electronics has also cut its memory chip output amid declining demand.

images.alt_text: Apple is gradually diversifying the geography of its manufacturing base as brewing tensions between Washington and Beijing threaten to disrupt its carefully orchestrated supply chain.

site_title: Karaage kings: judges hunt for Japan’s best fried chicken
summary: Judges in Japan have crowned the ultimate "karaage" – Japan's comfort food, a style of fried chicken – after a series of tasting sessions across the country. The Karaage Grand Prix, now in its 14th year, aims to find the best fried chicken in Japan. Winners will see their sales triple if their chicken wins an award, and the competition is fierce with shops from various regions vying for the top spot. The judges, experts in the food industry, looked for fried chicken that "tells a story" and praised the dish for its journey of flavors, rather than perfection.

images.alt_text: Cuisson's interiors are spacious and plush, with a see-through wine cellar.
Cinemas here are tapping growing demand for premium experiences: screening formats such as Imax and 3D, as well as luxurious viewing environments.
Glico's newest Pocky factory in Karawang is its largest, with a total floor space of 57,000 square metres.

site_title: Protesters shout down Macron on visit to the Netherlands
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's state visit to the Netherlands was disrupted by protesters who shouted down his speech, calling him "President of violence and hypocrisy." The protesters, who were also opposed to a pension law that delays retirement age by two years, had banners and shouted about climate change and democracy. Macron responded by saying those who do not respect the electoral process and elected leaders put democracy in danger. The protests are part of weeks of tense demonstrations at home against the pension law, with opinion polls showing a majority of voters oppose the reform.

images.alt_text: French riot police try to extinguish a fire amid clashes during a demonstration against the French government's pension reform, in Paris, France, March 25, 2023.

site_title: Kōki,: Destined for the limelight
summary: Japanese model-actress Kōki, born to celebrity parents, has carved out her own niche in the fashion and film world. At 7, she composed her own music, at 15, she became Bulgari's youngest ambassador, and at 16, she made her Paris Fashion Week debut in Chanel. Now 20, she's part of an exclusive club of women with famous parents, charisma, and smart career choices. Kōki cites her parents' influence, but emphasizes her own style and love for 90s supermodels like Naomi Campbell and Christy Turlington. She's set to conquer the silver screen with upcoming films, including "Touch," and remains committed to her dual career in modelling and acting.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Mae Tan

Nakata’s sake company and his new luxury tea brand Hanaahu, comprising cold-brew tea blends designed specifically to pair with food, are the opening initiatives in his overall plan to protect independent farmers and promote farm-based industries to a wider audience.
JJ Lin feeling festive at the Little Social., a private Peranakan home dining space. He wears a knitted pullover and denim jeans by Louis Vuitton.

site_title: Theodoric Chew: a young dropout turns his anxiety into a million-dollar mental health movement
summary: Theodoric Chew, a 27-year-old entrepreneur, has founded Intellect, a mental health app with 3 million users in 20 Asian countries. Chew, who struggled with anxiety as a teenager, aims to make mental healthcare accessible to all, regardless of income or stigma. Intellect offers culturally-relevant care and has seen significant adoption among companies, with 98% of Foodpanda employees wanting the app included in their mental health benefits. Chew believes mental health is on a spectrum and encourages companies to prioritize employee well-being without discrimination.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Kōki, wears an oversized sweater, skirt by Kenzo, and a Serpenti Tubogas single spiral watch by Bulgari.
Mae Tan

Nakata’s sake company and his new luxury tea brand Hanaahu, comprising cold-brew tea blends designed specifically to pair with food, are the opening initiatives in his overall plan to protect independent farmers and promote farm-based industries to a wider audience.

site_title: Vietnam to conduct ‘comprehensive inspection’ of TikTok over harmful content
summary: Vietnam's government announced it will conduct a comprehensive inspection of TikTok's operations in the country starting in May to ensure compliance with regulations on content management, tax payments, and commercial policies. The inspection comes after TikTok removed 1.7 million videos in the fourth quarter of last year that were deemed to be in violation of government policies. The platform has also upgraded its guidelines, expected to take effect on April 24, to be more transparent about its rules and enforcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Australia's ban underscores growing worries that China could use the Beijing-based company to harvest users’ data to advance its political agenda, undermining Western security interests.
TikTok is especially popular among younger audiences. A report by online marketplace Oberlo has found that nearly 40 per cent of the app’s users are between the ages of 18 and 24.
The TikTok logo is displayed outside TikTok social media app company offices in Culver City, California, on March 16, 2023. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: Seroja Investments gets delisting notice
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Seroja Investments has received a delisting notice from Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) due to failure to meet listing rules after talks for a reverse takeover with a new company fell through. The company had been searching for a new viable business since selling its operating business in 2019. Trading in its shares has been suspended since October 2020, with the last closing price at S$0.079. Seroja Investments' appeal for more time to sign a definitive agreement was rejected, and the company must now make a fair and reasonable exit offer to its shareholders.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Singapore shares snapped a 2-day winning streak on Thursday, spooked by the US Fed's hawkish tilt

site_title: Packing a punch
summary: This spring/summer season, the fashion world is embracing bold, bright, and eye-catching ensembles with striking colors, silhouettes, and textures. Key trends include punchy tones, glitterati, and flirt and flounce. Designers are focusing on balance and wearability, with controlled chaos and equilibrium between excitement and practicality. Key looks include a vibrant red pleated-georgette minidress from Valentino, a sequinned Michael Kors crimson gown, and a fringe-heavy wool viscose midi dress from Bottega Veneta. These trends aim to inject personality and visual impact into outfits while maintaining a sense of balance and elegance.

site_title: One young woman’s journey in keeping a 37-year-old Singaporean glassmaking business alive – and relevant
summary: Sara Ang, the second-generation leader of Singaporean glassmaking company Synergraphic Design, has successfully kept her family's 37-year-old business alive and relevant. After joining her mother's firm 11 years ago, Ang implemented various diversification strategies, including introducing a new affordable arm and a website offering bespoke art and sculptures. Despite facing numerous challenges, Synergraphic has maintained its visibility in the industry, collaborating with well-known designers and attracting hundreds of homeowners seeking unique glass features. Ang sees her role as a steward of traditions, preserving the company's expertise and knowledge for future generations.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

Nakata’s sake company and his new luxury tea brand Hanaahu, comprising cold-brew tea blends designed specifically to pair with food, are the opening initiatives in his overall plan to protect independent farmers and promote farm-based industries to a wider audience.
Mae Tan
JJ Lin feeling festive at the Little Social., a private Peranakan home dining space. He wears a knitted pullover and denim jeans by Louis Vuitton.

site_title: Cuisson brings French flair to Tanjong Pagar
summary: Cuisson, a French fine-dining eatery in Singapore, offers well-executed but predictable cuisine at a high price point. The restaurant's spacious and plush interiors, including a see-through wine cellar, set a sophisticated tone. The chef, Tan Wee Kiat, executes a no-meat policy, focusing on seafood and lighter options. A seven-course meal costs S$208, with dishes such as silky smooth chawanmushi and prawn pasta showcasing the chef's technique. While Cuisson may not stand out for originality, it is a suitable choice for special occasions and those willing to pay for fine dining. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: ONMI's calm, hanok-inspired eatery features geometric patterned wall accents.

site_title: Deutsche Bank emulates JPMorgan in first big deal under Sewing
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to buy UK boutique Numis, valued at £410 million, in its first major deal under CEO Christian Sewing. The acquisition aims to bolster the bank's deal advisory and capital underwriting capabilities, complementing its existing corporate banking and fixed-income trading strengths. The deal is seen as a counter-cyclical move, demonstrating confidence in the UK economy and the City's ability to remain a hub for public listings. The acquisition will not derail plans for a share buyback, and Deutsche Bank shares rose following the announcement, suggesting investors view the purchase positively.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's results mark an 11th consecutive quarter of profit at Germany’s biggest bank, making for the longest streak in the black in at least a decade.
Online and mobile shopping payments will be added later on, along with subscription instalments, and services such as buy now, pay later, over time.

A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. Deutsche Bank vowed to increase profit and revenue further this year, after snapping a long streak of market share gains in trading in the final quarter of Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing's turnaround plan. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Celebrating kebaya across the region
summary: Singapore museums are promoting the kebaya, a traditional garment worn in five South-east Asian countries, through a travelling exhibition. The National Museum of Singapore is hosting "Love, Kebaya" featuring beautiful examples of kebaya made from different fabrics and colours. The exhibition aims to strengthen the chances of the kebaya being added to Unesco's list of intangible cultural heritage. The joint nomination was made by Singapore, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand, with the kebaya being worn on special occasions by Malays, Peranakans, and Eurasians, as well as by female flight attendants.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Australia’s rental market tightens further amid housing crunch
summary: Australia's rental market is experiencing a housing crunch, with a record low vacancy rate of 1.1% and rents increasing 2.5% in the first quarter. The country is expected to face a shortage of over 100,000 homes over the next five years due to high interest rates, soaring immigration, and rising construction costs. Sydney is the most expensive city to rent, with an average price of A$699 per week. Experts attribute the shortage to a chronic undersupply of rental stock and forecast strong net migration to continue putting pressure on rental values.

site_title: Nature springs to life in Van Cleef & Arpels’ latest collection
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has unveiled its latest collection, "Éveil du Cyclamen," featuring stunning works of art combining multiple artisanal disciplines, including automaton artistry, métiers d'arts, watchmaking, and jewellery making. The collection includes intricate automaton objects such as a butterfly emerging from a cluster of cyclamens, a single majestic water lily, and a fairy that springs to life with a button. The automaton mechanism, crafted by a team of 20 artisans, features complex systems, including wheels, discs, levers, and springs, ensuring fluid and supple movements.

site_title: Hong Kong dining scene makes up for lost time
summary: Hong Kong's dining scene is making a comeback after the pandemic, with major arts and trade shows attracting tourists and locals. Reservations are filling up quickly in hot restaurants, and diners are eager to try new experiences. The city's food scene is regaining its reputation as a paradise for foodies, with new restaurants and menus emerging. The post-pandemic recovery is boosting the city's economy and culture, with the arts and trade scenes also thriving.

site_title: Singapore PMI back in contraction mode in March, echoes region’s softer factory activity
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 49.9 in March, marking a return to contraction territory, mirroring a region-wide softening in factory activity. The reading indicates a decline in factory activity, with softer new orders and continued contraction in new export orders. Economists attribute the drag to the Western bank crisis and China's reopening, with some expecting a mild stabilisation in the industry outlook. The region's PMIs show varying trends, with Myanmar leading growth and Vietnam performing the worst.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
For the upward momentum in Singapore's PMI to be sustainable, a further improvement in new export orders is key, says chief economist Selena Ling.

site_title: Numb Restaurant at Marina One spices things up with fiery Sichuan fare
summary: Numb Restaurant in Singapore's CBD offers a unique dining experience with its modern take on Chengdu-style Sichuan cooking, characterized by bold and spicy flavors. The semi-casual eatery features a bar and interior decor that lacks polish, but makes up for it with its tongue-tingling dishes, including a spicy pork belly, century egg and eggplant, applewood-smoked crispy chicken, and silky sea bass in a fiery chilli oil broth. While some dishes may be too hot for some diners, Numb also offers milder options and a variety of sweet treats, including brown sugar ice jelly and mochi. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: A new It bag for the ages
summary: Celine's new bag, the Triomphe, combines classic Parisian flair with contemporary cool. Inspired by a 1970s-era logo, the Triomphe features a sleek, modern aesthetic with a timeless design. The bag's origins are rooted in Paris, with its emblematic inverted-C motif emerging from a "minor collision" at the Place de l'Etoile. Creative director Hedi Slimane has updated the motif, transforming it into a clasp that now adorns every Triomphe bag. This season, light lavender and pollen are the hottest colors, adding a touch of fresh elegance to the stylish bag.

site_title: J&J unit files for second bankruptcy to pursue US$8.9 billion talc settlement
summary: Johnson & Johnson's talc subsidiary, LTL Management, filed for bankruptcy in New Jersey for a second time, seeking to settle US$8.9 billion in lawsuits alleging talc products caused cancer. The settlement follows a January appeals court ruling invalidating J&J's "Texas two-step" bankruptcy manoeuvre. About 60,000 talc claimants have agreed to the proposal, which will be presented to a judge on May 14. J&J reiterated that its talc products are safe and do not cause cancer, but attorneys representing plaintiffs oppose the settlement, calling it a "sham deal."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bottles of Johnson & Johnson baby powder line a drugstore shelf in New York October 15, 2015.  REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo
